tuple: ['What questions does psychology explore?', 'The field of psychology explores questions like these.']
['What does psychology refer to?', 'Psychology refers to the scientific study of the mind and behavior.']
['How does psychology study the mind and behavior?', 'Psychologists use the scientific method to acquire knowledge.']

['What is scientific method', 'To apply the scientific method, a researcher with a question about how or why something happens will propose a tentative explanation, called a hypothesis, to explain the phenomenon.']

['What is the context of a hypothesis?', 'A hypothesis should fit into the context of a scientific theory, which is a broad explanation or group of explanations for some aspect of the natural world that is consistently supported by evidence over time.']
['What is the best understanding we have of that part of the natural world?', 'A theory is the best understanding we have of that part of the natural world.']
['How is validity tested?', 'The researcher then makes observations or carries out an experiment to test the validity of the hypothesis.']
['What are the results of this research?', 'Those results are then published or presented at research conferences so that others can replicate or build on the results.']
['What do scientists test?', 'Scientists test that which is perceivable and measurable.']

['What kind of data is measurable?', 'For example, the hypothesis that a bird sings because it is happy is not a hypothesis that can be tested since we have no way to measure the happiness of a bird.']
['What is an example of perceivable data?', 'We must ask a different question, perhaps about the brain state of the bird, since this can be measured.']
['Why can we ask a different question?', 'However, we can ask individuals about whether they sing because they are happy since they are able to tell us.']
['What can we do with this data?', 'Thus, psychological science is empirical, based on measurable data.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'In general, science deals only with matter and energy, that is, those things that can be measured, and it cannot arrive at knowledge about values and morality.']
['Why is this?', 'This is one reason why our scientific understanding of the mind is so limited, since thoughts, at least as we experience them, are neither matter nor energy.']
['What is the other main ideas?', 'The scientific method is also a form of empiricism.']

['What is an empirical method for acquiring knowledge?', 'An empirical method for acquiring knowledge is one based on observation, including experimentation, rather than a method based only on forms of logical argument or previous authorities.']
['What was the first time that psychology became accepted as its own academic discipline?', 'It was not until the late 1800s that psychology became accepted as its own academic discipline.']
['What was the first scientific study of the workings of the mind?', 'Before this time, the workings of the mind were considered under the auspices of philosophy.']
['What is the relationship between psychology and biology?', 'Given that any behavior is, at its roots, biological, some areas of psychology take on aspects of a natural science like biology.']
['What do you know about psychology?', 'No biological organism exists in isolation, and our behavior is influenced by our interactions with others.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Therefore, psychology is also a social science.']

['What are some reasons for studying psychology?', 'Often, students take their first psychology course because they are interested in helping others and want to learn more about themselves and why they act the way they do.']

['What are some reasons people take psychology courses?', 'Sometimes, students take a psychology course because it either satisfies a general education requirement or is required for a program of study such as nursing or pre-med.']
['What happens to many students who take psychology courses?', 'Many of these students develop such an interest in the area that they go on to declare psychology as their major.']
['How many students declare psychology as their major?', 'As a result, psychology is one of the most popular majors on college campuses across the United States (Johnson & Lubin, 2011).']
['Did anyone famous study psychology?', 'A number of well-known individuals were psychology majors.']

['What famous people studied psychology?', 'Just a few famous names on this list are Facebook’s creator Mark Zuckerberg, television personality and political satirist Jon Stewart, actress Natalie Portman, and filmmaker Wes Craven (Halonen, 2011).']

['What percentage of all bachelor degrees granted in the United States are in the discipline of psychology?', 'About 6 percent of all bachelor degrees granted in the United States are in the discipline of psychology (U.S. Department of Education, 2016).']
['What is the most important reason to study psychology?', 'An education in psychology is valuable for a number of reasons.']
['What are some of the reasons that psychology students are important?', 'Psychology students hone critical thinking skills and are trained in the use of the scientific method.']

['What is the active application of a set of skills to information for the understanding and evaluation of that information?', 'Critical thinking is the active application of a set of skills to information for the understanding and evaluation of that information.']

['What is an important skill in a world full of competing “facts,” many of which are designed to be misleading?', 'The evaluation of information—assessing its reliability and usefulness— is an important skill in a world full of competing “facts,” many of which are designed to be misleading.']

['What does critical thinking involve?', 'For example, critical thinking involves maintaining an attitude of skepticism, recognizing internal biases, making use of logical thinking, asking appropriate questions, and making observations.']

['Do psychology students also study communication skills?', 'Psychology students also can develop better communication skills during the course of their undergraduate coursework (American Psychological Association, 2011).']

['What is the next step of their study?', 'Together, these factors increase students’ scientific literacy and prepare students to critically evaluate the various sources of information they encounter.']
['What else is important about psychology?', 'In addition to these broad-based skills, psychology students come to understand the complex factors that shape one’s behavior.']
['What are these complex factors?', 'They appreciate the interaction of our biology, our environment, and our experiences in determining who we are and how we will behave.']

['what else did they learn?', 'They learn about basic principles that guide how we think and behave, and they come to recognize the tremendous diversity that exists across individuals and across cultural boundaries (American Psychological Association, 2011).']
['What is the oldest science?', 'Psychology is a relatively young science with its experimental roots in the 19th century, compared, for example, to human physiology, which dates much earlier.']
['What is a philosophical context?', 'As mentioned, anyone interested in exploring issues related to the mind generally did so in a philosophical context prior to the 19th century.']

['What are some key individuals or groups in the study material?', 'Two 19th century scholars, Wilhelm Wundt and William James, are generally credited as being the founders of psychology as a science and academic discipline that was distinct from philosophy.']

['What are the shifts in paradigms that have influenced psychology from Wundt and James through today?', 'This section will provide an overview of the shifts in paradigms that have influenced psychology from Wundt and James through today.']

['What is the name of the scientist who was the first person to be referred to as a psychologist?', 'Wilhelm Wundt (1832–1920) was a German scientist who was the first person to be referred to as a psychologist.']
['When was the book published?', 'His famous book entitled Principles of Physiological Psychology was published in 1873.']

['What does he say about psychology?', 'Wundt viewed psychology as a scientific study of conscious experience, and he believed that the goal of psychology was to identify components of consciousness and how those components combined to result in our conscious experience.']

['What method does he use?', 'Wundt used introspection (he called it “internal perception”), a process by which someone examines their own conscious experience as objectively as possible, making the human mind like any other aspect of nature that a scientist observed.']

['What did Danziger believe?', 'He believed in the notion of voluntarism—that people have free will and should know the intentions of a psychological experiment if they were participating (Danziger, 1980).']
['What type of experiments do they conduct?', 'Wundt considered his version experimental introspection; he used instruments such as those that measured reaction time.']

['What did he suggest that psychology should include the study of culture, as it involves the study of people?', 'He also wrote Volkerpsychologie in 1904 in which he suggested that psychology should include the study of culture, as it involves the study of people.']
['Did he have students?', 'Edward Titchener, one of his students, went on to develop structuralism.']
['What is structuralism?', 'Its focus was on the contents of mental processes rather than their function (Pickren & Rutherford, 2010).']
['Where did Wundt conduct his research?', 'Wundt established his psychology laboratory at the University at Leipzig in 1879.']
['Did he conduct experiments?', 'In this laboratory, Wundt and his students conducted experiments on, for example, reaction times.']
['What kind of experiment did he conduct?', 'A subject, sometimes in a room isolated from the scientist, would receive a stimulus such as a light, image, or sound.']
['What would the subject do?', 'The subject’s reaction to the stimulus would be to push a button, and an apparatus would record the time to reaction.']
['Did he have any accuracy issues?', 'Wundt could measure reaction time to one-thousandth of a second (Nicolas & Ferrand, 1999).']
['Who was involved with functional psychology?', 'William James, John Dewey, and Charles Sanders Peirce helped establish functional psychology.']
['Why was there this interest in evolution?', 'They accepted Darwin’s theory of evolution by natural selection and viewed this theory as an explanation of an organism’s characteristics.']
['What is the key to the theory of evolution?', 'Key to that theory is the idea that natural selection leads to organisms that are adapted to their environment, including their behavior.']
['What does adaptation mean?', 'Adaptation means that a trait of an organism has a function for the survival and reproduction of the individual, because it has been naturally selected.']

["What was James's purpose in studying the concept?", 'As James saw it, psychology’s purpose was to study the function of behavior in the world, and as such, his perspective was known as functionalism.']
['What was one of the main findings of functionalism?', 'Functionalism focused on how mental activities helped an organism fit into its environment.']

['What was the second meaning of functionalism?', 'Functionalism has a second, more subtle meaning in that functionalists were more interested in the operation of the whole mind rather than of its individual parts, which were the focus of structuralism.']

['James studied the mind using what method?', 'Like Wundt, James believed that introspection could serve as one means by which someone might study mental activities, but James also relied on more objective measures, including the use of various recording devices, and examinations of concrete products of mental activities and of anatomy and physiology (Gordon, 1995).']
['What else are we going to be learning about?', 'Freud and Psychoanalytic']
['What is the last thing you would want to do?', 'Theory.']

['What was the name of the man who was the most influential and well-known figure in psychology’s history?', 'Perhaps one of the most influential and well-known figures in psychology’s history was Sigmund Freud.']
['What is he known for?', 'Freud (1856–1939) was an Austrian neurologist who was fascinated by patients suffering from “hysteria” and neurosis.']

['What was he fascinated with?', 'Hysteria was an ancient diagnosis for disorders, primarily of women with a wide variety of symptoms, including physical symptoms and emotional disturbances, none of which had an apparent physical cause.']
['What did Freud think the causes of his patients’ problems were?', 'Freud theorized that many of his patients’ problems arose from the unconscious mind.']
['What was the unconscious mind?', 'In Freud’s view, the unconscious mind was a repository of feelings and urges of which we have no awareness.']
['What was the purpose of the unconscious?', 'Gaining access to the unconscious, then, was crucial to the successful resolution of the patient’s problems.']

['Did he describe how to access it?', 'According to Freud, the unconscious mind could be accessed through dream analysis, by examinations of the first words that came to people’s minds, and through seemingly innocent slips of the tongue.']

['Did he write a book about it?', 'Psychoanalytic theory focuses on the role of a person’s unconscious, as well as early childhood experiences, and this particular perspective dominated clinical psychology for several decades (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']
['What else does this lesson teach?', 'Freud’s ideas were influential, and you will learn more about them when you study lifespan development, personality, and therapy.']
['What do therapists believe strongly in?', 'For instance, many therapists believe strongly in the unconscious and the impact of early childhood experiences on the rest of a person’s life.']

['What is the importance of patient talking about their experiences and selves?', 'The method of psychoanalysis, which involves the patient talking about their experiences and selves, while not invented by Freud, was certainly popularized by him and is still used today.']
['Are his ideas widely accepted?', 'Many of Freud’s other ideas, however, are controversial.']

['Are there any other people who disagree with Freud?', 'Drew Westen (1998) argues that many of the criticisms of Freud’s ideas are misplaced, in that they attack his older ideas without taking into account later writings.']

['Does Westen write anything else interesting?', 'Westen also argues that critics fail to consider the success of the broad ideas that Freud introduced or developed, such as the importance of childhood experiences in adult motivations, the role of unconscious versus conscious motivations in driving our behavior, the fact that motivations can cause conflicts that affect behavior, the effects of mental representations of ourselves and others in guiding our interactions, and the development of personality over time.']
['What does Westen do to support his ideas?', 'Westen identifies subsequent research support for all of these ideas.']
['What is the main idea of functionalism?', 'More modern iterations of Freud’s clinical approach have been empirically demonstrated to be effective (Knekt et al., 2008; Shedler, 2010).']

['What are some current practices in psychotherapy?', 'Some current practices in psychotherapy involve examining unconscious aspects of the self and relationships, often through the relationship between the therapist and the client.']

['What about Freud’s historical significance and contributions to clinical practice merit his inclusion in a discussion of the historical movements within psychology?', 'Freud’s historical significance and contributions to clinical practice merit his inclusion in a discussion of the historical movements within psychology.']

['What is the name of the German psychologists who immigrated to the United States in the early 20th century to escape Nazi Germany?', 'Max Wertheimer (1880–1943), Kurt Koffka (1886–1941), and Wolfgang Köhler (1887–1967) were three German psychologists who immigrated to the United States in the early 20th century to escape Nazi Germany.']
['What did these scholars do in the U.S.?', 'These scholars are credited with introducing psychologists in the United States to various Gestalt principles.']

['What was the main theory of Gestalt psychology?', 'The word Gestalt roughly translates to “whole;” a major emphasis of Gestalt psychology deals with the fact that although a sensory experience can be broken down into individual parts, how those parts relate to each other as a whole is often what the individual responds to in perception.']

['What are some other ideas?', 'For example, a song may be made up of individual notes played by different instruments, but the real nature of the song is perceived in the combinations of these notes as they form the melody, rhythm, and harmony.']
['What kind of criticism did they receive?', 'In many ways, this particular perspective would have directly contradicted Wundt’s ideas of structuralism (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['What happened in the United States?', 'Unfortunately, in moving to the United States, these scientists were forced to abandon much of their work and were unable to continue to conduct research on a large scale.']

['what happened after the scientists were forced to abandon much of their work?', 'These factors along with the rise of behaviorism (described next) in the United States prevented principles of Gestalt psychology from being as influential in the United States as they had been in their native Germany (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']
['What are some of the principles being studied today?', 'Despite these issues, several Gestalt principles are still very influential today.']

['what happened in the late century?', 'Considering the human individual as a whole rather than as a sum of individually measured parts became an important foundation in humanistic theory late in the century.']
['What other topics have been touched on?', 'The ideas of Gestalt have continued to influence research on sensation and perception.']
['What is the study material about?', 'Structuralism, Freud, and the Gestalt psychologists were all concerned in one way or another with describing and understanding inner experience.']

['what did some scientists want to study instead?', 'But other researchers had concerns that inner experience could be a legitimate subject of scientific inquiry and chose instead to exclusively study behavior, the objectively observable outcome of mental processes.']
['Who was the Russian physiologist who conducted early work in the field of behavior?', 'Early work in the field of behavior was conducted by the Russian physiologist Ivan Pavlov (1849–1936).']

['How was Pavlov able to determine conditioning?', 'Pavlov studied a form of learning behavior called a conditioned reflex, in which an animal or human produced a reflex (unconscious) response to a stimulus and, over time, was conditioned to produce the response to a different stimulus that the experimenter associated with the original stimulus.']
['What was the reflex Pavlov worked with?', 'The reflex Pavlov worked with was salivation in response to the presence of food.']

['What was the stimulus for salivation?', 'The salivation reflex could be elicited using a second stimulus, such as a specific sound, that was presented in association with the initial food stimulus several times.']
['What was the result of conditioning?', 'Once the response to the second stimulus was “learned,” the food stimulus could be omitted.']
['what did pavlov use conditioning for?', 'Pavlov’s “classical conditioning” is only one form of learning behavior studied by behaviorists.']
['What time period is this from?', 'John B. Watson (1878–1958) was an influential American psychologist whose most famous work occurred during the early 20th century at Johns Hopkins University.']
['What was the psychology topic of the passage?', 'While Wundt and James were concerned with understanding conscious experience, Watson thought that the study of consciousness was flawed.']

['what is interesting about Watson?', 'Because he believed that objective analysis of the mind was impossible, Watson preferred to focus directly on observable behavior and try to bring that behavior under control.']

['what else did Watson contribute?', 'Watson was a major proponent of shifting the focus of psychology from the mind to behavior, and this approach of observing and controlling behavior came to be known as behaviorism.']
['What was a major object of study by behaviorists?', 'A major object of study by behaviorists was learned behavior and its interaction with inborn qualities of the organism.']

['Did animal studies play a part in the development of behaviorism?', 'Behaviorism commonly used animals in experiments under the assumption that what was learned using animal models could, to some degree, be applied to human behavior.']

['What was the most common experiment?', 'Indeed, Tolman (1938) stated, “I believe that everything important in psychology (except … such matters as involve society and words) can be investigated in essence through the continued experimental and theoretical analysis of the determiners of rat behavior at a choice-point in a maze.”']

['What dominated experimental psychology for several decades?', 'Behaviorism dominated experimental psychology for several decades, and its influence can still be felt today (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['What methods was behaviorism responsible for establishing?', 'Behaviorism is largely responsible for establishing psychology as a scientific discipline through its objective methods and especially experimentation.']
['What is behaviorism used for?', 'In addition, it is used in behavioral and cognitive-behavioral therapy.']
['What kind of environments are used in behavior modification?', 'Behavior modification is commonly used in classroom settings.']
['What other types of influences do they have?', 'Behaviorism has also led to research on environmental influences on human behavior.']
["What is B. F. Skinner's occupation?", 'B. F. Skinner (1904–1990) was an American psychologist.']
['What did Skinner do?', 'Like Watson, Skinner was a behaviorist, and he concentrated on how behavior was affected by its consequences.']
['What did Skinner find?', 'Therefore, Skinner spoke of reinforcement and punishment as major factors in driving behavior.']
['who was he working with?', 'As a part of his research, Skinner developed a chamber that allowed the careful study of the principles of modifying behavior through reinforcement and punishment.']

['what is the skinner box?', 'This device, known as an operant conditioning chamber (or more familiarly, a Skinner box), has remained a crucial resource for researchers studying behavior (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']
['What is the Skinner box?', 'The Skinner box is a chamber that isolates the subject from the external environment and has a behavior indicator such as a lever or a button.']
['What does the box do?', 'When the animal pushes the button or lever, the box is able to deliver a positive reinforcement of the behavior (such as food) or a punishment (such as a noise).']

['What did Skinner’s focus on positive and negative reinforcement of learned behaviors have a lasting influence in psychology that has waned somewhat since the growth of research in cognitive psychology?', 'Skinner’s focus on positive and negative reinforcement of learned behaviors had a lasting influence in psychology that has waned somewhat since the growth of research in cognitive psychology.']
['What is conditioned learning still used for?', 'Despite this, conditioned learning is still used in human behavioral modification (Greengrass, 2004).']
["What is the first subject we'll study?", 'During the early 20th century, American psychology was dominated by behaviorism and psychoanalysis.']
['What were the problems with behaviorism?', 'However, some psychologists were uncomfortable with what they viewed as limited perspectives being so influential to the field.']
['What were some of the criticisms of Freud?', 'They objected to the pessimism and determinism (all actions driven by the unconscious) of Freud.']
['What did they object to?', 'They also disliked the reductionism, or simplifying nature, of behaviorism.']
['What is deterministic at its core?', 'Behaviorism is also deterministic at its core, because it sees human behavior as entirely determined by a combination of genetics and environment.']

['What did some psychologists begin to form their own ideas that emphasized personal control, intentionality, and a true predisposition for “good” as important for our self-concept and our behavior?', 'Some psychologists began to form their own ideas that emphasized personal control, intentionality, and a true predisposition for “good” as important for our self-concept and our behavior.']
['How did they get away with that?', 'Thus, humanism emerged.']
['What is humanism?', 'Humanism is a perspective within psychology that emphasizes the potential for good that is innate to all humans.']
['Who was the main humanist?', 'Two of the most well-known proponents of humanistic psychology are Abraham Maslow and Carl Rogers (O’Hara, n.d.).']
['What is the importance of Maslow?', 'Abraham Maslow (1908–1970) was an American psychologist who is best known for proposing a hierarchy of human needs in motivating behavior.']
['What are the main concepts in this chapter?', 'Although this concept will be discussed in more detail in a later chapter, a brief overview will be provided here.']

["What is the basic concept of Maslow's theory?", 'Maslow asserted that so long as basic needs necessary for survival were met (e.g., food, water, shelter), higher-level needs (e.g., social needs) would begin to motivate behavior.']
['what are the highest level needs?', 'According to Maslow, the highest-level needs relate to self-actualization, a process by which we achieve our full potential.']

['What are the major arguments made in this chapter?', 'Obviously, the focus on the positive aspects of human nature that are characteristic of the humanistic perspective is evident (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['What is the focus on human nature?', 'Humanistic psychologists rejected, on principle, the research approach based on reductionist experimentation in the tradition of the physical and biological sciences, because it missed the “whole” human being.']
['What other theories are mentioned?', 'Beginning with Maslow and Rogers, there was an insistence on a humanistic research program.']

['What was the research program?', 'This program has been largely qualitative (not measurement-based), but there exist a number of quantitative research strains within humanistic psychology, including research on happiness, self-concept, meditation, and the outcomes of humanistic psychotherapy (Friedman, 2008).']
['who is carl rogers?', 'Carl Rogers (1902–1987) was also an American psychologist who, like Maslow, emphasized the potential for good that exists within all people.']

['What is the name of the therapeutic technique that Rogers used?', 'Rogers used a therapeutic technique known as client-centered therapy in helping his clients deal with problematic issues that resulted in their seeking psychotherapy.']

['What is the difference between a psychoanalytic approach and client-centered therapy?', 'Unlike a psychoanalytic approach in which the therapist plays an important role in interpreting what conscious behavior reveals about the unconscious mind, client-centered therapy involves the patient taking a lead role in the therapy session.']

['what is the display three features?', 'Rogers believed that a therapist needed to display three features to maximize the effectiveness of this particular approach: unconditional positive regard, genuineness, and empathy.']
['What is unconditional positive regard?', 'Unconditional positive regard refers to the fact that the therapist accepts their client for who they are, no matter what they might say.']

['did rogers believe that people could deal with issues?', 'Provided these factors, Rogers believed that people were more than capable of dealing with and working through their own issues (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']
['What has humanism done for psychology?', 'Humanism has been influential to psychology as a whole.']

['What is significant about Maslow and Rogers?', 'Both Maslow and Rogers are well-known names among students of psychology (you will read more about both later in this text), and their ideas have influenced many scholars.']
['what is roberts contribution to psychology?', 'Furthermore, Rogers’ client-centered approach to therapy is still commonly used in psychotherapeutic settings today (O’hara, n.d.)']
['What is behaviorism?', 'Behaviorism’s emphasis on objectivity and focus on external behavior had pulled psychologists’ attention away from the mind for a prolonged period of time.']

['What was the early work of the humanistic psychologists?', 'The early work of the humanistic psychologists redirected attention to the individual human as a whole, and as a conscious and self-aware being.']

['What new disciplinary perspectives emerged?', 'By the 1950s, new disciplinary perspectives in linguistics, neuroscience, and computer science were emerging, and these areas revived interest in the mind as a focus of scientific inquiry.']

['What is the name of the particular perspective that has come to be known as the cognitive revolution?', 'This particular perspective has come to be known as the cognitive revolution (Miller, 2003).']

['What are cognitive psychology courses about?', 'By 1967, Ulric Neisser published the first textbook entitled Cognitive Psychology, which served as a core text in cognitive psychology courses around the country (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['What did Noam Chomsky do in the early days of the cognitive revolution?', 'Although no one person is entirely responsible for starting the cognitive revolution, Noam Chomsky was very influential in the early days of this movement.']
["What was Chomsky's contribution to the philosophy of science?", 'Chomsky (1928–), an American linguist, was dissatisfied with the influence that behaviorism had had on psychology.']

['What was Chomsky dissatisfied with?', 'He believed that psychology’s focus on behavior was short-sighted and that the field had to re-incorporate mental functioning into its purview if it were to offer any meaningful contributions to understanding behavior (Miller, 2003).']

['What helped reestablish lines of communication between European psychologists and their American counterparts?', 'European psychology had never really been as influenced by behaviorism as had American psychology; and thus, the cognitive revolution helped reestablish lines of communication between European psychologists and their American counterparts.']
['What did this revolution do?', 'Furthermore, psychologists began to cooperate with scientists in other fields, like anthropology, linguistics, computer science, and neuroscience, among others.']

['Was there a breakthrough with this revolution?', 'This interdisciplinary approach often was referred to as the cognitive sciences, and the influence and prominence of this particular perspective resonates in modern-day psychology (Miller, 2003).']
['What is the main idea of this section?', 'Culture impacts individuals, groups, and society.']

['What is an ongoing issue researchers are trying to correct?', 'An ongoing issue researchers are trying to correct is that certain populations have been over-studied and the results of these studies have been applied to other populations.']

['What are some examples of this?', 'For example, Henrich, Heine, and Norenzayan discuss how WEIRD societies have been overstudied and the results have been wrongly applied to non-WEIRD societies (2010).']
['What does WEIRD stand for?', 'WEIRD stands for western, educated, industrialized, rich, and democratic.']

['What is wrong with the studies?', 'Henrich, Heine, and Norenzayan found that there are many differences between people in the WEIRD group and people in less industrialized, less urban, and non-Western societies.']
['What are the differences between those groups?', 'These differences occur in a variety of areas, including perception, cooperation, and moral reasoning.']
['What is culture?', 'That is, people vary depending on their culture and environment.']
['What are theories about?', 'Multicultural psychologists develop theories and conduct research with diverse populations, typically within one country.']
['What do cross-cultural psychologists study?', 'Cross-cultural psychologists compare populations across countries, such as participants from the United States compared to participants from China.']
['What year did Francis Cecil Sumner receive his doctorate?', 'In 1920, Francis Cecil Sumner was the first African American to receive a PhD in psychology in the United States.']

["What was Sumner's greatest achievement?", 'Sumner established a psychology degree program at Howard University, leading to the education of a new generation of African American psychologists (Black, Spence, and Omari, 2004).']

['What were some examples of these achievements?', 'Much of the work of early psychologists from diverse backgrounds was dedicated to challenging intelligence testing and promoting innovative educational methods for children.']
['Who did Sanchez contest?', 'George I. Sanchez contested such testing with Mexican American children.']

['Why did Sanchez contest?', 'As a psychologist of Mexican heritage, he pointed out that the language and cultural barriers in testing were keeping children from equal opportunities (Guthrie, 1998).']
['What did Sanchez do after that contest?', 'By 1940, he was teaching with his doctoral degree at University of Texas at Austin and challenging segregated educational practices (Romo, 1986).']
['What are two famous African American researchers?', 'Two famous African American researchers and psychologists are Mamie Phipps Clark and her husband, Kenneth Clark.']

['What was their work?', 'They are best known for their studies conducted on African American children and doll preference, research that was instrumental in the Brown v. Board of Education Supreme Court desegregation case.']
['What did the Clarks do after?', 'The Clarks applied their research to social services and opened the first child guidance center in Harlem (American Psychological Association, 2019).']

['What is the American Psychological Association?', 'The American Psychological Association has several ethnically based organizations for professional psychologists that facilitate interactions among members.']

['What did they do?', 'Since psychologists belonging to specific ethnic groups or cultures have the most interest in studying the psychology of their communities, these organizations provide an opportunity for the growth of research on the interplay between culture and psychology.']
['What did women contribute to psychology?', 'Although rarely given credit, women have been contributing to psychology since its inception as a field of study.']
['What year did this start?', 'In 1894, Margaret Floy Washburn was the first woman awarded the doctoral degree in psychology.']
['Did she have a great amount of impact on the field?', 'She wrote The Animal Mind: A Textbook of Comparative Psychology, and it was the standard in the field for over 20 years.']

['What did Mary Whiton Calkins do?', 'In the mid 1890s, Mary Whiton Calkins completed all requirements toward the PhD in psychology, but Harvard University refused to award her that degree because she was a woman.']
['Who was she trying to convince to award her the doctoral degree?', 'She had been taught and mentored by William James, who tried and failed to convince Harvard to award her the doctoral degree.']

['What did she study?', 'Her memory research studied primacy and recency (Madigan & O’Hara, 1992), and she also wrote about how structuralism and functionalism both explained self-psychology (Calkins, 1906).']

['What are the main subjects of the document?', 'Another influential woman, Mary Cover Jones, conducted a study she considered to be a sequel to John B. Watson’s study of Little Albert (you’ll learn about this study in the chapter on Learning).']
['What did she study?', 'Jones unconditioned fear in Little Peter, who had been afraid of rabbits (Jones, 1924).']
['What are some of the women in psychology?', 'Ethnic minority women contributing to the field of psychology include Martha Bernal and Inez Beverly Prosser; their studies were related to education.']
['What did they study?', 'Bernal, the first Latina to earn her doctoral degree in psychology (1962) conducted much of her research with Mexican American children.']
['What university did Prosser get her degree from?', 'Prosser was the first African American woman awarded the PhD in 1933 at the University of Cincinnati (Benjamin, Henry, & McMahon, 2005).']
['What is contemporary psychology?', 'Contemporary psychology is a diverse field that is influenced by all of the historical perspectives described in the preceding section.']
['What are some other aspects of this topic?', 'Reflective of the discipline’s diversity is the diversity seen within the American Psychological Association (APA).']
['What is the APA?', 'The APA is a professional organization representing psychologists in the United States.']

['What is the main purpose of the APA?', 'The APA is the largest organization of psychologists in the world, and its mission is to advance and disseminate psychological knowledge for the betterment of people.']

['What divisions does the APA have?', 'There are 54 divisions within the APA, representing a wide variety of specialties that range from Societies for the Psychology of Religion and Spirituality to Exercise and Sport Psychology to Behavioral Neuroscience and Comparative Psychology.']

['What are some of the different types of members of the American Psychological Association?', 'Reflecting the diversity of the field of psychology itself, members, affiliate members, and associate members span the spectrum from students to doctoral-level psychologists, and come from a variety of places including educational settings, criminal justice, hospitals, the armed forces, and industry (American Psychological Association, 2014).']
['Who was the first president of the APA?', 'G. Stanley Hall was the first president of the APA.']

['What college did Hall go to?', 'Before he earned his doctoral degree, he was an adjunct instructor at Wilberforce University, a historically Black college/university (HBCU), while serving as faculty at Antioch College.']
['Did Hall have any mentors?', 'Hall went on to work under William James, earning his PhD.']
['What did he do next in his career?', 'Eventually, he became the first president of Clark University in Massachusetts when it was founded (Pickren & Rutherford, 2010).']
['What is the Association for Psychological Science?', 'The Association for Psychological Science (APS) was founded in 1988 and seeks to advance the scientific orientation of psychology.']
['What made the association form?', 'Its founding resulted from disagreements between members of the scientific and clinical branches of psychology within the APA.']
['What does the APS do?', 'The APS publishes five research journals and engages in education and advocacy with funding agencies.']
['What is the membership of the association?', 'A significant proportion of its members are international, although the majority is located in the United States.']

['What else was notable in the article?', 'Other organizations provide networking and collaboration opportunities for professionals of several ethnic or racial groups working in psychology, such as the National Latina/o Psychological Association (NLPA), the Asian American Psychological Association (AAPA), the Association of Black Psychologists (ABPsi), and the Society of Indian Psychologists (SIP).']
['What else can you tell me about the article?', 'Most of these groups are also dedicated to studying psychological and social issues within their specific communities.']

['What is the purpose of this section?', 'This section will provide an overview of the major subdivisions within psychology today in the order in which they are introduced throughout the remainder of this textbook.']

['What is the most important information you provided us?', 'This is not meant to be an exhaustive listing, but it will provide insight into the major areas of research and practice of modern-day psychologists.']
['What is the study of how biology influences our behavior?', 'As the name suggests, biopsychology explores how our biology influences our behavior.']

['What is the main goal of biological psychology?', 'While biological psychology is a broad field, many biological psychologists want to understand how the structure and function of the nervous system is related to behavior.']
['What is the research done on this subject?', 'As such, they often combine the research strategies of both psychologists and physiologists to accomplish this goal (as discussed in Carlson, 2013).']

['What kind of research do biopsychologists carry out?', 'The research interests of biological psychologists span a number of domains, including but not limited to, sensory and motor systems, sleep, drug use and abuse, ingestive behavior, reproductive behavior, neurodevelopment, plasticity of the nervous system, and biological correlates of psychological disorders.']

['What are some other areas of interest?', 'Given the broad areas of interest falling under the purview of biological psychology, it will probably come as no surprise that individuals from all sorts of backgrounds are involved in this research, including biologists, medical professionals, physiologists, and chemists.']
['Is this something they work on together?', 'This interdisciplinary approach is often referred to as neuroscience, of which biological psychology is a component (Carlson, 2013).']

['What is the difference between biopsychology and evolutionary psychology?', 'While biopsychology typically focuses on the immediate causes of behavior based in the physiology of a human or other animal, evolutionary psychology seeks to study the ultimate biological causes of behavior.']

['What is the adaptation?', 'To the extent that a behavior is impacted by genetics, a behavior, like any anatomical characteristic of a human or animal, will demonstrate adaption to its surroundings.']
['What are the surroundings?', 'These surroundings include the physical environment and, since interactions between organisms can be important to survival and reproduction, the social environment.']

['Who developed the theory of evolution by natural selection?', 'The study of behavior in the context of evolution has its origins with Charles Darwin, the co-discoverer of the theory of evolution by natural selection.']

['What was his theory?', 'Darwin was well aware that behaviors should be adaptive and wrote books titled, The Descent of Man (1871) and The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals (1872), to explore this field.']
['What has evolutionary psychology enjoyed in recent decades?', 'Evolutionary psychology, and specifically, the evolutionary psychology of humans, has enjoyed a resurgence in recent decades.']
['What must a behavior have to be subject to evolution by natural selection?', 'To be subject to evolution by natural selection, a behavior must have a significant genetic cause.']
['What else do we know about the topic?', 'In general, we expect all human cultures to express a behavior if it is caused genetically, since the genetic differences among human groups are small.']

['How do evolutionary psychologists test their theories?', 'The approach taken by most evolutionary psychologists is to predict the outcome of a behavior in a particular situation based on evolutionary theory and then to make observations, or conduct experiments, to determine whether the results match the theory.']

['What are the limitations of these studies?', 'It is important to recognize that these types of studies are not strong evidence that a behavior is adaptive, since they lack information that the behavior is in some part genetic and not entirely cultural (Endler, 1986).']

['Can we know the extent of this theory?', 'Demonstrating that a trait, especially in humans, is naturally selected is extraordinarily difficult; perhaps for this reason, some evolutionary psychologists are content to assume the behaviors they study have genetic determinants (Confer et al., 2010).']

['What is one drawback of evolutionary psychology?', 'One other drawback of evolutionary psychology is that the traits that we possess now evolved under environmental and social conditions far back in human history, and we have a poor understanding of what these conditions were.']
['What is a drawback of this?', 'This makes predictions about what is adaptive for a behavior difficult.']
['How difficult is it to predict?', 'Behavioral traits need not be adaptive under current conditions, only under the conditions of the past when they evolved, about which we can only hypothesize.']
['What are some of the important concepts covered in the material?', 'There are many areas of human behavior for which evolution can make predictions.']

['What are some examples of social organization?', 'Examples include memory, mate choice, relationships between kin, friendship and cooperation, parenting, social organization, and status (Confer et al., 2010).']

['What are some things you know about finding experimental correspondence?', 'Evolutionary psychologists have had success in finding experimental correspondence between observations and expectations.']

['What are some examples of mate preference differences between men and women?', 'In one example, in a study of mate preference differences between men and women that spanned 37 cultures, Buss (1989) found that women valued earning potential factors greater than men, and men valued potential reproductive factors (youth and attractiveness) greater than women in their prospective mates.']
['What were some of the predictions of evolution?', 'In general, the predictions were in line with the predictions of evolution, although there were deviations in some cultures.']

['Who is it written for?', 'Scientists interested in both physiological aspects of sensory systems as well as in the psychological experience of sensory information work within the area of sensation and perception.']
['Are these scientists from any other disciplines?', 'As such, sensation and perception research is also quite interdisciplinary.']
['What did you do to get to class?', 'Imagine walking between buildings as you move from one class to another.']
['What would you experience if you were in a zoo?', 'You are inundated with sights, sounds, touch sensations, and smells.']
['How else do you experience the air around you?', 'You also experience the temperature of the air around you and maintain your balance as you make your way.']
['What are these factors of interest to someone working in the domain of sensation and perception?', 'These are all factors of interest to someone working in the domain of sensation and perception.']

['What was the study about?', 'As described in a later chapter that focuses on the results of studies in sensation and perception, our experience of our world is not as simple as the sum total of all of the sensory information (or sensations) together.']

['How else is our experience different?', 'Rather, our experience (or perception) is complex and is influenced by where we focus our attention, our previous experiences, and even our cultural backgrounds.']

['What did the cognitive revolution create an impetus for psychologists to focus their attention on?', 'As mentioned in the previous section, the cognitive revolution created an impetus for psychologists to focus their attention on better understanding the mind and mental processes that underlie behavior.']

['What is the area of psychology that focuses on studying cognitions, or thoughts, and their relationship to our experiences and our actions?', 'Thus, cognitive psychology is the area of psychology that focuses on studying cognitions, or thoughts, and their relationship to our experiences and our actions.']

['What is the most important information I should know about cognitive psychology?', 'Like biological psychology, cognitive psychology is broad in its scope and often involves collaborations among people from a diverse range of disciplinary backgrounds.']

['What has led some to coin the term cognitive science to describe the interdisciplinary nature of this area of research?', 'This has led some to coin the term cognitive science to describe the interdisciplinary nature of this area of research (Miller, 2003).']

['What are the research interests of cognitive psychologists?', 'Cognitive psychologists have research interests that span a spectrum of topics, ranging from attention to problem solving to language to memory.']
['What are the approaches used in studying these topics?', 'The approaches used in studying these topics are equally diverse.']

['What are some examples of cognitive psychology?', 'Given such diversity, cognitive psychology is not captured in one chapter of this text per se; rather, various concepts related to cognitive psychology will be covered in relevant portions of the chapters in this text on sensation and perception, thinking and intelligence, memory, lifespan development, social psychology, and therapy.']
['What is the scientific study of development across a lifespan?', 'Developmental psychology is the scientific study of development across a lifespan.']
['What are developmental psychologists interested in?', 'Developmental psychologists are interested in processes related to physical maturation.']

['What are some of the other areas that they look at?', 'However, their focus is not limited to the physical changes associated with aging, as they also focus on changes in cognitive skills, moral reasoning, social behavior, and other psychological attributes.']

['What was the document about?', 'Early developmental psychologists focused primarily on changes that occurred through reaching adulthood, providing enormous insight into the differences in physical, cognitive, and social capacities that exist between very young children and adults.']
['What was one of the interesting things that happened in this study?', 'For instance, research by Jean Piaget demonstrated that very young children do not demonstrate object permanence.']
['What does object permanence refer to?', 'Object permanence refers to the understanding that physical things continue to exist, even if they are hidden from us.']
['Can you give me some examples of how this works?', 'If you were to show an adult a toy, and then hide it behind a curtain, the adult knows that the toy still exists.']
['How does a child respond to this?', 'However, very young infants act as if a hidden object no longer exists.']
['Did Piaget publish any further research?', 'The age at which object permanence is achieved is somewhat controversial (Munakata, McClelland, Johnson, and Siegler, 1997).']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'While Piaget was focused on cognitive changes during infancy and childhood as we move to adulthood, there is an increasing interest in extending research into the changes that occur much later in life.']
['What is the most interesting fact about the passage?', 'This may be reflective of changing population demographics of developed nations as a whole.']
['What is one example of that?', 'As more and more people live longer lives, the number of people of advanced age will continue to increase.']
['What is the largest population in the United States?', 'Indeed, it is estimated that there were just over 40 million people aged 65 or older living in the United States in 2010.']
['What is the largest population today?', 'However, by 2020, this number is expected to increase to about 55 million.']
['What year did it increase by?', 'By the year 2050, it is estimated that nearly 90 million people in this country will be 65 or older (Department of Health and Human Services, n.d.).']
['What does personality psychology focus on?', 'Personality psychology focuses on patterns of thoughts and behaviors that make each individual unique.']

['Who were the early theorists?', 'Several individuals (e.g., Freud and Maslow) that we have already discussed in our historical overview of psychology, and the American psychologist Gordon Allport, contributed to early theories of personality.']
['What did these early theorists attempt to explain?', 'These early theorists attempted to explain how an individual’s personality develops from their given perspective.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'For example, Freud proposed that personality arose as conflicts between the conscious and unconscious parts of the mind were carried out over the lifespan.']
['What did Freud theorize?', 'Specifically, Freud theorized that an individual went through various psychosexual stages of development.']

['What are the various stages?', 'According to Freud, adult personality would result from the resolution of various conflicts that centered on the migration of erogenous (or sexual pleasure-producing) zones from the oral (mouth) to the anus to the phallus to the genitals.']
['What is controversial about the theory?', 'Like many of Freud’s theories, this particular idea was controversial and did not lend itself to experimental tests (Person, 1980).']
['What is a quantitative approach?', 'More recently, the study of personality has taken on a more quantitative approach.']

['What is the quantitative approach?', 'Rather than explaining how personality arises, research is focused on identifying personality traits, measuring these traits, and determining how these traits interact in a particular context to determine how a person will behave in any given situation.']

['What are relatively consistent patterns of thought and behavior?', 'Personality traits are relatively consistent patterns of thought and behavior, and many have proposed that five trait dimensions are sufficient to capture the variations in personality seen across individuals.']

['What are the five dimensions of the Big Five?', 'These five dimensions are known as the “Big Five” or the Five Factor model, and include dimensions of conscientiousness, agreeableness, neuroticism, openness, and extraversion.']

['What are the results of the quantitiy approach?', 'Each of these traits has been demonstrated to be relatively stable over the lifespan (e.g., Rantanen, Metsäpelto, Feldt, Pulkinnen, and Kokko, 2007; Soldz & Vaillant, 1999; McCrae & Costa, 2008) and is influenced by genetics (e.g., Jang, Livesly, and Vernon, 1996).']
['What does social psychology focus on?', 'Social psychology focuses on how we interact with and relate to others.']

['What do social psychologists conduct research on?', 'Social psychologists conduct research on a wide variety of topics that include differences in how we explain our own behavior versus how we explain the behaviors of others, prejudice, and attraction, and how we resolve interpersonal conflicts.']
['What is interesting about Social Psychology?', 'Social psychologists have also sought to determine how being among other people changes our own behavior and patterns of thinking.']
['What is the next question?', 'There are many interesting examples of social psychological research, and you will read about many of these in a later chapter of this textbook.']
['What will you read about the most controversial psychology studies ever conducted?', 'Until then, you will be introduced to one of the most controversial psychological studies ever conducted.']
["What is Stanley Milgram's occupation?", 'Stanley Milgram was an American social psychologist who is most famous for research that he conducted on obedience.']
['What is Adolf Eichmann?', 'After the holocaust, in 1961, a Nazi war criminal, Adolf Eichmann, who was accused of committing mass atrocities, was put on trial.']

['What did the German soldiers do in the trial?', 'Many people wondered how German soldiers were capable of torturing prisoners in concentration camps, and they were unsatisfied with the excuses given by soldiers that they were simply following orders.']

['What is a major study that you have read about?', 'At the time, most psychologists agreed that few people would be willing to inflict such extraordinary pain and suffering, simply because they were obeying orders.']
["What did Milgram do after Eichmann's trial?", 'Milgram decided to conduct research to determine whether or not this was true.']

['What did Milgram find out?', 'As you will read later in the text, Milgram found that nearly two-thirds of his participants were willing to deliver what they believed to be lethal shocks to another person, simply because they were instructed to do so by an authority figure (in this case, a man dressed in a lab coat).']

['What did the participants agree to do?', 'This was in spite of the fact that participants received payment for simply showing up for the research study and could have chosen not to inflict pain or more serious consequences on another person by withdrawing from the study.']

['How were the participants injured?', 'No one was actually hurt or harmed in any way, Milgram’s experiment was a clever ruse that took advantage of research confederates, those who pretend to be participants in a research study who are actually working for the researcher and have clear, specific directions on how to behave during the research study (Hock, 2009).']

['Did the experiment have negative effects on others?', 'Milgram’s and others’ studies that involved deception and potential emotional harm to study participants catalyzed the development of ethical guidelines for conducting psychological research that discourage the use of deception of research subjects, unless it can be argued not to cause harm and, in general, requiring informed consent of participants.']

['What is the definition of Industrial-Organizational psychology?', 'Industrial-Organizational psychology (I-O psychology) is a subfield of psychology that applies psychological theories, principles, and research findings in industrial and organizational settings.']
['What is some other information you found interesting?', 'I-O psychologists are often involved in issues related to personnel management, organizational structure, and workplace environment.']

['What does I-O psychology help companies and their employees with?', 'Businesses often seek the aid of I-O psychologists to make the best hiring decisions as well as to create an environment that results in high levels of employee productivity and efficiency.']
['What is I-O psychology?', 'In addition to its applied nature, I-O psychology also involves conducting scientific research on behavior within I-O settings (Riggio, 2013).']
['What does health psychology focus on?', 'Health psychology focuses on how health is affected by the interaction of biological, psychological, and sociocultural factors.']
['What is the particular approach?', 'This particular approach is known as the biopsychosocial model.']
['What do health psychologists do?', 'Health psychologists are interested in helping individuals achieve better health through public policy, education, intervention, and research.']

['What might health psychologists research?', 'Health psychologists might conduct research that explores the relationship between one’s genetic makeup, patterns of behavior, relationships, psychological stress, and health.']
['What may be the purpose of this research?', 'They may research effective ways to motivate people to address patterns of behavior that contribute to poorer health (MacDonald, 2013).']

['What are some of the most interesting aspects of Sport and Exercise Psychology?', 'Researchers in sport and exercise psychology study the psychological aspects of sport performance, including motivation and performance anxiety, and the effects of sport on mental and emotional wellbeing.']
['What is the main topic of Sport and Exercise Psychology?', 'Research is also conducted on similar topics as they relate to physical exercise in general.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects about Sport and Exercise Psychology?', 'The discipline also includes topics that are broader than sport and exercise but that are related to interactions between mental and physical performance under demanding conditions, such as fire fighting, military operations, artistic performance, and surgery.']

['What is the area of psychology that focuses on the diagnosis and treatment of psychological disorders and other problematic patterns of behavior?', 'Clinical psychology is the area of psychology that focuses on the diagnosis and treatment of psychological disorders and other problematic patterns of behavior.']
['What is special about this area?', 'As such, it is generally considered to be a more applied area within psychology; however, some clinicians are also actively engaged in scientific research.']

['Which discipline is similar to forensic psychology?', 'Counseling psychology is a similar discipline that focuses on emotional, social, vocational, and health-related outcomes in individuals who are considered psychologically healthy.']

['What are the most important people that shaped clinical practice?', 'As mentioned earlier, both Freud and Rogers provided perspectives that have been influential in shaping how clinicians interact with people seeking psychotherapy.']

['What were the views of Rogers?', 'While aspects of the psychoanalytic theory are still found among some of today’s therapists who are trained from a psychodynamic perspective, Roger’s ideas about client-centered therapy have been especially influential in shaping how many clinicians operate.']

['What did the cognitive revolution shape clinical practice in?', 'Furthermore, both behaviorism and the cognitive revolution have shaped clinical practice in the forms of behavioral therapy, cognitive therapy, and cognitive-behavioral therapy.']

['What are the issues in treatment of psychological disorders?', 'Issues related to the diagnosis and treatment of psychological disorders and problematic patterns of behavior will be discussed in detail in later chapters of this textbook.']
['What is forensic psychology?', 'Forensic psychology is a branch of psychology that deals questions of psychology as they arise in the context of the justice system.']

['What do forensic psychologists help with?', 'For example, forensic psychologists (and forensic psychiatrists) will assess a person’s competency to stand trial, assess the state of mind of a defendant, act as consultants on child custody cases, consult on sentencing and treatment recommendations, and advise on issues such as eyewitness testimony and children’s testimony (American Board of Forensic Psychology, 2014).']
['What do they do in court cases?', 'In these capacities, they will typically act as expert witnesses, called by either side in a court case to provide their research- or experience-based opinions.']

['What must forensic psychologists have?', 'As expert witnesses, forensic psychologists must have a good understanding of the law and provide information in the context of the legal system rather than just within the realm of psychology.']
['What do forensic psychologists help with?', 'Forensic psychologists are also used in the jury selection process and witness preparation.']
['What else does the have to do with?', 'They may also be involved in providing psychological treatment within the criminal justice system.']
['Do criminal profilers profile people?', 'Criminal profilers are a relatively small proportion of psychologists that act as consultants to law enforcement.']
['What is important about the article?', 'Psychologists can work in many different places doing many different things.']

['What is the best place to get a psychology degree?', 'In general, anyone wishing to continue a career in psychology at a 4-year institution of higher education will have to earn a doctoral degree in psychology for some specialties and at least a master’s degree for others.']
['What does a doctoral degree in psychology mean?', 'In most areas of psychology, this means earning a PhD in a relevant area of psychology.']
['What does the PhD mean?', 'Literally, PhD refers to a doctor of philosophy degree, but here, philosophy does not refer to the field of philosophy per se.']
['Does it mean anything else?', 'Rather, philosophy in this context refers to many different disciplinary perspectives that would be housed in a traditional college of liberal arts and sciences.']

['What are the requirements to earn a PhD?', 'The requirements to earn a PhD vary from country to country and even from school to school, but usually, individuals earning this degree must complete a dissertation.']
['What is a dissertation?', 'A dissertation is essentially a long research paper or bundled published articles describing research that was conducted as a part of the candidate’s doctoral training.']
['What else does a dissertation involve?', 'In the United States, a dissertation generally has to be defended before a committee of expert reviewers before the degree is conferred.']
['What are some important things to know about the section on career options in psychology?', 'Once someone earns a PhD, they may seek a faculty appointment at a college or university.']

['What are the different responsibilities of being on the faculty?', 'Being on the faculty of a college or university often involves dividing time between teaching, research, and service to the institution and profession.']

['Are there any other important responsibilities that faculty have?', 'The amount of time spent on each of these primary responsibilities varies dramatically from school to school, and it is not uncommon for faculty to move from place to place in search of the best personal fit among various academic environments.']

['What are some of the major areas that are commonly represented in psychology departments around the country?', 'The previous section detailed some of the major areas that are commonly represented in psychology departments around the country; thus, depending on the training received, an individual could be anything from a biological psychologist to a clinical psychologist in an academic setting.']
['What is the main reason for the need for adjunct faculty?', 'Often times, schools offer more courses in psychology than their full-time faculty can teach.']
['What is a common problem for these schools?', 'In these cases, it is not uncommon to bring in an adjunct faculty member or instructor.']

['What experience do adjunct faculty members and instructors usually have?', 'Adjunct faculty members and instructors usually have an advanced degree in psychology, but they often have primary careers outside of academia and serve in this role as a secondary job.']

['What are some reasons why they have this secondary job?', 'Alternatively, they may not hold the doctoral degree required by most 4-year institutions and use these opportunities to gain experience in teaching.']
['What is another reason for the shortage?', 'Furthermore, many 2-year colleges and schools need faculty to teach their courses in psychology.']

['What degree is required for that?', 'In general, many of the people who pursue careers at these institutions have master’s degrees in psychology, although some PhDs make careers at these institutions as well.']
['What does that mean?', 'Some people earning PhDs may enjoy research in an academic setting.']
['How do you think teachers feel about the job?', 'However, they may not be interested in teaching.']
['What might they do instead?', 'These individuals might take on faculty positions that are exclusively devoted to conducting research.']
['What kind of positions would be more likely an option at large, research-focused universities?', 'This type of position would be more likely an option at large, research-focused universities.']

['What is the article about?', 'In some areas in psychology, it is common for individuals who have recently earned their PhD to seek out positions in postdoctoral training programs that are available before going on to serve as faculty.']
['What are these programs for?', 'In most cases, young scientists will complete one or two postdoctoral programs before applying for a full-time faculty position.']

['What do postdoctoral training programs allow young scientists to do?', 'Postdoctoral training programs allow young scientists to further develop their research programs and broaden their research skills under the supervision of other professionals in the field.']
['What is the major topic of discussion?', 'Individuals who wish to become practicing clinical psychologists have another option for earning a doctoral degree, which is known as a PsyD.']
['What is a doctor of psychology degree?', 'A PsyD is a doctor of psychology degree that is increasingly popular among individuals interested in pursuing careers in clinical psychology.']

['What are the benefits of a psyd program?', 'PsyD programs generally place less emphasis on research-oriented skills and focus more on application of psychological principles in the clinical context (Norcross & Castle, 2002).']

['What did you learn about postdoctoral work?', 'Regardless of whether earning a PhD or PsyD, in most states, an individual wishing to practice as a licensed clinical or counseling psychologist may complete postdoctoral work under the supervision of a licensed psychologist.']

['What is the most recent change in the law?', 'Within the last few years, however, several states have begun to remove this requirement, which would allow people to get an earlier start in their careers (Munsey, 2009).']

['What is the process for a person to sit for the licensing exam?', 'After an individual has met the state requirements, their credentials are evaluated to determine whether they can sit for the licensure exam.']
['What is the purpose of the examination?', 'Only individuals that pass this exam can call themselves licensed clinical or counseling psychologists (Norcross, n.d.).']
['What can they do with a license?', 'Licensed clinical or counseling psychologists can then work in a number of settings, ranging from private clinical practice to hospital settings.']
['What is another important point?', 'It should be noted that clinical psychologists and psychiatrists do different things and receive different types of education.']

['What are the differences between clinical psychologists and psychiatrists?', 'While both can conduct therapy and counseling, clinical psychologists have a PhD or a PsyD, whereas psychiatrists have a doctor of medicine degree (MD).']

['What is the main difference between a clinical psychologist and a psychiatrist?', 'As such, licensed clinical psychologists can administer and interpret psychological tests, while psychiatrists can prescribe medications.']
['What can a doctor do to get that type of work?', 'Individuals earning a PhD can work in a variety of settings, depending on their areas of specialization.']
['What other kinds of settings would a doctor find?', 'For example, someone trained as a biopsychologist might work in a pharmaceutical company to help test the efficacy of a new drug.']

['What kind of setting would someone trained as a forensic psychologist work within?', 'Someone with a clinical background might become a forensic psychologist and work within the legal system to make recommendations during criminal trials and parole hearings, or serve as an expert in a court case.']

['What are the main points of this passage?', 'While earning a doctoral degree in psychology is a lengthy process, usually taking between 5–6 years of graduate study (DeAngelis, 2010), there are a number of careers that can be attained with a master’s degree in psychology.']

['What are some examples of people who wish to provide psychotherapy?', 'People who wish to provide psychotherapy can become licensed to serve as various types of professional counselors (Hoffman, 2012).']

['What else is an example?', 'Relevant master’s degrees are also sufficient for individuals seeking careers as school psychologists (National Association of School Psychologists, n.d.), in some capacities related to sport psychology (American Psychological Association, 2014), or as consultants in various industrial settings (Landers, 2011, June 14).']

['What does the article say about psychology careers?', 'Undergraduate coursework in psychology may be applicable to other careers such as psychiatric social work or psychiatric nursing, where assessments and therapy may be a part of the job.']

['What is the main point of the study material?', 'As mentioned in the opening section of this chapter, an undergraduate education in psychology is associated with a knowledge base and skill set that many employers find quite attractive.']

['What type of careers do you see psychology graduates getting?', 'It should come as no surprise, then, that individuals earning bachelor’s degrees in psychology find themselves in a number of different careers, as shown in Table 1.1.']

['How many different careers are there?', 'Examples of a few such careers can involve serving as case managers, working in sales, working in human resource departments, and teaching in high schools.']

['What is another field in which an education in psychology is helpful and sometimes required?', 'The rapidly growing realm of healthcare professions is another field in which an education in psychology is helpful and sometimes required.']

['What is required to be admitted to medical school?', 'For example, the Medical College Admission Test (MCAT) exam that people must take to be admitted to medical school now includes a section on the psychological foundations of behavior.']
['What is the purpose of scientific research?', 'Scientific research is a critical tool for successfully navigating our complex world.']
['Why is it important to have a scientific method?', 'Without it, we would be forced to rely solely on intuition, other people’s authority, and blind luck.']

['What is important about the passage?', 'While many of us feel confident in our abilities to decipher and interact with the world around us, history is filled with examples of how very wrong we can be when we fail to recognize the need for evidence in supporting claims.']

['What evidence did we fail to recognize?', 'At various times in history, we would have been certain that the sun revolved around a flat earth, that the earth’s continents did not move, and that mental illness was caused by possession.']

['What is the most important thing about the passage?', 'It is through systematic scientific research that we divest ourselves of our preconceived notions and superstitions and gain an objective understanding of ourselves and our world.']
['What are the goals of all scientists?', 'The goal of all scientists is to better understand the world around them.']

['What do psychologists focus their attention on?', 'Psychologists focus their attention on understanding behavior, as well as the cognitive (mental) and physiological (body) processes that underlie behavior.']

['What is the hallmark of scientific research?', 'In contrast to other methods that people use to understand the behavior of others, such as intuition and personal experience, the hallmark of scientific research is that there is evidence to support a claim.']
['What kind of evidence is used in scientific knowledge?', 'Scientific knowledge is empirical:']
['What kind of evidence is used?', 'It is grounded in objective, tangible evidence that can be observed time and time again, regardless of who is observing.']
['What is observable?', 'While behavior is observable, the mind is not.']
['What is something that can be observed?', 'If someone is crying, we can see behavior.']
['What is the reason for the behavior?', 'However, the reason for the behavior is more difficult to determine.']
['What can be done to learn the reason for someone’s behavior?', 'Sometimes we can learn the reason for someone’s behavior by simply asking a question, like “Why are you crying?”']

["What happens if the question isn't answered honestly?", 'However, there are situations in which an individual is either uncomfortable or unwilling to answer the question honestly, or is incapable of answering.']
['What does incapable of answering mean?', 'For example, infants would not be able to explain why they are crying.']
['Why are they not able to explain?', 'In such circumstances, the psychologist must be creative in finding ways to better understand behavior.']
['What is knowledge?', 'This chapter explores how scientific knowledge is generated, and how important that knowledge is in forming decisions in our personal lives and in the public domain.']

['What is the content of our study material?', 'Trying to determine which theories are and are not accepted by the scientific community can be difficult, especially in an area of research as broad as psychology.']

['What are some of the challenges of a simple internet search on any given research topic?', 'More than ever before, we have an incredible amount of information at our fingertips, and a simple internet search on any given research topic might result in a number of contradictory studies.']

['What do you find most interesting about the scientific community in this section?', 'In these cases, we are witnessing the scientific community going through the process of reaching a consensus, and it could be quite some time before a consensus emerges.']
['What are some examples of how technology has changed our lives?', 'For example, the explosion in our use of technology has led researchers to question whether this ultimately helps or hinders us.']
['What is interesting about educational settings?', 'The use and implementation of technology in educational settings has become widespread over the last few decades.']
['Are there any other important points in the paragraph?', 'Researchers are coming to different conclusions regarding the use of technology.']

['What did you find interesting about this section?', 'To illustrate this point, a study investigating a smartphone app targeting surgery residents (graduate students in surgery training) found that the use of this app can increase student engagement and raise test scores (Shaw & Tan, 2015).']

['Did this app have any negative impacts?', 'Conversely, another study found that the use of technology in undergraduate student populations had negative impacts on sleep, communication, and time management skills (Massimini & Peterson, 2009).']
