["Are any other studies going to be conducted on the effects that technology has on a student's acquisition of knowledge, study skills, and mental health?", "Until sufficient amounts of research have been conducted, there will be no clear consensus on the effects that technology has on a student's acquisition of knowledge, study skills, and mental health."]

['What does it mean to think critically about the information we encounter by exercising a degree of healthy skepticism?', 'In the meantime, we should strive to think critically about the information we encounter by exercising a degree of healthy skepticism.']

['What are some reasons to be skeptical?', 'This is especially important when we consider how much information in advertising campaigns and on the internet claims to be based on “scientific evidence” when in actuality it is a belief or perspective of just a few individuals trying to sell a product or draw attention to their perspectives.']
['What is the topic of our study material?', 'We should be informed consumers of the information made available to us because decisions based on this information have significant consequences.']
['What is one consequence we can have based on this information?', 'One such consequence can be seen in politics and public policy.']
['What is a political consequence?', 'Imagine that you have been elected as the governor of your state.']
['What are your responsibilities as a state senator?', 'One of your responsibilities is to manage the state budget and determine how to best spend your constituents’ tax dollars.']
['What are the decisions you have to make as the new governor?', 'As the new governor, you need to decide whether to continue funding early intervention programs.']
['What are some examples of these programs?', 'These programs are designed to help children who come from low-income backgrounds, have special needs, or face other disadvantages.']

['What do these programs provide?', "These programs may involve providing a wide variety of services to maximize the children's development and position them for optimal levels of success in school and later in life (Blann, 2005)."]

['How would you want to be sure that such programs proved effective before investing additional money in these programs?', 'While such programs sound appealing, you would want to be sure that they also proved effective before investing additional money in these programs.']

['What is evidence that these programs are effective?', 'Fortunately, psychologists and other scientists have conducted vast amounts of research on such programs and, in general, the programs are found to be effective (Neil & Christensen, 2009; Peters-Scheffer, Didden, Korzilius, & Sturmey, 2011).']

['What else is known about these programs?', 'While not all programs are equally effective, and the short-term effects of many such programs are more pronounced, there is reason to believe that many of these programs produce long-term benefits for participants (Barnett, 2011).']

['What would you want to look at if you are committed to being a good steward of taxpayer money?', 'If you are committed to being a good steward of taxpayer money, you would want to look at research.']
['What should you do after examining the research?', 'After examining the research, you would be best equipped to make decisions about which programs to fund.']
['What can be learned from this study material?', 'Ultimately, it is not just politicians who can benefit from using research in guiding their decisions.']
['Why might we look to research from time to time when making decisions in our lives?', 'We all might look to research from time to time when making decisions in our lives.']
['What can you do to make the best decision for your sister Maria?', "Imagine you just found out that your sister Maria's child, Umberto, was recently diagnosed with autism."]
['What can you do to help someone with autism?', 'There are many treatments for autism that help decrease the negative impact of autism on the individual.']

['What are some examples of treatments for autism?', 'Some examples of treatments for autism are applied behavior analysis (ABA), social communication groups, social skills groups, occupational therapy, and even medication options.']
['How can you make the best decision?', 'You would likely want to review the research and learn about the efficacy of each treatment so you could best advise your sister.']
['What makes the difference between facts and opinions?', 'In the end, research is what makes the difference between facts and opinions.']
['What are facts and opinions?', 'Facts are observable realities, and opinions are personal judgments, conclusions, or attitudes that may or may not be accurate.']
['What does research help us with?', 'In the scientific community, facts can be established only using evidence collected through empirical research.']
['What is important about the notable researchers?', 'Psychological research has a long history involving important figures from diverse backgrounds.']

['What are some of the individuals who deserve attention in considering how psychology has advanced as a science through their work?', 'While the introductory chapter discussed several researchers who made significant contributions to the discipline, there are many more individuals who deserve attention in considering how psychology has advanced as a science through their work.']
['Who was the first woman to earn a PhD in psychology?', 'For instance, Margaret Floy Washburn (1871–1939) was the first woman to earn a PhD in psychology.']
['What did she research?', 'Her research focused on animal behavior and cognition (Margaret Floy Washburn, PhD, n.d.).']

['Who was the first American woman?', 'Mary Whiton Calkins (1863–1930) was a preeminent first-generation American psychologist who opposed the behaviorist movement, conducted significant research into memory, and established one of the earliest experimental psychology labs in the United States (Mary Whiton Calkins, n.d.).']
['What were the notable researchers?', 'Francis Sumner (1895–1954) was the first African American to receive a PhD in psychology in 1920.']
["What was Sumner's research focus?", 'His dissertation focused on issues related to psychoanalysis.']
['What else was his focus?', 'Sumner also had research interests in racial bias and educational justice.']

['What else can you tell me about Francis Sumner?', 'Sumner was one of the founders of Howard University’s department of psychology, and because of his accomplishments, he is sometimes referred to as the “Father of Black Psychology.”']
['What else can you tell me about Francis Sumner?', 'Thirteen years later, Inez Beverly Prosser (1895–1934) became the first African American woman to receive a PhD in psychology.']

['What was Prosser’s research focused on?', 'Prosser’s research highlighted issues related to education in segregated versus integrated schools, and ultimately, her work was very influential in the hallmark Brown v. Board of Education Supreme Court ruling that segregation of public schools was unconstitutional (Ethnicity and Health in America Series: Featured Psychologists, n.d.).']

['What is a significant fact in this article?', 'Although the establishment of psychology’s scientific roots occurred first in Europe and the United States, it did not take much time until researchers from around the world began to establish their own laboratories and research programs.']

['What were the first people to begin doing research on psychology?', 'For example, some of the first experimental psychology laboratories in South America were founded by Horatio Piñero (1869–1919) at two institutions in Buenos Aires, Argentina (Godoy & Brussino, 2010).']

['Who else contributed to the early research?', 'In India, Gunamudian David Boaz (1908–1965) and Narendra Nath Sen Gupta (1889–1944) established the first independent departments of psychology at the University of Madras and the University of Calcutta, respectively.']

['What was the response of the Indian researchers to this research?', 'These developments provided an opportunity for Indian researchers to make important contributions to the field (Gunamudian David Boaz, n.d.; Narendra Nath Sen Gupta, n.d.).']

['What are the demographics of the APA?', 'When the American Psychological Association (APA) was first founded in 1892, all of the members were White males (Women and Minorities in Psychology, n.d.).']

['Were they still primarily white?', 'However, by 1905, Mary Whiton Calkins was elected as the first female president of the APA, and by 1946, nearly one-quarter of American psychologists were female.']

['What demographic changes were there?', 'Psychology became a popular degree option for students enrolled in the nation’s historically Black higher education institutions, increasing the number of Black Americans who went on to become psychologists.']

['How did these changes effect the APA?', 'Given demographic shifts occurring in the United States and increased access to higher educational opportunities among historically underrepresented populations, there is reason to hope that the diversity of the field will increasingly match the larger population, and that the research contributions made by the psychologists of the future will better serve people of all backgrounds (Women and Minorities in Psychology, n.d.).']
['What is the scientific method?', 'Scientific knowledge is advanced through a process known as the scientific method.']

['How does it work?', 'Basically, ideas (in the form of theories and hypotheses) are tested against the real world (in the form of empirical observations), and those empirical observations lead to more ideas that are tested against the real world, and so on.']
['What is the most important part about scientific research?', 'In this sense, the scientific process is circular.']
['What are the types of reasoning within the circle called?', 'The types of reasoning within the circle are called deductive and inductive.']

['What is the difference between deductive reasoning and inductive reasoning?', 'In deductive reasoning, ideas are tested in the real world; in inductive reasoning, real-world observations lead to new ideas.']

['What is the purpose of separating these two kinds of reasoning?', 'These processes are inseparable, like inhaling and exhaling, but different research approaches place different emphasis on the deductive and inductive aspects.']

['What does deductive reasoning mean in the scientific context?', 'In the scientific context, deductive reasoning begins with a generalization—one hypothesis—that is then used to reach logical conclusions about the real world.']
['How does deductive reasoning work?', 'If the hypothesis is correct, then the logical conclusions reached through deductive reasoning should also be correct.']
['What is an example of deductive reasoning?', 'A deductive reasoning argument might go something like this:']
['What do all living things require energy to survive?', 'All living things require energy to survive (this would be your hypothesis).']
['Is this true for ducks?', 'Ducks are living things.']
['Is this true for quackers?', 'Therefore, ducks require energy to survive (logical conclusion).']
['Do you think the conclusion is correct?', 'In this example, the hypothesis is correct; therefore, the conclusion is correct as well.']
['What are some examples of incorrect hypotheses?', 'Sometimes, however, an incorrect hypothesis may lead to a logical but incorrect conclusion.']
['What is another example of an incorrect conclusion?', 'Consider this argument: all ducks are born with the ability to see.']
['Is this true for quackers?', 'Quackers is a duck.']
['Do you think Quackers was born with the ability to see?', 'Therefore, Quackers was born with the ability to see.']
['What are some examples of deductive reasoning?', 'Scientists use deductive reasoning to empirically test their hypotheses.']

['What happens to their hypotheses?', 'Returning to the example of the ducks, researchers might design a study to test the hypothesis that if all living things require energy to survive, then ducks will be found to require energy to survive.']

['how is this different from inductive reasoning?', 'Deductive reasoning starts with a generalization that is tested against real-world observations; however, inductive reasoning moves in the opposite direction.']
['What is the difference between inductive reasoning and deductive reasoning?', 'Inductive reasoning uses empirical observations to construct broad generalizations.']

['What are the limitations of inductive reasoning?', 'Unlike deductive reasoning, conclusions drawn from inductive reasoning may or may not be correct, regardless of the observations on which they are based.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'For instance, you may notice that your favorite fruits—apples, bananas, and oranges—all grow on trees; therefore, you assume that all fruit must grow on trees.']

['Do strawberries, blueberries, and kiwi demonstrate that this generalization is not correct despite it being based on a number of direct observations?', 'This would be an example of inductive reasoning, and, clearly, the existence of strawberries, blueberries, and kiwi demonstrate that this generalization is not correct despite it being based on a number of direct observations.']
['What is the process of inductive reasoning?', 'Scientists use inductive reasoning to formulate theories, which in turn generate hypotheses that are tested with deductive reasoning.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'In the end, science involves both deductive and inductive processes.']
['What do case studies refer to?', 'For example, case studies, which you will read about in the next section, are heavily weighted on the side of empirical observations.']

['What do case studies have to do with the scientific research method?', 'Thus, case studies are closely associated with inductive processes as researchers gather massive amounts of observations and seek interesting patterns (new ideas) in the data.']
['What are the two ways of calculating probability and statistics?', 'Experimental research, on the other hand, puts great emphasis on deductive reasoning.']
['What is a well-developed set of ideas that propose an explanation for observed phenomena?', 'A theory is a well-developed set of ideas that propose an explanation for observed phenomena.']

['How are theories tested?', 'Theories are repeatedly checked against the world, but they tend to be too complex to be tested all at once; instead, researchers create hypotheses to test specific aspects of a theory.']

['What is a hypothesis?', 'A hypothesis is a testable prediction about how the world will behave if our idea is correct, and it is often worded as an if-then statement (e.g., if I study all night, I will get a passing grade on the test).']
['What is the hypothesis?', 'The hypothesis is extremely important because it bridges the gap between the realm of ideas and the real world.']
['What is the most important information of the article?', 'As specific hypotheses are tested, theories are modified and refined to reflect and incorporate the result of these tests Figure 2.5.']
['What is the best place to get more information about this?', 'To see how this process works, let’s consider a specific theory and a hypothesis that might be generated from that theory.']

['What is the James-Lange theory of emotion?', 'As you’ll learn in a later chapter, the James-Lange theory of emotion asserts that emotional experience relies on the physiological arousal associated with the emotional state.']
['What is an example of a fear response?', 'If you walked out of your home and discovered a very aggressive snake waiting on your doorstep, your heart would begin to race and your stomach churn.']
['Why would this happen?', 'According to the James-Lange theory, these physiological changes would result in your feeling of fear.']

['What is important about the theory?', 'A hypothesis that could be derived from this theory might be that a person who is unaware of the physiological arousal that the sight of the snake elicits will not feel fear.']
['What are some key points about scientific hypothesis?', 'A scientific hypothesis is also falsifiable, or capable of being shown to be incorrect.']
['What did Sigmund Freud say?', 'Recall from the introductory chapter that Sigmund Freud had lots of interesting ideas to explain various human behaviors.']

['What is a major criticism of Freud’s theories?', 'However, a major criticism of Freud’s theories is that many of his ideas are not falsifiable; for example, it is impossible to imagine empirical observations that would disprove the existence of the id, the ego, and the superego—the three elements of personality described in Freud’s theories.']

['What else was he saying?', 'Despite this, Freud’s theories are widely taught in introductory psychology texts because of their historical significance for personality psychology and psychotherapy, and these remain the root of all modern forms of therapy.']
['What is the James-Lange theory?', 'In contrast, the James-Lange theory does generate falsifiable hypotheses, such as the one described above.']

['What else are you learning about the James-Lange theory?', 'Some individuals who suffer significant injuries to their spinal columns are unable to feel the bodily changes that often accompany emotional experiences.']

['What are we attempting to test?', 'Therefore, we could test the hypothesis by determining how emotional experiences differ between individuals who have the ability to detect these changes in their physiological arousal and those who do not.']

['Is this theory already known?', 'In fact, this research has been conducted and while the emotional experiences of people deprived of an awareness of their physiological arousal may be less intense, they still experience emotion (Chwalisz, Diener, & Gallagher, 1988).']
['What do you think about scientific research’s dependence on falsifiability?', 'Scientific research’s dependence on falsifiability allows for great confidence in the information that it produces.']
['Is this a bad thing?', 'Typically, by the time information is accepted by the scientific community, it has been tested repeatedly.']

['What are the research methods available to psychologists?', 'There are many research methods available to psychologists in their efforts to understand, describe, and explain behavior and the cognitive and biological processes that underlie it.']
['What observational techniques are used?', 'Some methods rely on observational techniques.']

['What other methods are used?', 'Other approaches involve interactions between the researcher and the individuals who are being studied—ranging from a series of simple questions to extensive, in-depth interviews—to well-controlled experiments.']

['What are some of the strengths and weaknesses of the research methods?', 'Each of these research methods has unique strengths and weaknesses, and each method may only be appropriate for certain types of research questions.']

['What are some of the weaknesses of studies that rely primarily on observation?', 'For example, studies that rely primarily on observation produce incredible amounts of information, but the ability to apply this information to the larger population is somewhat limited because of small sample sizes.']
['How do you increase sample sizes?', 'Survey research, on the other hand, allows researchers to easily collect data from relatively large samples.']

['What are some drawbacks of using surveys?', 'While this allows for results to be generalized to the larger population more easily, the information that can be collected on any given survey is somewhat limited and subject to problems associated with any type of self-reported data.']
['What is the archival research?', 'Some researchers conduct archival research by using existing records.']

['What are the limitations of this approach?', 'While this can be a fairly inexpensive way to collect data that can provide insight into a number of research questions, researchers using this approach have no control on how or what kind of data was collected.']
['What are some of the correlational methods?', 'All of the methods described thus far are correlational in nature.']
['What is correlational analysis?', 'This means that researchers can speak to important relationships that might exist between two or more variables of interest.']
['What limitations do correlational data have?', 'However, correlational data cannot be used to make claims about cause-and-effect relationships.']

['What can you tell me about correlational research?', 'Correlational research can find a relationship between two variables, but the only way a researcher can claim that the relationship between the variables is cause and effect is to perform an experiment.']

['What is the most important thing to know about experimental research?', 'In experimental research, which will be discussed later in this chapter, there is a tremendous amount of control over variables of interest.']
['What is the most important reason for this approach?', 'While this is a powerful approach, experiments are often conducted in artificial settings.']
['What are they called artificial settings?', 'This calls into question the validity of experimental findings with regard to how they would apply in real-world settings.']

['What else can you tell me about the limitations?', 'In addition, many of the questions that psychologists would like to answer cannot be pursued through experimental research because of ethical concerns.']
['what newspaper published a feature story on krista and tatiana hogan?', 'In 2011, the New York Times published a feature story on Krista and Tatiana Hogan, Canadian twin girls.']
['What is unique about Krista and Tatiana?', 'These particular twins are unique because Krista and Tatiana are conjoined twins, connected at the head.']
['What did the research find?', 'There is evidence that the two girls are connected in a part of the brain called the thalamus, which is a major sensory relay center.']
['What does the sensory relay center do?', 'Most incoming sensory information is sent through the thalamus before reaching higher regions of the cerebral cortex for processing.']

['What might the implications of this potential connection mean?', 'The implications of this potential connection mean that it might be possible for one twin to experience the sensations of the other twin.']

['how might one twin experience sensations of the other?', 'For instance, if Krista is watching a particularly funny television program, Tatiana might smile or laugh even if she is not watching the program.']
['Did you ever learn the details of the article?', 'This particular possibility has piqued the interest of many neuroscientists who seek to understand how the brain uses sensory information.']
['what are the clinical studies?', 'In observational research, scientists are conducting a clinical or case study when they focus on one person or just a few individuals.']
['What does the research consist of?', 'Indeed, some scientists spend their entire careers studying just 10–20 individuals.']
['Why do they do this?', 'Obviously, when they focus their attention on a very small number of people, they can gain a precious amount of insight into those cases.']
['What are some other interesting aspects about this material?', 'The richness of information that is collected in clinical or case studies is unmatched by any other single research method.']
['Why is this?', 'This allows the researcher to have a very deep understanding of the individuals and the particular phenomenon being studied.']
['What is the major benefit of this particular approach?', 'As it turns out, the major benefit of this particular approach is also a weakness.']
['What is the reason for this approach?', 'As mentioned earlier, this approach is often used when studying individuals who are interesting to researchers because they have a rare characteristic.']
['Why is that considered a weakness?', 'Therefore, the individuals who serve as the focus of case studies are not like most other people.']

['What is important about this case study approach?', 'If scientists ultimately want to explain all behavior, focusing attention on such a special group of people can make it difficult to generalize any observations to the larger population as a whole.']

['What is the ability to apply the findings of a particular research project to larger segments of society?', 'Generalizing refers to the ability to apply the findings of a particular research project to larger segments of society.']

['How do you try to generalize from case studies?', 'Again, case studies provide enormous amounts of information, but since the cases are so specific, the potential to apply what’s learned to the average person may be very limited.']

['What is one of the most important points you found in your research?', 'If you want to understand how behavior occurs, one of the best ways to gain information is to simply observe the behavior in its natural context.']
['What does the observation do?', 'However, people might change their behavior in unexpected ways if they know they are being observed.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'As an example, imagine that your professor asks everyone in your class to raise their hand if they always wash their hands after using the restroom.']

['What is the most common objection people have to a question?', 'This is very similar to the phenomenon mentioned earlier in this chapter: many individuals do not feel comfortable answering a question honestly.']
["What are the reasons they don't answer honestly?", 'But if we are committed to finding out the facts about hand washing, we have other options available to us.']

['What would the example you are going to give us involve the bathroom?', 'Suppose we send a classmate into the restroom to actually watch whether everyone washes their hands after using the restroom.']

['How should a classmate be watching the bathroom?', 'We want our researcher to be inconspicuous—perhaps standing at one of the sinks pretending to put in contact lenses while secretly recording the relevant information.']
['What do you mean by pretending to put in contact lenses?', 'This type of observational study is called naturalistic observation: observing behavior in its natural setting.']

['What was the next example you provided?', 'To better understand peer exclusion, Suzanne Fanger collaborated with colleagues at the University of Texas to observe the behavior of preschool children on a playground.']
['How did they observe the children?', 'They equipped a few of the children with wireless microphones (which the children quickly forgot about) and observed while taking notes from a distance.']

['How long did they watch the children?', 'Also, the children in that particular preschool (a “laboratory preschool”) were accustomed to having observers on the playground (Fanger, Frankel, & Hazen, 2012).']
['How is this conducted?', 'It is critical that the observer be as unobtrusive and as inconspicuous as possible: when people know they are being watched, they are less likely to behave naturally.']
['What are some of the questions you might ask yourself?', 'If you have any doubt about this, ask yourself how your driving behavior might differ in two situations:']

['What are these two situations?', 'In the first situation, you are driving down a deserted highway during the middle of the day; in the second situation, you are being followed by a police car down the same deserted highway.']
['Can you tell me more about Naturalistic Observation?', 'It should be pointed out that naturalistic observation is not limited to research involving humans.']

['Can you tell me more about naturalistic observation?', 'Indeed, some of the best-known examples of naturalistic observation involve researchers going into the field to observe various kinds of animals in their own environments.']
['What do they observe?', 'As with human studies, the researchers maintain their distance and avoid interfering with the animal subjects so as not to influence their natural behaviors.']
['What kind of interactions does this study examine?', 'Scientists have used this technique to study social hierarchies and interactions among animals ranging from ground squirrels to gorillas.']
['What do these studies show?', 'The information provided by these studies is invaluable in understanding how those animals organize socially and communicate with one another.']
['What are some examples of chimpanzees?', 'The anthropologist Jane Goodall, for example, spent nearly five decades observing the behavior of chimpanzees in Africa.']

['What did Goodall observe?', 'As an illustration of the types of concerns that a researcher might encounter in naturalistic observation, some scientists criticized Goodall for giving the chimps names instead of referring to them by numbers—using names was thought to undermine the emotional detachment required for the objectivity of the study (McKie, 2010).']

['What is the greatest benefit of naturalistic observation?', 'The greatest benefit of naturalistic observation is the validity, or accuracy, of information collected unobtrusively in a natural setting.']

['What is more important in the description of ecological validity?', 'Having individuals behave as they normally would in a given situation means that we have a higher degree of ecological validity, or realism, than we might achieve with other research approaches.']
['What is the greatest benefit of unobtrusive observations?', 'Therefore, our ability to generalize the findings of the research to real-world situations is enhanced.']
['How do we know if they will change their behavior?', 'If done correctly, we need not worry about people or animals modifying their behavior simply because they are being observed.']
['Do you think reality shows are really human?', 'Sometimes, people may assume that reality programs give us a glimpse into authentic human behavior.']

['Are there any problems with this method?', 'However, the principle of inconspicuous observation is violated as reality stars are followed by camera crews and are interviewed on camera for personal confessionals.']
['What does this violate?', 'Given that environment, we must doubt how natural and realistic their behaviors are.']
['What is a downside to naturalistic observation?', 'The major downside of naturalistic observation is that they are often difficult to set up and control.']
['What is the benefit of realistic data?', 'The benefit of realistic data comes at a cost.']
['How is observing animal behavior difficult?', 'As a researcher you have no control of when (or if) you have behavior to observe.']

['What other factors contribute to the difficult task of naturalistic observation?', 'In addition, this type of observational research often requires significant investments of time, money, and a good dose of luck.']
['What is included in the chapter?', 'Sometimes studies involve structured observation.']
['What happens during this structured observation?', 'In these cases, people are observed while engaging in set, specific tasks.']

['What are some examples of structured observation?', 'An excellent example of structured observation comes from Strange Situation by Mary Ainsworth (you will read more about this in the chapter on lifespan development).']
['What is the Strange Situation?', 'The Strange Situation is a procedure used to evaluate attachment styles that exist between an infant and caregiver.']
['What happens in that scenario?', 'In this scenario, caregivers bring their infants into a room filled with toys.']

['What happens after the caregiver leaves the room?', 'The Strange Situation involves a number of phases, including a stranger coming into the room, the caregiver leaving the room, and the caregiver’s return to the room.']

['What is the infant’s behavior closely monitored at each phase, but it is the behavior of the infant upon being reunited with the caregiver that is most telling in terms of characterizing the infant’s attachment style with the caregiver?', 'The infant’s behavior is closely monitored at each phase, but it is the behavior of the infant upon being reunited with the caregiver that is most telling in terms of characterizing the infant’s attachment style with the caregiver.']
['What are the other problems in observational research?', 'Another potential problem in observational research is observer bias.']

['What is observer bias?', 'Generally, people who act as observers are closely involved in the research project and may unconsciously skew their observations to fit their research goals or expectations.']

['how can we protect ourselves from this?', 'To protect against this type of bias, researchers should have clear criteria established for the types of behaviors recorded and how those behaviors should be classified.']

['what else does this include?', 'In addition, researchers often compare observations of the same event by multiple observers, in order to test inter-rater reliability: a measure of reliability that assesses the consistency of observations by different observers.']
['What do psychologists do with surveys?', 'Often, psychologists develop surveys as a means of gathering data.']

['What are some examples of surveys?', 'Surveys are lists of questions to be answered by research participants, and can be delivered as paper-and-pencil questionnaires, administered electronically, or conducted verbally.']

['Why does it take a short time to administer the survey?', 'Generally, the survey itself can be completed in a short time, and the ease of administering a survey makes it easy to collect data from a large number of people.']
['What kind of research does it involve?', 'Surveys allow researchers to gather data from larger samples than may be afforded by other research methods.']
['What is a sample?', 'A sample is a subset of individuals selected from a population, which is the overall group of individuals that the researchers are interested in.']
['What do the researchers study?', 'Researchers study the sample and seek to generalize their findings to the population.']
['What do researchers do to begin this process?', 'Generally, researchers will begin this process by calculating various measures of central tendency from the data they have collected.']
['What is an overall summary of what a typical response looks like?', 'These measures provide an overall summary of what a typical response looks like.']
['What are the three measures of central tendency?', 'There are three measures of central tendency: mode, median, and mean.']

['What are the three types of data points?', 'The mode is the most frequently occurring response, the median lies at the middle of a given data set, and the mean is the arithmetic average of all data points.']

['What does the mean tell?', 'Means tend to be most useful in conducting additional analyses like those described below; however, means are very sensitive to the effects of outliers, and so one must be aware of those effects when making assessments of what measures of central tendency tell us about a data set in question.']
['What are the strengths and weaknesses of a survey?', 'There is both strength and weakness of the survey in comparison to case studies.']
['What are the advantages of using surveys?', 'By using surveys, we can collect information from a larger sample of people.']
['Why is it important to have a larger sample size?', 'A larger sample is better able to reflect the actual diversity of the population, thus allowing better generalizability.']

['How is that determined?', 'Therefore, if our sample is sufficiently large and diverse, we can assume that the data we collect from the survey can be generalized to the larger population with more certainty than the information collected through a case study.']

['What are the strengths of a survey?', 'However, given the greater number of people involved, we are not able to collect the same depth of information on each person that would be collected in a case study.']
['What is the weakness of surveys?', "Another potential weakness of surveys is something we touched on earlier in this chapter: People don't always give accurate responses."]
['What happens to a person when they do not give accurate responses?', 'They may lie, misremember, or answer questions in a way that they think makes them look good.']
['Can you give me an example of this?', 'For example, people may report drinking less alcohol than is actually the case.']
['What can surveys do?', 'Any number of research questions can be answered through the use of surveys.']

['What are some examples you use?', 'One real-world example is the research conducted by Jenkins, Ruppel, Kizer, Yehl, and Griffin (2012) about the backlash against the US Arab-American community following the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001.']

['What was the purpose of this survey?', 'Jenkins and colleagues wanted to determine to what extent these negative attitudes toward Arab-Americans still existed nearly a decade after the attacks occurred.']

['What questions did they ask?', 'In one study, 140 research participants filled out a survey with 10 questions, including questions asking directly about the participant’s overt prejudicial attitudes toward people of various ethnicities.']

['What other questions did they ask?', 'The survey also asked indirect questions about how likely the participant would be to interact with a person of a given ethnicity in a variety of settings (such as, “How likely do you think it is that you would introduce yourself to a person of Arab-American descent?”).']
['What did the survey find?', 'The results of the research suggested that participants were unwilling to report prejudicial attitudes toward any ethnic group.']

['How did the survey effect social behavior?', 'However, there were significant differences between their pattern of responses to questions about social interaction with Arab-Americans compared to other ethnic groups: they indicated less willingness for social interaction with Arab-Americans compared to the other ethnic groups.']

['Why were they less willing?', 'This suggested that the participants harbored subtle forms of prejudice against Arab-Americans, despite their assertions that this was not the case (Jenkins et al., 2012).']
['What do you learn about the single research participant?', 'Some researchers gain access to large amounts of data without interacting with a single research participant.']
['What do they use instead of a library?', 'Instead, they use existing records to answer various research questions.']
['What do you learn about their research approach?', 'This type of research approach is known as archival research.']
['What is archival research?', 'Archival research relies on looking at past records or data sets to look for interesting patterns or relationships.']

['What are some of the methods?', 'For example, a researcher might access the academic records of all individuals who enrolled in college within the past ten years and calculate how long it took them to complete their degrees, as well as course loads, grades, and extracurricular involvement.']

['What is the purpose of this research?', 'Archival research could provide important information about who is most likely to complete their education, and it could help identify important risk factors for struggling students.']
['What are some of the important distinctions between this and other research methods?', 'In comparing archival research to other research methods, there are several important distinctions.']
['What are the distinctions between archival research and field research?', 'For one, the researcher employing archival research never directly interacts with research participants.']
['How can archival research be beneficial to the researcher?', 'Therefore, the investment of time and money to collect data is considerably less with archival research.']
['What else do researchers have no control over?', 'Additionally, researchers have no control over what information was originally collected.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Therefore, research questions have to be tailored so they can be answered within the structure of the existing data sets.']
['What else?', 'There is also no guarantee of consistency between the records from one source to another, which might make comparing and contrasting different data sets problematic.']
['How does this relate to human development?', 'Sometimes we want to see how people change over time, as in studies of human development and lifespan.']
['How does that relate to research?', 'When we test the same group of individuals repeatedly over an extended period of time, we are conducting longitudinal research.']

['What is the research design in which data-gathering is administered repeatedly over an extended period of time?', 'Longitudinal research is a research design in which data-gathering is administered repeatedly over an extended period of time.']
['What is an example of research?', 'For example, we may survey a group of individuals about their dietary habits at age 20, retest them a decade later at age 30, and then again at age 40.']
['Which is another approach to longitudinal research?', 'Another approach is cross-sectional research.']
['What is the difference between cross sectional research and longitudinal research?', 'In cross-sectional research, a researcher compares multiple segments of the population at the same time.']
['How does cross-sectional research compare multiple segments?', 'Using the dietary habits example above, the researcher might directly compare different groups of people by age.']

['How would he do that?', 'Instead of studying a group of people for 20 years to see how their dietary habits changed from decade to decade, the researcher would study a group of 20-year-old individuals and compare them to a group of 30-year-old individuals and a group of 40-year-old individuals.']

['What else is important about cross-sectional research?', 'While cross-sectional research requires a shorter-term investment, it is also limited by differences that exist between the different generations (or cohorts) that have nothing to do with age per se, but rather reflect the social and cultural experiences of different generations of individuals make them different from one another.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'To illustrate this concept, consider the following survey findings.']
['What are the survey findings?', 'In recent years there has been significant growth in the popular support of same-sex marriage.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Many studies on this topic break down survey participants into different age groups.']
['Are older people more supportive of same-sex marriage than younger people?', 'In general, younger people are more supportive of same-sex marriage than are those who are older (Jones, 2013).']

['What is longitudinal research?', 'Longitudinal research is a powerful approach because the same individuals are involved in the research project over time, which means that the researchers need to be less concerned with differences among cohorts affecting the results of their study.']
['What are the studies for?', 'Often longitudinal studies are employed when researching various diseases in an effort to understand particular risk factors.']
['What kind of studies are these?', 'Such studies often involve tens of thousands of individuals who are followed for several decades.']

['What is an advantage of these studies?', 'Given the enormous number of people involved in these studies, researchers can feel confident that their findings can be generalized to the larger population.']

['What is the biggest longitudinal study?', 'The Cancer Prevention Study-3 (CPS-3) is one of a series of longitudinal studies sponsored by the American Cancer Society aimed at determining predictive risk factors associated with cancer.']

['What information do participants give?', 'When participants enter the study, they complete a survey about their lives and family histories, providing information on factors that might cause or prevent the development of cancer.']
['When do the participants receive additional surveys?', 'Then every few years the participants receive additional surveys to complete.']
['How long do the studies last?', 'In the end, hundreds of thousands of participants will be tracked over 20 years to determine which of them develop cancer and which do not.']
['What can we learn from the study?', 'Clearly, this type of research is important and potentially very informative.']

['What are some examples of the links between increased rates of cancer and smoking?', 'For instance, earlier longitudinal studies sponsored by the American Cancer Society provided some of the first scientific demonstrations of the now well-established links between increased rates of cancer and smoking (American Cancer Society, n.d.).']
['What is the difference between longitudinal research and cross-sectional research?', 'As with any research strategy, longitudinal research is not without limitations.']
['What are some limitations of these studies?', 'For one, these studies require an incredible time investment by the researcher and research participants.']
['Are there any other restrictions?', 'Given that some longitudinal studies take years, if not decades, to complete, the results will not be known for a considerable period of time.']
['Are there any other restrictions?', 'In addition to the time demands, these studies also require a substantial financial investment.']
['What are the other restrictions that can be a problem for researchers?', 'Many researchers are unable to commit the resources necessary to see a longitudinal project through to the end.']
['What can be problematic about research?', 'Research participants must also be willing to continue their participation for an extended period of time, and this can be problematic.']
['What other problems can this lead to?', 'People move, get married and take new names, get ill, and eventually die.']
['Do we need to be ready for these?', 'Even without significant life changes, some people may simply choose to discontinue their participation in the project.']

['What happens in this case?', 'As a result, the attrition rates, or reduction in the number of research participants due to dropouts, in longitudinal studies are quite high and increases over the course of a project.']

['What do researchers do with this information?', 'For this reason, researchers using this approach typically recruit many participants fully expecting that a substantial number will drop out before the end.']
['What happens after this?', 'As the study progresses, they continually check whether the sample still represents the larger population, and make adjustments as necessary.']

['What is the relationship between ice cream and crime?', 'There is no question that a relationship exists between ice cream and crime (e.g., Harper, 2013), but it would be pretty foolish to decide that one thing actually caused the other to occur.']
['Did you find a positive correlation between both the data?', 'It is much more likely that both ice cream sales and crime rates are related to the temperature outside.']

['What is the most significant fact that you found?', 'When the temperature is warm, there are lots of people out of their houses, interacting with each other, getting annoyed with one another, and sometimes committing crimes.']
['What else did you find?', 'Also, when it is warm outside, we are more likely to seek a cool treat like ice cream.']

['What does correlation mean?', 'Correlation means that there is a relationship between two or more variables (such as ice cream consumption and crime), but this relationship does not necessarily imply cause and effect.']
['What does it mean when two variables are correlated?', 'When two variables are correlated, it simply means that as one variable changes, so does the other.']
['How do we measure correlation?', 'We can measure correlation by calculating a statistic known as a correlation coefficient.']
['What does a correlation coefficient mean?', 'A correlation coefficient is a number from -1 to +1 that indicates the strength and direction of the relationship between variables.']
['What is the correlation coefficient represented by?', 'The correlation coefficient is usually represented by the letter r.']
['What does the number portion of the correlation coefficient indicate?', 'The number portion of the correlation coefficient indicates the strength of the relationship.']

['What is the significance of a 1 in a relationship?', 'The closer the number is to 1 (be it negative or positive), the more strongly related the variables are, and the more predictable changes in one variable will be as the other variable changes.']
['What is the significance of a zero in a relationship?', 'The closer the number is to zero, the weaker the relationship, and the less predictable the relationships between the variables becomes.']
['How does a higher number equal a stronger relationship?', 'For instance, a correlation coefficient of 0.9 indicates a far stronger relationship than a correlation coefficient of 0.3.']
['If the variables are not related to one another at all, what is 0?', 'If the variables are not related to one another at all, the correlation coefficient is 0.']

['What is an example of two variables that we might expect to have no relationship to each other?', 'The example above about ice cream and crime is an example of two variables that we might expect to have no relationship to each other.']
['What is the sign of the correlation coefficient?', 'The sign—positive or negative—of the correlation coefficient indicates the direction of the relationship.']
['What does a positive correlation mean?', 'A positive correlation means that the variables move in the same direction.']

['What does it mean that the variables move in the same direction?', 'Put another way, it means that as one variable increases so does the other, and conversely, when one variable decreases so does the other.']
['What does a negative correlation mean?', 'A negative correlation means that the variables move in opposite directions.']
['what does a negative correlation mean?', 'If two variables are negatively correlated, a decrease in one variable is associated with an increase in the other and vice versa.']
['What do you think it is correlated with?', 'The example of ice cream and crime rates is a positive correlation because both variables increase when temperatures are warmer.']

['Did they mention anything else?', 'Other examples of positive correlations are the relationship between an individual’s height and weight or the relationship between a person’s age and number of wrinkles.']

['Did they mention anything else?', 'One might expect a negative correlation to exist between someone’s tiredness during the day and the number of hours they slept the previous night: the amount of sleep decreases as the feelings of tiredness increase.']

['What did they find?', 'In a real-world example of negative correlation, student researchers at the University of Minnesota found a weak negative correlation (r = -0.29) between the average number of days per week that students got fewer than 5 hours of sleep and their GPA (Lowry, Dean, & Manders, 2010).']
['What do you think about negative correlations?', 'Keep in mind that a negative correlation is not the same as no correlation.']
['Is there a positive correlation between hours of sleep and shoe size?', 'For example, we would probably find no correlation between hours of sleep and shoe size.']
['What do correlations have to do with college admission?', 'As mentioned earlier, correlations have predictive value.']
['Are there any specific questions you would like me to ask?', 'Imagine that you are on the admissions committee of a major university.']

['What do you do when you are faced with a huge number of applications?', 'You are faced with a huge number of applications, but you are able to accommodate only a small percentage of the applicant pool.']

['Do you have any specific ways of determining which applicants are most likely to succeed?', 'You might try to correlate your current students’ college GPA with their scores on standardized tests like the SAT or ACT.']

['What would happen if you did that?', 'By observing which correlations were strongest for your current students, you could use this information to predict relative success of those students who have applied for admission into the university.']

['What is the main reason correlational research is important?', 'Correlational research is useful because it allows us to discover the strength and direction of relationships that exist between two variables.']
['What is limited?', 'However, correlation is limited because establishing the existence of a relationship tells us little about cause and effect.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'While variables are sometimes correlated because one does cause the other, it could also be that some other factor, a confounding variable, is actually causing the systematic movement in our variables of interest.']

['What is an example of a confounding variable?', 'In the ice cream/crime rate example mentioned earlier, temperature is a confounding variable that could account for the relationship between the two variables.']

['What is the meaning of correlation does not indicate causality?', 'Even when we cannot point to clear confounding variables, we should not assume that a correlation between two variables implies that one variable causes changes in another.']
['Why is this not always clear?', 'This can be frustrating when a cause-and-effect relationship seems clear and intuitive.']

['What are some examples of this?', 'Think back to our discussion of the research done by the American Cancer Society and how their research projects were some of the first demonstrations of the link between smoking and cancer.']

['What is the best example of a correlational research?', 'It seems reasonable to assume that smoking causes cancer, but if we were limited to correlational research, we would be overstepping our bounds by making this assumption.']
['What are some important aspects of the study material?', 'Unfortunately, people mistakenly make claims of causation as a function of correlations all the time.']
['What are some places where they make these claims?', 'Such claims are especially common in advertisements and news stories.']

['What is the example?', 'For example, recent research found that people who eat cereal on a regular basis achieve healthier weights than those who rarely eat cereal (Frantzen, Treviño, Echon, Garcia-Dominic, & DiMarco, 2013; Barton et al., 2005).']
['What else did the research show?', 'Guess how the cereal companies report this finding.']

['What is the major limitation of correlational research?', 'While correlational research is invaluable in identifying relationships among variables, a major limitation is the inability to establish causality.']

['What is the reason why psychologists conduct experiments?', 'Psychologists want to make statements about cause and effect, but the only way to do that is to conduct an experiment to answer a research question.']

['How do scientists conduct an experiment?', 'The next section describes how scientific experiments incorporate methods that eliminate, or control for, alternative explanations, which allow researchers to explore how changes in one variable cause changes in another variable.']

['What is the consequence of making erroneous cause-and-effect statements based on correlational research?', 'The temptation to make erroneous cause-and-effect statements based on correlational research is not the only way we tend to misinterpret data.']
['What can happen if we misinterpret the data?', 'We also tend to make the mistake of illusory correlations, especially with unsystematic observations.']

['What is the definition of illusory correlations?', 'Illusory correlations, or false correlations, occur when people believe that relationships exist between two things when no such relationship exists.']
['What is an example of an illusory correlation?', 'One well-known illusory correlation is the supposed effect that the moon’s phases have on human behavior.']

['What effect does the moon have on human behavior?', 'Many people passionately assert that human behavior is affected by the phase of the moon, and specifically, that people act strangely when the moon is full.']
["What is the moon's powerful influence on our planet?", 'There is no denying that the moon exerts a powerful influence on our planet.']
['What is tightly tied to the gravitational forces of the moon?', 'The ebb and flow of the ocean’s tides are tightly tied to the gravitational forces of the moon.']
['what is many people believe?', 'Many people believe, therefore, that it is logical that we are affected by the moon as well.']
['What is largely made up of?', 'After all, our bodies are largely made up of water.']

['what is rotton and kelly?', 'A meta-analysis of nearly 40 studies consistently demonstrated, however, that the relationship between the moon and our behavior does not exist (Rotton & Kelly, 1985).']
['What is odd behavior?', 'While we may pay more attention to odd behavior during the full phase of the moon, the rates of odd behavior remain constant throughout the lunar cycle.']
['What do you think about the content of this document?', 'Often we read or hear about them and simply accept the information as valid.']

['What is confirmation bias?', 'Or, we have a hunch about how something works and then look for evidence to support that hunch, ignoring evidence that would tell us our hunch is false; this is known as confirmation bias.']

['What is the most important thing to know about this topic?', 'Other times, we find illusory correlations based on the information that comes most easily to mind, even if that information is severely limited.']

['What can you tell me about illusory correlations?', 'And while we may feel confident that we can use these relationships to better understand and predict the world around us, illusory correlations can have significant drawbacks.']

['What are some examples of illusory correlations?', 'For example, research suggests that illusory correlations—in which certain behaviors are inaccurately attributed to certain groups—are involved in the formation of prejudicial attitudes that can ultimately lead to discriminatory behavior (Fiedler, 2004).']

['What is the only way to establish that there is a cause-and-effect relationship between two variables?', 'As you’ve learned, the only way to establish that there is a cause-and-effect relationship between two variables is to conduct a scientific experiment.']
['What does experiment mean in the scientific context?', 'Experiment has a different meaning in the scientific context than in everyday life.']

['What is the difference in usage between experimenting and experimenting with something?', 'In everyday conversation, we often use it to describe trying something for the first time, such as experimenting with a new hair style or a new food.']
['How is the scientific context different from the everyday usage?', 'However, in the scientific context, an experiment has precise requirements for design and implementation.']
['What is the purpose of an experiment?', 'In order to conduct an experiment, a researcher must have a specific hypothesis to be tested.']
["What's the importance of hypotheses?", 'As you’ve learned, hypotheses can be formulated either through direct observation of the real world or after careful review of previous research.']

['What is a hypothesis?', 'For example, if you think that the use of technology in the classroom has negative impacts on learning, then you have basically formulated a hypothesis—namely, that the use of technology in the classroom should be limited because it decreases learning.']

['What other examples do you have of how technology can affect learning?', 'You may have noticed that your classmates who take notes on their laptops perform at lower levels on class exams than those who take notes by hand, or those who receive a lesson via a computer program versus via an in-person teacher have different levels of performance when tested.']

['What are the questions that can be asked?', 'These sorts of personal observations are what often lead us to formulate a specific hypothesis, but we cannot use limited personal observations and anecdotal evidence to rigorously test our hypothesis.']
['What do we need to do before we rigorously test our hypothesis?', 'Instead, to find out if real-world data supports our hypothesis, we have to conduct an experiment.']
['What is the most basic experimental design?', 'The most basic experimental design involves two groups: the experimental group and the control group.']
['What are the two groups designed to be?', 'The two groups are designed to be the same except for one difference— experimental manipulation.']

['What is the difference between the experimental and control groups?', 'The experimental group gets the experimental manipulation—that is, the treatment or variable being tested (in this case, the use of technology)—and the control group does not.']

['What can you learn about the difference between them?', 'Since experimental manipulation is the only difference between the experimental and control groups, we can be sure that any differences between the two are due to experimental manipulation rather than chance.']

['What was the main idea of the passage?', 'In our example of how the use of technology should be limited in the classroom, we have the experimental group learn algebra using a computer program and then test their learning.']
['What happened to our control group?', 'We measure the learning in our control group after they are taught algebra by a teacher in a traditional classroom.']

['What is important for the control group to be treated similarly to the experimental group, with the exception that the control group does not receive the experimental manipulation?', 'It is important for the control group to be treated similarly to the experimental group, with the exception that the control group does not receive the experimental manipulation.']
['What do we have to specifically do in our Designing an Experiment?', 'We also need to precisely define, or operationalize, how we measure learning of algebra.']

['What is the definition of an operational definition?', 'An operational definition is a precise description of our variables, and it is important in allowing others to understand exactly how and what a researcher measures in a particular experiment.']

['How do we operationalize learning?', 'In operationalizing learning, we might choose to look at performance on a test covering the material on which the individuals were taught by the teacher or the computer program.']
['Do we need a separate test for each subject?', 'We might also ask our participants to summarize the information that was just presented in some way.']

['What is the most important thing to consider when deciding what to write about?', 'Whatever we determine, it is important that we operationalize learning in such a way that anyone who hears about our study for the first time knows exactly what we mean by learning.']
['Why is this important?', 'This aids peoples’ ability to interpret our data as well as their capacity to repeat our experiment should they choose to do so.']

['What is the next step in the experiment?', 'Once we have operationalized what is considered use of technology and what is considered learning in our experiment participants, we need to establish how we will run our experiment.']

['How do we determine how much time participants spend learning the experimental technology?', 'In this case, we might have participants spend 45 minutes learning algebra (either through a computer program or with an in-person math teacher) and then give them a test on the material covered during the 45 minutes.']

['What are some important things to know about experimenter bias?', 'Ideally, the people who score the tests are unaware of who was assigned to the experimental or control group, in order to control for experimenter bias.']
['What is experimenter bias?', 'Experimenter bias refers to the possibility that a researcher’s expectations might skew the results of the study.']

['What is the next piece of information?', 'Remember, conducting an experiment requires a lot of planning, and the people involved in the research project have a vested interest in supporting their hypotheses.']

['What is known about experimenter bias?', 'If the observers knew which child was in which group, it might influence how they interpret ambiguous responses, such as sloppy handwriting or minor computational mistakes.']
['What is the next important information?', 'By being blind to which child is in which group, we protect against those biases.']

['What is the difference between a double-blind study and a single-blind study?', 'This situation is a single-blind study, meaning that one of the groups (participants) are unaware as to which group they are in (experiment or control group) while the researcher who developed the experiment knows which participants are in each group.']
['What are double-blind studies?', 'In a double-blind study, both the researchers and the participants are blind to group assignments.']
['Why is this important?', 'Because by doing so, we can control for both experimenter and participant expectations.']
['What is the placebo effect?', 'If you are familiar with the phrase placebo effect, you already have some idea as to why this is an important consideration.']
['What is the placebo effect?', "The placebo effect occurs when people's expectations or beliefs influence or determine their experience in a given situation."]
['How can this effect be used?', 'In other words, simply expecting something to happen can actually make it happen.']
['What is the placebo effect?', 'The placebo effect is commonly described in terms of testing the effectiveness of a new medication.']
['How do we use the placebo effect in an experiment?', 'Imagine that you work in a pharmaceutical company, and you think you have a new drug that is effective in treating depression.']
['What do you do next?', 'To demonstrate that your medication is effective, you run an experiment with two groups:']
['What are the two groups?', 'The experimental group receives the medication, and the control group does not.']
['What happens after the experiment is over?', 'But you don’t want participants to know whether they received the drug or not.']
['What is an experiment?', 'Imagine that you are a participant in this study, and you have just taken a pill that you think will improve your mood.']

['How would you feel afterwards?', 'Because you expect the pill to have an effect, you might feel better simply because you took the pill and not because of any drug actually contained in the pill—this is the placebo effect.']

["What are the control group's expectations?", 'To make sure that any effects on mood are due to the drug and not due to expectations, the control group receives a placebo (in this case a sugar pill).']
["What are the experimenter's expectations?", 'Now everyone gets a pill, and once again neither the researcher nor the experimental participants know who got the drug and who got the sugar pill.']

['What is the purpose of this experiment?', 'Any differences in mood between the experimental and control groups can now be attributed to the drug itself rather than to experimenter bias or participant expectations.']
['In a research experiment, what do independent and dependent variables mean?', 'In a research experiment, we strive to study whether changes in one thing cause changes in another.']

['What are the two important variables in any experimental study?', 'To achieve this, we must pay attention to two important variables, or things that can be changed, in any experimental study: the independent variable and the dependent variable.']
['What is an independent variable?', 'An independent variable is manipulated or controlled by the experimenter.']
['What are the variables designed for?', 'In a well-designed experimental study, the independent variable is the only important difference between the experimental and control groups.']
['What does an independent variable mean?', 'In our example of how technology use in the classroom affects learning, the independent variable is the type of learning by participants in the study.']

['What is the term for the variable that is measured to see how much effect the independent variable had?', 'A dependent variable is what the researcher measures to see how much effect the independent variable had.']
['What does the researcher measure?', 'In our example, the dependent variable is the learning exhibited by our participants.']
['We expect that the dependent variable will change what?', 'We expect that the dependent variable will change as a function of the independent variable.']
['What is the dependent variable in a scientific experiment?', 'In other words, the dependent variable depends on the independent variable.']

['What are some good ways to think about the relationship between the independent and dependent variables?', 'A good way to think about the relationship between the independent and dependent variables is with this question:']
['What are the steps in conducting a study?', 'Now that our study is designed, we need to obtain a sample of individuals to include in our experiment.']
['What is the best method to use to determine the best method for a study?', 'Our study involves human participants so we need to determine who to include.']

['What do participants do?', 'Participants are the subjects of psychological research, and as the name implies, individuals who are involved in psychological research actively participate in the process.']
['What do we want them to do?', 'Often, psychological research projects rely on college students to serve as participants.']
['Are there any studies about this?', 'In fact, the vast majority of research in psychology subfields has historically involved students as research participants (Sears, 1986; Arnett, 2008).']
['What are some differences between college students and the rest of society?', 'College students tend to be younger, more educated, more liberal, and less diverse than the general population.']

['What is the problem with using students as test subjects?', 'Although using students as test subjects is an accepted practice, relying on such a limited pool of research participants can be problematic because it is difficult to generalize findings to the larger population.']
['What were the basic questions we should ask in order to study it?', 'Our hypothetical experiment involves high school students, and we must first generate a sample of students.']
['Why do we need to do that?', 'Samples are used because populations are usually too large to reasonably involve every member in our particular experiment.']
['What are the different types of samples?', 'If possible, we should use a random sample (there are other types of samples, but for the purposes of this chapter, we will focus on random samples).']
['What is a random sample?', 'A random sample is a subset of a larger population in which every member of the population has an equal chance of being selected.']

['What is the reason for using random samples?', 'Random samples are preferred because if the sample is large enough we can be reasonably sure that the participating individuals are representative of the larger population.']

['What does representative mean?', 'This means that the percentages of characteristics in the sample—sex, ethnicity, socioeconomic level, and any other characteristics that might affect the results—are close to those percentages in the larger population.']
['What is the population of interest?', 'In our example, let’s say we decide our population of interest is algebra students.']

['How many algebra students are there in a particular city?', 'But all algebra students is a very large population, so we need to be more specific; instead we might say our population of interest is all algebra students in a particular city.']
['What should we include in our class?', 'We should include students from various income brackets, family situations, races, ethnicities, religions, and geographic areas of town.']

['How many students should we select?', 'With this more manageable population, we can work with the local schools in selecting a random sample of around 200 algebra students who we want to participate in our experiment.']

['What are the most important points in this section?', 'In summary, because we cannot test all of the algebra students in a city, we want to find a group of about 200 that reflects the composition of that city.']
['What is important about a representative group?', 'With a representative group, we can generalize our findings to the larger population without fear of our sample being biased in some way.']

['What is the next step of the experimental process?', 'Now that we have a sample, the next step of the experimental process is to split the participants into experimental and control groups through random assignment.']
['What happens in random assignment?', 'With random assignment, all participants have an equal chance of being assigned to either group.']

['What type of software is used to randomly assign?', 'There is statistical software that will randomly assign each of the algebra students in the sample to either the experimental or the control group.']
['What is a problem with random assignment?', 'Random assignment is critical for sound experimental design.']

['What happens when there are systematic differences between groups?', 'With sufficiently large samples, random assignment makes it unlikely that there are systematic differences between the groups.']

['What kinds of groups is this good for?', 'So, for instance, it would be very unlikely that we would get one group composed entirely of males, a given ethnic identity, or a given religious ideology.']

['Why is this important?', 'This is important because if the groups were systematically different before the experiment began, we would not know the origin of any differences we find between the groups:']

['How do you explain the origin of the differences between groups?', 'Random assignment allows us to assume that any differences observed between experimental and control groups result from the manipulation of the independent variable.']
['What are the issues with experiments?', 'While experiments allow scientists to make cause-and-effect claims, they are not without problems.']

['What do true experiments require the experimenter to manipulate?', 'True experiments require the experimenter to manipulate an independent variable, and that can complicate many questions that psychologists might want to address.']
['How does this complicate questions?', 'For instance, imagine that you want to know what effect sex (the independent variable) has on spatial memory (the dependent variable).']

['What can you do to find out this information?', 'Although you can certainly look for differences between males and females on a task that taps into spatial memory, you cannot directly control a person’s sex.']
['What does this mean for the research?', 'We categorize this type of research approach as quasi-experimental and recognize that we cannot make cause-and-effect claims in these circumstances.']
['What are some of the topics in this document?', 'Experimenters are also limited by ethical constraints.']

['What does it tell us about the restrictions?', 'For instance, you would not be able to conduct an experiment designed to determine if experiencing abuse as a child leads to lower levels of self-esteem among adults.']

['Why is this not permitted?', 'To conduct such an experiment, you would need to randomly assign some experimental participants to a group that receives abuse, and that experiment would be unethical.']

['What are two groups?', 'Once data is collected from both the experimental and the control groups, a statistical analysis is conducted to find out if there are meaningful differences between the two groups.']
['What is the purpose of statistical analysis?', 'A statistical analysis determines how likely any difference found is due to chance (and thus not meaningful).']

['What can we learn about the placebo pill?', 'For example, if an experiment is done on the effectiveness of a nutritional supplement, and those taking a placebo pill (and not the supplement) have the same result as those taking the supplement, then the experiment has shown that the nutritional supplement is not effective.']

['What do psychologists consider to be statistically significant?', 'Generally, psychologists consider differences to be statistically significant if there is less than a five percent chance of observing them if the groups did not actually differ from one another.']
['What can we learn about their findings?', 'Stated another way, psychologists want to limit the chances of making “false positive” claims to five percent or less.']

['What is the greatest strength of experiments?', 'The greatest strength of experiments is the ability to assert that any significant differences in the findings are caused by the independent variable.']

['What can we do with this information?', 'This occurs because random selection, random assignment, and a design that limits the effects of both experimenter bias and participant expectancy should create groups that are similar in composition and treatment.']
['What can we do next?', 'Therefore, any difference between the groups is attributable to the independent variable, and now we can finally make a causal statement.']

['What are the results of watching a violent television program?', 'If we find that watching a violent television program results in more violent behavior than watching a nonviolent program, we can safely say that watching violent television programs causes an increase in the display of violent behavior.']
['What is the purpose of a report?', 'When psychologists complete a research project, they generally want to share their findings with other scientists.']
['What kind of report is a scientific report?', 'The American Psychological Association (APA) publishes a manual detailing how to write a paper for submission to scientific journals.']

['What audience do scientific journals target?', 'Unlike an article that might be published in a magazine like Psychology Today, which targets a general audience with an interest in psychology, scientific journals generally publish peer-reviewed journal articles aimed at an audience of professionals and scholars who are actively involved in research themselves.']
['What is peer-review?', 'A peer-reviewed journal article is read by several other scientists (generally anonymously) with expertise in the subject matter.']
['What happens after peer-review?', 'These peer reviewers provide feedback—to both the author and the journal editor—regarding the quality of the draft.']
