['What do peer reviewers look for?', 'Peer reviewers look for a strong rationale for the research being described, a clear description of how the research was conducted, and evidence that the research was conducted in an ethical manner.']
['What else do they look for?', "They also look for flaws in the study's design, methods, and statistical analyses."]
['What else do they check?', 'They check that the conclusions drawn by the authors seem reasonable given the observations made during the research.']
['How else do they comment?', 'Peer reviewers also comment on how valuable the research is in advancing the discipline’s knowledge.']

['What does peer review do?', 'This helps prevent unnecessary duplication of research findings in the scientific literature and, to some extent, ensures that each research article provides new information.']

['What happens to the article after review?', 'Ultimately, the journal editor will compile all of the peer reviewer feedback and determine whether the article will be published in its current state (a rare occurrence), published with revisions, or not accepted for publication.']
['What does peer review do for research?', 'Peer review provides some degree of quality control for psychological research.']
['What can peer review improve?', 'Poorly conceived or executed studies can be weeded out, and even well-designed research can be improved by the revisions suggested.']

['What other benefits does peer review have?', 'Peer review also ensures that the research is described clearly enough to allow other scientists to replicate it, meaning they can repeat the experiment using different samples to determine reliability.']
['What does replication involve?', 'Sometimes replications involve additional measures that expand on the original finding.']

['What does replication serve to provide more evidence to support the original research findings?', 'In any case, each replication serves to provide more evidence to support the original research findings.']

['What is significant about successful replications of published research?', 'Successful replications of published research make scientists more apt to adopt those findings, while repeated failures tend to cast doubt on the legitimacy of the original article and lead scientists to look elsewhere.']

['What would be an example of replication?', 'For example, it would be a major advancement in the medical field if a published study indicated that taking a new drug helped individuals achieve a healthy weight without changing their diet.']
['What would happen if the results of that study were not replicated?', 'But if other scientists could not replicate the results, the original study’s claims would be questioned.']
['What is the replication crisis?', 'In recent years, there has been increasing concern about a “replication crisis” that has affected a number of scientific fields, including psychology.']

['What are some of the most well-known studies and scientists that have produced research that has failed to be replicated by others?', 'Some of the most well-known studies and scientists have produced research that has failed to be replicated by others (as discussed in Shrout & Rodgers, 2018).']

['What other notable studies have failed?', 'In fact, even a famous Nobel Prize-winning scientist has recently retracted a published paper because she had difficulty replicating her results (Nobel Prize-winning scientist Frances Arnold retracts paper, 2020 January 3).']

['What has the replication crisis prompted scientists to do?', 'These kinds of outcomes have prompted some scientists to begin to work together and more openly, and some would argue that the current “crisis” is actually improving the ways in which science is conducted and in how its results are shared with others (Aschwanden, 2018).']
['What is the difference between reliability and validity?', 'Reliability and validity are two important considerations that must be made with any type of data collection.']
['What does reliability mean?', 'Reliability refers to the ability to consistently produce a given result.']
['What does internal consistency mean?', 'In the context of psychological research, this would mean that any instruments or tools used to collect data do so in consistent, reproducible ways.']
['What are some different types of reliability?', 'There are a number of different types of reliability.']

['What are some of the different types of reliability?', 'Some of these include inter-rater reliability (the degree to which two or more different observers agree on what has been observed), internal consistency (the degree to which different items on a survey that measure the same thing correlate with one another), and test-retest reliability (the degree to which the outcomes of a particular measure remain consistent over multiple administrations).']
['What is the purpose of a consistent measurement?', 'Unfortunately, being consistent in measurement does not necessarily mean that you have measured something correctly.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'To illustrate this concept, consider a kitchen scale that would be used to measure the weight of cereal that you eat in the morning.']
['What might happen if the scale is not calibrated?', 'If the scale is not properly calibrated, it may consistently under- or overestimate the amount of cereal that’s being measured.']

['What is the significance of consistency in the scale?', 'While the scale is highly reliable in producing consistent results (e.g., the same amount of cereal poured onto the scale produces the same reading each time), those results are incorrect.']
['What does validity do?', 'This is where validity comes into play.']

['What is the extent to which a given instrument or tool accurately measures what it’s supposed to measure?', 'Validity refers to the extent to which a given instrument or tool accurately measures what it’s supposed to measure, and once again, there are a number of ways in which validity can be expressed.']

['What are some of these ways that researchers consider?', 'Ecological validity (the degree to which research results generalize to real-world applications), construct validity (the degree to which a given variable actually captures or measures what it is intended to measure), and face validity (the degree to which a given variable seems valid on the surface) are just a few types that researchers consider.']
['Are these the only two that matter?', 'While any valid measure is by necessity reliable, the reverse is not necessarily true.']
['Do researchers try to get both?', 'Researchers strive to use instruments that are both highly reliable and valid.']
['What is ethical in nature?', 'Today, scientists agree that good research is ethical in nature and is guided by a basic respect for human dignity and safety.']
['Why is that?', 'However, as you will read in the feature box, this has not always been the case.']
['What is the most important thing that modern researchers must demonstrate?', 'Modern researchers must demonstrate that the research they perform is ethically sound.']
['What is another important fact in this paragraph?', 'This section presents how ethical considerations affect the design and implementation of research conducted today.']

['What is the importance of this document?', 'Any experiment involving the participation of human subjects is governed by extensive, strict guidelines designed to ensure that the experiment does not result in harm.']
['What is an institution review board?', 'Any research institution that receives federal support for research involving human participants must have access to an institutional review board (IRB).']
['What is the Institution Review Board?', 'The IRB is a committee of individuals often made up of members of the institution’s administration, scientists, and community members.']
['What does the Institution Review Board do?', 'The purpose of the IRB is to review proposals for research that involves human participants.']

['What happens after the review?', 'The IRB reviews these proposals with the principles mentioned above in mind, and generally, approval from the IRB is required in order for the experiment to proceed.']
['What is the IRB?', 'An institution’s IRB requires several components in any experiment it approves.']
['What are the components of the experiment?', 'For one, each participant must sign an informed consent form before they can participate in the experiment.']

['What does an informed consent form say?', 'An informed consent form provides a written description of what participants can expect during the experiment, including potential risks and implications of the research.']
['What does the form tell participants?', 'It also lets participants know that their involvement is completely voluntary and can be discontinued without penalty at any time.']
['What does the informed consent form guarantee?', 'Furthermore, the informed consent guarantees that any data collected in the experiment will remain completely confidential.']

['What is required to be signed by the parents or legal guardians of a research participant under the age of 18?', 'In cases where research participants are under the age of 18, the parents or legal guardians are required to sign the informed consent form.']

['What is the most important thing to know about the researched participants?', 'While the informed consent form should be as honest as possible in describing exactly what participants will be doing, sometimes deception is necessary to prevent participants’ knowledge of the exact research question from affecting the results of the study.']

['What is the purpose of deception?', 'Deception involves purposely misleading experiment participants in order to maintain the integrity of the experiment, but not to the point where the deception could be considered harmful.']

["What examples are given about participants' involvement in research?", 'For example, if we are interested in how our opinion of someone is affected by their attire, we might use deception in describing the experiment to prevent that knowledge from affecting participants’ responses.']

['What else do we need to know about participants?', 'In cases where deception is involved, participants must receive a full debriefing upon conclusion of the study—complete, honest information about the purpose of the experiment, how the data collected will be used, the reasons why deception was necessary, and information about how to obtain additional information about the study.']
['What did the research cover?', 'Many psychologists conduct research involving animal subjects.']

['Who conducted the research?', 'Often, these researchers use rodents or birds as the subjects of their experiments—the APA estimates that 90% of all animal research in psychology uses these species (American Psychological Association, n.d.).']

['Why did they do that?', 'Because many basic processes in animals are sufficiently similar to those in humans, these animals are acceptable substitutes for research that would be considered unethical in human participants.']
['What does the study say about ethical concerns in animal research?', 'This does not mean that animal researchers are immune to ethical concerns.']

['What does the study say about the humane and ethical treatment of animal research subjects?', 'Indeed, the humane and ethical treatment of animal research subjects is a critical aspect of this type of research.']
['What does the study say animal subjects must be treated like?', 'Researchers must design their experiments to minimize any pain or distress experienced by animals serving as research subjects.']

['what are the animal experimental proposals?', 'Whereas IRBs review research proposals that involve human participants, animal experimental proposals are reviewed by an Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).']
['What consists of an IACUC?', 'An IACUC consists of institutional administrators, scientists, veterinarians, and community members.']
['What is the purpose of the committee?', 'This committee is charged with ensuring that all experimental proposals require the humane treatment of animal research subjects.']
['What else does the committee do?', 'It also conducts semi-annual inspections of all animal facilities to ensure that the research protocols are being followed.']
['What does the committee do?', 'No animal research project can proceed without the committee’s approval.']
['What do psychologists study?', 'Psychological researchers study genetics in order to better understand the biological factors that contribute to certain behaviors.']
['What are the unique characteristics of each individual?', 'While all humans share certain biological mechanisms, we are each unique.']

['What do we have in common?', 'And while our bodies have many of the same parts—brains and hormones and cells with genetic codes—these are expressed in a wide variety of behaviors, thoughts, and reactions.']
['What questions will we be answering?', 'To explore these questions, let’s start by focusing on a specific genetic disorder, sickle cell anemia, and how it might manifest in two affected sisters.']
['What is sickle cell anemia?', 'Sickle-cell anemia is a genetic condition in which red blood cells, which are normally round, take on a crescent-like shape.']

['What is the function of sickle-shaped cells?', 'The changed shape of these cells affects how they function: sickle-shaped cells can clog blood vessels and block blood flow, leading to high fever, severe pain, swelling, and tissue damage.']
['What are the negative evolutionary effects associated with sickle-cell anemia?', 'Many people with sickle-cell anemia—and the particular genetic mutation that causes it—die at an early age.']

['What is notable about the article?', 'While the notion of “survival of the fittest” may suggest that people with this disorder have a low survival rate and therefore the disorder will become less common, this is not the case.']
['What is the reason for this?', 'Despite the negative evolutionary effects associated with this genetic mutation, the sickle-cell gene remains relatively common among people of African descent.']
['What kind of explanation is illustrated with the following scenario?', 'The explanation is illustrated with the following scenario.']
['What should we do now to get started?', 'Imagine two young women—Luwi and Sena—sisters in rural Zambia, Africa.']
["How are Luwi and Sena's gene profiles different?", 'Luwi carries the gene for sickle-cell anemia; Sena does not carry the gene.']
['What do sickle-cell carriers have one copy of?', 'Sickle-cell carriers have one copy of the sickle-cell gene but do not have full-blown sickle-cell anemia.']
['How does sickle-cell disease impact their lives?', 'They experience symptoms only if they are severely dehydrated or are deprived of oxygen (as in mountain climbing).']

['What are the implications for Sena?', 'Carriers are thought to be immune from malaria (an often deadly disease that is widespread in tropical climates) because changes in their blood chemistry and immune functioning prevent the malaria parasite from having its effects (Gong, Parikh, Rosenthal, & Greenhouse, 2013).']
['What is the difference between sickle-cell anemia and malaria?', 'However, full-blown sickle-cell anemia, with two copies of the sickle-cell gene, does not provide immunity to malaria.']
['What happens to the women when they get malaria?', 'While walking home from school, both sisters are bitten by mosquitoes carrying the malaria parasite.']
['What is Luwi protected against?', 'Luwi is protected against malaria because she carries the sickle-cell mutation.']
["Why doesn't Sena die?", 'Sena, on the other hand, develops malaria and dies just two weeks later.']
['What happens to Luwi?', 'Luwi survives and eventually has children, to whom she may pass on the sickle-cell mutation.']

['What type of malaria is rare in the United States?', 'Malaria is rare in the United States, so the sickle-cell gene benefits nobody: the gene manifests primarily in minor health problems for carriers with one copy, or a severe full-blown disease with no health benefits for carriers with two copies.']
['What is the situation like in other parts of the world?', 'However, the situation is quite different in other parts of the world.']

['What is different in other parts of the world?', 'In parts of Africa where malaria is prevalent, having the sickle-cell mutation does provide health benefits for carriers (protection from malaria).']
['What theory did the story of malaria fit with?', "The story of malaria fits with Charles Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection."]

['What is the theory about?', 'In simple terms, the theory states that organisms that are better suited for their environment will survive and reproduce, while those that are poorly suited for their environment will die off.']

['What is the most important information in the passage?', 'In our example, we can see that, as a carrier, Luwi’s mutation is highly adaptive in her African homeland; however, if she resided in the United States (where malaria is rare), her mutation could prove costly—with a high probability of the disease in her descendants and minor health problems of her own.']
['What is genetic variation?', 'Genetic variation, the genetic difference between individuals, is what contributes to a species’ adaptation to its environment.']
['What is one factor that influences genetic variation?', 'In humans, genetic variation begins with an egg, about 100 million sperm, and fertilization.']
['When does one female ovum release an egg?', 'Roughly once per month, active ovaries release an egg from follicles.']

['What happens to an egg during its journey from the ovary through the fallopian tubes, to the uterus?', "During the egg's journey from the ovary through the fallopian tubes, to the uterus, a sperm may fertilize the egg."]
['How many chromosomes are in an egg?', 'The egg and the sperm each contain 23 chromosomes.']
['What is the structure of chromosomes?', 'Chromosomes are long strings of genetic material known as deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA).']
['What is DNA?', 'DNA is a helix-shaped molecule made up of nucleotide base pairs.']

['What type of traits are genetic?', 'In each chromosome, sequences of DNA make up genes that control or partially control a number of visible characteristics, known as traits, such as eye color, hair color, and so on.']
['What is the name of a variation of a gene?', 'A single gene may have multiple possible variations, or alleles.']
['What is an allele?', 'An allele is a specific version of a gene.']
['What kind of variation does a gene have?', 'So, a given gene may code for the trait of hair color, and the different alleles of that gene affect which hair color an individual has.']
['What are pairs?', 'When a sperm and egg fuse, their 23 chromosomes combine to create a zygote with 46 chromosomes (23 pairs).']

['What is the result of the fused chromosomes?', 'Therefore, each parent contributes half the genetic information carried by the offspring; the resulting physical characteristics of the offspring (called the phenotype) are determined by the interaction of genetic material supplied by the sperm and egg (called the genotype).']
['What is the genetic makeup of an individual?', 'A person’s genotype is the genetic makeup of that individual.']
['what is phenotype?', 'Phenotype, on the other hand, refers to the individual’s inherited physical characteristics, which are a combination of genetic and environmental influences.']

['What is the term for the individual organisms that contribute genetic material to offspring?', 'Note that, in genetics and reproduction, "parent" is often used to describe the individual organisms that contribute genetic material to offspring, usually in the form of gamete cells (sperm and egg).']

['What is different about people consider and may differ?', 'The concept of a genetic parent is distinct from social and legal concepts of parenthood, and may differ from those whom people consider their parents.']
['What does this mean?', 'Most traits are controlled by multiple genes, but some traits are controlled by one gene.']
['What is one gene?', 'A characteristic like cleft chin, for example, is influenced by a single gene from each parent.']

["How does one gene affect a person's phenotype?", 'In this example, we will call the gene for cleft chin “B,” and the gene for smooth chin “b.” Cleft chin is a dominant trait, which means that having the dominant allele either from one parent (Bb) or both parents (BB) will always result in the phenotype associated with the dominant allele.']
['What is homozygous?', 'When someone has two copies of the same allele, they are said to be homozygous for that allele.']
['What is heterozygous?', 'When someone has a combination of alleles for a given gene, they are said to be heterozygous.']

["How can this affect a person's phenotype?", 'For example, smooth chin is a recessive trait, which means that an individual will only display the smooth chin phenotype if they are homozygous for that recessive allele (bb).']
['How do we know this?', 'Imagine that a person with a cleft chin mates with a person with a smooth chin.']
['How could this be?', 'The answer to that depends on which alleles each parent carries.']
['How do we know what alleles?', 'If the person with a cleft is homozygous for cleft chin (BB), their offspring will always have cleft chin.']
['How is this different from heterozygous?', 'It gets a little more complicated, however, if the person is heterozygous for this gene (Bb).']

['What happens if the person is heterozygous?', 'Since the other person has a smooth chin—therefore homozygous for the recessive allele (bb)—we can expect the offspring to have a 50% chance of having a cleft chin and a 50% chance of having a smooth chin.']

['How does genetic variation relate to sickle cell anemia?', 'In sickle cell anemia, heterozygous carriers (like Luwi from the example) can develop blood resistance to malaria infection while those who are homozygous (like Sena) have a potentially lethal blood disorder.']
['What is sickle-cell anemia?', 'Sickle-cell anemia is just one of many genetic disorders caused by the pairing of two recessive genes.']

['What are some disorders that people suffer from?', 'For example, phenylketonuria (PKU) is a condition in which individuals lack an enzyme that normally converts harmful amino acids into harmless byproducts.']

['What is something unique about genetic variation?', 'If someone with this condition goes untreated, they will experience significant deficits in cognitive function, seizures, and an increased risk of various psychiatric disorders.']
['What can be said about genetic variation?', 'Because PKU is a recessive trait, each parent must have at least one copy of the recessive allele in order to produce a child with the condition.']
['What type of variation is discussed?', 'So far, we have discussed traits that involve just one gene, but few human characteristics are controlled by a single gene.']
['What is the term for traits controlled by more than one gene?', 'Most traits are polygenic: controlled by more than one gene.']
['What traits are polygenic?', 'Height is one example of a polygenic trait, as are skin color and weight.']
['What is genetic variation?', 'Gene mutations provide one source of harmful genes.']
['What is a mutation?', 'A mutation is a sudden, permanent change in a gene.']

['What is the reason some mutations benefit people?', 'While many mutations can be harmful or lethal, once in a while, a mutation benefits an individual by giving that person an advantage over those who do not have the mutation.']

['What is the theory of evolution?', 'Recall that the theory of evolution asserts that individuals best adapted to their particular environments are more likely to reproduce and pass on their genes to future generations.']

['What is competition?', 'In order for this process to occur, there must be competition—more technically, there must be variability in genes (and resultant traits) that allow for variation in adaptability to the environment.']

['What else should we know about genetic variation?', 'If a population consisted of identical individuals, then any dramatic changes in the environment would affect everyone in the same way, and there would be no variation in selection.']

['What is the result of genetic variation?', 'In contrast, diversity in genes and associated traits allows some individuals to perform slightly better than others when faced with environmental change.']

['What happens if diversity exists in the population?', 'This creates a distinct advantage for individuals best suited for their environments in terms of successful reproduction and genetic transmission.']
['What is the main idea of the article?', 'Genes do not exist in a vacuum.']

['What is the result of that fact?', 'Although we are all biological organisms, we also exist in an environment that is incredibly important in determining not only when and how our genes express themselves, but also in what combination.']

['What is the most important thing to remember about range of reaction?', 'Each of us represents a unique interaction between our genetic makeup and our environment; range of reaction is one way to describe this interaction.']

['What does range of reaction mean?', 'Range of reaction asserts that our genes set the boundaries within which we can operate, and our environment interacts with the genes to determine where in that range we will fall.']

['What else can you tell me about the passage?', 'For example, if an individual’s genetic makeup predisposes them to high levels of intellectual potential and they are reared in a rich, stimulating environment, then they will be more likely to achieve full potential than if they were raised under conditions of significant deprivation.']

['What is the concept of range of reaction?', 'According to the concept of range of reaction, genes set definite limits on potential, and environment determines how much of that potential is achieved.']
['What is discussed in the passage?', 'Some disagree with this theory and argue that genes do not set a limit on a person’s potential with reaction norms being determined by the environment.']

["What are some examples of adverse psychological and/or physical conditions that can last throughout one's life?", 'For example, when individuals experience neglect or abuse early in life, they are more likely to exhibit adverse psychological and/or physical conditions that can last throughout their lives.']

['What is discussed in the passage?', 'These conditions may develop as a function of the negative environmental experiences in individuals from dissimilar genetic backgrounds (Miguel, Pereira, Silveira, & Meaney, 2019; Short & Baram, 2019).']
['How do genes affect the environment?', 'Another perspective on the interaction between genes and the environment is the concept of genetic environmental correlation.']
['What does genetic environmental correlation mean?', 'Stated simply, our genes influence our environment, and our environment influences the expression of our genes.']
['What does this mean for the human body?', 'Not only do our genes and environment interact, as in range of reaction, but they also influence one another bidirectionally.']
['What does the exposure mean for an NBA player?', 'For example, the child of an NBA player would probably be exposed to basketball from an early age.']
['What might be the result of that?', 'Such exposure might allow the child to realize their full genetic, athletic potential.']

['What is another example of how genes influence the environment?', 'Thus, the parents’ genes, which the child shares, influence the child’s environment, and that environment, in turn, is well suited to support the child’s genetic potential.']

['What are these interactions?', 'In another approach to gene-environment interactions, the field of epigenetics looks beyond the genotype itself and studies how the same genotype can be expressed in different ways.']
['What does that mean?', 'In other words, researchers study how the same genotype can lead to very different phenotypes.']
['What is a unique environmental interactions?', 'As mentioned earlier, gene expression is often influenced by environmental context in ways that are not entirely obvious.']

['What is one example of a genetic difference between twins?', 'For instance, identical twins share the same genetic information (identical twins develop from a single fertilized egg that split, so the genetic material is exactly the same in each; in contrast, fraternal twins usually result from two different eggs fertilized by different sperm, so the genetic material varies as with non-twin siblings).']

['What is the difference between identical and fraternal twins?', 'But even with identical genes, there remains an incredible amount of variability in how gene expression can unfold over the course of each twin’s life.']
['What do they have in common?', 'Sometimes, one twin will develop a disease and the other will not.']
['What caused Aliya to die at age 7?', 'In one example, Aliya, an identical twin, died from cancer at age 7, but her twin, now 19 years old, has never had cancer.']

['How do individuals differ in their phenotypes?', 'Although these individuals share an identical genotype, their phenotypes differ as a result of how that genetic information is expressed over time and through their unique environmental interactions.']
['What is significant about epigenetics?', 'The epigenetic perspective is very different from range of reaction, because here the genotype is not fixed and limited.']
['What are we presently studying?', 'Genes affect more than our physical characteristics.']

['What are some of the other traits they affect?', 'Indeed, scientists have found genetic linkages to a number of behavioral characteristics, ranging from basic personality traits to sexual orientation to spirituality (for examples, see Mustanski et al., 2005; Comings, Gonzales, Saucier, Johnson, & MacMurray, 2000).']
['What other traits are related to genetics?', 'Genes are also associated with temperament and a number of psychological disorders, such as depression and schizophrenia.']

['What are the implications of this?', 'So while it is true that genes provide the biological blueprints for our cells, tissues, organs, and body, they also have a significant impact on our experiences and our behaviors.']
['What is the question about schizophrenia?', 'Let’s look at the following findings regarding schizophrenia in light of our three views of gene-environment interactions.']

['What was the study about?', 'Of adoptees whose biological mothers had schizophrenia (high genetic risk) and who were raised in disturbed family environments, 36.8% were likely to develop schizophrenia.']

['How many people would develop schizophrenia?', 'Of adoptees whose biological mothers had schizophrenia (high genetic risk) and who were raised in healthy family environments, 5.8% were likely to develop schizophrenia.']

['What was the number of people that developed schizophrenia based on the study?', 'Of adoptees with a low genetic risk (whose mothers did not have schizophrenia) and who were raised in disturbed family environments, 5.3% were likely to develop schizophrenia.']

['What other percentages came out of the study?', 'Of adoptees with a low genetic risk (whose mothers did not have schizophrenia) and who were raised in healthy family environments, 4.8% were likely to develop schizophrenia.']
['What is a disturbance?', 'The study shows that adoptees with high genetic risk were most likely to develop schizophrenia if they were raised in disturbed home environments.']

['Why does that matter?', 'This research lends credibility to the notion that both genetic vulnerability and environmental stress are necessary for schizophrenia to develop, and that genes alone do not tell the full tale.']
['What is psychology?', 'Psychologists striving to understand the human mind may study the nervous system.']
['What can we learn about the human body from studying cells and organs?', "Learning how the body's cells and organs function can help us understand the biological basis of human psychology."]
['What are some of the basic cell types in the nervous system?', 'The nervous system is composed of two basic cell types: glial cells (also known as glia) and neurons.']
['What role do glial cells traditionally play?', 'Glial cells are traditionally thought to play a supportive role to neurons, both physically and metabolically.']

['What other important functions do they have?', 'Glial cells provide scaffolding on which the nervous system is built, help neurons line up closely with each other to allow neuronal communication, provide insulation to neurons, transport nutrients and waste products, and mediate immune responses.']

['What do we know about the ratio of glial cells to neurons?', "For years, researchers believed that there were many more glial cells than neurons; however, more recent work from Suzanna Herculano-Houzel's laboratory has called this long-standing assumption into question and has provided important evidence that there may be a nearly 1:1 ratio of glia cells to neurons."]

['Why is this important?', 'This is important because it suggests that human brains are more similar to other primate brains than previously thought (Azevedo et al, 2009; Herculano-Houzel, 2012; Herculano-Houzel, 2009).']

['What is the difference between neurons and glial cells?', 'Neurons, on the other hand, serve as interconnected information processors that are essential for all of the tasks of the nervous system.']
['What is the structure and function of neurons?', 'This section briefly describes the structure and function of neurons.']
['What are the central building blocks of the nervous system?', 'Neurons are the central building blocks of the nervous system, 100 billion strong at birth.']
['What are the parts of a neuron?', 'Like all cells, neurons consist of several different parts, each serving a specialized function.']
['What is on the outer surface of a neuron?', 'A neuron’s outer surface is made up of a semipermeable membrane.']

['What allows smaller molecules and molecules without an electrical charge to pass through it, while stopping larger or highly charged molecules?', 'This membrane allows smaller molecules and molecules without an electrical charge to pass through it, while stopping larger or highly charged molecules.']
['Where is the nucleus of the neuron located?', 'The nucleus of the neuron is located in the soma, or cell body.']
['What are the branching extensions known as?', 'The soma has branching extensions known as dendrites.']
['What do dendrites serve as?', 'The neuron is a small information processor, and dendrites serve as input sites where signals are received from other neurons.']

['Where are these signals transmitted?', 'These signals are transmitted electrically across the soma and down a major extension from the soma known as the axon, which ends at multiple terminal buttons.']
['What do the terminal buttons contain?', 'The terminal buttons contain synaptic vesicles that house neurotransmitters, the chemical messengers of the nervous system.']
['What is the length of an axon?', 'Axons range in length from a fraction of an inch to several feet.']

['What do glial cells do?', 'In some axons, glial cells form a fatty substance known as the myelin sheath, which coats the axon and acts as an insulator, increasing the speed at which the signal travels.']
['What is the length of the myelin sheath?', 'The myelin sheath is not continuous and there are small gaps that occur down the length of the axon.']
['What are these gaps in the myelin sheath called?', 'These gaps in the myelin sheath are known as the Nodes of Ranvier.']

['What can you tell me about the myelin sheath?', 'The myelin sheath is crucial for the normal operation of the neurons within the nervous system: the loss of the insulation it provides can be detrimental to normal function.']
['What happens in between the Nodes of Ranvier?', 'To understand how this works, let’s consider an example.']

['What is the example of a genetic disorder discussed earlier?', 'PKU, a genetic disorder discussed earlier, causes a reduction in myelin and abnormalities in white matter cortical and subcortical structures.']

['What are the effects of the disorder?', 'The disorder is associated with a variety of issues including severe cognitive deficits, exaggerated reflexes, and seizures (Anderson & Leuzzi, 2010; Huttenlocher, 2000).']

['What else do you know about the myelin?', 'Another disorder, multiple sclerosis (MS), an autoimmune disorder, involves a large-scale loss of the myelin sheath on axons throughout the nervous system.']

['What is the effect of MS?', 'The resulting interference in the electrical signal prevents the quick transmittal of information by neurons and can lead to a number of symptoms, such as dizziness, fatigue, loss of motor control, and sexual dysfunction.']

['Is there anything else that you can tell me about multiple sclerosis?', 'While some treatments may help to modify the course of the disease and manage certain symptoms, there is currently no known cure for multiple sclerosis.']

['What happens after neurotransmitters are released?', 'In healthy individuals, the neuronal signal moves rapidly down the axon to the terminal buttons, where synaptic vesicles release neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft.']
['What is the synaptic cleft?', 'The synaptic cleft is a very small space between two neurons and is an important site where communication between neurons occurs.']

['What happens after neurotransmitters are released into the synaptic cleft?', 'Once neurotransmitters are released into the synaptic cleft, they travel across it and bind with corresponding receptors on the dendrite of an adjacent neuron.']
['Where do the receptors attach?', 'Receptors, proteins on the cell surface where neurotransmitters attach, vary in shape, with different shapes “matching” different neurotransmitters.']

['What can you tell me about the lock-and-key relationship?', 'The neurotransmitter and the receptor have what is referred to as a lock-and-key relationship—specific neurotransmitters fit specific receptors similar to how a key fits a lock.']
['Does the fact that it fits is a generalized idea?', 'The neurotransmitter binds to any receptor that it fits.']
['What do you mean by that?', 'We begin at the neuronal membrane.']
['What is the function of the neuronal membrane?', 'The neuron exists in a fluid environment—it is surrounded by extracellular fluid and contains intracellular fluid (i.e., cytoplasm).']

['What is the neuronal membrane trying to accomplish?', 'The neuronal membrane keeps these two fluids separate—a critical role because the electrical signal that passes through the neuron depends on the intra- and extracellular fluids being electrically different.']
['How does it keep it apart?', 'This difference in charge across the membrane, called the membrane potential, provides energy for the signal.']
['What is the cause of electrical charge of the fluids?', 'The electrical charge of the fluids is caused by charged molecules (ions) dissolved in the fluid.']

['What happens to the charge?', 'The semipermeable nature of the neuronal membrane somewhat restricts the movement of these charged molecules, and, as a result, some of the charged particles tend to become more concentrated either inside or outside the cell.']
['What happens during this process?', 'Between signals, the neuron membrane’s potential is held in a state of readiness, called the resting potential.']

['Why is it held in a state of readiness?', 'Like a rubber band stretched out and waiting to spring into action, ions line up on either side of the cell membrane, ready to rush across the membrane when the neuron goes active and the membrane opens its gates.']
['What happens as they line up?', 'Ions in high-concentration areas are ready to move to low-concentration areas, and positive ions are ready to move to areas with a negative charge.']
['What happens in the resting state?', 'In the resting state, sodium (Na+) is at higher concentrations outside the cell, so it will tend to move into the cell.']
['What happens to potassium?', 'Potassium (K+), on the other hand, is more concentrated inside the cell, and will tend to move out of the cell.']
['What else happens?', 'In addition, the inside of the cell is slightly negatively charged compared to the outside, due to the activity of the sodium-potassium pump.']
['What is the sodium-potassium pump?', 'This pump actively transports three sodium ions out of the cell for every two potassium ions in, creating a net negative charge inside the cell.']
['What does this do to sodium?', 'This provides an additional force on sodium, causing it to move into the cell.']
['What is the resting potential state?', 'From this resting potential state, the neuron receives a signal and its state changes abruptly.']

['How do ions get into the cell?', 'When a neuron receives signals at the dendrites—due to neurotransmitters from an adjacent neuron binding to its receptors—small pores, or gates, open on the neuronal membrane, allowing Na+ ions, propelled by both charge and concentration differences, to move into the cell.']
['What happens with this influx of positive ions?', 'With this influx of positive ions, the internal charge of the cell becomes more positive.']
['What happens when the charge reaches a certain level?', 'If that charge reaches a certain level, called the threshold of excitation, the neuron becomes active and the action potential begins.']
['What happens after the pores open?', 'Many additional pores open, causing a massive influx of Na+ ions and a huge positive spike in the membrane potential, the peak action potential.']
['What happens after the spike?', 'At the peak of the spike, the sodium gates close and the potassium gates open.']
['What happens when the potassium gates open?', 'As positively charged potassium ions leave, the cell quickly begins repolarization.']
['What happens after repolarization?', 'At first, it hyperpolarizes, becoming slightly more negative than the resting potential, and then it levels off, returning to the resting potential.']
['What is the positive spike called?', 'This positive spike constitutes the action potential: the electrical signal that typically moves from the cell body down the axon to the axon terminals.']
['How does the signal move?', 'The electrical signal moves down the axon with the impulses jumping in a leapfrog fashion between the Nodes of Ranvier.']
['What are the nodes of ranvier?', 'The Nodes of Ranvier are natural gaps in the myelin sheath.']

['How does the sodium ions make the movement?', 'At each point, some of the sodium ions that enter the cell diffuse to the next section of the axon, raising the charge past the threshold of excitation and triggering a new influx of sodium ions.']
['How does this affect the signals?', 'The action potential moves all the way down the axon in this fashion until reaching the terminal buttons.']
['What is an all-or-none phenomenon?', 'The action potential is an all-or-none phenomenon.']

['What does it mean that an incoming signal from another neuron is either sufficient or insufficient to reach the threshold of excitation?', 'In simple terms, this means that an incoming signal from another neuron is either sufficient or insufficient to reach the threshold of excitation.']
['What does turning mean?', 'There is no in-between, and there is no turning off an action potential once it starts.']
['How does text message relate to action potential?', 'Think of it like sending an email or a text message.']
['Do we have to send it?', 'You can think about sending it all you want, but the message is not sent until you hit the send button.']
['What happens after we hit the send button?', 'Furthermore, once you send the message, there is no stopping it.']
['How is the action potential recreated?', 'Because it is all or none, the action potential is recreated, or propagated, at its full strength at every point along the axon.']
['What is the signal like?', 'Much like the lit fuse of a firecracker, it does not fade away as it travels down the axon.']
['What is it used for?', 'It is this all-or-none property that explains the fact that your brain perceives an injury to a distant body part like your toe as equally painful as one to your nose.']

['When the action potential arrives at the terminal button, what happens?', 'As noted earlier, when the action potential arrives at the terminal button, the synaptic vesicles release their neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft.']

['How do the neurotransmitters travel?', 'The neurotransmitters travel across the synapse and bind to receptors on the dendrites of the adjacent neuron, and the process repeats itself in the new neuron (assuming the signal is sufficiently strong to trigger an action potential).']

['What happens to excess neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft?', 'Once the signal is delivered, excess neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft drift away, are broken down into inactive fragments, or are reabsorbed in a process known as reuptake.']
['What is the process of reuptake?', 'Reuptake involves the neurotransmitter being pumped back into the neuron that released it, in order to clear the synapse.']

['To what does clearing the synapse serve?', 'Clearing the synapse serves both to provide a clear “on” and “off” state between signals and to regulate the production of neurotransmitter (full synaptic vesicles provide signals that no additional neurotransmitters need to be produced).']
['What is neuronal communication?', 'Neuronal communication is often referred to as an electrochemical event.']

['What is an electrical event?', 'The movement of the action potential down the length of the axon is an electrical event, and movement of the neurotransmitter across the synaptic space represents the chemical portion of the process.']
['Do any other parts of the brain make up the process?', 'However, there are some specialized connections between neurons that are entirely electrical.']
['What happens when the communication is completely electrical?', 'In such cases, the neurons are said to communicate via an electrical synapse.']
['How do neurons physically connect to one another?', 'In these cases, two neurons physically connect to one another via gap junctions, which allows the current from one cell to pass into the next.']

['What does the brain do with its signals?', 'There are far fewer electrical synapses in the brain, but those that do exist are much faster than the chemical synapses that have been described above (Connors & Long, 2004).']

['What are the different types of neurotransmitters released by different neurons?', 'There are several different types of neurotransmitters released by different neurons, and we can speak in broad terms about the kinds of functions associated with different neurotransmitters.']

['What do psychologists know about the functions of neurotransmitters?', 'Much of what psychologists know about the functions of neurotransmitters comes from research on the effects of drugs in psychological disorders.']

['What are the physiological causes of behavior?', 'Psychologists who take a biological perspective and focus on the physiological causes of behavior assert that psychological disorders like depression and schizophrenia are associated with imbalances in one or more neurotransmitter systems.']
['What are psychotropic medications?', 'In this perspective, psychotropic medications can help improve the symptoms associated with these disorders.']
['What are drugs that treat psychiatric symptoms by restoring neurotransmitter balance?', 'Psychotropic medications are drugs that treat psychiatric symptoms by restoring neurotransmitter balance.']
['What are agonists?', 'Psychoactive drugs can act as agonists or antagonists for a given neurotransmitter system.']
['What are chemicals that mimic a neurotransmitter at the receptor site?', 'Agonists are chemicals that mimic a neurotransmitter at the receptor site.']
['What is the opposite of agonist?', 'An antagonist, on the other hand, blocks or impedes the normal activity of a neurotransmitter at the receptor.']

['What are the drugs that are prescribed to correct the specific neurotransmitter imbalances underlying a person’s condition?', 'Agonists and antagonists represent drugs that are prescribed to correct the specific neurotransmitter imbalances underlying a person’s condition.']
['What is the progressive nervous system disorder?', "For example, Parkinson's disease, a progressive nervous system disorder, is associated with low levels of dopamine."]
['How does dopamine help?', "Therefore, a common treatment strategy for Parkinson's disease involves using dopamine agonists, which mimic the effects of dopamine by binding to dopamine receptors."]
['Are certain symptoms of schizophrenia a result of overactive dopamine neurotransmission?', 'Certain symptoms of schizophrenia are associated with overactive dopamine neurotransmission.']

['What are the medications used to treat schizophrenia?', 'The antipsychotics used to treat these symptoms are antagonists for dopamine—they block dopamine’s effects by binding its receptors without activating them.']
['What does that mean for blocking dopamine?', 'Thus, they prevent dopamine released by one neuron from signaling information to adjacent neurons.']

['What do reuptake inhibitors prevent?', 'In contrast to agonists and antagonists, which both operate by binding to receptor sites, reuptake inhibitors prevent unused neurotransmitters from being transported back to the neuron.']
['Why does that help?', 'This allows neurotransmitters to remain active in the synaptic cleft for longer durations, increasing their effectiveness.']
['What happens when you have depression?', 'Depression, which has been consistently linked with reduced serotonin levels, is commonly treated with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).']
['What happens to the depression?', 'By preventing reuptake, SSRIs strengthen the effect of serotonin, giving it more time to interact with serotonin receptors on dendrites.']
['What are some common SSRIs on the market today?', 'Common SSRIs on the market today include Prozac, Paxil, and Zoloft.']
['What is the structurally similar to serotonin?', 'The drug LSD is structurally very similar to serotonin, and it affects the same neurons and receptors as serotonin.']
['What are the effects of psychotropic drugs?', 'Psychotropic drugs are not instant solutions for people suffering from psychological disorders.']
['How are psychoactive drugs used?', 'Often, an individual must take a drug for several weeks before seeing improvement, and many psychoactive drugs have significant negative side effects.']
['What are the negative side effects of the drugs?', 'Furthermore, individuals vary dramatically in how they respond to the drugs.']
['What other therapies are used?', 'To improve chances for success, it is not uncommon for people receiving pharmacotherapy to undergo psychological and/or behavioral therapies as well.']

['Why is this?', 'Some research suggests that combining drug therapy with other forms of therapy tends to be more effective than any one treatment alone (for one such example, see March et al., 2007).']

['What are the parts of the nervous system?', 'The nervous system can be divided into two major subdivisions: the central nervous system (CNS) and the peripheral nervous system (PNS), shown in Figure 3.13.']
['What are the parts of the central nervous system?', 'The CNS is comprised of the brain and spinal cord; the PNS connects the CNS to the rest of the body.']
['What do you know about the peripheral nervous system?', 'In this section, we focus on the peripheral nervous system; later, we look at the brain and spinal cord.']

['What is the peripheral nervous system made up of?', 'The peripheral nervous system is made up of thick bundles of axons, called nerves, carrying messages back and forth between the CNS and the muscles, organs, and senses in the periphery of the body (i.e., everything outside the CNS).']
['What are the major subdivisions of the PNS?', 'The PNS has two major subdivisions: the somatic nervous system and the autonomic nervous system.']
['What is the somatic nervous system?', 'The somatic nervous system is associated with activities traditionally thought of as conscious or voluntary.']

['What is involved in the relay of sensory and motor information to and from the CNS?', 'It is involved in the relay of sensory and motor information to and from the CNS; therefore, it consists of motor neurons and sensory neurons.']
['What is the motor information involved in?', 'Motor neurons, carrying instructions from the CNS to the muscles, are efferent fibers (efferent means “moving away from”).']
['What is sensory information involved in?', 'Sensory neurons, carrying sensory information to the CNS, are afferent fibers (afferent means “moving toward”).']
['What is a helpful way to remember this?', 'A helpful way to remember this is that efferent = exit and afferent = arrive.']
['What are some other interesting things about the text?', 'Each nerve is basically a bundle of neurons forming a two-way superhighway, containing thousands of axons, both efferent and afferent.']
['What does the autonomic nervous system control?', 'The autonomic nervous system controls our internal organs and glands and is generally considered to be outside the realm of voluntary control.']
['What are the divisions of the sympathetic nervous system?', 'It can be further subdivided into the sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions.']

['What do the divisions do to the body?', 'The sympathetic nervous system is involved in preparing the body for stress-related activities; the parasympathetic nervous system is associated with returning the body to routine, day-to-day operations.']

['What is the relationship between the autonomic nervous system and the sympathetic nervous system?', 'The two systems have complementary functions, operating in tandem to maintain the body’s homeostasis.']
['What is homeostasis?', 'Homeostasis is a state of equilibrium, or balance, in which biological conditions (such as body temperature) are maintained at optimal levels.']

['What is sympathetic nervous system activated when we are faced with stressful or high-arousal situations?', 'The sympathetic nervous system is activated when we are faced with stressful or high-arousal situations.']
['What was the sympathetic nervous system beneficial for?', 'The activity of this system was adaptive for our ancestors, increasing their chances of survival.']
['What did it do?', 'Imagine, for example, that one of our early ancestors, out hunting small game, suddenly disturbs a large bear with her cubs.']
["What happens to the hunter's body at this point?", "At that moment, the hunter's body undergoes a series of changes—a direct function of sympathetic activation—preparing them to face the threat."]

['What happens to the hunter during this arousal?', 'The pupils dilate, the heart rate and blood pressure increase, the bladder relaxes, and the liver releases glucose; adrenaline surges into the bloodstream.']

['What does this all lead to?', 'This constellation of physiological changes, known as the fight or flight response, allows the body access to energy reserves and heightened sensory capacity so that it might fight off a threat or run away to safety.']

['What was the study about?', 'While it is clear that such a response would be critical for survival for our ancestors, who lived in a world full of real physical threats, many of the high-arousal situations we face in the modern world are more psychological in nature.']

['How do we deal with the situations that would require our response?', 'For example, think about how you feel when you have to stand up and give a presentation in front of a roomful of people, or right before taking a big test.']
['What is the fight or flight response?', 'You are in no real physical danger in those situations, and yet you have evolved to respond to a perceived threat with the fight or flight response.']

['What are the negative health consequences of our fight or flight response?', 'This kind of response is not nearly as adaptive in the modern world; in fact, we suffer negative health consequences when faced constantly with psychological threats that we can neither fight nor flee.']

['What are the health consequences of persistent and repeated exposure to stressful situations?', 'Recent research suggests that an increase in susceptibility to heart disease (Chandola, Brunner, & Marmot, 2006) and impaired function of the immune system (Glaser & Kiecolt-Glaser, 2005) are among the many negative consequences of persistent and repeated exposure to stressful situations.']
['What can stress reactivity do to us?', 'Some of this tendency for stress reactivity can be wired by early experiences of trauma.']
['When does the parasympathetic nervous system take over?', 'Once the threat has been resolved, the parasympathetic nervous system takes over and returns bodily functions to a relaxed state.']

["What happens when he's relaxed?", 'Our hunter’s heart rate and blood pressure return to normal, the pupils constrict, bladder control is restored, and the liver begins to store glucose in the form of glycogen for future use.']
['What is this all about?', 'These restorative processes are associated with activation of the parasympathetic nervous system.']
['What is the brain comprised of?', 'The brain is a remarkably complex organ comprised of billions of interconnected neurons and glia.']
['What is the structure of the brain?', 'It is a bilateral, or two-sided, structure that can be separated into distinct lobes.']

['What do the lobes do?', 'Each lobe is associated with certain types of functions, but, ultimately, all of the areas of the brain interact with one another to provide the foundation for our thoughts and behaviors.']

['What is the spinal cord?', 'In this section, we discuss the overall organization of the brain and the functions associated with different brain areas, beginning with what can be seen as an extension of the brain, the spinal cord.']
['What is the spinal cord connected to?', 'It can be said that the spinal cord is what connects the brain to the outside world.']
['What happens to the brain when it receives information?', 'Because of it, the brain can act.']
['What does the spinal cord do for the brain?', 'The spinal cord is like a relay station, but a very smart one.']
['What does the spinal cord do?', 'It not only routes messages to and from the brain, but it also has its own system of automatic processes, called reflexes.']

['What is the top of the spinal cord?', 'The top of the spinal cord is a bundle of nerves that merges with the brain stem, where the basic processes of life are controlled, such as breathing and digestion.']

['What is the opposite of the top of the spinal cord?', 'In the opposite direction, the spinal cord ends just below the ribs—contrary to what we might expect, it does not extend all the way to the base of the spine.']
['How is the spinal cord functionally organized?', 'The spinal cord is functionally organized in 30 segments, corresponding with the vertebrae.']
['What is the peripheral nervous system?', 'Each segment is connected to a specific part of the body through the peripheral nervous system.']
['Where does the peripheral nervous system branch?', 'Nerves branch out from the spine at each vertebra.']
['What are sensory and motor nerves connected to?', 'Sensory nerves bring messages in; motor nerves send messages out to the muscles and organs.']
['What do the messages travel to and from the brain through?', 'Messages travel to and from the brain through every segment.']
['What happens in the spinal cord?', 'Some sensory messages are immediately acted on by the spinal cord, without any input from the brain.']
['What are two examples of sensory messages being immediately acted on by the spinal cord?', 'Withdrawal from a hot object and the knee jerk are two examples.']
['What is an automatic reflex?', 'When a sensory message meets certain parameters, the spinal cord initiates an automatic reflex.']
['What happens to the signal?', 'The signal passes from the sensory nerve to a simple processing center, which initiates a motor command.']
['How do spinal reflexes help in response times?', 'Seconds are saved, because messages don’t have to go the brain, be processed, and get sent back.']
['What can spinal reflexes do in matters of survival?', 'In matters of survival, the spinal reflexes allow the body to react extraordinarily fast.']
['What is an interesting fact about the spinal cord?', 'The spinal cord is protected by bony vertebrae and cushioned in cerebrospinal fluid, but injuries still occur.']
['What happens when the spinal cord is damaged?', 'When the spinal cord is damaged in a particular segment, all lower segments are cut off from the brain, causing paralysis.']
['What can you tell me about the spinal cord?', 'Therefore, the lower on the spine damage occurs, the fewer functions an injured individual will lose.']
['What happened to Bob Woodruff?', 'Bob Woodruff, a reporter for ABC, suffered a traumatic brain injury after a bomb exploded next to the vehicle he was in while covering a news story in Iraq.']
['What was the result of the injury?', 'As a consequence of these injuries, Woodruff experienced many cognitive deficits including difficulties with memory and language.']

['What did he do to recover?', 'However, over time and with the aid of intensive amounts of cognitive and speech therapy, Woodruff has shown an incredible recovery of function (Fernandez, 2008, October 16).']
['What was the factor that made this recovery possible?', 'One of the factors that made this recovery possible was neuroplasticity.']
['What is neuroplasticity?', 'Neuroplasticity refers to how the nervous system can change and adapt.']

['What can neuroplasticity refer to?', "Neuroplasticity can occur in a variety of ways including personal experiences, developmental processes, or, as in Woodruff's case, in response to some sort of damage or injury that has occurred."]
['What are the changes it enables?', 'Neuroplasticity can involve creation of new synapses, pruning of synapses that are no longer used, changes in glial cells, and even the birth of new neurons.']

['What is the most notable aspect of the article?', "Because of neuroplasticity, our brains are constantly changing and adapting, and while our nervous system is most plastic when we are very young, as Woodruff's case suggests, it is still capable of remarkable changes later in life."]

['What is the main point of this section?', 'The surface of the brain, known as the cerebral cortex, is very uneven, characterized by a distinctive pattern of folds or bumps, known as gyri (singular: gyrus), and grooves, known as sulci (singular: sulcus), shown in Figure 3.15.']
['What do these bumps represent?', 'These gyri and sulci form important landmarks that allow us to separate the brain into functional centers.']

['What is the most prominent sulcus?', 'The most prominent sulcus, known as the longitudinal fissure, is the deep groove that separates the brain into two halves or hemispheres: the left hemisphere and the right hemisphere.']

['What is evidence of specialization of function—referred to as lateralization—in each hemisphere?', 'There is evidence of specialization of function—referred to as lateralization—in each hemisphere, mainly regarding differences in language functions.']
['Did you find any other interesting thing?', 'The left hemisphere controls the right half of the body, and the right hemisphere controls the left half of the body.']

['Was there anything else that caught your attention?', 'Decades of research on lateralization of function by Michael Gazzaniga and his colleagues suggest that a variety of functions ranging from cause-and-effect reasoning to self-recognition may follow patterns that suggest some degree of hemispheric dominance (Gazzaniga, 2005).']

['What is one example of how the left hemisphere has been shown to be superior for forming associations in memory, selective attention, and positive emotions?', 'For example, the left hemisphere has been shown to be superior for forming associations in memory, selective attention, and positive emotions.']

['What did you find interesting about the right hemisphere?', 'The right hemisphere, on the other hand, has been shown to be superior in pitch perception, arousal, and negative emotions (Ehret, 2006).']

['What is the most important thing to know about the passage?', 'However, it should be pointed out that research on which hemisphere is dominant in a variety of different behaviors has produced inconsistent results, and therefore, it is probably better to think of how the two hemispheres interact to produce a given behavior rather than attributing certain behaviors to one hemisphere versus the other (Banich & Heller, 1998).']
['What does the corpus callosum consist of?', 'The two hemispheres are connected by a thick band of neural fibers known as the corpus callosum, consisting of about 200 million axons.']

['What does the corpus callosum do?', 'The corpus callosum allows the two hemispheres to communicate with each other and allows for information being processed on one side of the brain to be shared with the other side.']

['What are the two hemispheres?', 'Normally, we are not aware of the different roles that our two hemispheres play in day-to-day functions, but there are people who come to know the capabilities and functions of their two hemispheres quite well.']
['What is a way for people to have less of each hemisphere?', 'In some cases of severe epilepsy, doctors elect to sever the corpus callosum as a means of controlling the spread of seizures.']
['How is that different from cutting the brain?', 'While this is an effective treatment option, it results in individuals who have "split brains."']
['What did the scientists do with these split brains?', 'After surgery, these split-brain patients show a variety of interesting behaviors.']

['What is the reason for the variety of behaviors?', 'For instance, a split-brain patient is unable to name a picture that is shown in the patient’s left visual field because the information is only available in the largely nonverbal right hemisphere.']
['How is it described?', 'However, they are able to recreate the picture with their left hand, which is also controlled by the right hemisphere.']

['What happens after the patient recreates the picture?', 'When the more verbal left hemisphere sees the picture that the hand drew, the patient is able to name it (assuming the left hemisphere can interpret what was drawn by the left hand).']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Much of what we know about the functions of different areas of the brain comes from studying changes in the behavior and ability of individuals who have suffered damage to the brain.']
['What does the article say about the brain?', 'For example, researchers study the behavioral changes caused by strokes to learn about the functions of specific brain areas.']
['What does a stroke cause?', 'A stroke, caused by an interruption of blood flow to a region in the brain, causes a loss of brain function in the affected region.']
['How can this cause behavioral changes?', 'The damage can be in a small area, and, if it is, this gives researchers the opportunity to link any resulting behavioral changes to a specific area.']
['What type of deficits will be displayed after a stroke?', 'The types of deficits displayed after a stroke will be largely dependent on where in the brain the damage occurred.']
['What is the first thing we are going to consider?', 'Consider Theona, an intelligent, self-sufficient woman, who is 62 years old.']
['What caused her stroke?', 'Recently, she suffered a stroke in the front portion of her right hemisphere.']
['What happened to her after her stroke?', 'As a result, she has great difficulty moving her left leg.']

['What is the best way to explain this?', '(As you learned earlier, the right hemisphere controls the left side of the body; also, the brain’s main motor centers are located at the front of the head, in the frontal lobe.)']
['What else happened to Theona?', 'Theona has also experienced behavioral changes.']
['What did she do?', 'For example, while in the produce section of the grocery store, she sometimes eats grapes, strawberries, and apples directly from their bins before paying for them.']

['What would have been very embarrassing to her before the stroke?', 'This behavior—which would have been very embarrassing to her before the stroke—is consistent with damage in another region in the frontal lobe—the prefrontal cortex, which is associated with judgment, reasoning, and impulse control.']
['What is the first structure we are studying?', 'The two hemispheres of the cerebral cortex are part of the forebrain, which is the largest part of the brain.']

['What is the forebrain composed of?', 'The forebrain contains the cerebral cortex and a number of other structures that lie beneath the cortex (called subcortical structures): thalamus, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, and the limbic system (a collection of structures).']

['What is the cerebral cortex associated with?', 'The cerebral cortex, which is the outer surface of the brain, is associated with higher level processes such as consciousness, thought, emotion, reasoning, language, and memory.']
['What are the four lobes?', 'Each cerebral hemisphere can be subdivided into four lobes, each associated with different functions.']
['What are the four lobes of the brain?', 'The four lobes of the brain are the frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes.']
['What part of the brain is the frontal lobe located in?', 'The frontal lobe is located in the forward part of the brain, extending back to a fissure known as the central sulcus.']
['What does the frontal lobe do?', 'The frontal lobe is involved in reasoning, motor control, emotion, and language.']

['What is involved in planning and coordinating movement?', 'It contains the motor cortex, which is involved in planning and coordinating movement; the prefrontal cortex, which is responsible for higher-level cognitive functioning; and Broca’s area, which is essential for language production.']
["What is the Broca's area?", 'People who suffer damage to Broca’s area have great difficulty producing language of any form.']
["What is a typical case that would be considered Broca's area?", 'For example, Padma was an electrical engineer who was socially active and a caring, involved parent.']
['What happened to her?', 'About twenty years ago, she was in a car accident and suffered damage to her Broca’s area.']
['What did the damage cause her?', 'She completely lost the ability to speak and form any kind of meaningful language.']
['What was her mouth like?', 'There is nothing wrong with her mouth or her vocal cords, but she is unable to produce words.']
['What was her other communication like?', 'She can follow directions but can’t respond verbally, and she can read but no longer write.']
['How could she do routine tasks?', 'She can do routine tasks like running to the market to buy milk, but she could not communicate verbally if a situation called for it.']
['What was the most famous case of frontal lobe damage?', 'Probably the most famous case of frontal lobe damage is that of a man by the name of Phineas Gage.']
['What happened in 1848?', 'On September 13, 1848, Gage (age 25) was working as a railroad foreman in Vermont.']
['What was he doing as the railroad foreman?', 'He and his crew were using an iron rod to tamp explosives down into a blasting hole to remove rock along the railway’s path.']
['What happened when the iron rod was used?', 'Unfortunately, the iron rod created a spark and caused the rod to explode out of the blasting hole, into Gage’s face, and through his skull.']
['How did Gage react to the injury?', 'Although lying in a pool of his own blood with brain matter emerging from his head, Gage was conscious and able to get up, walk, and speak.']
['What happened to him after the accident?', 'But in the months following his accident, people noticed that his personality had changed.']
['What was his change in personality?', 'Many of his friends described him as no longer being himself.']
['how did he change?', 'Before the accident, it was said that Gage was a well-mannered, soft-spoken man, but he began to behave in odd and inappropriate ways after the accident.']
['What would be consistent with loss of impulse control—a frontal lobe function?', 'Such changes in personality would be consistent with loss of impulse control—a frontal lobe function.']

['What did the damage cause?', "Beyond the damage to the frontal lobe itself, subsequent investigations into the rod's path also identified probable damage to pathways between the frontal lobe and other brain structures, including the limbic system."]

['Did this affect his personality?', 'With connections between the planning functions of the frontal lobe and the emotional processes of the limbic system severed, Gage had difficulty controlling his emotional impulses.']
['Is there any evidence of lobe disease?', 'However, there is some evidence suggesting that the dramatic changes in Gage’s personality were exaggerated and embellished.']

["What did Gage's case involve?", "Gage's case occurred in the midst of a 19th century debate over localization—regarding whether certain areas of the brain are associated with particular functions."]

['What is important about this case?', 'On the basis of extremely limited information about Gage, the extent of his injury, and his life before and after the accident, scientists tended to find support for their own views, on whichever side of the debate they fell (Macmillan, 1999).']
['What is the parietal lobe?', 'The brain’s parietal lobe is located immediately behind the frontal lobe, and is involved in processing information from the body’s senses.']
['What is the somatosensory cortex?', 'It contains the somatosensory cortex, which is essential for processing sensory information from across the body, such as touch, temperature, and pain.']
['What is the somatosensory cortex?', 'The somatosensory cortex is an area of the brain which processes touch and sensation.']
['What is the somatosensory cortex?', 'The somatosensory cortex is fascinating because each different area of the cortex processes sensations from a different part of your body.']

['Why does it do this?', 'Furthermore, the larger the surface area of the specific body part and the greater amount of nerves in that body part, the larger the area dedicated to processing sensation from that body part in the somatosensory cortex.']
['What is the difference between fingers and toes?', 'For example, fingers take up a lot more space than toes.']
['What does this show?', 'As you can notice from, the amount of space to process sensation from fingers is much greater than that of toes.']

['What is the temporal lobe?', 'The temporal lobe is located on the side of the head (temporal means “near the temples”), and is associated with hearing, memory, emotion, and some aspects of language.']
['What is the main area responsible for processing auditory information?', 'The auditory cortex, the main area responsible for processing auditory information, is located within the temporal lobe.']
['What else does it do?', 'Wernicke’s area, important for speech comprehension, is also located here.']

['What else do you find helpful?', 'Whereas individuals with damage to Broca’s area have difficulty producing language, those with damage to Wernicke’s area can produce sensible language, but they are unable to understand it.']

['What is the primary function of the occipital lobe?', 'The occipital lobe is located at the very back of the brain, and contains the primary visual cortex, which is responsible for interpreting incoming visual information.']

['What is a feature of the occipital cortex?', 'The occipital cortex is organized retinotopically, which means there is a close relationship between the position of an object in a person’s visual field and the position of that object’s representation on the cortex.']
['What is the occipital cortex?', 'You will learn much more about how visual information is processed in the occipital lobe when you study sensation and perception.']
['What are some of the other areas of the forebrain?', 'Other areas of the forebrain, located beneath the cerebral cortex, include the thalamus and the limbic system.']
['What does the thalamus relay for the brain?', 'The thalamus is a sensory relay for the brain.']
['What do the senses route through?', 'All of our senses, with the exception of smell, are routed through the thalamus before being directed to other areas of the brain for processing.']
['What is the limbic system involved in?', 'The limbic system is involved in processing both emotion and memory.']

['How does the smell process emotion?', 'Interestingly, the sense of smell projects directly to the limbic system; therefore, not surprisingly, smell can evoke emotional responses in ways that other sensory modalities cannot.']

['What are the three structures of the limbic system?', 'The limbic system is made up of a number of different structures, but three of the most important are the hippocampus, the amygdala, and the hypothalamus.']
['What is the hippocampus?', 'The hippocampus is an essential structure for learning and memory.']
['What is the amygdala involved in?', 'The amygdala is involved in our experience of emotion and in tying emotional meaning to our memories.']
['What is the hypothalamus?', 'The hypothalamus regulates a number of homeostatic processes, including the regulation of body temperature, appetite, and blood pressure.']
['What does the hypothalamus do?', 'The hypothalamus also serves as an interface between the nervous system and the endocrine system and in the regulation of sexual motivation and behavior.']
['What did Henry have that had an effect on him?', 'In 1953, Henry Gustav Molaison (H. M.) was a 27-year-old man who experienced severe seizures.']
['What was the brain surgery to remove?', 'In an attempt to control his seizures, H. M. underwent brain surgery to remove his hippocampus and amygdala.']

['What was the result?', 'Following the surgery, H.M’s seizures became much less severe, but he also suffered some unexpected—and devastating—consequences of the surgery: he lost his ability to form many types of new memories.']
['What were the types of new memories that he lost?', 'For example, he was unable to learn new facts, such as who was president of the United States.']
['What was the worst thing that happened to him after the brain surgery?', 'He was able to learn new skills, but afterward he had no recollection of learning them.']
['What was one skill that he tried to learn?', 'For example, while he might learn to use a computer, he would have no conscious memory of ever having used one.']
['What else was that like?', 'He could not remember new faces, and he was unable to remember events, even immediately after they occurred.']
