['Who is Henry Molaison?', 'Researchers were fascinated by his experience, and he is considered one of the most studied cases in medical and psychological history (Hardt, Einarsson, & Nader, 2010; Squire, 2009).']
['What did the surgery do?', 'Indeed, his case has provided tremendous insight into the role that the hippocampus plays in the consolidation of new learning into explicit memory.']
['What is the midbrain?', 'The midbrain is comprised of structures located deep within the brain, between the forebrain and the hindbrain.']
['What is the reticular formation?', 'The reticular formation is centered in the midbrain, but it actually extends up into the forebrain and down into the hindbrain.']
['What does the reticular formation regulate?', 'The reticular formation is important in regulating the sleep/wake cycle, arousal, alertness, and motor activity.']
['What is the major component of the midbrain?', 'The substantia nigra (Latin for “black substance”) and the ventral tegmental area (VTA) are also located in the midbrain.']
['What are the two regions of the brain that are important for movement?', 'Both regions contain cell bodies that produce the neurotransmitter dopamine, and both are critical for movement.']
['What can happen to these regions?', 'Degeneration of the substantia nigra and VTA is involved in Parkinson’s disease.']
['Why are they important?', 'In addition, these structures are involved in mood, reward, and addiction (Berridge & Robinson, 1998; Gardner, 2011; George, Le Moal, & Koob, 2012).']
['What is the hindbrain?', 'The hindbrain is located at the back of the head and looks like an extension of the spinal cord.']
['What does the brain contain?', 'It contains the medulla, pons, and cerebellum.']
['What does the medulla control?', 'The medulla controls the automatic processes of the autonomic nervous system, such as breathing, blood pressure, and heart rate.']
['What does the pons connect the hindbrain to?', 'The word pons literally means “bridge,” and as the name suggests, the pons serves to connect the hindbrain to the rest of the brain.']
['What does it do?', 'It also is involved in regulating brain activity during sleep.']
['What spans the midbrain and the hindbrain?', 'The medulla, pons, and various structures are known as the brainstem, and aspects of the brainstem span both the midbrain and the hindbrain.']

['What does the cerebellum do?', 'The cerebellum (Latin for “little brain”) receives messages from muscles, tendons, joints, and structures in our ear to control balance, coordination, movement, and motor skills.']
['What is the cerebellum important for?', 'The cerebellum is also thought to be an important area for processing some types of memories.']
['What is the cerebellum involved with?', 'In particular, procedural memory, or memory involved in learning and remembering how to perform tasks, is thought to be associated with the cerebellum.']
['What type of memories are thought to be shaped by the cerebellum?', 'Recall that H. M. was unable to form new explicit memories, but he could learn new tasks.']
['Why was he unable to form new explicit memories?', 'This is likely due to the fact that H. M.’s cerebellum remained intact.']
['What is the first question you have to answer?', 'You have learned how brain injury can provide information about the functions of different parts of the brain.']
['How does the system find out about the brain?', 'Increasingly, however, we are able to obtain that information using brain imaging techniques on individuals who have not suffered brain injury.']

['Are there other methods for imaging the brain?', 'In this section, we take a more in-depth look at some of the techniques that are available for imaging the brain, including techniques that rely on radiation, magnetic fields, or electrical activity within the brain.']
["What's CT scan?", 'A computerized tomography (CT) scan involves taking a number of x-rays of a particular section of a person’s body or brain.']
['What does it do?', 'The x-rays pass through tissues of different densities at different rates, allowing a computer to construct an overall image of the area of the body being scanned.']
['What is a CT scan used for?', 'A CT scan is often used to determine whether someone has a tumor or significant brain atrophy.']
['What is the most important thing that the content talks about?', 'Positron emission tomography (PET) scans create pictures of the living, active brain.']
['What happens during a PET scan?', 'An individual receiving a PET scan drinks or is injected with a mildly radioactive substance, called a tracer.']
['Once in the bloodstream, what happens to the tracer?', 'Once in the bloodstream, the amount of tracer in any given region of the brain can be monitored.']
['How do brain areas become active?', 'As a brain area becomes more active, more blood flows to that area.']
['What is the result of the scan?', 'A computer monitors the movement of the tracer and creates a rough map of active and inactive areas of the brain during a given behavior.']

['What can be inferred from the data?', 'PET scans show little detail, are unable to pinpoint events precisely in time, and require that the brain be exposed to radiation; therefore, this technique has been replaced by the fMRI as an alternative diagnostic tool.']
['What is the comparison to fMRI?', 'However, combined with CT, PET technology is still being used in certain contexts.']
['What is one example of CT/PET scans?', 'For example, CT/PET scans allow better imaging of the activity of neurotransmitter receptors and open new avenues in schizophrenia research.']
['What is CT/PET technology?', 'In this hybrid CT/PET technology, CT contributes clear images of brain structures, while PET shows the brain’s activity.']
['What is the process of magnetic resonance imaging?', 'In magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), a person is placed inside a machine that generates a strong magnetic field.']
['What causes the hydrogen atoms in the body’s cells to move?', 'The magnetic field causes the hydrogen atoms in the body’s cells to move.']

['When the magnetic field is turned off, what happens to the hydrogen atoms?', 'When the magnetic field is turned off, the hydrogen atoms emit electromagnetic signals as they return to their original positions.']
["What can be learned about the body's density?", 'Tissues of different densities give off different signals, which a computer interprets and displays on a monitor.']

['What is another name for magnetic resonance imaging?', 'Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) operates on the same principles, but it shows changes in brain activity over time by tracking blood flow and oxygen levels.']
['What are the advantages of fMRI?', 'The fMRI provides more detailed images of the brain’s structure, as well as better accuracy in time, than is possible in PET scans.']

['What is another advantage of MRI and fMRI?', 'With their high level of detail, MRI and fMRI are often used to compare the brains of healthy individuals to the brains of individuals diagnosed with psychological disorders.']
['What is this used for?', 'This comparison helps determine what structural and functional differences exist between these populations.']

['What are some of the techniques involved in electrical activity?', 'In some situations, it is helpful to gain an understanding of the overall activity of a person’s brain, without needing information on the actual location of the activity.']
['What is EEG?', 'Electroencephalography (EEG) serves this purpose by providing a measure of a brain’s electrical activity.']
['What is done to do the EEG?', 'An array of electrodes is placed around a person’s head.']

['What happens after the electrodes are placed?', 'The signals received by the electrodes result in a printout of the electrical activity of their brain, or brainwaves, showing both the frequency (number of waves per second) and amplitude (height) of the recorded brainwaves, with an accuracy within milliseconds.']
['What happens when this information is recorded?', 'Such information is especially helpful to researchers studying sleep patterns among individuals with sleep disorders.']
['What is the endocrine system?', 'The endocrine system consists of a series of glands that produce chemical substances known as hormones.']
['What do hormones do?', 'Like neurotransmitters, hormones are chemical messengers that must bind to a receptor in order to send their signal.']

['what is special about hormones?', 'However, unlike neurotransmitters, which are released in close proximity to cells with their receptors, hormones are secreted into the bloodstream and travel throughout the body, affecting any cells that contain receptors for them.']
['what does this mean?', 'Thus, whereas neurotransmitters’ effects are localized, the effects of hormones are widespread.']
['Are there any other differences between hormones and neurotransmitters?', 'Also, hormones are slower to take effect, and tend to be longer lasting.']

['What are hormones involved in regulating all sorts of bodily functions?', 'Hormones are involved in regulating all sorts of bodily functions, and they are ultimately controlled through interactions between the hypothalamus (in the central nervous system) and the pituitary gland (in the endocrine system).']
['What are some disorders caused by imbalances of hormones?', 'Imbalances in hormones are related to a number of disorders.']
['What does this section explore?', 'This section explores some of the major glands that make up the endocrine system and the hormones secreted by these glands.']
['What is the pituitary gland?', 'The pituitary gland descends from the hypothalamus at the base of the brain, and acts in close association with it.']

['What is the master gland?', 'The pituitary is often referred to as the “master gland” because its messenger hormones control all the other glands in the endocrine system, although it mostly carries out instructions from the hypothalamus.']

['What does the pituitary secrete?', 'In addition to messenger hormones, the pituitary also secretes growth hormone, endorphins for pain relief, and a number of key hormones that regulate fluid levels in the body.']
['What is the most important characteristic of thyroid gland?', 'Located in the neck, the thyroid gland releases hormones that regulate growth, metabolism, and appetite.']
['What else can thyroid gland do?', 'In hyperthyroidism, or Grave’s disease, the thyroid secretes too much of the hormone thyroxine, causing agitation, bulging eyes, and weight loss.']
['What can this cause?', 'In hypothyroidism, reduced hormone levels cause sufferers to experience tiredness, and they often complain of feeling cold.']
['What can help them?', 'Fortunately, thyroid disorders are often treatable with medications that help reestablish a balance in the hormones secreted by the thyroid.']
['What are the adrenal glands?', 'The adrenal glands sit atop our kidneys and secrete hormones involved in the stress response, such as epinephrine (adrenaline) and norepinephrine (noradrenaline).']
['What is the pancreas?', 'The pancreas is an internal organ that secretes hormones that regulate blood sugar levels: insulin and glucagon.']

['What do these hormones do?', 'These pancreatic hormones are essential for maintaining stable levels of blood sugar throughout the day by lowering blood glucose levels (insulin) or raising them (glucagon).']

['What is the relationship between diabetes and insulin?', 'People who suffer from diabetes do not produce enough insulin; therefore, they must take medications that stimulate or replace insulin production, and they must closely control the amount of sugars and carbohydrates they consume.']
['What is your role in the gonads?', 'The gonads secrete sexual hormones, which are important in reproduction, and mediate both sexual motivation and behavior.']
['What are the female gonads called?', 'The female gonads are the ovaries; the male gonads are the testes.']
['What hormones do the ovaries secrete?', 'Ovaries secrete estrogens and progesterone, and the testes secrete androgens, such as testosterone.']
['What is consciousness?', 'Consciousness describes our awareness of internal and external stimuli.']
['What are some internal stimuli?', 'Awareness of internal stimuli includes feeling pain, hunger, thirst, sleepiness, and being aware of our thoughts and emotions.']

['What are some experiences that are external stimuli?', 'Awareness of external stimuli includes experiences such as seeing the light from the sun, feeling the warmth of a room, and hearing the voice of a friend.']
['What does consciousness mean?', 'We experience different states of consciousness and different levels of awareness on a regular basis.']
['Are we all conscious?', 'We might even describe consciousness as a continuum that ranges from full awareness to a deep sleep.']

['What is the state of consciousness?', 'Sleep is a state marked by relatively low levels of physical activity and reduced sensory awareness that is distinct from periods of rest that occur during wakefulness.']
['What is the difference between wakefulness and sleep?', 'Wakefulness is characterized by high levels of sensory awareness, thought, and behavior.']
['What are other states?', 'Beyond being awake or asleep, there are many other states of consciousness people experience.']
['What are some examples of other states?', 'These include daydreaming, intoxication, and unconsciousness due to anesthesia.']
['Are these drug-induced?', 'We might also experience unconscious states of being via drug-induced anesthesia for medical purposes.']
['Are there other states of consciousness?', 'Often, we are not completely aware of our surroundings, even when we are fully awake.']
['How is this different from intoxication?', 'You were capable of engaging in the all of the complex tasks involved with operating a motor vehicle even though you were not aware of doing so.']
['What is the origin of these processes?', 'Many of these processes, like much of psychological behavior, are rooted in our biology.']
['What is the internal rhythm of biological activity called?', 'Biological rhythms are internal rhythms of biological activity.']
['Can you tell me what a menstrual cycle is?', 'A woman’s menstrual cycle is an example of a biological rhythm—a recurring, cyclical pattern of bodily changes.']
['How long does a menstrual cycle last?', 'One complete menstrual cycle takes about 28 days—a lunar month—but many biological cycles are much shorter.']
['How long does the body temperature fluctuate?', 'For example, body temperature fluctuates cyclically over a 24-hour period.']
['What is the relationship between body temperature and alertness?', 'Alertness is associated with higher body temperatures, and sleepiness with lower body temperatures.']

['What is the pattern of temperature fluctuation, which repeats every day, is one example of a circadian rhythm?', 'This pattern of temperature fluctuation, which repeats every day, is one example of a circadian rhythm.']
['What is a circadian rhythm?', 'A circadian rhythm is a biological rhythm that takes place over a period of about 24 hours.']

['What are some other examples of circadian rhythms?', 'Our sleep-wake cycle, which is linked to our environment’s natural light-dark cycle, is perhaps the most obvious example of a circadian rhythm, but we also have daily fluctuations in heart rate, blood pressure, blood sugar, and body temperature.']
['What role do circadian rhythms play in the world of humans?', 'Some circadian rhythms play a role in changes in our state of consciousness.']
['What is the main center of homeostasis?', 'In the brain, the hypothalamus, which lies above the pituitary gland, is a main center of homeostasis.']
['What is the tendency to maintain a balance, or optimal level, within a biological system?', 'Homeostasis is the tendency to maintain a balance, or optimal level, within a biological system.']
['Where is the brain’s clock mechanism located?', 'The brain’s clock mechanism is located in an area of the hypothalamus known as the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN).']

['what is the retina?', 'The axons of light-sensitive neurons in the retina provide information to the SCN based on the amount of light present, allowing this internal clock to be synchronized with the outside world (Klein, Moore, & Reppert, 1991; Welsh, Takahashi, & Kay, 2010).']
['What do the circadian cycles mean?', 'Generally, and for most people, our circadian cycles are aligned with the outside world.']
['What are some examples of a circadian rhythm?', 'For example, most people sleep during the night and are awake during the day.']
['What is one important regulator of sleep-wake cycles?', 'One important regulator of sleep-wake cycles is the hormone melatonin.']

['What is the pineal gland?', 'The pineal gland, an endocrine structure located inside the brain that releases melatonin, is thought to be involved in the regulation of various biological rhythms and of the immune system during sleep (Hardeland, Pandi-Perumal, & Cardinali, 2006).']
['What inhibits it?', 'Melatonin release is stimulated by darkness and inhibited by light.']
['Are there any other things you can tell me about this article?', 'There are individual differences in regard to our sleep-wake cycle.']
['What kind of differences do people have?', 'For instance, some people would say they are morning people, while others would consider themselves to be night owls.']

['What does it mean that they have different sleep-wake cycles?', 'These individual differences in circadian patterns of activity are known as a person’s chronotype, and research demonstrates that morning larks and night owls differ with regard to sleep regulation (Taillard, Philip, Coste, Sagaspe, & Bioulac, 2003).']

['What is the brain’s control of switching between sleep and wakefulness as well as coordinating this cycle with the outside world?', 'Sleep regulation refers to the brain’s control of switching between sleep and wakefulness as well as coordinating this cycle with the outside world.']

['What are the types of disruptions that can cause circadian disruptions?', 'Whether lark, owl, or somewhere in between, there are situations in which a person’s circadian clock gets out of synchrony with the external environment.']
['What happens when this happens?', 'One way that this happens involves traveling across multiple time zones.']
['What happens when we do this?', 'When we do this, we often experience jet lag.']
['What are the symptoms of jet lag?', 'Jet lag is a collection of symptoms that results from the mismatch between our internal circadian cycles and our environment.']

['What other symptoms does it have?', 'These symptoms include fatigue, sluggishness, irritability, and insomnia (i.e., a consistent difficulty in falling or staying asleep for at least three nights a week over a month’s time) (Roth, 2007).']
['What does this paper have to do with individuals who do rotating shift work?', 'Individuals who do rotating shift work are also likely to experience disruptions in circadian cycles.']
['What is the difference between a rotating shift and a regular shift?', 'Rotating shift work refers to a work schedule that changes from early to late on a daily or weekly basis.']
['What is the schedule for a person?', 'For example, a person may work from 7:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. on Monday, 3:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. on Tuesday, and 11:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. on Wednesday.']

['What is disrupted when the individual’s schedule changes so frequently?', 'In such instances, the individual’s schedule changes so frequently that it becomes difficult for a normal circadian rhythm to be maintained.']
['What happens when you have disruptions in your sleep?', 'This often results in sleeping problems, and it can lead to signs of depression and anxiety.']

['What are the outcomes of this work?', 'These kinds of schedules are common for individuals working in health care professions and service industries, and they are associated with persistent feelings of exhaustion and agitation that can make someone more prone to making mistakes on the job (Gold et al., 1992; Presser, 1995).']

['What is one of the findings in your paper?', 'Rotating shift work has pervasive effects on the lives and experiences of individuals engaged in that kind of work, which is clearly illustrated in stories reported in a qualitative study that researched the experiences of middle-aged nurses who worked rotating shifts (West, Boughton & Byrnes, 2009).']
['What other findings did you find?', 'Several of the nurses interviewed commented that their work schedules affected their relationships with their family.']
['What did the nurses say?', 'One of the nurses said,']

['What can disrupt normal sleep?', 'While disruptions in circadian rhythms can have negative consequences, there are things we can do to help us realign our biological clocks with the external environment.']

['Are there any other aspects we should know about?', 'Some of these approaches, such as using a bright light as shown in Figure 4.4, have been shown to alleviate some of the problems experienced by individuals suffering from jet lag or from the consequences of rotating shift work.']

['How does using a bright light help combat insomnia?', 'Because the biological clock is driven by light, exposure to bright light during working shifts and dark exposure when not working can help combat insomnia and symptoms of anxiety and depression (Huang, Tsai, Chen, & Hsu, 2013).']
['What does sleep debt mean?', 'When people have difficulty getting sleep due to their work or the demands of day-to-day life, they accumulate a sleep debt.']
["What happens if people don't get sufficient sleep?", 'A person with a sleep debt does not get sufficient sleep on a chronic basis.']
['What is the result of insufficient sleep?', 'The consequences of sleep debt include decreased levels of alertness and mental efficiency.']
['What can you tell me about the modern work force?', 'Interestingly, since the advent of electric light, the amount of sleep that people get has declined.']

['What has caused people to sleep less?', 'While we certainly welcome the convenience of having the darkness lit up, we also suffer the consequences of reduced amounts of sleep because we are more active during the nighttime hours than our ancestors were.']
['What is the result of people sleeping less than 7–8 hours a night?', 'As a result, many of us sleep less than 7–8 hours a night and accrue a sleep debt.']

['What is the recommendation on sleep?', 'While there is tremendous variation in any given individual’s sleep needs, the National Sleep Foundation (n.d.) cites research to estimate that newborns require the most sleep (between 12 and 18 hours a night) and that this amount declines to just 7–9 hours by the time we are adults.']
['What happens when you have too little sleep?', 'If you lie down to take a nap and fall asleep very easily, chances are you may have sleep debt.']

['who does that affect?', 'Given that college students are notorious for suffering from significant sleep debt (Hicks, Fernandez, & Pellegrini, 2001; Hicks, Johnson, & Pellegrini, 1992; Miller, Shattuck, & Matsangas, 2010), chances are you and your classmates deal with sleep debt-related issues on a regular basis.']
['What was the recommended sleep length in 2015?', 'In 2015, the National Sleep Foundation updated their sleep duration hours, to better accommodate individual differences.']
['What is the table that was mentioned?', 'Table 4.1 shows the new recommendations, which describe sleep durations that are “recommended”, “may be appropriate”, and “not recommended”.']

['What are the negative psychological and physiological consequences of insufficient sleep?', 'Sleep debt and sleep deprivation have significant negative psychological and physiological consequences Figure 4.5.']
['What are the consequences of lack of sleep?', 'As mentioned earlier, lack of sleep can result in decreased mental alertness and cognitive function.']
['What are the other consequences of sleep deprivation?', 'In addition, sleep deprivation often results in depression-like symptoms.']

['What can occur as a function of accumulated sleep debt or in response to more acute periods of sleep deprivation?', 'These effects can occur as a function of accumulated sleep debt or in response to more acute periods of sleep deprivation.']

['What is the main point of this article?', 'It may surprise you to know that sleep deprivation is associated with obesity, increased blood pressure, increased levels of stress hormones, and reduced immune functioning (Banks & Dinges, 2007).']
['What are some other effects of sleep deprivation?', 'A sleep deprived individual generally will fall asleep more quickly than if they were not sleep deprived.']
['Why would they do this?', 'Some sleep-deprived individuals have difficulty staying awake when they stop moving (example sitting and watching television or driving a car).']

['How does this affect driving?', 'That is why individuals suffering from sleep deprivation can also put themselves and others at risk when they put themselves behind the wheel of a car or work with dangerous machinery.']

['What does sleep deprivation affect?', 'Some research suggests that sleep deprivation affects cognitive and motor function as much as, if not more than, alcohol intoxication (Williamson & Feyer, 2000).']

['What are the most severe effects of sleep deprivation?', 'Research shows that the most severe effects of sleep deprivation occur when a person stays awake for more than 24 hours (Killgore & Weber, 2014; Killgore et al., 2007), or following repeated nights with fewer than four hours in bed (Wickens, Hutchins, Lauk, Seebook, 2015).']
['What are the effects of a lack of sleep?', 'For example, irritability, distractibility, and impairments in cognitive and moral judgment can occur with fewer than four hours of sleep.']
['What happens if someone stays awake for 48 consecutive hours?', 'If someone stays awake for 48 consecutive hours, they could start to hallucinate.']
['How much sleep do people need?', 'The amount of sleep we get varies across the lifespan.']
['What is the average amount of sleep that people get per day?', 'When we are very young, we spend up to 16 hours a day sleeping.']
['What is the average sleep time of older adults?', 'As we grow older, we sleep less.']

['what does the average sleep per day do?', 'In fact, a meta-analysis, which is a study that combines the results of many related studies, conducted within the last decade indicates that by the time we are 65 years old, we average fewer than 7 hours of sleep per day (Ohayon, Carskadon, Guilleminault, & Vitiello, 2004).']
['What is the first fact in your answer?', 'We spend approximately one-third of our lives sleeping.']

['How many years of our lives do we spend sleeping?', 'Given the average life expectancy for U.S. citizens falls between 73 and 79 years old (Singh & Siahpush, 2006), we can expect to spend approximately 25 years of our lives sleeping.']

['What is the next fact in your answer?', 'Some animals never sleep (e.g., some fish and amphibian species); other animals sleep very little without apparent negative consequences (e.g., giraffes); yet some animals (e.g., rats) die after two weeks of sleep deprivation (Siegel, 2008).']
['What is the next fact?', 'This section will consider these questions and explore various explanations for why we sleep.']
['What is one of the important ideas that we have read?', 'You have read that sleep is distinguished by low levels of physical activity and reduced sensory awareness.']

['What is another concept we have learned?', 'As discussed by Siegel (2008), a definition of sleep must also include mention of the interplay of the circadian and homeostatic mechanisms that regulate sleep.']
['What is the homeostatic regulation of sleep?', 'Homeostatic regulation of sleep is evidenced by sleep rebound following sleep deprivation.']

['What is the term for the fact that a sleep-deprived individual will fall asleep more quickly during subsequent opportunities for sleep?', 'Sleep rebound refers to the fact that a sleep-deprived individual will fall asleep more quickly during subsequent opportunities for sleep.']

['What else do we know about sleep?', 'Sleep is characterized by certain patterns of activity of the brain that can be visualized using electroencephalography (EEG), and different phases of sleep can be differentiated using EEG as well.']
['What other interesting facts did you find while studying what is sleep?', 'Sleep-wake cycles seem to be controlled by multiple brain areas acting in conjunction with one another.']
['What are some of these brain areas?', 'Some of these areas include the thalamus, the hypothalamus, and the pons.']

['What is important about the hypothalamus?', 'As already mentioned, the hypothalamus contains the SCN—the biological clock of the body—in addition to other nuclei that, in conjunction with the thalamus, regulate slow-wave sleep.']
['What is important about the pons?', 'The pons is important for regulating rapid eye movement (REM) sleep (National Institutes of Health, n.d.).']

['What is sleep associated with?', 'Sleep is also associated with the secretion and regulation of a number of hormones from several endocrine glands including: melatonin, follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), and growth hormone (National Institutes of Health, n.d.).']
['What does the pineal gland release during sleep?', 'You have read that the pineal gland releases melatonin during sleep.']
['What is it associated with?', 'Melatonin is thought to be involved in the regulation of various biological rhythms and the immune system (Hardeland et al., 2006).']

['What else is the pineal gland associated with?', 'During sleep, the pituitary gland secretes both FSH and LH which are important in regulating the reproductive system (Christensen et al., 2012; Sofikitis et al., 2008).']

['What else is it associated with?', 'The pituitary gland also secretes growth hormone, during sleep, which plays a role in physical growth and maturation as well as other metabolic processes (Bartke, Sun, & Longo, 2013).']

['What is the content of this passage?', 'Given the central role that sleep plays in our lives and the number of adverse consequences that have been associated with sleep deprivation, one would think that we would have a clear understanding of why it is that we sleep.']
['What is the content about?', 'Unfortunately, this is not the case; however, several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the function of sleep.']
['What is a hypothesis in relation to sleep?', 'One popular hypothesis of sleep incorporates the perspective of evolutionary psychology.']

['What is the discipline that studies how universal patterns of behavior and cognitive processes have evolved over time as a result of natural selection?', 'Evolutionary psychology is a discipline that studies how universal patterns of behavior and cognitive processes have evolved over time as a result of natural selection.']

['What do you think about this hypothesis?', 'Variations and adaptations in cognition and behavior make individuals more or less successful in reproducing and passing their genes to their offspring.']
["What is the most important factor in a person's survival?", 'One hypothesis from this perspective might argue that sleep is essential to restore resources that are expended during the day.']
['What is the reason that people sleep at night?', 'Just as bears hibernate in the winter when resources are scarce, perhaps people sleep at night to reduce their energy expenditures.']
['Are there any other hypotheses in relation to this?', 'While this is an intuitive explanation of sleep, there is little research that supports this explanation.']

['How does the energy expenditure relate to sleep?', 'In fact, it has been suggested that there is no reason to think that energetic demands could not be addressed with periods of rest and inactivity (Frank, 2006; Rial et al., 2007), and some research has actually found a negative correlation between energetic demands and the amount of time spent sleeping (Capellini, Barton, McNamara, Preston, & Nunn, 2008).']

['What is another evolutionary hypothesis of sleep?', 'Another evolutionary hypothesis of sleep holds that our sleep patterns evolved as an adaptive response to predatory risks, which increase in darkness.']
['What is the appealing explanation of this hypothesis?', 'Thus we sleep in safe areas to reduce the chance of harm.']
['Are there any other interesting things about the article?', 'Again, this is an intuitive and appealing explanation for why we sleep.']
['What is the most likely explanation for the evolution of sleep?', 'Perhaps our ancestors spent extended periods of time asleep to reduce attention to themselves from potential predators.']
['What is the evidence of this hypothesis?', 'Comparative research indicates, however, that the relationship that exists between predatory risk and sleep is very complex and equivocal.']

['Did this research help with any other explanations?', 'Some research suggests that species that face higher predatory risks sleep fewer hours than other species (Capellini et al., 2008), while other researchers suggest there is no relationship between the amount of time a given species spends in deep sleep and its predation risk (Lesku, Roth, Amlaner, & Lima, 2006).']

['What is the most important detail about the passage?', 'It is quite possible that sleep serves no single universally adaptive function, and different species have evolved different patterns of sleep in response to their unique evolutionary pressures.']

['Did it tell me anything else about sleep?', 'While we have discussed the negative outcomes associated with sleep deprivation, it should be pointed out that there are many benefits that are associated with adequate amounts of sleep.']

['What are some benefits of getting enough sleep?', 'A few such benefits listed by the National Sleep Foundation (n.d.) include maintaining healthy weight, lowering stress levels, improving mood, and increasing motor coordination, as well as a number of benefits related to cognition and memory formation.']

['What is another theory regarding why we sleep?', 'Another theory regarding why we sleep involves sleep’s importance for cognitive function and memory formation (Rattenborg, Lesku, Martinez-Gonzalez, & Lima, 2007).']

['What is the effect of sleep deprivation on cognition and memory deficits?', 'Indeed, we know sleep deprivation results in disruptions in cognition and memory deficits (Brown, 2012), leading to impairments in our abilities to maintain attention, make decisions, and recall long-term memories.']

['What impairments become more severe as the amount of sleep deprivation increases?', 'Moreover, these impairments become more severe as the amount of sleep deprivation increases (Alhola & Polo-Kantola, 2007).']

['What is the result of slow-wave sleep after learning a new task?', 'Furthermore, slow-wave sleep after learning a new task can improve resultant performance on that task (Huber, Ghilardi, Massimini, & Tononi, 2004) and seems essential for effective memory formation (Stickgold, 2005).']

['What is the impact of sleep on cognitive function?', 'Understanding the impact of sleep on cognitive function should help you understand that cramming all night for a test may be not effective and can even prove counterproductive.']
['What is the content of the passage?', 'Getting the optimal amount of sleep has also been associated with other cognitive benefits.']

['What kind of benefits are there?', 'Research indicates that included among these possible benefits are increased capacities for creative thinking (Cai, Mednick, Harrison, Kanady, & Mednick, 2009; Wagner, Gais, Haider, Verleger, & Born, 2004), language learning (Fenn, Nusbaum, & Margoliash, 2003; Gómez, Bootzin, & Nadel, 2006), and inferential judgments (Ellenbogen, Hu, Payne, Titone, & Walker, 2007).']
['What else is there?', 'It is possible that even the processing of emotional information is influenced by certain aspects of sleep (Walker, 2009).']
['What is the uniform state of being?', 'Sleep is not a uniform state of being.']
['What is sleep?', 'Instead, sleep is composed of several different stages that can be differentiated from one another by the patterns of brain wave activity that occur during each stage.']
['What is the brain wave activity that is dominated by beta waves?', 'While awake, our brain wave activity is dominated by beta waves.']
['what else are they?', 'As compared to the brain wave patterns while asleep, beta waves have the highest frequency (13–30 Hz) and lowest amplitude, and they tend to show more variability.']
['What happens to the brain wave activity as you fall asleep?', 'As we begin to fall asleep, our brain wave activity changes.']

['What can be visualized using an EEG and are distinguished from one another by both the frequency and amplitude of the brain wave?', 'These changes can be visualized using an EEG and are distinguished from one another by both the frequency and amplitude of the brain wave.']
['What is the frequency of a brain wave?', 'The frequency of a brain wave is how many brain waves occur in a second, and frequency is measured in Hertz (Hz).']
['What is the height of the brain wave?', 'Amplitude is the height of the brain wave.']
['What are the two stages of sleep?', 'Sleep can be divided into two different general phases: REM sleep and non-REM (NREM) sleep.']
['What is REM sleep characterized by?', 'Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep is characterized by darting movements of the eyes under closed eyelids.']
['What is interesting about REM sleep?', 'Brain waves during REM sleep appear very similar to brain waves during wakefulness.']
['what else?', 'In contrast, non-REM (NREM) sleep is subdivided into three stages distinguished from each other and from wakefulness by characteristic patterns of brain waves.']
['What is the third stage of sleep?', 'The first three stages of sleep are NREM sleep, typically followed by REM sleep.']
['What was mentioned in the passage?', 'In this section, we will discuss each of these stages of sleep and their associated patterns of brain wave activity.']
['What are the stages of sleep that are known as NREM sleep?', 'As we begin to fall asleep, we enter NREM sleep, and brain wave patterns decrease in frequency and increase in amplitude.']
['What is the stage number of NREM sleep?', 'The first stage of NREM sleep is known as stage 1 sleep.']
['What is the transitional phase between wakefulness and sleep?', 'Stage 1 sleep is a transitional phase that occurs between wakefulness and sleep, the period during which we drift off to sleep.']
['During this time, what happens to the rate of respiration and heartbeat?', 'During this time, there is a slowdown in both the rates of respiration and heartbeat.']
['what else is going on during this time?', 'In addition, stage 1 sleep involves a marked decrease in both overall muscle tension and core body temperature.']
['What is the brain wave activity associated with stage 1 sleep?', 'In terms of brain wave activity, stage 1 sleep is associated with both alpha and theta waves.']
['What is the early portion of stage 1 sleep?', 'The early portion of stage 1 sleep produces alpha waves.']

['how do they look when the individual is awake?', 'These patterns of electrical activity (waves) resemble that of someone who is very relaxed, yet awake, but they have less variability (are more synchronized) and are relatively lower in frequency (8–12 Hz) and higher in amplitude than beta waves.']
['what happens as they progress through Stage 1?', 'As an individual continues through stage 1 sleep, there is an increase in theta wave activity.']
['What happens with theta waves?', 'Theta waves are even lower frequency (4–7 Hz), and higher in amplitude, than the alpha wave patterns.']
['What happens in stage 1 sleep?', 'It is relatively easy to wake someone from stage 1 sleep; in fact, people often report that they have not been asleep if they are awoken during stage 1 sleep.']
['What is the body doing as it moves into stage 2 sleep?', 'As we move into stage 2 sleep, the body goes into a state of deep relaxation.']
['What is theta wave dominance?', 'Theta waves still dominate the activity of the brain, but they are interrupted by brief bursts of activity known as sleep spindles.']
['what are sleep spindles?', 'A sleep spindle is a rapid burst of higher frequency brain waves that may be important for learning and memory (Fogel & Smith, 2011; Poe, Walsh, & Bjorness, 2010).']
['what are K complexes?', 'In addition, the appearance of K-complexes is often associated with stage 2 sleep.']
['What is a K-complex?', 'A K-complex is a very high amplitude pattern of brain activity that may in some cases occur in response to environmental stimuli.']
['what are the stimuli?', 'Thus, K-complexes might serve as a bridge to higher levels of arousal in response to what is going on in our environments (Halász, 1993; Steriade & Amzica, 1998).']

['What is the third stage of sleep?', 'NREM stage 3 sleep is often referred to as deep sleep or slow-wave sleep because this stage is characterized by low frequency (less than 3 Hz), high amplitude delta waves.']
['What are the delta waves?', 'These delta waves have the lowest frequency and highest amplitude of our sleeping brain wave patterns.']

['What else do we learn about the third stage of sleep?', 'During this time, an individual’s heart rate and respiration slow dramatically, and it is much more difficult to awaken someone from sleep during stage 3 than during earlier stages.']

['Do you know anything else about this stage?', 'Interestingly, individuals who have increased levels of alpha brain wave activity (more often associated with wakefulness and transition into stage 1 sleep) during stage 3 often report that they do not feel refreshed upon waking, regardless of how long they slept (Stone, Taylor, McCrae, Kalsekar, & Lichstein, 2008).']
['What is REM sleep?', 'As mentioned earlier, REM sleep is marked by rapid movements of the eyes.']

['What happens with these rapid movements of the eyes?', 'The brain waves associated with this stage of sleep are very similar to those observed when a person is awake, as shown in Figure 4.11, and this is the period of sleep in which dreaming occurs.']

['Are there any other interesting things about REM sleep?', 'It is also associated with paralysis of muscle systems in the body with the exception of those that make circulation and respiration possible.']

['What is the combination of high brain activity and lack of muscle tone called?', 'Therefore, no movement of voluntary muscles occurs during REM sleep in a normal individual; REM sleep is often referred to as paradoxical sleep because of this combination of high brain activity and lack of muscle tone.']
['What does the paradoxical sleep mean?', 'Like NREM sleep, REM has been implicated in various aspects of learning and memory (Wagner, Gais, & Born, 2001; Siegel, 2001).']

['What can you tell me about the content of this document?', 'If people are deprived of REM sleep and then allowed to sleep without disturbance, they will spend more time in REM sleep in what would appear to be an effort to recoup the lost time in REM.']
['What does this attempt mean?', 'This is known as the REM rebound, and it suggests that REM sleep is also homeostatically regulated.']

['What role does REM sleep play in processes related to learning and memory?', 'Aside from the role that REM sleep may play in processes related to learning and memory, REM sleep may also be involved in emotional processing and regulation.']

['How does it affect this?', 'In such instances, REM rebound may actually represent an adaptive response to stress in nondepressed individuals by suppressing the emotional salience of aversive events that occurred in wakefulness (Suchecki, Tiba, & Machado, 2012).']
['What is the most important thing to remember about sleep deprivation?', 'Sleep deprivation in general is associated with a number of negative consequences (Brown, 2012).']
['What is the definition of dreaming?', 'Dreams and their associated meanings vary across different cultures and periods of time.']
['What did Freud do?', 'By the late 19th century, Austrian psychiatrist Sigmund Freud had become convinced that dreams represented an opportunity to gain access to the unconscious.']

['What did Freud think people could gain from dream interpretation?', 'By analyzing dreams, Freud thought people could increase self-awareness and gain valuable insight to help them deal with the problems they faced in their lives.']
['What did Freud make distinctions between?', 'Freud made distinctions between the manifest content and the latent content of dreams.']
['What is manifest content?', 'Manifest content is the actual content, or storyline, of a dream.']
['What is latent content?', 'Latent content, on the other hand, refers to the hidden meaning of a dream.']

['What did Freud interpret dreams as?', 'For instance, if a woman dreams about being chased by a snake, Freud might have argued that this represents the woman’s fear of sexual intimacy, with the snake serving as a symbol of a man’s penis.']
['What was the theory behind the title of our study material?', 'Freud was not the only theorist to focus on the content of dreams.']

['Who believed that dreams allowed us to tap into the collective unconscious?', 'The 20th century Swiss psychiatrist Carl Jung believed that dreams allowed us to tap into the collective unconscious.']
['What is the collective unconscious?', 'The collective unconscious, as described by Jung, is a theoretical repository of information he believed to be shared by everyone.']

['What did he believe the dreams would reflect?', 'According to Jung, certain symbols in dreams reflected universal archetypes with meanings that are similar for all people regardless of culture or location.']
['What does Rosalind believe about dreams?', 'The sleep and dreaming researcher Rosalind Cartwright, however, believes that dreams simply reflect life events that are important to the dreamer.']
['What is her most popular claim?', 'Unlike Freud and Jung, Cartwright’s ideas about dreaming have found empirical support.']

['What is the evidence for her ideas?', 'For example, she and her colleagues published a study in which women going through divorce were asked several times over a five month period to report the degree to which their former spouses were on their minds.']
['What other information is known about this study?', 'These same women were awakened during REM sleep in order to provide a detailed account of their dream content.']

['What did they interpret their dream content as?', 'There was a significant positive correlation between the degree to which women thought about their former spouses during waking hours and the number of times their former spouses appeared as characters in their dreams (Cartwright, Agargun, Kirkby, & Friedman, 2006).']

['What else did she do?', 'Recent research (Horikawa, Tamaki, Miyawaki, & Kamitani, 2013) has uncovered new techniques by which researchers may effectively detect and classify the visual images that occur during dreaming by using fMRI for neural measurement of brain activity patterns, opening the way for additional research in this area.']
["What is Hobson's role in the activation-synthesis theory of dreaming?", 'Alan Hobson, a neuroscientist, is credited for developing activation-synthesis theory of dreaming.']

['What is the activation synthesis theory?', 'Early versions of this theory proposed that dreams were not the meaning-filled representations of angst proposed by Freud and others, but were rather the result of our brain attempting to make sense of ("synthesize") the neural activity ("activation") that was happening during REM sleep.']
['What are the latest adaptations?', 'Recent adaptations (e.g., Hobson, 2002) continue to update the theory based on accumulating evidence.']
['What can you tell me about Hobson and the dream state?', 'For example, Hobson (2009) suggests that dreaming may represent a state of protoconsciousness.']

['What does he mean by "dreaming involves constructing a virtual reality in our heads that we might use to help us during wakefulness."?', 'In other words, dreaming involves constructing a virtual reality in our heads that we might use to help us during wakefulness.']
['Who else supports this view?', 'Among a variety of neurobiological evidence, John Hobson cites research on lucid dreams as an opportunity to better understand dreaming in general.']
['What is lucid dreaming?', 'Lucid dreams are dreams in which certain aspects of wakefulness are maintained during a dream state.']
['What is the purpose of a lucid dream?', 'In a lucid dream, a person becomes aware of the fact that they are dreaming, and as such, they can control the dream’s content (LaBerge, 1990).']
['What is the main point of the passage?', 'Many people experience disturbances in their sleep at some point in their lives.']

['According to the passage, what percentage of people experience disturbances?', 'Depending on the population and sleep disorder being studied, between 30% and 50% of the population suffers from a sleep disorder at some point in their lives (Bixler, Kales, Soldatos, Kaels, & Healey, 1979; Hossain & Shapiro, 2002; Ohayon, 1997, 2002; Ohayon & Roth, 2002).']
['What are some disorders that are described in this section?', 'This section will describe several sleep disorders as well as some of their treatment options.']
['What is the most common of its type?', 'Insomnia, a consistent difficulty in falling or staying asleep, is the most common of the sleep disorders.']
['Are there any other interesting details about this text?', 'Individuals with insomnia often experience long delays between the times that they go to bed and actually fall asleep.']
['Why can that be?', 'In addition, these individuals may wake up several times during the night only to find that they have difficulty getting back to sleep.']

['What is the criteria for insomnia?', 'As mentioned earlier, one of the criteria for insomnia involves experiencing these symptoms for at least three nights a week for at least one month’s time (Roth, 2007).']

['What is something that people have trouble with that is related to the study material?', 'It is not uncommon for people suffering from insomnia to experience increased levels of anxiety about their inability to fall asleep.']

['What happens in this cycle?', 'This becomes a self-perpetuating cycle because increased anxiety leads to increased arousal, and higher levels of arousal make the prospect of falling asleep even more unlikely.']
['Is there anything else that can be found that can help them to sleep?', 'Chronic insomnia is almost always associated with feeling overtired and may be associated with symptoms of depression.']
['What are some of the factors that contribute to insomnia?', 'There may be many factors that contribute to insomnia, including age, drug use, exercise, mental status, and bedtime routines.']
['What is the treatment for insomnia?', 'Not surprisingly, insomnia treatment may take one of several different approaches.']

['What other treatments do people have for insomnia?', 'People who suffer from insomnia might limit their use of stimulant drugs (such as caffeine) or increase their amount of physical exercise during the day.']

['What are some of the side effects of sleeping pills?', 'Some people might turn to over-the-counter (OTC) or prescribed sleep medications to help them sleep, but this should be done sparingly because many sleep medications result in dependence and alter the nature of the sleep cycle, and they can increase insomnia over time.']
['what is the quality of life?', 'Those who continue to have insomnia, particularly if it affects their quality of life, should seek professional treatment.']
['What kind of psychotherapy can help people with insomnia?', 'Some forms of psychotherapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy, can help sufferers of insomnia.']
['What is cognitive-behavioral therapy?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy is a type of psychotherapy that focuses on cognitive processes and problem behaviors.']

['What are some ways you can treat insomnia with behavioral therapy?', 'The treatment of insomnia likely would include stress management techniques and changes in problematic behaviors that could contribute to insomnia (e.g., spending more waking time in bed).']

['Do studies support the use of behavioral therapy to treat insomnia?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy has been demonstrated to be quite effective in treating insomnia (Savard, Simard, Ivers, & Morin, 2005; Williams, Roth, Vatthauer, & McCrae, 2013).']
['What is a parasomnia?', 'A parasomnia is one of a group of sleep disorders in which unwanted, disruptive motor activity and/or experiences during sleep play a role.']
['What phase of sleep do these experiences occur?', 'Parasomnias can occur in either REM or NREM phases of sleep.']
['What are some of the symptoms of parasomnias?', 'Sleepwalking, restless leg syndrome, and night terrors are all examples of parasomnias (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000).']
['what complex behaviors ranging?', 'In sleepwalking, or somnambulism, the sleeper engages in relatively complex behaviors ranging from wandering about to driving an automobile.']
['What happens during a period of sleepwalking?', 'During periods of sleepwalking, sleepers often have their eyes open, but they are not responsive to attempts to communicate with them.']

['What happens during the sleep period?', 'Sleepwalking most often occurs during slow-wave sleep, but it can occur at any time during a sleep period in some affected individuals (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000).']
['What has been the history of somnambulism?', 'Historically, somnambulism has been treated with a variety of pharmacotherapies ranging from benzodiazepines to antidepressants.']
['How is this treatment done?', 'However, the success rate of such treatments is questionable.']
['Are there any other medications that can help?', 'Guilleminault et al. (2005) found that sleepwalking was not alleviated with the use of benzodiazepines.']

['What did they find?', 'However, all of their somnambulistic patients who also suffered from sleep-related breathing problems showed a marked decrease in sleepwalking when their breathing problems were effectively treated.']
['What can be learnt from the information of our study material?', 'REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) occurs when the muscle paralysis associated with the REM sleep phase does not occur.']
['What can be the reason of this issue?', 'Individuals who suffer from RBD have high levels of physical activity during REM sleep, especially during disturbing dreams.']

['What can happen as a result of these?', 'People who suffer from this disorder can injure themselves or their sleeping partners when engaging in these behaviors.']
['What else can happen with RBD?', 'Furthermore, these types of behaviors ultimately disrupt sleep, although affected individuals have no memories that these behaviors have occurred (Arnulf, 2012).']
['What is this disorder related to?', 'This disorder is associated with a number of neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson’s disease.']

['Is there anything else interesting that you can tell me about RBD?', 'As part of treatment, the sleeping environment is often modified to make it a safer place for those suffering from RBD (Zangini, Calandra-Buonaura, Grimaldi, & Cortelli, 2011).']

['What is the main information from this document?', 'Night terrors result in a sense of panic in the sufferer and are often accompanied by screams and attempts to escape from the immediate environment (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000).']

['How is sleep affected by sleep apnea?', 'While individuals suffering from sleep apnea may not be aware of these repeated disruptions in sleep, they do experience increased levels of fatigue.']

['What is the cause of sleep apnea?', 'Surprisingly, sleep apnea may exacerbate cardiovascular disease (Sánchez-de-la-Torre, Campos-Rodriguez, & Barbé, 2012).']

['Did they notice a pattern?', 'It was getting to the point where it was kind of scary” (Henry & Rosenthal, 2013, p. 52).']
['What are the different types of sleep apnea?', 'There are two types of sleep apnea: obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea.']

['What happens when an individual’s airway becomes blocked during sleep?', 'Obstructive sleep apnea occurs when an individual’s airway becomes blocked during sleep, and air is prevented from entering the lungs.']

['How else do these type of sleep apneas affect breathing?', 'In central sleep apnea, disruption in signals sent from the brain that regulate breathing cause periods of interrupted breathing (White, 2005).']
['What is one of the most common treatments for sleep apnea?', 'One of the most common treatments for sleep apnea involves the use of a special device during sleep.']

['What is a CPAP?', 'A continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) device includes a mask that fits over the sleeper’s nose and mouth, which is connected to a pump that pumps air into the person’s airways, forcing them to remain open, as shown in Figure 4.13.']
['Is the mask always in place?', 'Some newer CPAP masks are smaller and cover only the nose.']

['What other treatment options are out there for people suffering from mild to severe cases of sleep apnea?', 'This treatment option has proven to be effective for people suffering from mild to severe cases of sleep apnea (McDaid et al., 2009).']
['What is the most common treatment for obstructive sleep apnea?', 'However, alternative treatment options are being explored because consistent compliance by users of CPAP devices is a problem.']

['What is an alternative to a tracheostomy?', 'Recently, a new EPAP (expiratory positive air pressure) device has shown promise in double-blind trials as one such alternative (Berry, Kryger, & Massie, 2011).']
['What is sudden infant death syndrome?', 'In sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) an infant stops breathing during sleep and dies.']
['What is the most important information to know about SIDS?', 'Infants younger than 12 months appear to be at the highest risk for SIDS, and boys have a greater risk than girls.']
['What are some risk factors for SIDS?', 'A number of risk factors have been associated with SIDS including premature birth, smoking within the home, and hyperthermia.']
['What else did you learn about SIDS?', 'There may also be differences in both brain structure and function in infants that die from SIDS (Berkowitz, 2012; Mage & Donner, 2006; Thach, 2005).']
['What are some of the recommendations to protect children?', 'The substantial amount of research on SIDS has led to a number of recommendations to parents to protect their children.']

['What are some of the recommendations?', 'For one, research suggests that infants should be placed on their backs when put down to sleep, and their cribs should not contain any items which pose suffocation threats, such as blankets, pillows or padded crib bumpers (cushions that cover the bars of a crib).']

['What other recommendations were made?', 'Infants should not have caps placed on their heads when put down to sleep in order to prevent overheating, and people in the child’s household should abstain from smoking in the home.']

['What have the recommendations done?', 'Recommendations like these have helped to decrease the number of infant deaths from SIDS in recent years (Mitchell, 2009; Task Force on Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, 2011).']
['What does narcolepsy cause?', 'Unlike the other sleep disorders described in this section, a person with narcolepsy cannot resist falling asleep at inopportune times.']

['What is a side effect of narcolepsy?', 'These sleep episodes are often associated with cataplexy, which is a lack of muscle tone or muscle weakness, and in some cases involves complete paralysis of the voluntary muscles.']

['What is it like to be in REM sleep?', 'This is similar to the kind of paralysis experienced by healthy individuals during REM sleep (Burgess & Scammell, 2012; Hishikawa & Shimizu, 1995; Luppi et al., 2011).']
['Can you tell me something interesting about the information provided?', 'Narcoleptic episodes take on other features of REM sleep.']

['What other features do individuals with narcolepsy experience?', 'For example, around one third of individuals diagnosed with narcolepsy experience vivid, dream-like hallucinations during narcoleptic attacks (Chokroverty, 2010).']
['What is unusual about narcolepsy?', 'Surprisingly, narcoleptic episodes are often triggered by states of heightened arousal or stress.']
['What is the typical length of a typical episode?', 'The typical episode can last from a minute or two to half an hour.']
['What happens after the episode?', 'Once awakened from a narcoleptic attack, people report that they feel refreshed (Chokroverty, 2010).']

['What other things can happen to someone with narcolepsy?', 'Obviously, regular narcoleptic episodes could interfere with the ability to perform one’s job or complete schoolwork, and in some situations, narcolepsy can result in significant harm and injury (e.g., driving a car or operating machinery or other potentially dangerous equipment).']
['What is the most important aspect of this article that you have learned?', 'Generally, narcolepsy is treated using psychomotor stimulant drugs, such as amphetamines (Mignot, 2012).']
['what does these drugs do?', 'These drugs promote increased levels of neural activity.']

['what is one side effect?', 'Narcolepsy is associated with reduced levels of the signaling molecule hypocretin in some areas of the brain (De la Herrán-Arita & Drucker-Colín, 2012; Han, 2012), and the traditional stimulant drugs do not have direct effects on this system.']
['What is the hypocretin system?', 'Therefore, it is quite likely that new medications that are developed to treat narcolepsy will be designed to target the hypocretin system.']

['How can this disease be treated?', 'There is a tremendous amount of variability among sufferers, both in terms of how symptoms of narcolepsy manifest and the effectiveness of currently available treatment options.']

['What is the manifestation of excessive sleepiness during normal waking hours?', 'This is illustrated by McCarty’s (2010) case study of a 50-year-old woman who sought help for the excessive sleepiness during normal waking hours that she had experienced for several years.']

['How did this woman feel about this?', 'She indicated that she had fallen asleep at inappropriate or dangerous times, including while eating, while socializing with friends, and while driving her car.']
['What happened to the woman after this?', 'During periods of emotional arousal, the woman complained that she felt some weakness in the right side of her body.']
['What was the result of the sleep testing?', 'Although she did not experience any dream-like hallucinations, she was diagnosed with narcolepsy as a result of sleep testing.']
['What was unusual about her cataplexy?', 'In her case, the fact that her cataplexy was confined to the right side of her body was quite unusual.']
['What did her doctors do to treat her condition?', 'Early attempts to treat her condition with a stimulant drug alone were unsuccessful.']
['Did she try other treatments?', 'However, when a stimulant drug was used in conjunction with a popular antidepressant, her condition improved dramatically.']

['What are the concepts included in this paper?', 'While we all experience altered states of consciousness in the form of sleep on a regular basis, some people use drugs and other substances that result in altered states of consciousness as well.']
['What will we learn about in this section?', 'This section will present information relating to the use of various psychoactive drugs and problems associated with such use.']
['Do you know what the problems are?', 'This will be followed by brief descriptions of the effects of some of the more well-known drugs commonly used today.']

['What does the DSM-5 have to do with substance use disorders?', 'The fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) is used by clinicians to diagnose individuals suffering from various psychological disorders.']
['What are the criteria for substance use disorders?', 'Drug use disorders are addictive disorders, and the criteria for specific substance (drug) use disorders are described in DSM-5.']

['What are the signs of a substance use disorder?', 'A person who has a substance use disorder often uses more of the substance than they originally intended to and continues to use that substance despite experiencing significant adverse consequences.']

['are there other signs?', 'In individuals diagnosed with a substance use disorder, there is a compulsive pattern of drug use that is often associated with both physical and psychological dependence.']
['How are these substances harmful to the user?', 'Physical dependence involves changes in normal bodily functions—the user will experience withdrawal from the drug upon cessation of use.']

['How else is physical dependence different from psychological dependence?', 'In contrast, a person who has psychological dependence has an emotional, rather than physical, need for the drug and may use the drug to relieve psychological distress.']
['What is tolerance?', 'Tolerance is linked to physiological dependence, and it occurs when a person requires more and more drug to achieve effects previously experienced at lower doses.']
['What are some of the health risks associated with tolerance?', 'Tolerance can cause the user to increase the amount of drug used to a dangerous level—even to the point of overdose and death.']
['What happens when drug use is discontinued?', 'Drug withdrawal includes a variety of negative symptoms experienced when drug use is discontinued.']
['Are there other symptoms of the drug?', 'These symptoms usually are opposite of the effects of the drug.']
['What are some other effects of withdrawal from sedative drugs?', 'For example, withdrawal from sedative drugs often produces unpleasant arousal and agitation.']
['What other effects do substances have?', 'In addition to withdrawal, many individuals who are diagnosed with substance use disorders will also develop tolerance to these substances.']
['What is psychological dependence, or drug craving?', 'Psychological dependence, or drug craving, is a recent addition to the diagnostic criteria for substance use disorder in DSM-5.']
['What is an important factor?', 'This is an important factor because we can develop tolerance and experience withdrawal from any number of drugs that we do not abuse.']

['Can physical dependence be an important factor in determining whether or not someone has a substance use disorder?', 'In other words, physical dependence in and of itself is of limited utility in determining whether or not someone has a substance use disorder.']
['What happens to all psychoactive drugs?', 'The effects of all psychoactive drugs occur through their interactions with our endogenous neurotransmitter systems.']
['What are the drugs shown in Table 4.2?', 'Many of these drugs, and their relationships, are shown in Table 4.2.']
['What are the agonists and antagonists of a given neurotransmitter system?', 'As you have learned, drugs can act as agonists or antagonists of a given neurotransmitter system.']
['What are the differences between agonists and antagonists?', 'An agonist facilitates the activity of a neurotransmitter system, and antagonists impede neurotransmitter activity.']
['What can you tell me about alcohol?', 'Ethanol, which we commonly refer to as alcohol, is in a class of psychoactive drugs known as depressants.']
['What is the depressant?', 'A depressant is a drug that tends to suppress central nervous system activity.']
['What are some other depressants?', 'Other depressants include barbiturates and benzodiazepines.']
['What do these drugs have in common?', 'These drugs share in common their ability to serve as agonists of the gamma-Aminobutyric acid (GABA) neurotransmitter system.']

['What effect does GABA have on the brain?', 'Because GABA has a quieting effect on the brain, GABA agonists also have a quieting effect; these types of drugs are often prescribed to treat both anxiety and insomnia.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Acute alcohol administration results in a variety of changes to consciousness.']
['What other significant facts did you learn?', 'At rather low doses, alcohol use is associated with feelings of euphoria.']
['What does this do?', 'As the dose increases, people report feeling sedated.']
['What else did you learn about alcohol?', 'Generally, alcohol is associated with decreases in reaction time and visual acuity, lowered levels of alertness, and reduction in behavioral control.']

['What might a person experience with excessive alcohol use?', 'With excessive alcohol use, a person might experience a complete loss of consciousness and/or difficulty remembering events that occurred during a period of intoxication (McKim & Hancock, 2013).']

['What else?', 'In addition, if a pregnant person consumes alcohol, their infant may be born with a cluster of birth defects and symptoms collectively called fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) or fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS).']

['What are some of the topics covered in the passage?', 'With repeated use of many central nervous system depressants, such as alcohol, a person becomes physically dependent upon the substance and will exhibit signs of both tolerance and withdrawal.']
['What is another possible side effect of these drugs?', 'Psychological dependence on these drugs is also possible.']
['What is the abuse potential of central nervous system depressants?', 'Therefore, the abuse potential of central nervous system depressants is relatively high.']

['What is the first piece of information?', 'Drug withdrawal is usually an aversive experience, and it can be a life-threatening process in individuals who have a long history of very high doses of alcohol and/or barbiturates.']
['What is the second piece of information?', 'This is of such concern that people who are trying to overcome addiction to these substances should only do so under medical supervision.']
['What do stimulants do?', 'Stimulants are drugs that tend to increase overall levels of neural activity.']
['How do these drugs affect the system?', 'Many of these drugs act as agonists of the dopamine neurotransmitter system.']

['What is the relationship between dopamine and reward?', 'Dopamine activity is often associated with reward and craving; therefore, drugs that affect dopamine neurotransmission often have abuse liability.']
['What are some popular drugs?', 'Drugs in this category include cocaine, amphetamines (including methamphetamine), cathinones (i.e., bath salts), MDMA (ecstasy), nicotine, and caffeine.']
['What does cocaine do?', 'Cocaine can be taken in multiple ways.']
['What are some ways that people use cocaine?', 'While many users snort cocaine, intravenous injection and inhalation (smoking) are also common.']
['What is crack?', 'The freebase version of cocaine, known as crack, is a potent, smokable version of the drug.']
['What happens to dopamine when cocaine is taken?', 'Like many other stimulants, cocaine agonizes the dopamine neurotransmitter system by blocking the reuptake of dopamine in the neuronal synapse.']

['What is the mechanism of action of amphetamines?', 'Amphetamines have a mechanism of action quite similar to cocaine in that they block the reuptake of dopamine in addition to stimulating its release.']
['What is their use?', 'While amphetamines are often abused, they are also commonly prescribed to people diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']

['What is the therapeutic effect of stimulant medications?', 'It may seem counterintuitive that stimulant medications are prescribed to treat a disorder that involves hyperactivity, but the therapeutic effect comes from increases in neurotransmitter activity within certain areas of the brain associated with impulse control.']
['What brain areas are involved in the hippocampus?', 'These brain areas include the prefrontal cortex and basal ganglia.']
['What kind of stimulants are used?', 'In recent years, methamphetamine (meth) use has become increasingly widespread.']

['What is meth?', 'Methamphetamine is a type of amphetamine that can be made from ingredients that are readily available (e.g., medications containing pseudoephedrine, a compound found in many over-the-counter cold and flu remedies).']

['What are some side effects of methamphetamine?', 'Despite recent changes in laws designed to make obtaining pseudoephedrine more difficult, methamphetamine continues to be an easily accessible and relatively inexpensive drug option (Shukla, Crump, & Chrisco, 2012).']
['What are stimulants?', 'Stimulant users seek a euphoric high, feelings of intense elation and pleasure, especially in those users who take the drug via intravenous injection or smoking.']
['What is MDMA?', 'MDMA (3.4-methelynedioxy-methamphetamine, commonly known as "ecstasy" or "Molly") is a mild stimulant with perception-altering effects.']
['What is the most common way MDMA is consumed?', 'It is typically consumed in pill form.']
['What are the side effects of ecstasy?', 'Users experience increased energy, feelings of pleasure, and emotional warmth.']
['How do they effect them?', 'Repeated use of these stimulants can have significant adverse consequences.']
['What physical symptoms can users experience?', 'Users can experience physical symptoms that include nausea, elevated blood pressure, and increased heart rate.']
['What else can cause these side effects?', 'In addition, these drugs can cause feelings of anxiety, hallucinations, and paranoia (Fiorentini et al., 2011).']
['What does the brain do after these drugs are used?', 'Normal brain functioning is altered after repeated use of these drugs.']

['What can lead to overall depletion among the monoamine neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin)?', 'For example, repeated use can lead to overall depletion among the monoamine neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin).']
['What other negative effects does depletion have?', 'Depletion of certain neurotransmitters can lead to mood dysphoria, cognitive problems, and other factors.']

['Can these stimulants lead to addiction?', "This can lead to people compulsively using stimulants such as cocaine and amphetamines, in part to try to reestablish the person's physical and psychological pre-use baseline."]
['What is some information that has been published about MDMA?', '(Jayanthi & Ramamoorthy, 2005; Rothman, Blough, & Baumann, 2007).']
['What is caffeine?', 'Caffeine is another stimulant drug.']

['What is the most commonly used drug in the world?', 'While it is probably the most commonly used drug in the world, the potency of this particular drug pales in comparison to the other stimulant drugs described in this section.']
['What else did you learn about caffeine?', 'Generally, people use caffeine to maintain increased levels of alertness and arousal.']

['What are some common places caffeine is found in the world?', 'Caffeine is found in many common medicines (such as weight loss drugs), beverages, foods, and even cosmetics (Herman & Herman, 2013).']

['What is the primary mechanism of action of caffeine?', 'While caffeine may have some indirect effects on dopamine neurotransmission, its primary mechanism of action involves antagonizing adenosine activity (Porkka-Heiskanen, 2011).']
['What does this antagonize?', 'Adenosine is a neurotransmitter that promotes sleep.']
['What is the main effect of caffeine?', 'Caffeine is an adenosine antagonist, so caffeine inhibits the adenosine receptors, thus decreasing sleepiness and promoting wakefulness.']

['what is generally considered a relatively safe drug?', 'While caffeine is generally considered a relatively safe drug, high blood levels of caffeine can result in insomnia, agitation, muscle twitching, nausea, irregular heartbeat, and even death (Reissig, Strain, & Griffiths, 2009; Wolt, Ganetsky, & Babu, 2012).']
['what is the case study?', 'In 2012, Kromann and Nielson reported on a case study of a 40-year-old woman who suffered significant ill effects from her use of caffeine.']

['who used caffeine?', 'The woman used caffeine in the past to boost her mood and to provide energy, but over the course of several years, she increased her caffeine consumption to the point that she was consuming three liters of soda each day.']

['what was significant ill effects?', 'Although she had been taking a prescription antidepressant, her symptoms of depression continued to worsen and she began to suffer physically, displaying significant warning signs of cardiovascular disease and diabetes.']

['what was substance abuse?', 'Upon admission to an outpatient clinic for treatment of mood disorders, she met all of the diagnostic criteria for substance dependence and was advised to dramatically limit her caffeine intake.']
['What was her addiction?', 'Once she was able to limit her use to less than 12 ounces of soda a day, both her mental and physical health gradually improved.']

['What was the study about?', 'Despite the prevalence of caffeine use and the large number of people who confess to suffering from caffeine addiction, this was the first published description of soda dependence appearing in scientific literature.']

['What is the danger associated with tobacco products?', 'Nicotine is highly addictive, and the use of tobacco products is associated with increased risks of heart disease, stroke, and a variety of cancers.']
['What is the effect of nicotine on the body?', 'Nicotine exerts its effects through its interaction with acetylcholine receptors.']
['What is acetylcholine?', 'Acetylcholine functions as a neurotransmitter in motor neurons.']
['What does acetylcholine do in the central nervous system?', 'In the central nervous system, it plays a role in arousal and reward mechanisms.']

['What are some effective smoking cessation techniques?', 'Nicotine is most commonly used in the form of tobacco products like cigarettes or chewing tobacco; therefore, there is a tremendous interest in developing effective smoking cessation techniques.']

['What are the most common techniques to quit smoking?', 'To date, people have used a variety of nicotine replacement therapies in addition to various psychotherapeutic options in an attempt to discontinue their use of tobacco products.']

['What are the outcomes of using such strategies?', 'In general, smoking cessation programs may be effective in the short term, but it is unclear whether these effects persist (Cropley, Theadom, Pravettoni, & Webb, 2008; Levitt, Shaw, Wong, & Kaczorowski, 2007; Smedslund, Fisher, Boles, & Lichtenstein, 2004).']
['What is vaping?', 'Vaping as a means to deliver nicotine is becoming increasingly popular, especially among teens and young adults.']
['What is vaping?', 'Vaping uses battery-powered devices, sometimes called e-cigarettes, that deliver liquid nicotine and flavorings as a vapor.']
