['What is the danger of vaping?', 'Originally reported as a safe alternative to the known cancer-causing agents found in cigarettes, vaping is now known to be very dangerous and has led to serious lung disease and death in users (Shmerling, 2019).']
['What is an opioid?', 'An opioid is one of a category of drugs that includes heroin, morphine, methadone, and codeine.']
['What do opioids do?', 'Opioids have analgesic properties; that is, they decrease pain.']

['Why does it decrease pain?', 'Humans have an endogenous opioid neurotransmitter system—the body makes small quantities of opioid compounds that bind to opioid receptors reducing pain and producing euphoria.']
['What is the potential for abuse of opioid drugs?', 'Thus, opioid drugs, which mimic this endogenous painkilling mechanism, have an extremely high potential for abuse.']
['What are some other interesting aspects about this study?', 'Natural opioids, called opiates, are derivatives of opium, which is a naturally occurring compound found in the poppy plant.']

['What are some synthetic versions of opiate drugs?', 'There are now several synthetic versions of opiate drugs (correctly called opioids) that have very potent painkilling effects, and they are often abused.']

['Are there any harmful effects of opioids?', 'For example, the National Institutes of Drug Abuse has sponsored research that suggests the misuse and abuse of the prescription pain killers hydrocodone and oxycodone are significant public health concerns (Maxwell, 2006).']
['Are there regulations on these drugs?', 'In 2013, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration recommended tighter controls on their medical use.']
['What is the major opioid drug of abuse?', 'Historically, heroin has been a major opioid drug of abuse.']
['What are the ways that heroin is abused?', 'Heroin can be snorted, smoked, or injected intravenously.']
['Heroin is injected intravenously. What is the effect of this?', 'Heroin produces intense feelings of euphoria and pleasure, which are amplified when the heroin is injected intravenously.']
['What else is significant about heroin addiction?', 'Following the initial "rush," users experience 4–6 hours of "going on the nod," alternating between conscious and semiconscious states.']
['How is heroin abused?', 'Heroin users often shoot the drug directly into their veins.']

['Do people who inject drugs have negative side effects?', 'Some people who have injected many times into their arms will show "track marks,"  while other users will inject into areas between their fingers or between their toes, so as not to show obvious track marks and, like all abusers of intravenous drugs, have an increased risk for contraction of both tuberculosis and HIV.']
['What are opioid-like compounds used for?', 'Aside from their utility as analgesic drugs, opioid-like compounds are often found in cough suppressants, anti-nausea, and anti-diarrhea medications.']

['What is another interesting fact you can share?', 'Given that withdrawal from a drug often involves an experience opposite to the effect of the drug, it should be no surprise that opioid withdrawal resembles a severe case of the flu.']
['Does opioid withdrawal pose a health threat?', 'While opioid withdrawal can be extremely unpleasant, it is not life-threatening (Julien, 2005).']
['What are some important aspects of this section?', 'Still, people experiencing opioid withdrawal may be given methadone to make withdrawal from the drug less difficult.']
['What is methadone?', 'Methadone is a synthetic opioid that is less euphorigenic than heroin and similar drugs.']
['How is methadone used?', 'Methadone clinics help people who previously struggled with opioid addiction manage withdrawal symptoms through the use of methadone.']
['What other drugs have been used to alleviate symptoms of opiate withdrawal?', 'Other drugs, including the opioid buprenorphine, have also been used to alleviate symptoms of opiate withdrawal.']
['What is the most potent opioid?', 'Codeine is an opioid with relatively low potency.']
['What is it used for?', 'It is often prescribed for minor pain, and it is available over-the-counter in some other countries.']
['What is codeine used for?', 'Like all opioids, codeine does have abuse potential.']

['Can this be dangerous?', 'In fact, abuse of prescription opioid medications is becoming a major concern worldwide (Aquina, Marques-Baptista, Bridgeman, & Merlin, 2009; Casati, Sedefov, & Pfeiffer-Gerschel, 2012).']
['What is a hallucinogen?', 'A hallucinogen is one of a class of drugs that results in profound alterations in sensory and perceptual experiences.']
['What are the hallucinations that users experience?', 'In some cases, users experience vivid visual hallucinations.']

['What else are the hallucinations?', 'It is also common for these types of drugs to cause hallucinations of body sensations (e.g., feeling as if you are a giant) and a skewed perception of the passage of time.']
['What is important about hallucinogens?', 'As a group, hallucinogens are incredibly varied in terms of the neurotransmitter systems they affect.']

['Which neurotransmitter systems do hallucinogens affect?', 'Mescaline and LSD are serotonin agonists, and PCP (angel dust) and ketamine (an animal anesthetic) act as antagonists of the NMDA glutamate receptor.']
['How are these drugs abused?', 'In general, these drugs are not thought to possess the same sort of abuse potential as other classes of drugs discussed in this section.']
['What is the main concept of this study material?', 'Our states of consciousness change as we move from wakefulness to sleep.']
['What else does it cover?', 'We also alter our consciousness through the use of various psychoactive drugs.']

['What is included in this study material?', 'This final section will consider hypnotic and meditative states as additional examples of altered states of consciousness experienced by some individuals.']
['What is the study material about?', 'Hypnosis is a state of extreme self-focus and attention in which minimal attention is given to external stimuli.']
['What does the therapeutic setting involve?', 'In the therapeutic setting, a clinician may use relaxation and suggestion in an attempt to alter the thoughts and perceptions of a patient.']
['What is the other aspect of this material?', 'Hypnosis has also been used to draw out information believed to be buried deeply in someone’s memory.']

['What is one of the things that might be a result of this?', 'For individuals who are especially open to the power of suggestion, hypnosis can prove to be a very effective technique, and brain imaging studies have demonstrated that hypnotic states are associated with global changes in brain functioning (Del Casale et al., 2012; Guldenmund, Vanhaudenhuyse, Boly, Laureys, & Soddu, 2012).']
['What is the history of hypnosis?', 'Historically, hypnosis has been viewed with some suspicion because of its portrayal in popular media and entertainment.']
['Did the media get it right?', 'Therefore, it is important to make a distinction between hypnosis as an empirically based therapeutic approach versus as a form of entertainment.']
['How is hypnosis used?', 'Contrary to popular belief, individuals undergoing hypnosis usually have clear memories of the hypnotic experience and are in control of their own behaviors.']
['What can hypnosis do?', 'While hypnosis may be useful in enhancing memory or a skill, such enhancements are very modest in nature (Raz, 2011).']

['What are four parts that appear consistent in bringing people into the state of suggestibility associated with hypnosis?', 'While there are variations, there are four parts that appear consistent in bringing people into the state of suggestibility associated with hypnosis (National Research Council, 1994).']
['What are the four parts of a compass?', 'These components include:']
['What is the purpose of hypnosis?', 'The participant is guided to focus on one thing, such as the hypnotist’s words or a ticking watch.']
['What is the purpose of making comfortable?', 'The participant is made comfortable and is directed to be relaxed and sleepy.']
['What is the purpose of trust in hypnosis?', 'The participant is told to be open to the process of hypnosis, trust the hypnotist and let go.']
['What is the purpose of use?', 'The participant is encouraged to use their imagination.']

['What is the most important fact in the title of our study material?', 'People vary in terms of their ability to be hypnotized, but a review of available research suggests that most people are at least moderately hypnotizable (Kihlstrom, 2013).']

['What is one of the uses of hypnosis?', 'Hypnosis in conjunction with other techniques is used for a variety of therapeutic purposes and has shown to be at least somewhat effective for pain management, treatment of depression and anxiety, smoking cessation, and weight loss (Alladin, 2012; Elkins, Johnson, & Fisher, 2012; Golden, 2012; Montgomery, Schnur, & Kravits, 2012).']
['What is the question that the passage is trying to answer?', 'Two theories attempt to answer this question:']
['What are the two theories about hypnosis?', 'One theory views hypnosis as dissociation and the other theory views it as the performance of a social role.']

['What is the dissociation theory?', 'According to the dissociation view, hypnosis is effectively a dissociated state of consciousness, much like our earlier example where you may drive to work, but you are only minimally aware of the process of driving because your attention is focused elsewhere.']
['Does this theory support anything?', 'This theory is supported by Ernest Hilgard’s research into hypnosis and pain.']
['What was the most important factor in this theory?', 'In Hilgard’s experiments, he induced participants into a state of hypnosis, and placed their arms into ice water.']

['Did he say they would not feel pain?', 'Participants were told they would not feel pain, but they could press a button if they did; while they reported not feeling pain, they did, in fact, press the button, suggesting a dissociation of consciousness while in the hypnotic state (Hilgard & Hilgard, 1994).']

['What is the social-cognitive theory of hypnosis?', 'Taking a different approach to explain hypnosis, the social-cognitive theory of hypnosis sees people in hypnotic states as performing the social role of a hypnotized person.']
['What is the next information you provided?', 'As you will learn when you study social roles, people’s behavior can be shaped by their expectations of how they should act in a given situation.']

['What do these expectations shape?', 'Some view a hypnotized person’s behavior not as an altered or dissociated state of consciousness, but as their fulfillment of the social expectations for that role (Coe, 2009; Coe & Sarbin, 1966).']

['What is the act of focusing on a single target (such as the breath or a repeated sound) to increase awareness of the moment?', 'Meditation is the act of focusing on a single target (such as the breath or a repeated sound) to increase awareness of the moment.']
['How is hypnosis achieved?', 'While hypnosis is generally achieved through the interaction of a therapist and the person being treated, an individual can perform meditation alone.']
['Are there other ways to perform meditation?', 'Often, however, people wishing to learn to meditate receive some training in techniques to achieve a meditative state.']

['What is the central feature of all meditation?', 'Although there are a number of different techniques in use, the central feature of all meditation is clearing the mind in order to achieve a state of relaxed awareness and focus (Chen et al., 2013; Lang et al., 2012).']
['What has recently become popular?', 'Mindfulness meditation has recently become popular.']

['What is mindfulness meditation?', 'In the variation of mindful meditation, the meditator’s attention is focused on some internal process or an external object (Zeidan, Grant, Brown, McHaffie, & Coghill, 2012).']
['What is the main topic of this page?', 'Meditative techniques have their roots in religious practices, but their use has grown in popularity among practitioners of alternative medicine.']

['What health benefits have been found from meditation?', 'Research indicates that meditation may help reduce blood pressure, and the American Heart Association suggests that meditation might be used in conjunction with more traditional treatments as a way to manage hypertension, although there is not sufficient data for a recommendation to be made (Brook et al., 2013).']

['What else can meditation do?', 'Like hypnosis, meditation also shows promise in stress management, sleep quality (Caldwell, Harrison, Adams, Quin, & Greeson, 2010), treatment of mood and anxiety disorders (Chen et al., 2013; Freeman et al., 2010; Vøllestad, Nielsen, & Nielsen, 2012), and pain management (Reiner, Tibi, & Lipsitz, 2013).']
['What are sensory receptors?', 'Sensory receptors are specialized neurons that respond to specific types of stimuli.']
['What happens when sensory information is detected by a sensory receptor?', 'When sensory information is detected by a sensory receptor, sensation has occurred.']
['What other types of information can cause sensory receptors to respond?', 'For example, light that enters the eye causes chemical changes in cells that line the back of the eye.']
['What happens when sensory receptors respond?', 'These cells relay messages, in the form of action potentials (as you learned when studying biopsychology), to the central nervous system.']
['What is transduction?', 'The conversion from sensory stimulus energy to action potential is known as transduction.']

['How many senses do we have?', 'You have probably known since elementary school that we have five senses: vision, hearing (audition), smell (olfaction), taste (gustation), and touch (somatosensation).']
['What does the scientific community think about the five senses?', 'It turns out that this notion of five senses is oversimplified.']

['What other senses do we have?', 'We also have sensory systems that provide information about balance (the vestibular sense), body position and movement (proprioception and kinesthesia), pain (nociception), and temperature (thermoception).']

['What is the sensitivity of a given sensory system to the relevant stimuli expressed as an absolute threshold?', 'The sensitivity of a given sensory system to the relevant stimuli can be expressed as an absolute threshold.']
['What does absolute threshold refer to?', 'Absolute threshold refers to the minimum amount of stimulus energy that must be present for the stimulus to be detected 50% of the time.']
['What is another way to think about this?', 'Another way to think about this is by asking how dim can a light be or how soft can a sound be and still be detected half of the time.']
['How sensitive are our sensory receptors?', 'The sensitivity of our sensory receptors can be quite amazing.']

['How amazing is it that on a clear night, the most sensitive sensory cells in the back of the eye can detect a candle flame 30 miles away?', 'It has been estimated that on a clear night, the most sensitive sensory cells in the back of the eye can detect a candle flame 30 miles away (Okawa & Sampath, 2007).']
['What other amazing information is there?', 'Under quiet conditions, the hair cells (the receptor cells of the inner ear) can detect the tick of a clock 20 feet away (Galanter, 1962).']
['What is subliminal messages?', 'It is also possible for us to get messages that are presented below the threshold for conscious awareness—these are called subliminal messages.']
['What is the threshold of a stimulus?', 'A stimulus reaches a physiological threshold when it is strong enough to excite sensory receptors and send nerve impulses to the brain:']
['What is this called?', 'This is an absolute threshold.']
['What does this mean?', 'A message below that threshold is said to be subliminal:']
['What happens to subliminal messages?', 'We receive it, but we are not consciously aware of it.']

['What other uses are there of subliminal messages?', 'Over the years there has been a great deal of speculation about the use of subliminal messages in advertising, rock music, and self-help audio programs.']
['What happens in laboratory settings?', 'Research evidence shows that in laboratory settings, people can process and respond to information outside of awareness.']

['What does this mean?', 'But this does not mean that we obey these messages like zombies; in fact, hidden messages have little effect on behavior outside the laboratory (Kunst-Wilson & Zajonc, 1980; Rensink, 2004; Nelson, 2008; Radel, Sarrazin, Legrain, & Gobancé, 2009; Loersch, Durso, & Petty, 2013).']
['What conditions are generally measured?', 'Absolute thresholds are generally measured under incredibly controlled conditions in situations that are optimal for sensitivity.']
['What are the differences between the two stimuli?', 'Sometimes, we are more interested in how much difference in stimuli is required to detect a difference between them.']
['What is this called?', 'This is known as the just noticeable difference (jnd) or difference threshold.']
['Are these the same as absolute thresholds?', 'Unlike the absolute threshold, the difference threshold changes depending on the stimulus intensity.']
['What is an example of this?', 'As an example, imagine yourself in a very dark movie theater.']

['Why would you notice?', 'If an audience member were to receive a text message that caused the cell phone screen to light up, chances are that many people would notice the change in illumination in the theater.']
['What happens to the difference threshold in this case?', 'However, if the same thing happened in a brightly lit arena during a basketball game, very few people would notice.']
['What does the difference mean?', 'The cell phone brightness does not change, but its ability to be detected as a change in illumination varies dramatically between the two contexts.']
['What is the theory of change in difference threshold?', 'Ernst Weber proposed this theory of change in difference threshold in the 1830s, and it has become known as Weber’s law:']
['What does Weber define as the difference threshold?', 'The difference threshold is a constant fraction of the original stimulus, as the example illustrates.']

['What are the most important parts of the article?', 'While our sensory receptors are constantly collecting information from the environment, it is ultimately how we interpret that information that affects how we interact with the world.']
['What does perception refer to?', 'Perception refers to the way sensory information is organized, interpreted, and consciously experienced.']
['What happens in perception?', 'Perception involves both bottom-up and top-down processing.']

['What is bottom-up processing?', 'Bottom-up processing refers to sensory information from a stimulus in the environment driving a process, and top-down processing refers to knowledge and expectancy driving a process, as shown in Figure 5.2 (Egeth & Yantis, 1997; Fine & Minnery, 2009; Yantis & Egeth, 1999).']
['What was our first task?', 'Imagine that you and some friends are sitting in a crowded restaurant eating lunch and talking.']

['Why is that?', 'It is very noisy, and you are concentrating on your friend’s face to hear what they are saying, then the sound of breaking glass and clang of metal pans hitting the floor rings out.']
['What is the sound of?', 'The server dropped a large tray of food.']

['What happens when the server drops a tray of food?', 'Although you were attending to your meal and conversation, that crashing sound would likely get through your attentional filters and capture your attention.']
['How would you notice it?', 'You would have no choice but to notice it.']
['What was it like to notice the sound from the environment?', 'That attentional capture would be caused by the sound from the environment: it would be bottom-up.']

['What are top-down processes generally goal directed, slow, deliberate, effortful, and under your control?', "Alternatively, top-down processes are generally goal directed, slow, deliberate, effortful, and under your control (Fine & Minnery, 2009; Miller & Cohen, 2001; Miller & D'Esposito, 2005)."]

['What else do we need to know?', 'If you had a yellow key fob, you would probably look for yellowness of a certain size in specific locations, such as on the counter, coffee table, and other similar places.']
['What else do you need to know?', 'You would not look for yellowness on your ceiling fan, because you know keys are not normally lying on top of a ceiling fan.']
['How about the ceiling fan?', 'That act of searching for a certain size of yellowness in some locations and not others would be top-down—under your control and based on your experience.']
['How can we think of Perception as a different concept than sensation?', 'One way to think of this concept is that sensation is a physical process, whereas perception is psychological.']

['What are some examples of this?', 'For example, upon walking into a kitchen and smelling the scent of baking cinnamon rolls, the sensation is the scent receptors detecting the odor of cinnamon, but the perception may be “Mmm, this smells like the bread Grandma used to bake when the family gathered for holidays.”']
['What is perception?', 'Although our perceptions are built from sensations, not all sensations result in perception.']
["What happens when you don't perceive something?", 'In fact, we often don’t perceive stimuli that remain relatively constant over prolonged periods of time.']
['What happens when we do perceive it?', 'This is known as sensory adaptation.']
['What is an example of sensory adaptation?', 'Imagine going to a city that you have never visited.']
['What happens when you go to the city?', 'You check in to the hotel, but when you get to your room, there is a road construction sign with a bright flashing light outside your window.']
['What happens if you do not like that light?', 'Unfortunately, there are no other rooms available, so you are stuck with a flashing light.']
['What do you do when you do not want to go outside?', 'You decide to watch television to unwind.']
['How does the TV help you to unwind?', 'The flashing light was extremely annoying when you first entered your room.']

['Why was it annoying?', 'It was as if someone was continually turning a bright yellow spotlight on and off in your room, but after watching television for a short while, you no longer notice the light flashing.']

['Why did the light fade?', 'The light is still flashing and filling your room with yellow light every few seconds, and the photoreceptors in your eyes still sense the light, but you no longer perceive the rapid changes in lighting conditions.']
['How is this adapted?', 'That you no longer perceive the flashing light demonstrates sensory adaptation and shows that while closely associated, sensation and perception are different.']
['What is another factor that affects sensation and perception?', 'There is another factor that affects sensation and perception: attention.']
['What does attention affect?', 'Attention plays a significant role in determining what is sensed versus what is perceived.']
['What does it do?', 'Imagine you are at a party full of music, chatter, and laughter.']
['What does your attention focus on when you are in a conversation?', 'You get involved in an interesting conversation with a friend, and you tune out all the background noise.']

['What would happen if someone interrupted you to ask what song had just finished playing?', 'If someone interrupted you to ask what song had just finished playing, you would probably be unable to answer that question.']

['Who performed a study on perception?', 'One of the most interesting demonstrations of how important attention is in determining our perception of the environment occurred in a famous study conducted by Daniel Simons and Christopher Chabris (1999).']
['What did they observe?', 'In this study, participants watched a video of people dressed in black and white passing basketballs.']
['Who were the participants?', 'Participants were asked to count the number of times the team dressed in white passed the ball.']
['What happened during the video?', 'During the video, a person dressed in a black gorilla costume walks among the two teams.']
['What else did they find?', 'Nearly half of the people who watched the video didn’t notice the gorilla at all, despite the fact that he was clearly visible for nine seconds.']

['Why did they tune out the gorilla?', 'Because participants were so focused on the number of times the team dressed in white was passing the ball, they completely tuned out other visual information.']

['What was the study about?', 'Inattentional blindness is the failure to notice something that is completely visible because the person was actively attending to something else and did not pay attention to other things (Mack & Rock, 1998; Simons & Chabris, 1999).']
['What happened in the Perception experiment?', 'In a similar experiment, researchers tested inattentional blindness by asking participants to observe images moving across a computer screen.']
['What was the test like?', 'They were instructed to focus on either white or black objects, disregarding the other color.']
['What happened after the test?', 'When a red cross passed across the screen, about one third of subjects did not notice it (Most, Simons, Scholl, & Chabris, 2000).']
['What can also affect perception?', 'Motivation can also affect perception.']

['Did you ever detect a meaningful stimulus from the background noise while in pursuit of something interesting?', 'If so, then you have experienced how motivation to detect a meaningful stimulus can shift our ability to discriminate between a true sensory stimulus and background noise.']
['What is signal detection theory?', 'The ability to identify a stimulus when it is embedded in a distracting background is called signal detection theory.']
['What does the theory explain?', 'This might also explain why a mother is awakened by a quiet murmur from her baby but not by other sounds that occur while she is asleep.']
['What can Signal detection theory help with?', 'Signal detection theory has practical applications, such as increasing air traffic controller accuracy.']

['What do air traffic controllers need to be able to do to find planes?', 'Controllers need to be able to detect planes among many signals (blips) that appear on the radar screen and follow those planes as they move through the sky.']

['What was the original work of the researcher who developed signal detection theory focused on in 1964?', 'In fact, the original work of the researcher who developed signal detection theory was focused on improving the sensitivity of air traffic controllers to plane blips (Swets, 1964).']
['What can affect our perceptions?', 'Our perceptions can also be affected by our beliefs, values, prejudices, expectations, and life experiences.']

['What are some common factors that affect perception?', 'As you will see later in this chapter, individuals who are deprived of the experience of binocular vision during critical periods of development have trouble perceiving depth (Fawcett, Wang, & Birch, 2005).']
['What are some cultural factors?', 'The shared experiences of people within a given cultural context can have pronounced effects on perception.']

['What is an example of this?', 'For example, Marshall Segall, Donald Campbell, and Melville Herskovits (1963) published the results of a multinational study in which they demonstrated that individuals from Western cultures were more prone to experience certain types of visual illusions than individuals from non-Western cultures, and vice versa.']
['What were the illusions that Westerners were more likely to experience?', 'One such illusion that Westerners were more likely to experience was the Müller-Lyer illusion:']
['What was the illusion?', 'The lines appear to be different lengths, but they are actually the same length.']

['What was the reason for perceptual differences?', 'These perceptual differences were consistent with differences in the types of environmental features experienced on a regular basis by people in a given cultural context.']

['What are cultural factors?', 'People in Western cultures, for example, have a perceptual context of buildings with straight lines, what Segall’s study called a carpentered world (Segall et al., 1966).']

['What effect does the shape of the huts have on the illusion?', 'In contrast, people from certain non-Western cultures with an uncarpentered view, such as the Zulu of South Africa, whose villages are made up of round huts arranged in circles, are less susceptible to this illusion (Segall et al., 1999).']
['What else do cultural factors affect?', 'It is not just vision that is affected by cultural factors.']

['What else?', 'Indeed, research has demonstrated that the ability to identify an odor, and rate its pleasantness and its intensity, varies cross-culturally (Ayabe-Kanamura, Saito, Distel, Martínez-Gómez, & Hudson, 1998).']

['What is your main idea?', 'Children described as thrill seekers are more likely to show taste preferences for intense sour flavors (Liem, Westerbeek, Wolterink, Kok, & de Graaf, 2004), which suggests that basic aspects of personality might affect perception.']

['Did it also mention any other points?', 'Furthermore, individuals who hold positive attitudes toward reduced-fat foods are more likely to rate foods labeled as reduced fat as tasting better than people who have less positive attitudes about these products (Aaron, Mela, & Evans, 1994).']
['What kind of things happen with waves?', 'Visual and auditory stimuli both occur in the form of waves.']

['What is important about this to you?', 'Although the two stimuli are very different in terms of composition, wave forms share similar characteristics that are especially important to our visual and auditory perceptions.']
['What are physical properties of waves?', 'In this section, we describe the physical properties of the waves as well as the perceptual experiences associated with them.']
['What are the two physical characteristics of a wave?', 'Two physical characteristics of a wave are amplitude and wavelength.']
['What is the amplitude of a wave?', 'The amplitude of a wave is the distance from the center line to the top point of the crest or the bottom point of the trough.']
['What is the length of a wave from one peak to the next?', 'Wavelength refers to the length of a wave from one peak to the next.']
['What is the relationship between Amplitude and Wavelength?', 'Wavelength is directly related to the frequency of a given wave form.']
['What does frequency mean?', 'Frequency refers to the number of waves that pass a given point in a given time period and is often expressed in terms of hertz (Hz), or cycles per second.']
['How is frequency related to wavelength?', 'Longer wavelengths will have lower frequencies, and shorter wavelengths will have higher frequencies.']
['What is the visible spectrum?', 'The visible spectrum is the portion of the larger electromagnetic spectrum that we can see.']

['What is the electromagnetic spectrum?', 'As Figure 5.7 shows, the electromagnetic spectrum encompasses all of the electromagnetic radiation that occurs in our environment and includes gamma rays, x-rays, ultraviolet light, visible light, infrared light, microwaves, and radio waves.']

['What is the small distance?', 'The visible spectrum in humans is associated with wavelengths that range from 380 to 740 nm—a very small distance, since a nanometer (nm) is one billionth of a meter.']
['What are other species?', 'Other species can detect other portions of the electromagnetic spectrum.']

['What are some examples of them?', 'For instance, honeybees can see light in the ultraviolet range (Wakakuwa, Stavenga, & Arikawa, 2007), and some snakes can detect infrared radiation in addition to more traditional visual light cues (Chen, Deng, Brauth, Ding, & Tang, 2012; Hartline, Kass, & Loop, 1978).']
['In humans, light wavelength is associated with perception of what?', 'In humans, light wavelength is associated with perception of color.']

['What wavelength is red associated with?', 'Within the visible spectrum, our experience of red is associated with longer wavelengths, greens are intermediate, and blues and violets are shorter in wavelength.']
['Are there other wavelengths?', '(An easy way to remember this is the mnemonic ROYGBIV: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet.)']
['What is the amplitude of light waves?', 'The amplitude of light waves is associated with our experience of brightness or intensity of color, with larger amplitudes appearing brighter.']
['What are the physical properties of sound waves like?', 'Like light waves, the physical properties of sound waves are associated with various aspects of our perception of sound.']
['What do these sound waves affect?', 'The frequency of a sound wave is associated with our perception of that sound’s pitch.']
['What are these pitch variations?', 'High-frequency sound waves are perceived as high-pitched sounds, while low-frequency sound waves are perceived as low-pitched sounds.']

['What is the audible range of sound frequencies?', 'The audible range of sound frequencies is between 20 and 20000 Hz, with greatest sensitivity to those frequencies that fall in the middle of this range.']
['What can you tell me about Sound Waves?', 'As was the case with the visible spectrum, other species show differences in their audible ranges.']
['Is there anything else interesting about chickens?', 'For instance, chickens have a very limited audible range, from 125 to 2000 Hz.']

['What are the other examples of animals that have an audible range of 1000 to 91000 Hz?', 'Mice have an audible range from 1000 to 91000 Hz, and the beluga whale’s audible range is from 1000 to 123000 Hz.']

['What are some other examples of animals that have audible ranges of about 70–45000 Hz and 45–64000 Hz, respectively?', 'Our pet dogs and cats have audible ranges of about 70–45000 Hz and 45–64000 Hz, respectively (Strain, 2003).']
['What does loudness mean?', 'The loudness of a given sound is closely associated with the amplitude of the sound wave.']
['Are higher amplitudes more or less louder than lower ones?', 'Higher amplitudes are associated with louder sounds.']
['What is the logarithmic unit for loudness?', 'Loudness is measured in terms of decibels (dB), a logarithmic unit of sound intensity.']
['Do the logarithmic units for loudness vary depending on what kind of sound is being produced?', 'A typical conversation would correlate with 60 dB; a rock concert might check in at 120 dB.']

['How loud is a whisper?', 'A whisper 5 feet away or rustling leaves are at the low end of our hearing range; sounds like a window air conditioner, a normal conversation, and even heavy traffic or a vacuum cleaner are within a tolerable range.']
['Do we need to look at loudness when we are looking at hearing damage?', 'However, there is the potential for hearing damage from about 80 dB to 130 dB:']
['What kinds of sounds are louder than 80 dB?', 'These are sounds of a food processor, power lawnmower, heavy truck (25 feet away), subway train (20 feet away), live rock music, and a jackhammer.']

['Can too much loudness cause hearing damage?', 'About one-third of all hearing loss is due to noise exposure, and the louder the sound, the shorter the exposure needed to cause hearing damage (Le, Straatman, Lea, & Westerberg, 2017).']
['Is there any further information on loudness?', 'Listening to music through earbuds at maximum volume (around 100–105 decibels) can cause noise-induced hearing loss after 15 minutes of exposure.']

['What does this have to do with age-related hearing loss?', 'Although listening to music at maximum volume may not seem to cause damage, it increases the risk of age-related hearing loss (Kujawa & Liberman, 2006).']
['Can you tell me what sounds are considered dangerous?', 'The threshold for pain is about 130 dB, a jet plane taking off or a revolver firing at close range (Dunkle, 1982).']

['What are the key aspects of sound waves?', 'Although wave amplitude is generally associated with loudness, there is some interaction between frequency and amplitude in our perception of loudness within the audible range.']
['What are some examples of this interaction?', 'For example, a 10 Hz sound wave is inaudible no matter the amplitude of the wave.']

['Is there any other important information we need to know?', 'A 1000 Hz sound wave, on the other hand, would vary dramatically in terms of perceived loudness as the amplitude of the wave increased.']

['How can different musical instruments play the same musical note at the same level of loudness, yet they still sound quite different?', 'Of course, different musical instruments can play the same musical note at the same level of loudness, yet they still sound quite different.']
['What can you tell me about the sound?', 'This is known as the timbre of a sound.']
['What does timbre refer to?', 'Timbre refers to a sound’s purity, and it is affected by the complex interplay of frequency, amplitude, and timing of sound waves.']
['What does this passage cover?', 'The visual system constructs a mental representation of the world around us.']

['What does this do for our physical reality?', 'This contributes to our ability to successfully navigate through physical space and interact with important individuals and objects in our environments.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'This section will provide an overview of the basic anatomy and function of the visual system.']
['What do we see when we look at a picture?', 'In addition, we will explore our ability to perceive color and depth.']
['What is the major sensory organ involved in vision?', 'The eye is the major sensory organ involved in vision.']
['What do light waves do in the eye?', 'Light waves are transmitted across the cornea and enter the eye through the pupil.']
['What is the transparent covering over the eye?', 'The cornea is the transparent covering over the eye.']
['What does the retina do?', 'It serves as a barrier between the inner eye and the outside world, and it is involved in focusing light waves that enter the eye.']

['What is the small opening in the eye through which light passes?', 'The pupil is the small opening in the eye through which light passes, and the size of the pupil can change as a function of light levels as well as emotional arousal.']
['how does the pupil size change?', 'When light levels are low, the pupil will become dilated, or expanded, to allow more light to enter the eye.']
['What happens to the pupil when light levels are higher?', 'When light levels are high, the pupil will constrict, or become smaller, to reduce the amount of light that enters the eye.']
['who controls this?', 'The pupil’s size is controlled by muscles that are connected to the iris, which is the colored portion of the eye.']
['what is the lens?', 'After passing through the pupil, light crosses the lens, a curved, transparent structure that serves to provide additional focus.']

['What is attached to muscles that can change its shape to aid in focusing light that is reflected from near or far objects?', 'The lens is attached to muscles that can change its shape to aid in focusing light that is reflected from near or far objects.']

['what is a fovea?', 'In a normal-sighted individual, the lens will focus images perfectly on a small indentation in the back of the eye known as the fovea, which is part of the retina, the light-sensitive lining of the eye.']
['What is in the fovea?', 'The fovea contains densely packed specialized photoreceptor cells.']
['What are the photoreceptor cells?', 'These photoreceptor cells, known as cones, are light-detecting cells.']
['What are the cones?', 'The cones are specialized types of photoreceptors that work best in bright light conditions.']
['What is interesting about the cones?', 'Cones are very sensitive to acute detail and provide tremendous spatial resolution.']
['What is important about the cones?', 'They also are directly involved in our ability to perceive color.']
['What are rods?', 'While cones are concentrated in the fovea, where images tend to be focused, rods, another type of photoreceptor, are located throughout the remainder of the retina.']

['What do rods do?', 'Rods are specialized photoreceptors that work well in low light conditions, and while they lack the spatial resolution and color function of the cones, they are involved in our vision in dimly lit environments as well as in our perception of movement on the periphery of our visual field.']

['What is the difference between rods and cones?', 'We have all experienced the different sensitivities of rods and cones when making the transition from a brightly lit environment to a dimly lit environment.']
['What is your favorite kind of outdoor setting?', 'Imagine going to see a blockbuster movie on a clear summer day.']
['What would you do if you were in a dark theater?', 'As you walk from the brightly lit lobby into the dark theater, you notice that you immediately have difficulty seeing much of anything.']
['What happens after you leave the theater?', 'After a few minutes, you begin to adjust to the darkness and can see the interior of the theater.']
['What else can you tell me about this example?', 'In the bright environment, your vision was dominated primarily by cone activity.']
['What happens when you enter the dark environment?', 'As you move to the dark environment, rod activity dominates, but there is a delay in transitioning between the phases.']

['What is a common problem with night blindness?', 'If your rods do not transform light into nerve impulses as easily and efficiently as they should, you will have difficulty seeing in dim light, a condition known as night blindness.']
['What is the connection between rods and cones?', 'Rods and cones are connected (via several interneurons) to retinal ganglion cells.']
['How are these retinal ganglion cells connected to the optic nerve?', 'Axons from the retinal ganglion cells converge and exit through the back of the eye to form the optic nerve.']
['What nerve carries visual information from the eye to the brain?', 'The optic nerve carries visual information from the retina to the brain.']
['What does the blind spot mean?', 'There is a point in the visual field called the blind spot:']
['Why is this important?', 'Even when light from a small object is focused on the blind spot, we do not see it.']
["Why can't we see that object?", 'We are not consciously aware of our blind spots for two reasons:']
['What are the two reasons for the blind spots?', 'First, each eye gets a slightly different view of the visual field; therefore, the blind spots do not overlap.']

['What are the other two reasons?', 'Second, our visual system fills in the blind spot so that although we cannot respond to visual information that occurs in that portion of the visual field, we are also not aware that information is missing.']
['What is the point where the optic nerve from each eye merges just below the brain?', 'The optic nerve from each eye merges just below the brain at a point called the optic chiasm.']
['What shape is the optic chiasm?', 'As Figure 5.13 shows, the optic chiasm is an X-shaped structure that sits just below the cerebral cortex at the front of the brain.']

['What does the optic chiasm do?', 'At the point of the optic chiasm, information from the right visual field (which comes from both eyes) is sent to the left side of the brain, and information from the left visual field is sent to the right side of the brain.']
['What is the occipital lobe?', 'Once inside the brain, visual information is sent via a number of structures to the occipital lobe at the back of the brain for processing.']

['What are the parallel pathways that visual information might be processed in?', 'Visual information might be processed in parallel pathways which can generally be described as the “what pathway” and the “where/how” pathway.']

['What is the “what pathway”?', 'The “what pathway” is involved in object recognition and identification, while the “where/how pathway” is involved with location in space and how one might interact with a particular visual stimulus (Milner & Goodale, 2008; Ungerleider & Haxby, 1994).']

['What kind of object recognition and identification?', 'For example, when you see a ball rolling down the street, the “what pathway” identifies what the object is, and the “where/how pathway” identifies its location or movement in space.']
['How does our vision work?', 'We do not see the world in black and white; neither do we see it as two-dimensional (2-D) or flat (just height and width, no depth).']
['What are some of the things that we can see that are different?', 'Let’s look at how color vision works and how we perceive three dimensions (height, width, and depth).']
['What is the most important thing you have learned?', 'Normal-sighted individuals have three different types of cones that mediate color vision.']
['What does that mean?', 'Each of these cone types is maximally sensitive to a slightly different wavelength of light.']
['What is trichromatic theory?', 'According to the trichromatic theory of color vision, shown in Figure 5.14, all colors in the spectrum can be produced by combining red, green, and blue.']
['Are these the three types of cones?', 'The three types of cones are each receptive to one of the colors.']
['What other theories are there on color vision?', 'The trichromatic theory of color vision is not the only theory—another major theory of color vision is known as the opponent-process theory.']
['How does this theory work?', 'According to this theory, color is coded in opponent pairs: black-white, yellow-blue, and green-red.']
['What is the basic idea of the theory?', 'The basic idea is that some cells of the visual system are excited by one of the opponent colors and inhibited by the other.']
['What is an example of this?', 'So, a cell that was excited by wavelengths associated with green would be inhibited by wavelengths associated with red, and vice versa.']
['What is the effect of opponent processing on color perception?', 'One of the implications of opponent processing is that we do not experience greenish-reds or yellowish-blues as colors.']
['What is another implication of this theory?', 'Another implication is that this leads to the experience of negative afterimages.']
['What is an afterimage?', 'An afterimage describes the continuation of a visual sensation after removal of the stimulus.']

['What is the evidence to support this theory?', 'For example, when you stare briefly at the sun and then look away from it, you may still perceive a spot of light although the stimulus (the sun) has been removed.']
['What are the other aspects of this theory?', 'When color is involved in the stimulus, the color pairings identified in the opponent-process theory lead to a negative afterimage.']
['What is the test for this concept?', 'You can test this concept using the flag in Figure 5.16.']
['What is one theory?', 'But these two theories—the trichromatic theory of color vision and the opponent-process theory—are not mutually exclusive.']
['What is the difference between the two?', 'Research has shown that they just apply to different levels of the nervous system.']

['What are these different wavelengths that represent red, blue, and green?', 'For visual processing on the retina, trichromatic theory applies: the cones are responsive to three different wavelengths that represent red, blue, and green.']

['What else do you know about the opponent-process theory?', 'But once the signal moves past the retina on its way to the brain, the cells respond in a way consistent with opponent-process theory (Land, 1959; Kaiser, 1997).']
['What is depth perception?', 'Our ability to perceive spatial relationships in three-dimensional (3-D) space is known as depth perception.']
['What does depth perception describe?', 'With depth perception, we can describe things as being in front, behind, above, below, or to the side of other things.']

['What is the difference between two-dimensional and three-dimensional properties?', 'Our world is three-dimensional, so it makes sense that our mental representation of the world has three-dimensional properties.']
['How do we establish depth?', 'We use a variety of cues in a visual scene to establish our sense of depth.']
['What is binocular cues?', 'Some of these are binocular cues, which means that they rely on the use of both eyes.']
['What is an example of binocular disparity?', 'One example of a binocular depth cue is binocular disparity, the slightly different view of the world that each of our eyes receives.']
['How does this affect perception?', 'To experience this slightly different view, do this simple exercise: extend your arm fully and extend one of your fingers and focus on that finger.']
['What is another exercise?', 'Now, close your left eye without moving your head, then open your left eye and close your right eye without moving your head.']
['Do you think this exercise is helpful?', 'You will notice that your finger seems to shift as you alternate between the two eyes because of the slightly different view each eye has of your finger.']

['What does this study say about depth perception?', 'A 3-D movie works on the same principle: the special glasses you wear allow the two slightly different images projected onto the screen to be seen separately by your left and your right eye.']
['What does this give you?', 'As your brain processes these images, you have the illusion that the leaping animal or running person is coming right toward you.']
['what can we perceive depth in 2-D arrays?', 'Although we rely on binocular cues to experience depth in our 3-D world, we can also perceive depth in 2-D arrays.']
['What are the images seen as?', 'Think about all the paintings and photographs you have seen.']
['What about the sculptures, architecture?', 'Generally, you pick up on depth in these images even though the visual stimulus is 2-D.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'When we do this, we are relying on a number of monocular cues, or cues that require only one eye.']

['Are these things that we see?', 'If you think you can’t see depth with one eye, note that you don’t bump into things when using only one eye while walking—and, in fact, we have more monocular cues than binocular cues.']
['What are some examples of monocular cues?', 'An example of a monocular cue would be what is known as linear perspective.']
['What is linear perspective?', 'Linear perspective refers to the fact that we perceive depth when we see two parallel lines that seem to converge in an image.']

['What are some other examples of monocular depth cues?', 'Some other monocular depth cues are interposition, the partial overlap of objects, and the relative size and closeness of images to the horizon.']
['What is the auditory system?', 'Our auditory system converts pressure waves into meaningful sounds.']
['What does this mean for us?', 'This translates into our ability to hear the sounds of nature, to appreciate the beauty of music, and to communicate with one another through spoken language.']
['What is the main topic of the passage?', 'This section will provide an overview of the basic anatomy and function of the auditory system.']

['What is it going to cover?', 'It will include a discussion of how the sensory stimulus is translated into neural impulses, where in the brain that information is processed, how we perceive pitch, and how we know where sound is coming from.']
['What is the number of parts the ear has?', 'The ear can be separated into multiple sections.']

['What parts of the outer ear are there?', 'The outer ear includes the pinna, which is the visible part of the ear that protrudes from our heads, the auditory canal, and the tympanic membrane, or eardrum.']
['What parts does the middle ear contain?', 'The middle ear contains three tiny bones known as the ossicles, which are named the malleus (or hammer), incus (or anvil), and the stapes (or stirrup).']
['What parts does the inner ear contain?', 'The inner ear contains the semi-circular canals, which are involved in balance and movement (the vestibular sense), and the cochlea.']
['What is the cochlea?', 'The cochlea is a fluid-filled, snail-shaped structure that contains the sensory receptor cells (hair cells) of the auditory system.']
['What is an important fact about sound waves?', 'Sound waves travel along the auditory canal and strike the tympanic membrane, causing it to vibrate.']
['What causes the vibration?', 'This vibration results in movement of the three ossicles.']
['What else happens during vibration?', 'As the ossicles move, the stapes presses into a thin membrane of the cochlea known as the oval window.']

['What happens with the stapes?', 'As the stapes presses into the oval window, the fluid inside the cochlea begins to move, which in turn stimulates hair cells, which are auditory receptor cells of the inner ear embedded in the basilar membrane.']
['What is the thin strip of tissue within the cochlea called?', 'The basilar membrane is a thin strip of tissue within the cochlea.']
['What is the activation of hair cells?', 'The activation of hair cells is a mechanical process: the stimulation of the hair cell ultimately leads to activation of the cell.']
['How do they generate impulses?', 'As hair cells become activated, they generate neural impulses that travel along the auditory nerve to the brain.']

['What is the information shuttled to in the brain?', 'Auditory information is shuttled to the inferior colliculus, the medial geniculate nucleus of the thalamus, and finally to the auditory cortex in the temporal lobe of the brain for processing.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Like the visual system, there is also evidence suggesting that information about auditory recognition and localization is processed in parallel streams (Rauschecker & Tian, 2000; Renier et al., 2009).']
['What are some of the basics for you to know?', 'Different frequencies of sound waves are associated with differences in our perception of the pitch of those sounds.']
['What are the frequencies of low-frequency sounds and high-frequency sounds?', 'Low-frequency sounds are lower pitched, and high-frequency sounds are higher pitched.']
['What theories have been proposed to account for pitch perception?', 'Several theories have been proposed to account for pitch perception.']
['What are some theories of the universe?', 'We’ll discuss two of them here: temporal theory and place theory.']
['What does the temporal theory of pitch perception assert?', 'The temporal theory of pitch perception asserts that frequency is coded by the activity level of a sensory neuron.']
['What would this mean?', 'This would mean that a given hair cell would fire action potentials related to the frequency of the sound wave.']

['What is interesting about this theory?', 'While this is a very intuitive explanation, we detect such a broad range of frequencies (20–20,000 Hz) that the frequency of action potentials fired by hair cells cannot account for the entire range.']

['What is the theory behind the theory of a cell that cannot fire any faster?', 'Because of properties related to sodium channels on the neuronal membrane that are involved in action potentials, there is a point at which a cell cannot fire any faster (Shamma, 2001).']
['What is the place theory of pitch perception?', 'The place theory of pitch perception suggests that different portions of the basilar membrane are sensitive to sounds of different frequencies.']
['Are there different frequencies?', 'More specifically, the base of the basilar membrane responds best to high frequencies and the tip of the basilar membrane responds best to low frequencies.']

['How did they determine the frequency?', 'Therefore, hair cells that are in the base portion would be labeled as high-pitch receptors, while those in the tip of basilar membrane would be labeled as low-pitch receptors (Shamma, 2001).']
['What are the two theories of pitch perception?', 'In reality, both theories explain different aspects of pitch perception.']
['What frequency is the frequency of the sound?', 'At frequencies up to about 4000']

['What is the rate of action potentials and place that contribute to our perception of pitch?', 'Hz, it is clear that both the rate of action potentials and place contribute to our perception of pitch.']
['What can only be encoded using place cues?', 'However, much higher frequency sounds can only be encoded using place cues (Shamma, 2001).']
['What is important about hearing?', 'The ability to locate sound in our environments is an important part of hearing.']
['How do we know the distance between sound sources?', 'Localizing sound could be considered similar to the way that we perceive depth in our visual fields.']

['How does this compare to the visual fields?', 'Like the monocular and binocular cues that provided information about depth, the auditory system uses both monaural (one-eared) and binaural (two-eared) cues to localize sound.']
['What is one of the biggest underlying topics?', 'Each pinna interacts with incoming sound waves differently, depending on the sound’s source relative to our bodies.']
['What is this a part of?', 'This interaction provides a monaural cue that is helpful in locating sounds that occur above or below and in front or behind us.']

['Why are they used?', 'The sound waves received by your two ears from sounds that come from directly above, below, in front, or behind you would be identical; therefore, monaural cues are essential (Grothe, Pecka, & McAlpine, 2010).']

['What are the differences between binaural cues and acoustic cues?', 'Binaural cues, on the other hand, provide information on the location of a sound along a horizontal axis by relying on differences in patterns of vibration of the eardrum between our two ears.']
['What are the types of binaural cues?', 'If a sound comes from an off-center location, it creates two types of binaural cues: interaural level differences and interaural timing differences.']

['What does the interaural level difference refer to?', 'Interaural level difference refers to the fact that a sound coming from the right side of your body is more intense at your right ear than at your left ear because of the attenuation of the sound wave as it passes through your head.']

['What is the small difference in the time at which a given sound wave arrives at each ear?', 'Interaural timing difference refers to the small difference in the time at which a given sound wave arrives at each ear.']
['What do people use binaural cues for?', 'Certain brain areas monitor these differences to construct where along a horizontal axis a sound originates (Grothe et al., 2010).']
['What is the partial or complete inability to hear?', 'Deafness is the partial or complete inability to hear.']
['Are people born deaf?', 'Some people are born without hearing, which is known as congenital deafness.']
['What is the other way to lose hearing?', 'Other people suffer from conductive hearing loss, which is due to a problem delivering sound energy to the cochlea.']

['How does this cause hearing loss?', 'Causes for conductive hearing loss include blockage of the ear canal, a hole in the tympanic membrane, problems with the ossicles, or fluid in the space between the eardrum and cochlea.']
['What is the most common form of hearing loss?', 'Another group of people suffer from sensorineural hearing loss, which is the most common form of hearing loss.']

['What can cause Sensorineural hearing loss?', 'Sensorineural hearing loss can be caused by many factors, such as aging, head or acoustic trauma, infections and diseases (such as measles or mumps), medications, environmental effects such as noise exposure (noise-induced hearing loss, as shown in Figure 5.20), tumors, and toxins (such as those found in certain solvents and metals).']

['What happens in the hearing loss section?', 'Given the mechanical nature by which the sound wave stimulus is transmitted from the eardrum through the ossicles to the oval window of the cochlea, some degree of hearing loss is inevitable.']
['What is the cause of conductive hearing loss?', 'With conductive hearing loss, hearing problems are associated with a failure in the vibration of the eardrum and/or movement of the ossicles.']

['How are hearing problems treated?', 'These problems are often dealt with through devices like hearing aids that amplify incoming sound waves to make vibration of the eardrum and movement of the ossicles more likely to occur.']
['what is sensorineural hearing loss?', 'When the hearing problem is associated with a failure to transmit neural signals from the cochlea to the brain, it is called sensorineural hearing loss.']
['What is the name of a disease that results in sensorineural hearing loss?', "One disease that results in sensorineural hearing loss is Ménière's disease."]

["What is the most common symptom of Ménière's disease?", "Although not well understood, Ménière's disease results in a degeneration of inner ear structures that can lead to hearing loss, tinnitus (constant ringing or buzzing), vertigo (a sense of spinning), and an increase in pressure within the inner ear (Semaan & Megerian, 2011)."]
['What is the treatment for this kind of loss?', 'This kind of loss cannot be treated with hearing aids, but some individuals might be candidates for a cochlear implant as a treatment option.']
['What are cochlear implants made of?', 'Cochlear implants are electronic devices that consist of a microphone, a speech processor, and an electrode array.']
['How do they work?', 'The device receives incoming sound information and directly stimulates the auditory nerve to transmit information to the brain.']
['What are the body senses?', 'Vision and hearing have received an incredible amount of attention from researchers over the years.']
['Why is this?', 'While there is still much to be learned about how these sensory systems work, we have a much better understanding of them than of our other sensory modalities.']
['What are some of these other modalities?', 'In this section, we will explore our chemical senses (taste and smell) and our body senses (touch, temperature, pain, balance, and body position).']

['What are the chemical senses?', 'Taste (gustation) and smell (olfaction) are called chemical senses because both have sensory receptors that respond to molecules in the food we eat or in the air we breathe.']
['Is there any interaction between our chemical senses?', 'There is a pronounced interaction between our chemical senses.']

['What can you tell me about the interaction between these two?', 'For example, when we describe the flavor of a given food, we are really referring to both gustatory and olfactory properties of the food working in combination.']
['What are the four basic groupings of taste?', 'You have learned since elementary school that there are four basic groupings of taste: sweet, salty, sour, and bitter.']
['Are there more than four basic groupings?', 'Research demonstrates, however, that we have at least six taste groupings.']
['What is the fifth taste?', 'Umami is our fifth taste.']

['What is the Japanese word for yummy?', 'Umami is actually a Japanese word that roughly translates to yummy, and it is associated with a taste for monosodium glutamate (Kinnamon & Vandenbeuch, 2009).']

['What other tastes do we possess?', 'There is also a growing body of experimental evidence suggesting that we possess a taste for the fatty content of a given food (Mizushige, Inoue, & Fushiki, 2007).']

['What is the most important information in the passage?', 'Molecules from the food and beverages we consume dissolve in our saliva and interact with taste receptors on our tongue and in our mouth and throat.']
['What are the taste receptor cells like?', 'Taste buds are formed by groupings of taste receptor cells with hair-like extensions that protrude into the central pore of the taste bud.']

['What is the lifespan of these cells?', 'Taste buds have a life cycle of ten days to two weeks, so even destroying some by burning your tongue won’t have any long-term effect; they just grow right back.']

['What happens to the cells when taste molecules bind to receptors on this extension?', 'Taste molecules bind to receptors on this extension and cause chemical changes within the sensory cell that result in neural impulses being transmitted to the brain via different nerves, depending on where the receptor is located.']

['Where does the brain receive the information?', 'Taste information is transmitted to the medulla, thalamus, and limbic system, and to the gustatory cortex, which is tucked underneath the overlap between the frontal and temporal lobes (Maffei, Haley, & Fontanini, 2012; Roper, 2013).']
['Where are the receptor cells located?', 'Olfactory receptor cells are located in a mucous membrane at the top of the nose.']

['How are they able to sense?', 'Small hair-like extensions from these receptors serve as the sites for odor molecules dissolved in the mucus to interact with chemical receptors located on these extensions.']

['How do they get those signals to the brain?', 'Once an odor molecule has bound a given receptor, chemical changes within the cell result in signals being sent to the olfactory bulb: a bulb-like structure at the tip of the frontal lobe where the olfactory nerves begin.']

['Where does the information go from there?', 'From the olfactory bulb, information is sent to regions of the limbic system and to the primary olfactory cortex, which is located very near the gustatory cortex (Lodovichi & Belluscio, 2012; Spors et al., 2013).']
['What are the remarkable things about olfactory systems?', 'There is tremendous variation in the sensitivity of the olfactory systems of different species.']
['What do dogs have that humans do not?', 'We often think of dogs as having far superior olfactory systems than our own, and indeed, dogs can do some remarkable things with their noses.']
['What can dogs detect?', 'There is some evidence to suggest that dogs can “smell” dangerous drops in blood glucose levels as well as cancerous tumors (Wells, 2010).']

['What are the olfactory receptors?', 'Dogs’ extraordinary olfactory abilities may be due to the increased number of functional genes for olfactory receptors (between 800 and 1200), compared to the fewer than 400 observed in humans and other primates (Niimura & Nei, 2007).']
['what was the most important fact you learned about smell?', 'Many species respond to chemical messages, known as pheromones, sent by another individual (Wysocki & Preti, 2004).']
["What happens if it's a male?", 'Pheromonal communication often involves providing information about the reproductive status of a potential mate.']
['what do rats have to do with pheromones?', 'So, for example, when a female rat is ready to mate, it secretes pheromonal signals that draw attention from nearby male rats.']
['how does that affect the males?', 'Pheromonal activation is actually an important component in eliciting sexual behavior in the male rat (Furlow, 1996, 2012; Purvis & Haynes, 1972; Sachs, 1997).']

['What did you find the most interesting about the passage?', 'There has also been a good deal of research (and controversy) about pheromones in humans (Comfort, 1971; Russell, 1976; Wolfgang-Kimball, 1992; Weller, 1998).']
['Are there any other things we need to know about touch?', 'A number of receptors are distributed throughout the skin to respond to various touch-related stimuli.']
['What are these receptors called?', 'These receptors include Meissner’s corpuscles, Pacinian corpuscles, Merkel’s disks, and Ruffini corpuscles.']
['What do these receptors respond to?', 'Meissner’s corpuscles respond to pressure and lower frequency vibrations, and Pacinian corpuscles detect transient pressure and higher frequency vibrations.']
['What receptors respond to light pressure?', 'Merkel’s disks respond to light pressure, while Ruffini corpuscles detect stretch (Abraira & Ginty, 2013).']
['What were the free nerve endings?', 'In addition to the receptors located in the skin, there are also a number of free nerve endings that serve sensory functions.']

['what sensory functions do they serve?', 'These nerve endings respond to a variety of different types of touch-related stimuli and serve as sensory receptors for both thermoception (temperature perception) and nociception (a signal indicating potential harm and maybe pain) (Garland, 2012; Petho & Reeh, 2012; Spray, 1986).']

['What are some parts of the brain?', 'Sensory information collected from the receptors and free nerve endings travels up the spinal cord and is transmitted to regions of the medulla, thalamus, and ultimately to somatosensory cortex, which is located in the postcentral gyrus of the parietal lobe.']
['What is the definition of pain?', 'Pain is an unpleasant experience that involves both physical and psychological components.']
['Why is it important to feel pain?', 'Feeling pain is quite adaptive because it makes us aware of an injury, and it motivates us to remove ourselves from the cause of that injury.']
['Why do we want to remove ourselves from the cause?', 'In addition, pain also makes us less likely to suffer additional injury because we will be gentler with our injured body parts.']
['What can pain be considered to be?', 'Generally speaking, pain can be considered to be neuropathic or inflammatory in nature.']
['Pain that signals some type of tissue damage is known as what?', 'Pain that signals some type of tissue damage is known as inflammatory pain.']
['What is central nervous system?', 'In some situations, pain results from damage to neurons of either the peripheral or central nervous system.']
['What is the brain get exaggerated?', 'As a result, pain signals that are sent to the brain get exaggerated.']
['What is the type of pain that occurs when the nerves are damaged?', 'This type of pain is known as neuropathic pain.']
['What are the multiple treatment options for pain relief?', 'Multiple treatment options for pain relief range from relaxation therapy to the use of analgesic medications to deep brain stimulation.']

['What is the most effective treatment option for a given individual?', 'The most effective treatment option for a given individual will depend on a number of considerations, including the severity and persistence of the pain and any medical/psychological conditions.']
['What is the difference between born without and not feeling pain?', 'Some individuals are born without the ability to feel pain.']
['What is the name of the rare genetic disorder?', 'This very rare genetic disorder is known as congenital insensitivity to pain (or congenital analgesia).']
['What happens to those with congenital analgesia?', 'While those with congenital analgesia can detect differences in temperature and pressure, they cannot experience pain.']
['What happens when they get injured?', 'As a result, they often suffer significant injuries.']
['What happens to young children?', 'Young children have serious mouth and tongue injuries because they have bitten themselves repeatedly.']

['What happens to the people that were born with this?', 'Not surprisingly, individuals suffering from this disorder have much shorter life expectancies due to their injuries and secondary infections of injured sites (U.S. National Library of Medicine, 2013).']
['What is the main subject of this passage?', 'The vestibular sense contributes to our ability to maintain balance and body posture.']

['Where are the major sensory organs of this system found?', 'As Figure 5.24 shows, the major sensory organs (utricle, saccule, and the three semicircular canals) of this system are located next to the cochlea in the inner ear.']

['What kind of cells are in the vestibular organs?', 'The vestibular organs are fluid-filled and have hair cells, similar to the ones found in the auditory system, which respond to movement of the head and gravitational forces.']
['What does these hair cells do?', 'When these hair cells are stimulated, they send signals to the brain via the vestibular nerve.']

['How is this system important?', 'Although we may not be consciously aware of our vestibular system’s sensory information under normal circumstances, its importance is apparent when we experience motion sickness and/or dizziness related to infections of the inner ear (Khan & Chang, 2013).']

['What is the vestibular system?', 'In addition to maintaining balance, the vestibular system collects information critical for controlling movement and the reflexes that move various parts of our bodies to compensate for changes in body position.']

['What do we learn about the kinesthesia?', 'Therefore, both proprioception (perception of body position) and kinesthesia (perception of the body’s movement through space) interact with information provided by the vestibular system.']

['What are sensory systems?', 'These sensory systems also gather information from receptors that respond to stretch and tension in muscles, joints, skin, and tendons (Lackner & DiZio, 2005; Proske, 2006; Proske & Gandevia, 2012).']
['What is the information transported to the brain via?', 'Proprioceptive and kinesthetic information travels to the brain via the spinal column.']

['What else is significant about these sensory systems?', 'Several cortical regions in addition to the cerebellum receive information from and send information to the sensory organs of the proprioceptive and kinesthetic systems.']

['What is an insight?', 'In the early part of the 20th century, Max Wertheimer published a paper demonstrating that individuals perceived motion in rapidly flickering static images—an insight that came to him as he used a child’s toy tachistoscope.']

['What did Wertheimer, and his assistants Wolfgang Köhler and Kurt Koffka, who later became his partners, believe that perception involved more than simply combining sensory stimuli?', 'Wertheimer, and his assistants Wolfgang Köhler and Kurt Koffka, who later became his partners, believed that perception involved more than simply combining sensory stimuli.']
['What did his belief lead to?', 'This belief led to a new movement within the field of psychology known as Gestalt psychology.']
['What is the meaning of the word gestalt?', 'The word gestalt literally means form or pattern, but its use reflects the idea that the whole is different from the sum of its parts.']
['What is gestalt psychology?', 'In other words, the brain creates a perception that is more than simply the sum of available sensory inputs, and it does so in predictable ways.']
['What are these ways?', 'Gestalt psychologists translated these predictable ways into principles by which we organize sensory information.']
['What was the result of the study?', 'As a result, Gestalt psychology has been extremely influential in the area of sensation and perception (Rock & Palmer, 1990).']
['What is the figure-ground relationship?', 'One Gestalt principle is the figure-ground relationship.']
['According to this principle, what do we tend to segment our visual world into?', 'According to this principle, we tend to segment our visual world into figure and ground.']
['What is the difference between figure and ground?', 'Figure is the object or person that is the focus of the visual field, while the ground is the background.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'As Figure 5.25 shows, our perception can vary tremendously, depending on what is perceived as figure and what is perceived as ground.']

['What else is important about the figure-ground relationship?', 'Presumably, our ability to interpret sensory information depends on what we label as figure and what we label as ground in any particular case, although this assumption has been called into question (Peterson & Gibson, 1994; Vecera & O’Reilly, 1998).']
['What is another Gestalt principle?', 'Another Gestalt principle for organizing sensory stimuli into meaningful perception is proximity.']
['What is proximity?', 'This principle asserts that things that are close to one another tend to be grouped together, as Figure 5.26 illustrates.']
['What is proximity concept?', 'How we read something provides another illustration of the proximity concept.']
['What is an example of proximity concept?', 'For example, we read this sentence like this, notl iket hiso rt hat.']

['What are some examples of how we perceive words?', 'We group the letters of a given word together because there are no spaces between the letters, and we perceive words because there are spaces between each word.']
['What else can you tell me about this passage?', 'Here are some more examples:']
['What is something you learned about the visual field?', 'We might also use the principle of similarity to group things in our visual fields.']
['What is this principle about?', 'According to this principle, things that are alike tend to be grouped together.']
['What can this tell us about people?', 'For example, when watching a football game, we tend to group individuals based on the colors of their uniforms.']
['What can you tell me about offensive drive?', 'When watching an offensive drive, we can get a sense of the two teams simply by grouping along this dimension.']
['What are two additional gestalt principles?', 'Two additional Gestalt principles are the law of continuity (or good continuation) and closure.']
['What does the law of continuity mean?', 'The law of continuity suggests that we are more likely to perceive continuous, smooth flowing lines rather than jagged, broken lines.']
['What does the principle of closure mean?', 'The principle of closure states that we organize our perceptions into complete objects rather than as a series of parts.']

['What does pattern perception mean?', 'According to Gestalt theorists, pattern perception, or our ability to discriminate among different figures and shapes, occurs by following the principles described above.']
['How can people misperceive reality?', 'You probably feel fairly certain that your perception accurately matches the real world, but this is not always the case.']
['How do people make educated guesses?', 'Our perceptions are based on perceptual hypotheses: educated guesses that we make while interpreting sensory information.']
['How do these hypotheses influence perception?', 'These hypotheses are informed by a number of factors, including our personalities, experiences, and expectations.']
['What do we do with these hypotheses?', 'We use these hypotheses to generate our perceptual set.']

['What does research show about perception?', 'For instance, research has demonstrated that those who are given verbal priming produce a biased interpretation of complex ambiguous figures (Goolkasian & Woodbury, 2010).']
['What do birds do as winter approaches?', 'Birds build nests and migrate as winter approaches.']
['What do infants do for nurishment?', 'Infants suckle for nurishment.']
['What do dogs do to get rid of water?', 'Dogs shake water off wet fur.']
['What do salmon do?', 'Salmon swim upstream to spawn, and spiders spin intricate webs.']
['What is unlearned?', 'They all are unlearned behaviors.']
