['What are instincts?', 'Both instincts and reflexes are innate (unlearned) behaviors that organisms are born with.']
['What is the motor or neural reaction to a specific stimulus in the environment?', 'Reflexes are a motor or neural reaction to a specific stimulus in the environment.']

['What are reflexes like?', 'They tend to be simpler than instincts, involve the activity of specific body parts and systems (e.g., the knee-jerk reflex and the contraction of the pupil in bright light), and involve more primitive centers of the central nervous system (e.g., the spinal cord and the medulla).']

['What is the difference between instincts and reflexes?', 'In contrast, instincts are innate behaviors that are triggered by a broader range of events, such as maturation and the change of seasons.']
['What are instincts like?', 'They are more complex patterns of behavior, involve movement of the organism as a whole (e.g., sexual activity and migration), and involve higher brain centers.']
['What is the difference between instincts and learned behaviors?', 'Both reflexes and instincts help an organism adapt to its environment and do not have to be learned.']
['Are reflexes or instincts generally only found in one species?', 'For example, every healthy human baby has a sucking reflex, present at birth.']
['What is the sucking reflex?', 'Babies are born knowing how to suck on a nipple, whether artificial (from a bottle) or human.']
['Why are infants able to suck?', 'Nobody teaches the baby to suck, just as no one teaches a sea turtle hatchling to move toward the ocean.']
['What can be learned?', 'Learning, like reflexes and instincts, allows an organism to adapt to its environment.']

['What can be learned?', 'But unlike instincts and reflexes, learned behaviors involve change and experience: learning is a relatively permanent change in behavior or knowledge that results from experience.']
['What is the difference between innate behaviors and learning?', 'In contrast to the innate behaviors discussed above, learning involves acquiring knowledge and skills through experience.']

['What else is covered in this section?', 'Looking back at our surfing scenario, Julian will have to spend much more time training with his surfboard before he learns how to ride the waves like his father.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Learning to surf, as well as any complex learning process (e.g., learning about the discipline of psychology), involves a complex interaction of conscious and unconscious processes.']
['What is the simplest component of learning?', 'Learning has traditionally been studied in terms of its simplest components—the associations our minds automatically make between events.']
['What can explain this?', 'Our minds have a natural tendency to connect events that occur closely together or in sequence.']

['What happens when an organism makes connections between stimuli or events that occur together in the environment?', 'Associative learning occurs when an organism makes connections between stimuli or events that occur together in the environment.']

['How does that connect?', 'You will see that associative learning is central to all three basic learning processes discussed in this chapter; classical conditioning tends to involve unconscious processes, operant conditioning tends to involve conscious processes, and observational learning adds social and cognitive layers to all the basic associative processes, both conscious and unconscious.']

['Are there more facts?', 'These learning processes will be discussed in detail later in the chapter, but it is helpful to have a brief overview of each as you begin to explore how learning is understood from a psychological perspective.']
['What is classical conditioning?', 'In classical conditioning, also known as Pavlovian conditioning, organisms learn to associate events—or stimuli—that repeatedly happen together.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'We experience this process throughout our daily lives.']
['What is the difference between a flash of lightning and a loud boom of thunder?', 'For example, you might see a flash of lightning in the sky during a storm and then hear a loud boom of thunder.']
['What happens when you hear thunder?', 'The sound of the thunder naturally makes you jump (loud noises have that effect by reflex).']
['What happens when you see lightning?', 'Because lightning reliably predicts the impending boom of thunder, you may associate the two and jump when you see lightning.']
['What is the best part about the article?', 'Psychological researchers study this associative process by focusing on what can be seen and measured—behaviors.']
['What is operant conditioning?', 'In operant conditioning, organisms learn, again, to associate events—a behavior and its consequence (reinforcement or punishment).']
['What is the consequence of a behavior?', 'A pleasant consequence encourages more of that behavior in the future, whereas a punishment deters the behavior.']
['How is this used?', 'Imagine you are teaching your dog, Hodor, to sit.']
['What are you teaching him to do?', 'You tell Hodor to sit, and give him a treat when he does.']
['What does Hodor do?', 'After repeated experiences, Hodor begins to associate the act of sitting with receiving a treat.']
['What kind of treat does the dog get for sitting?', 'He learns that the consequence of sitting is that he gets a doggie biscuit.']

['How does it make the dog want to sit?', 'Conversely, if the dog is punished when exhibiting a behavior, it becomes conditioned to avoid that behavior (e.g., receiving a small shock when crossing the boundary of an invisible electric fence).']
['What is observational learning?', 'Observational learning extends the effective range of both classical and operant conditioning.']

['What is the process of watching others and then imitating what they do called?', 'In contrast to classical and operant conditioning, in which learning occurs only through direct experience, observational learning is the process of watching others and then imitating what they do.']
['What is a common example of observational learning?', 'A lot of learning among humans and other animals comes from observational learning.']
['What kind of example was used?', 'To get an idea of the extra effective range that observational learning brings, consider Ben and his son Julian from the introduction.']
['How does Julian learn the most?', 'By watching his father, he can imitate the moves that bring success and avoid the moves that lead to failure.']
['What is the next section about?', 'All of the approaches covered in this chapter are part of a particular tradition in psychology, called behaviorism, which we discuss in the next section.']
['What does the next section contain?', 'However, these approaches do not represent the entire study of learning.']

['How do the other chapters aid?', 'Separate traditions of learning have taken shape within different fields of psychology, such as memory and cognition, so you will find that other chapters will round out your understanding of the topic.']
['Are there other things to know about this passage?', 'Over time these traditions tend to converge.']

['What happens after this?', 'For example, in this chapter you will see how cognition has come to play a larger role in behaviorism, whose more extreme adherents once insisted that behaviors are triggered by the environment with no intervening thought.']
['What is the context of this document?', 'Even if you are new to the study of psychology, chances are that you have heard of Pavlov and his famous dogs.']
['Who did the experiment on dogs?', 'Pavlov (1849–1936), a Russian scientist, performed extensive research on dogs and is best known for his experiments in classical conditioning.']

['What is classical conditioning?', 'As we discussed briefly in the previous section, classical conditioning is a process by which we learn to associate stimuli and, consequently, to anticipate events.']
['What did Pavlov come to conclusions about?', 'Pavlov came to his conclusions about how learning occurs completely by accident.']
['Was Pavlov a psychologist?', 'Pavlov was a physiologist, not a psychologist.']
['What do physiologists study?', 'Physiologists study the life processes of organisms, from the molecular level to the level of cells, organ systems, and entire organisms.']
['What did Pavlov study?', 'Pavlov’s area of interest was the digestive system (Hunt, 2007).']
['What did Pavlov measure in his studies with dogs?', 'In his studies with dogs, Pavlov measured the amount of saliva produced in response to various foods.']

['What did Pavlov observe in the dogs?', "Over time, Pavlov (1927) observed that the dogs began to salivate not only at the taste of food, but also at the sight of food, at the sight of an empty food bowl, and even at the sound of the laboratory assistants' footsteps."]
['What is the significance of salivating at the smell of food?', 'Salivating to food in the mouth is reflexive, so no learning is involved.']
["What other responses do the dogs get in Pavlov's studies?", 'However, dogs don’t naturally salivate at the sight of an empty bowl or the sound of footsteps.']
['How many days have we got to study?', "These unusual responses intrigued Pavlov, and he wondered what accounted for what he called the dogs' “psychic secretions” (Pavlov, 1927)."]
['Why do the dogs salivate?', 'To explore this phenomenon in an objective manner, Pavlov designed a series of carefully controlled experiments to see which stimuli would cause the dogs to salivate.']

['What were the results of his studies?', 'He was able to train the dogs to salivate in response to stimuli that clearly had nothing to do with food, such as the sound of a bell, a light, and a touch on the leg.']

['What did Pavlov discover?', 'Through his experiments, Pavlov realized that an organism has two types of responses to its environment: (1) unconditioned (unlearned) responses, or reflexes, and (2) conditioned (learned) responses.']
['What is the first paragraph of the passage?', 'In Pavlov’s experiments, the dogs salivated each time meat powder was presented to them.']
['What is a reflexive response?', 'The meat powder in this situation was an unconditioned stimulus (UCS): a stimulus that elicits a reflexive response in an organism.']
['What is an unconditioned response?', 'The dogs’ salivation was an unconditioned response (UCR): a natural (unlearned) reaction to a given stimulus.']
['What can conditioning teach us?', 'Before conditioning, think of the dogs’ stimulus and response like this:']
['What is the neutral stimulus in classical conditioning?', 'In classical conditioning, a neutral stimulus is presented immediately before an unconditioned stimulus.']
['What would Pavlov sound to get the dogs to eat the meat?', 'Pavlov would sound a tone (like ringing a bell) and then give the dogs the meat powder.']
['What is the tone of the passage?', 'The tone was the neutral stimulus (NS), which is a stimulus that does not naturally elicit a response.']
['What is the result of conditioning?', 'Prior to conditioning, the dogs did not salivate when they just heard the tone because the tone had no association for the dogs.']

['Why did Pavlov do this experiment?', 'When Pavlov paired the tone with the meat powder over and over again, the previously neutral stimulus (the tone) also began to elicit salivation from the dogs.']

['What does the neutral stimulus become?', 'Thus, the neutral stimulus became the conditioned stimulus (CS), which is a stimulus that elicits a response after repeatedly being paired with an unconditioned stimulus.']
['What does tone alone evoke?', 'Eventually, the dogs began to salivate to the tone alone, just as they previously had salivated at the sound of the assistants’ footsteps.']
['What is the behavior caused by the conditioned stimulus called?', 'The behavior caused by the conditioned stimulus is called the conditioned response (CR).']
['What does CR signify?', 'In the case of Pavlov’s dogs, they had learned to associate the tone (CS) with being fed, and they began to salivate (CR) in anticipation of food.']
['What is the real world application of this passage?', 'Consider the case of Moisha, who was diagnosed with cancer.']
["What did Moisha's cancer do to her body?", 'When she received her first chemotherapy treatment, she vomited shortly after the chemicals were injected.']
['When did she vomit the chemicals?', 'In fact, every trip to the doctor for chemotherapy treatment shortly after the drugs were injected, she vomited.']
['How did Moisha’s treatment go?', 'Moisha’s treatment was a success and her cancer went into remission.']
['How did the conditioning affect Moisha?', "Now, when she visits her oncologist's office every 6 months for a check-up, she becomes nauseous."]

['What is the conditioned stimulus in this example?', 'In this case, the chemotherapy drugs are the unconditioned stimulus (UCS), vomiting is the unconditioned response (UCR), the doctor’s office is the conditioned stimulus (CS) after being paired with the UCS, and nausea is the conditioned response (CR).']
['What did Moisha do to become nauseous?', "Let's assume that the chemotherapy drugs that Moisha takes are given through a syringe injection."]
['What happens after Moisha receives her medication?', "After entering the doctor's office, Moisha sees a syringe, and then gets her medication."]
['What happens to Moisha?', "In addition to the doctor's office, Moisha will learn to associate the syringe with the medication and will respond to syringes with nausea."]

['What is an example of higher-order (or second-order) conditioning?', "This is an example of higher-order (or second-order) conditioning, when the conditioned stimulus (the doctor's office) serves to condition another stimulus (the syringe)."]
['What is second order conditioning?', 'It is hard to achieve anything above second-order conditioning.']

['How does it work?', "For example, if someone rang a bell every time Moisha received a syringe injection of chemotherapy drugs in the doctor's office, Moisha likely will never get sick in response to the bell."]
['What type of conditioning is involved in real world application?', 'Consider another example of classical conditioning.']
['What is an example of a pet?', 'Let’s say you have a cat named Tiger, who is quite spoiled.']
['What do you do to make sure the cat only eats cat food?', 'You keep her food in a separate cabinet, and you also have a special electric can opener that you use only to open cans of cat food.']
['What did the cat learn about the can opener?', 'For every meal, Tiger hears the distinctive sound of the electric can opener (“zzhzhz”) and then gets her food.']
['What is the cat\'s response when she hears "zzhzhz"?', 'Tiger quickly learns that when she hears “zzhzhz” she is about to get fed.']
['What will the cat do when it hears the sound?', 'She will likely get excited and run to where you are preparing her food.']
['What is the significance of this example?', 'This is an example of classical conditioning.']
['Did you have any other questions?', 'In that case, Tiger hears “squeak” (the cabinet), “zzhzhz” (the electric can opener), and then she gets her food.']
['Did the dog learn to do this?', 'Tiger will learn to get excited when she hears the “squeak” of the cabinet.']
['Did you find anything else interesting?', 'Pairing a new neutral stimulus (“squeak”) with the conditioned stimulus (“zzhzhz”) is called higher-order conditioning, or second-order conditioning.']
['What does the second-order conditioning mean?', 'This means you are using the conditioned stimulus of the can opener to condition another stimulus: the squeaky cabinet.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects of the article?', 'It is hard to achieve anything above second-order conditioning.']

['What are some examples of a stimulus that causes a response?', 'For example, if you ring a bell, open the cabinet (“squeak”), use the can opener (“zzhzhz”), and then feed Tiger, Tiger will likely never get excited when hearing the bell alone.']
['What is one of the things you learned about classical conditioning?', 'Classical conditioning also applies to humans, even babies.']
['What were some examples of applications?', 'For example, Elan buys formula in blue canisters for their six-month-old daughter, Angelina.']
['What did you learn about that?', 'Whenever Elan takes out a formula container, Angelina gets excited, tries to reach toward the food, and most likely salivates.']
['What are some examples of classical conditioning?', 'So far, all of the examples have involved food, but classical conditioning extends beyond the basic need to be fed.']
['What else do we do beyond feeding?', 'Consider our earlier example of a dog whose owners install an invisible electric dog fence.']
['What happens when the dog sees the invisible fence?', 'A small electrical shock (unconditioned stimulus) elicits discomfort (unconditioned response).']

['Does the dog move when the unconditioned stimulus (shock) is paired with a neutral stimulus (the edge of a yard)?', 'When the unconditioned stimulus (shock) is paired with a neutral stimulus (the edge of a yard), the dog associates the discomfort (unconditioned response) with the edge of the yard (conditioned stimulus) and stays within the set boundaries.']
['Does the dog associate itself with fear?', 'In this example, the edge of the yard  elicits fear and anxiety in the dog.']
['What is the conditioned response?', 'Fear and anxiety are the conditioned response.']
['What is your first question?', 'Now that you know how classical conditioning works and have seen several examples, let’s take a look at some of the general processes involved.']

['What is the simplest example of a general process?', 'In classical conditioning, the initial period of learning is known as acquisition, when an organism learns to connect a neutral stimulus and an unconditioned stimulus.']

['Does it teach a specific reaction?', 'During acquisition, the neutral stimulus begins to elicit the conditioned response, and eventually the neutral stimulus becomes a conditioned stimulus capable of eliciting the conditioned response by itself.']
['What is important for conditioning to occur?', 'Timing is important for conditioning to occur.']
['What happens if it is too long?', 'Typically, there should only be a brief interval between presentation of the conditioned stimulus and the unconditioned stimulus.']
['Do you think it has to be a long interval?', 'Depending on what is being conditioned, sometimes this interval is as little as five seconds (Chance, 2009).']
['Why does it have to be so short?', 'However, with other types of conditioning, the interval can be up to several hours.']

['What is taste aversion?', 'Taste aversion is a type of conditioning in which an interval of several hours may pass between the conditioned stimulus (something ingested) and the unconditioned stimulus (nausea or illness).']
['What is the study about?', 'Here’s how it works.']
['What do you do after you grab a quick lunch?', 'Between classes, you and a friend grab a quick lunch from a food cart on campus.']
['What do you do after class?', 'You share a dish of chicken curry and head off to your next class.']
['What happens after you eat it?', 'A few hours later, you feel nauseous and become ill.']

['How did you feel after eating the chicken curry?', 'Although your friend is fine and you determine that you have intestinal flu (the food is not the culprit), you’ve developed a taste aversion; the next time you are at a restaurant and someone orders curry, you immediately feel ill.']
['What caused the aversion?', 'While the chicken dish is not what made you sick, you are experiencing taste aversion: you’ve been conditioned to be averse to a food after a single, bad experience.']

['What is the purpose of taste aversion?', 'Research into taste aversion suggests that this response may be an evolutionary adaptation designed to help organisms quickly learn to avoid harmful foods (Garcia & Rusiniak, 1980; Garcia & Koelling, 1966).']

['What does the research say about this?', 'Not only may this contribute to species survival via natural selection, but it may also help us develop strategies for challenges such as helping cancer patients through the nausea induced by certain treatments (Holmes, 1993; Jacobsen et al., 1993; Hutton, Baracos, & Wismer, 2007; Skolin et al., 2006).']
['what is the main idea of the passage?', 'Garcia and Koelling (1966) showed not only that taste aversions could be conditioned, but also that there were biological constraints to learning.']
['How did they conditioned taste aversions?', 'In their study, separate groups of rats were conditioned to associate either a flavor with illness, or lights and sounds with illness.']

['How did it work?', 'Results showed that all rats exposed to flavor-illness pairings learned to avoid the flavor, but none of the rats exposed to lights and sounds with illness learned to avoid lights or sounds.']

['What added evidence to the idea that classical conditioning could contribute to species survival by helping organisms learn to avoid stimuli that posed real dangers to health and welfare?', 'This added evidence to the idea that classical conditioning could contribute to species survival by helping organisms learn to avoid stimuli that posed real dangers to health and welfare.']
['What is the first part of this section about?', 'Robert Rescorla demonstrated how powerfully an organism can learn to predict the UCS from the CS.']
['How did he do that?', 'Take, for example, the following two situations.']
['What did Ari do every day?', 'Ari’s dad always has dinner on the table every day at 6:00.']
['What did Soraya do?', 'Soraya’s mom switches it up so that some days they eat dinner at 6:00, some days they eat at 5:00, and other days they eat at 7:00.']

['What does Ari do every day before 6:00?', "For Ari, 6:00 reliably and consistently predicts dinner, so Ari will likely start feeling hungry every day right before 6:00, even if he's had a late snack."]
['What happened to Soraya?', 'Soraya, on the other hand, will be less likely to associate 6:00 with dinner, since 6:00 does not always predict that dinner is coming.']

['What else happened?', 'Rescorla, along with his colleague at Yale University, Alan Wagner, developed a mathematical formula that could be used to calculate the probability that an association would be learned given the ability of a conditioned stimulus to predict the occurrence of an unconditioned stimulus and other factors; today this is known as the Rescorla-Wagner model (Rescorla & Wagner, 1972)']
['What is the main idea of this section?', 'In Tiger’s case, imagine what would happen if you stopped using the electric can opener for her food and began to use it only for human food.']
['What would happen if Tiger heard the can opener?', 'Now, Tiger would hear the can opener, but she would not get food.']

['What would happen if you gave the conditioned stimulus, but not the unconditioned stimulus?', 'In classical conditioning terms, you would be giving the conditioned stimulus, but not the unconditioned stimulus.']
['Did Pavlov explore this scenario?', 'Pavlov explored this scenario in his experiments with dogs: sounding the tone without giving the dogs the meat powder.']
['How would the dogs respond to that?', 'Soon the dogs stopped responding to the tone.']

['What is the decrease in the conditioned response when the unconditioned stimulus is no longer presented with the conditioned stimulus?', 'Extinction is the decrease in the conditioned response when the unconditioned stimulus is no longer presented with the conditioned stimulus.']
['What happens next?', 'When presented with the conditioned stimulus alone, the dog, cat, or other organism would show a weaker and weaker response, and finally no response.']
['What happens with extinction?', 'In classical conditioning terms, there is a gradual weakening and disappearance of the conditioned response.']

['What did Pavlov study?', 'As we just discussed, Pavlov found that when he repeatedly presented the bell (conditioned stimulus) without the meat powder (unconditioned stimulus), extinction occurred; the dogs stopped salivating to the bell.']
['Did the dogs retrain?', 'However, after a couple of hours of resting from this extinction training, the dogs again began to salivate when Pavlov rang the bell.']

['What did Pavlov use to train his dog?', 'When you finally got it fixed and started using it to open Tiger’s food again, Tiger would remember the association between the can opener and her food—she would get excited and run to the kitchen when she heard the sound.']

['What concept did Pavlov call spontaneous recovery?', 'The behavior of Pavlov’s dogs and Tiger illustrates a concept Pavlov called spontaneous recovery: the return of a previously extinguished conditioned response following a rest period.']
['What is the general process of the passage?', 'Of course, these processes also apply in humans.']
['Can you give me an example of a situation where you would be a victim of a crime?', 'For example, let’s say that every day when you walk to campus, an ice cream truck passes your route.']
['What is your reaction to the truck?', 'Day after day, you hear the truck’s music (neutral stimulus), so you finally stop and purchase a chocolate ice cream bar.']
['What happens after you buy the chocolate ice cream?', 'You take a bite (unconditioned stimulus) and then your mouth waters (unconditioned response).']

['What happens after this?', 'This initial period of learning is known as acquisition, when you begin to connect the neutral stimulus (the sound of the truck) and the unconditioned stimulus (the taste of the chocolate ice cream in your mouth).']

['What happens during this period of learning?', 'During acquisition, the conditioned response gets stronger and stronger through repeated pairings of the conditioned stimulus and unconditioned stimulus.']

['Is there anything else that I should know?', 'Several days (and ice cream bars) later, you notice that your mouth begins to water (conditioned response) as soon as you hear the truck’s musical jingle—even before you bite into the ice cream bar.']
['What happened after that?', 'Then one day you head down the street.']
['What happens when you hear the truck’s music?', 'You hear the truck’s music (conditioned stimulus), and your mouth waters (conditioned response).']
['Is there anything else that you should know?', 'However, when you get to the truck, you discover that they are all out of ice cream.']
['What happens when you are unable to get a job?', 'You leave disappointed.']

['What happens after you pass by the truck and hear the music?', 'The next few days you pass by the truck and hear the music, but don’t stop to get an ice cream bar because you’re running late for class.']
['What happens when you practice singing?', 'You begin to salivate less and less when you hear the music, until by the end of the week, your mouth no longer waters when you hear the tune.']
['Is there anything else that I should know about this passage?', 'This illustrates extinction.']

['What is extinction?', 'The conditioned response weakens when only the conditioned stimulus (the sound of the truck) is presented, without being followed by the unconditioned stimulus (chocolate ice cream in the mouth).']
['What happens after the weekend?', 'Then the weekend comes.']
['What happens after you get to campus?', 'Monday morning arrives and you take your usual route to campus.']
['What happens after you round the corner?', 'You round the corner and hear the truck again.']
['What happens when you eat a lot of food?', 'Your mouth begins to water again.']
['Is there anything else that I should know?', 'After a break from conditioning, the conditioned response reappears, which indicates spontaneous recovery.']
['What are the two types of acquired associations?', 'Acquisition and extinction involve the strengthening and weakening, respectively, of a learned association.']

['What are the other learning processes involved in determining which stimuli will trigger learned responses?', 'Two other learning processes—stimulus discrimination and stimulus generalization—are involved in determining which stimuli will trigger learned responses.']

['What is stimulus discrimination?', 'Animals (including humans) need to distinguish between stimuli—for example, between sounds that predict a threatening event and sounds that do not—so that they can respond appropriately (such as running away if the sound is threatening).']

['When an organism learns to respond differently to various stimuli that are similar, what is it called?', 'When an organism learns to respond differently to various stimuli that are similar, it is called stimulus discrimination.']
['What is the key point of classical conditioning?', 'In classical conditioning terms, the organism demonstrates the conditioned response only to the conditioned stimulus.']

['What do you need to know about stimulus discrimination?', 'Pavlov’s dogs discriminated between the basic tone that sounded before they were fed and other tones (e.g., the doorbell), because the other sounds did not predict the arrival of food.']
['What else is important?', 'Similarly, Tiger, the cat, discriminated between the sound of the can opener and the sound of the electric mixer.']
['What happened after the first time?', 'When the electric mixer is going, Tiger is not about to be fed, so she does not come running to the kitchen looking for food.']
['What other examples are there?', 'In our other example, Moisha, the cancer patient, discriminated between oncologists and other types of doctors.']
['What happened after she had her treatment?', 'She learned not to feel ill when visiting doctors for other types of appointments, such as her annual physical.']

['What is stimulus discrimination?', 'On the other hand, when an organism demonstrates the conditioned response to stimuli that are similar to the condition stimulus, it is called stimulus generalization, the opposite of stimulus discrimination.']
['How is stimulus generalization related to conditioned response?', 'The more similar a stimulus is to the condition stimulus, the more likely the organism is to give the conditioned response.']
['How can stimulus generalization be applied?', 'For instance, if the electric mixer sounds very similar to the electric can opener, Tiger may come running after hearing its sound.']

['How can stimulus discrimination be applied?', 'But if you do not feed her following the electric mixer sound, and you continue to feed her consistently after the electric can opener sound, she will quickly learn to discriminate between the two sounds (provided they are sufficiently dissimilar that she can tell them apart).']
['What other examples can you provide?', 'In our other example, Moisha continued to feel ill whenever visiting other oncologists or other doctors in the same building as her oncologist.']
['What is the name of the person who is considered the founder of behaviorism?', 'John B. Watson, shown in Figure 6.8, is considered the founder of behaviorism.']

['What was the initial finding of behaviorism?', 'Behaviorism is a school of thought that arose during the first part of the 20th century, which incorporates elements of Pavlov’s classical conditioning (Hunt, 2007).']

['What are some of the differences between Watson and Freud?', 'In stark contrast with Freud, who considered the reasons for behavior to be hidden in the unconscious, Watson championed the idea that all behavior can be studied as a simple stimulus-response reaction, without regard for internal processes.']

['Why did Watson champion that idea?', 'Watson argued that in order for psychology to become a legitimate science, it must shift its concern away from internal mental processes because mental processes cannot be seen or measured.']
['What did Watson say about the measurement of behavior?', 'Instead, he asserted that psychology must focus on outward observable behavior that can be measured.']
['Did you find anything interesting about Watson or Pavlov?', 'Watson’s ideas were influenced by Pavlov’s work.']
["Watson's ideas were influenced by what?", 'According to Watson, human behavior, just like animal behavior, is primarily the result of conditioned responses.']

['What were conditioned responses?', 'Whereas Pavlov’s work with dogs involved the conditioning of reflexes, Watson believed the same principles could be extended to the conditioning of human emotions (Watson, 1919).']

['When was this experiment conducted?', 'In 1920, while chair of the psychology department at Johns Hopkins University, Watson and his graduate student, Rosalie Rayner, conducted research on a baby nicknamed Little Albert.']

['What did Rayner and Watson’s experiments with Little Albert demonstrate?', 'Rayner and Watson’s experiments with Little Albert demonstrated how fears can be conditioned using classical conditioning.']
['What was the result of the conditioning?', 'Through these experiments, Little Albert was exposed to and conditioned to fear certain things.']
['What did the rat do?', 'Initially he was presented with various neutral stimuli, including a rabbit, a dog, a monkey, masks, cotton wool, and a white rat.']
['What happened to him when he was not afraid?', 'He was not afraid of any of these things.']

['What did Watson, with the help of Rayner, conditioned Little Albert to associate these stimuli with an emotion—fear?', 'Then Watson, with the help of Rayner, conditioned Little Albert to associate these stimuli with an emotion—fear.']
['How did Watson do this?', 'For example, Watson handed Little Albert the white rat, and Little Albert enjoyed playing with it.']
['What happened to the rat?', 'Then Watson made a loud sound, by striking a hammer against a metal bar hanging behind Little Albert’s head, each time Little Albert touched the rat.']
['How did Albert react to the sound?', 'Little Albert was frightened by the sound—demonstrating a reflexive fear of sudden loud noises—and began to cry.']
['What did Watson do next?', 'Watson repeatedly paired the loud sound with the white rat.']
['Did Little Albert become frightened?', 'Soon Little Albert became frightened by the white rat alone.']
['What did Little Albert do next?', 'Days later, Little Albert demonstrated stimulus generalization—he became afraid of other furry things: a rabbit, a furry coat, and even a Santa Claus mask.']
['What did Watson find?', 'Watson had succeeded in conditioning a fear response in Little Albert, thus demonstrating that emotions could become conditioned responses.']

["What was Watson's intention?", 'It had been Watson’s intention to produce a phobia—a persistent, excessive fear of a specific object or situation— through conditioning alone, thus countering Freud’s view that phobias are caused by deep, hidden conflicts in the mind.']
['What did Watson find?', 'However, there is no evidence that Little Albert experienced phobias in later years.']
['What happened after that?', 'Little Albert’s mother moved away, ending the experiment.']
['What was wrong with Watson’s research?', 'While Watson’s research provided new insight into conditioning, it would be considered unethical by today’s standards.']
['what is classical conditioning?', 'The previous section of this chapter focused on the type of associative learning known as classical conditioning.']

['What is operant conditioning?', 'Remember that in classical conditioning, something in the environment triggers a reflex automatically, and researchers train the organism to react to a different stimulus.']
['What happens after that?', 'Now we turn to the second type of associative learning, operant conditioning.']
['what happens in operant conditioning?', 'In operant conditioning, organisms learn to associate a behavior and its consequence.']
['What happens if the consequence is unpleasant?', 'A pleasant consequence makes that behavior more likely to be repeated in the future.']
["What is another example of a dolphin's ability to do tricks?", 'For example, Spirit, a dolphin at the National Aquarium in Baltimore, does a flip in the air when her trainer blows a whistle.']
['What is the consequence of a girl stealing a fish?', 'The consequence is that she gets a fish.']

['What was one of the examples of classical conditioning?', 'Psychologist B. F. Skinner saw that classical conditioning is limited to existing behaviors that are reflexively elicited, and it doesn’t account for new behaviors such as riding a bike.']
['What did Skinner do after he saw this?', 'He proposed a theory about how such behaviors come about.']
['What is the theory of Skinner?', 'Skinner believed that behavior is motivated by the consequences we receive for the behavior: the reinforcements and punishments.']
['Did anyone else propose this theory?', 'His idea that learning is the result of consequences is based on the law of effect, which was first proposed by psychologist Edward Thorndike.']

['What was his theory about reinforcements and punishment?', 'According to the law of effect, behaviors that are followed by consequences that are satisfying to the organism are more likely to be repeated, and behaviors that are followed by unpleasant consequences are less likely to be repeated (Thorndike, 1911).']
['What is the law of effect?', 'Essentially, if an organism does something that brings about a desired result, the organism is more likely to do it again.']
["What happens if the result isn't good?", 'If an organism does something that does not bring about a desired result, the organism is less likely to do it again.']
['What are some examples of the law of effect?', 'An example of the law of effect is in employment.']
['What is the main reason we show up for work?', 'One of the reasons (and often the main reason) we show up for work is because we get paid to do so.']
['How would we feel without getting paid?', 'If we stop getting paid, we will likely stop showing up—even if we love our job.']

["What's a significant point of this section?", 'Working with Thorndike’s law of effect as his foundation, Skinner began conducting scientific experiments on animals (mainly rats and pigeons) to determine how organisms learn through operant conditioning (Skinner, 1938).']
['What was his experiment?', 'He placed these animals inside an operant conditioning chamber, which has come to be known as a “Skinner box”.']
['What does a Skinner box contain?', 'A Skinner box contains a lever (for rats) or disk (for pigeons) that the animal can press or peck for a food reward via the dispenser.']
['What do speakers and lights have to do with operant conditioning?', 'Speakers and lights can be associated with certain behaviors.']
['What does a recorder count?', 'A recorder counts the number of responses made by the animal.']
['What is the main topic of discussion?', 'In discussing operant conditioning, we use several everyday words—positive, negative, reinforcement, and punishment—in a specialized manner.']
['What does the specialized meaning mean?', 'In operant conditioning, positive and negative do not mean good and bad.']
['What does this mean?', 'Instead, positive means you are adding something, and negative means you are taking something away.']
['What does reinforcement mean?', 'Reinforcement means you are increasing a behavior, and punishment means you are decreasing a behavior.']
['What does punishment mean?', 'Reinforcement can be positive or negative, and punishment can also be positive or negative.']
['What is the effect of reinforcers on a behavior?', 'All reinforcers (positive or negative) increase the likelihood of a behavioral response.']
['What does punishment mean?', 'All punishers (positive or negative) decrease the likelihood of a behavioral response.']
['What else did you learn?', 'Now let’s combine these four terms: positive reinforcement, negative reinforcement, positive punishment, and negative punishment.']
['What is the most effective way to teach a person or animal a new behavior?', 'The most effective way to teach a person or animal a new behavior is with positive reinforcement.']
['What is a positive reinforcement?', 'In positive reinforcement, a desirable stimulus is added to increase a behavior.']
['How do you use the idea?', 'For example, you tell your five-year-old son, Jerome, that if he cleans his room, he will get a toy.']
['Why does Jerome clean his room?', 'Jerome quickly cleans his room because he wants a new art set.']
['What happens after that?', 'Let’s pause for a moment.']
['What would you say next?', 'Some people might say, “Why should I reward my child for doing what is expected?”']
['Why do people reward people for something that is already expected of them?', 'But in fact we are constantly and consistently rewarded in our lives.']
['What are some examples of rewards?', 'Our paychecks are rewards, as are high grades and acceptance into our preferred school.']
['How do we reinforce this?', 'Being praised for doing a good job and for passing a driver’s test is also a reward.']
['What is the next lesson?', 'Positive reinforcement as a learning tool is extremely effective.']

['What is one example of how to increase achievement in school districts with below-average reading scores?', 'It has been found that one of the most effective ways to increase achievement in school districts with below-average reading scores was to pay the children to read.']
['What was the purpose of the program?', 'Specifically, second-grade students in Dallas were paid $2 each time they read a book and passed a short quiz about the book.']
['What result did they see?', 'The result was a significant increase in reading comprehension (Fryer, 2010).']
['What do you think Skinner would think of this article?', 'If Skinner were alive today, he would probably think this was a great idea.']
['What was the next part of the article?', 'He was a strong proponent of using operant conditioning principles to influence students’ behavior at school.']

['What did Skinner use operant conditioning for?', 'In fact, in addition to the Skinner box, he also invented what he called a teaching machine that was designed to reward small steps in learning (Skinner, 1961)—an early forerunner of computer-assisted learning.']
['What else did he do?', 'His teaching machine tested students’ knowledge as they worked through various school subjects.']

['What happened if they answered incorrectly?', 'If students answered questions correctly, they received immediate positive reinforcement and could continue; if they answered incorrectly, they did not receive any reinforcement.']

['What was the effect of the reinforcement?', 'The idea was that students would spend additional time studying the material to increase their chance of being reinforced the next time (Skinner, 1961).']
['What is the difference between positive reinforcement and negative reinforcement?', 'In negative reinforcement, an undesirable stimulus is removed to increase a behavior.']

['What are some examples of negative reinforcement?', 'For example, car manufacturers use the principles of negative reinforcement in their seatbelt systems, which go “beep, beep, beep” until you fasten your seatbelt.']
['How does it increase a behavior?', 'The annoying sound stops when you exhibit the desired behavior, increasing the likelihood that you will buckle up in the future.']
['How can it be used in horse training?', 'Negative reinforcement is also used frequently in horse training.']

['What are the other things used in training horses?', 'Riders apply pressure—by pulling the reins or squeezing their legs—and then remove the pressure when the horse performs the desired behavior, such as turning or speeding up.']
['What does the horse want to remove?', 'The pressure is the negative stimulus that the horse wants to remove.']

['What is the difference between punishment and positive reinforcement?', 'Many people confuse negative reinforcement with punishment in operant conditioning, but they are two very different mechanisms.']
['Do either increase or decrease behavior?', 'Remember that reinforcement, even when it is negative, always increases a behavior.']
['What is the contrast between punishment and reward?', 'In contrast, punishment always decreases a behavior.']
['What is an undesirable stimulus?', 'In positive punishment, you add an undesirable stimulus to decrease a behavior.']
['What is an example of positive punishment?', 'An example of positive punishment is scolding a student to get the student to stop texting in class.']
['What happens when you scold someone?', 'In this case, a stimulus (the reprimand) is added in order to decrease the behavior (texting in class).']
['What is an example of negative punishment?', 'In negative punishment, you remove a pleasant stimulus to decrease behavior.']
['What is an example of negative punishment?', 'For example, when a child misbehaves, a parent can take away a favorite toy.']
['What happens when a favorite toy is taken away?', 'In this case, a stimulus (the toy) is removed in order to decrease the behavior.']
['What is the first article?', 'Punishment, especially when it is immediate, is one way to decrease undesirable behavior.']
['What are some examples of a child hitting another child?', 'For example, imagine your four-year-old son, Brandon, hit his younger brother.']
['What can you do to help Brandon?', 'You have Brandon write 100 times “I will not hit my brother" (positive punishment).']
['How would he feel if he was caught?', 'Chances are he won’t repeat this behavior.']
['How do spankings help children?', 'While strategies like this are common today, in the past children were often subject to physical punishment, such as spanking.']
['What are some drawbacks of using physical punishment on children?', 'It’s important to be aware of some of the drawbacks in using physical punishment on children.']
['What is important about punishment?', 'First, punishment may teach fear.']
['What might Brandon do after being punished?', 'Brandon may become fearful of the street, but he also may become fearful of the person who delivered the punishment—you, his parent.']

['What is another way that children who are punished by teachers may come to fear the teacher and try to avoid school?', 'Similarly, children who are punished by teachers may come to fear the teacher and try to avoid school (Gershoff et al., 2010).']
['What is the consequence of corporal punishment?', 'Consequently, most schools in the United States have banned corporal punishment.']
['What is the second important thing to know about punishment?', 'Second, punishment may cause children to become more aggressive and prone to antisocial behavior and delinquency (Gershoff, 2002).']
['What else?', 'They see their parents resort to spanking when they become angry and frustrated, so, in turn, they may act out this same behavior when they become angry and frustrated.']

['What does it do when you spank Brenda when you are angry with her for her misbehavior?', 'For example, because you spank Brenda when you are angry with her for her misbehavior, she might start hitting her friends when they won’t share their toys.']

['What is the purpose of punishment?', 'While positive punishment can be effective in some cases, Skinner suggested that the use of punishment should be weighed against the possible negative effects.']

['What are some negative effects of spanking?', 'Today’s psychologists and parenting experts favor reinforcement over punishment—they recommend that you catch your child doing something good and reward them for it.']
["What was Skinner's approach to operant conditioning?", 'In his operant conditioning experiments, Skinner often used an approach called shaping.']
['What is shaping?', 'Instead of rewarding only the target behavior, in shaping, we reward successive approximations of a target behavior.']
['What did the organism need to do first?', 'Remember that in order for reinforcement to work, the organism must first display the behavior.']
['What is shaping?', 'Shaping is needed because it is extremely unlikely that an organism will display anything but the simplest of behaviors spontaneously.']
['What are the steps in shaping?', 'In shaping, behaviors are broken down into many small, achievable steps.']
['Did they have to take these steps in reverse order?', 'The specific steps used in the process are the following:']
['How do we reinforce a response?', 'Reinforce any response that resembles the desired behavior.']
['Is there another way we can reinforce a response?', 'Then reinforce the response that more closely resembles the desired behavior.']
['When will you no longer reinforce?', 'You will no longer reinforce the previously reinforced response.']
['What will you do next?', 'Next, begin to reinforce the response that even more closely resembles the desired behavior.']
['What will you do next?', 'Continue to reinforce closer and closer approximations of the desired behavior.']
['What should you do after this point?', 'Finally, only reinforce the desired behavior.']
['What is shaping used for?', 'Shaping is often used in teaching a complex behavior or chain of behaviors.']

['What complex behavior is being taught?', 'Skinner used shaping to teach pigeons not only such relatively simple behaviors as pecking a disk in a Skinner box, but also many unusual and entertaining behaviors, such as turning in circles, walking in figure eights, and even playing ping pong; the technique is commonly used by animal trainers today.']
['What is an important part of shaping?', 'An important part of shaping is stimulus discrimination.']
['What is stimulus discrimination?', 'Recall Pavlov’s dogs—he trained them to respond to the tone of a bell, and not to similar tones or sounds.']
['What is another way discrimination is important?', 'This discrimination is also important in operant conditioning and in shaping behavior.']
['What is one example of shaping?', 'Let’s consider parents whose goal is to have their child learn to clean his room.']
['How do they teach their child to clean his room?', 'They use shaping to help him master steps toward the goal.']
['How do they use shaping?', 'Instead of performing the entire task, they set up these steps and reinforce each step.']
['What are the steps to clean up a toy?', 'First, he cleans up one toy.']
['What happens after he cleans one toy?', 'Second, he cleans up five toys.']
['What happens after he cleans five toys?', 'Third, he chooses whether to pick up ten toys or put his books and clothes away.']
['What happens after he chooses whether to pick up ten toys?', 'Fourth, he cleans up everything except two toys.']
['What happens after he cleans two toys?', 'Finally, he cleans his entire room.']
['What are the examples of primary and secondary reinforcers?', 'Rewards such as stickers, praise, money, toys, and more can be used to reinforce learning.']
['What do you think of Skinner’s rats?', 'Let’s go back to Skinner’s rats again.']
['Did they have any other positive reinforcement?', 'They were rewarded with food each time they pressed the lever.']
['What would be used to reinforce the rats?', 'For animals, food would be an obvious reinforcer.']
['What are some examples of primary reinforcers?', 'For your child Chris, it was the promise of a toy when they cleaned their room.']
['How is candy an example of primary reinforcer?', 'If you gave Sydney a piece of candy every time Sydney scored a goal, you would be using a primary reinforcer.']
['What does primary mean?', 'Primary reinforcers are reinforcers that have innate reinforcing qualities.']
['Are there other benefits of primary reinforcers?', 'These kinds of reinforcers are not learned.']
['What are some examples of primary reinforcers?', 'Water, food, sleep, shelter, sex, and touch, among others, are primary reinforcers.']
['What are some examples of primary reinforcers?', 'Pleasure is also a primary reinforcer.']
['What are primary reinforcers?', 'Organisms do not lose their drive for these things.']

['What would be a primary reinforcer for most people?', 'For most people, jumping in a cool lake on a very hot day would be reinforcing and the cool lake would be innately reinforcing—the water would cool the person off (a physical need), as well as provide pleasure.']
['What is the difference between primary and secondary reinforcers?', 'A secondary reinforcer has no inherent value and only has reinforcing qualities when linked with a primary reinforcer.']
['What is one example of a secondary reinforcer?', 'Praise, linked to affection, is one example of a secondary reinforcer, as when you called out “Great shot!” every time Sydney made a goal.']

['What are some examples of primary reinforcers?', 'Another example, money, is only worth something when you can use it to buy other things—either things that satisfy basic needs (food, water, shelter—all primary reinforcers) or other secondary reinforcers.']

['How would money affect your life if you could not spend it?', 'If you were on a remote island in the middle of the Pacific Ocean and you had stacks of money, the money would not be useful if you could not spend it.']
['What do you think of sodas?', 'They also are secondary reinforcers.']
['What are secondary reinforcers?', 'Sometimes, instead of stickers on a sticker chart, a token is used.']
['What is the token used for?', 'Tokens, which are also secondary reinforcers, can then be traded in for rewards and prizes.']
['What is another interesting fact about tokens?', 'Entire behavior management systems, known as token economies, are built around the use of these kinds of token reinforcers.']
['What do token economies do?', 'Token economies have been found to be very effective at modifying behavior in a variety of settings such as schools, prisons, and mental hospitals.']

['What is a recent study?', 'For example, a study by Adibsereshki and Abkenar (2014) found that use of a token economy increased appropriate social behaviors and reduced inappropriate behaviors in a group of eight grade students.']

['What other studies show demonstrable gains on behavior and academic achievement for groups ranging from first grade to high school, and representing a wide array of abilities and disabilities?', 'Similar studies show demonstrable gains on behavior and academic achievement for groups ranging from first grade to high school, and representing a wide array of abilities and disabilities.']

['What can you tell me about secondary reinforcers?', 'For example, during studies involving younger students, when children in the study exhibited appropriate behavior (not hitting or pinching), they received a “quiet hands” token.']
['What happened when they did the opposite?', 'When they hit or pinched, they lost a token.']
['What was the reward for the children?', 'The children could then exchange specified amounts of tokens for minutes of playtime.']
['What is the best way to teach a person or animal a behavior?', 'Remember, the best way to teach a person or animal a behavior is to use positive reinforcement.']
['What type of reinforcement did Skinner use to teach rats to press a lever in a Skinner box?', 'For example, Skinner used positive reinforcement to teach rats to press a lever in a Skinner box.']
['What was the lever used for?', 'At first, the rat might randomly hit the lever while exploring the box, and out would come a pellet of food.']
['What did the rat do after this?', 'It hit the lever again, and received another pellet of food.']
['What happens after the rat hits the lever?', 'Each time the rat hit the lever, a pellet of food came out.']

['When an organism receives a reinforcer each time it displays a behavior, what is it called?', 'When an organism receives a reinforcer each time it displays a behavior, it is called continuous reinforcement.']
['What is the quickest way to teach someone a behavior?', 'This reinforcement schedule is the quickest way to teach someone a behavior, and it is especially effective in training a new behavior.']
['How do you use this?', 'Let’s look back at the dog that was learning to sit earlier in the chapter.']
['What did you teach him?', 'Now, each time he sits, you give him a treat.']

['How does it work?', 'Timing is important here: you will be most successful if you present the reinforcer immediately after he sits, so that he can make an association between the target behavior (sitting) and the consequence (getting a treat).']
["What's a reinforcement schedule?", 'Once a behavior is trained, researchers and trainers often turn to another type of reinforcement schedule—partial reinforcement.']

['What is the type of partial reinforcement?', 'In partial reinforcement, also referred to as intermittent reinforcement, the person or animal does not get reinforced every time they perform the desired behavior.']
['What is the difference between regular training and partial reinforcement?', 'There are several different types of partial reinforcement schedules.']
['What other details can you provide about partial reinforcement?', 'These schedules are described as either fixed or variable, and as either interval or ratio.']
['How does fixed relate to training?', 'Fixed refers to the number of responses between reinforcements, or the amount of time between reinforcements, which is set and unchanging.']
['What is variable?', 'Variable refers to the number of responses or amount of time between reinforcements, which varies or changes.']
['What are interval and ratio?', 'Interval means the schedule is based on the time between reinforcements, and ratio means the schedule is based on the number of responses between reinforcements.']
["Let's begin by learning the four terms that will form our reinforcement schedule.", 'Now let’s combine these four terms.']
['What is the meaning of the term "fixed interval"?', 'A fixed interval reinforcement schedule is when behavior is rewarded after a set amount of time.']
['What type of event is this for?', 'For example, June undergoes major surgery in a hospital.']
['What is the goal of this?', 'During recovery, they are expected to experience pain and will require prescription medications for pain relief.']
['What is the method used to deliver these?', 'June is given an IV drip with a patient-controlled painkiller.']
['How many doses are needed per day?', 'Their doctor sets a limit: one dose per hour.']
['What is the treatment June receives when the pain becomes difficult?', 'June pushes a button when pain becomes difficult, and they receive a dose of medication.']
['How does this affect the behavior?', 'Since the reward (pain relief) only occurs on a fixed interval, there is no point in exhibiting the behavior when it will not be rewarded.']

['What does variable interval schedule mean?', 'With a variable interval reinforcement schedule, the person or animal gets the reinforcement based on varying amounts of time, which are unpredictable.']
["How did Manuel's behavior change?", 'Say that Manuel is the manager at a fast-food restaurant.']
['What did Manuel do at the restaurant?', 'Every once in a while someone from the quality control division comes to Manuel’s restaurant.']
["What is the result of the quality control person's visit?", 'If the restaurant is clean and the service is fast, everyone on that shift earns a $20 bonus.']

["How is Manuel's behavior changed by the variable interval schedule?", 'Manuel never knows when the quality control person will show up, so he always tries to keep the restaurant clean and ensures that his employees provide prompt and courteous service.']
['What did you find interesting about the boss?', 'His productivity regarding prompt service and keeping a clean restaurant are steady because he wants his crew to earn the bonus.']

['What is the difference between a fixed ratio reinforcement schedule and a variable ratio reinforcement schedule?', 'With a fixed ratio reinforcement schedule, there are a set number of responses that must occur before the behavior is rewarded.']
['What kind of rewards are used?', 'Carla sells glasses at an eyeglass store, and she earns a commission every time she sells a pair of glasses.']
['Why does she want to sell more pairs?', 'She always tries to sell people more pairs of glasses, including prescription sunglasses or a backup pair, so she can increase her commission.']
['Does Carla sell people what they need?', 'She does not care if the person really needs the prescription sunglasses, Carla just wants her bonus.']
['Why does Carla ignore quality?', 'The quality of what Carla sells does not matter because her commission is not based on quality; it’s only based on the number of pairs sold.']

['What distinction in the quality of performance can help determine which reinforcement method is most appropriate for a particular situation?', 'This distinction in the quality of performance can help determine which reinforcement method is most appropriate for a particular situation.']

['What is the difference between fixed ratios and fixed intervals?', 'Fixed ratios are better suited to optimize the quantity of output, whereas a fixed interval, in which the reward is not quantity based, can lead to a higher quality of output.']
['What is variable ratio reinforcement schedule?', 'In a variable ratio reinforcement schedule, the number of responses needed for a reward varies.']
['What kind of schedule does this help people with?', 'This is the most powerful partial reinforcement schedule.']
['What is one example of the variable ratio reinforcement schedule?', 'An example of the variable ratio reinforcement schedule is gambling.']
['What is the case study?', 'Imagine that Sarah—generally a smart, thrifty woman—visits Las Vegas for the first time.']
['What does she do during this time?', 'She is not a gambler, but out of curiosity she puts a quarter into the slot machine, and then another, and another.']
['How does she do with the quarters?', 'Nothing happens.']
['What does the girl do next?', 'Two dollars in quarters later, her curiosity is fading, and she is just about to quit.']
['What happened after the machine lights up?', 'But then, the machine lights up, bells go off, and Sarah gets 50 quarters back.']
['How did Sarah feel about this?', 'That’s more like it!']
['What does Sarah do next?', 'Sarah gets back to inserting quarters with renewed interest, and a few minutes later she has used up all her gains and is $10 in the hole.']
['What does the student think happens next?', 'Now might be a sensible time to quit.']
['What does the woman do?', 'And yet, she keeps putting money into the slot machine because she never knows when the next reinforcement is coming.']
['What does the girl do with the quarters?', 'She keeps thinking that with the next quarter she could win $50, or $100, or even more.']
['Why do people keep playing?', 'Because the reinforcement schedule in most types of gambling has a variable ratio schedule, people keep trying and hoping that the next time they will win big.']
['What is one of the reasons that gambling is so addictive—and so resistant to extinction?', 'This is one of the reasons that gambling is so addictive—and so resistant to extinction.']

['When does extinction come?', 'In operant conditioning, extinction of a reinforced behavior occurs at some point after reinforcement stops, and the speed at which this happens depends on the reinforcement schedule.']
['How does variable ratio schedule affect extinction?', 'In a variable ratio schedule, the point of extinction comes very slowly, as described above.']
['How does fixed interval schedule affect extinction?', 'But in the other reinforcement schedules, extinction may come quickly.']

['What are some examples of a person pressing the button for pain relief medication before the allotted time the doctor has approved?', 'For example, if June presses the button for the pain relief medication before the allotted time the doctor has approved, no medication is administered.']
['Why would it not be administered?', 'They are on a fixed interval reinforcement schedule (dosed hourly), so extinction occurs quickly when reinforcement doesn’t come at the expected time.']
['What is variable ratio?', 'Among the reinforcement schedules, variable ratio is the most productive and the most resistant to extinction.']
['What is the least productive and the easiest to extinguish?', 'Fixed interval is the least productive and the easiest to extinguish.']

['What did strict behaviorists like Watson and Skinner focus exclusively on studying?', 'Strict behaviorists like Watson and Skinner focused exclusively on studying behavior rather than cognition (such as thoughts and expectations).']
["What was Skinner's view on cognition?", "In fact, Skinner was such a staunch believer that cognition didn't matter that his ideas were considered radical behaviorism."]
["What was Skinner's view of the brain?", 'Skinner considered the mind a "black box"—something completely unknowable—and, therefore, something not to be studied.']
['What was the opinion of Tolman?', 'However, another behaviorist, Edward C. Tolman, had a different opinion.']

['What did Tolman say?', 'Tolman’s experiments with rats demonstrated that organisms can learn even if they do not receive immediate reinforcement (Tolman & Honzik, 1930; Tolman, Ritchie, & Kalish, 1946).']

['What was the result of this finding?', 'This finding was in conflict with the prevailing idea at the time that reinforcement must be immediate in order for learning to occur, thus suggesting a cognitive aspect to learning.']
['What was the study about?', 'In the experiments, Tolman placed hungry rats in a maze with no reward for finding their way through it.']
['What else did he do in the study?', 'He also studied a comparison group that was rewarded with food at the end of the maze.']
['what happened to the rats?', 'As the unreinforced rats explored the maze, they developed a cognitive map: a mental picture of the layout of the maze.']
['what happened after that?', 'After 10 sessions in the maze without reinforcement, food was placed in a goal box at the end of the maze.']

['How did the rats react to the food?', 'As soon as the rats became aware of the food, they were able to find their way through the maze quickly, just as quickly as the comparison group, which had been rewarded with food all along.']
['What is latent learning?', 'This is known as latent learning: learning that occurs but is not observable in behavior until there is a reason to demonstrate it.']
['What is latent learning?', 'Latent learning also occurs in humans.']
['What does it mean for humans?', 'Children may learn by watching the actions of their parents but only demonstrate it at a later date, when the learned material is needed.']
['What does it mean for children?', 'For example, suppose that Ravi’s dad drives him to school every day.']

['What else happens in this example?', 'In this way, Ravi learns the route from his house to his school, but he’s never driven there himself, so he has not had a chance to demonstrate that he’s learned the way.']
['What does Ravi’s dad do?', 'One morning Ravi’s dad has to leave early for a meeting, so he can’t drive Ravi to school.']
['What does Ravi do?', 'Instead, Ravi follows the same route on his bike that his dad would have taken in the car.']
['What does that mean?', 'This demonstrates latent learning.']
['What does Ravi need to do before this?', 'Ravi had learned the route to school, but had no need to demonstrate this knowledge earlier.']

['What are the topics that were covered in previous sections of this chapter?', 'Previous sections of this chapter focused on classical and operant conditioning, which are forms of associative learning.']
['What is observational learning?', 'In observational learning, we learn by watching others and then imitating, or modeling, what they do or say.']
['What are the individuals performing the imitated behavior called?', 'The individuals performing the imitated behavior are called models.']

['What else do we know about the observer and model?', 'Research suggests that this imitative learning involves a specific type of neuron, called a mirror neuron (Hickock, 2010; Rizzolatti, Fadiga, Fogassi, & Gallese, 2002; Rizzolatti, Fogassi, & Gallese, 2006).']
['What is the important information about observational learning?', 'Humans and other animals are capable of observational learning.']
['Why is that?', 'For example, in a study of social learning in chimpanzees, researchers gave juice boxes with straws to two groups of captive chimpanzees.']
['What did the first group do?', 'The first group dipped the straw into the juice box, and then sucked on the small amount of juice at the end of the straw.']
['Did the other group do that?', 'The second group sucked through the straw directly, getting much more juice.']
['What did the first group do?', 'All of the “dippers” in the first group switched to sucking through the straws directly.']
['Why did they do that?', 'By simply observing the other chimps and modeling their behavior, they learned that this was a more efficient method of getting juice (Yamamoto, Humle, and Tanaka, 2013).']
['What can you tell me about imitation?', 'Imitation is sometimes called the highest form of flattery.']
['Why do you think that is?', 'But consider Claire’s experience with observational learning.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Claire’s nine-year-old son, Jay, was getting into trouble at school and was defiant at home.']
["Did Claire do anything to try to change Jay's behavior?", 'Claire feared that Jay would end up like her brothers, two of whom were in prison.']
['How did she get him to behave?', 'One day, after yet another bad day at school and another negative note from the teacher, Claire, at her wit’s end, beat her son with a belt to get him to behave.']
['What did her daughter do after she beat him?', 'Later that night, as she put her children to bed, Claire witnessed her four-year-old daughter, Anna, take a belt to her teddy bear and whip it.']
['How did Claire feel about her daughter?', 'Claire was horrified, realizing that Anna was imitating her mother.']
['What did she do to change the way she disciplined her children?', 'It was then that Claire knew she wanted to discipline her children in a different manner.']

['What is the first topic of the passage?', 'Like Tolman, whose experiments with rats suggested a cognitive component to learning, psychologist Albert Bandura’s ideas about learning were different from those of strict behaviorists.']
["What was Bandura's theory about?", 'Bandura and other researchers proposed a brand of behaviorism called social learning theory, which took cognitive processes into account.']
['What was the problem with pure behaviorism?', 'According to Bandura, pure behaviorism could not explain why learning can take place in the absence of external reinforcement.']
['What did Bandura say about internal mental states?', 'He felt that internal mental states must also have a role in learning and that observational learning involves much more than imitation.']
['What happens in imitation?', 'In imitation, a person simply copies what the model does.']
['What happens in observational learning?', 'Observational learning is much more complex.']
['What happens when observational learning happens?', 'According to Lefrançois (2012) there are several ways that observational learning can occur:']
['What do you need to know about the document?', 'You learn a new response.']
['What is this response?', 'After watching your coworker get chewed out by your boss for coming in late, you start leaving home 10 minutes earlier so that you won’t be late.']
['What do you need to know about the model?', 'You choose whether or not to imitate the model depending on what you saw happen to the model.']
['What is another interesting aspect about the document?', 'When learning to surf, Julian might watch how his father pops up successfully on his surfboard and then attempt to do the same thing.']
['What might Julian try to do?', 'On the other hand, Julian might learn not to touch a hot stove after watching his father get burned on a stove.']
['What do you learn when you read a passage?', 'You learn a general rule that you can apply to other situations.']
['What are the three kinds of models Bandura identified?', 'Bandura identified three kinds of models: live, verbal, and symbolic.']
['What is a live model?', 'A live model demonstrates a behavior in person, as when Ben stood up on his surfboard so that Julian could see how he did it.']

['What is a verbal model?', 'A verbal instructional model does not perform the behavior, but instead explains or describes the behavior, as when a soccer coach tells his young players to kick the ball with the side of the foot, not with the toe.']
['What can be a symbolic model?', 'A symbolic model can be fictional characters or real people who demonstrate behaviors in books, movies, television shows, video games, or Internet sources.']
['What was the modeling process?', 'Of course, we don’t learn a behavior simply by observing a model.']

['What is the process of modeling?', 'Bandura described specific steps in the process of modeling that must be followed if learning is to be successful: attention, retention, reproduction, and motivation.']
['What are the steps to follow when you are a model?', 'First, you must be focused on what the model is doing—you have to pay attention.']
['You must pay attention to what?', 'Next, you must be able to retain, or remember, what you observed; this is retention.']
['What must you remember?', 'Then, you must be able to perform the behavior that you observed and committed to memory; this is reproduction.']
['How do you perform the behavior?', 'Finally, you must have motivation.']
['What does motivation mean?', 'You need to want to copy the behavior, and whether or not you are motivated depends on what happened to the model.']
['What would happen if you saw that the model was reinforced for their behavior?', 'If you saw that the model was reinforced for their behavior, you will be more motivated to copy them.']
['What is the term for the feeling of being able to see someone else succeed?', 'This is known as vicarious reinforcement.']
['What else did you learn?', 'On the other hand, if you observed the model being punished, you would be less motivated to copy them.']
["What is the term for the feeling of being punished for someone else's actions?", 'This is called vicarious punishment.']

['what was the most important part of this article?', 'For example, imagine that four-year-old Allison watched her older sister Kaitlyn playing in their mother’s makeup, and then saw Kaitlyn get a time out when their mother came in.']
['What did Allison do after their mother left the room?', 'After their mother left the room, Allison was tempted to play in the make-up, but she did not want to get a time-out from her mother.']
['What is the result of this experience?', 'Once you actually demonstrate the new behavior, the reinforcement you receive plays a part in whether or not you will repeat the behavior.']

['What is the first step in the modeling process?', 'Bandura researched modeling behavior, particularly children’s modeling of adults’ aggressive and violent behaviors (Bandura, Ross, & Ross, 1961).']
['What did Bandura do in his research?', 'He conducted an experiment with a five-foot inflatable doll that he called a Bobo doll.']
['What did he find in his research?', 'In the experiment, children’s aggressive behavior was influenced by whether the teacher was punished for her behavior.']
['What was the most important thing about the research?', 'In one scenario, a teacher acted aggressively with the doll, hitting, throwing, and even punching the doll, while a child watched.']
['What did the child do as a result of watching the teacher?', 'There were two types of responses by the children to the teacher’s behavior.']
['Did the teacher ever get punished for her bad behavior?', 'When the teacher was punished for her bad behavior, the children decreased their tendency to act as she had.']
['What was the most important thing the study found?', 'When the teacher was praised or ignored (and not punished for her behavior), the children imitated what she did, and even what she said.']
['What did the children do to the doll?', 'They punched, kicked, and yelled at the doll.']
['What conclusion did Bandura draw from his research?', 'Bandura concluded that we watch and learn, and that this learning can have both prosocial and antisocial effects.']
['What can be used to encourage socially acceptable behavior?', 'Prosocial (positive) models can be used to encourage socially acceptable behavior.']
['What is the third step in the process?', 'Parents in particular should take note of this finding.']
['What is the fourth step in teaching children to read?', 'If you want your children to read, then read to them.']
['What can you do to help your children to learn to read?', 'Let them see you reading.']
['What can you do to help yourself learn?', 'Keep books in your home.']
['What can you do to help me remember this?', 'Talk about your favorite books.']

['What other steps do you take to help your children be healthy?', 'If you want your children to be healthy, then let them see you eat right and exercise, and spend time engaging in physical fitness activities together.']
['What other steps do you take to be a good person?', 'The same holds true for qualities like kindness, courtesy, and honesty.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'The main idea is that children observe and learn from their parents, even their parents’ morals, so be consistent and toss out the old adage “Do as I say, not as I do,” because children tend to copy what you do instead of what you say.']

['Who can be prosocial models?', 'Besides parents, many public figures, such as Martin Luther King, Jr. and Mahatma Gandhi, are viewed as prosocial models who are able to inspire global social change.']
['What are the antisocial effects of observational learning?', 'The antisocial effects of observational learning are also worth mentioning.']
['How does this play a role in bullying behavior?', 'As you saw from the example of Claire at the beginning of this section, her daughter viewed Claire’s aggressive behavior and copied it.']
['What is a factor in abuse?', 'Research suggests that this may help to explain why victims of abuse often grow up to be abusers themselves (Murrell, Christoff, & Henning, 2007).']
['What happens to people who abuse?', 'In fact, about 30% of child abuse victims become abusive parents (U.S. Department of Health & Human Services, 2013).']
['Why do we do what we do?', 'We tend to do what we know.']

['how can aggressive acts lead to abuse?', 'Children who grow up witnessing their parents deal with anger and frustration through violent and aggressive acts often learn to behave in that manner themselves.']

['What is the main idea of the study?', 'Some studies suggest that violent television shows, movies, and video games may also have antisocial effects although further research needs to be done to understand the correlational and causational aspects of media violence and behavior.']

['Did this study have any other implications?', 'Some studies have found a link between viewing violence and aggression seen in children (Anderson & Gentile, 2008; Kirsch, 2010; Miller, Grabell, Thomas, Bermann, & Graham-Bermann, 2012).']
