['What were the findings?', 'These findings may not be surprising, given that a child graduating from high school has been exposed to around 200,000 violent acts including murder, robbery, torture, bombings, beatings, and rape through various forms of media (Huston et al., 1992).']

['What else can you tell me about the study?', 'Not only might viewing media violence affect aggressive behavior by teaching people to act that way in real life situations, but it has also been suggested that repeated exposure to violent acts also desensitizes people to it.']
['What is the rest of the article about?', 'Psychologists are working to understand this dynamic.']
['What are the key ideas presented here?', 'Imagine all of your thoughts as if they were physical entities, swirling rapidly inside your mind.']
['What is the brain constantly doing?', 'The brain is endlessly perceiving, processing, planning, organizing, and remembering—it is always active.']
['What does the brain always do?', 'Yet, you don’t notice most of your brain’s activity as you move throughout your daily routine.']
['What is consciousness?', 'This is only one facet of the complex processes involved in cognition.']
['What is cognition?', 'Simply put, cognition is thinking, and it encompasses the processes associated with perception, knowledge, problem solving, judgment, language, and memory.']

['What else can you tell me about this content?', 'Scientists who study cognition are searching for ways to understand how we integrate, organize, and utilize our conscious cognitive experiences without being aware of all of the unconscious work that our brains are doing (for example, Kahneman, 2011).']
['What is one example of Cognition?', 'Upon waking each morning, you begin thinking—contemplating the tasks that you must complete that day.']
['Are these thoughts thought as cognition?', 'These thoughts are one example of cognition at work.']
['Are there other examples of cognition?', 'Exceptionally complex, cognition is an essential feature of human consciousness, yet not all aspects of cognition are consciously experienced.']
['What is the field of psychology dedicated to examining how people think?', 'Cognitive psychology is the field of psychology dedicated to examining how people think.']

['What does it attempt to explain?', 'It attempts to explain how and why we think the way we do by studying the interactions among human thinking, emotion, creativity, language, and problem solving, in addition to other cognitive processes.']

['What else does cognitive psychology study?', 'Cognitive psychologists strive to determine and measure different types of intelligence, why some people are better at problem solving than others, and how emotional intelligence affects success in the workplace, among countless other topics.']

['What else is it studying?', 'They also sometimes focus on how we organize thoughts and information gathered from our environments into meaningful categories of thought, which will be discussed later.']
['What is the most important information regarding your study material?', 'The human nervous system is capable of handling endless streams of information.']

['How do the senses work together?', 'The senses serve as the interface between the mind and the external environment, receiving stimuli and translating it into nervous impulses that are transmitted to the brain.']

['What can be learned about the brain from the article?', 'The brain then processes this information and uses the relevant pieces to create thoughts, which can then be expressed through language or stored in memory for future use.']
['What can be learned about the brain?', 'To make this process more complex, the brain does not gather information from external environments only.']
['How does the mind gather information from other sources?', 'When thoughts are formed, the mind synthesizes information from emotions and memories.']
['What can you learn from the article?', 'Emotion and memory are powerful influences on both our thoughts and behaviors.']
['What is the first concept we will study?', 'In order to organize this staggering amount of information, the mind has developed a "file cabinet" of sorts in the mind.']
['What are the different files stored in the file cabinet called?', 'The different files stored in the file cabinet are called concepts.']

['What are the categories or groupings of linguistic information, images, ideas, or memories, such as life experiences?', 'Concepts are categories or groupings of linguistic information, images, ideas, or memories, such as life experiences.']

['What are some examples of how we use concepts?', 'Concepts are, in many ways, big ideas that are generated by observing details, and categorizing and combining these details into cognitive structures.']

['What can you tell me about how we use concepts?', 'You use concepts to see the relationships among the different elements of your experiences and to keep the information in your mind organized and accessible.']

['What is the content of this chapter about?', 'Concepts are informed by our semantic memory (you will learn more about semantic memory in a later chapter) and are present in every aspect of our lives; however, one of the easiest places to notice concepts is inside a classroom, where they are discussed explicitly.']

['What do you learn about individual events when you study United States history?', 'When you study United States history, for example, you learn about more than just individual events that have happened in America’s past.']

['How do you absorb a large quantity of information?', 'You absorb a large quantity of information by listening to and participating in discussions, examining maps, and reading first-hand accounts of people’s lives.']
['What does your brain do when you read?', 'Your brain analyzes these details and develops an overall understanding of American history.']
['What does this lead to?', 'In the process, your brain gathers details that inform and refine your understanding of related concepts like democracy, power, and freedom.']
['What are some examples of concepts?', 'Concepts can be complex and abstract, like justice, or more concrete, like types of birds.']
['What are examples of abstract concepts?', 'In psychology, for example, Piaget’s stages of development are abstract concepts.']
['Do concepts have a certain number of uses?', 'Some concepts, like tolerance, are agreed upon by many people, because they have been used in various ways over many years.']

['Can you give me another example of a concept that is personal and individualized?', 'Other concepts, like the characteristics of your ideal friend or your family’s birthday traditions, are personal and individualized.']
['What are some of the most important concepts?', 'In this way, concepts touch every aspect of our lives, from our many daily routines to the guiding principles behind the way governments function.']
['What is another technique used?', 'Another technique used by your brain to organize information is the identification of prototypes for the concepts you have developed.']
['What is the best example or representation of a concept?', 'A prototype is the best example or representation of a concept.']
['What is the golden retriever?', 'Most likely your early experiences with dogs will shape what you imagine.']
['What are your good chances?', 'If your first pet was a Golden Retriever, there is a good chance that this would be your prototype for the category of dogs.']
['What are natural and artificial concepts?', 'In psychology, concepts can be divided into two categories, natural and artificial.']
['What are examples of natural concepts?', 'Natural concepts are created “naturally” through your experiences and can be developed from either direct or indirect experiences.']
['What is an example of indirect experience?', 'For example, if you live in Essex Junction, Vermont, you have probably had a lot of direct experience with snow.']

['What is an example of direct experience?', 'You’ve watched it fall from the sky, you’ve seen lightly falling snow that barely covers the windshield of your car, and you’ve shoveled out 18 inches of fluffy white snow as you’ve thought, “This is perfect for skiing.”']
['What is another example of a direct experience?', 'You’ve thrown snowballs at your best friend and gone sledding down the steepest hill in town.']
['What is the short version of snow?', 'In short, you know snow.']
['How do you know snow?', 'You know what it looks like, smells like, tastes like, and feels like.']

['What is another example of a natural concept?', 'If, however, you’ve lived your whole life on the island of Saint Vincent in the Caribbean, you may never have actually seen snow, much less tasted, smelled, or touched it.']
['How do you know snow without direct experience?', 'You know snow from the indirect experience of seeing pictures of falling snow—or from watching films that feature snow as part of the setting.']

['What is the ultimate result of snow?', 'Either way, snow is a natural concept because you can construct an understanding of it through direct observations, experiences with snow, or indirect knowledge (such as from films or books).']
['What is a concept that is defined by a specific set of characteristics?', 'An artificial concept, on the other hand, is a concept that is defined by a specific set of characteristics.']
['What kinds of things are examples of artificial concepts?', 'Various properties of geometric shapes, like squares and triangles, serve as useful examples of artificial concepts.']
['What are the properties of a triangle?', 'A triangle always has three angles and three sides.']
['What are the properties of a square?', 'A square always has four equal sides and four right angles.']

['What are some examples of artificial concepts?', 'Mathematical formulas, like the equation for area (length × width) are artificial concepts defined by specific sets of characteristics that are always the same.']
['What can artificial concepts do?', 'Artificial concepts can enhance the understanding of a topic by building on one another.']
['How do they build on one another?', 'For example, before learning the concept of “area of a square” (and the formula to find it), you must understand what a square is.']

['What other ways can artificial concepts build on one another?', 'Once the concept of “area of a square” is understood, an understanding of area for other geometric shapes can be built upon the original understanding of area.']
['What can you tell me about artificial concepts?', 'The use of artificial concepts to define an idea is crucial to communicating with others and engaging in complex thought.']
['What do artificial concepts do?', 'According to Goldstone and Kersten (2003), concepts act as building blocks and can be connected in countless combinations to create complex thoughts.']
['What is a mental construct consisting of a cluster or collection of related concepts?', 'A schema is a mental construct consisting of a cluster or collection of related concepts (Bartlett, 1932).']

['What are schemata used for?', 'There are many different types of schemata, and they all have one thing in common: schemata are a method of organizing information that allows the brain to work more efficiently.']
['What happens when a schema is activated?', 'When a schema is activated, the brain makes immediate assumptions about the person or object being observed.']
['What are the types of schemata?', 'There are several types of schemata.']
['What is a role schema?', 'A role schema makes assumptions about how individuals in certain roles will behave (Callero, 1994).']
['How do they activate?', 'For example, imagine you meet someone who introduces himself as a firefighter.']

['Does that make a difference to you?', 'When this happens, your brain automatically activates the “firefighter schema” and begins making assumptions that this person is brave, selfless, and community-oriented.']
['What does that mean?', 'Despite not knowing this person, already you have unknowingly made judgments about them.']
['Do they help you in anything?', 'Schemata also help you fill in gaps in the information you receive from the world around you.']

['Can schemata be harmful?', 'While schemata allow for more efficient information processing, there can be problems with schemata, regardless of whether they are accurate: Perhaps this particular firefighter is not brave, they just work as a firefighter to pay the bills while studying to become a children’s librarian.']
['What is a set of behaviors that can feel like a routine?', 'An event schema, also known as a cognitive script, is a set of behaviors that can feel like a routine.']
['How are schemas related to our daily lives?', 'Think about what you do when you walk into an elevator.']
['What does it tell you to do when you are in an elevator?', 'First, the doors open and you wait to let exiting passengers leave the elevator car.']
['How many passengers are there in the elevator?', 'Then, you step into the elevator and turn around to face the doors, looking for the correct button to push.']
['What do you think of the passage?', 'Interestingly, event schemata can vary widely among different cultures and countries.']

['What is the common greeting in the United States?', 'For example, while it is quite common for people to greet one another with a handshake in the United States, in Tibet, you greet someone by sticking your tongue out at them, and in Belize, you bump fists (Cairns Regional Council, n.d.)']
['What can be so challenging about changing an event schema?', 'Because event schemata are automatic, they can be difficult to change.']
['How would you apply it in real life?', 'Imagine that you are driving home from work or school.']
['What does the event schema look like?', 'This event schema involves getting in the car, shutting the door, and buckling your seatbelt before putting the key in the ignition.']
['How often do you perform this script?', 'You might perform this script two or three times each day.']
['What is unique about this event schema?', 'As you drive home, you hear your phone’s ring tone.']
['What does the tone signal?', 'Typically, the event schema that occurs when you hear your phone ringing involves locating the phone and answering it or responding to your latest text message.']
['What else does the event schema involve?', 'So without thinking, you reach for your phone, which could be in your pocket, in your bag, or on the passenger seat of the car.']

['What is important about this event schema?', 'This powerful event schema is informed by your pattern of behavior and the pleasurable stimulation that a phone call or text message gives your brain.']

['How can you change the behavior?', 'Because it is a schema, it is extremely challenging for us to stop reaching for the phone, even though we know that we endanger our own lives and the lives of others while we do it (Neyfakh, 2013).']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'It feels almost impossible to walk in and not face the door.']
['What do you think we need to know about this topic?', 'Our powerful event schema dictates our behavior in the elevator, and it is no different with our phones.']

['What is the habit of checking our phones in many different situations that makes refraining from checking them while driving especially difficult?', 'Current research suggests that it is the habit, or event schema, of checking our phones in many different situations that makes refraining from checking them while driving especially difficult (Bayer & Campbell, 2012).']

['What can we learn from the passage?', 'Because texting and driving has become a dangerous epidemic in recent years, psychologists are looking at ways to help people interrupt the “phone schema” while driving.']

['What are the reasons why many habits are difficult to break once they have been acquired?', 'Event schemata like these are the reason why many habits are difficult to break once they have been acquired.']
['What did you find interesting about the article?', 'As we continue to examine thinking, keep in mind how powerful the forces of concepts and schemata are to our understanding of the world.']
['What does language involve?', 'Language is a communication system that involves using words and systematic rules to organize those words to transmit information from one individual to another.']
['What is the difference between language and communication?', 'While language is a form of communication, not all communication is language.']
['What else does it involve?', 'Many species communicate with one another through their postures, movements, odors, or vocalizations.']
['What is the importance of this communication?', 'This communication is crucial for species that need to interact and develop social relationships with their conspecifics.']

['What is important about language?', 'However, many people have asserted that it is language that makes humans unique among all of the animal species (Corballis & Suddendorf, 2007; Tomasello & Rakoczy, 2003).']

['What is unique about language?', 'This section will focus on what distinguishes language as a special form of communication, how the use of language develops, and how language affects the way we think.']
['What other topics will you be studying?', 'Language, be it spoken, signed, or written, has specific components: a lexicon and grammar.']
['What is the lexicon?', 'Lexicon refers to the words of a given language.']
['What is the difference between lexicon and vocabulary?', 'Thus, lexicon is a language’s vocabulary.']
['What is grammar?', 'Grammar refers to the set of rules that are used to convey meaning through the use of the lexicon (Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']
['What are some examples of grammar?', 'For instance, English grammar dictates that most verbs receive an “-ed” at the end to indicate past tense.']
['How do words form?', 'Words are formed by combining the various phonemes that make up the language.']

['What is the most important thing to know about phonemes?', 'A phoneme (e.g., the sounds “ah” vs. “eh”) is a basic sound unit of a given language, and different languages have different sets of phonemes.']

['What are the smallest units of language that convey some type of meaning?', 'Phonemes are combined to form morphemes, which are the smallest units of language that convey some type of meaning (e.g., “I” is both a phoneme and a morpheme).']
['What are the parts of language?', 'We use semantics and syntax to construct language.']
['What is the difference between semantics and syntax?', 'Semantics and syntax are part of a language’s grammar.']
['What does semantics refer to?', 'Semantics refers to the process by which we derive meaning from morphemes and words.']
['What is syntax?', 'Syntax refers to the way words are organized into sentences (Chomsky, 1965; Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']

['What can we communicate with language?', 'We apply the rules of grammar to organize the lexicon in novel and creative ways, which allow us to communicate information about both concrete and abstract concepts.']
['What can we communicate with language?', 'We can talk about our immediate and observable surroundings as well as the surface of unseen planets.']
['What can we communicate with language?', 'We can share our innermost thoughts, our plans for the future, and debate the value of a college education.']
['What else can we communicate with language?', 'We can provide detailed instructions for cooking a meal, fixing a car, or building a fire.']
['What are some uses of language?', 'Through our use of words and language, we are able to form, organize, and express ideas, schema, and artificial concepts.']

['What do you find most interesting about the reading?', 'Given the remarkable complexity of a language, one might expect that mastering a language would be an especially arduous task; indeed, for those of us trying to learn a second language as adults, this might seem to be true.']
['What is the reverse of a child learning language?', 'However, young children master language very quickly with relative ease.']
['What is the name of the person who proposed that language is learned through reinforcement?', 'B. F. Skinner (1957) proposed that language is learned through reinforcement.']

['What did Noam Chomsky say about this behaviorist approach?', 'Noam Chomsky (1965) criticized this behaviorist approach, asserting instead that the mechanisms underlying language acquisition are biologically determined.']

['What did Chomsky say about language development?', 'The use of language develops in the absence of formal instruction and appears to follow a very similar pattern in children from vastly different cultures and backgrounds.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'It would seem, therefore, that we are born with a biological predisposition to acquire a language (Chomsky, 1965; Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']

['What else did he say?', 'Moreover, it appears that there is a critical period for language acquisition, such that this proficiency at acquiring language is maximal early in life; generally, as people age, the ease with which they acquire and master new languages diminishes (Johnson & Newport, 1989; Lenneberg, 1967; Singleton, 1995).']
['What happens in the early years?', 'Children begin to learn about language from a very early age.']
['What age is this?', 'In fact, it appears that this is occurring even before we are born.']
['What other interesting information?', 'Newborns show preference for their mother’s voice and appear to be able to discriminate between the language spoken by their mother and other languages.']

['What else?', 'Babies are also attuned to the languages being used around them and show preferences for videos of faces that are moving in synchrony with the audio of spoken language versus videos that do not synchronize with the audio (Blossom & Morgan, 2006; Pickens, 1994; Spelke & Cortelyou, 1981).']
['What is the process of language development?', 'You may recall that each language has its own set of phonemes that are used to generate morphemes, words, and so on.']

['What can children learn from hearing sounds?', 'Babies can discriminate among the sounds that make up a language (for example, they can tell the difference between the “s” in vision and the “ss” in fission); early on, they can differentiate between the sounds of all human languages, even those that do not occur in the languages that are used in their environments.']

['Can they discriminate those sounds later on?', 'However, by the time that they are about 1 year old, they can only discriminate among those phonemes that are used in the language or languages in their environments (Jensen, 2011; Werker & Lalonde, 1988; Werker & Tees, 1984).']

['What type of development is that?', 'After the first few months of life, babies enter what is known as the babbling stage, during which time they tend to produce single syllables that are repeated over and over.']
['What happens after that?', 'As time passes, more variations appear in the syllables that they produce.']

['Are they trying to communicate?', 'During this time, it is unlikely that the babies are trying to communicate; they are just as likely to babble when they are alone as when they are with their caregivers (Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']

['What can you tell me about babies who are raised in environments in which sign language is used?', 'Interestingly, babies who are raised in environments in which sign language is used will also begin to show babbling in the gestures of their hands during this stage (Petitto, Holowka, Sergio, Levy, & Ostry, 2004).']

['How many words does a child use before they start talking?', 'Generally, a child’s first word is uttered sometime between the ages of 1 year to 18 months, and for the next few months, the child will remain in the “one word” stage of language development.']
['What else does the one word stage refer to?', 'During this time, children know a number of words, but they only produce one-word utterances.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'The child’s early vocabulary is limited to familiar objects or events, often nouns.']
['Are there any other interesting parts of this article?', 'Although children in this stage only make one-word utterances, these words often carry larger meaning (Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']
['What does this mean?', 'So, for example, a child saying “cookie” could be identifying a cookie or asking for a cookie.']
['What is Language Development?', 'As a child’s lexicon grows, they begin to utter simple sentences and to acquire new vocabulary at a very rapid pace.']
['What happens when children learn to read?', 'In addition, children begin to demonstrate a clear understanding of the specific rules that apply to their language(s).']
['What is the best way to teach children about the rules?', 'Even the mistakes that children sometimes make provide evidence of just how much they understand about those rules.']
['What is another way this is seen?', 'This is sometimes seen in the form of overgeneralization.']
['What is overgeneralization?', 'In this context, overgeneralization refers to an extension of a language rule to an exception to the rule.']
['How can you explain this?', 'For example, in English, it is usually the case that an “s” is added to the end of a word to indicate plurality.']
['What can you tell me about the difference between one dog and two dogs?', 'For example, we speak of one dog versus two dogs.']

['What happens when young children overgeneralize this rule to cases that are exceptions to the “add an s to the end of the word” rule?', 'Young children will overgeneralize this rule to cases that are exceptions to the “add an s to the end of the word” rule and say things like “those two gooses” or “three mouses.”']
['What are some of the things we learned?', 'Clearly, the rules of the language are understood, even if the exceptions to the rules are still being learned (Moskowitz, 1978).']
['What is significant about language that we will be studying?', 'When we speak one language, we agree that words are representations of ideas, people, places, and events.']
['What is important about language?', 'The given language that children learn is connected to their culture and surroundings.']

['What is the question psychologists have long investigated?', 'Psychologists have long investigated the question of whether language shapes thoughts and actions, or whether our thoughts and beliefs shape our language.']
['Who investigated this question?', 'Two researchers, Edward Sapir and Benjamin Lee Whorf, began this investigation in the 1940s.']

['What did Edward and Whorf study?', 'They wanted to understand how the language habits of a community encourage members of that community to interpret language in a particular manner (Sapir, 1941/1964).']
['What other research was done on language?', 'Sapir and Whorf proposed that language determines thought.']
['What is the difference between the word "love" and "love" in different languages?', 'For example, in some languages there are many different words for love.']
['What is the difference between the word love and the word love in English?', 'However, in English we use the word love for all types of love.']

['What was wrong with the conclusion of the teacher?', 'Researchers have since identified this view as too absolute, pointing out a lack of empiricism behind what Sapir and Whorf proposed (Abler, 2013; Boroditsky, 2011; van Troyer, 1994).']
['What is the relationship between language and thought?', 'Today, psychologists continue to study and debate the relationship between language and thought.']
['What is the main idea of Language and Thought?', 'Language may indeed influence the way that we think, an idea known as linguistic determinism.']

['What were some of the examples of this phenomenon?', 'One recent demonstration of this phenomenon involved differences in the way that English and Mandarin Chinese speakers talk and think about time.']

['What is one example of how English speakers talk about time?', 'English speakers tend to talk about time using terms that describe changes along a horizontal dimension, for example, saying something like “I’m running behind schedule” or “Don’t get ahead of yourself.”']

['Are there any other examples of time in Mandarin Chinese?', 'While Mandarin Chinese speakers also describe time in horizontal terms, it is not uncommon to also use terms associated with a vertical arrangement.']
['What does that look like?', 'For example, the past might be described as being “up” and the future as being “down.”']

['What does this tell us about the mind?', 'It turns out that these differences in language translate into differences in performance on cognitive tests designed to measure how quickly an individual can recognize temporal relationships.']
['What did they say?', 'Specifically, when given a series of tasks with vertical priming, Mandarin Chinese speakers were faster at recognizing temporal relationships between months.']
['What can we learn from this study?', 'Indeed, Boroditsky (2001) sees these results as suggesting that “habits in language encourage habits in thought” (p. 12).']

['Who conducted the study?', 'One group of researchers who wanted to investigate how language influences thought compared how English speakers and the Dani people of Papua New Guinea think and speak about color.']
['How many words did the Dani use for color?', 'The Dani have two words for color: one word for light and one word for dark.']
['How many words are used in the English language?', 'In contrast, the English language has 11 color words.']
['What did researchers hypothesize about the number of color terms?', 'Researchers hypothesized that the number of color terms could limit the ways that the Dani people conceptualized color.']
['What was their finding?', 'However, the Dani were able to distinguish colors with the same ability as English speakers, despite having fewer words at their disposal (Berlin & Kay, 1969).']

['What did they conclude about the study?', 'A recent review of research aimed at determining how language might affect something like color perception suggests that language can influence perceptual phenomena, especially in the left hemisphere of the brain.']
['What does the left hemisphere have to do with language?', 'You may recall from earlier chapters that the left hemisphere is associated with language for most people.']
['Who found this?', 'However, the right (less linguistic hemisphere) of the brain is less affected by linguistic influences on perception (Regier & Kay, 2009)']
['What are the problems people face?', 'People face problems every day—usually, multiple problems throughout the day.']
['What do these problems involve?', 'Sometimes these problems are straightforward:']
['Are there any other examples of doubling a recipe?', 'To double a recipe for pizza dough, for example, all that is required is that each ingredient in the recipe be doubled.']
['What about the complex problems?', 'Sometimes, however, the problems we encounter are more complex.']
['What is a more complicated problem?', 'For example, say you have a work deadline, and you must mail a printed copy of a report to your supervisor by the end of the business day.']
['What else are they required to do?', 'The report is time-sensitive and must be sent overnight.']
['What happened to you?', 'You finished the report last night, but your printer will not work today.']
['What do you do when you have this problem?', 'First, you need to identify the problem and then apply a strategy for solving the problem.']
['What should be your next question?', 'Before finding a solution to the problem, the problem must first be clearly identified.']
['How do you identify the problem?', 'After that, one of many problem solving strategies can be applied, hopefully resulting in a solution.']
['What is a problem-solving strategy?', 'A problem-solving strategy is a plan of action used to find a solution.']
['What is an action plan?', 'Different strategies have different action plans associated with them.']
['What is a well-known strategy?', 'For example, a well-known strategy is trial and error.']
['What is the old adage?', 'The old adage, “If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again” describes trial and error.']

['What did you do in terms of your broken printer?', 'In terms of your broken printer, you could try checking the ink levels, and if that doesn’t work, you could check to make sure the paper tray isn’t jammed.']
["What might I check if I can't print from my laptop?", 'Or maybe the printer isn’t actually connected to your laptop.']
['What would you do when using trial and error?', 'When using trial and error, you would continue to try different solutions until you solved your problem.']
['Was trial and error good or bad?', 'Although trial and error is not typically one of the most time-efficient strategies, it is a commonly used one.']
['What is another type of strategy?', 'Another type of strategy is an algorithm.']
['What is an algorithm?', 'An algorithm is a problem-solving formula that provides you with step-by-step instructions used to achieve a desired outcome (Kahneman, 2011).']
['What are some characteristics about an algorithm?', 'You can think of an algorithm as a recipe with highly detailed instructions that produce the same result every time they are performed.']
['What are some ways algorithms are used?', 'Algorithms are used frequently in our everyday lives, especially in computer science.']

['What happens if you run a search on the Internet?', 'When you run a search on the Internet, search engines like Google use algorithms to decide which entries will appear first in your list of results.']
['What other uses do algorithms have?', 'Facebook also uses algorithms to decide which posts to display on your newsfeed.']
['What is another type of problem solving strategy?', 'A heuristic is another type of problem solving strategy.']

['What is the difference between an algorithm and a heuristic?', 'While an algorithm must be followed exactly to produce a correct result, a heuristic is a general problem-solving framework (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974).']
['What are mental shortcuts?', 'You can think of these as mental shortcuts that are used to solve problems.']
['What are some examples of mental shortcuts?', 'A “rule of thumb” is an example of a heuristic.']

['What is a rule of thumb?', 'Such a rule saves the person time and energy when making a decision, but despite its time-saving characteristics, it is not always the best method for making a rational decision.']

['What are the five conditions that heuristics must meet to work?', 'Different types of heuristics are used in different types of situations, but the impulse to use a heuristic occurs when one of five conditions is met (Pratkanis, 1989):']
["What's one of the conditions in which you should apply heuristics?", 'When the time to make a decision is limited']
['When should you use heuristics?', 'When there is access to very little information to use in making the decision']
['When should you apply heuristics?', 'When an appropriate heuristic happens to come to mind in the same moment']
['What is the definition of working backwards?', 'Working backwards is a useful heuristic in which you begin solving the problem by focusing on the end result.']
['What is an example of a symbiotic relationship?', 'Consider this example:']
['What is the problem with the passage?', 'You live in Washington, D.C. and have been invited to a wedding at 4 PM on Saturday in Philadelphia.']
['How would you get there?', 'Knowing that Interstate 95 tends to back up any day of the week, you need to plan your route and time your departure accordingly.']
['What is the outcome of this example?', 'You use the working backwards heuristic to plan the events of your day on a regular basis, probably without even thinking about it.']
['what is another useful heuristic?', 'Another useful heuristic is the practice of accomplishing a large goal or task by breaking it into a series of smaller steps.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'Students often use this common method to complete a large research project or long essay for school.']

['What are some steps to take for this?', 'For example, students typically brainstorm, develop a thesis or main topic, research the chosen topic, organize their information into an outline, write a rough draft, revise and edit the rough draft, develop a final draft, organize the references list, and proofread their work before turning in the project.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'The large task becomes less overwhelming when it is broken down into a series of small steps.']
['What can you tell me about successfully solved problems?', 'Not all problems are successfully solved, however.']
["What is the first question you'll ask?", 'Imagine a person in a room that has four doorways.']
['What is the reason this person cannot get in?', 'One doorway that has always been open in the past is now locked.']
['What does this person do?', 'The person, accustomed to exiting the room by that particular doorway, keeps trying to get out through the same doorway even though the other three doorways are open.']
['What happens when a person is stuck in a doorway?', 'The person is stuck—but they just need to go to another doorway, instead of trying to get out through the locked doorway.']
['What is the mental set?', 'A mental set is where you persist in approaching a problem in a way that has worked in the past but is clearly not working now.']

['What is the type of mental set where you cannot perceive an object being used for something other than what it was designed for?', 'Functional fixedness is a type of mental set where you cannot perceive an object being used for something other than what it was designed for.']
['Who conducted the research on functional fixness?', 'Duncker (1945) conducted foundational research on functional fixedness.']
['What did he do?', 'He created an experiment in which participants were given a candle, a book of matches, and a box of thumbtacks.']
['What did they do with the candle?', 'They were instructed to use those items to attach the candle to the wall so that it did not drip wax onto the table below.']
['What did they find out?', 'Participants had to use functional fixedness to overcome the problem.']

['How did this affect the nasa engineers?', 'During the Apollo 13 mission to the moon, NASA engineers at Mission Control had to overcome functional fixedness to save the lives of the astronauts aboard the spacecraft.']
['What else did they have to overcome?', 'An explosion in a module of the spacecraft damaged multiple systems.']
['What did the astronauts need to overcome?', 'The astronauts were in danger of being poisoned by rising levels of carbon dioxide because of problems with the carbon dioxide filters.']

['How did the engineers find a way for the astronauts to use spare plastic bags, tape, and air hoses to create a makeshift air filter?', 'The engineers found a way for the astronauts to use spare plastic bags, tape, and air hoses to create a makeshift air filter, which saved the lives of the astronauts.']
['What has the research been about?', 'Researchers have investigated whether functional fixedness is affected by culture.']

['What was the result of the experiment?', 'In one experiment, individuals from the Shuar group in Ecuador were asked to use an object for a purpose other than that for which the object was originally intended.']

['What was the test about?', 'For example, the participants were told a story about a bear and a rabbit that were separated by a river and asked to select among various objects, including a spoon, a cup, erasers, and so on, to help the animals.']

['Why did they use the spoon?', 'The spoon was the only object long enough to span the imaginary river, but if the spoon was presented in a way that reflected its normal usage, it took participants longer to choose the spoon to solve the problem.']
['What was the name of the study that was done?', '(German & Barrett, 2005).']

['What else is there to know about the researchers?', 'The researchers wanted to know if exposure to highly specialized tools, as occurs with individuals in industrialized nations, affects their ability to transcend functional fixedness.']
['What did they find?', 'It was determined that functional fixedness is experienced in both industrialized and nonindustrialized cultures (German & Barrett, 2005).']
['How can you make good decisions?', 'In order to make good decisions, we use our knowledge and our reasoning.']
['What is knowledge and reasoning?', 'Often, this knowledge and reasoning is sound and solid.']
['What is important about sound and solid knowledge?', 'Sometimes, however, we are swayed by biases or by others manipulating a situation.']
['What would be an example of anchoring bias?', 'For example, let’s say you and three friends wanted to rent a house and had a combined target budget of $1,600.']
['What would the realtor do?', 'The realtor shows you only very run-down houses for $1,600 and then shows you a very nice house for $2,000.']
['What is the realtor trying to accomplish?', 'The realtor may be challenging your anchoring bias.']

['What happens when you focus on one piece of information when making a decision or solving a problem?', 'An anchoring bias occurs when you focus on one piece of information when making a decision or solving a problem.']
['What does this cause?', 'In this case, you’re so focused on the amount of money you are willing to spend that you may not recognize what kinds of houses are available at that price point.']
['What is confirmation bias?', 'The confirmation bias is the tendency to focus on information that confirms your existing beliefs.']

['What is an example of confirmation bias?', 'For example, if you think that your professor is not very nice, you notice all of the instances of rude behavior exhibited by the professor while ignoring the countless pleasant interactions he is involved in on a daily basis.']
['What does hindsight bias lead you to believe?', 'Hindsight bias leads you to believe that the event you just experienced was predictable, even though it really wasn’t.']
['What is a common misconception about hindsight bias?', 'In other words, you knew all along that things would turn out the way they did.']

['What is representative bias?', 'Representative bias describes a faulty way of thinking, in which you unintentionally stereotype someone or something; for example, you may assume that your professors spend their free time reading books and engaging in intellectual conversation, because the idea of them spending their time playing volleyball or visiting an amusement park does not fit in with your stereotypes of professors.']

['Which of the following heuristics is mentioned?', 'Finally, the availability heuristic is a heuristic in which you make a decision based on an example, information, or recent experience that is that readily available to you, even though it may not be the best example to inform your decision.']

['What are some of the biases?', 'Biases tend to “preserve that which is already established—to maintain our preexisting knowledge, beliefs, attitudes, and hypotheses” (Aronson, 1995; Kahneman, 2011).']
['What are the biases summarized in?', 'These biases are summarized in Table 7.3.']
['What are the answers to our questions?', 'You need nine.']
['What are the answers to the question?', 'Here are the answers.']
['What is the content of this passage?', 'A four-and-a-half-year-old boy sits at the kitchen table with his father, who is reading a new story aloud to him.']
['What is he reading aloud?', 'He turns the page to continue reading, but before he can begin, the boy says, “Wait, Daddy!”']
['Why does the boy ask him to wait?', 'He points to the words on the new page and reads aloud, “Go, Pig! Go!”']
['What does the boy do when he stops reading?', 'The father stops and looks at his son.']
['What does the father say to the boy?', '“Can you read that?” he asks.']
['Do you think the boy will agree to read?', '“Yes, Daddy!”']
['What does the boy do next?', 'And he points to the words and reads again, “Go, Pig! Go!”']

['What does this story represent?', 'This father was not actively teaching his son to read, even though the child constantly asked questions about letters, words, and symbols that they saw everywhere: in the car, in the store, on the television.']
["Why didn't the father want to teach the son?", 'The dad wondered about what else his son might understand and decided to try an experiment.']
['What did the experiment entail?', 'Grabbing a sheet of blank paper, he wrote several simple words in a list: mom, dad, dog, bird, bed, truck, car, tree.']
['What did the father do with the list?', 'He put the list down in front of the boy and asked him to read the words.']
['Did the boy follow through with the list?', '“Dad, dog, bird, bed, truck, car, tree,” he read, slowing down to carefully pronounce bird and truck.']
['What did the boy say to his father?', 'Then, “Did I do it, Daddy?” “You sure did!']
["What was the father's reaction to the news?", 'That is very good.”']

['What did the father do after reading the story?', 'The father gave his little boy a warm hug and continued reading the story about the pig, all the while wondering if his son’s abilities were an indication of exceptional intelligence or simply a normal pattern of linguistic development.']
['What are some of the other aspects of the article?', 'Like the father in this example, psychologists have wondered what constitutes intelligence and how it can be measured.']
['What can you tell me about the first part of the document?', 'The way that researchers have defined the concept of intelligence has been modified many times since the birth of psychology.']

['What can you tell me about Spearman?', 'British psychologist Charles Spearman believed intelligence consisted of one general factor, called g, which could be measured and compared among individuals.']
["What did Spearman's view differ from modern psychology?", 'Spearman focused on the commonalities among various intellectual abilities and de-emphasized what made each unique.']

['What ancient philosophers, such as Aristotle, held a similar view?', 'Long before modern psychology developed, however, ancient philosophers, such as Aristotle, held a similar view (Cianciolo & Sternberg, 2004).']

['What are some important things that you should know about Classifying Intelligence?', 'Others psychologists believe that instead of a single factor, intelligence is a collection of distinct abilities.']

['how was crystallized intelligence created?', 'In the 1940s, Raymond Cattell proposed a theory of intelligence that divided general intelligence into two components: crystallized intelligence and fluid intelligence (Cattell, 1963).']
['What is the characterization of crystallized intelligence?', 'Crystallized intelligence is characterized as acquired knowledge and the ability to retrieve it.']
['what is crystallized intelligence used for?', 'When you learn, remember, and recall information, you are using crystallized intelligence.']
['What is the most important thing about this?', 'You use crystallized intelligence all the time in your coursework by demonstrating that you have mastered the information covered in the course.']
['What does fluid intelligence encompass?', 'Fluid intelligence encompasses the ability to see complex relationships and solve problems.']
['Can you give me an example of fluid intelligence?', 'Navigating your way home after being detoured onto an unfamiliar route because of road construction would draw upon your fluid intelligence.']

['how is fluid intelligence different from crystallized intelligence?', 'Fluid intelligence helps you tackle complex, abstract challenges in your daily life, whereas crystallized intelligence helps you overcome concrete, straightforward problems (Cattell, 1963).']
['What do other theorists and psychologists believe that intelligence should be defined in?', 'Other theorists and psychologists believe that intelligence should be defined in more practical terms.']
['What are some of the practical terms?', 'Think about this for a moment.']
['What is the term for practical intelligence?', 'Practical intelligence, as proposed by Sternberg, is sometimes compared to “street smarts.”']
['What does being practical mean?', 'Being practical means you find solutions that work in your everyday life by applying knowledge based on your experiences.']

['Do people have IQ?', 'This type of intelligence appears to be separate from traditional understanding of IQ; individuals who score high in practical intelligence may or may not have comparable scores in creative and analytical intelligence (Sternberg, 1988).']
['What did Sternberg say about analytical intelligence?', 'Analytical intelligence is closely aligned with academic problem solving and computations.']
['What is a characteristic of analytical intelligence?', 'Sternberg says that analytical intelligence is demonstrated by an ability to analyze, evaluate, judge, compare, and contrast.']

['What is the main reason for this need to be done?', 'When reading a classic novel for literature class, for example, it is usually necessary to compare the motives of the main characters of the book or analyze the historical context of the story.']
['What are some examples of analytical intelligence?', 'In a science course such as anatomy, you must study the processes by which the body uses various minerals in different human systems.']
['What does this have to do with analytical intelligence?', 'In developing an understanding of this topic, you are using analytical intelligence.']

['Do any other examples relate to analytical intelligence?', 'When solving a challenging math problem, you would apply analytical intelligence to analyze different aspects of the problem and then solve it section by section.']
['What is creative intelligence?', 'Creative intelligence is marked by inventing or imagining a solution to a problem or situation.']
['What is creativity?', 'Creativity in this realm can include finding a novel solution to an unexpected problem or producing a beautiful work of art or a well-developed short story.']

['What is a solution to the problem of forgetting your camp coffee pot?', 'Imagine for a moment that you are camping in the woods with some friends and realize that you’ve forgotten your camp coffee pot.']
['What does that mean?', 'The person in your group who figures out a way to successfully brew coffee for everyone would be credited as having higher creative intelligence.']
['What is the difference between multiple intelligences and a single intelligence?', 'Multiple Intelligences']
['Who developed the theory?', 'Theory was developed by Howard Gardner, a Harvard psychologist and former student of Erik Erikson.']
['What is the theory of multiple intelligences?', 'In Gardner’s theory, each person possesses at least eight intelligences.']

['What are the eight intelligences?', 'The eight intelligences are linguistic intelligence, logical-mathematical intelligence, musical intelligence, bodily kinesthetic intelligence, spatial intelligence, interpersonal intelligence, intrapersonal intelligence, and naturalistic intelligence.']
['What is Gardner’s theory being supported by?', 'Among cognitive psychologists, Gardner’s theory has been heavily criticized for lacking empirical evidence.']

['What is the result of this criticism?', 'However, educators continue to study and use Gardner’s theory, with some colleges even discussing how they integrate Gardner’s theory into their classrooms.']

['What is one possible reason for the continued use of Gardner’s theory?', 'Gottfredson describes one possible reason for the continued use of Gardner’s theory: “ . . . that there are multiple independent intelligences, suggesting that everyone can be smart in some way.']
['What is the view of people?', 'This is, understandably, a very attractive idea in democratic societies” (2004).']

['What is the single type of intelligence that Gardner combined into a single type: emotional intelligence?', 'Gardner’s inter- and intrapersonal intelligences are often combined into a single type: emotional intelligence.']

['What does emotional intelligence consist of?', 'Emotional intelligence encompasses the ability to understand the emotions of yourself and others, show empathy, understand social relationships and cues, and regulate your own emotions and respond in culturally appropriate ways (Parker, Saklofske, & Stough, 2009).']
['What does this include?', 'People with high emotional intelligence typically have well-developed social skills.']

['What does this tell about how we perform?', 'Some researchers, including Daniel Goleman, the author of Emotional Intelligence: Why It Can Matter More than IQ, argue that emotional intelligence is a better predictor of success than traditional intelligence (Goleman, 1995).']

['What else is important about emotional intelligence?', 'However, emotional intelligence has been widely debated, with researchers pointing out inconsistencies in how it is defined and described, as well as questioning results of studies on a subject that is difficult to measure and study empirically (Locke, 2005; Mayer, Salovey, & Caruso, 2004)']

['What is the most comprehensive theory of intelligence?', 'The most comprehensive theory of intelligence to date is the Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) theory of cognitive abilities (Schneider & McGrew, 2018).']

['What are the general abilities at the top of the hierarchy?', 'In this theory, abilities are related and arranged in a hierarchy with general abilities at the top, broad abilities in the middle, and narrow (specific) abilities at the bottom.']
['What is the significance of those at the bottom?', 'The narrow abilities are the only ones that can be directly measured; however, they are integrated within the other abilities.']
['What is at the general level?', 'At the general level is general intelligence.']

['What is the broad level consists of general abilities such as fluid reasoning, short-term memory, and processing speed?', 'Next, the broad level consists of general abilities such as fluid reasoning, short-term memory, and processing speed.']
['What is the narrow level of the hierarchy?', 'Finally, as the hierarchy continues, the narrow level includes specific forms of cognitive abilities.']
['What is an example of a broad level?', 'For example, short-term memory would further break down into memory span and working memory capacity.']
['Are there any other theories of intelligence out there?', 'Intelligence can also have different meanings and values in different cultures.']

['How would it be useful to people if they lived on a small island?', 'If you live on a small island, where most people get their food by fishing from boats, it would be important to know how to fish and how to repair a boat.']
['What can you tell me about the example?', 'If you were an exceptional angler, your peers would probably consider you intelligent.']
['What is another example of intelligence?', 'If you were also skilled at repairing boats, your intelligence might be known across the whole island.']
['What is your next question?', 'Think about your own family’s culture.']
['What are some things Irish people like to do?', 'In Irish families, hospitality and telling an entertaining story are marks of the culture.']
['What does the storyteller do?', 'If you are a skilled storyteller, other members of Irish culture are likely to consider you intelligent.']
['What did Sternberg think about groups superseding individuals?', 'Some cultures place a high value on working together as a collective.']
['What happens to groups and individuals in these cultures?', 'In these cultures, the importance of the group supersedes the importance of individual achievement.']

['How can we adapt to this cultural norm?', 'When you visit such a culture, how well you relate to the values of that culture exemplifies your cultural intelligence, sometimes referred to as cultural competence.']
['What is creativity?', 'Creativity is the ability to generate, create, or discover new ideas, solutions, and possibilities.']

['What are some characteristics of creativity?', 'Very creative people often have intense knowledge about something, work on it for years, look at novel solutions, seek out the advice and help of other experts, and take risks.']
['What does creativity mean?', 'Although creativity is often associated with the arts, it is actually a vital form of intelligence that drives people in many disciplines to discover something new.']
['Where can we find creativity?', 'Creativity can be found in every area of life, from the way you decorate your residence to a new way of understanding how a cell works.']
['What is a trait of creativity?', 'Creativity is often connected to a person’s ability to engage in divergent thinking.']

['What is the definition of divergent thinking?', 'Divergent thinking can be described as thinking “outside the box;” it allows an individual to arrive at unique, multiple solutions to a given problem.']

['What can convergent thinking describe?', 'In contrast, convergent thinking describes the ability to provide a correct or well-established answer or solution to a problem (Cropley, 2006; Gilford, 1967)']
['What is the meaning of IQ?', 'IQ stands for intelligence quotient and describes a score earned on a test designed to measure intelligence.']
['What did you learn about intelligence?', 'You’ve already learned that there are many ways psychologists describe intelligence (or more aptly, intelligences).']
['What other information did you find?', 'Similarly, IQ tests—the tools designed to measure intelligence—have been the subject of debate throughout their development and use.']

['What are some of the other benefits to intelligence testing?', 'While there are certainly many benefits to intelligence testing, it is important to also note the limitations and controversies surrounding these tests.']
['What are some of the other limitations?', 'For example, IQ tests have sometimes been used as arguments in support of insidious purposes, such as the eugenics movement (Severson, 2011).']

['What was the result of the forced sterilization of people deemed “feeble-minded” through this type of testing?', 'The infamous Supreme Court Case, Buck v. Bell, legalized the forced sterilization of some people deemed “feeble-minded” through this type of testing, resulting in about 65,000 sterilizations (Buck v. Bell, 274 U.S. 200; Ko, 2016).']

['What other information did you find interesting?', 'Today, only professionals trained in psychology can administer IQ tests, and the purchase of most tests requires an advanced degree in psychology.']

['What other professionals in the field, such as social workers and psychiatrists, cannot administer IQ tests?', 'Other professionals in the field, such as social workers and psychiatrists, cannot administer IQ tests.']
['What is the next step in the study?', 'In this section, we will explore what intelligence tests measure, how they are scored, and how they were developed.']

['What is some of the relevant information that was discussed in our study material?', 'It seems that the human understanding of intelligence is somewhat limited when we focus on traditional or academic-type intelligence.']
['What is the main idea of the article?', 'In the following paragraphs, we will explore how intelligence tests were developed and the history of their use.']
['What is the IQ test?', 'The IQ test has been synonymous with intelligence for over a century.']
['Who developed the first broad test of intelligence?', 'In the late 1800s, Sir Francis Galton developed the first broad test of intelligence (Flanagan & Kaufman, 2004).']

['What was his contribution to the concepts of intelligence testing?', 'Although he was not a psychologist, his contributions to the concepts of intelligence testing are still felt today (Gordon, 1995).']

['what is reliable intelligence testing?', 'Reliable intelligence testing (you may recall from earlier chapters that reliability refers to a test’s ability to produce consistent results) began in earnest during the early 1900s with a researcher named Alfred Binet.']

['Who asked him to develop the test?', 'Binet was asked by the French government to develop an intelligence test to use on children to determine which ones might have difficulty in school; it included many verbally based tasks.']
['What did American researchers realize about the test?', 'American researchers soon realized the value of such testing.']

['Who modified Binet’s work?', 'Louis Terman, a Stanford professor, modified Binet’s work by standardizing the administration of the test and tested thousands of different-aged children to establish an average score for each age.']

['What was the result of the test?', 'As a result, the test was normed and standardized, which means that the test was administered consistently to a large enough representative sample of the population that the range of scores resulted in a bell curve (bell curves will be discussed later).']
['What does standardization mean?', 'Standardization means that the manner of administration, scoring, and interpretation of results is consistent.']

['What is the process of giving a test to a large population so data can be collected comparing groups, such as age groups?', 'Norming involves giving a test to a large population so data can be collected comparing groups, such as age groups.']
['What is a norm?', 'The resulting data provide norms, or referential scores, by which to interpret future scores.']
['What does a norm represent?', 'Norms are not expectations of what a given group should know but a demonstration of what that group does know.']
['What can the test help you do?', 'Norming and standardizing the test ensures that new scores are reliable.']
['What was the new version of the test called?', 'This new version of the test was called the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scale (Terman, 1916).']
['How was the test received?', 'Remarkably, an updated version of this test is still widely used today.']
['Who developed the new IQ test?', 'In 1939, David Wechsler, a psychologist who spent part of his career working with World War I veterans, developed a new IQ test in the United States.']
['What did Wechsler combine several subtests from?', 'Wechsler combined several subtests from other intelligence tests used between 1880 and World War I.']

['Why did he combine the subtests?', 'These subtests tapped into a variety of verbal and nonverbal skills, because Wechsler believed that intelligence encompassed “the global capacity of a person to act purposefully, to think rationally, and to deal effectively with his environment” (Wechsler, 1958, p. 7).']
['What was the name of the test that was created by Wechsler?', 'He named the test the Wechsler-Bellevue Intelligence Scale (Wechsler, 1981).']
['What did the test do?', 'This combination of subtests became one of the most extensively used intelligence tests in the history of psychology.']

['Did they ever make any changes to the test?', 'Although its name was later changed to the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS) and has been revised several times, the aims of the test remain virtually unchanged since its inception (Boake, 2002).']

['What else is important about this article?', 'Today, there are three intelligence tests credited to Wechsler, the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale-fourth edition (WAIS-IV), the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC-V), and the Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence—IV (WPPSI-IV) (Wechsler, 2012).']
['Are they still used?', 'These tests are used widely in schools and communities throughout the United States, and they are periodically normed and standardized as a means of recalibration.']

['Did they have to test children as well?', 'As a part of the recalibration process, the WISC-V was given to thousands of children across the country, and children taking the test today are compared with their same-age peers.']
['What is the WISC-V composed of?', 'The WISC-V is composed of 14 subtests, which comprise five indices, which then render an IQ score.']
['What are the five indices?', 'The five indices are Verbal Comprehension, Visual Spatial, Fluid Reasoning, Working Memory, and Processing Speed.']
['What score does one receive when the test is complete?', 'When the test is complete, individuals receive a score for each of the five indices and a Full Scale IQ score.']

['What is the method of scoring?', 'The method of scoring reflects the understanding that intelligence is comprised of multiple abilities in several cognitive realms and focuses on the mental processes that the child used to arrive at their answers to each test item.']
['What is the Flynn effect?', 'Interestingly, the periodic recalibrations have led to an interesting observation known as the Flynn effect.']

['What is the flynn effect?', 'Named after James Flynn, who was among the first to describe this trend, the Flynn effect refers to the observation that each generation has a significantly higher IQ than the last.']
['What does it mean?', 'Flynn himself argues, however, that increased IQ scores do not necessarily mean that younger generations are more intelligent per se (Flynn, Shaughnessy, & Fulgham, 2012).']
['What were you left with?', 'Ultimately, we are still left with the question of how valid intelligence tests are.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects of this material?', 'Certainly, the most modern versions of these tests tap into more than verbal competencies, yet the specific skills that should be assessed in IQ testing, the degree to which any test can truly measure an individual’s intelligence, and the use of the results of IQ tests are still issues of debate (Gresham & Witt, 1997; Flynn, Shaughnessy, & Fulgham, 2012; Richardson, 2002; Schlinger, 2003).']
['What is the general shape of the bell curve?', 'The results of intelligence tests follow the bell curve, a graph in the general shape of a bell.']
['What is it used for?', 'When the bell curve is used in psychological testing, the graph demonstrates a normal distribution of a trait, in this case, intelligence, in the human population.']
['Do all traits follow the bell curve?', 'Many human traits naturally follow the bell curve.']

['What else does this curve relate to?', 'For example, if you lined up all your female schoolmates according to height, it is likely that a large cluster of them would be the average height for an American woman: 5’4”–5’6”.']
['What would be the average height for American women?', 'This cluster would fall in the center of the bell curve, representing the average height for American women.']
['Are there any other examples?', 'There would be fewer women who stand closer to 4’11”.']
['What else can you tell me about this study?', 'The same would be true for women of above-average height: those who stand closer to 5’11”.']
['What is important to note about finding a bell curve in nature?', 'The trick to finding a bell curve in nature is to use a large sample size.']
['What is the advantage of a large sample size?', 'Without a large sample size, it is less likely that the bell curve will represent the wider population.']
['What is a subset of the population that accurately represents the general population?', 'A representative sample is a subset of the population that accurately represents the general population.']
['Why is this important?', 'If, for example, you measured the height of the women in your classroom only, you might not actually have a representative sample.']
['What happens if you only measure the tallest women?', 'Perhaps the women’s basketball team wanted to take this course together, and they are all in your class.']

['What happens to the rest of the women?', 'Because basketball players tend to be taller than average, the women in your class may not be a good representative sample of the population of American women.']
['What is the best solution to this problem?', 'But if your sample included all the women at your school, it is likely that their heights would form a natural bell curve.']
['Which of the following is true?', 'The same principles apply to intelligence tests scores.']
['What is the score called?', 'Individuals earn a score called an intelligence quotient (IQ).']
['What is the way scores are interpreted?', 'Over the years, different types of IQ tests have evolved, but the way scores are interpreted remains the same.']
['What is the average score for most IQ tests?', 'On most IQ tests, the average (or mean) IQ score is 100.']
['What do standard deviations describe?', 'Standard deviations describe how data are dispersed in a population and give context to large data sets.']

['What does the bell curve use to show how all scores are dispersed from the average score?', 'The bell curve uses the standard deviation to show how all scores are dispersed from the average score.']
['How many points is one standard deviation in IQ testing?', 'In modern IQ testing, one standard deviation is 15 points.']
['What would this tell you about the individual?', 'So a score of 85 would be described as “one standard deviation below the mean.”']

['Is this the average IQ score?', 'Any IQ score that falls within one standard deviation above and below the mean (between 85 and 115) is considered average, and 68% of the population has IQ scores in this range.']
['What is the IQ score of a superior person?', 'An IQ score of 130 or above is considered a superior level.']
['What is important to know about The Bell Curve?', 'Only 2.2% of the population has an IQ score below 70 (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2013).']

['What is the second part of the question?', 'If a person earns a score approximately two standard deviations below the mean on an intelligence test, (about 70 on a test with a mean of 100), has major deficits in adaptive functioning, and these cognitive and adaptive deficits were present before the age of 18, they could be diagnosed as having an intellectual disability (ID).']

['What kind of disabilities does ID include?', 'Formerly known as mental retardation, the accepted term now is intellectual disability, and it has four subtypes: mild, moderate, severe, and profound.']
['What is the criteria for each subtype?', 'The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Psychological Disorders lists criteria for each subgroup (APA, 2013).']
['What is the other end of the intelligence spectrum?', 'On the other end of the intelligence spectrum are those individuals whose IQs fall into the highest ranges.']
['How many people fall into this category?', 'Consistent with the bell curve, about 2% of the population falls into this category.']

['What is a good test for this?', 'People are considered to have a higher aptitude for learning (and may be classified as "gifted" within educational systems) if they have an IQ score of 130 or higher, or superior intelligence in a particular area.']
['What was popular belief about people of high intelligence?', 'Long ago, popular belief suggested that people of high intelligence were maladjusted.']
['What was the breakthrough study of these children?', 'This idea was disproven through a groundbreaking study of these children.']

['In what year did Lewis Terman begin a longitudinal study of over 1500 children with IQs over 135?', 'In 1921, Lewis Terman began a longitudinal study of over 1500 children with IQs over 135 (Terman, 1925).']
['Was his study conclusive?', 'His findings showed that these children became well-educated, successful adults who were, in fact, well-adjusted (Terman & Oden, 1947).']

['what else was discovered?', 'Additionally, Terman’s study showed that the subjects were above average in physical build and attractiveness, dispelling an earlier popular notion that highly intelligent people were “weaklings.”']

['What are some things to look out for when deciding if someone is smart?', 'Some people with very high IQs elect to join Mensa, an organization dedicated to identifying, researching, and fostering intelligence.']
['What criteria do they use to select members?', 'Members must have an IQ score in the top 2% of the population, and they may be required to pass other exams in their application to join the group.']
['What is the value of IQ testing?', 'The value of IQ testing is most evident in educational or clinical settings.']

['How can it be helpful?', 'Children who seem to be experiencing learning difficulties or severe behavioral problems can be tested to ascertain whether the child’s difficulties can be partly attributed to an IQ score that is significantly different from the mean for their age group.']
['What are some other uses of IQ testing?', 'Without IQ testing—or another measure of intelligence—children and adults needing extra support might not be identified effectively.']

['What else is there?', 'In addition, IQ testing is used in courts to determine whether a defendant has special or extenuating circumstances that preclude them from participating in some way in a trial.']
['What else can IQ testing results be used for?', 'People also use IQ testing results to seek disability benefits from the Social Security Administration.']
['What is it about?', 'The following case study demonstrates the usefulness and benefits of IQ testing.']
['What is the case study about?', 'Candace, a 14-year-old girl experiencing problems at school in Connecticut, was referred for a court-ordered psychological evaluation.']
['Why did she request that evaluation?', 'She was in regular education classes in ninth grade and was failing every subject.']
['Did she want a special education or disability based on this information?', 'Candace had never been a stellar student but had always been passed to the next grade.']
['What did she do in her classes?', 'Frequently, she would curse at any of her teachers who called on her in class.']
['What else did she do in her school days?', 'She also got into fights with other students and occasionally shoplifted.']

['What did Candace say when she arrived for the evaluation?', 'When she arrived for the evaluation, Candace immediately said that she hated everything about school, including the teachers, the rest of the staff, the building, and the homework.']

['What were her parents thoughts about her?', 'Her parents stated that they felt their daughter was picked on, because she was of a different ethnicity than the teachers and most of the other students.']
['What did her teachers think of her?', 'When asked why she cursed at her teachers, Candace replied, “They only call on me when I don’t know the answer.']
['What else did she say?', 'I don’t want to say, ‘I don’t know’ all of the time and look like an idiot in front of my friends.']
['Did she have any other reasons for cursing?', 'The teachers embarrass me.”']
['What was done during the evaluation?', 'She was given a battery of tests, including an IQ test.']
['What was her score on the IQ test?', 'Her score on the IQ test was 68.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Despite evidence for the value of intelligence and related evaluations, the methods and interpretations of these tests are continually evolving.']

['Who developed or improved on testing programs in order to make them more accurate, equitable, and useful?', 'Researchers such as Jack A. Naglieri (2020) have developed or improved on testing programs in order to make them more accurate, equitable, and useful.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Beyond new testing instruments, some researchers demonstrate value in differentiating tests for different age groups, abilities, and contexts.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'A young girl, born of teenage parents, lives with her grandmother in rural Mississippi.']
['How did her childhood go?', 'She learns to read when she is just 3 years old.']
['How did she adapt to her rural environment?', 'As she grows older, she longs to live with her mother, who now resides in Wisconsin.']
['How old is she when she moves to Wisconsin?', 'She moves there at the age of 6 years.']
['What happened to her in Wisconsin?', 'At 9 years of age, she is raped.']
['What happened to her after that?', 'During the next several years, several different male relatives repeatedly molest her.']
['How did this affect her life?', 'Her life unravels.']
['What did she do after this?', 'She turns to drugs and sex to fill the deep, lonely void inside her.']

['What did her mother do to help her?', 'Her mother then sends her to Nashville to live with her father, who imposes strict behavioral expectations upon her, and over time, her wild life settles once again.']

['What did she do after her wild life?', 'She begins to experience success in school, and at 19 years old, becomes the youngest and first African-American female news anchor (“Dates and Events,” n.d.).']
['What did she do after that?', 'The woman—Oprah Winfrey—goes on to become a media giant known for both her intelligence and her empathy.']
['What do some researchers believe?', 'Some researchers believe that intelligence is a trait inherited from a person’s parents.']
['What studies?', 'Scientists who research this topic typically use twin studies to determine the heritability of intelligence.']
['What is one of the most well known twin studies?', 'The Minnesota Study of Twins Reared Apart is one of the most well-known twin studies.']

['What was revealed in this study?', 'In this investigation, researchers found that identical twins raised together and identical twins raised apart exhibit a higher correlation between their IQ scores than siblings or fraternal twins raised together (Bouchard, Lykken, McGue, Segal, & Tellegen, 1990).']
['What did this study reveal?', 'The findings from this study reveal a genetic component to intelligence.']
['How do psychologists disagree with their view?', 'At the same time, other psychologists believe that intelligence is shaped by a child’s developmental environment.']

['What does this mean?', 'If parents were to provide their children with intellectual stimuli from before they are born, it is likely that they would absorb the benefits of that stimulation, and it would be reflected in intelligence levels.']
['What is the reality of each idea?', 'The reality is that aspects of each idea are probably correct.']

['what is one study suggests?', 'In fact, one study suggests that although genetics seem to be in control of the level of intelligence, the environmental influences provide both stability and change to trigger manifestation of cognitive abilities (Bartels, Rietveld, Van Baal, & Boomsma, 2002).']
['What is the next generation of intelligence?', 'Certainly, there are behaviors that support the development of intelligence, but the genetic component of high intelligence should not be ignored.']
['is there anything else interesting?', 'As with all heritable traits, however, it is not always possible to isolate how and when high intelligence is passed on to the next generation.']

['What is the theory that each person responds to the environment in a unique way based on their genetic makeup?', 'Range of Reaction is the theory that each person responds to the environment in a unique way based on their genetic makeup.']
