['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'According to this idea, your genetic potential is a fixed quantity, but whether you reach your full intellectual potential is dependent upon the environmental stimulation you experience, especially in childhood.']
['Does this theory work?', 'Think about this scenario: A couple adopts a child who has average genetic intellectual potential.']
['What did they do to make her intellectually stronger?', 'They raise her in an extremely stimulating environment.']
['How would this influence her intellectual potential?', 'It is likely that the stimulating environment will improve her intellectual outcomes over the course of her life.']
["What is the most likely cause of the child's poor performance?", 'If a child with an extremely strong genetic background is placed in an environment that does not stimulate him:']

['What else has been found about this theory?', 'Interestingly, according to a longitudinal study of highly gifted individuals, it was found that “the two extremes of optimal and pathological experience are both represented disproportionately in the backgrounds of creative individuals”; however, those who experienced supportive family environments were more likely to report being happy (Csikszentmihalyi & Csikszentmihalyi, 1993, p. 187).']
['What is the challenge to determining origins of high intelligence?', 'Another challenge to determining origins of high intelligence is the confounding nature of our human social structures.']

['What social structures?', 'It is troubling to note that some ethnic groups perform better on IQ tests than others—and it is likely that the results do not have much to do with the quality of each ethnic group’s intellect.']
['What is important for a person to be able to do?', 'The same is true for socioeconomic status.']

['What is it that causes children to experience more stress?', 'Children who live in poverty experience more pervasive, daily stress than children who do not worry about the basic needs of safety, shelter, and food.']
['What impact does this have on the brain?', 'These worries can negatively affect how the brain functions and develops, causing a dip in IQ scores.']

['What did they determine?', 'Mark Kishiyama and his colleagues determined that children living in poverty demonstrated reduced prefrontal brain functioning comparable to children with damage to the lateral prefrontal cortex (Kishiyama, Boyce, Jimenez, Perry, & Knight, 2009).']

['What was the debate around the foundations and influences on intelligence exploding in 1969?', 'The debate around the foundations and influences on intelligence exploded in 1969, when an educational psychologist named Arthur Jensen published the article “How Much Can We Boost I.Q. and Achievement” in the Harvard Educational Review.']
['What did Jensen conclude about IQ?', 'Jensen had administered IQ tests to diverse groups of students, and his results led him to the conclusion that IQ is determined by genetics.']
['What is his theory about intelligence?', 'He also posited that intelligence was made up of two types of abilities: Level I and Level II.']
['What is the difference between Level I and Level II?', 'In his theory, Level I is responsible for rote memorization, whereas Level II is responsible for conceptual and analytical abilities.']
['Was level i consistent?', 'According to his findings, Level I remained consistent among the human race.']
['Did he find any other studies about level i and its use?', 'Level II, however, exhibited differences among ethnic groups (Modgil & Routledge, 1987).']
['What conclusion did Jensen make about intelligence?', 'Jensen’s most controversial conclusion was that Level II intelligence is prevalent among Asian people, then White people, then Black people.']
['What was the case?', 'Robert Williams was among those who called out racial bias in Jensen’s results (Williams, 1970).']

['What year was this article published?', 'Obviously, Jensen’s interpretation of his own data caused an intense response in a nation that continued to grapple with the effects of racism (Fox, 2012).']

['Why was he so controversial?', "While even some who took issue with Jensen's findings indicated that they did not detect overt racism in his work, Jensen himself made a number of racist statements during an interview with a White nationalist publication, American Renaissance."]

['Why was that?', 'He indicated his belief that many Black people were not "educable up to a level for which there’s any economic demand," while also having a higher birth rate than other groups, which would lead to a shift in population and a deterioration of the nation (Taylor, 1992).']

['What happened to Jensen’s ideas?', 'However, Jensen’s ideas were not solitary or unique; rather, they represented one of many examples of psychologists asserting racial differences in IQ and cognitive ability.']
['Are there any other examples of the same?', 'In fact, Rushton and Jensen (2005) reviewed three decades worth of research on the relationship between race and cognitive ability.']

['What is the core of Jensen’s conclusions?', 'Jensen’s belief in the inherited nature of intelligence and the validity of the IQ test to be the truest measure of intelligence are at the core of his conclusions.']

['What other information is available in our study material?', 'In a related story, parents of African American students filed a case against the State of California in 1979, because they believed that the testing method used to identify students with learning disabilities was culturally unfair as the tests were normed and standardized using White children (Larry P. v. Riles).']

['What did they believe was unfair?', 'The testing method used by the state disproportionately identified African American children as “mentally retarded," which resulted in many students being incorrectly classified.']
['What was the outcome of the case?', 'According to a summary of the case, Larry P. v. Riles:']
['What are cognitive disorders that affect different areas of cognition?', 'Learning disabilities are cognitive disorders that affect different areas of cognition, particularly language or reading.']
['Are there any other things to know about this topic?', 'It should be pointed out that learning disabilities are not the same thing as intellectual disabilities.']

['Are learning disabilities and global intellectual or developmental disabilities related in any way?', 'Learning disabilities are considered specific neurological impairments rather than global intellectual or developmental disabilities.']

['What is the difference between a language and reading disability?', 'A person with a language disability has difficulty understanding or using spoken language, whereas someone with a reading disability, such as dyslexia, has difficulty processing what they are reading.']
['What age do learning disabilities develop?', 'Often, learning disabilities are not recognized until a child reaches school age.']
['What is one confounding aspect of learning disabilities?', 'One confounding aspect of learning disabilities is that they most often affect children with average to above-average intelligence.']
['What is significant about the confounding aspect?', 'In other words, the disability is specific to a particular area and not a measure of overall intellectual ability.']
['Are there any other aspects to be considered?', 'At the same time, learning disabilities tend to exhibit comorbidity with other disorders, like attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']

['Can you tell me the incidence of ADHD in relation to learning disabilities?', 'Anywhere between 30–70% of individuals with diagnosed cases of ADHD also have some sort of learning disability (Riccio, Gonzales, & Hynd, 1994).']
['Are there any other interesting aspects in the article?', 'Let’s take a look at three examples of common learning disabilities: dysgraphia, dyslexia, and dyscalculia.']
['What does dysgraphia mean?', 'Children with dysgraphia have a learning disability that results in a struggle to write legibly.']
['What can be found to happen with dysgraphia?', 'The physical task of writing with a pen and paper is extremely challenging for the person.']

['What is the main difference between dysgraphia and other forms of writing impairment?', 'These children often have extreme difficulty putting their thoughts down on paper (Smits-Engelsman & Van Galen, 1997).']
['How is this hard for these people to do?', 'This difficulty is inconsistent with a person’s IQ.']
['What is inconsistent with a person’s IQ?', 'That is, based on the child’s IQ and/or abilities in other areas, a child with dysgraphia should be able to write, but can’t.']
['What is found about dysgraphia?', 'Children with dysgraphia may also have problems with spatial abilities.']
['What are the reasons students with dysgraphia are required to have academic accommodations?', 'Students with dysgraphia need academic accommodations to help them succeed in school.']
['What kind of accommodations do students with dysgraphia need?', 'These accommodations can provide students with alternative assessment opportunities to demonstrate what they know (Barton, 2003).']
['How can students with dysgraphia demonstrate what they know?', 'For example, a student with dysgraphia might be permitted to take an oral exam rather than a traditional paper-and-pencil test.']

['Can students with dysgraphia receive special treatment?', 'Treatment is usually provided by an occupational therapist, although there is some question as to how effective such treatment is (Zwicker, 2005).']
['What is the most common learning disability in children?', 'Dyslexia is the most common learning disability in children.']
['What does dyslexia have to do with reading?', 'An individual with dyslexia exhibits an inability to correctly process letters.']
['Does sound processing matter?', 'The neurological mechanism for sound processing does not work properly in someone with dyslexia.']
['What does this mean for the dyslexic?', 'As a result, dyslexic children may not understand sound-letter correspondence.']

['What is a typical dyslexic sign?', 'A child with dyslexia may mix up letters within words and sentences—letter reversals, such as those shown in Figure 7.17, are a hallmark of this learning disability—or skip whole words while reading.']
['What does the dyslexic child have trouble with?', 'A dyslexic child may have difficulty spelling words correctly while writing.']
['What is the disordered way that the brain processes letters and sound?', 'Because of the disordered way that the brain processes letters and sound, learning to read is a frustrating experience.']
['What did you find interesting about dyslexic individuals?', 'Some dyslexic individuals cope by memorizing the shapes of most words, but they never actually learn to read (Berninger, 2008).']
['What is the difference between dyscalculia and dyscalculia?', 'Dyscalculia is difficulty in learning or comprehending arithmetic.']

['What do you find difficult about learning arithmetic?', 'This learning disability is often first evident when children exhibit difficulty discerning how many objects are in a small group without counting them.']

['What are some symptoms of dyscalculia?', 'Other symptoms may include struggling to memorize math facts, organize numbers, or fully differentiate between numerals, math symbols, and written numbers (such as “3” and “three”).']
['What does memory do?', 'Memory is an information processing system; therefore, we often compare it to a computer.']
['What does memory store?', 'Memory is the set of processes used to encode, store, and retrieve information over different periods of time.']
['What is Encoding?', 'We get information into our brains through a process called encoding, which is the input of information into the memory system.']
['What does the brain do with sensory information?', 'Once we receive sensory information from the environment, our brains label or code it.']
['What do we do with the information?', 'We organize the information with other similar information and connect new concepts to existing concepts.']
['How is this information input processed?', 'Encoding information occurs through automatic processing and effortful processing.']
['What are some questions we will be asking to help us remember the passage?', 'If someone asks you what you ate for lunch today, more than likely you could recall this information quite easily.']
['What is automatic processing?', 'This is known as automatic processing, or the encoding of details like time, space, frequency, and the meaning of words.']
['What is automatic processing?', 'Automatic processing is usually done without any conscious awareness.']
['What is another example of automatic processing?', 'Recalling the last time you studied for a test is another example of automatic processing.']
['What else do you know about automatic processing?', 'It probably required a lot of work and attention on your part in order to encode that information.']
['What is another way of saying automatic processing?', 'This is known as effortful processing.']
['What are the most important encoding principles in the chapter about simple sentence?', 'Even a simple sentence is easier to recall when it is meaningful (Anderson, 1984).']

['Did you find any other important principles in the chapter?', 'Read the following sentences (Bransford & McCarrell, 1974), then look away and count backwards from 30 by threes to zero, and then try to write down the sentences (no peeking back at this page!).']
['How are the notes described?', 'The notes were sour because the seams split.']
['Why was the voyage delayed?', "The voyage wasn't delayed because the bottle shattered."]
['What was important about the haystack?', 'The haystack was important because the cloth ripped.']
['What did you write down?', 'By themselves, the statements that you wrote down were most likely confusing and difficult for you to recall.']
['What happened when you tried to write them again?', 'Now, try writing them again, using the following prompts: bagpipe, ship christening, and parachutist.']
['What was your next question?', 'Next count backwards from 40 by fours, then check yourself to see how well you recalled the sentences this time.']
['What happened after that?', 'Material is far better encoded when you make it meaningful.']
['What are the three types of encoding?', 'There are three types of encoding.']
['What is semantic encoding?', 'The encoding of words and their meaning is known as semantic encoding.']
['What was significant about this?', 'It was first demonstrated by William Bousfield (1935) in an experiment in which he asked people to memorize words.']
['How did the experiment go?', 'The 60 words were actually divided into 4 categories of meaning, although the participants did not know this because the words were randomly presented.']

['Did they understand the meanings of the words?', 'When they were asked to remember the words, they tended to recall them in categories, showing that they paid attention to the meanings of the words as they learned them.']
['What is the encoding of images called?', 'Visual encoding is the encoding of images, and acoustic encoding is the encoding of sounds, words in particular.']
['How does visual encoding work?', 'To see how visual encoding works, read over this list of words: car, level, dog, truth, book, value.']
['What can you remember from those words?', 'You would probably have an easier time recalling the words car, dog, and book, and a more difficult time recalling the words level, truth, and value.']
['Why do you recall images over words?', 'Because you can recall images (mental pictures) more easily than words alone.']
['What does created images mean?', 'When you read the words car, dog, and book you created images of these things in your mind.']
['What do you create images of?', 'These are concrete, high-imagery words.']
['How do they differ from abstract words?', 'On the other hand, abstract words like level, truth, and value are low-imagery words.']
['What can you recall when there is an image?', 'High-imagery words are encoded both visually and semantically (Paivio, 1986), thus building a stronger memory.']
['What else does the material cover?', 'Now let’s turn our attention to acoustic encoding.']

['What happens when a person uses the recall feature?', 'You are driving in your car and a song comes on the radio that you haven’t heard in at least 10 years, but you sing along, recalling every word.']

['What songs do people sing?', 'In the United States, children often learn the alphabet through song, and they learn the number of days in each month through rhyme: “Thirty days hath September, / April, June, and November; / All the rest have thirty-one, / Save February, with twenty-eight days clear, / And twenty-nine each leap year.”']
['What does the music teach?', 'These lessons are easy to remember because of acoustic encoding.']
['What does it encode?', 'We encode the sounds the words make.']
['Why is it encoded?', 'This is one of the reasons why much of what we teach young children is done through song, rhyme, and rhythm.']

['What were the experiments that psychologists Fergus Craik and Endel Tulving (1975) conducted to find out?', 'Some years ago, psychologists Fergus Craik and Endel Tulving (1975) conducted a series of experiments to find out.']
['What was their research about?', 'Participants were given words along with questions about them.']
['How did the questions require the participants to process the words at one of the three levels?', 'The questions required the participants to process the words at one of the three levels.']
['What questions were asked about visual processing?', 'The visual processing questions included such things as asking the participants about the font of the letters.']

['How did they perceive the letters?', 'The acoustic processing questions asked the participants about the sound or rhyming of the words, and the semantic processing questions asked the participants about the meaning of the words.']

['What were the participants asked after they were presented with the words and questions?', 'After participants were presented with the words and questions, they were given an unexpected recall or recognition task.']
['What are some important aspects about the content of the document?', 'Words that had been encoded semantically were better remembered than those encoded visually or acoustically.']
['What does semantic encoding involve?', 'Semantic encoding involves a deeper level of processing than the shallower visual or acoustic encoding.']

['What conclusion did Craig and Tulving draw from their research?', 'Craik and Tulving concluded that we process verbal information best through semantic encoding, especially if we apply what is called the self-reference effect.']

['What is the self reference effect?', 'The self-reference effect is the tendency for an individual to have better memory for information that relates to oneself in comparison to material that has less personal relevance (Rogers, Kuiper, & Kirker, 1977).']
['What does storage involve?', 'Once the information has been encoded, we have to somehow retain it.']
['How do we encode information?', 'Our brains take the encoded information and place it in storage.']
['What is the creation of a permanent record of information called?', 'Storage is the creation of a permanent record of information.']

['What are the 3 stages of memory?', 'In order for a memory to go into storage (i.e., long-term memory), it has to pass through three distinct stages: Sensory Memory, Short-Term Memory, and finally Long-Term Memory.']
['Who discovered these stages?', 'These stages were first proposed by Richard Atkinson and Richard Shiffrin (1968).']

['What model of human memory is based on the belief that we process memories in the same way that a computer processes information?', "Their model of human memory, called Atkinson and Shiffrin's model, is based on the belief that we process memories in the same way that a computer processes information."]
['What is the other model of memory?', "Atkinson and Shiffrin's model is not the only model of memory."]
['Who proposed a working memory model?', 'Baddeley and Hitch (1974) proposed a working memory model in which short-term memory has different forms.']
['How does their model help with memory?', 'In their model, storing memories in short-term memory is like opening different files on a computer and adding information.']
['Does the model explain how working memory works?', 'The working memory files hold a limited amount of information.']
['What are the different types of short-term memory?', 'The type of short-term memory (or computer file) depends on the type of information received.']

['What are the different types of memory files?', 'There are memories in visual-spatial form, as well as memories of spoken or written material, and they are stored in three short-term systems: a visuospatial sketchpad, an episodic buffer (Baddeley, 2000), and a phonological loop.']

['What else is the model of working memory?', 'According to Baddeley and Hitch, a central executive part of memory supervises or controls the flow of information to and from the three short-term systems, and the central executive is responsible for moving information into long-term memory.']
['What is sensory memory?', 'In the Atkinson-Shiffrin model, stimuli from the environment are processed first in sensory memory: storage of brief sensory events, such as sights, sounds, and tastes.']
['What kind of storage is it?', 'It is very brief storage—up to a couple of seconds.']
['What else do we have to learn about it?', 'We are constantly bombarded with sensory information.']
['What does it really matter what the professor was wearing?', 'As long as the professor was dressed appropriately, it does not really matter what she was wearing.']
['How does it affect us?', 'Sensory information about sights, sounds, smells, and even textures, which we do not view as valuable information, we discard.']
['What is the most important information to remember?', 'If we view something as valuable, the information will move into our short-term memory system.']
['What is a temporary storage system that processes incoming sensory memory?', 'Short-term memory (STM) is a temporary storage system that processes incoming sensory memory.']
['What is the difference between short-term and working memory?', 'The terms short-term and working memory are sometimes used interchangeably, but they are not exactly the same.']
['What is more accurately described as a component of working memory?', 'Short-term memory is more accurately described as a component of working memory.']
['What is short-term memory?', 'Short-term memory takes information from sensory memory and sometimes connects that memory to something already in long-term memory.']
['What is the storage time for short-term memory?', 'Short-term memory storage lasts 15 to 30 seconds.']
['What is the best way to think of a computer screen?', 'Think of it as the information you have displayed on your computer screen, such as a document, spreadsheet, or website.']
['What happens to this information?', 'Then, information in STM goes to long-term memory (you save it to your hard drive), or it is discarded (you delete a document or close a web browser).']
['What happens during rehearsal?', 'Rehearsal moves information from short-term memory to long-term memory.']
['What is active rehearsal?', 'Active rehearsal is a way of attending to information to move it from short-term to long-term memory.']
['What is the practice of active rehearsal?', 'During active rehearsal, you repeat (practice) the information to be remembered.']
['How many times do you repeat the information?', 'If you repeat it enough, it may be moved into long-term memory.']
['What is an example of this?', 'For example, this type of active rehearsal is the way many children learn their ABCs by singing the alphabet song.']

['What is the act of linking new information you are trying to learn to existing information that you already know?', 'Alternatively, elaborative rehearsal is the act of linking new information you are trying to learn to existing information that you already know.']

['What is an example of this?', 'For example, if you meet someone at a party and your phone is dead but you want to remember his phone number, which starts with area code 203, you might remember that your uncle Abdul lives in Connecticut and has a 203 area code.']
['What happens if you write down the area code of a phone number?', 'This way, when you try to remember the phone number of your new prospective friend, you will easily remember the area code.']
['What did Craig and Lockhart (1972) propose?', 'Craik and Lockhart (1972) proposed the levels of processing hypothesis that states the deeper you think about something, the better you remember it.']
['What do you want to study next?', 'You may find yourself asking, “How much information can our memory handle at once?”']

['What are some of the tests you want to use?', 'To explore the capacity and duration of your short-term memory, have a partner read the strings of random numbers out loud to you, beginning each string by saying, “Ready?” and ending each by saying, “Recall,” at which point you should try to write down the string of numbers from memory.']
['What was the longest string at which you got the series correct?', 'Note the longest string at which you got the series correct.']
['What is the current working memory capacity?', 'For most people, the capacity will probably be close to 7 plus or minus 2.']

['what does george miller review', 'In 1956, George Miller reviewed most of the research on the capacity of short-term memory and found that people can retain between 5 and 9 items, so he reported the capacity of short-term memory was the "magic number" 7 plus or minus 2.']
['What is the contemporary research on working memory capacity?', 'However, more contemporary research has found working memory capacity is 4 plus or minus 1 (Cowan, 2010).']

['What else does this study include?', 'Generally, recall is somewhat better for random numbers than for random letters (Jacobs, 1887) and also often slightly better for information we hear (acoustic encoding) rather than information we see (visual encoding) (Anderson, 1969).']
['What are two factors that affect short-term memory retention?', 'Memory trace decay and interference are two factors that affect short-term memory retention.']

['What did the experiment have to do with?', 'Peterson and Peterson (1959) investigated short-term memory using the three letter sequences called trigrams (e.g., CLS) that had to be recalled after various time intervals between 3 and 18 seconds.']

['What happened after a 3 second delay?', 'Participants remembered about 80% of the trigrams after a 3-second delay, but only 10% after a delay of 18 seconds, which caused them to conclude that short-term memory decayed in 18 seconds.']
['What happens to the memory trace during decay?', 'During decay, the memory trace becomes less activated over time, and the information is forgotten.']

['What other aspects of decay are important?', 'However, Keppel and Underwood (1962) examined only the first trials of the trigram task and found that proactive interference also affected short-term memory retention.']
['What is the main idea of proactive interference?', 'During proactive interference, previously learned information interferes with the ability to learn new information.']
['What can we learn from these studies?', 'Both memory trace decay and proactive interference affect short-term memory.']

['How long does it take to consolidate information into long-term memory?', 'Once the information reaches long-term memory, it has to be consolidated at both the synaptic level, which takes a few hours, and into the memory system, which can take weeks or longer.']
['What is the continuous storage of information called?', 'Long-term memory (LTM) is the continuous storage of information.']
['What is the storage capacity of long-term memory?', 'Unlike short-term memory, long-term memory storage capacity is believed to be unlimited.']
['What is long-term memory?', 'It encompasses all the things you can remember that happened more than just a few minutes ago.']
['What is the arrangement of thoughts?', 'One cannot really consider long-term memory without thinking about the way it is organized.']
['If you were to think of peanut butter and jelly, what would you think of?', 'If you did, you probably have associated peanut butter and jelly in your mind.']
['What is the general term for the way memories are organized?', 'It is generally accepted that memories are organized in semantic (or associative) networks (Collins & Loftus, 1975).']

['what are the concepts?', 'A semantic network consists of concepts, and as you may recall from what you’ve learned about memory, concepts are categories or groupings of linguistic information, images, ideas, or memories, such as life experiences.']

['how are the concepts organized?', 'Although individual experiences and expertise can affect concept arrangement, concepts are believed to be arranged hierarchically in the mind (Anderson & Reder, 1999; Johnson & Mervis, 1997, 1998; Palmer, Jones, Hennessy, Unze, & Pick, 1989; Rosch, Mervis, Gray, Johnson, & Boyes-Braem, 1976; Tanaka & Taylor, 1991).']
['Are the concepts related?', 'Related concepts are linked, and the strength of the link depends on how often two concepts have been associated.']
['What are semantic networks?', 'Semantic networks differ depending on personal experiences.']
['How do semantic networks impact memory?', 'Importantly for memory, activating any part of a semantic network also activates the concepts linked to that part to a lesser degree.']
['What is the process of spreading activation?', 'The process is known as spreading activation (Collins & Loftus, 1975).']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'If one part of a network is activated, it is easier to access the associated concepts because they are already partially activated.']
['How is it accomplished?', 'When you remember or recall something, you activate a concept, and the related concepts are more easily remembered because they are partially activated.']
['Is this the only thing going on?', 'However, the activations do not spread in just one direction.']

['What is happening?', 'When you remember something, you usually have several routes to get the information you are trying to access, and the more links you have to a concept, the better your chances of remembering.']
['What are the two types of long-term memory?', 'There are two types of long-term memory: explicit and implicit.']

['How is the difference between them important?', 'Understanding the difference between explicit memory and implicit memory is important because aging, particular types of brain trauma, and certain disorders can impact explicit and implicit memory in different ways.']
['What is the difference between explicit and implicit memory?', 'Explicit memories are those we consciously try to remember, recall, and report.']
['What are some examples of explicit memories?', 'For example, if you are studying for your chemistry exam, the material you are learning will be part of your explicit memory.']

['What is the analogy for the information in your long-term memory?', 'In keeping with the computer analogy, some information in your long-term memory would be like the information you have saved on the hard drive.']
['How does it relate to computer analogies?', 'It is not there on your desktop (your short-term memory), but most of the time you can pull up this information when you want it.']
['How are these memories stored?', 'Not all long-term memories are strong memories, and some memories can only be recalled using prompts.']

['What are some examples of strong memories?', 'For example, you might easily recall a fact, such as the capital of the United States, but you might struggle to recall the name of the restaurant at which you had dinner when you visited a nearby city last summer.']
['What is a prompt?', 'A prompt, such as that the restaurant was named after its owner, might help you recall the name of the restaurant.']
['What is declarative memory?', 'Explicit memory is sometimes referred to as declarative memory, because it can be put into words.']
['Are there any other types of memories?', 'Explicit memory is divided into episodic memory and semantic memory.']
['What is the definition of episodic memory?', 'Episodic memory is information about events we have personally experienced (i.e., an episode).']
['What is an example of an episodic memory?', 'For instance, the memory of your last birthday is an episodic memory.']
['How is the memory reported?', 'Usually, episodic memory is reported as a story.']
['When was the concept of episodic memory proposed?', 'The concept of episodic memory was first proposed about in the 1970s (Tulving, 1972).']

['What was the theory of episodic memory?', 'Since then, Tulving and others have reformulated the theory, and currently scientists believe that episodic memory is memory about happenings in particular places at particular times—the what, where, and when of an event (Tulving, 2002).']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'It involves recollection of visual imagery as well as the feeling of familiarity (Hassabis & Maguire, 2007).']
['What is semantic memory?', 'Semantic memory is knowledge about words, concepts, and language-based knowledge and facts.']
['What is significant about semantic memory?', 'Semantic memory is typically reported as facts.']
['What does semantic mean?', 'Semantic means having to do with language and knowledge about language.']

['What are some facts stored in semantic memory?', 'For example, answers to the following questions like “what is the definition of psychology” and “who was the first African American president of the United States” are stored in your semantic memory.']
['What are the implications of implicit memories?', 'Implicit memories are long-term memories that are not part of our consciousness.']

['What can one do to detect that?', 'Although implicit memories are learned outside of our awareness and cannot be consciously recalled, implicit memory is demonstrated in the performance of some task (Roediger, 1990; Schacter, 1987).']

['What kind of tasks?', 'Implicit memory has been studied with cognitive demand tasks, such as performance on artificial grammars (Reber, 1976), word memory (Jacoby, 1983; Jacoby & Witherspoon, 1982), and learning unspoken and unwritten contingencies and rules (Greenspoon, 1955; Giddan & Eriksen, 1959; Krieckhaus & Eriksen, 1960).']

['What does the computer metaphor have to do with this?', 'Returning to the computer metaphor, implicit memories are like a program running in the background, and you are not aware of their influence.']
['What can implicit memories influence?', 'Implicit memories can influence observable behaviors as well as cognitive tasks.']
['What are some examples of a memory that cannot be put into words?', 'In either case, you usually cannot put the memory into words that adequately describe the task.']
['What are some examples of implicit memories?', 'There are several types of implicit memories, including procedural, priming, and emotional conditioning.']

['What authors have studied implicit procedural memory using observable behaviors?', 'Implicit procedural memory is often studied using observable behaviors (Adams, 1957; Lacey & Smith, 1954; Lazarus & McCleary, 1951).']

['What is implicit procedural memory?', 'Implicit procedural memory stores information about the way to do something, and it is the memory for skilled actions, such as brushing your teeth, riding a bicycle, or driving a car.']

['How does implicit procedural memory improve?', 'You were probably not that good at riding a bicycle or driving a car the first time you tried, but you were much better after doing those things for a year.']
['What was the result of doing that?', 'Your improved bicycle riding was due to learning balancing abilities.']
['What do you think happens when you are in a car accident?', 'You likely thought about staying upright in the beginning, but now you just do it.']
['Is this because the memory is implicit?', 'Moreover, you probably are good at staying balanced, but cannot tell someone the exact way you do it.']

['What can you tell me about the first time you learned to drive?', 'Similarly, when you first learned to drive, you probably thought about a lot of things that you just do now without much thought.']
['What is implicit priming?', 'Implicit priming is another type of implicit memory (Schacter, 1992).']
['How does priming affect us?', 'During priming exposure to a stimulus affects the response to a later stimulus.']
['What kind of stimulus do we use?', 'Stimuli can vary and may include words, pictures, and other stimuli to elicit a response or increase recognition.']
['What is an example of a good way to spend time outdoors?', 'For instance, some people really enjoy picnics.']
['What do people do with a campfire?', 'They love going into nature, spreading a blanket on the ground, and eating a delicious meal.']
['What is the last question?', 'Now, unscramble the following letters to make a word.']
['What was the second question?', 'Chances are good that it was "plate."']
['Had you read it?', 'Had you read, “Some people really enjoy growing flowers.']

['Why do some people like to grow flowers?', 'They love going outside to their garden, fertilizing their plants, and watering their flowers,” you probably would have come up with the word "petal" instead of plate.']

['What is the first thing I want to know about your study?', 'The reason people are more likely to come up with “plate” after reading about a picnic is that plate is associated (linked) with picnic.']
['How was the word primed?', 'Plate was primed by activating the semantic network.']
['What did the study connect picnic to plate?', 'Similarly, “petal” is linked to flower and is primed by flower.']
['What is the reason you probably said jelly in response to peanut butter?', 'Priming is also the reason you probably said jelly in response to peanut butter.']

['What is the type of memory involved in classically conditioned emotion responses?', 'Implicit emotional conditioning is the type of memory involved in classically conditioned emotion responses (Olson & Fazio, 2001).']
['How do these emotional relationships work?', 'These emotional relationships cannot be reported or recalled but can be associated with different stimuli.']
['What is an example of this?', 'For example, specific smells can cause specific emotional responses for some people.']

['what does an implicit emotional response mean?', "If there is a smell that makes you feel positive and nostalgic, and you don't know where that response comes from, it is an implicit emotional response."]
['What are some examples of emotional responses?', 'Similarly, most people have a song that causes a specific emotional response.']
['What is the effect of that song?', "That song's effect could be an implicit emotional memory (Yang, Xu, Du, Shi, & Fang, 2011)."]
['What is it about?', 'So you have worked hard to encode (via effortful processing) and store some important information for your upcoming final exam.']
['What is retrieval?', 'The act of getting information out of memory storage and back into conscious awareness is known as retrieval.']

['What would it feel like to find and open a paper you had previously saved on your computer’s hard drive?', 'This would be similar to finding and opening a paper you had previously saved on your computer’s hard drive.']
['What is the importance of long-term memory?', 'Our ability to retrieve information from long-term memory is vital to our everyday functioning.']

['What kind of information?', 'You must be able to retrieve information from memory in order to do everything from knowing how to brush your hair and teeth, to driving to work, to knowing how to perform your job once you get there.']

['What are three ways you can retrieve information out of your long-term memory storage system?', 'There are three ways you can retrieve information out of your long-term memory storage system: recall, recognition, and relearning.']
['What does recall mean?', 'Recall is what we most often think about when we talk about memory retrieval: it means you can access information without cues.']
['How would you use recall?', 'For example, you would use recall for an essay test.']

['What happens when you recognize information that you have previously learned after encountering it again?', 'Recognition happens when you identify information that you have previously learned after encountering it again.']
['What is the process of comparison?', 'It involves a process of comparison.']
['What is another example of recognition?', 'When you take a multiple-choice test, you are relying on recognition to help you choose the correct answer.']
['What else can you tell me about memory retrieval?', 'Here is another example.']
['What is another example of a resentment?', 'Let’s say you graduated from high school 10 years ago, and you have returned to your hometown for your 10-year reunion.']
['What happens when you look at your yearbook photos?', 'You may not be able to recall all of your classmates, but you recognize many of them based on their yearbook photos.']
['What is the third form of retrieval?', 'The third form of retrieval is relearning, and it’s just what it sounds like.']
['What does it involve?', 'It involves learning information that you previously learned.']
['What did Whitney do in high school?', 'Whitney took Spanish in high school, but after high school she did not have the opportunity to speak Spanish.']
['What are some interesting facts about Whitney?', 'Whitney is now 31, and her company has offered her an opportunity to work in their Mexico City office.']
['What does Whitney do after the offer?', 'In order to prepare herself, she enrolls in a Spanish course at the local community center.']
['What does she find when she starts learning?', 'She’s surprised at how quickly she’s able to pick up the language after not speaking it for 13 years; this is an example of relearning.']
['Who is Karl Lashley?', 'Karl Lashley began exploring this problem, about 100 years ago, by making lesions in the brains of animals such as rats and monkeys.']
['What was he searching for?', 'He was searching for evidence of the engram: the group of neurons that serve as the “physical representation of memory” (Josselyn, 2010).']
['What experiments did Lashley do?', 'First, Lashley (1950) trained rats to find their way through a maze.']
['What did they do to the rats?', 'Then, he used the tools available at the time—in this case a soldering iron—to create lesions in the rats’ brains, specifically in the cerebral cortex.']
['Why did he do that?', 'He did this because he was trying to erase the engram, or the original memory trace that the rats had of the maze.']

['What did the rats find when they were in the maze?', 'Lashley did not find evidence of the engram, and the rats were still able to find their way through the maze, regardless of the size or location of the lesion.']

['What was the experiment based on?', 'Based on his creation of lesions and the animals’ reaction, he formulated the equipotentiality hypothesis: if part of one area of the brain involved in memory is damaged, another part of the same area can take over that memory function (Lashley, 1950).']
['What did psychologists discover?', 'Although Lashley’s early work did not confirm the existence of the engram, modern psychologists are making progress locating it.']

['What else was discovered about the engram?', 'For example, Eric Kandel has spent decades studying the synapse and its role in controlling the flow of information through neural circuits needed to store memories (Mayford, Siegelbaum, & Kandel, 2012).']
['What is one of the parts that scientists believe involves memory?', 'Many scientists believe that the entire brain is involved with memory.']
['Did anyone make the discovery that memory is part of the brain?', 'However, since Lashley’s research, other scientists have been able to look more closely at the brain and memory.']

['What have scientists discovered about memory?', 'They have argued that memory is located in specific parts of the brain, and specific neurons can be recognized for their involvement in forming memories.']

['What are some of the main parts of the brain involved with memory?', 'The main parts of the brain involved with memory are the amygdala, the hippocampus, the cerebellum, and the prefrontal cortex.']
['What are some of the specifics of this study?', 'First, let’s look at the role of the amygdala in memory formation.']
['What is the main job of the amygdala?', 'The main job of the amygdala is to regulate emotions, such as fear and aggression.']
['What is the main role of the amygdala in memory formation?', 'The amygdala plays a part in how memories are stored because storage is influenced by stress hormones.']
['What kind of research has been done on this topic?', 'For example, one researcher experimented with rats and the fear response (Josselyn, 2010).']
['How did they experiment with rats?', 'Using Pavlovian conditioning, a neutral tone was paired with a foot shock to the rats.']
['What happened after the experiment?', 'This produced a fear memory in the rats.']

["What was the rat's reaction after being conditioned?", 'After being conditioned, each time they heard the tone, they would freeze (a defense response in rats), indicating a memory for the impending shock.']
['What did they do after this experiment?', 'Then the researchers induced cell death in neurons in the lateral amygdala, which is the specific area of the brain responsible for fear memories.']
['What happened after that?', 'They found the fear memory faded (became extinct).']

['What is another interesting aspect of the article?', 'Because of its role in processing emotional information, the amygdala is also involved in memory consolidation: the process of transferring new learning into long-term memory.']
['How does this effect the amygdala?', 'The amygdala seems to facilitate encoding memories at a deeper level when the event is emotionally arousing.']
['Why did researchers experiment with rats?', 'Another group of researchers also experimented with rats to learn how the hippocampus functions in memory processing.']

['What were the results of the experiment?', 'They created lesions in the hippocampi of the rats, and found that the rats demonstrated memory impairment on various tasks, such as object recognition and maze running.']

['What conclusion did they draw?', 'They concluded that the hippocampus is involved in memory, specifically normal recognition memory as well as spatial memory (when the memory tasks are like recall tests) (Clark, Zola, & Squire, 2000).']
['What does the hippocampus do?', 'Another job of the hippocampus is to project information to cortical regions that give memories meaning and connect them with other memories.']
['What is the other job of the hippocampus?', 'It also plays a part in memory consolidation: the process of transferring new learning into long-term memory.']
['What is the hippocampus and what does it do?', 'Injury to this area leaves us unable to process new declarative memories.']

['What was a famous patient?', 'One famous patient, known for years only as H. M., had both his left and right temporal lobes (hippocampi) removed in an attempt to help control the seizures he had been suffering from for years (Corkin, Amaral, González, Johnson, & Hyman, 1997).']
['What happened to the patient?', 'As a result, his declarative memory was significantly affected, and he could not form new semantic knowledge.']
['What did the patient do after that surgery?', 'He lost the ability to form new memories, yet he could still remember information and events that had occurred prior to the surgery.']

['What is the main topic of the study material?', 'Although the hippocampus seems to be more of a processing area for explicit memories, you could still lose it and be able to create implicit memories (procedural memory, motor learning, and classical conditioning), thanks to your cerebellum.']
['What are some examples of classical conditioning?', 'For example, one classical conditioning experiment is to accustom subjects to blink when they are given a puff of air to the eyes.']

['What was the result of the damage to the cerebellums of rabbits?', 'When researchers damaged the cerebellums of rabbits, they discovered that the rabbits were not able to learn the conditioned eye-blink response (Steinmetz, 1999; Green & Woodruff-Pak, 2000).']
['What is the topic of the study material?', 'Other researchers have used brain scans, including positron emission tomography (PET) scans, to learn how people process and retain information.']
['What is the prefrontal cortex involved in?', 'From these studies, it seems the prefrontal cortex is involved.']

['what other information is there?', 'In one study, participants had to complete two different tasks: either looking for the letter a in words (considered a perceptual task) or categorizing a noun as either living or non-living (considered a semantic task) (Kapur et al., 1994).']
['What else did they do in the study?', 'Participants were then asked which words they had previously seen.']
['What was significant about the study?', 'Recall was much better for the semantic task than for the perceptual task.']
['what else did they find?', 'According to PET scans, there was much more activation in the left inferior prefrontal cortex in the semantic task.']
['who was in the studies?', 'In another study, encoding was associated with left frontal activity, while retrieval of information was associated with the right frontal region (Craik et al., 1999).']

['What are some of the specific neurotransmitters involved with the process of memory?', 'There also appear to be specific neurotransmitters involved with the process of memory, such as epinephrine, dopamine, serotonin, glutamate, and acetylcholine (Myhrer, 2003).']
['which neurotransmitter is the most important to memory?', 'There continues to be discussion and debate among researchers as to which neurotransmitter plays which specific role (Blockland, 1996).']

['what is most important about neurotransmitters and memory?', 'Although we don’t yet know which role each neurotransmitter plays in memory, we do know that communication among neurons via neurotransmitters is critical for developing new memories.']
['What happens when people do the repetitive exercise?', 'Repeated activity by neurons leads to increased neurotransmitters in the synapses and more efficient and more synaptic connections.']
['How is that beneficial to memory?', 'This is how memory consolidation occurs.']

['What is another important fact about the content of our study material?', 'It is also believed that strong emotions trigger the formation of strong memories, and weaker emotional experiences form weaker memories; this is called arousal theory (Christianson, 1992).']

['What is an example of this theory?', 'For example, strong emotional experiences can trigger the release of neurotransmitters, as well as hormones, which strengthen memory; therefore, our memory for an emotional event is usually better than our memory for a non-emotional event.']

['What is another example of arousal theory?', 'When humans and animals are stressed, the brain secretes more of the neurotransmitter glutamate, which helps them remember the stressful event (McGaugh, 2003).']
["What is McGaugh's theory of memory?", 'This is clearly evidenced by what is known as the flashbulb memory phenomenon.']
['What is a flashbulb memory?', 'A flashbulb memory is an exceptionally clear recollection of an important event.']
['Can you explain what kind of memories are mentioned?', 'Many people who have lived through historic and momentous events can recall exactly where they were and how they heard about them.']

['What are some examples of how people remember events?', 'For example, a Pew Research Center (2011) survey found that for those Americans who were age 8 or older at the time of 9/11 terrorist attacks, 97% can recall the moment they learned of this event, even a decade after it happened.']

['What is the definition of flashbulb memories?', 'Many widely discussed examples of flashbulb memories pertain to national or global events, but according to their initial definition by researchers Brown and Kulik (1977) as well as additional work by more recent researchers, such a widely shared event is not required (Hirst & Phelps, 2016).']

['What are some examples of how people remember events?', 'Family members might always remember how they heard about an important event in their lives, or people in a school may recall nearly everything about the way they experienced a major event in that setting.']
['what other memories are mentioned?', 'And although most studies (and many conversations) involve negative memories, positive events can also elicit flashbulb memories.']

['What is the purpose of this study material?', 'You may pride yourself on your amazing ability to remember the birthdates and ages of all of your friends and family members, or you may be able recall vivid details of your 5th birthday party at Chuck E. Cheese’s.']
['Do you think this study material has any other interesting information?', 'However, all of us have at times felt frustrated, and even embarrassed, when our memories have failed us.']
['What is the reason for this?', 'There are several reasons why this happens.']

['What is the loss of long-term memory that occurs as the result of disease, physical trauma, or psychological trauma?', 'Amnesia is the loss of long-term memory that occurs as the result of disease, physical trauma, or psychological trauma.']
['Who studied K. C. for years?', 'Endel Tulving (2002) and his colleagues at the University of Toronto studied K. C. for years.']
['What caused K. C. to have severe amnesia?', 'K. C. suffered a traumatic head injury in a motorcycle accident and then had severe amnesia.']
['What else did Tulving study?', 'Tulving writes,']
['What are two common types of amnesia?', 'There are two common types of amnesia: anterograde amnesia and retrograde amnesia.']
['What is the cause of anterograde amnesia?', 'Anterograde amnesia is commonly caused by brain trauma, such as a blow to the head.']

['Does anterograde amnesia affect what you remember?', 'With anterograde amnesia, you cannot remember new information, although you can remember information and events that happened prior to your injury.']
['What is usually affected in anterograde amnesia?', 'The hippocampus is usually affected (McLeod, 2011).']

['Why does this cause amnesia?', 'This suggests that damage to the brain has resulted in the inability to transfer information from short-term to long-term memory; that is, the inability to consolidate memories.']

['What do you find interesting about Anterograde Amnesia?', 'Many people with this form of amnesia are unable to form new episodic or semantic memories, but are still able to form new procedural memories (Bayley & Squire, 2002).']
["What happened in H. M.'s case?", 'This was true of H. M., which was discussed earlier.']
['What did brain damage cause?', 'The brain damage caused by his surgery resulted in anterograde amnesia.']
['Why was this significant?', 'H. M. would read the same magazine over and over, having no memory of ever reading it—it was always new to him.']
['Did this cause problems in everyday life?', 'He also could not remember people he had met after his surgery.']

['How did this effect social interactions?', 'If you were introduced to H. M. and then you left the room for a few minutes, he would not know you upon your return and would introduce himself to you again.']

['What else is significant?', 'However, when presented the same puzzle several days in a row, although he did not remember having seen the puzzle before, his speed at solving it became faster each day (because of relearning) (Corkin, 1965, 1968).']
['What is the cause of retrograde amnesia?', 'Retrograde amnesia is loss of memory for events that occurred prior to the trauma.']
['What is the name of the condition that causes people to forget their past?', 'People with retrograde amnesia cannot remember some or even all of their past.']
["What are the symptoms of a person with Alzheimer's disease?", 'They have difficulty remembering episodic memories.']
['What was the cause of this?', 'You were in a car accident, suffered a head injury, and now have retrograde amnesia.']
['What happens to you if you have this?', 'You don’t remember anything about your life prior to waking up in the hospital.']

['What happened after that?', 'This may sound like the stuff of Hollywood movies, and Hollywood has been fascinated with the amnesia plot for nearly a century, going all the way back to the film Garden of Lies from 1915 to more recent movies such as the Jason Bourne spy thrillers.']
['What is the most interesting fact about the passage?', 'However, for real-life sufferers of retrograde amnesia, like former NFL football player Scott Bolzan, the story is not a Hollywood movie.']
['What happened to Bolzan?', 'Bolzan fell, hit his head, and deleted 46 years of his life in an instant.']
['What was his future like?', 'He is now living with one of the most extreme cases of retrograde amnesia on record.']
['What is the process of bringing up old memories called?', 'The formulation of new memories is sometimes called construction, and the process of bringing up old memories is called reconstruction.']
['Is reconstruction the same as memory?', 'Yet as we retrieve our memories, we also tend to alter and modify them.']
['Are these two things related?', 'A memory pulled from long-term storage into short-term memory is flexible.']
['What can happen to a memory?', 'New events can be added and we can change what we think we remember about past events, resulting in inaccuracies and distortions.']
['What can cause distortions?', 'People may not intend to distort facts, but it can happen in the process of retrieving old memories and combining them with new memories (Roediger & DeSoto, 2015).']
['How do people make suggestions to the subject?', 'When someone witnesses a crime, that person’s memory of the details of the crime is very important in catching the suspect.']
['Why is that?', 'Because memory is so fragile, witnesses can be easily (and often accidentally) misled due to the problem of suggestibility.']
['What is suggestibility?', 'Suggestibility describes the effects of misinformation from external sources that leads to the creation of false memories.']
['What are some examples of false memories?', 'In the fall of 2002, a sniper in the DC area shot people at a gas station, leaving Home Depot, and walking down the street.']
['Was there a particular cause for the false memories?', 'These attacks went on in a variety of places for over three weeks and resulted in the deaths of ten people.']
['Why were people scared?', 'During this time, as you can imagine, people were terrified to leave their homes, go shopping, or even walk through their neighborhoods.']
['What was done to help resolve this issue?', 'Police officers and the FBI worked frantically to solve the crimes, and a tip hotline was set up.']
['How many possible suspects were identified?', 'Law enforcement received over 140,000 tips, which resulted in approximately 35,000 possible suspects (Newseum, n.d.).']
['What happened during the white van debacle?', 'Most of the tips were dead ends, until a white van was spotted at the site of one of the shootings.']
['What did the police chief do after this?', 'The police chief went on national television with a picture of the white van.']
['Why was it going on national television?', 'After the news conference, several other eyewitnesses called to say that they too had seen a white van fleeing from the scene of the shooting.']
['Was the white van a good thing?', 'At the time, there were more than 70,000 white vans in the area.']
['What was happening with the vans?', 'Police officers, as well as the general public, focused almost exclusively on white vans because they believed the eyewitnesses.']
['What was happening?', 'Other tips were ignored.']
["What was the suspects' car?", 'When the suspects were finally caught, they were driving a blue sedan.']
['What are some of the topics discussed in Suggestibility?', 'As illustrated by this example, we are vulnerable to the power of suggestion, simply based on something we see on the news.']
['What is the cause of a false memory?', 'It is the suggestion that is the cause of the false memory.']

['What else do you find interesting about this topic?', 'Even though memory and the process of reconstruction can be fragile, police officers, prosecutors, and the courts often rely on eyewitness identification and testimony in the prosecution of criminals.']
['Does this lead to any mistakes?', 'However, faulty eyewitness identification and testimony can lead to wrongful convictions.']
['What was the name of the victim?', 'In 1984, Jennifer Thompson, then a 22-year-old college student in North Carolina, was brutally raped at knifepoint.']
['What happened next?', 'As she was being raped, she tried to memorize every detail of her rapist’s face and physical characteristics, vowing that if she survived, she would help get him convicted.']
['What did the police do?', 'After the police were contacted, a composite sketch was made of the suspect, and Jennifer was shown six photos.']
['What was the response to the question?', 'She chose two, one of which was of Ronald Cotton.']
['How did she decide who was the guy?', 'After looking at the photos for 4–5 minutes, she said, “Yeah.']
['What did she mean when she said, "This is the one," and then she added, "I think this is the guy."?', 'This is the one,” and then she added, “I think this is the guy.”']
['How did she feel?', 'Positive?”']
['How did she know he was the guy?', 'Then she asked the detective if she did OK, and he reinforced her choice by telling her she did great.']
['Did it help with the investigation?', 'These kinds of unintended cues and suggestions by police officers can lead witnesses to identify the wrong suspect.']

['What was the district attorney concerned about the first time she tried to identify the defendant?', 'The district attorney was concerned about her lack of certainty the first time, so she viewed a lineup of seven men.']
['What did she do with the line up?', 'She said she was trying to decide between numbers 4 and 5, finally deciding that Cotton, number 5, “Looks most like him.”']
['Who is Ronald Cotton?', 'He was 22 years old.']
['What was the trial about?', 'By the time the trial began, Jennifer Thompson had absolutely no doubt that she was raped by Ronald Cotton.']
['What did he do after the trial began?', 'She testified at the court hearing, and her testimony was compelling enough that it helped convict him.']

['what is the significance of a witness being misidentified?', 'Gary Wells and Deah Quinlivan (2009) assert it’s suggestive police identification procedures, such as stacking lineups to make the defendant stand out, telling the witness which person to identify, and confirming witnesses choices by telling them “Good choice,” or “You picked the guy.”']
['How long did he serve in prison?', 'After Cotton was convicted of the rape, he was sent to prison for life plus 50 years.']
['Did he ever have another trial?', 'After 4 years in prison, he was able to get a new trial.']
['Did he lose the new trial?', 'Jennifer Thompson once again testified against him.']
['How long was he in prison for the new trial?', 'This time Ronald Cotton was given two life sentences.']

['Was he ever released?', 'After serving 11 years in prison, DNA evidence finally demonstrated that Ronald Cotton did not commit the rape, was innocent, and had served over a decade in prison for a crime he did not commit.']
['What is unique about Ronald Cotton’s story?', 'Ronald Cotton’s story, unfortunately, is not unique.']
["What is unique about other people's stories?", 'There are also people who were convicted and placed on death row, who were later exonerated.']
['What does the Innocence Project do?', 'The Innocence Project is a non-profit group that works to exonerate falsely convicted people, including those convicted by eyewitness testimony.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects about the article?', 'To learn more, you can visit http://www.innocenceproject.org.']
["What do you think you'll learn about Elizabeth Loftus?", 'Cognitive psychologist Elizabeth Loftus has conducted extensive research on memory.']
['What else did she research?', 'She has studied false memories as well as recovered memories of childhood sexual abuse.']

['What did Loftus also develop?', 'Loftus also developed the misinformation effect paradigm, which holds that after exposure to additional and possibly inaccurate information, a person may misremember the original event.']
['What is the misinformation effect?', 'According to Loftus, an eyewitness’s memory of an event is very flexible due to the misinformation effect.']
['How did he test this theory?', 'To test this theory, Loftus and John Palmer (1974) asked 45 U.S. college students to estimate the speed of cars using different forms of questions.']
['What else did they test?', 'The participants were shown films of car accidents and were asked to play the role of the eyewitness and describe what happened.']
['What was the question to them?', 'They were asked, “About how fast were the cars going when they (smashed, collided, bumped, hit, contacted) each other?”']
['What were the results of the experiment?', 'The participants estimated the speed of the cars based on the verb used.']
['What was the result of our study?', 'Participants who heard the word “smashed” estimated that the cars were traveling at a much higher speed than participants who heard the word “contacted.”']

['What was the effect of the verb they heard on the participants’ memory of the accident?', 'The implied information about speed, based on the verb they heard, had an effect on the participants’ memory of the accident.']
['What else do you think will help us understand this effect?', 'In a follow-up one week later, participants were asked if they saw any broken glass (none was shown in the accident pictures).']
['What did the follow-up reveal?', 'Participants who had been in the “smashed” group were more than twice as likely to indicate that they did remember seeing glass.']

['Why did they think they saw broken glass?', 'Loftus and Palmer demonstrated that a leading question encouraged them to not only remember the cars were going faster, but to also falsely remember that they saw broken glass.']
['What are the controversies about the recollection of events?', 'Other researchers have described how whole events, not just words, can be falsely recalled, even when they did not happen.']

['Who else supports this?', 'The idea that memories of traumatic events could be repressed has been a theme in the field of psychology, beginning with Sigmund Freud, and the controversy surrounding the idea continues today.']
['What is false memory syndrome?', 'Recall of false autobiographical memories is called false memory syndrome.']

['What happened in the article that caused this?', 'This syndrome has received a lot of publicity, particularly as it relates to memories of events that do not have independent witnesses—often the only witnesses to the abuse are the perpetrator and the victim (e.g., sexual abuse).']
['What are the different sides of the debate?', 'On one side of the debate are those who have recovered memories of childhood abuse years after it occurred.']

['What do these researchers argue?', 'These researchers argue that some children’s experiences have been so traumatizing and distressing that they must lock those memories away in order to lead some semblance of a normal life.']

['Are there any other points made in the debate?', 'They believe that repressed memories can be locked away for decades and later recalled intact through hypnosis and guided imagery techniques (Devilly, 2007).']
['What was revealed in this study?', 'Research suggests that having no memory of childhood sexual abuse is quite common in adults.']

['What else did the study say about memory?', 'For instance, one large-scale study conducted by John Briere and Jon Conte (1993) revealed that 59% of 450 men and women who were receiving treatment for sexual abuse that had occurred before age 18 had forgotten their experiences.']
['What was the most important insight?', 'Ross Cheit (2007) suggested that repressing these memories created psychological distress in adulthood.']

['What was the Recovered Memory Project?', 'The Recovered Memory Project was created so that victims of childhood sexual abuse can recall these memories and allow the healing process to begin (Cheit, 2007; Devilly, 2007).']

['What does Loftus challenge?', 'Loftus is not saying that childhood sexual abuse doesn’t happen, but she does question whether or not those memories are accurate, and she is skeptical of the questioning process used to access these memories, given that even the slightest suggestion from the therapist can lead to misinformation effects.']

['What are some examples of questioning process used?', 'For example, researchers Stephen Ceci and Maggie Brucks (1993, 1995) asked three-year-old children to use an anatomically correct doll to show where their pediatricians had touched them during an exam.']
['What did the children do?', 'Fifty-five percent of the children pointed to the genital/anal area on the dolls, even when they had not received any form of genital exam.']

['What is the challenge of Loftus?', 'Ever since Loftus published her first studies on the suggestibility of eyewitness testimony in the 1970s, social scientists, police officers, therapists, and legal practitioners have been aware of the flaws in interview practices.']
['What has been done to decrease suggestibility of witnesses?', 'Consequently, steps have been taken to decrease suggestibility of witnesses.']
['What is one way to make sure witnesses are truthful?', 'One way is to modify how witnesses are questioned.']

['Why use less leading language?', 'When interviewers use neutral and less leading language, children more accurately recall what happened and who was involved (Goodman, 2006; Pipe, 1996; Pipe, Lamb, Orbach, & Esplin, 2004).']
['What else has been done to decrease suggestibility?', 'Another change is in how police lineups are conducted.']
['What would be the best way to do a blind photo lineup?', 'It’s recommended that a blind photo lineup be used.']
['Why would a police officer use a photo lineup?', 'This way the person administering the lineup doesn’t know which photo belongs to the suspect, minimizing the possibility of giving leading cues.']
['What other ways to decrease suggestibility have been tried?', 'Additionally, judges in some states now inform jurors about the possibility of misidentification.']
['What other changes have been made?', 'Judges can also suppress eyewitness testimony if they deem it unreliable.']

['What did you find most interesting in your reading?', 'To answer this question, we will look at several perspectives on forgetting.']

['What is the main idea of Memory Errors?', 'Psychologist Daniel Schacter (2001), a well-known memory researcher, offers seven ways our memories fail us.']

['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Let’s look at the first sin of the forgetting errors: transience, which means that memories can fade over time.']

['What does Nathan wonder if his mother actually read the book?', 'Nathan wonders if his mother actually read the book, and his mother is surprised she can’t recall the plot.']

['When was the process of memorization analyzed?', 'In 1885, German psychologist Hermann Ebbinghaus analyzed the process of memorization.']
['What did he memorize first?', 'First, he memorized lists of nonsense syllables.']
['What did he do after his lists were memorized?', 'Then he measured how much he learned (retained) when he attempted to relearn each list.']
['How long did he test himself for?', 'He tested himself over different periods of time from 20 minutes later to 30 days later.']
['What was the result of the testing?', 'The result is his famous forgetting curve.']

['What is the storage decay?', 'Due to storage decay, an average person will lose 50% of the memorized information after 20 minutes and 70% of the information after 24 hours (Ebbinghaus, 1885/1964).']
['What happens to your memory when you learn something new?', 'Your memory for new information decays quickly and then eventually levels out.']
['What do you think about the passage?', 'You probably answered yes to at least one, if not all, of these examples—but don’t worry, you are not alone.']

['What is the term for lapses in memory caused by breaks in attention or our focus being somewhere else?', 'We are all prone to committing the memory error known as absentmindedness, which describes lapses in memory caused by breaks in attention or our focus being somewhere else.']
['What is the main concept of our assignment?', '“I just streamed this movie called Oblivion, and it had that famous actor in it.']
['What movies has that actor been in?', 'He’s been in all of those movies, like The Shawshank Redemption and The Dark Knight trilogy.']

['What are the three errors of distortion?', 'Now let’s take a look at the three errors of distortion: misattribution, suggestibility, and bias.']

['how do we improve memory?', 'In this section, we’ll look at some ways to help you remember better, and at some strategies for more effective studying.']
['What are these strategies?', 'To help make sure information goes from short-term memory to long-term memory, you can use memory-enhancing strategies.']
['What is one of those strategies?', 'One strategy is rehearsal, or the conscious repetition of information to be remembered (Craik & Watkins, 1973).']
['How can you use rehearsal to learn multiplication tables?', 'Think about how you learned your multiplication tables as a child.']
['What are some examples of these?', 'You may recall that 6 x 6 = 36, 6 x 7 = 42, and 6 x 8 = 48.']
['What is the best way to memorize these facts?', 'Memorizing these facts is rehearsal.']
["What is one of the strategies we'll be studying?", 'Another strategy is chunking: you organize information into manageable bits or chunks (Bodie, Powers, & Fitch-Hauser, 2006).']
['What is the best way to remember information?', 'Chunking is useful when trying to remember information like dates and phone numbers.']
['How does chunking work with phone numbers?', 'Instead of trying to remember 5205550467, you remember the number as 520-555-0467.']

['How is rehearsal strategy related to this?', 'So, if you met an interesting person at a party and you wanted to remember his phone number, you would naturally chunk it, and you could repeat the number over and over, which is the rehearsal strategy.']

['What is elaborative rehearsal?', 'You could also enhance memory by using elaborative rehearsal: a technique in which you think about the meaning of new information and its relation to knowledge already stored in your memory (Tigner, 1999).']
['What does Elaborative Rehearsal involve?', 'Elaborative rehearsal involves both linking the information to knowledge already stored and repeating the information.']
['What could be an example of this?', 'For example, in this case, you could remember that 520 is an area code for Arizona and the person you met is from Arizona.']

['What are mnemonic devices?', 'Mnemonic devices are memory aids that help us organize information for encoding.']

['What can you do to help you remember the material?', 'Relate the material to something you have already learned for another class, or think how you can apply the concepts to your own life.']
['What is the best way to remember the passage?', 'When you do this, you are building a web of retrieval cues that will help you access the material when you want to remember it.']
['What is the best way to learn the passage?', 'Use distributed practice: Study across time in short durations rather than trying to cram it all in at once.']
['Why does studying across time make sense?', 'Memory consolidation takes time, and studying across time allows time for memories to consolidate.']

['What else did he mention?', 'In addition, cramming can cause the links between concepts to become so active that you get stuck in a link, and it prevents you from accessing the rest of the information that you learned.']
['What is the best way to learn the passage?', 'Rehearse, rehearse, rehearse: Review the material over time, in spaced and organized study sessions.']
['What is the best way to learn this passage?', 'Organize and study your notes, and take practice quizzes/exams.']
['What can you do to help you remember the information?', 'Link the new information to other information you already know well.']

['What was the main idea of the passage?', 'Study efficiently: Students are great highlighters, but highlighting is not very efficient because students spend too much time studying the things they already learned.']
['What can you do instead of highlighting?', 'Instead of highlighting, use index cards.']
['What is the best way to study?', 'When you study, separate your cards into those you got right and those you got wrong.']
['What should you do with those cards?', 'Study the ones you got wrong and keep sorting.']
['How many cards does that cover?', 'Eventually, all your cards will be in the pile you answered correctly.']
['What else did he say?', 'Be aware of interference:']

['when you study, it is important to prevent interference from the things that can cause your brain to', 'To reduce the likelihood of interference, study during a quiet time without interruptions or distractions (like television or music).']
['What is mentioned in the passage?', 'Keep moving:']
['What can keep you mentally sharp and active?', 'Research suggests that regular aerobic exercise (anything that gets your heart rate elevated) is beneficial for memory (van Praag, 2008).']
['What does aerobic exercise promote?', 'Aerobic exercise promotes neurogenesis: the growth of new brain cells in the hippocampus, an area of the brain known to play a role in memory and learning.']
['What is mentioned in the passage?', 'Get enough sleep:']
['Why do you need to get enough sleep?', 'While you are sleeping, your brain is still at work.']
['What does the brain do during sleep?', 'During sleep the brain organizes and consolidates information to be stored in long-term memory (Abel & Bäuml, 2013).']
['What else can you do to help remember the passage?', 'Make use of mnemonic devices:']
['What is a mnemonic device?', 'As you learned earlier in this chapter, mnemonic devices often help us to remember and recall information.']
['What are some examples of mnemonic devices?', 'There are different types of mnemonic devices, such as the acronym.']
['What is an acronym?', 'An acronym is a word formed by the first letter of each of the words you want to remember.']
