['What is an example of a good acronym?', 'For example, even if you live near one, you might have difficulty recalling the names of all five Great Lakes.']
['What is the acronym for the five Great Lakes?', 'HOMES is an acronym that represents Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie, and Superior: the five Great Lakes.']
['what other type of mnemonic devices are there?', 'Another type of mnemonic device is an acrostic: you make a phrase of all the first letters of the words.']

['What are some examples of acrostics?', 'For example, if you are taking a math test and you are having difficulty remembering the order of operations, recalling the following sentence will help you: “Please Excuse My Dear Aunt Sally,” because the order of mathematical operations is Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication, Division, Addition, Subtraction.']
['what else does it remember?', 'There also are jingles, which are rhyming tunes that contain key words related to the concept, such as i before e, except after c.']
['What did you learn from the poem?', 'In this poem, William Wordsworth writes, “the child is father of the man.”']
['What is he trying to tell us with this phrase?', 'Wordsworth might be suggesting that the person he is as an adult depends largely on the experiences he had in childhood.']
['What was the poem about?', 'Consider the following questions:']

["What are some of the questions we'll be studying today?", 'These are the types of questions developmental psychologists try to answer, by studying how humans change and grow from conception through childhood, adolescence, adulthood, and death.']

['What does lifespan development mean?', 'They view development as a lifelong process that can be studied scientifically across three developmental domains—physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development.']
['What is physical development?', 'Physical development involves growth and changes in the body and brain, the senses, motor skills, and health and wellness.']
['What is cognitive development?', 'Cognitive development involves learning, attention, memory, language, thinking, reasoning, and creativity.']
['What is the development of emotions, personality, and social relationships?', 'Psychosocial development involves emotions, personality, and social relationships.']
['What other topics do we refer to throughout the chapter?', 'We refer to these domains throughout the chapter.']
['What is the normative approach to development?', 'Across these three domains—physical, cognitive, and psychosocial—the normative approach to development is also discussed.']
['What is the normative approach to development?', 'This approach asks, “What is normal development?”']

['What do psychologists determine when is normative?', 'In the early decades of the 20th century, normative psychologists studied large numbers of children at various ages to determine norms (i.e., average ages) of when most children reach specific developmental milestones in each of the three domains (Gesell, 1933, 1939, 1940; Gesell & Ilg, 1946; Hall, 1904).']

['What else is covered in the text?', 'Although children develop at slightly different rates, we can use these age-related averages as general guidelines to compare children with same-age peers to determine the approximate ages they should reach specific normative events called developmental milestones (e.g., crawling, walking, writing, dressing, naming colors, speaking in sentences, and starting puberty).']
['What kind of normative events are there?', 'Not all normative events are universal, meaning they are not experienced by all individuals across all cultures.']

['What kind of milestones are universal?', 'Biological milestones, such as puberty, tend to be universal, but social milestones, such as the age when children begin formal schooling, are not necessarily universal; instead, they affect most individuals in a particular culture (Gesell & Ilg, 1946).']

["What's the age children begin formal schooling?", 'For example, in developed countries children begin school around 5 or 6 years old, but in developing countries, like Nigeria, children often enter school at an advanced age, if at all (Huebler, 2005; United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization [UNESCO], 2013).']
['What is the normative approach?', 'To better understand the normative approach, imagine two new mothers, Louisa and Kimberly, who are close friends and have children around the same age.']
['What is the age of the child?', 'Louisa’s daughter is 14 months old, and Kimberly’s son is 12 months old.']
['What can you tell me about the normative approach?', 'According to the normative approach, the average age a child starts to walk is 12 months.']
["What happened to Louisa's daughter?", 'However, at 14 months Louisa’s daughter still isn’t walking.']
['What does Louisa do?', 'She tells Kimberly she is worried that something might be wrong with her baby.']
['What does Kimberly do?', 'Kimberly is surprised because her son started walking when he was only 10 months old.']
['What are different theoretical approaches regarding human development?', 'There are many different theoretical approaches regarding human development.']

['what else is important?', 'As we evaluate them in this chapter, recall that developmental psychology focuses on how people change, and keep in mind that all the approaches that we present in this chapter address questions of change:']
['What is the content of our study material?', 'Continuous development views development as a cumulative process, gradually improving on existing skills.']
['What is the benefit of this type of development?', 'With this type of development, there is gradual change.']
['What are some examples of continuous development?', 'Consider, for example, a child’s physical growth: adding inches to height year by year.']
['What does the opposite type of development believe?', 'In contrast, theorists who view development as discontinuous believe that development takes place in unique stages:']
['What does the second type of development believe?', 'It occurs at specific times or ages.']

['What is the difference between continuous development and episodic development?', 'With this type of development, the change is more sudden, such as an infant’s ability to conceive object permanence.']
['What does stage theory hold?', 'Stage theories hold that the sequence of development is universal.']

['how does it claim to be universal?', 'For example, in cross-cultural studies of language development, children from around the world reach language milestones in a similar sequence (Gleitman & Newport, 1995).']
['What are universal concepts mentioned?', 'Infants in all cultures coo before they babble.']
['What is universal about the developmental timeline?', 'They begin babbling at about the same age and utter their first word around 12 months old.']
['How does the universal timeline correlate to different cultures?', 'Yet we live in diverse contexts that have a unique effect on each of us.']
['Did the stage theory have any side effects?', 'For example, researchers once believed that motor development follows one course for all children regardless of culture.']

['what else is universal about motor development?', 'However, child care practices vary by culture, and different practices have been found to accelerate or inhibit achievement of developmental milestones such as sitting, crawling, and walking (Karasik, Adolph, Tamis-LeMonda, & Bornstein, 2010).']
['What can you find this document online?', 'For instance, let’s look at the Aché society in Paraguay.']
['What are they known for?', 'They spend a significant amount of time foraging in forests.']
['What do they do while foraging?', 'While foraging, Aché mothers carry their young children, rarely putting them down in order to protect them from getting hurt in the forest.']
['What are the benefits of this?', 'Consequently, their children walk much later:']

['What is the difference between infants in Western cultures and infants in East Asia?', 'They walk around 23–25 months old, in comparison to infants in Western cultures who begin to walk around 12 months old.']

['How do they do this?', 'However, as Aché children become older, they are allowed more freedom to move about, and by about age 9, their motor skills surpass those of U.S. children of the same age: Aché children are able to climb trees up to 25 feet tall and use machetes to chop their way through the forest (Kaplan & Dove, 1987).']
['What is notable about their development?', 'As you can see, our development is influenced by multiple contexts, so the timing of basic motor functions may vary across cultures.']
['How do these vary?', 'However, the functions themselves are present in all societies.']
['What is the longstanding question?', 'This longstanding question is known in psychology as the nature versus nurture debate.']

['What is the nature versus nurture debate?', 'It seeks to understand how our personalities and traits are the product of our genetic makeup and biological factors, and how they are shaped by our environment, including our guardians, peers, and culture.']
['What are some traits that are inherited from our parents?', 'We are all born with specific genetic traits inherited from our parents, such as eye color, height, and certain personality traits.']
['What is the deep interaction?', 'Beyond our basic genotype, however, there is a deep interaction between our genes and our environment:']

['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Our unique experiences in our environment influence whether and how particular traits are expressed, and at the same time, our genes influence how we interact with our environment (Diamond, 2009; Lobo, 2008).']

['What is the reciprocal interaction?', 'This chapter will show that there is a reciprocal interaction between nature and nurture as they both shape who we become, but the debate continues as to the relative contributions of each.']
['What is the purpose of this document?', 'There are many theories regarding how babies and children grow and develop into happy, healthy adults.']
['What theories are explored in this section?', 'We explore several of these theories in this section.']
["What was Freud's belief about personality?", 'Sigmund Freud (1856–1939) believed that personality develops during early childhood.']
['What was he trying to achieve with this statement?', 'For Freud, childhood experiences shape our personalities and behavior as adults.']

['what else did he believe about development?', 'Freud viewed development as discontinuous; he believed that each of us must pass through a series of stages during childhood, and that if we lack proper nurturance and parenting during a stage, we may become stuck, or fixated, in that stage.']
['What were the stages of psychosexual development?', 'Freud’s stages are called the stages of psychosexual development.']

['what were the stages of psychosexual development?', 'According to Freud, children’s pleasure-seeking urges are focused on a different area of the body, called an erogenous zone, at each of the five stages of development: oral, anal, phallic, latency, and genital.']

['What is the most important information from this passage?', 'While most of Freud’s ideas have not found support in modern research, we cannot discount the contributions that Freud has made to the field of psychology.']

['What are some of the modern psychology ideas?', "Psychologists today dispute Freud's psychosexual stages as a legitimate explanation for how one's personality develops, but what we can take away from Freud’s theory is that personality is shaped, in some part, by experiences we have in childhood."]
['What are the stages of development discussed in this passage?', 'These stages are discussed in detail in the chapter on personality.']
['What is significant about this document?', 'Erik Erikson (1902–1994), another stage theorist, took Freud’s theory and modified it as psychosocial theory.']
['What is different about Erikson’s theory?', 'Erikson’s psychosocial development theory emphasizes the social nature of our development rather than its sexual nature.']
['What was his suggestion?', 'While Freud believed that personality is shaped only in childhood, Erikson proposed that personality development takes place all through the lifespan.']
['How do we interact with others?', 'Erikson suggested that how we interact with others is what affects our sense of self, or what he called the ego identity.']
['What did Erikson propose?', 'Erikson proposed that we are motivated by a need to achieve competence in certain areas of our lives.']
['What are the eight stages of development?', 'According to psychosocial theory, we experience eight stages of development over our lifespan, from infancy through late adulthood.']
['What is a conflict?', 'At each stage there is a conflict, or task, that we need to resolve.']
['What happens when you succeed?', 'Successful completion of each developmental task results in a sense of competence and a healthy personality.']
['What happens when you fail at something?', 'Failure to master these tasks leads to feelings of inadequacy.']
['Which of the following statements is true?', 'According to Erikson (1963), trust is the basis of our development during infancy (birth to 12 months).']
['How is trust created?', 'Therefore, the primary task of this stage is trust versus mistrust.']

['What can you tell me about trust?', 'Infants are dependent upon their caregivers, so caregivers who are responsive and sensitive to their infant’s needs help their baby to develop a sense of trust; their baby will see the world as a safe, predictable place.']
['How else is trust created?', 'Unresponsive caregivers who do not meet their baby’s needs can engender feelings of anxiety, fear, and mistrust; their baby may see the world as unpredictable.']
['What is the first element in the passage?', 'As toddlers (ages 1–3 years) begin to explore their world, they learn that they can control their actions and act on the environment to get results.']
['What is the next element?', 'They begin to show clear preferences for certain elements of the environment, such as food, toys, and clothing.']
['What is the main task of a toddler?', 'A toddler’s main task is to resolve the issue of autonomy versus shame and doubt, by working to establish independence.']
['What is the next element?', 'This is the “me do it” stage.']
['How can we observe this?', 'For example, we might observe a budding sense of autonomy in a 2-year-old child who wants to choose her clothes and dress herself.']
["What is significant about the girl's outfits?", 'Although her outfits might not be appropriate for the situation, her input in such basic decisions has an effect on her sense of independence.']

["What is the effect of a woman's environment on her?", 'If denied the opportunity to act on her environment, she may begin to doubt her abilities, which could lead to low self-esteem and feelings of shame.']

['What does this study say?', 'Once children reach the preschool stage (ages 3–6 years), they are capable of initiating activities and asserting control over their world through social interactions and play.']
['Why is this so important?', 'According to Erikson, preschool children must resolve the task of initiative versus guilt.']
['How can preschool children master this task?', 'By learning to plan and achieve goals while interacting with others, preschool children can master this task.']
['What will happen to those who do this?', 'Those who do will develop self-confidence and feel a sense of purpose.']
['What is the most important thing to remember about this section?', 'Those who are unsuccessful at this stage—with their initiative misfiring or stifled—may develop feelings of guilt.']
['What is the next item we should study?', 'During the elementary school stage (ages 7–11), children face the task of industry versus inferiority.']
['Why do children feel inferior?', 'Children begin to compare themselves to their peers to see how they measure up.']

['How do people feel when they measure up to others?', 'They either develop a sense of pride and accomplishment in their schoolwork, sports, social activities, and family life, or they feel inferior and inadequate when they don’t measure up.']
['What is the task of identity versus role confusion?', 'In adolescence (ages 12–18), children face the task of identity versus role confusion.']
['According to Erikson, an adolescent’s main task is developing a sense of self. How do they deal with that task?', 'According to Erikson, an adolescent’s main task is developing a sense of self.']
['What do adolescents struggle with?', 'Adolescents struggle with questions such as “Who am I?” and “What do I want to do with my life?”']
['How do adolescents deal with that confusion?', 'Along the way, most adolescents try on many different selves to see which ones fit.']

['What do adolescents who are successful at this stage have?', 'Adolescents who are successful at this stage have a strong sense of identity and are able to remain true to their beliefs and values in the face of problems and other people’s perspectives.']
["What happens if they can't do that?", 'These teens will have a weak sense of self and experience role confusion.']
['How does this affect them?', 'They are unsure of their identity and confused about the future.']
['What is the most important thing for us to learn from the passage?', 'People in early adulthood (i.e., 20s through early 40s) are concerned with intimacy versus isolation.']
['What is important in adolescence?', 'After we have developed a sense of self in adolescence, we are ready to share our life with others.']
['What did Erikson say about developing intimate relationships with others?', 'Erikson said that we must have a strong sense of self before developing intimate relationships with others.']

['What is important about developing a positive self-concept in adolescence?', 'Adults who do not develop a positive self-concept in adolescence may experience feelings of loneliness and emotional isolation.']
['How long does middle adulthood last?', 'When people reach their 40s, they enter the time known as middle adulthood, which extends to the mid-60s.']
['What is the social task of middle adulthood?', 'The social task of middle adulthood is generativity versus stagnation.']

['What does generativity involve?', 'Generativity involves finding your life’s work and contributing to the development of others, through activities such as volunteering, mentoring, and raising children.']

['What is the difference between generativity and stagnation?', 'Those who do not master this task may experience stagnation, having little connection with others and little interest in productivity and self-improvement.']
['what was late adulthood?', 'From the mid-60s to the end of life, we are in the period of development known as late adulthood.']
['What was Erikson’s task at this stage?', 'Erikson’s task at this stage is called integrity versus despair.']
['What was his theory?', 'He said that people in late adulthood reflect on their lives and feel either a sense of satisfaction or a sense of failure.']
['What does the author mean by integrity?', 'People who feel proud of their accomplishments feel a sense of integrity, and they can look back on their lives with few regrets.']

['What does he mean by "people who are not successful at this stage may feel as if their life has been wasted."?', 'However, people who are not successful at this stage may feel as if their life has been wasted.']
['What was lost?', 'They focus on what “would have,” “should have,” and “could have” been.']
['What did they feel about the end of their lives?', 'They face the end of their lives with feelings of bitterness, depression, and despair.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Table 9.1 summarizes the stages of Erikson’s theory.']
['Who studied childhood development?', 'Jean Piaget (1896–1980) is another stage theorist who studied childhood development.']
["What was Piaget's approach to development?", 'Instead of approaching development from a psychoanalytical or psychosocial perspective, Piaget focused on children’s cognitive growth.']
['What did he think about children?', 'He believed that thinking is a central aspect of development and that children are naturally inquisitive.']
['How is that?', 'However, he said that children do not think and reason like adults (Piaget, 1930, 1932).']

['What did he think about development?', 'His theory of cognitive development holds that our cognitive abilities develop through specific stages, which exemplifies the discontinuity approach to development.']
['What is the concept of discontinuity?', 'As we progress to a new stage, there is a distinct shift in how we think and reason.']
['What did Piaget say about schemata?', 'Piaget said that children develop schemata to help them understand the world.']
['What are schemata?', 'Schemata are concepts (mental models) that are used to help us categorize and interpret information.']
['What are examples of schemata?', 'By the time children have reached adulthood, they have created schemata for almost everything.']
['How do children adapt to new information?', 'When children learn new information, they adjust their schemata through two processes: assimilation and accommodation.']

['What is the second process?', 'First, they assimilate new information or experiences in terms of their current schemata: assimilation is when they take in information that is comparable to what they already know.']
['What is accommodation?', 'Accommodation describes when they change their schemata based on new information.']
['What happens to the children as they develop schemata?', 'This process continues as children interact with their environment.']
['What does cognitive theory have to do with developing language?', 'For example, 2-year-old Abdul learned the schema for dogs because his family has a Labrador retriever.']
['What did Abdul do with the dogs he learned about?', 'When Abdul sees other dogs in his picture books, he says, “Look mommy, dog!”']
['Does that mean he has made them into his schema?', 'Thus, he has assimilated them into his schema for dogs.']
['What does the dog schema include?', 'One day, Abdul sees a sheep for the first time and says, “Look mommy, dog!”']
['What does the theory have to do with this?', 'Having a basic schema that a dog is an animal with four legs and fur, Abdul thinks all furry, four-legged creatures are dogs.']

['What is important in how kids learn?', 'When Abdul’s mom tells him that the animal he sees is a sheep, not a dog, Abdul must accommodate his schema for dogs to include more information based on his new experiences.']
["What happens when the schema doesn't include all the information?", 'Abdul’s schema for dog was too broad, since not all furry, four-legged creatures are dogs.']
['What does the theory have to do with learning?', 'He now modifies his schema for dogs and forms a new one for sheep.']
['What is the cognitive theory of development?', 'Like Freud and Erikson, Piaget thought development unfolds in a series of stages approximately associated with age ranges.']
['What other stages does he propose?', 'He proposed a theory of cognitive development that unfolds in four stages: sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, and formal operational.']
['What is the first stage of development?', 'The first stage is the sensorimotor stage, which lasts from birth to about 2 years old.']
['What do children learn about the world through their senses and motor behavior?', 'During this stage, children learn about the world through their senses and motor behavior.']

['How do young children learn about objects?', 'Young children put objects in their mouths to see if the items are edible, and once they can grasp objects, they may shake or bang them to see if they make sounds.']

['What can they learn about object permanence?', 'Between 5 and 8 months old, the child develops object permanence, which is the understanding that even if something is out of sight, it still exists (Bogartz, Shinskey, & Schilling, 2000).']
['What do piaget say?', 'According to Piaget, young infants do not remember an object after it has been removed from sight.']

['What did Piaget study infants’ reactions when a toy was first shown to an infant and then hidden under a blanket?', 'Piaget studied infants’ reactions when a toy was first shown to an infant and then hidden under a blanket.']

['What happens when they do that?', 'Infants who had already developed object permanence would reach for the hidden toy, indicating that they knew it still existed, whereas infants who had not developed object permanence would appear confused.']

['What is the cognitive theory of development about?', 'In Piaget’s view, around the same time children develop object permanence, they also begin to exhibit stranger anxiety, which is a fear of unfamiliar people.']

['What is one of the things babies can do to show that they are afraid?', 'Babies may demonstrate this by crying and turning away from a stranger, by clinging to a caregiver, or by attempting to reach their arms toward familiar faces such as parents.']

['what makes the baby afraid?', 'Stranger anxiety results when a child is unable to assimilate the stranger into an existing schema; therefore, she can’t predict what her experience with that stranger will be like, which results in a fear response.']
['What is the second stage of Piaget’s theory?', 'Piaget’s second stage is the preoperational stage, which is from approximately 2 to 7 years old.']

['What are some things children in this stage engage in?', 'In this stage, children can use symbols to represent words, images, and ideas, which is why children in this stage engage in pretend play.']
['How does it affect their actions?', 'A child’s arms might become airplane wings as they zoom around the room, or a child with a stick might become a brave knight with a sword.']

['What are some other things kids engage in in the preoperational stage?', 'Children also begin to use language in the preoperational stage, but they cannot understand adult logic or mentally manipulate information (the term operational refers to logical manipulation of information, so children at this stage are considered to be pre-operational).']
['What is significant about this stage?', 'Children’s logic is based on their own personal knowledge of the world so far, rather than on conventional knowledge.']
['What are some examples of sharing?', 'For example, dad gave a slice of pizza to 10-year-old Keiko and another slice to her 3-year-old brother, Kenny.']
['What did Kenny do?', 'Kenny’s pizza slice was cut into five pieces, so Kenny told his sister that he got more pizza than she did.']

['What is the reason children in this stage cannot perform mental operations?', 'Children in this stage cannot perform mental operations because they have not developed an understanding of conservation, which is the idea that even if you change the appearance of something, it is still equal in size as long as nothing has been removed or added.']
['What are the examples of egocentrism?', 'During this stage, we also expect children to display egocentrism, which means that the child is not able to take the perspective of others.']
['What is interesting about this stage?', 'A child at this stage thinks that everyone sees, thinks, and feels just as they do.']
['Do you think Kenny and Keiko would be able to get along?', 'Let’s look at Kenny and Keiko again.']
['What does Kenny do?', 'Keiko’s birthday is coming up, so their mom takes Kenny to the toy store to choose a present for his sister.']
['What did Kenny do for his sister?', 'He selects an Iron Man action figure for her, thinking that if he likes the toy, his sister will too.']
['What happens to Kenny?', 'An egocentric child is not able to infer the perspective of other people and instead attributes his own perspective.']
['What is the third stage of Piaget’s theory?', 'Piaget’s third stage is the concrete operational stage, which occurs from about 7 to 11 years old.']
['What happens during this stage?', 'In this stage, children can think logically about real (concrete) events; they have a firm grasp on the use of numbers and start to employ memory strategies.']

['How do they use numbers?', 'They can perform mathematical operations and understand transformations, such as addition is the opposite of subtraction, and multiplication is the opposite of division.']
['What else does this stage have to do with numbers?', 'In this stage, children also master the concept of conservation: Even if something changes shape, its mass, volume, and number stay the same.']
['Why is that?', 'For example, if you pour water from a tall, thin glass to a short, fat glass, you still have the same amount of water.']

['what are some examples of the concrete operational stage also understand?', 'Children in the concrete operational stage also understand the principle of reversibility, which means that objects can be changed and then returned back to their original form or condition.']
['What are some examples of objects that can be changed and then returned back to their original form?', 'Take, for example, water that you poured into the short, fat glass:']
['What happens if the water is returned back to the fat glass?', 'You can pour water from the fat glass back to the thin glass and still have the same amount (minus a couple of drops).']
['What was the fourth stage in Piaget’s theory?', 'The fourth, and last, stage in Piaget’s theory is the formal operational stage, which is from about age 11 to adulthood.']

['what else did he write about the formal operational stage?', 'Whereas children in the concrete operational stage are able to think logically only about concrete events, children in the formal operational stage can also deal with abstract ideas and hypothetical situations.']
['What other topics did he discuss in this section?', 'Children in this stage can use abstract thinking to problem solve, look at alternative solutions, and test these solutions.']
['What else did he talk about in this section?', 'In adolescence, a renewed egocentrism occurs.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'For example, a 15-year-old with a very small pimple on her face might think it is huge and incredibly visible, under the mistaken impression that others must share her perceptions.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Thought.']

['what other theories have come under criticism?', 'As with other major contributors of theories of development, several of Piaget’s ideas have come under criticism based on the results of further research.']

['What is important about his theories?', 'For example, several contemporary studies support a model of development that is more continuous than Piaget’s discrete stages (Courage & Howe, 2002; Siegler, 2005, 2006).']
['Did he have any other theories?', 'Many others suggest that children reach cognitive milestones earlier than Piaget describes (Baillargeon, 2004; de Hevia & Spelke, 2010).']
['What is the highest level of cognitive development?', 'According to Piaget, the highest level of cognitive development is formal operational thought, which develops between 11 and 20 years old.']

['What other stages are there?', 'However, many developmental psychologists disagree with Piaget, suggesting a fifth stage of cognitive development, known as the postformal stage (Basseches, 1984; Commons & Bresette, 2006; Sinnott, 1998).']

['What is postformal thinking?', 'In postformal thinking, decisions are made based on situations and circumstances, and logic is integrated with emotion as adults develop principles that depend on contexts.']

['What are some of the differences between formal operational thought and postformal thinking?', 'One way that we can see the difference between an adult in postformal thought and an adolescent in formal operations is in terms of how they handle emotionally charged issues.']
['What is interesting about this paper?', 'It seems that once we reach adulthood our problem solving abilities change:']

['what else does the paper reveal?', 'As we attempt to solve problems, we tend to think more deeply about many areas of our lives, such as relationships, work, and politics (Labouvie-Vief & Diehl, 1999).']
['What do postformal thinkers do with their past?', 'Because of this, postformal thinkers are able to draw on past experiences to help them solve new problems.']
['What did the paper reveal?', 'Problem-solving strategies using postformal thought vary, depending on the situation.']

['What does it depend on?', 'Adults can recognize, for example, that what seems to be an ideal solution to a problem at work involving a disagreement with a colleague may not be the best solution to a disagreement with a significant other.']
["What was Lev Vygotsky's occupation?", 'Lev Vygotsky was a Russian psychologist who proposed a sociocultural theory of development.']
['What does sociocultural theory suggest?', 'He suggested that human development is rooted in one’s culture.']
['What is the basis for the formation of language and thought?', 'A child’s social world, for example, forms the basis for the formation of language and thought.']
['What is the influence of culture on people?', 'The language one speaks and the ways a person thinks about things is dependent on one’s cultural background.']
['What does Vygotsky consider historical influences as key to one’s development?', 'Vygotsky also considered historical influences as key to one’s development.']
['What was Steiner interested in?', 'He was interested in the process of development and the individual’s interactions with their environment (John-Steiner & Mahn, 1996).']
['What is the first task i should discuss?', 'A major task beginning in childhood and continuing into adolescence is discerning right from wrong.']
['Who is Lawrence Kohlberg?', 'Psychologist Lawrence Kohlberg (1927–1987) extended upon the foundation that Piaget built regarding cognitive development.']
['What did Kolberg believe?', 'Kohlberg believed that moral development, like cognitive development, follows a series of stages.']

['How did Kohlberg prove this?', 'To develop this theory, Kohlberg posed moral dilemmas to people of all ages, and then he analyzed their answers to find evidence of their particular stage of moral development.']

['what was the first task you should discuss?', "Before reading about the stages, take a minute to consider how you would answer one of Kohlberg's best-known moral dilemmas, commonly known as the Heinz dilemma:"]
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Kohlberg was not interested in whether you answer yes or no to the dilemma: Instead, he was interested in the reasoning behind your answer.']

['What was kohlberg reviewing people for?', 'After presenting people with this and various other moral dilemmas, Kohlberg reviewed people’s responses and placed them in different stages of moral reasoning.']

['How did the kohlberg review people work?', 'According to Kohlberg, an individual progresses from the capacity for pre-conventional morality (before age 9) to the capacity for conventional morality (early adolescence), and toward attaining post-conventional morality (once formal operational thought is attained), which only a few fully achieve.']

['What is the most important fact in this article?', 'Kohlberg placed in the highest stage responses that reflected the reasoning that Heinz should steal the drug because his wife’s life is more important than the pharmacist making money.']
['What can you tell me about the most important fact?', 'The value of a human life overrides the pharmacist’s greed.']

['What is important to realize?', 'It is important to realize that even those people who have the most sophisticated, post-conventional reasons for some choices may make other choices for the simplest of pre-conventional reasons.']

['What do psychologists believe about moral development?', "Many psychologists agree with Kohlberg's theory of moral development but point out that moral reasoning is very different from moral behavior."]
['What does this mean?', 'In other words, we might “talk the talk,” but not “walk the walk.”']
['What does Kohlberg feel about men moving past stage four in their moral development?', 'Kohlberg (1969) felt that more men than women move past stage four in their moral development.']
['What was his reasoning behind this?', 'He went on to note that women seem to be deficient in their moral reasoning abilities.']

["What were people's reactions to the ideas?", 'These ideas were not well received by Carol Gilligan, a research assistant of Kohlberg, who consequently developed her own ideas of moral development.']

['What was she doing in 1982?', 'In her groundbreaking book, In a Different Voice: Psychological Theory and Women’s Development, Gilligan (1982) criticized her former mentor’s theory because it was based only on upper class']
['What does this mean?', 'White men and boys.']
['What did she argue?', 'She argued that women are not deficient in their moral reasoning—she proposed that different genders reason differently.']
['What are some of the ways girls and women focus more on staying connected?', 'Girls and women focus more on staying connected and the importance of interpersonal relationships.']
['What was their reaction to the Heinz dilemma?', 'Therefore, in the Heinz dilemma, many girls and women respond that Heinz should not steal the medicine.']

['What was the reason for this?', 'Their reasoning is that if he steals the medicine, is arrested, and is put in jail, then he and his wife will be separated, and she could die while he is still in prison.']

['What is this about?', 'As discussed at the beginning of this chapter, developmental psychologists often divide our development into three areas: physical development, cognitive development, and psychosocial development.']
['What is the study divided into?', 'Mirroring Erikson’s stages, lifespan development is divided into different stages that are based on age.']
['What is this about?', 'We will discuss prenatal, infant, child, adolescent, and adult development.']
['What was the most interesting part of this document?', 'From beginning as a one-cell structure to your birth, your prenatal development occurred in an orderly and delicate sequence.']
['What are three stages of prenatal development?', 'There are three stages of prenatal development: germinal, embryonic, and fetal.']
['What happens to the developing baby in each of these stages?', 'Let’s take a look at what happens to the developing baby in each of these stages.']
['What is the Germinal Stage?', 'In the discussion of biopsychology earlier in the book, you learned about genetics and DNA.']
['How is DNA passed on?', 'DNA is passed on to the child at the moment of conception.']
['When does conception occur?', 'Conception occurs when sperm fertilizes an egg and forms a zygote.']
['What is a zygote?', 'A zygote begins as a one-cell structure that is created when a sperm and egg merge.']
['What is the genetic makeup of the zygote?', 'The genetic makeup and sex of the zygote are set at this point.']

['What happens during the first week of development?', 'During the first week after conception, the zygote divides and multiplies, going from a one-cell structure to two cells, then four cells, then eight cells, and so on.']
['What is the process of cell division called?', 'This process of cell division is called mitosis.']
['What happens if mitosis is not successful?', 'Mitosis is a fragile process, and fewer than one-half of all zygotes survive beyond the first two weeks (Hall, 2004).']
['What happens if successful?', 'After 5 days of mitosis there are 100 cells, and after 9 months there are billions of cells.']
['What happens after that point?', 'As the cells divide, they become more specialized, forming different organs and body parts.']
['What happens during the germinal stage?', 'In the germinal stage, the mass of cells has yet to attach itself to the lining of the mother’s uterus.']
['Does it attach to the lining?', 'Once it does, the next stage begins.']
['What happens at week 3?', 'After the zygote divides for about 7–10 days and has 150 cells, it travels down the fallopian tubes and implants itself in the lining of the uterus.']
['What does the implant become?', 'Upon implantation, this multi-cellular organism is called an embryo.']
['What do they develop?', 'Now blood vessels grow, forming the placenta.']
['What is the placenta?', 'The placenta is a structure connected to the uterus that provides nourishment and oxygen from the mother to the developing embryo via the umbilical cord.']
['What happens to the basic structures of the embryo?', 'Basic structures of the embryo start to develop into areas that will become the head, chest, and abdomen.']
['What happens at week 4?', 'During the embryonic stage, the heart begins to beat and organs form and begin to function.']
['What happens at week 5?', 'The neural tube forms along the back of the embryo, developing into the spinal cord and brain.']
['What happens to the fetus at 9 weeks?', 'When the organism is about nine weeks old, the embryo is called a fetus.']
['What else happens at nine weeks?', 'At this stage, the fetus is about the size of a kidney bean and begins to take on the recognizable form of a human being as the “tail” begins to disappear.']
['What happens in week 9?', 'From 9–12 weeks, the sex organs begin to differentiate.']
['What happens in weeks 16 & 17?', 'At about 16 weeks, the fetus is approximately 4.5 inches long.']
['What happens in week 17?', 'Fingers and toes are fully developed, and fingerprints are visible.']
['What happens in week 18?', 'By the time the fetus reaches the sixth month of development (24 weeks), it weighs up to 1.4 pounds.']
['What happens in week 19?', 'Hearing has developed, so the fetus can respond to sounds.']

['What happens in week 20 of pregnancy?', 'The internal organs, such as the lungs, heart, stomach, and intestines, have formed enough that a fetus born prematurely at this point has a chance to survive outside of the mother’s womb.']
['What happens in week 21?', 'Throughout the fetal stage the brain continues to grow and develop, nearly doubling in size from weeks 16 to 28.']
['What happens in week 30?', 'Around 36 weeks, the fetus is almost ready for birth.']

['What happens in week 37?', 'It weighs about 6 pounds and is about 18.5 inches long, and by week 37 all of the fetus’s organ systems are developed enough that it could survive outside the uterus without many of the risks associated with premature birth.']
['What happens in week 38?', 'The fetus continues to gain weight and grow in length until approximately 40 weeks.']
['What happens in week 40?', 'By then, the fetus has very little room to move around and birth becomes imminent.']
['What happens in week 43?', 'The progression through the stages is shown in Figure 9.8.']
['What does that mean?', 'During each prenatal stage, genetic and environmental factors can affect development.']
['What is the prenatal stage?', 'The developing fetus is completely dependent on the mother for life.']

['What does it mean to receive prenatal care?', 'It is important that the mother takes good care of herself and receives prenatal care, which is medical care during pregnancy that monitors the health of both the mother and the fetus.']

['Why is it important?', 'According to the National Institutes of Health ([NIH], 2013), routine prenatal care is important because it can reduce the risk of complications to the mother and fetus during pregnancy.']
['What can be done to prevent pregnancy?', 'In fact, women who are trying to become pregnant or who may become pregnant should discuss pregnancy planning with their doctor.']

['What may be advised to pregnant women?', 'They may be advised, for example, to take a vitamin containing folic acid, which helps prevent certain birth defects, or to monitor aspects of their diet or exercise routines.']
['What do you recall about the study material?', 'Recall that when the zygote attaches to the wall of the mother’s uterus, the placenta is formed.']
['What happens to the placenta during pregnancy?', 'The placenta provides nourishment and oxygen to the fetus.']

['What else happens with the placenta?', 'Most everything the mother ingests, including food, liquid, and even medication, travels through the placenta to the fetus, hence the common phrase “eating for two.”']
['What can happen to the fetus?', 'Anything the mother is exposed to in the environment affects the fetus; if the mother is exposed to something harmful, the child can show life-long effects.']
['What is the definition of a teratogen?', 'A teratogen is any environmental agent—biological, chemical, or physical—that causes damage to the developing embryo or fetus.']
['What are the different types of teratogens?', 'There are different types of teratogens.']
['What are some examples of drugs that cross the placenta?', 'Alcohol and most drugs cross the placenta and affect the fetus.']
['What is safe for pregnant women to consume?', 'Alcohol is not safe to drink in any amount during pregnancy.']

['What is the leading preventable cause of intellectual disabilities in children in the United States?', 'Alcohol use during pregnancy has been found to be the leading preventable cause of intellectual disabilities in children in the United States (Maier & West, 2001).']

['What is the maximum amount of alcohol a pregnant woman can consume?', 'Excessive maternal drinking while pregnant can cause fetal alcohol spectrum disorders with life-long consequences for the child ranging in severity from minor to major.']

['What is the term for a collection of birth defects associated with heavy consumption of alcohol during pregnancy?', 'Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) are a collection of birth defects associated with heavy consumption of alcohol during pregnancy.']
['What are some physical signs of FASD?', 'Physically, children with FASD may have a small head size and abnormal facial features.']
['What does it look like when children have poor judgment?', 'Cognitively, these children may have poor judgment, poor impulse control, higher rates of ADHD, learning issues, and lower IQ scores.']
['Is there a cure for autism?', 'These developmental problems and delays persist into adulthood (Streissguth et al., 2004).']

["Can a person's reaction be reversed?", "Based on studies conducted on animals, it also has been suggested that a parent's alcohol consumption during pregnancy may predispose their child to like alcohol (Youngentob et al., 2007)."]
['What is the main topic of the passage?', 'Smoking is also considered a teratogen because nicotine travels through the placenta to the fetus.']
['What can smoking do to a baby?', 'When the mother smokes, the developing baby experiences a reduction in blood oxygen levels.']

['What else can smoking cause?', 'According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (2013), smoking while pregnant can result in premature birth, low-birth-weight infants, stillbirth, and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).']
['What other drugs are teratogens?', 'Heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine, almost all prescription medicines, and most over-the counter medications are also considered teratogens.']
['Are they harmful for the babies?', 'Babies born with a heroin addiction need heroin just like an adult addict.']
['What happens when babies are exposed to heroin?', 'The child will need to be gradually weaned from the heroin under medical supervision; otherwise, the child could have seizures and die.']
['What other things are known as teratogens?', 'Other teratogens include radiation, viruses such as HIV and herpes, and rubella (German measles).']

['Are there any vaccines that protect against rubella?', 'Women in the United States are much less likely to be afflicted with rubella because most women received childhood immunizations or vaccinations that protect the body from disease.']
['What are the sensitive periods of a pregnancy?', 'Each organ of the fetus develops during a specific period in the pregnancy, called the critical or sensitive period.']

['what are facial characteristics associated with fetal alcohol syndrome?', 'For example, research with primate models of FASD has demonstrated that the time during which a developing fetus is exposed to alcohol can dramatically affect the appearance of facial characteristics associated with fetal alcohol syndrome.']

['how long does alcohol exposure lead to facial abnormalities?', 'Specifically, this research suggests that alcohol exposure that is limited to day 19 or 20 of gestation can lead to significant facial abnormalities in the offspring (Ashley, Magnuson, Omnell, & Clarren, 1999).']

['What is the most sensitive period of the brain?', 'Given regions of the brain also show sensitive periods during which they are most susceptible to the teratogenic effects of alcohol (Tran & Kelly, 2003).']
['How much does the average newborn weigh?', 'The average newborn weighs approximately 7.5 pounds.']

['Why are newborns not completely helpless?', 'Although small, newborns are not completely helpless because their reflexes and sensory capacities help them interact with the environment from the moment of birth.']
['What are some examples of newborn reflexes?', 'All healthy babies are born with newborn reflexes: inborn automatic responses to particular forms of stimulation.']
['What is one of the most important things that newborns have?', 'Reflexes help the newborn survive until it is capable of more complex behaviors—these reflexes are crucial to survival.']
['What type of babies have newborn reflexes?', 'They are present in babies whose brains are developing normally and usually disappear around 4–5 months old.']
['How are newborn reflexes important for survival?', 'Let’s take a look at some of these newborn reflexes.']
['What is the rooting reflex?', 'The rooting reflex is the newborn’s response to anything that touches their cheek:']
['What happens to the baby?', 'When you stroke a baby’s cheek, the baby naturally turns the head in that direction and begins to suck.']
['What is the automatic, unlearned, sucking motions that infants do with their mouths?', 'The sucking reflex is the automatic, unlearned, sucking motions that infants do with their mouths.']
['What do newborns need to suck?', 'Several other interesting newborn reflexes can be observed.']
['What is grasping reflex?', 'For instance, if you put your finger into a newborn’s hand, you will witness the grasping reflex, in which a baby automatically grasps anything that touches the palms.']
['What is the Moro reflex?', 'The Moro reflex is the newborn’s response to the sensation of falling.']
['How does the baby respond to falling?', 'The baby spreads the arms, pulls them back in, and then (usually) cries.']
['What is significant about newborn infants’ sensory abilities?', 'Newborn infants’ sensory abilities are significant, but their senses are not yet fully developed.']
['What are the preferred things for newborns?', 'Many of a newborn’s innate preferences facilitate interaction with caregivers and other humans.']
['What is the least developed sense?', 'Although vision is their least developed sense, newborns already show a preference for faces.']

['what are some more interesting facts?', 'Babies who are just a few days old also prefer human voices, they will listen to voices longer than sounds that do not involve speech (Vouloumanos & Werker, 2004), and they seem to prefer their mother’s voice over a stranger’s voice (Mills & Melhuish, 1974).']
['What was the experiment?', 'In an interesting experiment, 3-week-old babies were given pacifiers that played a recording of the infant’s mother’s voice and of a stranger’s voice.']
['how did the babies respond?', 'When the infants heard their mother’s voice, they sucked more strongly at the pacifier (Mills & Melhuish, 1974).']
['Did they have any other preferences?', 'Newborns also have a strong sense of smell.']
['What does that mean?', 'For instance, newborn babies can distinguish the smell of their own mother from that of others.']
['What did MacFarlane (1978) find?', 'In a study by MacFarlane (1978), 1-week-old babies who were being breastfed were placed between two gauze pads.']
['What were the gauze pads used for?', 'One gauze pad was from the bra of a nursing mother who was a stranger, and the other gauze pad was from the bra of the infant’s own mother.']
['How did the babies react?', 'More than two-thirds of the week-old babies turned toward the gauze pad with their mother’s scent.']
['What is important about physical development?', 'In infancy, toddlerhood, and early childhood, the body’s physical development is rapid.']
['What is one example of how physical development is rapid?', 'On average, newborns weigh between 5 and 10 pounds, and a newborn’s weight typically doubles in six months and triples in one year.']
['What is one of the other examples of rapid physical development?', 'By 2 years old the weight will have quadrupled, so we can expect that a 2 year old should weigh between 20 and 40 pounds.']
['How about length?', 'The average length of a newborn is 19.5 inches, increasing to 29.5 inches by 12 months and 34.4 inches by 2 years old (WHO Multicentre Growth Reference Study Group, 2006).']
['What is steady rate?', 'During infancy and childhood, growth does not occur at a steady rate (Carel, Lahlou, Roger, & Chaussain, 2004).']
['How does this affect children?', 'Growth slows between 4 and 6 years old: During this time children gain 5–7 pounds and grow about 2–3 inches per year.']
['What happens to the growth rate of females?', 'Once females reach 8–9 years old, their growth rate outpaces that of males due to a pubertal growth spurt.']
['What does the growth spurt do?', 'This growth spurt continues until around 12 years old, coinciding with the start of the menstrual cycle.']
['What are the averages of how much children weigh?', 'By 10 years old, the average female weighs 88 pounds, and the average male weighs 85 pounds.']
['What is the current scientific understanding of physical development?', 'It was previously believed that we are born with all of the brain cells we will ever have.']
['What was the theory behind this?', 'More recent research suggests that neurogenesis (the formation of neurons) can continue through adulthood.']

['How does this work?', 'However, the vast majority of neural connections and pathways occur during the first few years of a child’s life (National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, 2019).']
['What is blooming?', 'This period of rapid neural growth is called blooming.']
['What is important about blooming?', 'Neural pathways continue to develop through puberty.']
['What happens after blooming?', 'The blooming period of neural growth is then followed by a period of pruning, where neural connections are reduced.']
['Why does pruning happen?', 'It is thought that pruning causes the brain to function more efficiently, allowing for mastery of more complex skills (Hutchinson, 2011).']

['What is the difference between blooming and pruning?', 'Blooming occurs during the first few years of life, and pruning continues through childhood and into adolescence in various areas of the brain.']
['What do you find interesting about the content of the document?', 'The size of our brains increases rapidly.']
['What else does this say?', 'For example, the brain of a 2-year-old is 55% of its adult size, and by 6 years old the brain is about 90% of its adult size (Tanner, 1978).']
['When do the frontal lobes grow rapidly?', 'During early childhood (ages 3–6), the frontal lobes grow rapidly.']

['What are the frontal lobes associated with?', 'Recalling our discussion of the 4 lobes of the brain earlier in this book, the frontal lobes are associated with planning, reasoning, memory, and impulse control.']
['What does this mean?', 'Therefore, by the time children reach school age, they are developmentally capable of controlling their attention and behavior.']
['What is the name of the part of the brain that grows in size?', 'Through the elementary school years, the frontal, temporal, occipital, and parietal lobes all grow in size.']

['What does this mean?', 'The brain growth spurts experienced in childhood tend to follow Piaget’s sequence of cognitive development, so that significant changes in neural functioning account for cognitive advances (Kolb & Whishaw, 2009; Overman, Bachevalier, Turner, & Peuster, 1992).']

['What does motor development occur in an orderly sequence as infants move from reflexive reactions (e.g., sucking and rooting) to more advanced motor functioning?', 'Motor development occurs in an orderly sequence as infants move from reflexive reactions (e.g., sucking and rooting) to more advanced motor functioning.']

["What is the orderly sequence of a baby's development?", 'For instance, babies first learn to hold their heads up, then to sit with assistance, and then to sit unassisted, followed later by crawling and then walking.']
['What are motor skills?', 'Motor skills refer to our ability to move our bodies and manipulate objects.']

['What are fine motor skills?', 'Fine motor skills focus on the muscles in our fingers, toes, and eyes, and enable coordination of small actions (e.g., grasping a toy, writing with a pencil, and using a spoon).']
['What are gross motor skills?', 'Gross motor skills focus on large muscle groups that control our arms and legs and involve larger movements (e.g., balancing, running, and jumping).']
['What are some important aspects of the document?', 'As motor skills develop, there are certain developmental milestones that young children should achieve.']
['Are these age levels important?', 'For each milestone there is an average age, as well as a range of ages in which the milestone should be reached.']
['What are some examples of developmental milestones?', 'An example of a developmental milestone is sitting.']
['What age do babies sit alone?', 'On average, most babies sit alone at 7 months old.']
['What does sitting involve?', 'Sitting involves both coordination and muscle strength, and 90% of babies achieve this milestone between 5 and 9 months old.']
['Do these age levels have ranges?', 'In another example, babies on average are able to hold up their head at 6 weeks old, and 90% of babies achieve this between 3 weeks and 4 months old.']
['What can you tell me about delays?', 'If a baby is not holding up their head by 4 months old, they are showing a delay.']

['Are there other delays to note?', 'If the child is displaying delays on several milestones, that is reason for concern, and the parent or caregiver should discuss this with the child’s pediatrician.']
['What can you do to help a child with developmental delays?', 'Some developmental delays can be identified and addressed through early intervention.']
['What is the main subject of the passage?', 'In addition to rapid physical growth, young children also exhibit significant development of their cognitive abilities.']

['What is an example of a cognitive skill that develops slowly as a child matures and interacts with the environment?', 'Piaget thought that children’s ability to understand objects—such as learning that a rattle makes a noise when shaken—was a cognitive skill that develops slowly as a child matures and interacts with the environment.']
["What was the problem with Piaget's theory?", 'Today, developmental psychologists think Piaget was incorrect.']

['What does research show?', 'Researchers have found that even very young children understand objects and how they work long before they have experience with those objects (Baillargeon, 1987; Baillargeon, Li, Gertner, & Wu, 2011).']

['What study backs up this?', 'For example, children as young as 3 months old demonstrated knowledge of the properties of objects that they had only viewed and did not have prior experience with them.']
['What was an example of this?', 'In one study, 3-month-old infants were shown a truck rolling down a track and behind a screen.']
['What was the box used for?', 'The box, which appeared solid but was actually hollow, was placed next to the track.']
['Was the truck able to go through the box?', 'The truck rolled past the box as would be expected.']
['Did the infants know what the box was?', 'Then the box was placed on the track to block the path of the truck.']
['What happened when the truck was rolled down the track this time?', 'When the truck was rolled down the track this time, it continued unimpeded.']
['What did the infants do next?', 'The infants spent significantly more time looking at this impossible event.']
["What can we know about infants' understanding?", 'Baillargeon (1987) concluded that they knew solid objects cannot pass through each other.']

['Did he do anything else?', 'Baillargeon’s findings suggest that very young children have an understanding of objects and how they work, which Piaget (1954) would have said is beyond their cognitive abilities due to their limited experiences in the world.']
['What are some cognitive milestones that babies should reach?', 'Just as there are physical milestones that we expect children to reach, there are also cognitive milestones.']
['What are some cognitive milestones that babies should learn?', 'It is helpful to be aware of these milestones as children gain new abilities to think, problem solve, and communicate.']

['What are some examples of cognitive milestones?', 'For example, infants shake their head “no” around 6–9 months, and they respond to verbal requests to do things like “wave bye-bye” or “blow a kiss” around 9–12 months.']
['What other milestones do children need to reach?', 'We can expect children to grasp the concept that objects continue to exist even when they are not in sight by around 8 months old.']

['What do toddlers learn during this period?', 'Because toddlers (i.e., 12–24 months old) have mastered object permanence, they enjoy games like hide and seek, and they realize that when someone leaves the room they will come back (Loop, 2013).']
['What are some other cognitive milestones that toddlers have to reach?', 'Toddlers also point to pictures in books and look in appropriate places when you ask them to find objects.']
['What is the age range of children that make steady progress in cognitive development?', 'Preschool-age children (i.e., 3–5 years old) also make steady progress in cognitive development.']
['How do they develop cognitively?', 'Not only can they count, name colors, and tell you their name and age, but they can also make some decisions on their own, such as choosing an outfit to wear.']

['Can preschool-age children tell what time it is?', 'Preschool-age children understand basic time concepts and sequencing (e.g., before and after), and they can predict what will happen next in a story.']
['What else do they have learned?', 'They also begin to enjoy the use of humor in stories.']
['What are some common examples of symbolic thinking?', 'Because they can think symbolically, they enjoy pretend play and inventing elaborate characters and scenarios.']
['What is one of the most common examples of their cognitive growth?', 'One of the most common examples of their cognitive growth is their blossoming curiosity.']
['What are some of the most curious behaviors preschool-age children have?', 'Preschool-age children love to ask “Why?”']
['What is cognitive development?', 'An important cognitive change occurs in children this age.']
['What happens to 2–3 year olds?', 'Recall that Piaget described 2–3 year olds as egocentric, meaning that they do not have an awareness of others’ points of view.']

['What is the age at which children come to understand that people have thoughts, feelings, and beliefs that are different from their own?', 'Between 3 and 5 years old, children come to understand that people have thoughts, feelings, and beliefs that are different from their own.']
['What is that known as?', 'This is known as theory-of-mind (TOM).']
['What can children do with this skill?', 'Children can use this skill to tease others, persuade their parents to purchase a candy bar, or understand why a sibling might be angry.']
['What can they do with this?', 'When children develop TOM, they can recognize that others have false beliefs (Dennett, 1987; Callaghan et al., 2005).']
['What is significant about the content?', 'Cognitive skills continue to expand in middle and late childhood (6–11 years old).']
['How do these skills expand?', 'Thought processes become more logical and organized when dealing with concrete information.']
['What else?', 'Children at this age understand concepts such as the past, present, and future, giving them the ability to plan and work toward goals.']
['What else can they do?', 'Additionally, they can process complex ideas such as addition and subtraction and cause-and-effect relationships.']
['What else?', 'However, children’s attention spans tend to be very limited until they are around 11 years old.']
['How does it improve?', 'After that point, it begins to improve through adulthood.']
['What is a well researched aspect of cognitive development?', 'One well-researched aspect of cognitive development is language acquisition.']
['What is consistent across children and cultures?', 'As mentioned earlier, the order in which children learn language structures is consistent across children and cultures (Hatch, 1983).']
['What did you learn about language acquisition?', 'You’ve also learned that some psychological researchers have proposed that children possess a biological predisposition for language acquisition.']
['What does it mean for a baby to learn language?', 'Starting before birth, babies begin to develop language and communication skills.']

['What are some other things you learned?', 'At birth, babies apparently recognize their mother’s voice and can discriminate between the language(s) spoken by their mothers and foreign languages, and they show preferences for faces that are moving in synchrony with audible language (Blossom & Morgan, 2006; Pickens, 1994; Spelke & Cortelyou, 1981).']

['What is one of the primary ideas of this article?', 'Children communicate information through gesturing long before they speak, and there is some evidence that gesture usage predicts subsequent language development (Iverson & Goldin-Meadow, 2005).']
['What is the result of babies beginning to coo almost immediately?', 'In terms of producing spoken language, babies begin to coo almost immediately.']
['What is the difference between cooing and cooing?', 'Cooing is a one-syllable combination of a consonant and a vowel sound (e.g., coo or ba).']
['Do babies replicate sounds from their own languages?', 'Interestingly, babies replicate sounds from their own languages.']
['How is it different?', 'A baby whose parents speak French will coo in a different tone than a baby whose parents speak Spanish or Urdu.']
['What happens after the baby coos?', 'After cooing, the baby starts to babble.']
['How does it sound?', 'Babbling begins with repeating a syllable, such as ma-ma, da-da, or ba-ba.']
['What is the difference?', 'When babies are about 12 months old, we expect them to say their first word for meaning, and to start combining words for meaning at about 18 months.']

['What kinds of things can cognitive development be used for?', 'At about 2 years old, a toddler uses between 50 and 200 words; by 3 years old they have a vocabulary of up to 1,000 words and can speak in sentences.']
['What does that mean?', "During the early childhood years, children's vocabulary increases at a rapid pace."]

['What is the name of the expansion in vocabulary at a rate of 10–20 new words per week?', 'This is sometimes referred to as the “vocabulary spurt” and has been claimed to involve an expansion in vocabulary at a rate of 10–20 new words per week.']
['Do all children experience these spurts?', 'Recent research may indicate that while some children experience these spurts, it is far from universal (as discussed in Ganger & Brent, 2004).']
['What is the article about?', 'It has been estimated that, 5 year olds understand about 6,000 words, speak 2,000 words, and can define words and question their meanings.']
['What can they do?', 'They can rhyme and name the days of the week.']
['How can they develop their language?', 'Seven year olds speak fluently and use slang and clichés (Stork & Widdowson, 1974).']

['What did B. F. Skinner think about how we learn language?', 'Behaviorist B. F. Skinner thought that we learn language in response to reinforcement or feedback, such as through parental approval or through being understood.']
['What examples does he give?', 'For example, when a two-year-old child asks for juice, he might say, “me juice,” to which his mother might respond by giving him a cup of apple juice.']
["Who challenged Skinner's theory?", 'Noam Chomsky (1957) criticized Skinner’s theory and proposed that we are all born with an innate capacity to learn language.']
['What does Chomsky call this mechanism?', 'Chomsky called this mechanism a language acquisition device (LAD).']
['Are there other ideas out there?', 'Both Chomsky and Skinner are right.']
['What are the implications of this?', 'Remember that we are a product of both nature and nurture.']

['How do we know this?', 'Researchers now believe that language acquisition is partially inborn and partially learned through our interactions with our linguistic environment (Gleitman & Newport, 1995; Stork & Widdowson, 1974).']
['What is the main topic of discussion?', 'Psychosocial development occurs as children form relationships, interact with others, and understand and manage their feelings.']
['What are the social milestones of infancy?', 'In social and emotional development, forming healthy attachments is very important and is the major social milestone of infancy.']
['What is the relationship between a person and another person?', 'Attachment is a long-standing connection or bond with others.']
['What was the development of the squirt?', 'Developmental psychologists are interested in how infants reach this milestone.']
['What did Harlow do?', 'Researchers Harry Harlow, John Bowlby, and Mary Ainsworth conducted studies designed to answer these questions.']
['When did Harlow conduct his studies?', 'In the 1950s, Harlow conducted a series of experiments on monkeys.']
['What did he do to the monkeys?', 'He separated newborn monkeys from their mothers.']
['Did he give the monkeys other caregivers?', 'Each monkey was presented with two surrogate mothers.']
['Was she a wire monkey?', 'One surrogate monkey was made out of wire mesh, and she could dispense milk.']
['What was the other monkey made from?', 'The other monkey was softer and made from cloth:']
['What did the monkey do?', 'This monkey did not dispense milk.']
['Did the monkeys like the soft, cuddly cloth monkey?', 'Research shows that the monkeys preferred the soft, cuddly cloth monkey, even though she did not provide any nourishment.']
['What did the baby monkeys do with the cloth monkey?', 'The baby monkeys spent their time clinging to the cloth monkey and only went to the wire monkey when they needed to be fed.']
['Did they find anything else interesting?', 'Prior to this study, the medical and scientific communities generally thought that babies become attached to the people who provide their nourishment.']
['Did they find anything else interesting?', 'However, Harlow (1958) concluded that there was more to the mother-child bond than nourishment.']

['What are the critical components to maternal-infant bonding?', 'Feelings of comfort and security are the critical components to maternal-infant bonding, which leads to healthy psychosocial development.']
['Who developed the concept of attachment theory?', 'Building on the work of Harlow and others, John Bowlby developed the concept of attachment theory.']
['What does he define attachment theory as?', 'He defined attachment as the affectional bond or tie that an infant forms with the mother (Bowlby, 1969).']
['What happens after an infant forms attachment?', 'An infant must form this bond with a primary caregiver in order to have normal social and emotional development.']
['What else is important about the attachment theory?', 'In addition, Bowlby proposed that this attachment bond is very powerful and continues throughout life.']
['What does secure base refer to?', 'He used the concept of secure base to define a healthy attachment between parent and child (1988).']
['What is the concept of a secure base?', 'A secure base is a parental presence that gives the child a sense of safety as he explores his surroundings.']
['What did Bowlby say that two things are needed for a healthy attachment?', 'Bowlby said that two things are needed for a healthy attachment:']

['What are the two things that must be done to ensure that a child is safe?', 'The caregiver must be responsive to the child’s physical, social, and emotional needs; and the caregiver and child must engage in mutually enjoyable interactions (Bowlby, 1969).']
['What did Mary Ainsworth say about this topic?', 'While Bowlby thought attachment was an all-or-nothing process, Mary Ainsworth’s (1970) research showed otherwise.']
['What did Ainsworth want to know?', 'Ainsworth wanted to know if children differ in the ways they bond, and if so, why.']
['How did she find the answers?', 'To find the answers, she used the Strange Situation procedure to study attachment between mothers and their infants (1970).']
['What was the Strange Situation?', 'In the Strange Situation, the mother (or primary caregiver) and the infant (age 12-18 months) are placed in a room together.']
['What did the caregiver and child do in the room?', 'There are toys in the room, and the caregiver and child spend some time alone in the room.']
['What did the stranger do in the room?', 'After the child has had time to explore her surroundings, a stranger enters the room.']
['What did the mother do after the stranger entered the room?', 'The mother then leaves her baby with the stranger.']
['What did the mother do after the stranger left?', 'After a few minutes, she returns to comfort her child.']

['What is the first type of attachment?', 'Based on how the infants/toddlers responded to the separation and reunion, Ainsworth identified three types of parent-child attachments: secure, avoidant, and resistant (Ainsworth & Bell, 1970).']
['What is the fourth type of attachment?', 'A fourth style, known as disorganized attachment, was later described (Main & Solomon, 1990).']
['What is the most common type of attachment?', 'The most common type of attachment—also considered the healthiest—is called secure attachment.']
['Does the toddler prefer a certain attachment figure?', 'In this type of attachment, the toddler prefers his parent over a stranger.']
['What does the attachment figure do?', 'The attachment figure is used as a secure base to explore the environment and is sought out in times of stress.']

['What was the Strange Situation experiment?', 'Securely attached children were distressed when their caregivers left the room in the Strange Situation experiment, but when their caregivers returned, the securely attached children were happy to see them.']
['What makes the children happy?', 'Securely attached children have caregivers who are sensitive and responsive to their needs.']
['What is avoidant attachment?', 'With avoidant attachment, the child is unresponsive to the parent, does not use the parent as a secure base, and does not care if the parent leaves.']
['Do children react differently to a stranger or their parent?', 'The toddler reacts to the parent the same way she reacts to a stranger.']
['What happens when the parent does return?', 'When the parent does return, the child is slow to show a positive reaction.']
['Who is Ainsworth?', 'Ainsworth theorized that these children were most likely to have a caregiver who was insensitive and inattentive to their needs (Ainsworth, Blehar, Waters, & Wall, 1978).']

['What is resistant attachment?', 'In cases of resistant attachment, children tend to show clingy behavior, but then they reject the attachment figure’s attempts to interact with them (Ainsworth & Bell, 1970).']
['How can this be defined?', 'These children do not explore the toys in the room, as they are too fearful.']
['Do they tend to behave in certain ways?', 'During separation in the Strange Situation, they became extremely disturbed and angry with the parent.']
['How can the caregivers help them?', 'When the parent returns, the children are difficult to comfort.']
['What can caregivers do to prevent resistant attachment?', 'Resistant attachment is the result of the caregivers’ inconsistent level of response to their child.']
['What are some of the topics for this class?', 'Finally, children with disorganized attachment behaved oddly in the Strange Situation.']
['When the caregiver returns, what happens to the baby?', 'They freeze, run around the room in an erratic manner, or try to run away when the caregiver returns (Main & Solomon, 1990).']
['What type of attachment does this have?', 'This type of attachment is seen most often in kids who have been abused.']
['Why does it disrupt their emotions?', 'Research has shown that abuse disrupts a child’s ability to regulate their emotions.']
['What is the underlying theory of Ainsworth’s research?', 'While Ainsworth’s research has found support in subsequent studies, it has also met criticism.']

['What has been pointed out that a child’s temperament may have a strong influence on attachment?', 'Some researchers have pointed out that a child’s temperament may have a strong influence on attachment (Gervai, 2009; Harris, 2009), and others have noted that attachment varies from culture to culture, a factor not accounted for in Ainsworth’s research (Rothbaum, Weisz, Pott, Miyake, & Morelli, 2000; van Ijzendoorn & Sagi-Schwartz, 2008).']

['What is the main psychosocial milestone of infancy?', 'Just as attachment is the main psychosocial milestone of infancy, the primary psychosocial milestone of childhood is the development of a positive sense of self.']
['What is the difference between infants and adults?', 'Infants don’t have a self-concept, which is an understanding of who they are.']
['Can you give me one of the tests?', 'If you place a baby in front of a mirror, they will reach out to touch their image, thinking it is another baby.']
['What is it?', 'However, by about 18 months a toddler will recognize that the person in the mirror is themself.']

['What was the experiment that was done to test this theory?', 'In a well-known experiment, a researcher placed a red dot of paint on children’s noses before putting them in front of a mirror (Amsterdam, 1972).']
['What is the mirror test?', 'Commonly known as the mirror test, this behavior is demonstrated by humans and a few other species and is considered evidence of self-recognition (Archer, 1992).']
['What did they do after the paint got on their nose?', 'At 18 months old they would touch their own noses when they saw the paint, surprised to see a spot on their faces.']
['Why did they do this?', 'By 24–36 months old children can name and/or point to themselves in pictures, clearly indicating self-recognition.']
['What is the age range when self-concept becomes important to young children?', 'Children from 2–4 years old display a great increase in social behavior once they have established a self-concept.']
