['What does this social behavior involve?', 'They enjoy playing with other children, but they have difficulty sharing their possessions.']

['What else is this social behavior connected to?', 'Also, through play children explore and come to understand their gender roles and can label themselves as a girl or boy (Chick, Heilman-Houser, & Hunter, 2002).']

['By what age can children cooperate with other children, share when asked, and separate from parents with little anxiety?', 'By 4 years old, children can cooperate with other children, share when asked, and separate from parents with little anxiety.']
['What else does this age mean for them?', 'Children at this age also exhibit autonomy, initiate tasks, and carry out plans.']
['What is the most important thing to them?', 'Success in these areas contributes to a positive sense of self.']

['What else is important about their self-concept?', 'Once children reach 6 years old, they can identify themselves in terms of group memberships: “I’m a first grader!” School-age children compare themselves to their peers and discover that they are competent in some areas and less so in others (recall Erikson’s task of industry versus inferiority).']
['What can be learned about this age group?', 'At this age, children recognize their own personality traits as well as some other traits they would like to have.']
['What was a negative characteristic they recognized?', 'For example, 10-year-old Layla says, “I’m kind of shy.']
['How would Alexa feel as a result?', 'I wish I could be more talkative like my friend Alexa.”']
['What is the importance of developing a positive self-concept?', 'Development of a positive self-concept is important to healthy development.']

['What is significant about positive self?', 'Children with a positive self-concept tend to be more confident, do better in school, act more independently, and are more willing to try new activities (Maccoby, 1980; Ferrer & Fugate, 2003).']

['When do children form positive self-concept?', 'Formation of a positive self-concept begins in Erikson’s toddlerhood stage, when children establish autonomy and become confident in their abilities.']
['When does their concept continue?', 'Development of self-concept continues in elementary school, when children compare themselves to others.']
['What happens if they compare themselves to others negatively?', 'When the comparison is favorable, children feel a sense of competence and are motivated to work harder and accomplish more.']
['What is the reason their concept is re-evaluated?', 'Self-concept is re-evaluated in Erikson’s adolescence stage, as teens form an identity.']
['What happens as teens form their identity?', 'They internalize the messages they have received regarding their strengths and weaknesses, keeping some messages and rejecting others.']
['What can be learned from this study?', 'Adolescents who have achieved identity formation are capable of contributing positively to society (Erikson, 1968).']
['What is the name of the person who thinks parenting style may be a factor?', 'Diana Baumrind (1971, 1991) thinks parenting style may be a factor.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'The way we parent is an important factor in a child’s socioemotional growth.']
['What is the theory of Baumrind?', 'Baumrind developed and refined a theory describing four parenting styles: authoritative, authoritarian, permissive, and uninvolved.']

['What is one example of the authoritative style?', 'With the authoritative style, the parent gives reasonable demands and consistent limits, expresses warmth and affection, and listens to the child’s point of view.']
['What is mentioned in the passage?', 'Parents set rules and explain the reasons behind them.']

['What are some other things that are said?', 'They are also flexible and willing to make exceptions to the rules in certain cases—for example, temporarily relaxing bedtime rules to allow for a nighttime swim during a family vacation.']
['What is the most common parenting style in modern American society?', 'Of the four parenting styles, the authoritative style is the one that is most encouraged in modern American society.']
['What are the benefits of this?', 'American children raised by authoritative parents tend to have high self-esteem and social skills.']

['Do authoritative parenting styles apply everywhere?', 'However, effective parenting styles vary as a function of culture and, as Small (1999) points out, the authoritative style is not necessarily preferred or appropriate in all cultures.']
['What is the most important part of the authoritarian style?', 'In authoritarian style, the parent places high value on conformity and obedience.']
['What can you tell me about this style?', 'The parents are often strict, tightly monitor their children, and express little warmth.']

['What can you tell me about the authoritative style?', 'In contrast to the authoritative style, authoritarian parents probably would not relax bedtime rules during a vacation because they consider the rules to be set, and they expect obedience.']
['What are the consequences of this style?', 'This style can create anxious, withdrawn, and unhappy kids.']

['What is the authoritarian style good for?', 'However, it is important to point out that authoritarian parenting is as beneficial as the authoritative style in some ethnic groups (Russell, Crockett, & Chao, 2010).']

['What are some examples of this style?', 'For instance, first-generation Chinese American children raised by authoritarian parents did just as well in school as their peers who were raised by authoritative parents (Russell et al., 2010).']
["How does it fit in with what we're learning?", 'For parents who employ the permissive style of parenting, the kids run the show and anything goes.']
['What do you think about the content?', 'Permissive parents make few demands and rarely use punishment.']
['What is their role with the kids?', 'They tend to be very nurturing and loving, and may play the role of friend rather than parent.']

['What is the most important thing to know about vacation bedtimes?', 'In terms of our example of vacation bedtimes, permissive parents might not have bedtime rules at all—instead they allow the child to choose their bedtime whether on vacation or not.']

['What does that lead to?', 'Not surprisingly, children raised by permissive parents tend to lack self-discipline, and the permissive parenting style is negatively associated with grades (Dornbusch, Ritter, Leiderman, Roberts, & Fraleigh, 1987).']

['What may be the result of a permissive style?', 'The permissive style may also contribute to other risky behaviors such as alcohol abuse (Bahr & Hoffman, 2010), risky sexual behavior especially among female children (Donenberg, Wilson, Emerson, & Bryant, 2002), and increased display of disruptive behaviors by male children (Parent et al., 2011).']
['What are some positive outcomes associated with children raised by permissive parents?', 'However, there are some positive outcomes associated with children raised by permissive parents.']
['What are the positive outcomes of a healthy lifestyle?', 'They tend to have higher self-esteem, better social skills, and report lower levels of depression (Darling, 1999).']
['What is the uninvolved style of parenting?', 'With the uninvolved style of parenting, the parents are indifferent, uninvolved, and sometimes referred to as neglectful.']
['What is their treatment?', 'They don’t respond to the child’s needs and make relatively few demands.']
['What is the cause of their neglect?', 'This could be because of severe depression or substance abuse, or other factors such as the parents’ extreme focus on work.']
['Why do some parents work?', 'These parents may provide for the child’s basic needs, but little else.']

['How do their children fare?', 'The children raised in this parenting style are usually emotionally withdrawn, fearful, anxious, perform poorly in school, and are at an increased risk of substance abuse (Darling, 1999).']
['What is temperament?', 'Temperament refers to innate traits that influence how one thinks, behaves, and reacts with the environment.']
['What happens with an easy temperament?', 'Children with easy temperaments demonstrate positive emotions, adapt well to change, and are capable of regulating their emotions.']
['What happens with a difficult temperament?', 'Conversely, children with difficult temperaments demonstrate negative emotions and have difficulty adapting to change and regulating their emotions.']
['What happens with these children?', 'Difficult children are much more likely to challenge parents, teachers, and other caregivers (Thomas, 1984).']

['What is the difference between easy and demanding children?', 'Therefore, it’s possible that easy children (i.e., social, adaptable, and easy to soothe) tend to elicit warm and responsive parenting, while demanding, irritable, withdrawn children evoke irritation in their parents or cause their parents to withdraw (Sanson & Rothbart, 1995).']
['What are the characteristics of adolescence?', 'Adolescence is a socially constructed concept.']

['What was the reason for creating adolescence?', 'In pre-industrial society, children were considered adults when they reached physical maturity, but today we have an extended time between childhood and adulthood called adolescence.']

['What is the period of development that begins at puberty and ends at emerging adulthood?', 'Adolescence is the period of development that begins at puberty and ends at emerging adulthood, which is discussed later.']
['What is the cultural image of adolescence?', 'In the United States, adolescence is seen as a time to develop independence from parents while remaining connected to them.']

['What is the typical age range of adolescence?', 'The typical age range of adolescence is from 12 to 18 years, and this stage of development also has some predictable physical, cognitive, and psychosocial milestones.']
['What is one of the most important things you can remember about the article?', 'As noted above, adolescence begins with puberty.']
['What is the sequence of physical changes in puberty?', 'While the sequence of physical changes in puberty is predictable, the onset and pace of puberty vary widely.']

['What are some of the physical changes that take place during puberty?', 'Several physical changes occur during puberty, such as adrenarche and gonadarche, the maturing of the adrenal glands and sex glands, respectively.']
['What else happens during puberty?', 'Also during this time, primary and secondary sexual characteristics develop and mature.']
['What are some of the primary sexual characteristics?', 'Primary sexual characteristics are organs specifically needed for reproduction, like the uterus and ovaries in females and testes in males.']

['Are there any other characteristics that develop?', 'Secondary sexual characteristics are physical signs of sexual maturation that do not directly involve sex organs, such as development of breasts and hips in females, and development of facial hair and a deepened voice in males.']

['What happens after this stage?', 'Females experience menarche, the beginning of menstrual periods, usually around 12–13 years old, and males experience spermarche, the first ejaculation, around 13–14 years old.']
['What is the most important fact in the text?', 'During puberty, people experience a rapid increase in height (i.e., growth spurt).']
['How old is this?', 'For females this begins between 8 and 13 years old, with adult height reached between 10 and 16 years old.']

['How old is it for males to reach their adult height?', 'Males begin their growth spurt slightly later, usually between 10 and 16 years old, and reach their adult height between 13 and 17 years old.']
['What else can influence height?', 'Both nature (i.e., genes) and nurture (e.g., nutrition, medications, and medical conditions) can influence height.']
['What is puberty?', 'Because rates of physical development vary so widely among teenagers, puberty can be a source of pride or embarrassment.']
['Are there differences in physical development between boys and girls?', 'Early maturing boys tend to be stronger, taller, and more athletic than their later maturing peers.']

['What does it mean that they are more popular?', 'They are usually more popular, confident, and independent, but they are also at a greater risk for substance abuse and early sexual activity (Flannery, Rowe, & Gulley, 1993; Kaltiala-Heino, Rimpela, Rissanen, & Rantanen, 2001).']
['What can you tell me about physical development?', 'Early maturing girls may be teased or overtly admired, which can cause them to feel self-conscious about their developing bodies.']

['What happens when girls are self-conscious about their developing bodies?', 'These girls are at a higher risk for depression, substance abuse, and eating disorders (Ge, Conger, & Elder, 2001; Graber, Lewinsohn, Seeley, & Brooks-Gunn, 1997; Striegel-Moore & Cachelin, 1999).']

['What are the differences between boys and girls in their physical development?', 'Late blooming boys and girls (i.e., they develop more slowly than their peers) may feel self-conscious about their lack of physical development.']

['What other problems do they encounter as a result of this?', 'Negative feelings are particularly a problem for late maturing boys, who are at a higher risk for depression and conflict with parents (Graber et al., 1997) and more likely to be bullied (Pollack & Shuster, 2000).']

['What are some things that relate to physical development?', 'Psychologists and clinicians also study the impact of gender identity and the impacts of puberty on transgender and gender-nonconforming youth.']
['Are there other things that are related to physical development?', 'This is a relatively recent area of study, and the impacts should not be over-generalized.']

['What are some of the risks that come with this?', 'However, the research seems to indicate that transgender and gender-nonconforming youth who are supported in their identity do not have significantly higher incidences of depression or anxiety symptoms when compared to control groups, while those who are not supported exhibit more symptoms and risk factors (Olson, Durwood, & McLaughlin, 2016).']
['What is significant about physical development?', 'Expression and exploration of gender identity can take many forms and manifest at different times depending on a wide array of factors.']
['What is happening during adolescence?', 'The adolescent brain also remains under development.']
['What is happening to the brain?', 'Up until puberty, brain cells continue to bloom in the frontal region.']

['What are some of the risk taking behaviors that happen?', 'Adolescents engage in increased risk-taking behaviors and emotional outbursts possibly because the frontal lobes of their brains are still developing.']

['What is the frontal region responsible for?', 'Recall that this area is responsible for judgment, impulse control, and planning, and it is still maturing into early adulthood (Casey, Tottenham, Liston, & Durston, 2005).']
['When does cognitive development begin?', 'More complex thinking abilities emerge during adolescence.']

['What is the result of this?', 'Some researchers suggest this is due to increases in processing speed and efficiency rather than as the result of an increase in mental capacity—in other words, due to improvements in existing skills rather than development of new ones (Bjorkland, 1987; Case, 1985).']
['Are there any other interesting aspects about this section?', 'During adolescence, teenagers move beyond concrete thinking and become capable of abstract thought.']
['What does Piaget refer to this stage as formal operational thought?', 'Recall that Piaget refers to this stage as formal operational thought.']

['How does this influence thinking?', 'Teen thinking is also characterized by the ability to consider multiple points of view, imagine hypothetical situations, debate ideas and opinions (e.g., politics, religion, and justice), and form new ideas.']
['What is another characteristic of this characterized by?', 'In addition, it’s not uncommon for adolescents to question authority or challenge established societal norms.']

['What is cognitive empathy?', 'Cognitive empathy, also known as theory-of-mind (which we discussed earlier with regard to egocentrism), relates to the ability to take the perspective of others and feel concern for others (Shamay-Tsoory, Tomer, & Aharon-Peretz, 2005).']
['What is cognitive empathy?', 'Cognitive empathy begins to increase in adolescence and is an important component of social problem solving and conflict avoidance.']

['What other information can you give me about cognitive empathy?', 'According to one longitudinal study, levels of cognitive empathy begin rising in girls around 13 years old, and around 15 years old in boys (Van der Graaff et al., 2013).']

['How can people take the perspective of others?', 'Teens who reported having supportive fathers with whom they could discuss their worries were found to be better able to take the perspective of others (Miklikowska, Duriez, & Soenens, 2011).']
['What does psychosocial development mean?', 'Adolescents continue to refine their sense of self as they relate to others.']
['Who referred to the task of the adolescent as one of identity versus role confusion?', 'Erikson referred to the task of the adolescent as one of identity versus role confusion.']
['What were the main questions that Erikson thought adolescents had?', 'Thus, in Erikson’s view, an adolescent’s main questions are “Who am I?” and “Who do I want to be?”']
['Who expects', 'Some adolescents adopt the values and roles that their parents expect for them.']
['What do teens develop?', 'Other teens develop identities that are in opposition to their parents but align with a peer group.']
['How is this relevant to adolescents?', 'This is common as peer relationships become a central focus in adolescents’ lives.']

['When did adolescents work to form their identities?', 'As adolescents work to form their identities, they pull away from their parents, and the peer group becomes very important (Shanahan, McHale, Osgood, & Crouter, 2007).']
['What do they stay with?', 'Despite spending less time with their parents, most teens report positive feelings toward them (Moore, Guzman, Hair, Lippman, & Garrett, 2004).']

['What does this mean?', 'Warm and healthy parent-child relationships have been associated with positive child outcomes, such as better grades and fewer school behavior problems, in the United States as well as in other countries (Hair et al., 2005).']

['What is significant about psychosocial development?', 'It appears that most teens don’t experience adolescent storm and stress to the degree once famously suggested by G. Stanley Hall, a pioneer in the study of adolescent development.']
['What else is significant about psychosocial development?', 'Only small numbers of teens have major conflicts with their parents (Steinberg & Morris, 2001), and most disagreements are minor.']

['What are some of the day-to-day issues that teens have conflicts over?', 'For example, in a study of over 1,800 parents of adolescents from various cultural and ethnic groups, Barber (1994) found that conflicts occurred over day-to-day issues such as homework, money, curfews, clothing, chores, and friends.']
['Do arguments decrease as teens develop?', 'These types of arguments tend to decrease as teens develop (Galambos & Almeida, 1992).']
['What is the research on the adolescent brain?', 'There is emerging research on the adolescent brain.']
['What else has been done about adolescence?', 'Galvan, Hare, Voss, Glover and Casey (2007) examined its role in risk-taking behavior.']
['How was this determined?', 'They used fMRI to assess the readings’ relationship to risk-taking, risk perception, and impulsivity.']
['What was the result of this study?', 'The researchers found that there was no correlation between brain activity in the neural reward center and impulsivity and risk perception.']
['What did the study show about impulsivity and reward?', 'However, activity in that part of the brain was correlated to risk taking.']
['What was the correlation between risk taking and reward?', 'In other words, risk-taking adolescents experienced brain activity in the reward center.']
['What was the conclusion of the study?', 'The idea that adolescents, however, are more impulsive than other demographics was challenged in their research, which included children and adults.']
['What is the next stage of development?', 'The next stage of development is emerging adulthood.']

['Is it a relatively newly defined period of lifespan development spanning from 18 years old to the mid-20s, characterized as an in-between time where identity exploration is focused on work and love?', 'This is a relatively newly defined period of lifespan development spanning from 18 years old to the mid-20s, characterized as an in-between time where identity exploration is focused on work and love.']
['What are some ways that this can be said?', 'There are many ways to answer this question.']
['What is the earliest age an adult can be considered as having lived enough time?', 'In the United States, you are legally considered an adult at 18 years old.']

['How is this defined in other societies?', 'But other definitions of adulthood vary widely; in sociology, for example, a person may be considered an adult when they become self-supporting, choose a career, get married, or start a family.']
['What are the ages at which we achieve these milestones?', 'The ages at which we achieve these milestones vary from person to person as well as from culture to culture.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'For example, in the African country of Malawi, 15-year-old Njemile was married at 14 years old and had her first child at 15 years old.']
['Is she considered an adult?', 'In her culture she is considered an adult.']

['What are some examples of children in Malawi taking on adult responsibilities?', 'Children in Malawi take on adult responsibilities such as marriage and work (e.g., carrying water, tending babies, and working fields) as early as 10 years old.']
['What is the main reason for the delay in Western culture?', 'In stark contrast, independence in Western cultures is taking longer and longer, effectively delaying the onset of adult life.']
['What is one thing that you find interesting?', 'It seems that emerging adulthood is a product of both Western culture and our current times (Arnett, 2000).']

['What is one of the times that people are living longer?', 'People in higher income and more industrialized countries are living longer, allowing the freedom to take an extra decade to start a career and family.']
['What other factor contributes to the aging of the population?', 'Changes in the workforce also play a role.']
['What was the example of the passage?', 'For example, 50 years ago, a young adult with a high school diploma could immediately enter the work force and climb the economic ladder.']
['Is this still true?', 'That is no longer the case.']
['What is a more accurate way to describe the changes?', 'Bachelor’s and even graduate degrees are required more and more often—even for entry-level jobs (Arnett, 2000).']
['What other changes happened?', 'In addition, many students are taking longer (five or six years) to complete a college degree as a result of working and going to school at the same time.']
['What else can you tell me about these changes?', 'After graduation, many young adults return to the family home because they have difficulty finding a job.']

["What is the term for a group of recent college graduates who return to their parents' home after college?", 'The term Boomerang Generation describes recent college graduates for whom lack of adequate employment upon college graduation often leads to a return to the parental home (Davidson, 2014).']
['What is the most important reason for the delay in entering adult roles?', 'Changing cultural expectations may be the most important reason for the delay in entering adult roles.']

['What are these expectations?', 'Young people are spending more time exploring their options, so they are delaying marriage and work as they change majors and jobs multiple times, putting them on a much later timetable than their parents (Arnett, 2000).']
['What are some important aspects of adulthood?', 'Adulthood begins around 20 years old and has three distinct stages: early, middle, and late.']
['What is said about the stages?', 'Each stage brings its own set of rewards and challenges.']

['What is the basic concept of physical maturation?', 'By the time we reach early adulthood (20 to early 40s), our physical maturation is complete, although our height and weight may increase slightly.']
['Why is this important?', 'In young adulthood, our physical abilities are at their peak, including muscle strength, reaction time, sensory abilities, and cardiac functioning.']
['What happens during this stage?', 'Most professional athletes are at the top of their game during this stage.']
['Do women also have children during this stage?', 'Many women have children in the young adulthood years, so they may see additional weight gain and breast changes.']
['What is middle adulthood?', 'Middle adulthood extends from the 40s to the 60s.']
['What happens during the 60s?', 'Physical decline is gradual.']
['What happens to your skin as you age?', 'The skin loses some elasticity, and wrinkles are among the first signs of aging.']
['What happens in your eyes when you are in a car accident?', 'Visual acuity decreases during this time.']
['What can happen during this time?', 'Women experience a gradual decline in fertility as they approach the onset of menopause, the end of the menstrual cycle, around 50 years old.']
['What can happen to your body if you gain weight?', 'Both men and women tend to gain weight: in the abdominal area for men and in the hips and thighs for women.']
['What happens to the hair as you get older?', 'Hair begins to thin and turn gray.']
["What happens as people reach their 60's?", 'Late adulthood is considered to extend from the 60s on.']
['What is the last stage of physical change?', 'This is the last stage of physical change.']
['What is the biggest change that happens in late adulthood?', 'The skin continues to lose elasticity, reaction time slows further, and muscle strength diminishes.']
['What is a change that happens in late adulthood?', 'Smell, taste, hearing, and vision, so sharp in our twenties, decline significantly.']
['What other changes occur?', 'The brain may also no longer function at optimal levels, leading to problems like memory loss, dementia, and Alzheimer’s disease in later years.']
['Why is this?', 'Because we spend so many years in adulthood (more than any other stage), cognitive changes are numerous.']

['What does that mean?', 'In fact, research suggests that adult cognitive development is a complex, ever changing process that may be even more active than cognitive development in infancy and early childhood (Fischer, Yan, & Stewart, 2003).']

['What are the two most important things we should know about cognitive development?', 'Unlike our physical abilities, which peak in our mid-20s and then begin a slow decline, our cognitive abilities remain steady throughout early and middle adulthood.']

['What is important about our crystallized intelligence?', 'Our crystallized intelligence (information, skills, and strategies we have gathered through a lifetime of experience) tends to hold steady as we age—it may even improve.']

['What is a particular example of the increasing scores on intelligence tests?', 'For example, adults show relatively stable to increasing scores on intelligence tests until their mid-30s to mid-50s (Bayley & Oden, 1955).']

['What else is significant about cognitive development?', 'However, in late adulthood we begin to experience a decline in another area of our cognitive abilities—fluid intelligence (information processing abilities, reasoning, and memory).']
['How does this impact the way we think?', 'These processes become slower.']
['What can be done to counteract this effect?', 'Mental and physical activity seems to play a part.']

['What can we do to counteract these declines?', 'Research has found adults who engage in mentally and physically stimulating activities experience less cognitive decline and have a reduced incidence of mild cognitive impairment and dementia (Hertzog, Kramer, Wilson, & Lindenberger, 2009; Larson et al., 2006; Podewils et al., 2005).']
['How does the aging brain differ from younger people?', 'Researchers have examined the aging brain by comparing it to brain functioning in younger people.']
['What is one study?', 'Forstmann and colleagues (2011) compared elderly participants to younger participants, who in the study were asked to report the direction of movement of a set of dots.']
['How did they learn it?', 'They were given feedback regarding speed and accuracy.']
['What were the findings of the researchers?', 'The researchers found that older participants made more errors and were slower due to degeneration of corticostriatal connections.']
['What is interesting about this study?', 'In other words, the decreased ability typically assigned to elderly people may be due to circumstances in the brain beyond their control.']
['What other research has been done?', 'Interestingly, other researchers have found similarities in spatial representations when comparing children aged 6–7 to those over the age of 80.']
['What is the cause of this?', 'Ruggiero, D’Errico, and Iachini (2016) reported that this is due to neurodegeneration in older adults and immature neurology in young children.']
['What does cognitive development mean?', 'Many elderly people experience dementia, changes in the brain that negatively affect cognition.']
['What is the first medical researcher involved in this?', 'Alzheimer’s disease is one type of dementia, initially studied by medical researcher Solomon Carter Fuller.']
['What is the genetic basis of Alzheimer’s disease?', 'Alzheimer’s disease has a genetic basis.']
['What is the cell death?', 'Plaques in the brain are due to cell death, which then causes those affected with the disease severe forgetfulness.']
['What can happen in this situation?', 'A person can forget how to walk, talk, and eventually eat.']

['What can we do to help this?', 'The disease can be mitigated by assessing environmental factors (exposure to lead, iron, and zinc increase risk) and nutritional factors (the Mediterranean diet lowers risk) (Arora, Mittal, & Kakkar, 2015).']
['What is the cure for AIDS?', 'Although there is no cure, there is hope.']
['What can we do to offset mild cognitive impairment?', 'Cognitive rehabilitation can offset mild cognitive impairment, as it can evolve into dementia.']

['What was the use of virtual reality as a possible cognitive rehabilitative method?', 'Garcia-Betances, Jimenez-Mixco, Arredondo, and Cabrera-Umpierrez (2015) examined the use of virtual reality as a possible cognitive rehabilitative method.']

['What did they suggest that virtual reality technology should involve?', 'They suggested that virtual reality technology should involve daily living activities, memory, and language, among other considerations.']
['What are the theories about?', 'There are many theories about the social and emotional aspects of aging.']
['What are some aspects of healthy aging?', 'Some aspects of healthy aging include activities, social connectedness, and the role of a person’s culture.']

['What is meaning?', 'According to many theorists, including George Vaillant (2002), who studied and analyzed over 50 years of data, we need to have and continue to find meaning throughout our lives.']
["What else does Vaillant's data show?", 'For those in early and middle adulthood, meaning is found through work (Sterns & Huyck, 2001) and family life (Markus, Ryff, Curan, & Palmersheim, 2004).']
['What else does Erikson refer to?', 'These areas relate to the tasks that Erikson referred to as generativity and intimacy.']
['What is one thing the students learned?', 'As mentioned previously, adults tend to define themselves by what they do—their careers.']

['What are other aspects of their lives?', 'Earnings peak during this time, yet job satisfaction is more closely tied to work that involves contact with other people, is interesting, provides opportunities for advancement, and allows some independence (Mohr & Zoghi, 2006) than it is to salary (Iyengar, Wells, & Schwartz, 2006).']

['What is the most important topic in this assignment?', 'Positive relationships with significant others in our adult years have been found to contribute to a state of well-being (Ryff & Singer, 2009).']

['What other interesting fact is in the paragraph?', 'Most adults in the United States identify themselves through their relationships with family—particularly with spouses, children, and parents (Markus et al., 2004).']

['What are some benefits of raising children?', 'While raising children can be stressful, especially when they are young, research suggests that parents reap the rewards down the road, as adult children tend to have a positive effect on parental well-being (Umberson, Pudrovska, & Reczek, 2010).']
['How is stable marriage related to well-being?', 'Having a stable marriage has also been found to contribute to well-being throughout adulthood (Vaillant, 2002).']
['What type of development are you discussing?', 'Another aspect of positive aging is believed to be social connectedness and social support.']

['What does this say?', 'As we get older, socioemotional selectivity theory suggests that our social support and friendships dwindle in number, but remain as close, if not more close than in our earlier years (Carstensen, 1992).']
['What was the end of each story?', 'Every story has an ending.']
['What does death mark?', 'Death marks the end of your life story.']
['What do people do when they are near death?', 'Our culture and individual backgrounds influence how we view death.']
['What is the way the Americans view death?', 'In some cultures, death is accepted as a natural part of life and is embraced.']

['What is the perception of the passage?', 'In contrast, until about 50 years ago in the United States, a doctor might not inform someone that they were dying, and the majority of deaths occurred in hospitals.']
['What changed in the 50s?', 'In 1967 that reality began to change with Cicely Saunders, who created the first modern hospice in England.']

['What is the aim of hospice?', 'The aim of hospice is to help provide a death with dignity and pain management in a humane and comfortable environment, which is usually outside of a hospital setting.']
['What is the history of hospice in America?', 'In 1974, Florence Wald founded the first hospice in the United States.']
['What is the most important thing to know about hospice?', 'Today, hospice provides care for 1.65 million Americans and their families.']
['Why do they want to live at home?', 'Because of hospice care, many terminally ill people are able to spend their last days at home.']

['What can you tell me about hospice care?', 'Research has indicated that hospice care is beneficial for the patient (Brumley, Enquidanos, & Cherin, 2003; Brumley et al., 2007; Godkin, Krant, & Doster, 1984) and for the patient’s family (Rhodes, Mitchell, Miller, Connor, & Teno, 2008; Godkin et al., 1984).']

['Why is it beneficial?', 'Hospice patients report high levels of satisfaction with hospice care because they are able to remain at home and are not completely dependent on strangers for care (Brumley et al., 2007).']
['What is another benefit of hospice care?', 'In addition, hospice patients tend to live longer than non-hospice patients (Connor, Pyenson, Fitch, Spence, & Iwasaki, 2007; Temel et al., 2010).']

['What is significant about family members receiving emotional support and being regularly informed of their loved one’s treatment and condition?', 'Family members receive emotional support and are regularly informed of their loved one’s treatment and condition.']
['What is another benefit of telehealth?', 'The family member’s burden of care is also reduced (McMillan et al., 2006).']

['What else can you tell me about this?', 'Both the patient and the patient’s family members report increased family support, increased social support, and improved coping while receiving hospice services (Godkin et al., 1984).']

['Who described the process of an individual accepting his own death?', 'Elizabeth Kübler-Ross (1969), who worked with the founders of hospice care, described the process of an individual accepting his own death.']
['What are the stages of grief?', 'She proposed five stages of grief: denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance.']
['What do you think about the stages?', 'Most individuals experience these stages, but the stages may occur in different orders, depending on the individual.']
['What is unique about the stages?', 'In addition, not all people experience all of the stages.']

['What is significant about the passage?', 'It is also important to note that some psychologists believe that the more a dying person fights death, the more likely they are to remain stuck in the denial phase.']
['What would happen if they are stuck?', 'This could make it difficult for the dying person to face death with dignity.']
['What did psychologists think about the stages?', 'However, other psychologists believe that not facing death until the very end is an adaptive coping mechanism for some people.']

["Why isn't everyone going through this?", 'Whether due to illness or old age, not everyone facing death or the loss of a loved one experiences the negative emotions outlined in the Kübler-Ross model (Nolen-Hoeksema & Larson, 1999).']

["Are there other reasons why some don't go through this?", 'For example, research suggests that people with religious or spiritual beliefs are better able to cope with death because of their hope in an afterlife and because of social support from religious or spiritual associations (Hood, Spilka, Hunsberger, & Corsuch, 1996; McIntosh, Silver, & Wortman, 1993; Paloutzian, 1996; Samarel, 1991; Wortman & Park, 2008).']

['What is a prominent example of a person creating meaning through death?', 'A prominent example of a person creating meaning through death is Randy Pausch, who was a well-loved and respected professor at Carnegie Mellon University.']
['What was he dying from?', 'Diagnosed with terminal pancreatic cancer in his mid-40s and given only 3–6 months to live, Pausch focused on living in a fulfilling way in the time he had left.']
['How did he focus on living in a fulfilling way?', 'Instead of becoming angry and depressed, he presented his now famous last lecture called “Really Achieving Your Childhood Dreams.”']

['How did he share his insights?', 'In his moving, yet humorous talk, he shares his insights on seeing the good in others, overcoming obstacles, and experiencing zero gravity, among many other things.']

['What did Pausch share in his lecture?', 'Despite his terminal diagnosis, Pausch lived the final year of his life with joy and hope, showing us that our plans for the future still matter, even if we know that we are dying.']

['What is the content of this study material?', 'As individuals become more knowledgeable about medical procedures and practices, some people want to ensure that their wishes and desires are known in advance.']
['Why do they want their wishes known in advance?', 'This ensures that if the person ever becomes incapacitated or can no longer express themselves, their loved ones will know what they want.']
['What is a living will?', 'For this reason, a person might write a living will or advance directive, which is a written legal document that details specific interventions a person wants.']
['What can you tell me about this type of information?', 'For example, a person in the last stages of a terminal illness may not want to receive life-extending treatments.']
['Who else does the person want to be told about their wishes?', 'A person may also include a Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) Order, which they would share this with family and close friends.']

['What is a DNR Order?', 'A DNR Order states that if a person stops breathing or their heart stops beating, medical personnel such as doctors and nurses are not to take steps to revive or resuscitate the patient.']

['What can you tell me about a health care proxy?', 'A living will can also include a health care proxy, which appoints a specific person to make medical decisions for you if you are unable to speak for yourself.']
['What are some reasons people have for wanting living wills and DNRs?', 'People’s desire for living wills and DNRs are often influenced by their religion, culture, and upbringing.']
['What does motivation describe?', 'Motivation describes the wants or needs that direct behavior toward a goal.']

['What are some other things that motivate people?', 'In addition to biological motives, motivations can be intrinsic (arising from internal factors) or extrinsic (arising from external factors) (Figure 10.2).']

['What are the differences between intrinsic and extrinsic motivation?', 'Intrinsically motivated behaviors are performed because of the sense of personal satisfaction that they bring, while extrinsically motivated behaviors are performed in order to receive something from others.']
['What would motivate you most to learn the passage?', 'Think about why you are pursuing an education.']
['Do you feel great when you do something?', 'If so, then you are intrinsically motivated.']

['You are motivated to study because you enjoy learning and pursuing knowledge.', 'However, if you are here because you want to get a college degree to make yourself more marketable for a high-paying career or to satisfy the demands of your parents, then your motivation is more extrinsic in nature.']

['What is intrinsic motivation?', 'In reality, our motivations are often a mix of both intrinsic and extrinsic factors, but the nature of the mix of these factors might change over time (often in ways that seem counter-intuitive).']

['What can you tell me about this?', 'There is an old adage: “Choose a job that you love, and you will never have to work a day in your life,” meaning that if you enjoy your occupation, work doesn’t seem like . . . well, work.']
['Is this true?', 'Some research suggests that this isn’t necessarily the case (Daniel & Esser, 1980; Deci, 1972; Deci, Koestner, & Ryan, 1999).']

['Are these researchers correct?', 'According to this research, receiving some sort of extrinsic reinforcement (i.e., getting paid) for engaging in behaviors that we enjoy leads to those behaviors being thought of as work no longer providing that same enjoyment.']
['Is this bad for us?', 'As a result, we might spend less time engaging in these reclassified behaviors in the absence of any extrinsic reinforcement.']
['What are some interesting facts about Odessa?', 'For example, Odessa loves baking, so in her free time, she bakes for fun.']

['What does she do after stocking shelves at her grocery store job?', 'Oftentimes, after stocking shelves at her grocery store job, she often whips up pastries in the evenings because she enjoys baking.']
['How did she get the job in the store?', 'When a coworker in the store’s bakery department leaves his job, Odessa applies for his position and gets transferred to the bakery department.']
['Do the changes in her attitude change with time?', 'Although she enjoys what she does in her new job, after a few months, she no longer has much desire to concoct tasty treats in her free time.']
['What happens to baking?', 'Baking has become work in a way that changes her motivation to do it (Figure 10.3).']
["What can you tell me about Odessa's experience?", 'What Odessa has experienced is called the overjustification effect—intrinsic motivation is diminished when extrinsic motivation is given.']

['Can this overjustification effect lead to bad outcomes?', 'This can lead to extinguishing the intrinsic motivation and creating a dependence on extrinsic rewards for continued performance (Deci et al., 1999).']

["What is the most important information that you'll be learning from this article?", 'Other studies suggest that intrinsic motivation may not be so vulnerable to the effects of extrinsic reinforcements, and in fact, reinforcements such as verbal praise might actually increase intrinsic motivation (Arnold, 1976; Cameron & Pierce, 1994).']

['What is a specific example that you can give us?', 'In that case, Odessa’s motivation to bake in her free time might remain high if, for example, customers regularly compliment her baking or cake decorating skills.']
['What is the motivation research?', 'These apparent discrepancies in the researchers’ findings may be understood by considering several factors.']

["What is one factor the researchers' findings may be understood by considering?", 'For one, physical reinforcement (such as money) and verbal reinforcement (such as praise) may affect an individual in very different ways.']

['What is one example of the different ways they may affect an individual?', 'In fact, tangible rewards (i.e., money) tend to have more negative effects on intrinsic motivation than do intangible rewards (i.e., praise).']
['What do they look at as an extrinsic motivator?', 'Furthermore, the expectation of the extrinsic motivator by an individual is crucial:']
['What is the effect of expectation on intrinsic motivation?', 'If the person expects to receive an extrinsic reward, then intrinsic motivation for the task tends to be reduced.']

['How does expectation affect intrinsic motivation?', 'If, however, there is no such expectation, and the extrinsic motivation is presented as a surprise, then intrinsic motivation for the task tends to persist (Deci et al., 1999).']
['What do we want to learn about culture?', 'In addition, culture may influence motivation.']

['What kind of influence is it common to do things for your family members because the emphasis is on the group and what is best for the entire group, rather than what is best for any one individual?', 'For example, in collectivistic cultures, it is common to do things for your family members because the emphasis is on the group and what is best for the entire group, rather than what is best for any one individual (Nisbett, Peng, Choi, & Norenzayan, 2001).']

['What can a group do better than an individual?', 'This focus on others provides a broader perspective that takes into account both situational and cultural influences on behavior; thus, a more nuanced explanation of the causes of others’ behavior becomes more likely.']
['Are there any more examples of collectivistic and individualistic cultures?', '(You will learn more about collectivistic and individualistic cultures when you learn about social psychology.)']

['What is the most important fact in this paragraph?', 'In educational settings, students are more likely to experience intrinsic motivation to learn when they feel a sense of belonging and respect in the classroom.']

['What is important about this passage?', 'This internalization can be enhanced if the evaluative aspects of the classroom are de-emphasized and if students feel that they exercise some control over the learning environment.']

['What is the most important thing to remember about the passage?', 'Furthermore, providing students with activities that are challenging, yet doable, along with a rationale for engaging in various learning activities can enhance intrinsic motivation for those tasks (Niemiec & Ryan, 2009).']
['What is your question?', 'Consider Hakim, a first-year law student with two courses this semester: Family Law and Criminal Law.']
['What was the professor like?', 'The Family Law professor has a rather intimidating classroom:']
['What is the professor like?', 'He likes to put students on the spot with tough questions, which often leaves students feeling belittled or embarrassed.']
['What is the most important thing to remember about the passage?', 'Grades are based exclusively on quizzes and exams, and the instructor posts results of each test on the classroom door.']
['What is the professor like?', 'In contrast, the Criminal Law professor facilitates classroom discussions and respectful debates in small groups.']
['What is the most important part of the course?', 'The majority of the course grade is not exam-based, but centers on a student-designed research project on a crime issue of the student’s choice.']

['What is the reason Hakim will be less intrinsically motivated in his Family Law course?', 'Research suggests that Hakim will be less intrinsically motivated in his Family Law course, where students are intimidated in the classroom setting, and there is an emphasis on teacher-driven evaluations.']

['What is the motivation level?', 'Hakim is likely to experience a higher level of intrinsic motivation in his Criminal Law course, where the class setting encourages inclusive collaboration and a respect for ideas, and where students have more influence over their learning activities.']

['What is William James known for?', 'William James (1842–1910) was an important contributor to early research into motivation, and he is often referred to as the father of psychology in the United States.']
['What did James theorize about instincts?', 'James theorized that behavior was driven by a number of instincts, which aid survival (Figure 10.4).']
['What is the definition of instinct?', 'From a biological perspective, an instinct is a species-specific pattern of behavior that is not learned.']
['Did James have any controversy?', 'There was, however, considerable controversy among James and his contemporaries over the exact definition of instinct.']
["Did James' proposals gain support?", 'James proposed several dozen special human instincts, but many of his contemporaries had their own lists that differed.']

['What other types of instincts are out there?', 'A mother’s protection of her baby, the urge to lick sugar, and hunting prey were among the human behaviors proposed as true instincts during James’s era.']

['Was his view popular?', 'This view—that human behavior is driven by instincts—received a fair amount of criticism because of the undeniable role of learning in shaping all sorts of human behavior.']

['How did he explain learning?', 'In fact, as early as the 1900s, some instinctive behaviors were experimentally demonstrated to result from associative learning (recall when you learned about Watson’s conditioning of fear response in “Little Albert”) (Faris, 1921).']

['What theory of motivation proposed that the maintenance of homeostasis is particularly important in directing behavior?', 'Another early theory of motivation proposed that the maintenance of homeostasis is particularly important in directing behavior.']

['What is the tendency to maintain a balance, or optimal level, within a biological system?', 'You may recall from your earlier reading that homeostasis is the tendency to maintain a balance, or optimal level, within a biological system.']
['What is a control center?', 'In a body system, a control center (which is often part of the brain) receives input from receptors (which are often complexes of neurons).']
['What does the control center direct?', 'The control center directs effectors (which may be other neurons) to correct any imbalance detected by the control center.']
['What is the most interesting thing about this chapter?', 'According to the drive theory of motivation, deviations from homeostasis create physiological needs.']
['What is the result of psychological drive states?', 'These needs result in psychological drive states that direct behavior to meet the need and, ultimately, bring the system back to homeostasis.']
['What is an example you use to explain this theory?', 'For example, if it’s been a while since you ate, your blood sugar levels will drop below normal.']

['What would happen if you had low blood sugar?', 'This low blood sugar will induce a physiological need and a corresponding drive state (i.e., hunger) that will direct you to seek out and consume food (Figure 10.5).']
['How would this result in your return to homeostasis?', 'Eating will eliminate the hunger, and, ultimately, your blood sugar levels will return to normal.']
['What did you like about drive theory?', 'Interestingly, drive theory also emphasizes the role that habits play in the type of behavioral response in which we engage.']
['What is a pattern of behavior in which we regularly engage?', 'A habit is a pattern of behavior in which we regularly engage.']

['How does the theory of habits effect our behavior?', 'Once we have engaged in a behavior that successfully reduces a drive, we are more likely to engage in that behavior whenever faced with that drive in the future (Graham & Weiner, 1996).']
['What did you find most interesting about the chapter about the theory of motivation?', 'Extensions of drive theory take into account levels of arousal as potential motivators.']
['What did the theory assert?', 'As you recall from your study of learning, these theories assert that there is an optimal level of arousal that we all try to maintain (Figure 10.6).']
['What is the theory of underaroused?', 'If we are underaroused, we become bored and will seek out some sort of stimulation.']
['When someone is overaroused, what happens?', 'On the other hand, if we are overaroused, we will engage in behaviors to reduce our arousal (Berlyne, 1960).']
['What are some examples of academic success?', 'Most students have experienced this need to maintain optimal levels of arousal over the course of their academic career.']
['How does this effect the student?', 'Think about how much stress students experience toward the end of spring semester.']
['What makes it so stressful?', 'They feel overwhelmed with seemingly endless exams, papers, and major assignments that must be completed on time.']
['What are some things that stress the students?', 'They probably yearn for the rest and relaxation that awaits them over the extended summer break.']
['How do they feel about it?', 'However, once they finish the semester, it doesn’t take too long before they begin to feel bored.']
['Do they feel bored during the summer?', 'Generally, by the time the next semester is beginning in the fall, many students are quite happy to return to school.']
['How does this affect them?', 'This is an example of how arousal theory works.']
["What is the main topic we're studying?", 'Research shows that moderate arousal is generally best; when arousal is very high or very low, performance tends to suffer (Yerkes & Dodson, 1908).']
['What did they study for the exam?', 'Think of your arousal level regarding taking an exam for this class.']
['What are your thoughts on arousal?', 'If your level is very low, such as boredom and apathy, your performance will likely suffer.']
['What happens if your level is too low?', 'Similarly, a very high level, such as extreme anxiety, can be paralyzing and hinder performance.']
['What does arousal do to your performance?', 'Consider the example of a softball team facing a tournament.']
['What happened to them?', 'They are favored to win their first game by a large margin, so they go into the game with a lower level of arousal and get beat by a less skilled team.']
['When is the middle level of arousal usually best?', 'But optimal arousal level is more complex than a simple answer that the middle level is always best.']

['What are the complexity and difficulty?', 'Researchers Robert Yerkes (pronounced “Yerk-EES”) and John Dodson discovered that the optimal arousal level depends on the complexity and difficulty of the task to be performed (Figure 10.7).']

['What is the relationship between arousal and performance of a task?', 'This relationship is known as Yerkes-Dodson law, which holds that a simple task is performed best when arousal levels are relatively high and complex tasks are best performed when arousal levels are lower.']

['What is an individual’s belief in their own capability to complete a task?', 'Self-efficacy is an individual’s belief in their own capability to complete a task, which may include a previous successful completion of the exact task or a similar task.']
['What did Albert Bandura theorize?', 'Albert Bandura (1994) theorized that an individual’s sense of self-efficacy plays a pivotal role in motivating behavior.']

['What does Bandura say about motivation?', 'Bandura argues that motivation derives from expectations that we have about the consequences of our behaviors, and ultimately, it is the appreciation of our capacity to engage in a given behavior that will determine what we do and the future goals that we set for ourselves.']

['What does he think about self-efficacy?', 'For example, if you have a sincere belief in your ability to achieve at the highest level, you are more likely to take on challenging tasks and to not let setbacks dissuade you from seeing the task through to the end.']

['What is the most important information in your introduction?', 'A number of theorists have focused their research on understanding social motives (McAdams & Constantian, 1983; McClelland & Liberman, 1949; Murray et al., 1938).']
['What are the social motives?', 'Among the motives they describe are needs for achievement, affiliation, and intimacy.']
['What does the need for achievement do to people?', 'It is the need for achievement that drives accomplishment and performance.']
['How does the need for intimacy affect people?', 'The need for affiliation encourages positive interactions with others, and the need for intimacy causes us to seek deep, meaningful relationships.']
['Who categorized these needs?', 'Henry Murray et al. (1938) categorized these needs into domains.']
['What are the domains of the need for achievement and recognition?', 'For example, the need for achievement and recognition falls under the domain of ambition.']
['What are other domains?', 'Dominance and aggression were recognized as needs under the domain of human power, and play was a recognized need in the domain of interpersonal affection.']

['What do these need hierarchies cover?', 'While the theories of motivation described earlier relate to basic biological drives, individual characteristics, or social contexts, Abraham Maslow (1943) proposed a hierarchy of needs that spans the spectrum of motives ranging from the biological to the individual to the social.']
['What are the needs depicted as in the pyramid?', 'These needs are often depicted as a pyramid (Figure 10.8).']
['What can you tell me about the base of the pyramid?', 'At the base of the pyramid are all of the physiological needs that are necessary for survival.']
['What are these basic needs?', 'These are followed by basic needs for security and safety, the need to be loved and to have a sense of belonging, and the need to have self-worth and confidence.']

['What is the top tier of the pyramid?', 'The top tier of the pyramid is self-actualization, which is a need that essentially equates to achieving one’s full potential, and it can only be realized when needs lower on the pyramid have been met.']
['What is special about self-actualization?', 'To Maslow and humanistic theorists, self-actualization reflects the humanistic emphasis on positive aspects of human nature.']

['How does it help?', 'Maslow suggested that this is an ongoing, life-long process and that only a small percentage of people actually achieve a self-actualized state (Francis & Kritsonis, 2006; Maslow, 1943).']
['how is this related to your study?', 'According to Maslow (1943), one must satisfy lower-level needs before addressing those needs that occur higher in the pyramid.']

['How is this related to your study?', 'So, for example, if someone is struggling to find enough food to meet their nutritional requirements, it is quite unlikely that they would spend an inordinate amount of time thinking about whether others viewed them as a good person or not.']
['How would you describe the energy of a lion?', 'Instead, all of their energies would be geared toward finding something to eat.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'However, it should be pointed out that Maslow’s theory has been criticized for its subjective nature and its inability to account for phenomena that occur in the real world (Leonard, 1982).']

["What is the relationship between Maslow's self-actualization and self-transcendence?", 'Other research has more recently addressed that late in life, Maslow proposed a self-transcendence level above self-actualization—to represent striving for meaning and purpose beyond the concerns of oneself (Koltko-Rivera, 2006).']
['What is self-transcendence?', 'For example, people sometimes make self-sacrifices in order to make a political statement or in an attempt to improve the conditions of others.']

['What did Mahatma Gandhi do to protest a particular situation?', 'Mohandas K. Gandhi, a world-renowned advocate for independence through nonviolent protest, on several occasions went on hunger strikes to protest a particular situation.']
['How is this related to your study?', 'People may starve themselves or otherwise put themselves in danger displaying higher-level motives beyond their own needs.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Eating is essential for survival, and it is no surprise that a drive like hunger exists to ensure that we seek out sustenance.']

["What is the body's regulation of hunger?", 'While this chapter will focus primarily on the physiological mechanisms that regulate hunger and eating, powerful social, cultural, and economic influences also play important roles.']
['What is one important aspect of this article?', 'This section will explain the regulation of hunger, eating, and body weight, and we will discuss the adverse consequences of disordered eating.']
['What are the physiological mechanisms that serve as the basis for hunger?', 'There are a number of physiological mechanisms that serve as the basis for hunger.']
['What happens when the stomach is empty?', 'When our stomachs are empty, they contract.']
['What happens after a person has eaten?', 'Typically, a person then experiences hunger pangs.']
['What is the function of chemical messages?', 'Chemical messages travel to the brain, and serve as a signal to initiate feeding behavior.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'When our blood glucose levels drop, the pancreas and liver generate a number of chemical signals that induce hunger (Konturek et al., 2003; Novin, Robinson, Culbreth, & Tordoff, 1985) and thus initiate feeding behavior.']
['What is the key concept of the passage?', 'For most people, once they have eaten, they feel satiation, or fullness and satisfaction, and their eating behavior stops.']
['What is satiation?', 'Like the initiation of eating, satiation is also regulated by several physiological mechanisms.']

['What is the most important fact in this article?', 'As blood glucose levels increase, the pancreas and liver send signals to shut off hunger and eating (Drazen & Woods, 2003; Druce, Small, & Bloom, 2004; Greary, 1990).']

['What happens after the food passes through the gastrointestinal tract?', 'The food’s passage through the gastrointestinal tract also provides important satiety signals to the brain (Woods, 2004), and fat cells release leptin, a satiety hormone.']
['What is it about?', 'The various hunger and satiety signals that are involved in the regulation of eating are integrated in the brain.']

['What part of the brain is this?', 'Research suggests that several areas of the hypothalamus and hindbrain are especially important sites where this integration occurs (Ahima & Antwi, 2008; Woods & D’Alessio, 2008).']
['What determines whether or not we engage in feeding behavior?', 'Ultimately, activity in the brain determines whether or not we engage in feeding behavior (Figure 10.9).']

["What are some of the topics that we'll be discussing today?", 'Our body weight is affected by a number of factors, including gene-environment interactions, and the number of calories we consume versus the number of calories we burn in daily activity.']
['What happens to your body when you consume too many calories?', 'If our caloric intake exceeds our caloric use, our bodies store excess energy in the form of fat.']
['What happens when you consume fewer calories than you burn off?', 'If we consume fewer calories than we burn off, then stored fat will be converted to energy.']
['What do you know about the relationship between calories and weight?', 'Our energy expenditure is obviously affected by our levels of activity, but our body’s metabolic rate also comes into play.']

['What is the amount of energy that is expended in a given period of time?', 'A person’s metabolic rate is the amount of energy that is expended in a given period of time, and there is tremendous individual variability in our metabolic rates.']
['What does the variability mean?', 'People with high rates of metabolism are able to burn off calories more easily than those with lower rates of metabolism.']

['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'We all experience fluctuations in our weight from time to time, but generally, most people’s weights fluctuate within a narrow margin, in the absence of extreme changes in diet and/or physical activity.']
['What is the set-point theory of body weight regulation?', 'This observation led some to propose a set-point theory of body weight regulation.']
['What is the set-point theory?', 'The set-point theory asserts that each individual has an ideal body weight, or set point, which is resistant to change.']

['What is the proof that weight is genetically predetermined?', 'This set-point is genetically predetermined and efforts to move our weight significantly from the set-point are resisted by compensatory changes in energy intake and/or expenditure (Speakman et al., 2011).']
['What does the paper say about the predictions generated from this particular theory?', 'Some of the predictions generated from this particular theory have not received empirical support.']

['What are some of the predictions that are unsupported?', 'For example, there are no changes in metabolic rate between individuals who had recently lost significant amounts of weight and a control group (Weinsier et al., 2000).']

['Did the paper discuss any other unsupported hypotheses?', 'In addition, the set-point theory fails to account for the influence of social and environmental factors in the regulation of body weight (Martin-Gronert & Ozanne, 2013; Speakman et al., 2011).']
['What is the rationale for the theory being limited?', 'Despite these limitations, set-point theory is still often used as a simple, intuitive explanation of how body weight is regulated.']
['What other theories did they discuss?', 'See Psychological Disorders for further discussion about eating disorders.']
['What is the term for overweight or obese?', 'When someone weighs more than what is generally accepted as healthy for a given height, they are considered overweight or obese.']

["What's the definition of overweight?", 'According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), an adult with a body mass index (BMI) between 25 and 29.9 is considered overweight (Figure 10.10).']
['What is the definition of obese?', 'An adult with a BMI of 30 or higher is considered obese (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2012).']
['What is morbid obesity?', 'People who are so overweight that they are at risk for death are classified as morbidly obese.']
['What is the definition of morbid obesity?', 'Morbid obesity is defined as having a BMI over 40.']

['What is the healthy weight indicator?', 'Note that although BMI has been used as a healthy weight indicator by the World Health Organization (WHO), the CDC, and other groups, its value as an assessment tool has been questioned.']
['What is the BMI?', 'The BMI is most useful for studying populations, which is the work of these organizations.']
['What is significant about the study?', 'It is less useful in assessing an individual since height and weight measurements fail to account for important factors like fitness level.']
['How does fitness level affect weight?', 'An athlete, for example, may have a high BMI because the tool doesn’t distinguish between the body’s percentage of fat and muscle in a person’s weight.']
['What are the health consequences of obesity?', 'Being extremely overweight or obese is a risk factor for several negative health consequences.']

['What are some of the health consequences of obesity?', 'These include, but are not limited to, an increased risk for cardiovascular disease, stroke, Type 2 diabetes, liver disease, sleep apnea, colon cancer, breast cancer, infertility, and arthritis.']

['Is obesity a public health concern?', 'Given that it is estimated that in the United States around forty percent of the adult population is obese and that nearly three-quarters of adults and one in six children qualify as overweight (CDC, 2018), there is substantial interest in trying to understand how to combat this important public health concern.']

['What can you tell me about genes and environment in the Obesity document?', 'You have already read that both genes and environment are important factors for determining body weight, and if more calories are consumed than expended, excess energy is stored as fat.']
['What else is important about genes and environment?', 'However, socioeconomic status and the physical environment must also be considered as contributing factors (CDC, 2012).']

['How are these factors related to the physical environment?', 'For example, an individual who lives in a neighborhood with high crime rates and few food options may never feel comfortable walking or biking to work or to the local market.']
['What might they do if they are unable to exercise?', 'This might limit the amount of physical activity in which they engage.']

['What other factors are important?', 'Similarly, some people may not be able to afford healthy food options from their market, or these options may be unavailable (especially in urban areas or poorer neighborhoods); therefore, some people must rely primarily on available, inexpensive, high fat, and high calorie fast food as their primary source of nutrition.']
['What is the most important information provided?', 'Generally, people are encouraged to try to maintain and improve health through a combination of both diet and exercise.']
['What about with diet alone?', 'While some people are very successful with these approaches, many are not.']
['Why is this?', 'In cases in which a person has had no success with repeated attempts to reduce weight or is at risk for death because of obesity, bariatric surgery may be recommended.']

['What is bariatric surgery?', 'Bariatric surgery is a type of surgery specifically aimed at weight reduction, and it involves modifying the gastrointestinal system to reduce the amount of food that can be eaten and/or limiting how much of the digested food can be absorbed (Figure 10.11) (Mayo Clinic, 2013).']

['What is the name of the meta-analysis that suggests bariatric surgery is more effective than non-surgical treatment for obesity in the two-years immediately following the procedure, but to date, no long-term studies yet exist?', 'A recent meta-analysis suggests that bariatric surgery is more effective than non-surgical treatment for obesity in the two-years immediately following the procedure, but to date, no long-term studies yet exist (Gloy et al., 2013).']

['What is the result of eating disorders?', 'While nearly two out of three US adults struggle with issues related to being overweight, a smaller, but significant, portion of the population has eating disorders that typically result in being normal weight or underweight.']
['How do those suffer from eating disorders feel?', 'Often, these individuals are fearful of gaining weight.']
['What are the health risks from eating disorders?', 'Individuals who have bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa face many adverse health consequences (Mayo Clinic, 2012a, 2012b).']
['What is the cause of bulimia?', 'People suffering from bulimia nervosa engage in binge eating behavior that is followed by an attempt to compensate for the large amount of food consumed.']
['How do they try to compensate for the food they ate?', 'Purging the food by inducing vomiting or through the use of laxatives are two common compensatory behaviors.']
['How do some people try to compensate for their binges?', 'Some affected individuals engage in excessive amounts of exercise to compensate for their binges.']
['What are the health complications of this?', 'Bulimia is associated with many adverse health consequences that can include kidney failure, heart failure, and tooth decay.']

['What are some of the other health issues that can be caused by a traumatic brain injury?', 'In addition, these individuals often suffer from anxiety and depression, and they are at an increased risk for substance abuse (Mayo Clinic, 2012b).']

['What is the lifetime prevalence rate for bulimia nervosa?', 'The lifetime prevalence rate for bulimia nervosa is estimated at around 1% for women and less than 0.5% for men (Smink, van Hoeken, & Hoek, 2012).']

['What is the difference between eating disorders and obesity?', 'As of the 2013 release of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, fifth edition, Binge eating disorder is a disorder recognized by the American Psychiatric Association (APA).']

['What are some symptoms of binge eating disorder?', 'Unlike with bulimia, eating binges are not followed by inappropriate behavior, such as purging, but they are followed by distress, including feelings of guilt and embarrassment.']

['Are there any other distinguishing characteristics of this disorder?', 'The resulting psychological distress distinguishes binge eating disorder from overeating (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2013).']
['What is anorexia nervosa?', 'Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by the maintenance of a body weight well below average through starvation and/or excessive exercise.']

['What are some symptoms of the eating disorder?', 'Individuals with anorexia nervosa often have a distorted body image, referenced in literature as a type of body dysmorphia, meaning that they view themselves as overweight even though they are not.']

['Do eating disorders cause health problems?', 'Like bulimia nervosa, anorexia nervosa is associated with a number of significant negative health outcomes: bone loss, heart failure, kidney failure, amenorrhea (cessation of the menstrual period), reduced function of the gonads, and in extreme cases, death.']

['What else is the health problems?', 'Furthermore, there is an increased risk for a number of psychological problems, which include anxiety disorders, mood disorders, and substance abuse (Mayo Clinic, 2012a).']

['What is the prevalence of anorexia nervosa?', 'Estimates of the prevalence of anorexia nervosa vary from study to study but generally range from just under one percent to just over four percent in women.']
['Are there any prevalence rates for men?', 'Generally, prevalence rates are considerably lower for men (Smink et al., 2012).']

['What do we read in that section?', 'While both anorexia and bulimia nervosa occur in people from many different cultures, White females from Western societies tend to be the most at-risk population.']

["What's interesting in the article?", 'Recent research indicates that females between the ages of 15 and 19 are most at risk, and it has long been suspected that these eating disorders are culturally-bound phenomena that are related to messages of a thin ideal often portrayed in popular media and the fashion world (Figure 10.13) (Smink et al., 2012).']

['What is significant about the development of eating disorders?', 'While social factors play an important role in the development of eating disorders, there is also evidence that genetic factors may predispose people to these disorders (Collier & Treasure, 2004).']
['What do you like about food?', "Like food, sex is an important part of many people's lives."]
['What can you tell me about sex?', 'From an evolutionary perspective, the reason is obvious—perpetuation of the species.']
['What else is sex?', 'Sexual behavior in humans, however, involves much more than reproduction.']
['What is the main idea of this section?', 'This section provides an overview of research that has been conducted on human sexual behavior and motivation.']
['What will we learn about?', 'This section will close with a discussion of issues related to gender identity and expression and sexual orientation.']
['What kind of animal research is this?', 'Much of what we know about the physiological mechanisms that underlie sexual behavior and motivation comes from animal research.']
['What is the hypothalamus involved in?', 'As you’ve learned, the hypothalamus plays an important role in motivated behaviors, and sex is no exception.']
['What else is notable about hypothalamus?', 'In fact, lesions to an area of the hypothalamus called the medial preoptic area completely disrupt a male rat’s ability to engage in sexual behavior.']
['Why does it disrupt sexual behavior?', 'Surprisingly, medial preoptic lesions do not change how hard a male rat is willing to work to gain access to a sexually receptive female (Figure 10.14).']

['What did this study suggest about sexual behavior?', 'This suggests that the ability to engage in sexual behavior and the motivation to do so may be mediated by neural systems distinct from one another.']

['What are the structures of the limbic system important for?', 'Animal research suggests that limbic system structures such as the amygdala and nucleus accumbens are especially important for sexual motivation.']
['Why do they matter?', 'Damage to these areas results in a decreased motivation to engage in sexual behavior, while leaving the ability to do so intact (Figure 10.15) (Everett, 1990).']
['What is the article about?', 'Similar dissociations of sexual motivation and sexual ability have also been observed in the female rat (Becker, Rudick, & Jenkins, 2001; Jenkins & Becker, 2001).']
['What did the article cover?', 'Although human sexual behavior is much more complex than that seen in rats, some parallels between animals and humans can be drawn from this research.']

['What are some examples of these parallels?', 'The worldwide popularity of drugs used to treat erectile dysfunction (Conrad, 2005) speaks to the fact that sexual motivation and the ability to engage in sexual behavior can also be dissociated in humans.']

['What is another example of a disorder that involves abnormal hypothalamic function?', 'Moreover, disorders that involve abnormal hypothalamic function are often associated with hypogonadism (reduced function of the gonads) and reduced sexual function (e.g., Prader-Willi syndrome).']

['What role did the hypothalamus play?', 'Given the hypothalamus’s role in endocrine function, it is not surprising that hormones secreted by the endocrine system also play important roles in sexual motivation and behavior.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'For example, many animals show no sign of sexual motivation in the absence of the appropriate combination of sex hormones from their gonads.']
