['What is the main reason for this?', 'While this is not the case for humans, there is considerable evidence that sexual motivation for all genders varies as a function of circulating testosterone levels (Bhasin, Enzlin, Coviello, & Basson, 2007; Carter, 1992; Sherwin, 1988).']
["What was Kinsey's research?", 'Before the late 1940s, access to reliable, empirically-based information on sex was limited.']

['What was the result of that?', 'Physicians were considered authorities on all issues related to sex, despite the fact that they had little to no training in these issues, and it is likely that most of what people knew about sex had been learned either through their own experiences or by talking with their peers.']

['Why did Kinsey start research?', 'Convinced that people would benefit from a more open dialogue on issues related to human sexuality, Dr. Alfred Kinsey of Indiana University initiated large-scale survey research on the topic (Figure 10.16).']

['What was his research on?', 'The results of some of these efforts were published in two books—Sexual Behavior in the Human Male and Sexual Behavior in the Human Female—which were published in 1948 and 1953, respectively (Bullough, 1998).']
['What was the reaction to the Kinsey reports?', 'At the time, the Kinsey reports were quite sensational.']
['What else can you tell me about sensational?', 'Never before had the American public seen its private sexual behavior become the focus of scientific scrutiny on such a large scale.']

['What else can you tell me about sensational?', 'The books, which were filled with statistics and scientific lingo, sold remarkably well to the general public, and people began to engage in open conversations about human sexuality.']
['How did the public react to the information being published?', 'As you might imagine, not everyone was happy that this information was being published.']
['What did the public think of this information?', 'In fact, these books were banned in some countries.']

['What did the controversy result in for Kinsey?', 'Ultimately, the controversy resulted in Kinsey losing funding that he had secured from the Rockefeller Foundation to continue his research efforts (Bancroft, 2004).']

['What kind of controversy does this research cause?', 'Although Kinsey’s research has been widely criticized as being riddled with sampling and statistical errors (Jenkins, 2010), there is little doubt that this research was very influential in shaping future research on human sexual behavior and motivation.']

['What is the most important point you can make with this research?', 'Kinsey described a remarkably diverse range of sexual behaviors and experiences reported by the volunteers participating in his research.']

['What are some other significant findings of this research?', 'Behaviors that had once been considered exceedingly rare or problematic were demonstrated to be much more common and innocuous than previously imagined (Bancroft, 2004; Bullough, 1998).']

['What were some of the findings of Kinsey’s research?', 'Among the results of Kinsey’s research were the findings that women are as interested and experienced in sex as men, that both males and females masturbate without adverse health consequences, and that relationships and sexual acts between people of the same sex and/or the same gender are fairly common (Bancroft, 2004).']

['What did he find?', 'Kinsey also developed a continuum known as the Kinsey scale that is still commonly used today to categorize an individual’s sexual orientation, which is an individual’s emotional, romantic, and erotic attractions to other people or no people (Jenkins, 2010).']

['what happened in 1966?', 'In 1966, William Masters and Virginia Johnson published a book detailing the results of their observations of nearly 700 people who agreed to participate in their study of physiological responses during sexual behavior.']

['what other aspects of the book were important?', 'Unlike Kinsey, who used personal interviews and surveys to collect data, Masters and Johnson observed people having intercourse in a variety of positions, and they observed people masturbating, manually or with the aid of a device.']

['what type of device?', 'While this was occurring, researchers recorded measurements of physiological variables, such as blood pressure and respiration rate, as well as measurements of sexual arousal, such as vaginal lubrication and penile tumescence (swelling associated with an erection).']
['How many sexual acts did Masters and Johnson observe?', 'In total, Masters and Johnson observed nearly 10,000 sexual acts as a part of their research (Hock, 2008).']

['What did Masters and Johnson divide the sexual response cycle into?', 'Based on these observations, Masters and Johnson divided the sexual response cycle into four phases that are fairly similar in men and women: excitement, plateau, orgasm, and resolution (Figure 10.17).']

['What is the arousal phase of the sexual response cycle?', 'The excitement phase is the arousal phase of the sexual response cycle, and it is marked by erection of the penis or clitoris and lubrication and expansion of the vaginal canal.']
['What is the plateau phase?', 'During plateau, the vagina swells further and blood flow to the labia minora increases, and the penis becomes fully erect and may exhibit pre-ejaculatory fluid.']
['What else can you tell me about the plateau phase?', 'People experience increases in muscle tone during this time.']
['What is the orgasm phase?', 'Orgasm is marked in females by rhythmic contractions of the pelvis and uterus along with increased muscle tension.']

['What is the buildup of seminal fluid near the urethra called?', 'In males, pelvic contractions are accompanied by a buildup of seminal fluid near the urethra that is ultimately forced out by contractions of genital muscles, (i.e., ejaculation).']

['What is the relatively rapid return to an unaroused state accompanied by a decrease in blood pressure and muscular relaxation?', 'Resolution is the relatively rapid return to an unaroused state accompanied by a decrease in blood pressure and muscular relaxation.']
['What is the refractory period?', 'The refractory period is a period of time that follows an orgasm during which an individual is incapable of experiencing another orgasm.']

['What is the duration of the refractory period?', 'The duration of the refractory period can vary dramatically from individual to individual with some refractory periods as short as several minutes and others as long as a day.']
['What is another interesting fact?', 'As people age, their refractory periods tend to span longer periods of time.']

['What insights did Masters and Johnson provide with regards to the sexual response cycle and the multi-orgasmic potential of females?', 'In addition to the insights that their research provided with regards to the sexual response cycle and the multi-orgasmic potential of females, Masters and Johnson also collected important information about reproductive anatomy.']

['How did the research show anything about sexual response?', 'Their research demonstrated the oft-cited statistic of the average size of a flaccid and an erect penis (3 and 6 inches, respectively) as well as dispelling long-held beliefs about relationships between the size of an erect penis and its ability to provide sexual pleasure to a partner.']
['What did the research show about sexual response?', 'Furthermore, they determined that the vagina is a very elastic structure that can conform to penises of various sizes (Hock, 2008).']

['Did Masters and Johnson’s research have any criticism?', 'In a similar manner to Kinsey’s work and other studies, Masters and Johnson’s research has been criticized, built on, and in some cases proven wrong.']
['What is the most important thing to know about the research?', 'The research represents an important element of the history of sexual research, and is not viewed as entirely accurate today.']
['What can you tell me about sexual orientation?', 'As mentioned earlier, a person’s sexual orientation is their emotional, romantic, and erotic attraction toward other people or no people.']

['Are there specific sexual orientations?', 'While the majority of people identify as heterosexual, there is a sizable population of people within the United States who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, pansexual, asexual, or other non-hetero sexualities.']

['How do the orientations differ?', 'Bisexual people are attracted to people of their own gender and another gender; pansexual people experience attraction without regard to sex, gender identity or gender expression; asexual people do not experience sexual attraction or have little or no interest in sexual activity.']

['What is an umbrella term used to describe sexual orientation, gender identity, or gender expression?', 'Queer is an umbrella term used to describe sexual orientation, gender identity, or gender expression.']
['What are the descriptive terms for a sexual attraction?', 'Other descriptive terms may not refer to a sexual attraction, but rather a romantic one.']

['What are the terms for a person who does not experience romantic attraction?', 'For example, an aromantic person does not experience romantic attraction; this is different from asexuality, which refers to a lack of sexual attraction.']
['What is another example of a sexual orientation that does not refer to gender in its description?', 'And some sexual orientations do not refer to gender in their description (PFLAG, 2021).']

['Do you know any other things about sexual orientation?', 'It is important to acknowledge and understand that many of these orientations exist on on a spectrum, and there may be no specific term to describe how an individual feels.']

['What are some definitions and information on these terms?', 'Some of these terms have been associated in abbreviations such as LGBTQ (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer or questioning).']

['What are some other terms that have been used?', 'In some cases, people and organizations may add "I" to represent intersex people (described below), and "A" for asexual or aromantic people (or sometimes for "allies"), as well as one "P" to describe pansexual people and sometimes another "P" to describe polysexual people.']
['What else can you tell me about these terms?', 'Finally, some people and organizations add a plus sign (+) to represent other possible identities or orientations.']

['What is the most important thing to know about sexual orientation?', 'Sexuality and gender terminology are constantly changing, and may mean different things to different people; they are not universal, and each individual defines them for themselves (UC Davis LGBTQIA Resource Center 2020).']
['What is it about?', 'Issues of sexual orientation have long fascinated scientists interested in determining what causes one individual to be straight while another is gay.']

['What is the main reason for the differences in the brains of different people?', 'For many years, people believed that these differences arose because of different socialization and familial experiences.']

['Do those studies prove it?', 'However, research has consistently demonstrated that the family backgrounds and experiences are very similar among straight people and LGBTQ people (Bell, Weinberg, & Hammersmith, 1981; Ross & Arrindell, 1988).']

['What are some important facts about sexual orientation?', 'Genetic and biological mechanisms have also been proposed, and the balance of research evidence suggests that sexual orientation has an underlying biological component.']

['What is evidence of this?', 'For instance, over the past 25 years, research has demonstrated gene-level contributions to sexual orientation (Bailey & Pillard, 1991; Hamer, Hu, Magnuson, Hu, & Pattatucci, 1993; Rodriguez-Larralde & Paradisi, 2009), with some researchers estimating that genes account for at least half of the variability seen in human sexual orientation (Pillard & Bailey, 1998).']

['How else does science back this claim up?', 'Other studies report differences in brain structure and function among those with different sexual orientations (Allen & Gorski, 1992; Byne et al., 2001; Hu et al., 2008; LeVay, 1991; Ponseti et al., 2006; Rahman & Wilson, 2003a; Swaab & Hofman, 1990), and even differences in basic body structure and function have been observed (Hall & Kimura, 1994; Lippa, 2003; Loehlin & McFadden, 2003; McFadden & Champlin, 2000; McFadden & Pasanen, 1998; Rahman & Wilson, 2003b).']
['What do you need to know about sexual orientation to know it is genetic?', 'In aggregate, the data suggest that to a significant extent, sexual orientations are something with which we are born.']

['What is one of the most important points from the article?', 'Regardless of how sexual orientation is determined, research has made clear that sexual orientation is not a choice, but rather it is a relatively stable characteristic of a person that cannot be changed.']

['What are the results of conversion therapy?', 'Claims of effective conversion therapy have received wide criticism from the research community due to significant concerns with research design, recruitment of experimental participants, and interpretation of data.']
['What is one of the most important points about this study?', 'As such, there is no credible scientific evidence to suggest that individuals can change their sexual orientation (Jenkins, 2010).']

['What did Dr. Robert Spitzer do in the letter?', 'Dr. Robert Spitzer, the author of one of the most widely-cited examples of conversion therapy, apologized to both the scientific community and the LGBTQ community for his mistakes, and he publically recanted his own paper in a public letter addressed to the editor of Archives of Sexual Behavior in the spring of 2012 (Carey, 2012).']
['What did Spitzer write in this letter?', 'In this letter, Spitzer wrote,']
['What is gender identity?', 'Many people conflate sexual orientation with gender identity because of misconceptions and attitudes that exist about sexuality.']
['What do you think of gender identity?', 'In reality, these are two related, but different, aspects of who we are.']
['What is gender identity?', 'Gender identity refers to one’s sense of being male, female, neither of these, both of these, or another gender.']
['What is the relationship between gender identity and sex?', 'Generally, our gender identities correspond to our chromosomal and phenotypic sex, but this is not always the case.']
['What is the difference between a male and female gender?', 'Transgender people’s gender identity differs from the sex they were assigned at birth.']
['What are other ways of describing gender identity?', 'Transgender people may use a range of terms to describe themselves, including abbreviations (e.g. trans) or terms such as non-binary.']
['What does gender dysphoria mean?', 'When individuals do not feel comfortable identifying with the gender associated with their biological sex, then they may experience gender dysphoria.']

['What is gender dysphoria?', 'Gender dysphoria is a diagnostic category in the fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) that describes individuals who do not identify as the gender that most people would assume they are.']
['What is the definition of dysphoria?', 'This dysphoria must persist for at least six months and result in significant distress or dysfunction to meet DSM-5 diagnostic criteria.']
['Do they have to verbalize their desire to become the other gender?', 'In order for children to be assigned this diagnostic category, they must verbalize their desire to become the other gender.']

['Do all transgender people experience gender dysphoria?', 'It is important to note that not all transgender people experience gender dysphoria, and that its diagnostic categorization is not universally accepted.']

['What does this mean?', 'For example, in 2019, the World Health Organization reclassified “gender identity disorder” as “gender incongruence,” and categorized it under sexual health rather than a mental disorder.']

['What is the response to the question?', 'However, health and mental health professionals indicate that the presence of the diagnostic category does assist in supporting those who need treatment or help.']

['What is transition?', 'Some transgender individuals may undertake a process of transition, in which they move from living in a way that is more aligned with the sex assigned at birth to living in a way that is aligned with their gender identity.']

['What are some other things involved in transitioning?', "Transitioning may take the form of social, legal, or medical aspects of someone's life, but not everyone undertakes any or all types of transition."]
['How does social transition help?', "Social transition may involve the person's presentation, name, pronouns, and relationships."]
['What does legal transition involve?', 'Legal transition can include changing their gender on government or other official documents, changing their legal name, and so on.']

['What is medical transition?', 'Some people may undergo a physical or medical transition, in which they change their outward, physical, or sexual characteristics in order for their physical being to better align with their gender identity (UCSF Transgender Care 2019).']

['What is another type of transition?', 'Not all transgender individuals choose to alter their bodies: many will maintain their original anatomy but may present themselves to society as another gender.']
['How do they present themselves?', 'This is typically done by adopting the dress, hairstyle, mannerisms, or other characteristics typically assigned to another gender.']

['What else should you know about transition?', 'It is important to note that people who cross-dress, or wear clothing that is traditionally assigned to a gender different from their biological sex, are not necessarily transgender.']

['What does cross-dressing mean?', "Cross-dressing is typically a form of self-expression or personal style, and it does not indicate a person's gender identity or that they are transgender (TSER 2021)."]

['What is the term for people whose sex traits, reproductive anatomy, hormones, or chromosomes are different from the usual two ways human bodies develop?', 'Intersex is a general term used to describe people whose sex traits, reproductive anatomy, hormones, or chromosomes are different from the usual two ways human bodies develop.']
['How do people learn that they are intersex?', 'Some intersex traits are recognized at birth, while others are not recognizable until puberty or later in life (interACT 2021).']

['Are there different views on transgender?', 'Intersex and transgender are not interchangeable terms; many transgender people have no intersex traits, and many intersex people do not consider themselves transgender.']

['What is the term for those who identify with the sex they were assigned at birth?', 'Those who identify with the sex they were assigned at birth are often referred to as cisgender, utilizing the Latin prefix "cis," which means "on the same side."']
['What does the prefix "trans" mean?', '(The prefix "trans" means "across.")']
['What is cisgender?', 'Many cisgender people do not self-identify as such.']
['What does it indicate?', "As with transgender people, the term or usage of cisgender does not indicate a person's sexual orientation, gender, or gender expression (TSER 2021)."]

['What is the most recent study about gender identity?', 'Our scientific knowledge and general understanding about gender identity continue to evolve, and young people today have more opportunity to explore and openly express different ideas about what gender means than previous generations.']

['What do most millennials regard gender as?', 'Recent studies indicate that the majority of millennials (those ages 18–34) regard gender as a spectrum instead of a strict male/female binary, and that 12% identify as transgender or gender non-conforming.']
['What did the studies show?', 'Additionally, more people know others who use gender-neutral pronouns (such as they/them) (Kennedy, 2017).']
['What can this say about millennials?', 'This change in language may indicate that millennials and Generation Z people understand the experience of gender itself differently.']
['What else can you tell me about gender identity?', 'As young people lead this change, other changes are emerging in a range of spheres, from public bathroom policies to retail organizations.']
['What changes are emerging?', 'For example, some retailers are starting to change traditional gender-based marketing of products, such as removing “pink and blue” clothing and toy aisles.']
['What is the biggest change?', 'Even with these changes, those who exist outside of traditional gender norms face difficult challenges.']
['Are they still forced to follow traditional gender norms?', 'Even people who vary slightly from traditional norms are often the target of discrimination and violence.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Issues related to sexual orientation and gender identity are very much influenced by sociocultural factors.']
['How do we define sexual orientation and gender?', 'Even the ways in which we define sexual orientation and gender vary from one culture to the next.']

['What does this mean?', 'While in the United States heterosexuality has historically been viewed as the norm (making it a heteronormative society), there are societies that have different attitudes regarding LGBTQ people.']

['Are there other cultures with different attitudes?', 'In fact, in some instances, periods of exclusively same-sex sexual behavior are socially prescribed as a part of normal development and maturation.']

['In what parts of the world is this practice prevalent?', 'For example, in parts of New Guinea, young boys are expected to engage in sexual behavior with other boys for a given period of time because it is believed that doing so is necessary for these boys to become men (Baldwin & Baldwin, 1989).']
['What was the US gendered culture like?', 'There has historically been a two-gendered culture in the United States.']

['What else is significant about this?', 'We have tended to classify an individual as either male or female according to the sex they were assigned at birth, leading the United States to be considered a cisnormative society.']
['What can you tell me about this culture?', 'However, in some cultures there are additional gender variants resulting in more than two gender categories.']
['What other cultures have gender variants?', 'For example, in Thailand, you can be male, female, or kathoey.']
['What is kathoey?', 'A kathoey is an individual who would be described as intersex or transgender in the United States (Tangmunkongvorakul, Banwell, Carmichael, Utomo, & Sleigh, 2010).']
['What are some important points to learn from the content?', 'As we move through our daily lives, we experience a variety of emotions.']
['What does an emotion mean to you?', 'An emotion is a subjective state of being that we often describe as our feelings.']

['What do emotions result from?', 'Emotions result from the combination of subjective experience, expression, cognitive appraisal, and physiological responses (Levenson, Carstensen, Friesen, & Ekman, 1991).']

['How do these components contribute to emotion?', 'However, as discussed later in the chapter, the exact order in which the components occur is not clear, and some parts may happen at the same time.']
['What does an emotion begin with?', 'An emotion often begins with a subjective (individual) experience, which is a stimulus.']
['What is the stimulus?', 'Often the stimulus is external, but it does not have to be from the outside world.']
['What does this mean?', 'For example, it might be that one thinks about war and becomes sad, even though they never experienced war.']
['What is the way one displays an emotion called?', 'Emotional expression refers to the way one displays an emotion and includes nonverbal and verbal behaviors (Gross, 1999).']

['What else is included in emotional expression?', 'One also performs a cognitive appraisal in which a person tries to determine the way they will be impacted by a situation (Roseman & Smith, 2001).']
['What other aspects are part of emotional expression?', 'In addition, emotions include physiological responses, such as possible changes in heart rate, sweating, etc. (Soussignan, 2002).']
['What are the two different things emotion and mood refers to?', 'The words emotion and mood are sometimes used interchangeably, but psychologists use these words to refer to two different things.']

['What does the word emotion indicate?', 'Typically, the word emotion indicates a subjective, affective state that is relatively intense and that occurs in response to something we experience (Figure 10.20).']
['What are the ways in which emotions are experienced?', 'Emotions are often thought to be consciously experienced and intentional.']
['How is mood different from emotion?', 'Mood, on the other hand, refers to a prolonged, less intense, affective state that does not occur in response to something we experience.']

['What is the difference between mood states and emotion?', 'Mood states may not be consciously recognized and do not carry the intentionality that is associated with emotion (Beedie, Terry, Lane, & Devonport, 2011).']
['Do you want me to tell you more about mood?', 'Here we will focus on emotion, and you will learn more about mood in the chapter that covers psychological disorders.']
['What are the different kinds of emotions?', 'We can be at the heights of joy or in the depths of despair.']
['Why might we feel angry?', 'We might feel angry when we are betrayed, fear when we are threatened, and surprised when something unexpected happens.']
['What do emotions make us feel?', 'This section will outline some of the most well-known theories explaining our emotional experience and provide insight into the biological bases of emotion.']
['What is the section about?', 'This section closes with a discussion of the ubiquitous nature of facial expressions of emotion and our abilities to recognize those expressions in others.']
['What are the components of our emotional states?', 'Our emotional states are combinations of physiological arousal, psychological appraisal, and subjective experiences.']
['What are the components of emotion?', 'Together, these are the components of emotion, and our experiences, backgrounds, and cultures inform our emotions.']
['Do people experience emotions in the same ways?', 'Therefore, different people may have different emotional experiences even when faced with similar circumstances.']

['How do the various components interact?', 'Over time, several different theories of emotion, shown in Figure 10.21, have been proposed to explain how the various components of emotion interact with one another.']
['What does the James-Lange theory of emotion assert?', 'The James-Lange theory of emotion asserts that emotions arise from physiological arousal.']
['What is the fight or flight response?', 'Recall what you have learned about the sympathetic nervous system and our fight or flight response when threatened.']

['What happens during flight response?', 'If you were to encounter some threat in your environment, like a venomous snake in your backyard, your sympathetic nervous system would initiate significant physiological arousal, which would make your heart race and increase your respiration rate.']
['Is this what produces emotions?', 'According to the James-Lange theory of emotion, you would only experience a feeling of fear after this physiological arousal had taken place.']
['What does it say about arousal patterns?', 'Furthermore, different arousal patterns would be associated with different feelings.']

['What is the most important point of the text?', 'Other theorists, however, doubted that the physiological arousal that occurs with different types of emotions is distinct enough to result in the wide variety of emotions that we experience.']
['What was the result of their doubts?', 'Thus, the Cannon-Bard theory of emotion was developed.']
['Why is it important to understand this theory?', 'According to this view, physiological arousal and emotional experience occur simultaneously, yet independently (Lang, 1994).']
['What happened after Lang published this theory?', 'So, when you see the venomous snake, you feel fear at exactly the same time that your body mounts its fight or flight response.']
['What does this tell us about the theory?', 'This emotional reaction would be separate and independent of the physiological arousal, even though they co-occur.']

['What is the facial feedback hypothesis?', 'The facial feedback hypothesis proposes that your facial expression can actually affect your emotional experience (Adelman & Zajonc, 1989; Boiger & Mesquita, 2012; Buck, 1980; Capella, 1993; Soussignan, 2001).']

['What is the evidence for the facial feedback hypothesis?', 'Research investigating the facial feedback hypothesis suggested that suppression of facial expression of emotion lowered the intensity of some emotions experienced by participants (Davis, Senghas, & Ochsner, 2009).']

['What else is known about this hypothesis?', 'Havas, Glenberg, Gutowski, Lucarelli, and Davidson (2010) used Botox injections to paralyze facial muscles and limit facial expressions, including frowning, and they found that depressed people reported less depression after their frowning muscles were paralyzed.']
['What is known about this hypothesis?', 'Other research found that the intensities of facial expressions affected the emotional reactions (Soussignan, 2002).']

['What is the most interesting thing you learned in the article?', 'In other words, if something insignificant occurs and you smile as if you just won lottery, you will actually be happier about the little thing than you would be if you only had a tiny smile.']

['What can you tell me about the facial feedback hypothesis?', 'Conversely, if you walk around frowning all the time, it might cause you to have less positive emotions than you would if you had smiled.']
['What else do you learn about this hypothesis?', 'Interestingly, Soussignan (2002) also reported physiological arousal differences associated with the intensities of one type of smile.']
['Who was the Spanish physician?', 'G. Marañon Posadillo was a Spanish physician who studied the psychological effects of adrenaline to create a model for the experience of emotion.']
['What was the two factor theory?', "Marañon's model preceded Schachter's two-factor or arousal-cognition theory of emotion (Cornelius, 1991)."]

['What is the Schachter-Singer two-factor theory of emotion about?', 'The Schachter-Singer two-factor theory of emotion is another variation on theories of emotions that takes into account both physiological arousal and the emotional experience.']
['What else is it?', 'According to this theory, emotions are composed of two factors: physiological and cognitive.']
['What does this theory say?', 'In other words, physiological arousal is interpreted in context to produce the emotional experience.']

['How so?', 'In revisiting our example involving the venomous snake in your backyard, the two-factor theory maintains that the snake elicits sympathetic nervous system activation that is labeled as fear given the context, and our experience is that of fear.']
['What else would you have experienced?', 'If you had labeled your sympathetic nervous system activation as joy, you would have experienced joy.']
['What other theories are there?', 'The Schachter-Singer two-factor theory depends on labeling the physiological experience, which is a type of cognitive appraisal.']

['What is one key fact about Magda Arnold?', 'Magda Arnold was the first theorist to offer an exploration of the meaning of appraisal, and to present an outline of what the appraisal process might be and how it relates to emotion (Roseman & Smith, 2001).']

['What is the key idea of appraisal theory?', 'The key idea of appraisal theory is that you have thoughts (a cognitive appraisal) before you experience an emotion, and the emotion you experience depends on the thoughts you had (Frijda, 1988; Lazarus, 1991).']
['What are some examples of appraisal?', 'If you think something is positive, you will have more positive emotions about it than if your appraisal was negative, and the opposite is true.']
['What is another example of appraisal theory?', 'Appraisal theory explains the way two people can have two completely different emotions regarding the same event.']

['Why do they have two completely different emotions?', 'For example, suppose your psychology instructor selected you to lecture on emotion; you might see that as positive, because it represents an opportunity to be the center of attention, and you would experience happiness.']
['What would you experience if you dislike speaking in public?', 'However, if you dislike speaking in public, you could have a negative appraisal and experience discomfort.']

['What are some of the more important parts of the article?', 'Schachter and Singer believed that physiological arousal is very similar across the different types of emotions that we experience, and therefore, the cognitive appraisal of the situation is critical to the actual emotion experienced.']

['What might be possible to misattribute arousal to an emotional experience if the circumstances were right (Schachter & Singer, 1962)?', 'In fact, it might be possible to misattribute arousal to an emotional experience if the circumstances were right (Schachter & Singer, 1962).']
['What was one of the experiments they did?', 'They performed a clever experiment to test their idea.']
['What did they do?', 'A group of men participating in the experiment were randomly assigned to one of several groups.']

['What happened to the group of men?', 'Some of the participants received injections of epinephrine that caused bodily changes that mimicked the fight-or-flight response of the sympathetic nervous system; however, only some of these men were told to expect these reactions as side effects of the injection.']

['What else did they do in the experiment?', 'The other men that received injections of epinephrine were told either that the injection would have no side effects or that it would result in a side effect unrelated to a sympathetic response, such as itching feet or headache.']
['What happened next?', 'After receiving these injections, participants waited in a room with someone else they thought was another subject in the research project.']
["What was the other person's role in the research?", 'In reality, the other person was a confederate (someone working on behalf of) of the researcher.']
['What did the confederate engage in?', 'The confederate engaged in scripted displays of euphoric or angry behavior (Schachter & Singer, 1962).']

['Did you find any interesting information from our document?', 'When those participants who were told that they should expect to feel symptoms of physiological arousal were asked about any emotional changes that they had experienced related to either euphoria or anger (depending on the way the confederate behaved), they reported none.']

['What was significant about this article?', 'However, the men who weren’t expecting physiological arousal as a function of the injection were more likely to report that they experienced euphoria or anger as a function of their assigned confederate’s behavior.']

['What did Schachtter & Singer report?', 'While everyone who received an injection of epinephrine experienced the same physiological arousal, only those who were not expecting the arousal used context to interpret the arousal as a change in emotional state (Schachter & Singer, 1962).']

['What are the signs of physiological arousal that can be used to determine whether someone is telling the truth or not?', 'Strong emotional responses are associated with strong physiological arousal, which caused some theorists to suggest that the signs of physiological arousal, including increased heart rate, respiration rate, and sweating, might be used to determine whether someone is telling the truth or not.']
['What is a polygraph?', 'A polygraph, or lie detector test, measures the physiological arousal of an individual responding to a series of questions.']

['What are the signs of arousal?', 'Someone trained in reading these tests would look for answers to questions that are associated with increased levels of arousal as potential signs that the respondent may have been dishonest on those answers.']

['Are lie detector tests still commonly used?', 'While polygraphs are still commonly used, their validity and accuracy are highly questionable because there is no evidence that lying is associated with any particular pattern of physiological arousal (Saxe & Ben-Shakhar, 1999).']

['What is the relationship between our experiencing of emotions and our cognitive processing of them?', 'The relationship between our experiencing of emotions and our cognitive processing of them, and the order in which these occur, remains a topic of research and debate.']

['Who developed the cognitive-mediational theory that asserts our emotions are determined by our appraisal of the stimulus?', 'Lazarus (1991) developed the cognitive-mediational theory that asserts our emotions are determined by our appraisal of the stimulus.']
['What is the appraisal?', 'This appraisal mediates between the stimulus and the emotional response, and it is immediate and often unconscious.']
['What does the appraisal precede?', 'In contrast to the Schachter-Singer model, the appraisal precedes a cognitive label.']
['What can you tell me about Lazarus’s appraisal concept?', 'You will learn more about Lazarus’s appraisal concept when you study stress, health, and lifestyle.']
['What is another interesting fact about this passage?', 'However, there are other views of emotions that also emphasize the cognitive processes.']
['What are the questions that I will be asking you?', 'Return to the example of being asked to lecture by your professor.']
['What would you do if this is your first time teaching a lecture?', 'Even if you do not enjoy speaking in public, you probably could manage to do it.']

['How would you regulate your emotions?', 'You would purposefully control your emotions, which would allow you to speak, but we constantly regulate our emotions, and much of our emotion regulation occurs without us actively thinking about it.']

['What else is important that we should know about emotion regulation?', 'Mauss and her colleagues studied automatic emotion regulation (AER), which refers to the non-deliberate control of emotions.']
['What is automatic emotion regulation?', 'It is simply not reacting with your emotions, and AER can affect all aspects of emotional processes.']

['What can AER influence you to do?', 'AER can influence the things you attend to, your appraisal, your choice to engage in an emotional experience, and your behaviors after an emotion is experienced (Mauss, Bunge, & Gross, 2007; Mauss, Levenson, McCarter, Wilhelm, & Gross, 2005).']
['What is AER?', 'AER is similar to other automatic cognitive processes in which sensations activate knowledge structures that affect functioning.']
['What knowledge structures do they activate?', 'These knowledge structures can include concepts, schemas, or scripts.']

['What does AER stand for?', 'The idea of AER is that people develop an automatic process that works like a script or schema, and the process does not require deliberate thought to regulate emotions.']
['What does the process work like?', 'AER works like riding a bicycle.']
['How does it work?', 'Once you develop the process, you just do it without thinking about it.']
['What are some of the health implications of AER?', 'AER can be adaptive or maladaptive and has important health implications (Hopp, Troy, & Mauss, 2011).']

['What are the important health implications of Adaptive AER?', 'Adaptive AER leads to better health outcomes than maladaptive AER, primarily due to experiencing or mitigating stressors better than people with maladaptive AERs (Hopp, Troy, & Mauss, 2011).']
['What is significant about the article?', 'Alternatively, maladaptive AERs may be critical for maintaining some psychological disorders (Hopp, Troy, & Mauss, 2011).']

['What did Mauss and her colleagues find?', 'Mauss and her colleagues found that strategies could reduce negative emotions, which in turn should increase psychological health (Mauss, Cook, Cheng, & Gross, 2007; Mauss, Cook, & Gross, 2007; Shallcross, Troy, Boland, & Mauss, 2010; Troy, Shallcross, & Mauss, 2013; Troy, Wilhelm, Shallcross, & Mauss, 2010).']

['What has Mauss suggested there are problems with the way emotions are measured?', 'Mauss has also suggested there are problems with the way emotions are measured, but she believes most of the aspects of emotions that are typically measured are useful (Mauss, et al., 2005; Mauss & Robinson, 2009).']
['What is another way of determining emotion?', 'However, another way of considering emotions challenges our entire understanding of emotions.']
['What is the important thing to know about Theories of Emotion?', 'After about three decades of interdisciplinary research, Barrett argued that we do not understand emotions.']
['What does she say about emotions?', 'She proposed that emotions were not built into your brain at birth, but rather they were constructed based on your experiences.']
['What is the constructivist theory?', 'Emotions in the constructivist theory are predictions that construct your experience of the world.']
['What did you learn in the study?', 'In chapter 7 you learned that concepts are categories or groupings of linguistic information, images, ideas, or memories, such as life experiences.']
['Who extended that to include emotions as concepts that are predictions?', 'Barrett extended that to include emotions as concepts that are predictions (Barrett, 2017).']
['What are some other interesting aspects of the text?', 'Two identical physiological states can result in different emotional states depending on your predictions.']
['What is a specific example of a churning stomach?', 'For example, your brain predicting a churning stomach in a bakery could lead to you constructing hunger.']
['How can you explain this to me?', 'However, your brain predicting a churning stomach while you were waiting for medical test results could lead your brain to construct worry.']
['What did you learn about the theory?', 'Thus, you can construct two different emotions from the same physiological sensations.']
['What did you find interesting about emotions?', 'Rather than emotions being something over which you have no control, you can control and influence your emotions.']
['What other views do we have?', 'Two other prominent views arise from the work of Robert Zajonc and Joseph LeDoux.']

['What did Zajonc assert?', 'Zajonc asserted that some emotions occur separately from or prior to our cognitive interpretation of them, such as feeling fear in response to an unexpected loud sound (Zajonc, 1998).']

['What did he believe about gut feelings?', 'He also believed in what we might casually refer to as a gut feeling—that we can experience an instantaneous and unexplainable like or dislike for someone or something (Zajonc, 1980).']
['What other person believed in this?', 'LeDoux also views some emotions as requiring no cognition: some emotions completely bypass contextual interpretation.']
['What else does Joseph LeDoux believe in?', 'His research into the neuroscience of emotion has demonstrated the amygdala’s primary role in fear (Cunha, Monfils, & LeDoux, 2010; LeDoux 1996, 2002).']

['Where is this located?', 'A fear stimulus is processed by the brain through one of two paths: from the thalamus (where it is perceived) directly to the amygdala or from the thalamus through the cortex and then to the amygdala.']
['What do these paths involve?', 'The first path is quick, while the second enables more processing about details of the stimulus.']
['What is the next section about?', 'In the following section, we will look more closely at the neuroscience of emotional response.']
['What did you learn about the limbic system?', 'Earlier, you learned about the limbic system, which is the area of the brain involved in emotion and memory (Figure 10.22).']
['What is the limbic system?', 'The limbic system includes the hypothalamus, thalamus, amygdala, and the hippocampus.']

['What is the role of the hypothalamus in the activation of the sympathetic nervous system that is a part of any given emotional reaction?', 'The hypothalamus plays a role in the activation of the sympathetic nervous system that is a part of any given emotional reaction.']
['What role does the thalamus play?', 'The thalamus serves as a sensory relay center whose neurons project to both the amygdala and the higher cortical regions for further processing.']
['What role does the amygdala play?', 'The amygdala plays a role in processing emotional information and sending that information on (Fossati, 2012).']
['What role does the hippocampus play?', 'The hippocampus integrates emotional experience with cognition (Femenía, Gómez-Galán, Lindskog, & Magara, 2012).']

['What is the amygdala?', 'The amygdala has received a great deal of attention from researchers interested in understanding the biological basis for emotions, especially fear and anxiety (Blackford & Pine, 2012; Goosens & Maren, 2002; Maren, Phan, & Liberzon, 2013).']
['What are the subnuclei of the amygdala?', 'The amygdala is composed of various subnuclei, including the basolateral complex and the central nucleus (Figure 10.23).']
['What is dense connections with a variety of sensory areas of the brain?', 'The basolateral complex has dense connections with a variety of sensory areas of the brain.']
['What is the importance of classical conditioning?', 'It is critical for classical conditioning and for attaching emotional value to learning processes and memory.']

['What is the central nucleus?', 'The central nucleus plays a role in attention, and it has connections with the hypothalamus and various brainstem areas to regulate the autonomic nervous and endocrine systems’ activity (Pessoa, 2010).']

['What is the study about?', 'Animal research has demonstrated that there is increased activation of the amygdala in rat pups that have odor cues paired with electrical shock when their mother is absent.']
['What is the result of this?', 'This leads to an aversion to the odor cue that suggests the rats learned to fear the odor cue.']
['What is significant about this?', 'Interestingly, when the mother was present, the rats actually showed a preference for the odor cue despite its association with an electrical shock.']
['What is significant about this preference?', 'This preference was associated with no increases in amygdala activation.']

['What does this mean?', 'This suggests a differential effect on the amygdala by the context (the presence or absence of the mother) determined whether the pups learned to fear the odor or to be attracted to it (Moriceau & Sullivan, 2006).']

['What did Raineki, Cortés, Belnoue, and Sullivan (2012) demonstrate?', 'Raineki, Cortés, Belnoue, and Sullivan (2012) demonstrated that, in rats, negative early life experiences could alter the function of the amygdala and result in adolescent patterns of behavior that mimic human mood disorders.']
['What is significant about this?', 'In this study, rat pups received either abusive or normal treatment during postnatal days 8–12.']
['How many forms of abuse were there?', 'There were two forms of abusive treatment.']
['What is the first form of abusive treatment?', 'The first form of abusive treatment had an insufficient bedding condition.']

['What did the mother do?', 'The mother rat had insufficient bedding material in her cage to build a proper nest that resulted in her spending more time away from her pups trying to construct a nest and less times nursing her pups.']

['What is the second form of abusive treatment?', 'The second form of abusive treatment had an associative learning task that involved pairing odors and an electrical stimulus in the absence of the mother, as described above.']
['What was the control group like?', 'The control group was in a cage with sufficient bedding and was left undisturbed with their mothers during the same time period.']
['What did the study find?', 'The rat pups that experienced abuse were much more likely to exhibit depressive-like symptoms during adolescence when compared to controls.']
['Did the animal do anything else?', 'These depressive-like behaviors were associated with increased activation of the amygdala.']

['What kind of relationship do you see between the amygdala and psychological disorders?', 'Human research also suggests a relationship between the amygdala and psychological disorders of mood or anxiety.']

['What does this mean?', 'Changes in amygdala structure and function have been demonstrated in adolescents who are either at-risk or have been diagnosed with various mood and/or anxiety disorders (Miguel-Hidalgo, 2013; Qin et al., 2013).']

['What does this mean for the diagnosis of mental illness?', 'It has also been suggested that functional differences in the amygdala could serve as a biomarker to differentiate individuals suffering from bipolar disorder from those suffering from major depressive disorder (Fournier, Keener, Almeida, Kronhaus, & Phillips, 2013).']
['What is the Hippocampus?', 'As mentioned earlier, the hippocampus is also involved in emotional processing.']

['What is the relationship between the Hippocampus and moods?', 'Like the amygdala, research has demonstrated that hippocampal structure and function are linked to a variety of mood and anxiety disorders.']

['What is the relationship between the Hippocampus and anxiety?', 'Individuals suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) show marked reductions in the volume of several parts of the hippocampus, which may result from decreased levels of neurogenesis and dendritic branching (the generation of new neurons and the generation of new dendrites in existing neurons, respectively) (Wang et al., 2010).']

['What are some of the studies that demonstrate these findings?', 'While it is impossible to make a causal claim with correlational research like this, studies have demonstrated behavioral improvements and hippocampal volume increases following either pharmacological or cognitive-behavioral therapy in individuals suffering from PTSD (Bremner & Vermetten, 2004; Levy-Gigi, Szabó, Kelemen, & Kéri, 2013).']
['What kind of cultural influence do you have?', 'Culture can impact the way in which people display emotion.']

['What is a cultural display rule?', 'A cultural display rule is one of a collection of culturally specific standards that govern the types and frequencies of displays of emotions that are acceptable (Malatesta & Haviland, 1982).']
['What kind of cultural display rule are there?', 'Therefore, people from varying cultural backgrounds can have very different cultural display rules of emotion.']

['what is one example of cultural display rule?', 'For example, research has shown that individuals from the United States express negative emotions like fear, anger, and disgust both alone and in the presence of others, while Japanese individuals only do so while alone (Matsumoto, 1990).']

['what else is interesting?', 'Furthermore, individuals from cultures that tend to emphasize social cohesion are more likely to engage in suppression of emotional reaction so they can evaluate which response is most appropriate in a given context (Matsumoto, Yoo, & Nakagawa, 2008).']
['What are some other things you might find interesting in the study material?', 'Other distinct cultural characteristics might be involved in emotionality.']
['What is the most important thing you learned?', 'For instance, there may be gender differences involved in emotional processing.']

['What are the gender differences involved?', 'While research into gender differences in emotional display is equivocal, there is some evidence that people of different genders may differ in regulation of emotions (McRae, Ochsner, Mauss, Gabrieli, & Gross, 2008).']

['What was significant about the man?', 'Paul Ekman (1972) researched a New Guinea man who was living in a preliterate culture using stone implements, and which was isolated and had never seen any outsiders before.']

['What did he ask him?', 'Ekman asked the man to show what his facial expression would be if: (1) friends visited, (2) his child had just died, (3) he was about to fight, (4) he stepped on a smelly dead pig.']
['What else did he study?', 'After Ekman’s return from New Guinea, he researched facial expressions for more than four decades.']
['What did this research show about human culture?', 'Despite different emotional display rules, our ability to recognize and produce facial expressions of emotion appears to be universal.']

['What else was interesting?', 'In fact, even congenitally blind individuals produce the same facial expression of emotions, despite their never having the opportunity to observe these facial displays of emotion in other people.']

['What would seem to suggest that the pattern of activity in facial muscles involved in generating emotional expressions is universal?', 'This would seem to suggest that the pattern of activity in facial muscles involved in generating emotional expressions is universal, and indeed, this idea was suggested in the late 19th century in Charles Darwin’s book The Expression of Emotions in Man and Animals (1872).']
['How many universal emotions are recognized?', 'In fact, there is substantial evidence for seven universal emotions that are each associated with distinct facial expressions.']
['What are the emotions that are characterized by a shivering?', 'These include: happiness, surprise, sadness, fright, disgust, contempt, and anger (Figure 10.24) (Ekman & Keltner, 1997).']
['Are there any other specific information that you find in this material?', 'Of course, emotion is not only displayed through facial expression.']
['What else does it display?', 'We also use the tone of our voices, various behaviors, and body language to communicate information about our emotional states.']
['What does body language mean?', 'Body language is the expression of emotion in terms of body position or movement.']

['What is the most important information you found in the article?', 'Research suggests that we are quite sensitive to the emotional information communicated through body language, even if we’re not consciously aware of it (de Gelder, 2006; Tamietto et al., 2009).']

['What is the term for the long-standing traits and patterns that propel individuals to consistently think, feel, and behave in specific ways?', 'Personality refers to the long-standing traits and patterns that propel individuals to consistently think, feel, and behave in specific ways.']
['How does it help us perceive people?', 'Our personality is what makes us unique individuals.']

['What is discussed in the paper?', 'Each person has an idiosyncratic pattern of enduring, long-term characteristics and a manner in which they interact with other individuals and the world around them.']
['How do people perceive their personalities?', 'Our personalities are thought to be long term, stable, and not easily changed.']
['What is the origin of the word personality?', 'The word personality comes from the Latin word persona.']
['What does persona mean?', 'In the ancient world, a persona was a mask worn by an actor.']

['What was the original purpose of a mask?', 'While we tend to think of a mask as being worn to conceal one’s identity, the theatrical mask was originally used to either represent or project a specific personality trait of a character (Figure 11.2).']
['What did Hippocrates study?', 'The concept of personality has been studied for at least 2,000 years, beginning with Hippocrates in 370 BCE (Fazeli, 2012).']

['What theories did Hippocrates have?', 'Hippocrates theorized that personality traits and human behaviors are based on four separate temperaments associated with four fluids (“humors”) of the body: choleric temperament (yellow bile from the liver), melancholic temperament (black bile from the kidneys), sanguine temperament (red blood from the heart), and phlegmatic temperament (white phlegm from the lungs) (Clark & Watson, 2008; Eysenck & Eysenck, 1985; Lecci & Magnavita, 2013; Noga, 2007).']

['What did Galen suggest?', 'Centuries later, the influential Greek physician and philosopher Galen built on Hippocrates’s theory, suggesting that both diseases and personality differences could be explained by imbalances in the humors and that each person exhibits one of the four temperaments.']

['What are the characteristics of the personalities?', 'For example, the choleric person is passionate, ambitious, and bold; the melancholic person is reserved, anxious, and unhappy; the sanguine person is joyful, eager, and optimistic; and the phlegmatic person is calm, reliable, and thoughtful (Clark & Watson, 2008; Stelmack & Stalikas, 1991).']
['Did people believe Galen’s theories?', 'Galen’s theory was prevalent for over 1,000 years and continued to be popular through the Middle Ages.']

['What is the historical perspective of the bumps on the skull?', 'In 1780, Franz Gall, a German physician, proposed that the distances between bumps on the skull reveal a person’s personality traits, character, and mental abilities (Figure 11.3).']

['Why would they reveal personality traits?', 'According to Gall, measuring these distances revealed the sizes of the brain areas underneath, providing information that could be used to determine whether a person was friendly, prideful, murderous, kind, good with languages, and so on.']

['Did the theory gain much traction?', 'Initially, phrenology was very popular; however, it was soon discredited for lack of empirical support and has long been relegated to the status of pseudoscience (Fancher, 1979).']

['What kind of people did Galen study with?', 'In the centuries after Galen, other researchers contributed to the development of his four primary temperament types, most prominently Immanuel Kant (in the 18th century) and psychologist Wilhelm Wundt (in the 19th century) (Eysenck, 2009; Stelmack & Stalikas, 1991; Wundt, 1874/1886) (Figure 11.4).']

['What did Galen agree with Kant about?', 'Kant agreed with Galen that everyone could be sorted into one of the four temperaments and that there was no overlap between the four categories (Eysenck, 2009).']
['How did he develop them?', 'He developed a list of traits that could be used to describe the personality of a person from each of the four temperaments.']

['Which traits were separating the temperaments?', 'However, Wundt suggested that a better description of personality could be achieved using two major axes: emotional/nonemotional and changeable/unchangeable.']
['What kind of emotion separated those axes?', 'The first axis separated strong from weak emotions (the melancholic and choleric temperaments from the phlegmatic and sanguine).']
['What is the second axis?', 'The second axis divided the changeable temperaments (choleric and sanguine) from the unchangeable ones (melancholic and phlegmatic) (Eysenck, 2009).']

['What is the most important aspect of this material?', 'Sigmund Freud’s psychodynamic perspective of personality was the first comprehensive theory of personality, explaining a wide variety of both normal and abnormal behaviors.']

['According to Freud, what are the forces that influence our personality?', 'According to Freud, unconscious drives influenced by sex and aggression, along with childhood sexuality, are the forces that influence our personality.']
['What happened to Freud?', 'Freud attracted many followers who modified his ideas to create new theories about personality.']

['What did these theorists agree with Freud on?', 'These theorists, referred to as neo-Freudians, generally agreed with Freud that childhood experiences matter, but they reduced the emphasis on sex and focused more on the social environment and effects of culture on personality.']

['What was the dominant theory of personality for the first half of the 20th century?', 'The perspective of personality proposed by Freud and his followers was the dominant theory of personality for the first half of the 20th century.']
['What are some of the major theories about personalities?', 'Other major theories then emerged, including the learning, humanistic, biological, evolutionary, trait, and cultural perspectives.']
['Are these theories still used today?', 'In this chapter, we will explore these various perspectives on personality in depth.']
['What is Sigmund Freud considered?', 'Sigmund Freud (1856–1939) is probably the most controversial and misunderstood psychological theorist.']
['What were some of his theories?', 'When reading Freud’s theories, it is important to remember that he was a medical doctor, not a psychologist.']

['Why was he not a psychologist?', 'There was no such thing as a degree in psychology at the time that he received his education, which can help us understand some of the controversy over his theories today.']

['What was the most important thing to know about Freud?', 'However, Freud was the first to systematically study and theorize the workings of the unconscious mind in the manner that we associate with modern psychology.']
['What happened in the early years of his career?', 'In the early years of his career, Freud worked with Josef Breuer, a Viennese physician.']
['what happened with anna?', 'During this time, Freud became intrigued by the story of one of Breuer’s patients, Bertha Pappenheim, who was referred to by the pseudonym Anna O. (Launer, 2005).']

['what happened to her?', 'Anna O. had been caring for her dying father when she began to experience symptoms such as partial paralysis, headaches, blurred vision, amnesia, and hallucinations (Launer, 2005).']
['Did they have any other symptoms?', 'In Freud’s day, these symptoms were commonly referred to as hysteria.']
['What happened to Anna O.?', 'Anna O. turned to Breuer for help.']
['How did he treat her?', 'He spent 2 years (1880–1882) treating Anna O. and discovered that allowing her to talk about her experiences seemed to bring some relief of her symptoms.']
['What was the treatment called?', 'Anna O. called his treatment the “talking cure” (Launer, 2005).']
['was this the beginning of his career?', 'Despite the fact that Freud never met Anna O., her story served as the basis for the 1895 book, Studies on Hysteria, which he co-authored with Breuer.']

['was there anything else significant that happened with anna?', 'Based on Breuer’s description of Anna O.’s treatment, Freud concluded that hysteria was the result of sexual abuse in childhood and that these traumatic experiences had been hidden from consciousness.']
['Did he disagree with Freud?', 'Breuer disagreed with Freud, which soon ended their work together.']
['What did Freud continue to work on during this time?', 'However, Freud continued to work to refine talk therapy and build his theory on personality.']

['How did Freud help explain the concept of conscious versus unconscious experience?', 'To explain the concept of conscious versus unconscious experience, Freud compared the mind to an iceberg (Figure 11.5).']
['What does Freud say about the iceberg concept?', 'He said that only about one-tenth of our mind is conscious, and the rest of our mind is unconscious.']
['What does the word "unconscious" refer to?', 'Our unconscious refers to that mental activity of which we are unaware and are unable to access (Freud, 1923).']
['What else does Freud say about the unconscious?', 'According to Freud, unacceptable urges and desires are kept in our unconscious through a process called repression.']
['What does this lead to?', 'For example, we sometimes say things that we don’t intend to say by unintentionally substituting another word for the one we meant.']
['What is the term used to describe this?', 'You’ve probably heard of a Freudian slip, the term used to describe this.']
['What does Freud suggest that slips of the tongue are?', 'Freud suggested that slips of the tongue are actually sexual or aggressive urges, accidentally slipping out of our unconscious.']
['Are these slips common?', 'Speech errors such as this are quite common.']

['What else is known about Freudian slips?', 'Seeing them as a reflection of unconscious desires, linguists today have found that slips of the tongue tend to occur when we are tired, nervous, or not at our optimal level of cognitive functioning (Motley, 2002).']

['What does Freud have to do with this?', 'According to Freud, our personality develops from a conflict between two forces: our biological aggressive and pleasure-seeking drives versus our internal (socialized) control over these drives.']
['Are there any other quotes in the passage?', 'Our personality is the result of our efforts to balance these two competing forces.']
['What other quotes are in the passage?', 'Freud suggested that we can understand this by imagining three interacting systems within our minds.']
['What did he call these three systems?', 'He called them the id, ego, and superego (Figure 11.6).']
['What is the unconscious?', 'The unconscious id contains our most primitive drives or urges, and is present from birth.']
['What does the brain direct?', 'It directs impulses for hunger, thirst, and sex.']
['What does the id seek?', 'Freud believed that the id operates on what he called the “pleasure principle,” in which the id seeks immediate gratification.']
['Who does it interact with?', 'Through social interactions with parents and others in a child’s environment, the ego and superego develop to help control the id.']
['What does the superego develop as a child interacts with others?', 'The superego develops as a child interacts with others, learning the social rules for right and wrong.']
['What does the superego tell us?', 'The superego acts as our conscience; it is our moral compass that tells us how we should behave.']
['What does the ego feel like?', 'It strives for perfection and judges our behavior, leading to feelings of pride or—when we fall short of the ideal—feelings of guilt.']
['What is the ego?', 'In contrast to the instinctual id and the rule-based superego, the ego is the rational part of our personality.']
['What does the ego do?', 'Its job is to balance the demands of the id and superego in the context of reality; thus, it operates on what Freud called the “reality principle.”']
['How does the ego help the id?', 'The ego helps the id satisfy its desires in a realistic way.']

['What are the two parts of the ego that are in constant conflict?', 'The id and superego are in constant conflict, because the id wants instant gratification regardless of the consequences, but the superego tells us that we must behave in socially acceptable ways.']
['What are the two in constant conflict about?', 'Thus, the ego’s job is to find the middle ground.']
['Why is this important?', 'It helps satisfy the id’s desires in a rational way that will not lead us to feelings of guilt.']
['Is there anything else I should know?', 'According to Freud, a person who has a strong ego, which can balance the demands of the id and the superego, has a healthy personality.']

['What are the consequences of imbalances in the system?', 'Freud maintained that imbalances in the system can lead to neurosis (a tendency to experience negative emotions), anxiety disorders, or unhealthy behaviors.']
['What kind of behaviors are unhealthy?', 'For example, a person who is dominated by their id might be narcissistic and impulsive.']

['What is the most important thing we should know about the superego?', 'A person with a dominant superego might be controlled by feelings of guilt and deny themselves even socially acceptable pleasures; conversely, if the superego is weak or absent, a person might become a psychopath.']

['Can you give me more information on the dominant superego?', 'An overly dominant superego might be seen in an over-controlled individual whose rational grasp on reality is so strong that they are unaware of their emotional needs, or, in a neurotic who is overly defensive (overusing ego defense mechanisms).']
['What did Freud believe?', 'Freud believed that feelings of anxiety result from the ego’s inability to mediate the conflict between the id and superego.']
['what does he do when this happens?', 'When this happens, Freud believed that the ego seeks to restore balance through various protective measures known as defense mechanisms (Figure 11.7).']
['What does this mean?', 'When certain events, feelings, or yearnings cause an individual anxiety, the individual wishes to reduce that anxiety.']

['What can the individual’s unconscious mind do to reduce anxiety?', 'To do that, the individual’s unconscious mind uses ego defense mechanisms, unconscious protective behaviors that aim to reduce anxiety.']
['Are they conscious?', 'The ego, usually conscious, resorts to unconscious strivings to protect the ego from being overwhelmed by anxiety.']
['What is one of the effects of defense mechanisms?', 'When we use defense mechanisms, we are unaware that we are using them.']
['Are they good or bad?', 'Further, they operate in various ways that distort reality.']
['According to Freud, what do we all use to defend ourselves?', 'According to Freud, we all use ego defense mechanisms.']
['What is the content of defense mechanisms?', 'While everyone uses defense mechanisms, Freud believed that overuse of them may be problematic.']
['What other things are relevant?', 'For example, let’s say Joe is a high school football player.']
['What does Joe feel?', 'Deep down, Joe feels sexually attracted to males.']
['What does he believe?', 'His conscious belief is that being gay is immoral and that if he were gay, his family would disown him and he would be ostracized by his peers.']

['What is the conflict between his conscious beliefs and his unconscious urges?', 'Therefore, there   is a conflict between his conscious beliefs (being gay is wrong and will result in being ostracized) and his unconscious urges (attraction to males).']
['What does Joe do after he realizes he might be gay?', 'The idea that he might be gay causes Joe to have feelings of anxiety.']
['What happens when Joe acts gay?', 'Joe may find himself acting very “macho,” making gay jokes, and picking on a school peer who is gay.']
['What happens when Joe’s unconscious impulses are further submerged?', 'This way, Joe’s unconscious impulses are further submerged.']
['What are some defense mechanisms?', 'There are several different types of defense mechanisms.']
['What is one defense mechanism?', 'For instance, in repression, anxiety-causing memories from consciousness are blocked.']

['Why is this done?', 'As an analogy, let’s say your car is making a strange noise, but because you do not have the money to get it fixed, you just turn up the radio so that you no longer hear the strange noise.']
['How long does it take for that to stop?', 'Eventually you forget about it.']

['What is the analogy for the human psyche?', 'Similarly, in the human psyche, if a memory is too overwhelming to deal with, it might be repressed and thus removed from conscious awareness (Freud, 1920).']
['What might cause symptoms in other areas?', 'This repressed memory might cause symptoms in other areas.']
['what is another defense mechanism?', 'Another defense mechanism is reaction formation, in which someone expresses feelings, thoughts, and behaviors opposite to their inclinations.']
['What is an example of this?', 'In the above example, Joe made fun of a gay peer while himself being attracted to males.']
['What is regression?', 'In regression, an individual acts much younger than their age.']
['What is an example of regression?', 'For example, a four-year-old child who resents the arrival of a newborn sibling may act like a baby and revert to drinking out of a bottle.']

['What is the term for a person who refuses to acknowledge her own unconscious feelings and instead sees those feelings in someone else?', 'In projection, a person refuses to acknowledge her own unconscious feelings and instead sees those feelings in someone else.']
['What are other defense mechanisms?', 'Other defense mechanisms include rationalization, displacement, and sublimation.']
['What does Freud believe?', 'Freud believed that personality develops during early childhood: Childhood experiences shape our personalities as well as our behavior as adults.']
['What does he assert?', 'He asserted that we develop via a series of stages during childhood.']

['What do these stages consist of?', 'Each of us must pass through these childhood stages, and if we do not have the proper nurturing and parenting during a stage, we will be stuck, or fixated, in that stage, even as adults.']

['What is this study material about?', 'In each psychosexual stage of development, the child’s pleasure-seeking urges, coming from the id, are focused on a different area of the body, called an erogenous zone.']
['What are the names of the stages?', 'The stages are oral, anal, phallic, latency, and genital (Table 11.1).']
['What is a controversy about Freud’s psychosexual development theory?', 'Freud’s psychosexual development theory is quite controversial.']

['What was his theory about?', 'To understand the origins of the theory, it is helpful to be familiar with the political, social, and cultural influences of Freud’s day in Vienna at the turn of the 20th century.']

['What were these influences?', 'During this era, a climate of sexual repression, combined with limited understanding and education surrounding human sexuality, heavily influenced Freud’s perspective.']
['Did he make up this theory?', 'Given that sex was a taboo topic, Freud assumed that negative emotional states (neuroses) stemmed from suppression of unconscious sexual and aggressive urges.']

["Was Freud's theory well received?", 'For Freud, his own recollections and interpretations of patients’ experiences and dreams were sufficient proof that psychosexual stages were universal events in early childhood.']
['What is oral stage?', 'In the oral stage (birth to 1 year), pleasure is focused on the mouth.']
['What is oral stage about?', 'Eating and the pleasure derived from sucking (nipples, pacifiers, and thumbs) play a large part in a baby’s first year of life.']

['What is the most important information in the passage?', 'At around 1 year of age, babies are weaned from the bottle or breast, and this process can create conflict if not handled properly by caregivers.']

['Does the paper talk about anything else?', 'According to Freud, an adult who smokes, drinks, overeats, or bites her nails is fixated in the oral stage of her psychosexual development; she may have been weaned too early or too late, resulting in these fixation tendencies, all of which seek to ease anxiety.']
['What is this stage about?', 'After passing through the oral stage, children enter what Freud termed the anal stage (1–3 years).']
["What's interesting in this stage?", 'In this stage, children experience pleasure in their bowel and bladder movements, so it makes sense that the conflict in this stage is over toilet training.']
['What else is significant about this stage?', 'During this stage of development, children work to master control of themselves.']
['How can parents help their child with toilet training?', 'Freud suggested that success at the anal stage depended on how parents handled toilet training.']
['How do you handle toilet training?', 'Parents who offer praise and rewards encourage positive results and can help children feel competent.']

['What can you tell me about toilet training?', 'Parents who are harsh in toilet training can cause a child to become so fearful of soiling that they over-control and become fixated at the anal stage, leading to the development of an anal-retentive personality.']
['What happens to a child who is so afraid?', 'The anal-retentive personality is stingy and stubborn, has a compulsive need for order and neatness, and might be considered a perfectionist.']

['Are there any other aspects about toilet training?', 'If parents are too lenient in toilet training, the child may fail to develop sufficient self-control, become fixated at this stage, and develop an anal-expulsive personality.']
['What happens to a child who is too easy on them?', 'The anal-expulsive personality is messy, careless, disorganized, and prone to emotional outbursts.']

['What is this stage about?', 'Freud’s third stage of psychosexual development is the phallic stage (3–6 years), corresponding to the age when children become aware of their bodies and recognize the differences between boys and girls.']
['What is the erogenous zone in this stage?', 'The erogenous zone in this stage is the genitals.']
['What is the conflict between a child and their parents?', 'Conflict arises when the child feels a desire for the opposite-sex parent, and jealousy and hatred toward the same-sex parent.']

["For boys, what is called the Oedipus complex, involving a boy's desire for his mother and his urge to replace his father who is seen as a rival for the mother’s attention?", "For boys, this is called the Oedipus complex, involving a boy's desire for his mother and his urge to replace his father who is seen as a rival for the mother’s attention."]
['Does he have trouble with his father?', 'At the same time, the boy is afraid his father will punish him for his feelings, so he experiences castration anxiety.']
['How does the boy resolve this?', 'The Oedipus complex is successfully resolved when the boy begins to identify with his father as an indirect way to have the mother.']

['What happens if the Oedipus complex is not resolved?', 'Failure to resolve the Oedipus complex may result in fixation and development of a personality that might be described as vain and overly ambitious.']
['What are some significant aspects of the study material?', 'Girls experience a comparable conflict in the phallic stage—the Electra complex.']
['Who proposed the Electra complex?', 'The Electra complex, while often attributed to Freud, was actually proposed by Freud’s protégé, Carl Jung (Jung & Kerenyi, 1963).']
['What does this mean for girls?', 'A girl desires the attention of her father and wishes to take her mother’s place.']
["What is the mother's place in Jung's theory?", 'Jung also said that girls are angry with the mother for not providing them with a penis—which he termed penis envy.']

['What else is significant?', 'While Freud initially embraced the Electra complex as a parallel to the Oedipus complex, he later rejected it, yet it remains as a cornerstone of Freudian theory, thanks in part to academics in the field (Freud, 1931/1968; Scott, 2005).']

['What is the period known as after the phallic stage of psychosexual development?', 'Following the phallic stage of psychosexual development is a period known as the latency period (6 years to puberty).']

['What is special about the latency period?', 'This period is not considered a stage, because sexual feelings are dormant as children focus on other pursuits, such as school, friendships, hobbies, and sports.']
