['What else can you tell me about the latency period?', 'Children generally engage in activities with peers of the same sex, which serves to consolidate a child’s gender-role identity.']
['What is the final stage of adolescence?', 'The final stage is the genital stage (from puberty on).']
['What happens in this stage?', 'In this stage, there is a sexual reawakening as the incestuous urges resurface.']
['What does the young person do about this urge?', 'The young person redirects these urges to other, more socially acceptable partners (who often resemble the other-sex parent).']
['What does the mature sexual interest mean?', 'People in this stage have mature sexual interests, which for Freud meant a strong desire for the opposite sex.']

['Are those who successfully completed the previous stages good people?', 'Individuals who successfully completed the previous stages, reaching the genital stage with no fixations, are said to be well-balanced, healthy adults.']

["What is a major part of Freud's ideas?", 'While most of Freud’s ideas have not found support in modern research, and several contemporary researchers rejected his premises, we cannot discount the contributions that Freud has made to the field of psychology.']

['What was Freud able to do?', 'It was Freud who pointed out that a large part of our mental life is influenced by the experiences of early childhood and takes place outside of our conscious awareness; his theories paved the way for others.']

['What is it about?', "While Freud's focus on biological drives led him to emphasize the impact of sociocultural factors on personality development, his followers quickly realized that biology alone could not account for the diversity they encountered as the practice of psychoanalysis spread during the time of the Nazi Holocaust."]

['What may have led mainstream psychoanalysts to focus primarily on the universality of the psychological structures of the mind?', 'The antisemitism which was prevalent during this period of time may have led mainstream psychoanalysts to focus primarily on the universality of the psychological structures of the mind.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Freud attracted many followers who modified his ideas to create new theories about personality.']

['What was the impact of these theories?', 'These theorists, referred to as neo-Freudians, generally agreed with Freud that childhood experiences matter, but deemphasized sex, focusing more on the social environment and effects of culture on personality.']
['What are some of the names of the neo-Freudians?', 'Four notable neo-Freudians include Alfred Adler, Erik Erikson, Carl Jung (pronounced “Yoong”), and Karen Horney (pronounced “HORN-eye”).']

['What can you tell me about Alfred Adler?', 'Alfred Adler, a colleague of Freud’s and the first president of the Vienna Psychoanalytical Society (Freud’s inner circle of colleagues), was the first major theorist to break away from Freud (Figure 11.8).']
['What is his theory about?', 'He subsequently founded a school of psychology called individual psychology, which focuses on our drive to compensate for feelings of inferiority.']
['What else is noteworthy about his theory?', 'Adler (1937, 1956) proposed the concept of the inferiority complex.']
['What is an inferiority complex?', 'An inferiority complex refers to a person’s feelings that they lack worth and don’t measure up to the standards of others or of society.']
['What is the difference between Adler’s ideas about inferiority and Freud’s?', 'Adler’s ideas about inferiority represent a major difference between his thinking and Freud’s.']

['What did Freud believe that we are motivated by?', 'Freud believed that we are motivated by sexual and aggressive urges, but Adler (1930, 1961) believed that feelings of inferiority in childhood are what drive people to attempt to gain superiority and that this striving is the force behind all of our thoughts, emotions, and behaviors.']

['What did Adler believe in?', 'Adler also believed in the importance of social connections, seeing childhood development emerging through social development rather than the sexual stages Freud outlined.']
['What did Adler do?', 'Adler noted the inter-relatedness of humanity and the need to work together for the betterment of all.']

['What did he think about the human race?', 'He said, “The happiness of mankind lies in working together, in living as if each individual had set himself the task of contributing to the common welfare” (Adler, 1964, p. 255) with the main goal of psychology being “to recognize the equal rights and equality of others” (Adler, 1961, p. 691).']

['What was the first social task that Adler identified?', 'With these ideas, Adler identified three fundamental social tasks that all of us must experience: occupational tasks (careers), societal tasks (friendship), and love tasks (finding an intimate partner for a long-term relationship).']
['What was his purpose in studying social work?', 'Rather than focus on sexual or aggressive motives for behavior as Freud did, Adler focused on social motives.']
['Did he study more?', 'He also emphasized conscious rather than unconscious motivation, since he believed that the three fundamental social tasks are explicitly known and pursued.']
['Did he believe in unconscious processes?', 'That is not to say that Adler did not also believe in unconscious processes—he did—but he felt that conscious processes were more important.']
['What was one of Adler’s major contributions to personality psychology?', 'One of Adler’s major contributions to personality psychology was the idea that our birth order shapes our personality.']

['What does the birth order mean?', 'He proposed that older siblings, who start out as the focus of their parents’ attention but must share that attention once a new child joins the family, compensate by becoming overachievers.']

['What does the middle child do?', 'The youngest children, according to Adler, may be spoiled, leaving the middle child with the opportunity to minimize the negative dynamics of the youngest and oldest children.']
['What is the result of Adler’s hypotheses about birth order?', 'Despite popular attention, research has not conclusively confirmed Adler’s hypotheses about birth order.']

["What was the background on young Erik Erikson met Freud'?", 'As an art school dropout with an uncertain future, young Erik Erikson met Freud’s daughter, Anna Freud, while he was tutoring the children of an American couple undergoing psychoanalysis in Vienna.']
['What did they teach Erikson?', 'It was Anna Freud who encouraged Erikson to study psychoanalysis.']

['What did Erikson do after he received his diploma from the Vienna Psychoanalytic Institute?', 'Erikson received his diploma from the Vienna Psychoanalytic Institute in 1933, and as Nazism spread across Europe, he fled the country and immigrated to the United States that same year.']

['What is the theory of Erikson?', 'As you learned when you studied lifespan development, Erikson later proposed a psychosocial theory of development, suggesting that an individual’s personality develops throughout the lifespan—a departure from Freud’s view that personality is fixed in early life.']
['What else is important?', 'In his theory, Erikson emphasized the social relationships that are important at each stage of personality development, in contrast to Freud’s emphasis on sex.']
["What is the stage of Erikson's theory?", 'Erikson identified eight stages, each of which represents a conflict or developmental task (Table 11.2).']

['What is the development of a healthy personality and a sense of competence depend on?', 'The development of a healthy personality and a sense of competence depend on the successful completion of each task.']
['What is Carl Jung?', 'Carl Jung (Figure 11.9) was a Swiss psychiatrist and protégé of Freud, who later split off from Freud and developed his own theory, which he called analytical psychology.']

['What was the focus of analytical psychology?', 'The focus of analytical psychology is on working to balance opposing forces of conscious and unconscious thought, and experience within one’s personality.']

['what is the continuous learning process?', 'According to Jung, this work is a continuous learning process—mainly occurring in the second half of life—of becoming aware of unconscious elements and integrating them into consciousness.']
['What was the most important topic of discussion?', 'Jung’s split from Freud was based on two major disagreements.']
['How were they similar?', 'First, Jung, like Adler and Erikson, did not accept that sexual drive was the primary motivator in a person’s mental life.']
['What did Jung agree with Freud’s concept of a personal unconscious?', 'Second, although Jung agreed with Freud’s concept of a personal unconscious, he thought it to be incomplete.']
['What did Jung think was incomplete?', 'In addition to the personal unconscious, Jung focused on the collective unconscious.']

['What is the collective unconscious?', 'The collective unconscious is a universal version of the personal unconscious, holding mental patterns, or memory traces, which are common to all of us (Jung, 1928).']
['What are archetypes?', 'These ancestral memories, which Jung called archetypes, are represented by universal themes in various cultures, as expressed through literature, art, and dreams (Jung).']
['What do archetypes represent?', 'Jung said that these themes reflect common experiences of people the world over, such as facing death, becoming independent, and striving for mastery.']

['What is interesting about his work?', 'Jung (1964) believed that through biology, each person is handed down the same themes and that the same types of symbols—such as the hero, the maiden, the sage, and the trickster—are present in the folklore and fairy tales of every culture.']

['What did he believe about archetypes?', 'In Jung’s view, the task of integrating these unconscious archetypal aspects of the self is part of the self-realization process in the second half of life.']

['What else is interesting about his work?', 'With this orientation toward self-realization, Jung parted ways with Freud’s belief that personality is determined solely by past events and anticipated the humanistic movement with its emphasis on self-actualization and orientation toward the future.']
['What are some key elements of this passage?', 'Jung also proposed two attitudes or approaches toward life: extroversion and introversion (Jung, 1923) (Table 11.3).']

['What are these ideas considered?', 'These ideas are considered Jung’s most important contributions to the field of personality psychology, as almost all models of personality now include these concepts.']
['How does extroversion impact individuals?', 'If you are an extrovert, then you are a person who is energized by being outgoing and socially oriented:']
['What does it mean to be socially oriented?', 'You derive your energy from being around others.']

['Do introverts have different energy than extroverts?', 'If you are an introvert, then you are a person who may be quiet and reserved, or you may be social, but your energy is derived from your inner psychic activity.']
['what does jung believe that the balance between introversion and extrovertism is?', 'Jung believed a balance between extroversion and introversion best served the goal of self-realization.']
['What was another concept proposed by Jung?', 'Another concept proposed by Jung was the persona, which he referred to as a mask that we adopt.']
['Where does that persona come from?', 'According to Jung, we consciously create this persona; however, it is derived from both our conscious experiences and our collective unconscious.']
['What does Jung believe the persona is?', 'Jung believed that it is a compromise between who we really are (our true self) and what society expects us to be.']
['What do we hide?', 'We hide those parts of ourselves that are not aligned with society’s expectations.']
['Did you find anything interesting in the article?', 'Karen Horney was one of the first women trained as a Freudian psychoanalyst.']
['Did she do anything significant?', 'During the Great Depression, Horney moved from Germany to the United States, and subsequently moved away from Freud’s teachings.']

['What did Horney believe?', 'Like Jung, Horney believed that each individual has the potential for self-realization and that the goal of psychoanalysis should be moving toward a healthy self rather than exploring early childhood patterns of dysfunction.']
['Were there any other differences?', 'Horney also disagreed with the Freudian idea that girls have penis envy and are jealous of male biological features.']

['What did she say?', 'According to Horney, any jealousy is most likely culturally based, due to the greater privileges that men often have, meaning that the differences between men’s and women’s personalities are culturally based, not biologically based.']
['What did she say?', 'She further suggested that men have womb envy, because they cannot give birth.']
['What were Horney’s theories?', 'Horney’s theories focused on the role of unconscious anxiety.']
['What are some of her theories?', 'She suggested that normal growth can be blocked by basic anxiety stemming from needs not being met, such as childhood experiences of loneliness and/or isolation.']
['How do you describe coping?', 'Horney suggested three styles of coping (Table 11.4).']
['What is the first coping style?', 'The first coping style, moving toward people, relies on affiliation and dependence.']

['Why do children become dependent on their parents and other caregivers?', 'These children become dependent on their parents and other caregivers in an effort to receive attention and affection, which provides relief from anxiety (Burger, 2008).']

['What is interesting about the relationship?', 'When these children grow up, they tend to use this same coping strategy to deal with relationships, expressing an intense need for love and acceptance (Burger, 2008).']
['What is the second coping style?', 'The second coping style, moving against people, relies on aggression and assertiveness.']

['Why is this?', 'Children with this coping style find that fighting is the best way to deal with an unhappy home situation, and they deal with their feelings of insecurity by bullying other children (Burger, 2008).']
['How does this affect others?', 'As adults, people with this coping style tend to lash out with hurtful comments and exploit others (Burger, 2008).']
['What is the third coping style?', 'The third coping style, moving away from people, centers on detachment and isolation.']
['How do these children handle their anxiety?', 'These children handle their anxiety by withdrawing from the world.']
['What is unique about a solitary person?', 'They need privacy and tend to be self-sufficient.']

['What are the outcomes of this?', 'When these children are adults, they continue to avoid such things as love and friendship, and they also tend to gravitate toward careers that require little interaction with others (Burger, 2008).']

['What are the differences between learning approaches and psychodynamic approaches?', 'In contrast to the psychodynamic approaches of Freud and the neo-Freudians, which relate personality to inner (and hidden) processes, the learning approaches focus only on observable behavior.']
['How do these approaches differ from one another?', 'This illustrates one significant advantage of the learning approaches over psychodynamics:']
['What is another advantage of learning approaches?', 'Because learning approaches involve observable, measurable phenomena, they can be scientifically tested.']
['What do Behaviorists believe in?', 'Behaviorists do not believe in biological determinism:']
['What do they believe about personality traits?', 'They do not see personality traits as inborn.']
["Why don't they see personality traits as inborn?", 'Instead, they view personality as significantly shaped by the reinforcements and consequences outside of the organism.']
['What do they say about how people behave?', 'In other words, people behave in a consistent manner based on prior learning.']

['Who believed that environment was solely responsible for all behavior?', 'B. F. Skinner, a strict behaviorist, believed that environment was solely responsible for all behavior, including the enduring, consistent behavior patterns studied by personality theorists.']

['What did Skinner propose?', 'As you may recall from your study on the psychology of learning, Skinner proposed that we demonstrate consistent behavior patterns because we have developed certain response tendencies (Skinner, 1953).']
['What does developing certain response tendencies mean?', 'In other words, we learn to behave in particular ways.']
['What happens when our behaviors are learned?', 'We increase the behaviors that lead to positive consequences, and we decrease the behaviors that lead to negative consequences.']
['Who disagreed with Skinner?', 'Skinner disagreed with Freud’s idea that personality is fixed in childhood.']
['What did Skinner disagree with Freud on?', 'He argued that personality develops over our entire life, not only in the first few years.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Our responses can change as we come across new situations; therefore, we can expect more variability over time in personality than Freud would anticipate.']
['For example, what was the first example mentioned?', 'For example, consider a young woman, Greta, a risk taker.']
['What does Greta do?', 'She drives fast and participates in dangerous sports such as hang gliding and kiteboarding.']
["What happened to Greta's response after she got married and had children?", 'But after she gets married and has children, the system of reinforcements and punishments in her environment changes.']
['What happens as a result of that?', 'Speeding and extreme sports are no longer reinforced, so she no longer engages in those behaviors.']
['Is Greta now a more cautious person?', 'In fact, Greta now describes herself as a cautious person.']
['What is the first sentence in this passage?', 'Albert Bandura agreed with Skinner that personality develops through learning.']

['Why did he disagree with Skinner?', 'He disagreed, however, with Skinner’s strict behaviorist approach to personality development, because he felt that thinking and reasoning are important components of learning.']
['How did he disagree with Skinner?', 'He presented a social-cognitive theory of personality that emphasizes both learning and cognition as sources of individual differences in personality.']
['What did Bandura say about learning?', 'In social-cognitive theory, the concepts of reciprocal determinism, observational learning, and self-efficacy all play a part in personality development.']

['What is reciprocal determinism?', 'In contrast to Skinner’s idea that the environment alone determines behavior, Bandura (1990) proposed the concept of reciprocal determinism, in which cognitive processes, behavior, and context all interact, each factor influencing and being influenced by the others simultaneously (Figure 11.10).']
['What are cognitive processes?', 'Cognitive processes refer to all characteristics previously learned, including beliefs, expectations, and personality characteristics.']
['What does behavior refer to?', 'Behavior refers to anything that we do that may be rewarded or punished.']
['What is the context in which the behavior occurs?', 'Finally, the context in which the behavior occurs refers to the environment or situation, which includes rewarding/punishing stimuli.']
['How would you arrive at that conclusion?', 'Consider, for example, that you’re at a festival and one of the attractions is bungee jumping from a bridge.']
['What is an example of a behavior that is a risky one?', 'In this example, the behavior is bungee jumping.']
['What other cognitive factors influence this behavior?', 'Cognitive factors that might influence this behavior include your beliefs and values, and your past experiences with similar behaviors.']
['What does context refer to?', 'Finally, context refers to the reward structure for the behavior.']
['What is there to know about this?', 'According to reciprocal determinism, all of these factors are in play.']
['What is Bandura’s key contribution to learning theory?', 'Bandura’s key contribution to learning theory was the idea that much learning is vicarious.']
["What is one of Bandura's theories?", 'We learn by observing someone else’s behavior and its consequences, which Bandura called observational learning.']
["What was Bandura's view on this?", 'He felt that this type of learning also plays a part in the development of our personality.']
['What does Bandura think about models?', 'Just as we learn individual behaviors, we learn new behavior patterns when we see them performed by other people or models.']

['What does Bandura believe about models?', 'Drawing on the behaviorists’ ideas about reinforcement, Bandura suggested that whether we choose to imitate a model’s behavior depends on whether we see the model reinforced or punished.']

['What else is Bandura known for?', 'Through observational learning, we come to learn what behaviors are acceptable and rewarded in our culture, and we also learn to inhibit deviant or socially unacceptable behaviors by seeing what behaviors are punished.']
['What can we learn from observational learning?', 'We can see the principles of reciprocal determinism at work in observational learning.']

['What are some examples of reciprocal determinism at work?', 'For example, personal factors determine which behaviors in the environment a person chooses to imitate, and those environmental events in turn are processed cognitively according to other personal factors.']

['What might result from receiving heightened attention?', 'One person may experience receiving attention as reinforcing, and that person may be more inclined to imitate behaviors such as boasting when a model has been reinforced.']

['What happens to others after boasting?', 'For others, boasting may be viewed negatively, despite the attention that might result—or receiving heightened attention may be perceived as being scrutinized.']
['How would it be perceived?', 'In either case, the person may be less likely to imitate those behaviors even though the reasons for not doing so would be different.']

['What is it about?', 'Bandura (1977, 1995) has studied a number of cognitive and personal factors that affect learning and personality development, and most recently has focused on the concept of self-efficacy.']
['What is the definition of self-efficacy?', 'Self-efficacy is our level of confidence in our own abilities, developed through our social experiences.']
['What does self-efficacy affect?', 'Self-efficacy affects how we approach challenges and reach goals.']

['What is a cognitive factor that affects which behaviors we choose to imitate as well as our success in performing those behaviors?', 'In observational learning, self-efficacy is a cognitive factor that affects which behaviors we choose to imitate as well as our success in performing those behaviors.']

['what are the important aspects of self-efficacy?', 'People who have high self-efficacy believe that their goals are within reach, have a positive view of challenges seeing them as tasks to be mastered, develop a deep interest in and strong commitment to the activities in which they are involved, and quickly recover from setbacks.']

['How is this different from low self-efficacy?', 'Conversely, people with low self-efficacy avoid challenging tasks because they doubt their ability to be successful, tend to focus on failure and negative outcomes, and lose confidence in their abilities if they experience setbacks.']
['How specific are these feelings?', 'Feelings of self-efficacy can be specific to certain situations.']
['What situations might a student feel confident in her ability in?', 'For instance, a student might feel confident in her ability in English class but much less so in math class.']
['What else is significant about Julian Rotter?', 'Julian Rotter (1966) proposed the concept of locus of control, another cognitive factor that affects learning and personality development.']

['What is the difference between self-efficacy and locus of control?', 'Distinct from self-efficacy, which involves our belief in our own abilities, locus of control refers to our beliefs about the power we have over our lives.']
["What is rotter's view?", 'In Rotter’s view, people possess either an internal or an external locus of control (Figure 11.11).']
['What is significant about the internal locus?', 'Those of us with an internal locus of control (“internals”) tend to believe that most of our outcomes are the direct result of our efforts.']
['What about external locus of control?', 'Those of us with an external locus of control (“externals”) tend to believe that our outcomes are outside of our control.']
['What is something interesting about external locus of control?', 'Externals see their lives as being controlled by other people, luck, or chance.']
['What can you tell me about this example?', 'For example, say you didn’t spend much time studying for your psychology test and went out to dinner with friends instead.']
['What happens when you receive your test score?', 'When you receive your test score, you see that you earned a D.']

['What did you do after you received the test?', 'If you possess an internal locus of control, you would most likely admit that you failed because you didn’t spend enough time studying and decide to study more for the next test.']

['What happens if you possess an external locus of control?', 'On the other hand, if you possess an external locus of control, you might conclude that the test was too hard and not bother studying for the next test, because you figure you will fail it anyway.']

['Why is internal locus important?', 'Researchers have found that people with an internal locus of control perform better academically, achieve more in their careers, are more independent, are healthier, are better able to cope, and are less depressed than people who have an external locus of control (Benassi, Sweeney, & Durfour, 1988; Lefcourt, 1982; Maltby, Day, & Macaskill, 2007; Whyte, 1977, 1978, 1980).']
["Who was Julian Rotter's student?", 'Walter Mischel was a student of Julian Rotter and taught for years at Stanford, where he was a colleague of Albert Bandura.']

['What conclusions did he make?', 'Mischel surveyed several decades of empirical psychological literature regarding trait prediction of behavior, and his conclusion shook the foundations of personality psychology.']
['What did the data not support?', 'Mischel found that the data did not support the central principle of the field—that a person’s personality traits are consistent across situations.']
['What did the person-situation debate turn out to be?', 'His report triggered a decades-long period of self-examination, known as the person-situation debate, among personality psychologists.']
['What is the most important thing you want to know about the study material?', 'Mischel suggested that perhaps we were looking for consistency in the wrong places.']

['What else did Mischel find?', 'He found that although behavior was inconsistent across different situations, it was much more consistent within situations—so that a person’s behavior in one situation would likely be repeated in a similar one.']
['What else did Mischel find?', 'And as you will see next regarding his famous “marshmallow test,” Mischel also found that behavior is consistent in equivalent situations across time.']
['What did Mischel study?', 'One of Mischel’s most notable contributions to personality psychology was his ideas on self-regulation.']

['What is self-regulation?', 'According to Lecci & Magnavita (2013), “Self-regulation is the process of identifying a goal or set of goals and, in pursuing these goals, using both internal (e.g., thoughts and affect) and external (e.g., responses of anything or anyone in the environment) feedback to maximize goal attainment” (p. 6.3).']
['What is another name for self-regulation?', 'Self-regulation is also known as will power.']
['What is the ability to delay gratification called?', 'When we talk about will power, we tend to think of it as the ability to delay gratification.']
['What kind of things are meant to delay?', 'For example, Bettina’s teenage son made strawberry cupcakes, and they looked delicious.']

['Bettina got a box of cupcakes. How did she feel about them?', 'However, Bettina forfeited the pleasure of eating one, because she is training for a 5K race and wants to be fit and do well in the race.']
['What did Mischel study?', 'This is the question Mischel investigated in his now-classic marshmallow test.']
['What did Mischel design?', 'Mischel designed a study to assess self-regulation in young children.']
['What was the marshmallow study?', 'In the marshmallow study, Mischel and his colleagues placed a preschool child in a room with one marshmallow on the table.']

['What did the child do?', 'The children were told they could either eat the marshmallow now, or wait until the researcher returned to the room, and then they could have two marshmallows (Mischel, Ebbesen & Raskoff, 1972).']
['What was accomplished with this study?', 'This was repeated with hundreds of preschoolers.']
['What did Mischel and his team find?', 'What Mischel and his team found was that young children differ in their degree of self-control.']
["Did he study other people's self-control?", 'The children who had more self-control in preschool (the ones who waited for the bigger reward) were more successful in high school.']

['What did they have to show for this?', 'They had higher SAT scores, had positive peer relationships, and were less likely to have substance abuse issues; as adults, they also had more stable marriages (Mischel, Shoda, & Rodriguez, 1989; Mischel et al., 2010).']

['What else was found?', 'On the other hand, those children who had poor self-control in preschool (the ones who grabbed the one marshmallow) were not as successful in high school, and they were found to have academic and behavioral problems.']

['What was the most recent study that found associations between early delay of gratification and measures of achievement in adolescence?', 'A more recent study using a larger and more representative sample found  associations between early delay of gratification (Watts, Duncan, & Quan, 2018) and measures of achievement in adolescence.']

['What else did researchers find?', "However, researchers also found that the associations were not as strong as those reported during Mischel's initial experiment and were quite sensitive to situational factors such as early measures of cognitive capacity, family background, and home environment."]
['What can you tell me about the research?', 'This research suggests that consideration of situational factors is important to better understand behavior.']
['What happens with this debate?', 'Today, the debate is mostly resolved, and most psychologists consider both the situation and personal factors in understanding behavior.']
['What did Walter Mischel study with?', 'For Mischel (1993), people are situation processors.']
['What is a reward structure?', 'The children in the marshmallow test each processed, or interpreted, the rewards structure of that situation in their own way.']
['What kind of approach does he take?', 'Mischel’s approach to personality stresses the importance of both the situation and the way the person perceives the situation.']

['What kind of behavior is described in the article?', 'Instead of behavior being determined by the situation, people use cognitive processes to interpret the situation and then behave in accordance with that interpretation.']

['What is third force?', 'As the “third force” in psychology, humanism is touted as a reaction both to the pessimistic determinism of psychoanalysis, with its emphasis on psychological disturbance, and to the behaviorists’ view of humans passively reacting to the environment, which has been criticized as making people out to be personality-less robots.']

['What does it suggest?', 'It does not suggest that psychoanalytic, behaviorist, and other points of view are incorrect but argues that these perspectives do not recognize the depth and meaning of human experience, and fail to recognize the innate capacity for self-directed change and transforming personal experiences.']
['What is the third force based on?', 'This perspective focuses on how healthy people develop.']

['What is the name of the humanist who studied people who were healthy, creative, and productive?', 'One pioneering humanist, Abraham Maslow, studied people who he considered to be healthy, creative, and productive, including Albert Einstein, Eleanor Roosevelt, Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln, and others.']

['What did he study?', 'Maslow (1950, 1970) found that such people share similar characteristics, such as being open, creative, loving, spontaneous, compassionate, concerned for others, and accepting of themselves.']

['What else did he find?', "When you studied motivation, you learned about one of the best-known humanistic theories, Maslow's hierarchy of needs theory, in which Maslow proposes that human beings have certain needs in common and that these needs must be met in a certain order."]
['What is the highest need?', 'The highest need is the need for self-actualization, which is the achievement of our fullest potential.']
['What did he discover?', 'Maslow differentiated between needs that motivate us to fulfill something that is missing and needs that inspire us to grow.']
['What were some of his findings?', 'He believed that many emotional and behavioral concerns arise as a result of failing to meet these hierarchical needs.']
['What is the name of the other humanistic theorist?', 'Another humanistic theorist was Carl Rogers.']
['What does he think about personality?', 'One of Rogers’s main ideas about personality regards self-concept, our thoughts and feelings about ourselves.']
['How do we define ourselves as human beings?', 'How would you respond to the question, “Who am I?” Your answer can show how you see yourself.']
['What will your response tell you?', 'If your response is primarily positive, then you tend to feel good about who you are, and you see the world as a safe and positive place.']
['What if your response is mainly negative?', 'If your response is mainly negative, then you may feel unhappy with who you are.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Rogers further divided the self into two categories: the ideal self and the real self.']
['What are the two categories of self?', 'The ideal self is the person that you would like to be; the real self is the person you actually are.']
['What is his take on this?', 'Rogers focused on the idea that we need to achieve consistency between these two selves.']
['What is congruence?', 'We experience congruence when our thoughts about our real self and ideal self are very similar—in other words, when our self-concept is accurate.']
['How does this help?', 'High congruence leads to a greater sense of self-worth and a healthy, productive life.']
['What can parents do to help their children achieve this?', 'Parents can help their children achieve this by giving them unconditional positive regard, or unconditional love.']
['Can you explain what unconditional love means?', 'According to Rogers (1980), “As persons are accepted and prized, they tend to develop a more caring attitude towards themselves” (p. 116).']

['What does Rogers call the state where there is a great discrepancy between our ideal and actual selves?', 'Conversely, when there is a great discrepancy between our ideal and actual selves, we experience a state Rogers called incongruence, which can lead to maladjustment.']
['What is the difference between Rogers and Maslow?', 'Both Rogers’s and Maslow’s theories focus on individual choices and do not believe that biology is deterministic.']

['what does biological approach believe mean?', 'Psychologists who favor the biological approach believe that inherited predispositions as well as physiological processes can be used to explain differences in our personalities (Burger, 2008).']
['What is significant about this section?', 'Evolutionary psychology relative to personality development looks at personality traits that are universal, as well as differences across individuals.']
['What are the theories of evolution?', 'In this view, adaptive differences have evolved and then provide a survival and reproductive advantage.']
['What are the reasons individual differences are important from an evolutionary viewpoint?', 'Individual differences are important from an evolutionary viewpoint for several reasons.']
['What is heritability determined by?', 'Certain individual differences, and the heritability of these characteristics, have been well documented.']

['What are the theories of personality traits?', 'David Buss has identified several theories to explore this relationship between personality traits and evolution, such as life-history theory, which looks at how people expend their time and energy (such as on bodily growth and maintenance, reproduction, or parenting).']

['What other theories are there?', 'Another example is costly signaling theory, which examines the honesty and deception in the signals people send one another about their quality as a mate or friend (Buss, 2009).']

['When was the study conducted?', 'In the field of behavioral genetics, the Minnesota Study of Twins Reared Apart—a well-known study of the genetic basis for personality—conducted research with twins from 1979 to 1999.']

['What were the findings?', 'In studying 350 pairs of twins, including pairs of identical and fraternal twins reared together and apart, researchers found that identical twins, whether raised together or apart, have very similar personalities (Bouchard, 1994; Bouchard, Lykken, McGue, Segal, & Tellegen, 1990; Segal, 2012).']
['What did the findings suggest?', 'These findings suggest the heritability of some personality traits.']
['What does heritability refer to?', 'Heritability refers to the proportion of difference among people that is attributed to genetics.']

['What traits were attributed to genetics?', 'Some of the traits that the study reported as having more than a 0.50 heritability ratio include leadership, obedience to authority, a sense of well-being, alienation, resistance to stress, and fearfulness.']

['What can we infer from these findings?', 'The implication is that some aspects of our personalities are largely controlled by genetics; however, it’s important to point out that traits are not determined by a single gene, but by a combination of many genes, as well as by epigenetic factors that control whether the genes are expressed.']
['What is the biological basis of temperament?', 'Most contemporary psychologists believe temperament has a biological basis due to its appearance very early in our lives (Rothbart, 2011).']

['What did Thomas and Chess (1977) find that babies could be categorized into one of three temperaments: easy, difficult, or slow to warm up?', 'As you learned when you studied lifespan development, Thomas and Chess (1977) found that babies could be categorized into one of three temperaments: easy, difficult, or slow to warm up.']

['Is there anything else worth mentioning that is relevant?', 'However, environmental factors (family interactions, for example) and maturation can affect the ways in which children’s personalities are expressed (Carter et al., 2008).']

['What are the two dimensions?', 'Research suggests that there are two dimensions of our temperament that are important parts of our adult personality—reactivity and self-regulation (Rothbart, Ahadi, & Evans, 2000).']

['How do they work together?', 'Reactivity refers to how we respond to new or challenging environmental stimuli; self-regulation refers to our ability to control that response (Rothbart & Derryberry, 1981; Rothbart, Sheese, Rueda, & Posner, 2011).']

['What does it mean when one person responds to new stimuli with a high level of anxiety, while another barely notices it?', 'For example, one person may immediately respond to new stimuli with a high level of anxiety, while another barely notices it.']
['What are the trait theory?', 'Trait theorists believe personality can be understood via the approach that all people have certain traits, or characteristic ways of behaving.']
['What did the early trait theorists try to do?', 'Early trait theorists tried to describe all human personality traits.']
['What is the article about?', 'For example, one trait theorist, Gordon Allport (Allport & Odbert, 1936), found 4,500 words in the English language that could describe people.']
['What did he organize these personality traits into?', 'He organized these personality traits into three categories: cardinal traits, central traits, and secondary traits.']
['What is a cardinal trait?', 'A cardinal trait is one that dominates your entire personality, and hence your life—such as Ebenezer Scrooge’s greed and Mother Theresa’s altruism.']
['What do you know about cardinal traits?', 'Cardinal traits are not very common:']
['Are there more than one cardinal trait?', 'Few people have personalities dominated by a single trait.']
['Is there only one type of trait in the world?', 'Instead, our personalities typically are composed of multiple traits.']
['What are the traits that make up our personalities?', 'Central traits are those that make up our personalities (such as loyal, kind, agreeable, friendly, sneaky, wild, and grouchy).']
['What are traits that are not quite as obvious or as consistent as central traits?', 'Secondary traits are those that are not quite as obvious or as consistent as central traits.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects of the article?', 'They are present under specific circumstances and include preferences and attitudes.']

["What are some examples of a person's personality?", 'For example, one person gets angry when people try to tickle him; another can only sleep on the left side of the bed; and yet another always orders her salad dressing on the side.']
['What can you say about secondary traits?', 'And you—although not normally an anxious person—feel nervous before making a speech in front of your English class.']
['What is the most important thing about the passage?', 'In an effort to make the list of traits more manageable, Raymond Cattell (1946, 1957) narrowed down the list to about 171 traits.']

['What does saying that a trait is either present or absent not accurately reflect?', 'However, saying that a trait is either present or absent does not accurately reflect a person’s uniqueness, because all of our personalities are actually made up of the same traits; we differ only in the degree to which each trait is expressed.']

['What are some other interesting aspects about the article?', 'Cattell (1957) identified 16 factors or dimensions of personality: warmth, reasoning, emotional stability, dominance, liveliness, rule-consciousness, social boldness, sensitivity, vigilance, abstractedness, privateness, apprehension, openness to change, self-reliance, perfectionism, and tension (Table 11.5).']
['What did the reading tell me?', 'He developed a personality assessment based on these 16 factors, called the 16PF.']
['How is the 16PF scored?', 'Instead of a trait being present or absent, each dimension is scored over a continuum, from high to low.']
['What is the 16PF?', 'For example, your level of warmth describes how warm, caring, and nice to others you are.']
['Are you warm to others?', 'If you score low on this index, you tend to be more distant and cold.']
['How can you be perceived as warm?', 'A high score on this index signifies you are supportive and comforting.']

['What are traits that characterize people?', 'Psychologists Hans and Sybil Eysenck were personality theorists (Figure 11.12) who focused on temperament, the inborn, genetically based personality differences that you studied earlier in the chapter.']
['What did they believe about personality?', 'They believed personality is largely governed by biology.']

['What are the two specific personality dimensions?', 'The Eysencks (Eysenck, 1990, 1992; Eysenck & Eysenck, 1963) viewed people as having two specific personality dimensions: extroversion/introversion and neuroticism/stability.']

['What is important about extroversion and introversion?', 'According to their theory, people high on the trait of extroversion are sociable and outgoing, and readily connect with others, whereas people high on the trait of introversion have a higher need to be alone, engage in solitary behaviors, and limit their interactions with others.']

['What was the overactivity of sympathetic nervous system?', 'In the neuroticism/stability dimension, people high on neuroticism tend to be anxious; they tend to have an overactive sympathetic nervous system and, even with low stress, their bodies and emotional state tend to go into a flight-or-fight reaction.']

['How can that affect the body and emotions?', 'In contrast, people high on stability tend to need more stimulation to activate their flight-or-fight reaction and are considered more emotionally stable.']
['What were these dimensions?', 'Based on these two dimensions, the Eysencks’ theory divides people into four quadrants.']
['What are these four quadrants?', 'These quadrants are sometimes compared with the four temperaments described by the Greeks: melancholic, choleric, phlegmatic, and sanguine (Figure 11.13).']
["What's an important thing we learned from this study material?", 'Later, the Eysencks added a third dimension: psychoticism versus superego control (Eysenck, Eysenck & Barrett, 1985).']

['What are some characteristics of people with psychoticism versus superego control?', 'In this dimension, people who are high on psychoticism tend to be independent thinkers, cold, nonconformists, impulsive, antisocial, and hostile, whereas people who are high on superego control tend to have high impulse control—they are more altruistic, empathetic, cooperative, and conventional (Eysenck, Eysenck & Barrett, 1985).']
['What are some of the main points made about Cattell’s 16 factors?', 'While Cattell’s 16 factors may be too broad, the Eysenck’s two-factor system has been criticized for being too narrow.']

['How many personality traits are there?', 'Another personality theory, called the Five Factor Model, effectively hits a middle ground, with its five factors referred to as the Big Five personality factors.']

['What is the most important theory in personality psychology today?', 'It is the most popular theory in personality psychology today and the most accurate approximation of the basic personality dimensions (Funder, 2001).']
['What are the five factors?', 'The five factors are openness to experience, conscientiousness, extroversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism (Figure 11.14).']
['How can we remember the factors?', 'A helpful way to remember the factors is by using the mnemonic OCEAN.']
['How does the spectrum of personality affect the way people behave?', 'In the Five Factor Model, each person has each factor, but they occur along a spectrum.']
['What is openness characterized by?', 'Openness to experience is characterized by imagination, feelings, actions, and ideas.']
['What do people who score high on imagination have?', 'People who score high on this factor tend to be curious and have a wide range of interests.']
['What do people who score high on conscientiousness have?', 'Conscientiousness is characterized by competence, self-discipline, thoughtfulness, and achievement-striving (goal-directed behavior).']
['What does trustworthy mean to people?', 'People who score high on this factor are hardworking and dependable.']

['Do studies show that conscientiousness leads to good results in school?', 'Numerous studies have found a positive correlation between conscientiousness and academic success (Akomolafe, 2013; Chamorro-Premuzic & Furnham, 2008; Conrad & Patry, 2012; Noftle & Robins, 2007; Wagerman & Funder, 2007).']
['What are the characteristics of extroverts?', 'Extroversion is characterized by sociability, assertiveness, excitement-seeking, and emotional expression.']
['What are the characteristics of people who have extroversion?', 'People who score high on this factor are usually described as outgoing and warm.']

['Are people who have extroversion more likely to do adventure sports?', 'Not surprisingly, people who score high on both extroversion and openness are more likely to participate in adventure and risky sports due to their curious and excitement-seeking nature (Tok, 2011).']
['What is the fourth factor?', 'The fourth factor is agreeableness, which is the tendency to be pleasant, cooperative, trustworthy, and good-natured.']

['Do people who are more agreeable tend to be more successful?', 'People who score low on agreeableness tend to be described as rude and uncooperative, yet one recent study reported that men who scored low on this factor actually earned more money than men who were considered more agreeable (Judge, Livingston, & Hurst, 2012).']
['What is the last factor of the Big Five?', 'The last of the Big Five factors is neuroticism, which is the tendency to experience negative emotions.']
['What are the negative emotions like for people who have neuroticism?', 'People high on neuroticism tend to experience emotional instability and are characterized as angry, impulsive, and hostile.']
['Do people who have neuroticism also feel anxious and unhappy?', 'Watson and Clark (1984) found that people reporting high levels of neuroticism also tend to report feeling anxious and unhappy.']
['What else do people who have neuroticism feel?', 'In contrast, people who score low in neuroticism tend to be calm and even-tempered.']
['What are the five personality factors?', 'The Big Five personality factors each represent a range between two extremes.']
['What is the difference between these two extremes?', 'In reality, most of us tend to lie somewhere midway along the continuum of each factor, rather than at polar ends.']
['What are the Big Five factors?', 'It’s important to note that the Big Five factors are relatively stable over our lifespan, with some tendency for the factors to increase or decrease slightly.']

['What is the reason for conscientiousness increasing or decreasing slightly?', 'Researchers have found that conscientiousness increases through young adulthood into middle age, as we become better able to manage our personal relationships and careers (Donnellan & Lucas, 2008).']
['What other factor increase with age?', 'Agreeableness also increases with age, peaking between 50 to 70 years (Terracciano, McCrae, Brant, & Costa, 2005).']
['What other factor decrease with age?', 'Neuroticism and extroversion tend to decline slightly with age (Donnellan & Lucas; Terracciano et al.).']

['What is notable about the article?', 'Additionally, The Big Five factors have been shown to exist across ethnicities, cultures, and ages, and may have substantial biological and genetic components (Jang, Livesley, & Vernon, 1996; Jang et al., 2006; McCrae & Costa, 1997; Schmitt et al., 2007).']
['What is another model of personality traits?', 'Another model of personality traits is the HEXACO model.']

['What is the acronym for the six broad traits?', 'HEXACO is an acronym for six broad traits: honesty-humility, emotionality, extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, and openness to experience (Anglim & O’Connor, 2018).']
['What is the most important information about these traits?', 'Table 11.6 provides a brief overview of each trait.']
['What is the topic of the study?', 'As you have learned in this chapter, personality is shaped by both genetic and environmental factors.']

['What is the most important environmental factor that shapes your personality?', 'The culture in which you live is one of the most important environmental factors that shapes your personality (Triandis & Suh, 2002).']
['What is the meaning of culture?', 'The term culture refers to all of the beliefs, customs, art, and traditions of a particular society.']

['How is culture transmitted to people?', 'Culture is transmitted to people through language as well as through the modeling of culturally acceptable and nonacceptable behaviors that are either rewarded or punished (Triandis & Suh, 2002).']
['What is significant about the study?', 'With these ideas in mind, personality psychologists have become interested in the role of culture in understanding personality.']
['What questions do they have?', 'They ask whether personality traits are the same across cultures or if there are variations.']
['What are the results of the study?', 'It appears that there are both universal and culture-specific aspects that account for variation in people’s personalities.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Western ideas about personality may not be applicable to other cultures (Benet-Martinez & Oishi, 2008).']
['What is the evidence that the strength of personality traits varies across cultures?', 'In fact, there is evidence that the strength of personality traits varies across cultures.']
['What are some examples of cultural differences?', 'Let’s take a look at some of the Big Five factors (conscientiousness, neuroticism, openness, and extroversion) across cultures.']
['What else did you find?', 'As you will learn when you study social psychology, Asian cultures are more collectivist, and people in these cultures tend to be less extroverted.']

['What else was found?', 'People in Central and South American cultures tend to score higher on openness to experience, whereas Europeans score higher on neuroticism (Benet-Martinez & Karakitapoglu-Aygun, 2003).']
['What were the most important findings?', 'According to a study by Rentfrow and colleagues, there also seem to be regional personality differences within the United States (Figure 11.15).']

['What was the study about?', 'Researchers analyzed responses from over 1.5 million individuals in the United States and found that there are three distinct regional personality clusters: Cluster 1, which is in the Upper Midwest and Deep South, is dominated by people who fall into the “friendly and conventional” personality; Cluster 2, which includes the West, is dominated by people who are more relaxed, emotionally stable, calm, and creative; and Cluster 3, which includes the Northeast, has more people who are stressed, irritable, and depressed.']
['What is known about Cluster 2?', 'People who live in Clusters 2 and 3 are also generally more open (Rentfrow et al., 2013).']
['What is the explanation for the regional differences?', 'One explanation for the regional differences is selective migration (Rentfrow et al., 2013).']

['What is the concept that people choose to move to places that are compatible with their personalities and needs?', 'Selective migration is the concept that people choose to move to places that are compatible with their personalities and needs.']
['What do people choose to move?', 'For example, a person high on the agreeable scale would likely want to live near family and friends, and would choose to settle or remain in such an area.']
['What other examples of selective migration are there?', 'In contrast, someone high on openness would prefer to settle in a place that is recognized as diverse and innovative (such as California).']

['Who else noted this overlap?', 'Further, Rentfrow, Jost, Gosling, & Potter (2009) noted an overlap between geographical regions and personality characteristics that goes beyond the often-used explanations of religion, racial diversity, and education.']
['What did they note?', 'Their research suggests that the psychological profile of a region is closely related to that of its residents.']

['What did they find?', 'They found that levels of openness and conscientiousness in a state may predict voting patterns, indicating that there are correlations between geographic regions and personality differences between liberals and conservatives relating to political views, levels of economic vitality, and entrepreneurial rates.']
['What is important about individualist cultures and collectivist cultures?', 'Individualist cultures and collectivist cultures place emphasis on different basic values.']
['What kind of values do the individuals focus on?', 'People who live in individualist cultures tend to believe that independence, competition, and personal achievement are important.']
['What countries score high on individualism?', 'Individuals in Western nations such as the United States, England, and Australia score high on individualism (Oyserman, Coon, & Kemmelmier, 2002).']
['What kind of values do the people live in?', 'People who live in collectivist cultures value social harmony, respectfulness, and group needs over individual needs.']
['What kind of countries are they from?', 'Individuals who live in countries in Asia, Africa, and South America score high on collectivism (Hofstede, 2001; Triandis, 1995).']
['What impact do the cultures have on the individual?', 'These values influence personality.']

['What other studies have examined the impact of cultural values?', 'For example, Yang (2006) found that people in individualist cultures displayed more personally oriented personality traits, whereas people in collectivist cultures displayed more socially oriented personality traits.']
['What studies have found similar results?', 'Frewer and Bleus (1991) conducted a study of the Eysenk Personality Inventory in a collectivist culture using Papua New Guinean university students.']
['What did the study find?', 'They found that the results of the personality inventory were only relevant when analyzed within the context of a collectivist society.']

['What other studies have been done on Native Americans?', 'Similarly, Dana (1986) suggested that personality assessment services for Native Americans are often provided without a proper recognition of culture-specific responses and a tribe-specific frame of reference.']

['What can we learn from the study?', 'Assessors need to have more than a general knowledge of history, tribal differences, contemporary culture on reservations, and levels of acculturation in order to interpret psychological test responses with a minimal bias.']

['What are these approaches?', 'There are three approaches that can be used to study personality in a cultural context, the cultural-comparative approach; the indigenous approach; and the combined approach, which incorporates elements of both views.']

['How does the comparative approach work?', 'Since ideas about personality have a Western basis, the cultural-comparative approach seeks to test Western ideas about personality in other cultures to determine whether they can be generalized and if they have cultural validity (Cheung van de Vijver, & Leong, 2011).']

['What are some examples of the cultural-comparative approach?', 'For example, recall from the previous section on the trait perspective that researchers used the cultural-comparative approach to test the universality of McCrae and Costa’s Five Factor Model.']
['What did they discover?', 'They found applicability in numerous cultures around the world, with the Big Five factors being stable in many cultures (McCrae & Costa, 1997; McCrae et al., 2005).']

['What is the indigenous approach?', 'The indigenous approach came about in reaction to the dominance of Western approaches to the study of personality in non-Western settings (Cheung et al., 2011).']

['Why did they react?', 'Because Western-based personality assessments cannot fully capture the personality constructs of other cultures, the indigenous model has led to the development of personality assessment instruments that are based on constructs relevant to the culture being studied (Cheung et al., 2011).']

['What is the third approach to cross-cultural studies of personality?', 'The third approach to cross-cultural studies of personality is the combined approach, which serves as a bridge between Western and indigenous psychology as a way of understanding both universal and cultural variations in personality (Cheung et al., 2011).']
['What is the article about?', 'Roberto, Mikhail, and Nat are college friends and all want to be police officers.']
["What was Roberto's personality like?", 'Roberto is quiet and shy, lacks self-confidence, and usually follows others.']
['What was his character like?', 'He is a kind person, but lacks motivation.']
["What was Mikhail's personality like?", 'Mikhail is loud and boisterous, a leader.']
['What was his character like?', 'He works hard, but is impulsive and drinks too much on the weekends.']
["What was Nat's personality like?", 'Nat is thoughtful and well liked.']
['What was their character?', 'They are trustworthy, but are very methodical and therefore have difficulty making quick decisions.']
['What is the purpose of these tests?', 'A police officer’s job is very high in stress, and law enforcement agencies want to make sure they hire the right people.']
['What is the purpose of the tests?', 'Personality testing is often used for this purpose—to screen applicants for employment and job training.']
['What are some other types of testing?', 'Personality tests are also used in criminal cases and custody battles, and to assess psychological disorders.']
['What are the different types of personality tests?', 'This section explores the best known among the many different types of personality tests.']
['What are self-report inventories?', 'Self-report inventories are a kind of objective test used to assess personality.']
['What kind of questions do they use?', 'They typically use multiple-choice items or numbered scales, which represent a range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree).']
['What are Likert scales known as?', 'They often are called Likert scales after their developer, Rensis Likert (1932) (Figure 11.16).']
['How long do they take to administer?', 'Self-report inventories are generally easy to administer and cost effective.']

['What is the increased likelihood of test takers being inclined to answer in ways that are intentionally or unintentionally more socially desirable, exaggerated, biased, or misleading?', 'There is also an increased likelihood of test takers being inclined to answer in ways that are intentionally or unintentionally more socially desirable, exaggerated, biased, or misleading.']
['Why does someone do this?', 'For example, someone applying for a job will likely try to present themselves in a positive light, perhaps as an even better candidate than they actually are.']

['What is the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory?', 'One of the most widely used personality inventories is the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI), first published in 1943, with 504 true/false questions, and updated to the MMPI-2 in 1989, with 567 questions.']

['What is significant about the MMPI?', 'The original MMPI was based on a small, limited sample, composed mostly of Minnesota farmers and psychiatric patients; the revised inventory was based on a more representative, national sample to allow for better standardization.']
['How long does the MMPI take?', 'The MMPI-2 takes 1–2 hours to complete.']

['What are the 10 scales that are used to score the responses?', 'Responses are scored to produce a clinical profile composed of 10 scales: hypochondriasis, depression, hysteria, psychopathic deviance (social deviance), masculinity versus femininity, paranoia, psychasthenia (obsessive/compulsive qualities), schizophrenia, hypomania, and social introversion.']
['What else can you tell me about the MMPI?', 'There is also a scale to ascertain risk factors for alcohol abuse.']
['What is the MMPI-2?', 'In 2008, the test was again revised, using more advanced methods, to the MMPI-2-RF.']
['What are the differences between the two versions?', 'This version takes about one-half the time to complete and has only 338 questions (Figure 11.17).']
['What is significant about the MMPI-2?', 'Despite the new test’s advantages, the MMPI-2 is more established and is still more widely used.']
['How is the MMPI-2-RF administered?', 'Typically, the tests are administered by computer.']

['What other types of tests do they have?', 'Although the MMPI was originally developed to assist in the clinical diagnosis of psychological disorders, it is now also used for occupational screening, such as in law enforcement, and in college, career, and marital counseling (Ben-Porath & Tellegen, 2008).']
['What are the tests based on?', 'In addition to clinical scales, the tests also have validity and reliability scales.']
['What are reliability and validity scales?', '(Recall the concepts of reliability and validity from your study of psychological research.)']

['What is the Lie Scale?', 'One of the validity scales, the Lie Scale (or “L” Scale), consists of 15 items and is used to ascertain whether the respondent is “faking good” (underreporting psychological problems to appear healthier).']

['How can the Lie scale be used to detect false self-reporting?', 'For example, if someone responds “yes” to a number of unrealistically positive items such as “I have never told a lie,” they may be trying to “fake good” or appear better than they actually are.']

['What do reliability scales test?', 'Reliability scales test an instrument’s consistency over time, assuring that if you take the MMPI-2-RF today and then again 5 years later, your two scores will be similar.']
['What are some articles about a study?', 'Beutler, Nussbaum, and Meredith (1988) gave the MMPI to newly recruited police officers and then to the same police officers 2 years later.']

['What did they find out?', 'After 2 years on the job, police officers’ responses indicated an increased vulnerability to alcoholism, somatic symptoms (vague, unexplained physical complaints), and anxiety.']
['Why was it that way?', 'When the test was given an additional 2 years later (4 years after starting on the job), the results suggested  high risk for alcohol-related difficulties.']
['What are some other terms for projective tests?', 'Another method for assessment of personality is projective testing.']

['What kind of test relies on one of the defense mechanisms proposed by Freud—projection—as a way to assess unconscious processes?', 'This kind of test relies on one of the defense mechanisms proposed by Freud—projection—as a way to assess unconscious processes.']

['How does the person complete the projective test?', 'During this type of testing, a series of ambiguous cards is shown to the person being tested, who then is encouraged to project their feelings, impulses, and desires onto the cards—by telling a story, interpreting an image, or completing a sentence.']

['What can projective tests be used to access?', 'Many projective tests have undergone standardization procedures (for example, Exner, 2002) and can be used to access whether someone has unusual thoughts or a high level of anxiety, or is likely to become volatile.']

['What are some examples of projective tests?', 'Some examples of projective tests are the Rorschach Inkblot Test, the Thematic Apperception Test (TAT), the Contemporized-Themes Concerning Blacks test, the TEMAS (Tell-Me-A-Story), and the Rotter Incomplete Sentence Blank (RISB).']
['What is another benefit of projective tests?', 'Projective tests are less subject to intentional distortion; it is hard to fake “good" because it is not obvious what a "good” answer is.']
['Are there any disadvantages to using a self-report inventory?', 'Projective tests are more time consuming for the evaluator than self-report inventories.']
['What is the Exner scoring system?', 'If an evaluator scores the Rorschach using the Exner scoring system, the test is considered a valid and reliable measure.']
['Can you tell me about other test scores?', 'However, the validity of the other projective tests is questionable, and the results are often not usable for court cases (Goldstein, n.d.).']
['Who invented the Rorschach Inkblot Test?', 'The Rorschach Inkblot Test was developed in 1921 by a Swiss psychologist named Hermann Rorschach (pronounced “ROAR-shock”).']
['What is the fMRI test?', 'It is a series of symmetrical inkblot cards that are presented to a client by a psychologist.']
['How are the cards presented?', 'Upon presentation of each card, the psychologist asks the client, “What might this be?”']
['What does the test taker see?', 'What the test-taker sees reveals unconscious feelings and struggles (Piotrowski, 1987; Weiner, 2003).']
['What else can you tell me about the Rorschach?', 'The Rorschach has been standardized using the Exner system and is effective in measuring depression, psychosis, and anxiety.']

['What is the second projective test?', 'A second projective test is the Thematic Apperception Test (TAT), created in the 1930s by Henry Murray, an American psychologist, and a psychoanalyst named Christiana Morgan.']
['What happens in the TAT?', 'A person taking the TAT is shown 8–12 ambiguous pictures and is asked to tell a story about each picture (Figure 11.18).']
['What do the stories reveal about the characters?', 'The stories give insight into their social world, revealing hopes, fears, interests, and goals.']

['Does the storytelling format help to lower a person’s resistance divulging unconscious personal details?', 'The storytelling format helps to lower a person’s resistance divulging unconscious personal details (Cramer, 2004).']

['What is the TAT used for?', 'The TAT has been used in clinical settings to evaluate psychological disorders; more recently, it has been used in counseling settings to help clients gain a better understanding of themselves and achieve personal growth.']

['How does the TAT perform?', 'Standardization of test administration is virtually nonexistent among clinicians, and the test tends to be modest to low on validity and reliability (Aronow, Weiss, & Rezinkoff, 2001; Lilienfeld, Wood, & Garb, 2000).']
['What is the scalability issue with the TAT?', 'Despite these shortcomings, the TAT has been one of the most widely used projective tests.']

['What is the third projective test?', 'A third projective test is the Rotter Incomplete Sentence Blank (RISB) developed by Julian Rotter in 1950 (recall his theory of locus of control, covered earlier in this chapter).']
['What age groups can you use it with?', 'There are three forms of this test for use with different age groups: the school form, the college form, and the adult form.']
['What happens if someone does not complete the test quickly?', 'The tests include 40 incomplete sentences that people are asked to complete as quickly as possible (Figure 11.19).']
['How long does it take to complete the test?', 'The average time for completing the test is approximately 20 minutes, as responses are only 1–2 words in length.']

['What happens with the test results?', 'This test is similar to a word association test, and like other types of projective tests, it is presumed that responses will reveal desires, fears, and struggles.']
['What are the applications of the RISB?', 'The RISB is used in screening college students for adjustment problems and in career counseling (Holaday, Smith, & Sherry, 2010; Rotter & Rafferty 1950).']
['What are some of the characteristics associated with these tests?', 'For many decades, these traditional projective tests have been used in cross-cultural personality assessments.']
['What is some evidence that these tests have been useful?', 'However, it was found that test bias limited their usefulness (Hoy-Watkins & Jenkins-Moore, 2008).']

['What is the main reason for this?', 'It is difficult to assess the personalities and lifestyles of members of widely divergent ethnic/cultural groups using personality instruments based on data from a single culture or race (Hoy-Watkins & Jenkins-Moore, 2008).']

['What other problems did this have?', 'For example, when the TAT was used with African-American test takers, the result was often shorter story length and low levels of cultural identification (Duzant, 2005).']

['Was it vital to develop other personality assessments that explored factors such as race, language, and level of acculturation?', 'Therefore, it was vital to develop other personality assessments that explored factors such as race, language, and level of acculturation (Hoy-Watkins & Jenkins-Moore, 2008).']

['What was the result of the test?', 'To address this need, Robert Williams developed the first culturally specific projective test designed to reflect the everyday life experiences of African Americans (Hoy-Watkins & Jenkins-Moore, 2008).']
['What was the updated version of the instrument?', 'The updated version of the instrument is the Contemporized-Themes Concerning Blacks Test (C-TCB) (Williams, 1972).']
['What is the difference between the C-TCB and the other tests?', 'The C-TCB contains 20 color images that show scenes of African-American lifestyles.']

['Was the C-TCB better than the TAT for African Americans?', 'When the C-TCB was compared with the TAT for African Americans, it was found that use of the C-TCB led to increased story length, higher degrees of positive feelings, and stronger identification with the C-TCB (Hoy, 1997; Hoy-Watkins & Jenkins-Moore, 2008).']
['What is the main point of our study material?', 'The TEMAS Multicultural Thematic Apperception']
['What is TEMAS?', 'Test is another tool designed to be culturally relevant to minority groups, especially Hispanic youths.']

['What is unique about TEMAS?', 'TEMAS—standing for “Tell Me a Story” but also a play on the Spanish word temas (themes)—uses images and storytelling cues that relate to minority culture (Constantino, 1982).']
['What is social psychology?', 'Social psychology examines how people affect one another, and it looks at the power of the situation.']

['What are some of the things social psychologists study?', 'According to the American Psychological Association (n.d.), social psychologists "are interested in all aspects of personality and social interaction, exploring the influence of interpersonal and group relationships on human behavior."']

['What did you find interesting about the article?', "Throughout this chapter, we will examine how the presence of other individuals and groups of people impacts a person's behaviors, thoughts, and feelings."]
['What does that mean?', 'Essentially, people will change their behavior to align with the social situation at hand.']
['What else did you learn about social psychology?', 'If we are in a new situation or are unsure how to behave, we will take our cues from other individuals.']
['What is the field of social psychology?', 'The field of social psychology studies topics at both the intra- and interpersonal levels.']

['What are some examples of topics that pertain to the individual?', 'Intrapersonal topics (those that pertain to the individual) include emotions and attitudes, the self, and social cognition (the ways in which we think about ourselves and others).']

['What are some examples of topics that pertain to dyads and groups?', 'Interpersonal topics (those that pertain to dyads and groups) include helping behavior (Figure 12.2), aggression, prejudice and discrimination, attraction and close relationships, and group processes and intergroup relationships.']

['What do social psychologists focus on?', 'Social psychologists focus on how people conceptualize and interpret situations and how these interpretations influence their thoughts, feelings, and behaviors (Ross & Nisbett, 1991).']
['What does social psychology study?', 'Thus, social psychology studies individuals in a social context and how situational variables interact to influence behavior.']

['What are the intrapersonal and interpersonal processes?', 'In this chapter, we discuss the intrapersonal processes of self-presentation, cognitive dissonance and attitude change, and the interpersonal processes of conformity and obedience, aggression and altruism, and, finally, love and attraction.']

['What are the situational and dispositional influences?', 'Behavior is a product of both the situation (e.g., cultural influences, social roles, and the presence of bystanders) and of the person (e.g., personality characteristics).']
['What is one influence?', 'Subfields of psychology tend to focus on one influence or behavior over others.']

['What is the view that our behavior and actions are determined by our immediate environment and surroundings?', 'Situationism is the view that our behavior and actions are determined by our immediate environment and surroundings.']
['What is contrast to situationism?', 'In contrast, dispositionism holds that our behavior is determined by internal factors (Heider, 1958).']
['What is an internal factor?', 'An internal factor is an attribute of a person and includes personality traits and temperament.']

['What are some important aspects of this discussion?', 'Social psychologists have tended to take the situationist perspective, whereas personality psychologists have promoted the dispositionist perspective.']

['What is modern approaches?', 'Modern approaches to social psychology, however, take both the situation and the individual into account when studying human behavior (Fiske, Gilbert, & Lindzey, 2010).']

['What is the field of social-personality psychology?', 'In fact, the field of social-personality psychology has emerged to study the complex interaction of internal and situational factors that affect human behavior (Mischel, 1977; Richard, Bond, & Stokes-Zoota, 2003).']
['What kind of approach do people prefer in explaining human behavior?', 'In the United States, the predominant culture tends to favor a dispositional approach in explaining human behavior.']

['What are the reasons for this preference?', 'We tend to think that people are in control of their own behaviors, and, therefore, any behavior change must be due to something internal, such as their personality, habits, or temperament.']

['what does social psychologists have to say?', 'According to some social psychologists, people tend to overemphasize internal factors as explanations—or attributions—for the behavior of other people.']
['what is another person?', 'They tend to assume that the behavior of another person is a trait of that person, and to underestimate the power of the situation on the behavior of others.']
['What else did they say?', 'They tend to fail to recognize when the behavior of another is due to situational variables, and thus to the person’s state.']
['What is the erroneous assumption called?', 'This erroneous assumption is called the fundamental attribution error (Ross, 1977; Riggio & Garcia, 2009).']

['What happened after Jamie returned home from work?', 'To better understand, imagine this scenario: Jamie returns home from work, and opens the front door to a happy greeting from spouse Morgan who inquires how the day has been.']
['How would you interpret this scenario?', 'The most common response is that Jamie is a mean, angry, or unfriendly person (traits).']
['What type of explanation is this?', 'This is an internal or dispositional explanation.']
