['What does it mean that Jamie is a good employee?', 'However, imagine that Jamie was just laid off from work due to company downsizing.']
['What would you do if you were Jamie?', 'Your revised explanation might be that Jamie was frustrated and disappointed about being laid off and was therefore in a bad mood (state).']
['Why is this different?', 'This is now an external or situational explanation for Jamie’s behavior.']
['What does fundamental attribution error mean?', 'The fundamental attribution error is so powerful that people often overlook obvious situational influences on behavior.']
['What is a classic example of a classic example?', 'A classic example was demonstrated in a series of experiments known as the quizmaster study (Ross, Amabile, & Steinmetz, 1977).']
['How was the quizmaster study conducted?', 'Student participants were randomly assigned to play the role of a questioner (the quizmaster) or a contestant in a quiz game.']
['What were the questions that were asked?', 'Questioners developed difficult questions to which they knew the answers, and they presented these questions to the contestants.']
['How did the contestants do on the test?', 'The contestants answered the questions correctly only 4 out of 10 times (Figure 12.3).']
['What happened after the task?', 'After the task, the questioners and contestants were asked to rate their own general knowledge compared to the average student.']

['What did the contestants think of the questioners?', 'Questioners did not rate their general knowledge higher than the contestants, but the contestants rated the questioners’ intelligence higher than their own.']
['What was significant about the interaction?', 'In a second study, observers of the interaction also rated the questioner as having more general knowledge than the contestant.']
['What happens with attribution?', 'The obvious influence on performance is the situation.']
['What did the questioners do?', 'The questioners wrote the questions, so of course they had an advantage.']
['What did the contestants and observers do?', 'Both the contestants and observers made an internal attribution for the performance.']
['What did they conclude?', 'They concluded that the questioners must be more intelligent than the contestants.']
['What is the halo effect?', 'The halo effect refers to the tendency to let the overall impression of an individual color the way in which we feel about their character.']

['What are some examples of people who are physically attractive?', 'For instance, we might assume that people who are physically attractive are more likely to be good people than less attractive individuals.']

['What are some examples of how the halo effect might manifest?', 'Another example of how the halo effect might manifest would involve assuming that someone whom we perceive to be outgoing or friendly has a better moral character than someone who is not.']

['What is the fundamental attribution error?', 'As demonstrated in the examples above, the fundamental attribution error is considered a powerful influence in how we explain the behaviors of others.']

['What did you find interesting about the passage?', 'However, it should be noted that some researchers have suggested that the fundamental attribution error may not be as powerful as it is often portrayed.']

['Are there other factors to consider?', 'In fact, a recent review of more than 173 published studies suggests that several factors (e.g., high levels of idiosyncrasy of the character and how well hypothetical events are explained) play a role in determining just how influential the fundamental attribution error is (Malle, 2006).']
['Did we ever discuss how the fundamental attribution error impacts individuals?', 'You may be able to think of examples of the fundamental attribution error in your life.']
['Do people generally think people are bad in this situation?', 'Research suggests that they do not.']

['What does research indicate about this theory?', 'People from an individualistic culture, that is, a culture that focuses on individual achievement and autonomy, have the greatest tendency to commit the fundamental attribution error.']

['What type of countries tend to focus on the individual?', 'Individualistic cultures, which tend to be found in western countries such as the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom, promote a focus on the individual.']
['What does this theory state?', 'Therefore, a person’s disposition is thought to be the primary explanation for her behavior.']

['What type of culture is this?', 'In contrast, people from a collectivistic culture, that is, a culture that focuses on communal relationships with others, such as family, friends, and community (Figure 12.4), are less likely to commit the fundamental attribution error (Markus & Kitayama, 1991; Triandis, 2001).']

['What do we learn about cultural factors?', 'Collectivistic cultures, which tend to be found in east Asian countries and in Latin American and African countries, focus on the group more than on the individual (Nisbett, Peng, Choi, & Norenzayan, 2001).']

['What are some other interesting things that you learned about cultural factors?', 'This focus on others provides a broader perspective that takes into account both situational and cultural influences on behavior; thus, a more nuanced explanation of the causes of others’ behavior becomes more likely.']
['What is the Table 12.1 about?', 'Table 12.1 summarizes compares individualistic and collectivist cultures.']

['What did Masuda and Nisbett demonstrate?', 'Masuda and Nisbett (2001) demonstrated that the kinds of information that people attend to when viewing visual stimuli (e.g., an aquarium scene) can differ significantly depending on whether the observer comes from a collectivistic versus an individualistic culture.']

['What was the other cultural difference shown?', 'Japanese participants were much more likely to recognize objects that were presented when they occurred in the same context in which they were originally viewed.']
['What was the result of manipulating the context in which object recall occurred?', 'Manipulating the context in which object recall occurred had no such impact on American participants.']
['What were other findings?', 'Other researchers have shown similar differences across cultures.']

['What did they do?', 'For example, Zhang, Fung, Stanley, Isaacowitz, and Zhang (2014) demonstrated differences in the ways that holistic thinking might develop between Chinese and American participants, and Ramesh and Gelfand (2010) demonstrated that job turnover rates are more related to the fit between a person and the organization in which they work in an Indian sample, but the fit between the person and their specific job was more predictive of turnover in an American sample.']
['What is the scenario we are studying today?', 'Returning to our earlier example, Jamie was laid off, but an observer would not know.']
['What did you learn from the scenario?', 'So a naïve observer would tend to attribute Jamie’s hostile behavior to Jamie’s disposition rather than to the true, situational cause.']
['Why might this happen?', 'One reason is that we often don’t have all the information we need to make a situational explanation for another person’s behavior.']

['What other reasons do we have for assuming the behavior is due to a dispositional, or internal, factor?', 'Due to this lack of information we have a tendency to assume the behavior is due to a dispositional, or internal, factor.']
['Why do we have to explain our own behaviors?', 'When it comes to explaining our own behaviors, however, we have much more information available to us.']

['What might you say you were very tired or feeling unwell and needed quiet time—a situational explanation?', 'You might say you were very tired or feeling unwell and needed quiet time—a situational explanation.']

['Did you find any other interesting facts?', 'The actor-observer bias is the phenomenon of attributing other people’s behavior to internal factors (fundamental attribution error) while attributing our own behavior to situational forces (Jones & Nisbett, 1971; Nisbett, Caputo, Legant, & Marecek, 1973; Choi & Nisbett, 1998).']
['Why do we tend to focus on our own behavior?', 'As actors of behavior, we have more information available to explain our own behavior.']
['How do we know that the narrator is a dispositionist?', 'However as observers, we have less information available; therefore, we tend to default to a dispositionist perspective.']
['What was the study on actor-observer bias?', 'One study on the actor-observer bias investigated reasons male participants gave for why they liked their girlfriend (Nisbett et al., 1973).']

['Why did they choose their girlfriend?', 'When asked why participants liked their own girlfriend, participants focused on internal, dispositional qualities of their girlfriends (for example, her pleasant personality).']
['What was their answer to the question?', 'The participants’ explanations rarely included causes internal to themselves, such as dispositional traits (for example, “I need companionship.”).']
['What else was discovered?', 'In contrast, when speculating why a male friend likes his girlfriend, participants were equally likely to give dispositional and external explanations.']
['Did they explain why they were acting the way they were?', 'This supports the idea that actors tend to provide few internal explanations but many situational explanations for their own behavior.']
['What did they discover?', 'In contrast, observers tend to provide more dispositional explanations for a friend’s behavior (Figure 12.5).']
['How can we understand self-serving bias?', 'We can understand self-serving bias by digging more deeply into attribution, a belief about the cause of a result.']

['What are the three main dimensions of the model?', 'One model of attribution proposes three main dimensions: locus of control (internal versus external), stability (stable versus unstable), and controllability (controllable versus uncontrollable).']
['What does stability refer to in this context?', 'In this context, stability refers to the extent in which the circumstances that result in a given outcome are changeable.']
['What are the circumstances considered to be if they are unlikely to change?', 'The circumstances are considered stable if they are unlikely to change.']
['What is controllability?', 'Controllability refers to the extent to which the circumstances that are associated with a given outcome can be controlled.']
['What is controllability?', 'Obviously, those things that we have the power to control would be labeled controllable (Weiner, 1979).']

['What kind of biases do we have?', 'Following an outcome, self-serving biases are those attributions that enable us to see ourselves in a favorable light (for example, making internal attributions for success and external attributions for failures).']

['What can people do to help them to see themselves in a good light?', 'When you do well at a task, for example acing an exam, it is in your best interest to make a dispositional attribution for your behavior (“I’m smart,”) instead of a situational one (“The exam was easy,”).']

['What is the specifics of the biases?', 'Self-serving bias is the tendency to explain our successes as due to dispositional (internal) characteristics, but to explain our failures as due to situational (external) factors.']
['Why do we tend to make these attributions?', 'Again, this is culture dependent.']
['Why are we more inclined to see ourselves as successful than other people?', 'This bias serves to protect self-esteem.']

['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'You can imagine that if people always made situational attributions for their behavior, they would never be able to take credit and feel good about their accomplishments.']
['How can you use self-serving bias?', 'Consider the example of how we explain our favorite sports team’s wins.']

['What do we make internal, stable, and controllable attributions for our team’s victory?', 'Research shows that we make internal, stable, and controllable attributions for our team’s victory (Figure 12.6) (Grove, Hanrahan, & McInman, 1991).']
['How do we justify our winning team?', 'For example, we might tell ourselves that our team is talented (internal), consistently works hard (stable), and uses effective strategies (controllable).']

['When our favorite sports team loses, do we make negative comments about the other teams?', 'In contrast, we are more likely to make external, unstable, and uncontrollable attributions when our favorite team loses.']

['How do we justify the loss to the other team?', 'For example, we might tell ourselves that the other team has more experienced players or that the referees were unfair (external), the other team played at home (unstable), and the cold weather affected our team’s performance (uncontrollable).']
['what is victim blame?', 'One consequence of westerners’ tendency to provide dispositional explanations for behavior is victim blame (Jost & Major, 2001).']
['how do they assume they are responsible?', 'When people experience bad fortune, others tend to assume that they somehow are responsible for their own fate.']
['What is a common ideology, or worldview, in the United States?', 'A common ideology, or worldview, in the United States is the just-world hypothesis.']
['What is the just-world hypothesis?', 'The just-world hypothesis is the belief that people get the outcomes they deserve (Lerner & Miller, 1978).']

['what does this belief lead to?', 'In order to maintain the belief that the world is a fair place, people tend to think that good people experience positive outcomes, and bad people experience negative outcomes (Jost, Banaji, & Nosek, 2004; Jost & Major, 2001).']

['how does this help people?', 'The ability to think of the world as a fair place, where people get what they deserve, allows us to feel that the world is predictable and that we have some control over our life outcomes (Jost et al., 2004; Jost & Major, 2001).']
['What do people think of this?', 'For example, if you want to experience positive outcomes, you just need to work hard to get ahead in life.']
['What were some negative consequences of this document?', 'One negative consequence is people’s tendency to blame poor individuals for their plight.']
['What are some other important points to consider?', 'These dispositional explanations are clear examples of the fundamental attribution error.']

['What are some other examples?', 'Blaming poor people for their poverty ignores situational factors that impact them, such as high unemployment rates, recession, poor educational opportunities, and the familial cycle of poverty (Figure 12.7).']

['What other important information was found in the document?', 'Other research shows that people who hold just-world beliefs have negative attitudes toward people who are unemployed and people living with AIDS (Sutton & Douglas, 2005).']
['What is one example of a victim being blamed?', 'In the United States and other countries, victims of sexual assault may find themselves blamed for their abuse.']

['Who are advocates for?', 'Victim advocacy groups, such as Domestic Violence Ended (DOVE), attend court in support of victims to ensure that blame is directed at the perpetrators of sexual violence, not the victims.']

['What is the study of how people affect one another’s thoughts, feelings, and behaviors?', 'As you’ve learned, social psychology is the study of how people affect one another’s thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.']

['What are some of the studies that have been done?', 'We have discussed situational perspectives and social psychology’s emphasis on the ways in which a person’s environment, including culture and other social influences, affect behavior.']

['What are some of the other studies that were discussed?', 'In this section, we examine situational forces that have a strong influence on human behavior including social roles, social norms, and scripts.']
['What did you find out about the social environment?', 'We discuss how humans use the social environment as a source of information, or cues, on how to behave.']

['What are some examples of situational influences on our behavior?', 'Situational influences on our behavior have important consequences, such as whether we will help a stranger in an emergency or how we would behave in an unfamiliar environment.']
['What is one major social determinant of human behavior?', 'One major social determinant of human behavior is our social roles.']

['What is a pattern of behavior that is expected of a person in a given setting or group?', 'A social role is a pattern of behavior that is expected of a person in a given setting or group (Hare, 2003).']
['What other social roles do we have?', 'Each one of us has several social roles.']
['Can you tell me an example of a social role?', 'You may be, at the same time, a student, a parent, an aspiring teacher, a son or daughter, a spouse, and a lifeguard.']
['What are some examples of social roles?', 'Social roles are defined by culturally shared knowledge.']
['What does that mean?', 'That is, nearly everyone in a given culture knows what behavior is expected of a person in a given role.']

['Can you give me an example of a social role?', 'If you look around a college classroom you will likely see students engaging in studious behavior, taking notes, listening to the professor, reading the textbook, and sitting quietly at their desks (Figure 12.8).']

['What happens to students in a college classroom?', 'Of course you may see students deviating from the expected studious behavior such as texting on their phones or using Facebook on their laptops, but in all cases, the students that you observe are attending class—a part of the social role of students.']
['What can social roles vary across different settings?', 'Social roles, and our related behavior, can vary across different settings.']

['What are some examples of how you behave when you are engaged in the role of employee at your workplace?', 'Now imagine how you behave when you are engaged in the role of employee at your workplace.']
['How do you behave when you are engaging in the role of boss?', 'It is very likely that your behavior will be different.']
['How can social roles influence your behavior?', 'Perhaps you are more relaxed and outgoing with your family, making jokes and doing silly things.']
['Do you have any examples of these?', 'But at your workplace you might speak more professionally, and although you may be friendly, you are also serious and focused on getting the work completed.']

['What are examples of how our social roles influence and often dictate our behavior to the extent that identity and personality can vary with context (that is, in different social groups)?', 'These are examples of how our social roles influence and often dictate our behavior to the extent that identity and personality can vary with context (that is, in different social groups) (Malloy, Albright, Kenny, Agatstein & Winquist, 1997).']

['What are the characteristics of social roles?', 'As discussed previously, social roles are defined by a culture’s shared knowledge of what is expected behavior of an individual in a specific role.']
['What is the shared knowledge of what is expected behavior of an individual in a specific role?', 'This shared knowledge comes from social norms.']

['What is a group’s expectation of what is appropriate and acceptable behavior for its members?', 'A social norm is a group’s expectation of what is appropriate and acceptable behavior for its members—how they are supposed to behave and think (Deutsch & Gerard, 1955; Berkowitz, 2004).']

['What other things are you interested in learning?', 'In our discussion of social roles we noted that colleges have social norms for students’ behavior in the role of student and workplaces have social norms for employees’ behaviors in the role of employee.']
['Are there other examples of social norms?', 'Social norms are everywhere including in families, gangs, and on social media outlets.']
['What are some specific points about social roles?', 'Because of social roles, people tend to know what behavior is expected of them in specific, familiar settings.']
['What is a script?', 'A script is a person’s knowledge about the sequence of events expected in a specific setting (Schank & Abelson, 1977).']
['What can you share about cultural differences?', 'For example, at a restaurant in the United States, if we want the server’s attention, we try to make eye contact.']
['What might happen in Brazil?', 'In Brazil, you would make the sound “psst” to get the server’s attention.']
['What about other countries?', 'You can see the cultural differences in scripts.']
['What other cultural differences are there?', 'To an American, saying “psst” to a server might seem rude, yet to a Brazilian, trying to make eye contact might not seem an effective strategy.']
['What are important sources of information to guide behavior in given situations?', 'Scripts are important sources of information to guide behavior in given situations.']
['What is wrong with a script that cannot be used?', 'This could be uncomfortable and confusing.']

['What was the purpose of the Stanford prison experiment?', 'The famous Stanford prison experiment, conducted by social psychologist Philip Zimbardo and his colleagues at Stanford University, demonstrated the power of social roles, social norms, and scripts.']

['What year did the experiment take place?', 'In the summer of 1971, an advertisement was placed in a California newspaper asking for male volunteers to participate in a study about the psychological effects of prison life.']

['How many men volunteered?', 'More than 70 men volunteered, and these volunteers then underwent psychological testing to eliminate candidates who had underlying psychiatric issues, medical issues, or a history of crime or drug abuse.']
['How many men were chosen?', 'The pool of volunteers was whittled down to 24 healthy male college students.']
['What did they do in the experiment?', 'Each student was paid $15 per day (equivalent to about $80 today) and was randomly assigned to play the role of either a prisoner or a guard in the study.']
['What was constructed in the basement of the psychology building at Stanford?', 'A mock prison was constructed in the basement of the psychology building at Stanford.']

['What else happened at the psychology building?', 'Participants assigned to play the role of prisoners were “arrested” at their homes by Palo Alto police officers, booked at a police station, and subsequently taken to the mock prison.']
['How long did the experiment last?', 'The experiment was scheduled to run for several weeks.']
['Did they have any complaints?', 'To the surprise of the researchers, both the “prisoners” and “guards” assumed their roles with zeal.']

['What other interesting information was mentioned in the article?', 'On the second day of the experiment, the guards forced the prisoners to strip, took their beds, and isolated the ringleaders using solitary confinement.']

['How did the guards do this?', 'In a relatively short time, the guards came to harass the prisoners in an increasingly sadistic manner, through a complete lack of privacy, lack of basic comforts such as mattresses to sleep on, and through degrading chores and late-night counts.']
['What was the most interesting piece of content you learned?', 'The prisoners, in turn, began to show signs of severe anxiety and hopelessness—they began tolerating the guards’ abuse.']

['Who else besides the prisoners were involved in the experiment?', 'Even the Stanford professor who designed the study and was the head researcher, Philip Zimbardo, found himself acting as if the prison was real and his role, as prison supervisor, was real as well.']
['How long did the experiment last?', 'After only six days, the experiment had to be ended due to the participants’ deteriorating behavior.']
["What was Zimbardo's purpose with the experiment?", 'Zimbardo explained,']

['What is the Stanford Prison Experiment about?', 'The Stanford Prison Experiment has been used as a memorable demonstration of the incredible power that social roles, norms, and scripts have in affecting human behavior.']
["What was the critics' view on the study?", 'However, multiple aspects of the study have been subject to criticism since its inception.']
['What were some of the criticisms?', 'The nature of these criticisms range from ethical concerns to issues of generalizability (Bartels, Milovich, & Moussier, 2016; Griggs, 2014; Le Texier, 2019).']
['What is one of the other criticisms?', 'One criticism is that the way students were recruited for the experiment may have impacted the outcome (Carnahan & McFarland, 2007).']
['What was the next criticism?', 'Another criticism questions the conclusions that can be drawn from the study.']
['What was there to say about the study?', 'Zimbardo appears to have provided specific guidelines of the types of behaviors that were expected of the guards (Zimbardo, 2007).']

['What happened next with the study?', 'Subsequent research suggests that such guidelines likely created an expectation of the types of behavior that Zimbardo reported observing in the Stanford Prison Experiment (Bartels, 2019), and that given these expectations, the guards simply acted as they thought they were expected to act.']
['What has been problematic about the study?', 'It has also been problematic that attempts to replicate aspects of the study have not been successful.']
['How did they fail?', 'For example, when no guidelines were presented to the guards, researchers documented different outcomes than those observed by Zimbardo.']
['What other criticism did they have?', '(Reicher & Haslam, 2006).']

['What is the most important aspect of this study?', 'The Stanford Prison Experiment has some parallels with the abuse of prisoners of war by U.S. Army troops and CIA personnel at the Abu Ghraib prison in 2003 and 2004 during the Iraq War.']
['What did this article discuss?', 'The offenses at Abu Ghraib were documented by photographs of the abuse, some taken by the abusers themselves (Figure 12.10).']
['What are some important points to remember as you read?', 'Social psychologists have documented how the power of the situation can influence our behaviors.']
['What is the key part of this section?', 'Now we turn to how the power of the situation can influence our attitudes and beliefs.']
['What is the definition of attitude?', 'Attitude is our evaluation of a person, an idea, or an object.']
['What do we have attitudes about?', 'We have attitudes for many things ranging from products that we might pick up in the supermarket to people around the world to political policies.']
['How do we evaluate?', 'Typically, attitudes are favorable or unfavorable: positive or negative (Eagly & Chaiken, 1993).']

['What are the three components of attitudes?', 'And, they have three components: an affective component (feelings), a behavioral component (the effect of the attitude on behavior), and a cognitive component (belief and knowledge) (Rosenberg & Hovland, 1960).']
['What are some examples of positive attitudes?', 'For example, you may hold a positive attitude toward recycling.']

['What is the importance of attitude toward recycling?', 'This attitude should result in positive feelings toward recycling (such as “It makes me feel good to recycle” or “I enjoy knowing that I make a small difference in reducing the amount of waste that ends up in landfills”).']
['How is this attitude reflected in our behavior?', 'Certainly, this attitude should be reflected in our behavior:']
['What kind of behavior is being reflected in the passage?', 'You actually recycle as often as you can.']
['How about thought?', 'Finally, this attitude will be reflected in favorable thoughts (for example, “Recycling is good for the environment” or “Recycling is the responsible thing to do”).']
['What can we learn from the study material?', 'Our attitudes and beliefs are not only influenced by external forces, but also by internal influences that we control.']

['Are our attitudes and beliefs always the same?', 'Like our behavior, our attitudes and thoughts are not always changed by situational pressures, but they can be consciously changed by our own free will.']
['What is the next section?', 'In this section we discuss the conditions under which we would want to change our own attitudes and beliefs.']

['What type of psychology do we explore here?', 'Social psychologists have documented that feeling good about ourselves and maintaining positive self-esteem is a powerful motivator of human behavior (Tavris & Aronson, 2008).']

['What do they say about our society?', 'In the United States, members of the predominant culture typically think very highly of themselves and view themselves as good people who are above average on many desirable traits (Ehrlinger, Gilovich, & Ross, 2005).']
['What are some things we can do to avoid this?', 'Often, our behavior, attitudes, and beliefs are affected when we experience a threat to our self-esteem or positive self-image.']

['What is cognitive dissonance?', 'Psychologist Leon Festinger (1957) defined cognitive dissonance as psychological discomfort arising from holding two or more inconsistent attitudes, behaviors, or cognitions (thoughts, beliefs, or opinions).']

['How does dissonance help us?', 'Festinger’s theory of cognitive dissonance states that when we experience a conflict in our behaviors, attitudes, or beliefs that runs counter to our positive self-perceptions, we experience psychological discomfort (dissonance).']

['What are some examples of dissonance?', 'For example, if you believe smoking is bad for your health but you continue to smoke, you experience conflict between your belief and behavior (Figure 12.11).']
['What were the results of the studies?', 'Later research documented that only conflicting cognitions that threaten individuals’ positive self-image cause dissonance (Greenwald & Ronis, 1978).']

['What other studies were done on dissonance?', 'Additional research found that dissonance is not only psychologically uncomfortable but also can cause physiological arousal (Croyle & Cooper, 1983) and activate regions of the brain important in emotions and cognitive functioning (van Veen, Krug, Schooler, & Carter, 2009).']
['What did the studies indicate?', 'When we experience cognitive dissonance, we are motivated to decrease it because it is psychologically, physically, and mentally uncomfortable.']
['How can we reduce cognitive dissonance?', 'We can reduce cognitive dissonance by bringing our cognitions, attitudes, and behaviors in line—that is, making them harmonious.']
['What other ways can it be done?', 'This can be done in different ways, such as:']
['What is a classic example of cognitive dissonance?', 'A classic example of cognitive dissonance is Joaquin, a 20-year-old who enlists in the military.']

['How does boot camp impact Joaquin?', 'During boot camp he is awakened at 5:00 a.m., is chronically sleep deprived, yelled at, covered in sand flea bites, physically bruised and battered, and mentally exhausted (Figure 12.12).']
['What does Joaquin do to cope with the situation?', 'It gets worse.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Recruits that make it to week 11 of boot camp have to do 54 hours of continuous training.']
["Which of these subjects you've discussed is related to Joaquin?", 'Not surprisingly, Joaquin is miserable.']
['How does that make him feel?', 'No one likes to be miserable.']
['What are the last options that people can change?', 'In this type of situation, people can change their beliefs, their attitudes, or their behaviors.']
['How can Joaquin change his behaviors?', 'The last option, a change of behaviors, is not available to Joaquin.']
['What happened to Joaquin?', 'He has signed on to the military for four years, and he cannot legally leave.']
['Are there any interesting aspects about the article?', 'If Joaquin keeps thinking about how miserable he is, it is going to be a very long four years.']
['What will happen to Joaquin if he keeps thinking?', 'He will be in a constant state of cognitive dissonance.']
['What can Joaquin do to relieve this misery?', 'As an alternative to this misery, Joaquin can change his beliefs or attitudes.']
['How can Joaquin change his thoughts?', 'He can tell himself, “I am becoming stronger, healthier, and sharper.']
['What can Joaquin tell himself to relieve this misery?', 'I am learning discipline and how to defend myself and my country.']
['What is important to you?', 'What I am doing is really important.”']
['What does Joaquin need to do for this change?', 'If this is his belief, he will realize that he is becoming stronger through his challenges.']
['What will happen to Joaquin if he makes this change?', 'He then will feel better and not experience cognitive dissonance, which is an uncomfortable state.']
['What is the military example about?', 'The military example demonstrates the observation that a difficult initiation into a group influences us to like the group more.']
['What is the effort effect?', 'Another social psychology concept, justification of effort, suggests that we value goals and achievements that we put a lot of effort into.']
['What is the effort effect?', 'According to this theory, if something is difficult for us to achieve, we believe it is more worthwhile.']

['What else do you think is interesting about the effort effect?', 'For example, if you move to an apartment and spend hours assembling a dresser you bought from Ikea, you will value that more than a fancier dresser someone else bought you.']
['Why do we want to avoid the wasted time and effort?', 'We do not want to have wasted time and effort to join a group that we eventually leave.']
['What is the name of the experiment that demonstrated this justification of effort effect?', 'A classic experiment by Aronson and Mills (1959) demonstrated this justification of effort effect.']
['What was the experiment about?', 'College students volunteered to join a campus group that would meet regularly to discuss the psychology of sex.']
['What was their test?', 'Participants were randomly assigned to one of three conditions: no initiation, an easy initiation, and a difficult initiation into the group.']
['What did they find out?', 'After participating in the first discussion, which was deliberately made very boring, participants rated how much they liked the group.']

['What conclusion did they come to?', 'Participants who underwent a difficult initiation process to join the group rated the group more favorably than did participants with an easy initiation or no initiation (Figure 12.13).']
['What else can you tell me about this chapter?', 'Similar effects can be seen in a more recent study of how student effort affects course evaluations.']

['What was the name of the person who surveyed 463 undergraduates enrolled in courses at a midwestern university about the amount of effort that their courses required of them?', 'Heckert, Latier, Ringwald-Burton, and Drazen (2006) surveyed 463 undergraduates enrolled in courses at a midwestern university about the amount of effort that their courses required of them.']
['Was there anything else important about the study?', 'In addition, the students were also asked to evaluate various aspects of the course.']

['Did they find any correlations between student effort and their courses?', 'Given what you’ve just read, it will come as no surprise that those courses that were associated with the highest level of effort were evaluated as being more valuable than those that did not.']

['What did students feel about these courses?', 'Furthermore, students indicated that they learned more in courses that required more effort, regardless of the grades that they received in those courses (Heckert et al., 2006).']

['What is an example of the effect of initiation?', 'Here is one: Maria and Marco live in Fairfield County, Connecticut, which is one of the wealthiest areas in the United States and has a very high cost of living.']
['What do Maria and Marco do?', 'Maria telecommutes from home and Marco does not work outside of the home.']
['What do they do at home?', 'They rent a very small house for more than $3000 a month.']
['What does Marco do to save money?', 'Marco shops at consignment stores for clothes and economizes when possible.']

['What else do they do?', 'When asked why they do not move to a less expensive location, since Maria telecommutes, they respond that Fairfield County is beautiful, they love the beaches, and they feel comfortable there.']

['What is the motivation to reduce cognitive dissonance?', 'In the previous section we discussed that the motivation to reduce cognitive dissonance leads us to change our attitudes, behaviors, and/or cognitions to make them consonant.']
['What is the process of persuasion?', 'Persuasion is the process of changing our attitude toward something based on some kind of communication.']
['What kind of communication do we experience?', 'Much of the persuasion we experience comes from outside forces.']
["What's one of the things that was extensively researched?", 'The topic of persuasion has been one of the most extensively researched areas in social psychology (Fiske et al., 2010).']
['What did Carl Hovland do during the Second World War?', 'During the Second World War, Carl Hovland extensively researched persuasion for the U.S. Army.']
['Did Hovland continue his research after the war?', 'After the war, Hovland continued his exploration of persuasion at Yale University.']
['What did he find out?', 'Out of this work came a model called the Yale attitude change approach, which describes the conditions under which people tend to change their attitudes.']

['What did Hovland demonstrate?', 'Hovland demonstrated that certain features of the source of a persuasive message, the content of the message, and the characteristics of the audience will influence the persuasiveness of a message (Hovland, Janis, & Kelley, 1953).']

['What are some characteristics of the source of the persuasive message?', 'Features of the source of the persuasive message include the credibility of the speaker (Hovland & Weiss, 1951) and the physical attractiveness of the speaker (Eagly & Chaiken, 1975; Petty, Wegener, & Fabrigar, 1997).']

['What is the most important factor in being persuasive?', 'Thus, speakers who are credible, or have expertise on the topic, and who are deemed as trustworthy are more persuasive than less credible speakers.']
['What about attractiveness?', 'Similarly, more attractive speakers are more persuasive than less attractive speakers.']
['What is included in the ad?', 'The use of famous actors and athletes to advertise products on television and in print relies on this principle.']
['What else was included in the persuasion?', 'The immediate and long term impact of the persuasion also depends, however, on the credibility of the messenger (Kumkale & Albarracín, 2004).']

['What are some of the features of the message itself that affect persuasion?', 'Features of the message itself that affect persuasion include subtlety (the quality of being important, but not obvious) (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986; Walster & Festinger, 1962); sidedness (that is, having more than one side) (Crowley & Hoyer, 1994; Igou & Bless, 2003; Lumsdaine & Janis, 1953); timing (Haugtvedt & Wegener, 1994; Miller & Campbell, 1959), and whether both sides are presented.']
['What are the consequences of messages with subtlety?', 'Messages that are more subtle are more persuasive than direct messages.']
['What are some of the other implications?', 'Arguments that occur first, such as in a debate, are more influential if messages are given back-to-back.']

['What is significant about the last message presented?', 'However, if there is a delay after the first message, and before the audience needs to make a decision, the last message presented will tend to be more persuasive (Miller & Campbell, 1959).']

['What are the features of the audience that affect persuasion?', 'Features of the audience that affect persuasion are attention (Albarracín & Wyer, 2001; Festinger & Maccoby, 1964), intelligence, self-esteem (Rhodes & Wood, 1992), and age (Krosnick & Alwin, 1989).']
['What are the most important things to remember when persuading an audience?', 'In order to be persuaded, audience members must be paying attention.']

['Is there anything else interesting about the passage?', 'People with lower intelligence are more easily persuaded than people with higher intelligence; whereas people with moderate self-esteem are more easily persuaded than people with higher or lower self-esteem (Rhodes & Wood, 1992).']
['What about older adults?', 'Finally, younger adults aged 18–25 are more persuadable than older adults.']

['What is the elaboration likelihood model of persuasion?', 'An especially popular model that describes the dynamics of persuasion is the elaboration likelihood model of persuasion (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986).']

['What is the elaboration likelihood model?', 'The elaboration likelihood model considers the variables of the attitude change approach—that is, features of the source of the persuasive message, contents of the message, and characteristics of the audience are used to determine when attitude change will occur.']

['What else is significant about the model?', 'According to the elaboration likelihood model of persuasion, there are two main routes that play a role in delivering a persuasive message: central and peripheral (Figure 12.15).']
['What is the central route?', 'The central route is logic driven and uses data and facts to convince people of an argument’s worthiness.']
['What are examples of this?', 'For example, a car company seeking to persuade you to purchase their model will emphasize the car’s safety features and fuel economy.']
['What is a direct route to persuasion that focuses on the quality of the information?', 'This is a direct route to persuasion that focuses on the quality of the information.']

['What is the central route of persuasion?', 'In order for the central route of persuasion to be effective in changing attitudes, thoughts, and behaviors, the argument must be strong and, if successful, will result in lasting attitude change.']

['What is the central route to persuasion?', 'The central route to persuasion works best when the target of persuasion, or the audience, is analytical and willing to engage in processing of the information.']
['What is one example of this?', 'One example is buying a computer.']

['What is a small business owner?', 'It is likely, for example, that small business owners might be especially influenced by the focus on the computer’s quality and features such as processing speed and memory capacity.']
['What is the peripheral route?', 'The peripheral route is an indirect route that uses peripheral cues to associate positivity with the message (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986).']

['What are some examples of the peripheral route?', 'Instead of focusing on the facts and a product’s quality, the peripheral route relies on association with positive characteristics such as positive emotions and celebrity endorsement.']

['What can be used to encourage young adults to purchase the shoes?', 'For example, having a popular athlete advertise athletic shoes is a common method used to encourage young adults to purchase the shoes.']
['Does this method require much effort or information processing?', 'This route to attitude change does not require much effort or information processing.']

['What does this method of persuasion result in?', 'This method of persuasion may promote positivity toward the message or product, but it typically results in less permanent attitude or behavior change.']
['What does not require much processing?', 'The audience does not need to be analytical or motivated to process the message.']
['Any other interesting information?', 'In fact, a peripheral route to persuasion may not even be noticed by the audience, for example in the strategy of product placement.']
['What is product placement?', 'Product placement refers to putting a product with a clear brand name or brand identity in a TV show or movie to promote the product (Gupta & Lord, 1998).']

['What is an example of a product that is marketed to children?', 'For example, one season of the reality series American Idol prominently showed the panel of judges drinking out of cups that displayed the Coca-Cola logo.']
['What are some examples of how a retailer can use celebrity endorsements?', 'Another example is clothing: A retailer may focus on celebrities that are wearing the same style of clothing.']
['What kind of strategies are tested?', 'Researchers have tested many persuasion strategies that are effective in selling products and changing people’s attitude, ideas, and behaviors.']
['What is the name of the person who discovered the foot-in-the-door technique?', 'One effective strategy is the foot-in-the-door technique (Cialdini, 2001; Pliner, Hart, Kohl, & Saari, 1974).']

['What does this technique consist of?', 'Using the foot-in-the-door technique, the persuader gets a person to agree to bestow a small favor or to buy a small item, only to later request a larger favor or purchase of a bigger item.']

['What are the outcomes of this technique?', 'The foot-in-the-door technique was demonstrated in a study by Freedman and Fraser (1966) in which participants who agreed to a post small sign in their yard or sign a petition were more likely to agree to put a large sign in their yard than people who declined the first request (Figure 12.16).']

['What is the principle of consistency?', 'Research on this technique also illustrates the principle of consistency (Cialdini, 2001): Our past behavior often directs our future behavior, and we have a desire to maintain consistency once we have committed to a behavior.']

['What is the Foot-in-the-Door Technique?', 'A common application of foot-in-the-door is when teens ask their parents for a small permission (for example, extending curfew by a half hour) and then asking them for something larger.']
['How does this help them get the larger request?', 'Having granted the smaller request increases the likelihood that parents will acquiesce with the later, larger request.']

['What are some examples of a salesperson recommending a data plan?', 'For example, say that you are buying the latest model smartphone, and the salesperson suggests you purchase the best data plan.']
['What does this help you to do?', 'You agree to this.']
['What does the salesperson suggest?', 'The salesperson then suggests a bigger purchase—the three-year extended warranty.']
['How does this help?', 'After agreeing to the smaller request, you are more likely to also agree to the larger request.']
['What other examples of this are there?', 'You may have encountered this if you have bought a car.']

['What else do you know about car sales?', 'When salespeople realize that a buyer intends to purchase a certain model, they might try to get the customer to pay for many or most available options on the car.']

['How does the foot-in-the-door technique work?', 'Another example of the foot-in-the-door technique would be applied to an individual in the market for a used car who decides to buy a fully loaded new car.']
['Why did the buyer buy the new car?', 'Because the salesperson convinced the buyer that they need a car that has all of the safety features that were not available in the used car.']
['What is the main idea of this section?', 'In this section, we discuss additional ways in which people influence others.']

['What is the topic of the passage?', 'The topics of conformity, social influence, obedience, and group processes demonstrate the power of the social situation to change our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.']
['What did you study in this section?', 'We begin this section with a discussion of a famous social psychology experiment that demonstrated how susceptible humans are to outside social pressures.']

['What is the first thing you would like to know about conformity?', 'Solomon Asch conducted several experiments in the 1950s to determine how people are affected by the thoughts and behaviors of other people.']
['What was the first experiment that he conducted?', 'In one study, a group of participants was shown a series of printed line segments of different lengths: a, b, and c (Figure 12.17).']
['What were the line segments of different lengths called?', 'Participants were then shown a fourth line segment: x.']
['What was their test?', 'They were asked to identify which line segment from the first group (a, b, or c) most closely resembled the fourth line segment in length.']
['What are the participants called?', 'Each group of participants had only one true, naïve subject.']
['What were the remaining members of the group?', 'The remaining members of the group were confederates of the researcher.']
['What is a person who is aware of the experiment and works for the researcher called?', 'A confederate is a person who is aware of the experiment and works for the researcher.']

['How do they manipulate social situations?', 'Confederates are used to manipulate social situations as part of the research design, and the true, naïve participants believe that confederates are, like them, uninformed participants in the experiment.']
['What did the confederates have to do with this experiment?', 'In Asch’s study, the confederates identified a line segment that was obviously shorter than the target line—a wrong answer.']
['What was the naive participant asked to do after that?', 'The naïve participant then had to identify aloud the line segment that best matched the target line segment.']
['What happened to the participants when they conformed?', 'Asch (1955) found that 76% of participants conformed to group pressure at least once by indicating the incorrect line.']

['What is the change in a person’s behavior to go along with the group, even if he does not agree with the group?', 'Conformity is the change in a person’s behavior to go along with the group, even if he does not agree with the group.']

['What does the Asch effect mean?', 'Research shows that the size of the majority, the presence of another dissenter, and the public or relatively private nature of responses are key influences on conformity.']
['What does the study material have to do with size?', 'The size of the majority:']
['What does size have to do with the Asch effect?', 'The greater the number of people in the majority, the more likely an individual will conform.']
['How can this be increased?', 'There is, however, an upper limit: a point where adding more members does not increase conformity.']
["what number was there in Asch's study?", 'In Asch’s study, conformity increased with the number of people in the majority—up to seven individuals.']
['What was the point where adding more members does not increase conformity?', 'At numbers beyond seven, conformity leveled off and decreased slightly (Asch, 1955).']
['What is another dissenter?', 'The presence of another dissenter:']
['What happens when there is a dissenter?', 'If there is at least one dissenter, conformity rates drop to near zero (Asch, 1955).']
['What is another factor?', 'The public or private nature of the responses:']

['What is the difference between public and private responses?', 'When responses are made publicly (in front of others), conformity is more likely; however, when responses are made privately (e.g., writing down the response), conformity is less likely (Deutsch & Gerard, 1955).']

['What is the reason for voting in secret?', 'The finding that conformity is more likely to occur when responses are public than when they are private is the reason government elections require voting in secret, so we are not coerced by others (Figure 12.18).']
['What are some examples of the Asch effect?', 'The Asch effect can be easily seen in children when they have to publicly vote for something.']

['What is one example?', 'For example, if the teacher asks whether the children would rather have extra recess, no homework, or candy, once a few children vote, the rest will comply and go with the majority.']
['What is another example of a majority rule?', 'In a different classroom, the majority might vote differently, and most of the children would comply with that majority.']
['What did you find interesting about the section?', 'When someone’s vote changes if it is made in public versus private, this is known as compliance.']
['What does it mean to be a conformist?', 'Compliance can be a form of conformity.']
['What does compliance mean?', 'Compliance is going along with a request or demand, even if you do not agree with the request.']
['What does compliance mean in practice?', 'In Asch’s studies, the participants complied by giving the wrong answers, but privately did not accept that the obvious wrong answers were correct.']
['What are some examples of normative social influence and informational social influence?', 'The correct answer to the line segment question was obvious, and it was an easy task.']

['What were the influences on individuals?', 'Researchers have categorized the motivation to conform into two types: normative social influence and informational social influence (Deutsch & Gerard, 1955).']
['What does normative social influence mean?', 'In normative social influence, people conform to the group norm to fit in, to feel good, and to be accepted by the group.']

['What is informational social influence?', 'However, with informational social influence, people conform because they believe the group is competent and has the correct information, particularly when the task or situation is ambiguous.']
['What else should I know about social influence?', 'Since the line judgment task was unambiguous, participants did not need to rely on the group for information.']
['What is social influence?', 'Instead, participants complied to fit in and avoid ridicule, an instance of normative social influence.']
['What are some examples of informational social influence?', 'An example of informational social influence may be what to do in an emergency situation.']

['What should you do if you are in a movie theater watching a film and what seems to be smoke comes in the theater from under the emergency exit door?', 'Imagine that you are in a movie theater watching a film and what seems to be smoke comes in the theater from under the emergency exit door.']
['What happens if there is smoke in a movie theater?', 'You are not certain that it is smoke—it might be a special effect for the movie, such as a fog machine.']
['When you are uncertain, what will you do?', 'When you are uncertain you will tend to look at the behavior of others in the theater.']
['What will you do if other people show concern and get up to leave?', 'If other people show concern and get up to leave, you are likely to do the same.']
['What happens if other people seem unconcerned?', 'However, if others seem unconcerned, you are likely to stay put and continue watching the movie (Figure 12.19).']
['What do the students say about the study?', 'Many students say they would not conform, that the study is outdated, and that people nowadays are more independent.']
['Are there any other studies that support this?', 'To some extent this may be true.']
['What else happened?', 'Research suggests that overall rates of conformity may have reduced since the time of Asch’s research.']
['What did you find interesting about the passage?', 'Furthermore, efforts to replicate']
['What else has Asch’s study made it clear?', 'Asch’s study have made it clear that many factors determine how likely it is that someone will demonstrate conformity to the group.']

['What are the factors that affect the participant’s performance?', 'These factors include the participant’s age, gender, and socio-cultural background (Bond & Smith, 1996; Larsen, 1990; Walker & Andrade, 1996).']
['What is the effect of conformity on our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors?', 'Conformity is one effect of the influence of others on our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.']
["What's another form of social influence?", 'Another form of social influence is obedience to authority.']

['What is the change of an individual’s behavior to comply with a demand by an authority figure?', 'Obedience is the change of an individual’s behavior to comply with a demand by an authority figure.']
['What is the reason people often comply with requests?', 'People often comply with the request because they are concerned about a consequence if they do not comply.']
['What is a phenomenon?', 'To demonstrate this phenomenon, we review another classic social psychology experiment.']
['What did Stanley Milgram do with a Nazi war criminal?', 'Stanley Milgram was a social psychology professor at Yale who was influenced by the trial of Adolf Eichmann, a Nazi war criminal.']

['What was the experiment about?', 'Eichmann’s defense for the atrocities he committed was that he was “just following orders.” Milgram (1963) wanted to test the validity of this defense, so he designed an experiment and initially recruited 40 men for his experiment.']
['What were the participants doing in the experiment?', 'The volunteer participants were led to believe that they were participating in a study to improve learning and memory.']
['What were the test items?', 'The participants were told that they were to teach other students (learners) correct answers to a series of test items.']
['What were the different intensities of the shocks?', 'The participants were shown how to use a device that they were told delivered electric shocks of different intensities to the learners.']
['What was the purpose of the shocks?', 'The participants were told to shock the learners if they gave a wrong answer to a test item—that the shock would help them to learn.']
['What other results were found?', 'The participants believed they gave the learners shocks, which increased in 15-volt increments, all the way up to 450 volts.']
['How were the participants informed?', 'The participants did not know that the learners were confederates and that the confederates did not actually receive shocks.']

['What did the participants do in response to a string of incorrect answers from the learners?', 'In response to a string of incorrect answers from the learners, the participants obediently and repeatedly shocked them.']
['What did the confederate learners do?', 'The confederate learners cried out for help, begged the participant teachers to stop, and even complained of heart trouble.']

['Why did they continue the shocks?', 'Yet, when the researcher told the participant-teachers to continue the shock, 65% of the participants continued the shock to the maximum voltage and to the point that the learner became unresponsive (Figure 12.20).']
['What were the variations of the original Milgram experiment?', 'Several variations of the original Milgram experiment were conducted to test the boundaries of obedience.']
['What happened in the original experiment?', 'When certain features of the situation were changed, participants were less likely to continue to deliver shocks (Milgram, 1965).']

['What other things happened during this experiment?', 'For example, when the setting of the experiment was moved to an off-campus office building, the percentage of participants who delivered the highest shock dropped to 48%.']
['What happened when the learner was in the same room as the teacher?', 'When the learner was in the same room as the teacher, the highest shock rate dropped to 40%.']
['What was the third variable used during this experiment?', 'When the teachers’ and learners’ hands were touching, the highest shock rate dropped to 30%.']
['What did this experiment test?', 'When the researcher gave the orders by phone, the rate dropped to 23%.']
['What did the results show?', 'These variations show that when the humanity of the person being shocked was increased, obedience decreased.']
['What was found during the experiment?', 'Similarly, when the authority of the experimenter decreased, so did obedience.']
['What is the case about?', 'This case is still very applicable today.']

['What was the study by Martin and Bull (2008)?', 'In a study by Martin and Bull (2008), midwives privately filled out a questionnaire regarding best practices and expectations in delivering a baby.']

['What happened after the junior midwives were told to do something they had previously stated they were opposed to?', 'Then, a more senior midwife and supervisor asked the junior midwives to do something they had previously stated they were opposed to.']
['What did the midwives do?', 'Most of the junior midwives were obedient to authority, going against their own beliefs.']
['What else can you tell me about this study?', 'Burger (2009) partially replicated this study.']
['What did he find?', "He found among a multicultural sample of women and men that their levels of obedience matched Milgram's research."]

['What else did he do?', "Doliński et al. (2017) performed a replication of Burger's work in Poland and controlled for the gender of both participants and learners, and once again, results that were consistent with Milgram's original work were observed."]
['What is the study material based on?', 'When in group settings, we are often influenced by the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors of people around us.']
['What is the most important part of the information?', 'Whether it is due to normative or informational social influence, groups have power to influence individuals.']
['What is another factor of influence?', 'Another phenomenon of group conformity is groupthink.']

['What is the modification of the opinions of members of a group to align with what they believe is the group consensus?', 'Groupthink is the modification of the opinions of members of a group to align with what they believe is the group consensus (Janis, 1972).']

['What does it mean to take extreme action?', 'In group situations, the group often takes action that individuals would not perform outside the group setting because groups make more extreme decisions than individuals do.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Moreover, groupthink can hinder opposing trains of thought.']
['What does hinder opposing trains of thought mean?', 'This elimination of diverse opinions contributes to faulty decision by the group.']
['What are the causes of groupthink?', 'There are several causes of groupthink, which makes it preventable.']

['What are the causes of group hysteria?', 'When the group is highly cohesive, or has a strong sense of connection, maintaining group harmony may become more important to the group than making sound decisions.']
['What can cause groupthink?', 'If the group leader is directive and makes his opinions known, this may discourage group members from disagreeing with the leader.']
['What other factors may lead to groupthink?', 'If the group is isolated from hearing alternative or new viewpoints, groupthink may be more likely.']

['What other subjects did you cover in class?', 'There are several strategies that can improve group decision making including seeking outside opinions, voting in private, having the leader withhold position statements until all group members have voiced their views, conducting research on all viewpoints, weighing the costs and benefits of all options, and developing a contingency plan (Janis, 1972; Mitchell & Eckstein, 2009).']
['What happens in groups?', 'Another phenomenon that occurs within group settings is group polarization.']

['What is the strengthening of an original group attitude after the discussion of views within a group?', 'Group polarization (Teger & Pruitt, 1967) is the strengthening of an original group attitude after the discussion of views within a group.']

['What is it considered a group attitude if a group initially favors a viewpoint, after discussion the group consensus is likely a stronger endorsement of the viewpoint?', 'That is, if a group initially favors a viewpoint, after discussion the group consensus is likely a stronger endorsement of the viewpoint.']
['What happens if the group was initially opposed to a viewpoint?', 'Conversely, if the group was initially opposed to a viewpoint, group discussion would likely lead to stronger opposition.']
['Are groups better than individuals for this?', 'Group polarization explains many actions taken by groups that would not be undertaken by individuals.']

['Are there any other interesting facts?', 'Group polarization can be observed at political conventions, when platforms of the party are supported by individuals who, when not in a group, would decline to support them.']

['What is the most important thing to know about this topic?', 'Recently, some theorists have argued that group polarization may be partly responsible for the extreme political partisanship that seems ubiquitous in modern society.']

["What is the effect of this on people's voting?", 'Given that people can self-select media outlets that are most consistent with their own political views, they are less likely to encounter opposing viewpoints.']
['What happens in these group settings?', 'Over time, this leads to a strengthening of their own perspective and of hostile attitudes and behaviors towards those with different political ideals.']

['What can you tell me about the polarization?', 'Remarkably, political polarization leads to open levels of discrimination that are on par with, or perhaps exceed, racial discrimination (Iyengar & Westwood, 2015).']
['What other groups are doing this?', 'A more everyday example is a group’s discussion of how attractive someone is.']

['What do social traps refer to?', 'Social traps refer to situations that arise when individuals or groups of individuals behave in ways that are not in their best interest and that may have negative, long-term consequences.']
['How do they cause problems?', 'However, once established, a social trap is very difficult to escape.']
['What was the example given?', 'For example, following World War II, the United States and the former Soviet Union engaged in a nuclear arms race.']

['What was the reason for the arms race?', "While the presence of nuclear weapons is not in either party's best interest, once the arms race began, each country felt the need to continue producing nuclear weapons to protect itself from the other."]
['What is social loafing?', 'Imagine you were just assigned a group project with other students whom you barely know.']
['What would happen to your grades if you all barely know each other?', 'Everyone in your group will get the same grade.']
['What does social loafing mean?', 'Social loafing involves a reduction in individual output on tasks where contributions are pooled.']
['What are the effects of social loafing?', "Because each individual's efforts are not evaluated, individuals can become less motivated to perform well."]
['What research has been done on social loafing?', 'Karau and Williams (1993) and Simms and Nichols (2014) reviewed the research on social loafing and discerned when it was least likely to happen.']

['How can social loafing be mitigated?', 'The researchers noted that social loafing could be alleviated if, among other situations, individuals knew their work would be assessed by a manager (in a workplace setting) or instructor (in a classroom setting), or if a manager or instructor required group members to complete self-evaluations.']
['What does this study say?', 'The likelihood of social loafing in student work groups increases as the size of the group increases (Shepperd & Taylor, 1999).']
['What about college students?', 'According to Kamau and Williams (1993), college students were the population most likely to engage in social loafing.']

['How do they explain this?', 'Their study also found that women and participants from collectivistic cultures were less likely to engage in social loafing, explaining that their group orientation may account for this.']
['What is it about?', 'College students could work around social loafing or “free-riding” by suggesting to their professors use of a flocking method to form groups.']

['What do they do?', 'Harding (2018) compared groups of students who had self-selected into groups for class to those who had been formed by flocking, which involves assigning students to groups who have similar schedules and motivations.']
['What did she find?', 'Not only did she find that students reported less “free riding,” but that they also did better in the group assignments compared to those whose groups were self-selected.']
['What is the opposite of social loafing?', 'Interestingly, the opposite of social loafing occurs when the task is complex and difficult (Bond & Titus, 1983; Geen, 1989).']

['What can we learn from that?', 'In a group setting, such as the student work group, if your individual performance cannot be evaluated, there is less pressure for you to do well, and thus less anxiety or physiological arousal (Latané, Williams, & Harkens, 1979).']
['What happens as a result of this?', 'This puts you in a relaxed state in which you can perform your best, if you choose (Zajonc, 1965).']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'If the task is a difficult one, many people feel motivated and believe that their group needs their input to do well on a challenging project (Jackson & Williams, 1985).']
['What is the most important thing you learned from this topic?', 'Another way that being part of a group can affect behavior is exhibited in instances in which deindividuation occurs.']
['What is deindividuation?', 'Deindividuation refers to situations in which a person may feel a sense of anonymity and therefore a reduction in accountability and sense of self when among others.']

['Can you tell me some more interesting aspects of the article?', 'Deindividuation is often pointed to in cases in which mob or riot-like behaviors occur (Zimbardo, 1969), but research on the subject and the role that deindividuation plays in such behaviors has resulted in inconsistent results (as discussed in Granström, Guvå, Hylander, & Rosander, 2009).']
['What is the result of human conflict?', 'Human conflict can result in crime, war, and mass murder, such as genocide.']
['What causes human conflict?', 'Prejudice and discrimination often are root causes of human conflict, which explains how strangers come to hate one another to the extreme of causing others harm.']
['What are the effects of prejudice and discrimination?', 'Prejudice and discrimination affect everyone.']
['What are some examples of discrimination?', 'In this section we will examine the definitions of prejudice and discrimination, examples of these concepts, and causes of these biases.']

['What is the first important fact in the article?', 'As we discussed in the opening story of Trayvon Martin, humans are very diverse and although we share many similarities, we also have many differences.']
['What is the second important fact?', 'The social groups we belong to help form our identities (Tajfel, 1974).']
['What is the third important fact?', 'These differences may be difficult for some people to reconcile, which may lead to prejudice toward people who are different.']
['What is prejudice?', 'Prejudice is a negative attitude and feeling toward an individual based solely on one’s membership in a particular social group (Allport, 1954; Brown, 2010).']
['What is prejudice against?', 'Prejudice is common against people who are members of an unfamiliar cultural group.']

['What can be done to reduce the tendency toward prejudice?', 'Thus, certain types of education, contact, interactions, and building relationships with members of different cultural groups can reduce the tendency toward prejudice.']
['How can you reduce prejudice?', 'In fact, simply imagining interacting with members of different cultural groups might affect prejudice.']

['what happened as a result of this?', 'Indeed, when experimental participants were asked to imagine themselves positively interacting with someone from a different group, this led to an increased positive attitude toward the other group and an increase in positive traits associated with the other group.']
['What else happened to reduce prejudice?', 'Furthermore, imagined social interaction can reduce anxiety associated with inter-group interactions (Crisp & Turner, 2009).']
['What are some social groups?', 'Social groups can include gender, race, ethnicity, nationality, social class, religion, sexual orientation, profession, and many more.']
['what else are social groups?', 'And, as is true for social roles, you can simultaneously be a member of more than one social group.']
['What is an example of prejudice?', 'An example of prejudice is having a negative attitude toward people who are not born in the United States.']
['How is this an example?', 'Although people holding this prejudiced attitude do not know all people who were not born in the United States, they dislike them due to their status as foreigners.']

['what is prejudice?', 'Prejudice often begins in the form of a stereotype—that is, a specific belief or assumption about individuals based solely on their membership in a group, regardless of their individual characteristics.']
['How are stereotypes applied?', 'Stereotypes become overgeneralized and applied to all members of a group.']

['what is an example of prejudice?', 'For example, someone holding prejudiced attitudes toward older adults, may believe that older adults are slow and incompetent (Cuddy, Norton, & Fiske, 2005; Nelson, 2004).']
['How do you know that all older adults are slow and incompetent?', 'We cannot possibly know each individual person of advanced age to know that all older adults are slow and incompetent.']

['What are the consequences of prejudice?', 'Therefore, this negative belief is overgeneralized to all members of the group, even though many of the individual group members may in fact be spry and intelligent.']
['What is another example of a well known stereotype?', 'Another example of a well-known stereotype involves beliefs about racial differences among athletes.']

['What are some high profile examples of these?', 'As Hodge, Burden, Robinson, and Bennett (2008) point out, Black athletes are often believed to be more athletic, yet less intelligent, than their White counterparts.']
['What is the reason for the belief persisting?', 'These beliefs persist despite a number of high profile examples to the contrary.']
['How can such beliefs impact athletes?', 'Sadly, such beliefs often influence how these athletes are treated by others and how they view themselves and their own capabilities.']
['Is this thought pattern a common one?', 'Whether or not you agree with a stereotype, stereotypes are generally well-known within a given culture (Devine, 1989).']
['What is discrimination?', 'Sometimes people will act on their prejudiced attitudes toward a group of people, and this behavior is known as discrimination.']
['What is discrimination?', 'Discrimination is negative action toward an individual as a result of one’s membership in a particular group (Allport, 1954; Dovidio & Gaertner, 2004).']

['How does older adults fit into this category?', 'As a result of holding negative beliefs (stereotypes) and negative attitudes (prejudice) about a particular group, people often treat the target of prejudice poorly, such as excluding older adults from their circle of friends.']
['What is oppression?', 'In this way, discrimination is a form of oppression.']
['Who experienced gender discrimination?', 'An example of a psychologist experiencing gender discrimination is found in the life and studies of Mary Whiton Calkins.']

['What else did she do to experience discrimination?', 'Calkins was given special permission to attend graduate seminars at Harvard (at that time in the late 1880s, Harvard did not accept women) and at one point was the sole student of the famous psychologist William James.']
['How did her studies go?', 'She passed all the requirements needed for a PhD and was described by psychologist Hugo Münsterberg as “one of the strongest professors of psychology in this country.”']
['Was Calkins allowed to obtain her PhD?', 'However, Harvard refused to grant Calkins a PhD because she was a woman (Harvard University, 2019).']
['What are the characteristics of stereotypes, prejudices and discrimination?', 'Table 12.3 summarizes the characteristics of stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'So far, we’ve discussed stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination as negative thoughts, feelings, and behaviors because these are typically the most problematic.']

['What can you tell me more about this?', 'However, it is important to also point out that people can hold positive thoughts, feelings, and behaviors toward individuals based on group membership; for example, they would show preferential treatment for people who are like themselves—that is, who share the same gender, race, or favorite sports team.']

['What are three pieces of information that we automatically process when we meet strangers?', 'When we meet strangers we automatically process three pieces of information about them: their race, gender, and age (Ito & Urland, 2003).']

['Why are these two secondary characteristics important?', 'Although these secondary characteristics are important in forming a first impression of a stranger, the social categories of race, gender, and age provide a wealth of information about an individual.']
['What is this information based on?', 'This information, however, often is based on stereotypes.']
['What happens to the strangers depending on these secondary characteristics?', 'We may have different expectations of strangers depending on their race, gender, and age.']

['What is racism?', 'Racism is prejudice and discrimination against an individual based solely on one’s membership in a specific racial group (such as toward African Americans, Asian Americans, Latinos, Native Americans, European Americans).']

['What is some stereotypes?', 'Research suggests cultural stereotypes for Asian Americans include cold, sly, and intelligent; for Latinos, cold and unintelligent; for European Americans, cold and intelligent; and for African Americans, aggressive, athletic, and more likely to be law breakers (Devine & Elliot, 1995; Fiske, Cuddy, Glick, & Xu, 2002; Sommers & Ellsworth, 2000; Dixon & Linz, 2000).']
['What does racism encompass?', 'Racism exists for many racial and ethnic groups.']

['How does racism affect black people?', 'For example, Black people are significantly more likely to have their vehicles searched during traffic stops than White people, particularly when Black people are driving in predominately White neighborhoods, a phenomenon often termed “DWB” or “driving while Black” (Rojek, Rosenfeld, & Decker, 2012).']
['I was wondering what you were going to study next?', 'Mexican Americans and other Latino groups also are targets of racism from the police and other members of the community.']

['What are some examples of discrimination?', 'For example, when purchasing items with a personal check, Latino shoppers are more likely than White shoppers to be asked to show formal identification (Dovidio et al., 2010).']
