['What are the facts about the case?', 'In one case of alleged harassment by the police, several East Haven, Connecticut, police officers were arrested on federal charges due to reportedly continued harassment and brutalization of Latinos.']
['What else can you tell me about this case?', 'When the accusations came out, the mayor of East Haven was asked, “What are you doing for the Latino community today?”']
['What did the Mayor respond to the question?', 'The Mayor responded, “I might have tacos when I go home, I’m not quite sure yet” (“East Haven Mayor,” 2012).']

['What else did the mayor do?', 'This statement undermines the important issue of racial profiling and police harassment of Latinos, while belittling Latino culture by emphasizing an interest in a food product stereotypically associated with Latinos.']

['Is racism prevalent toward other groups in the US?', 'Racism is prevalent toward many other groups in the United States including Native Americans, Arab Americans, Jewish Americans, and Asian Americans.']
['What is dual attitudes model?', 'One reason modern forms of racism, and prejudice in general, are hard to detect is related to the dual attitudes model (Wilson, Lindsey, & Schooler, 2000).']

['What is implicit attitudes?', 'Humans have two forms of attitudes: explicit attitudes, which are conscious and controllable, and implicit attitudes, which are unconscious and uncontrollable (Devine, 1989; Olson & Fazio, 2003).']

['What is the important part of implicit attitudes?', 'Because holding egalitarian views is socially desirable (Plant & Devine, 1998), most people do not show extreme racial bias or other prejudices on measures of their explicit attitudes.']

['What kind of racial bias do implicit attitudes often show?', 'However, measures of implicit attitudes often show evidence of mild to strong racial bias or other prejudices (Greenwald, McGee, & Schwartz, 1998; Olson & Fazio, 2003).']
['What is sexism?', 'Sexism is prejudice and discrimination toward individuals based on their sex.']
['What do you think of this discrimination?', 'Typically, sexism takes the form of men holding biases against women, but anyone can show sexism toward their own or the other sex.']
['What are some things that you think can be done to help the situation?', 'Like racism, sexism may be subtle and difficult to detect.']
['What do you think of gender role expectations?', 'Common forms of sexism in modern society include gender role expectations, such as expecting women to be the caretakers of the household.']
['What other gender role expectations do you see?', 'Sexism also includes people’s expectations for how members of a gender group should behave.']

['What does that mean for people?', 'For example, women are expected to be friendly, passive, and nurturing, and when women behave in an unfriendly, assertive, or neglectful manner they often are disliked for violating their gender role (Rudman, 1998).']

['What does Rudman say about self-promotion?', 'Research by Laurie Rudman (1998) finds that when female job applicants self-promote, they are likely to be viewed as competent, but they may be disliked and are less likely to be hired because they violated gender expectations for modesty.']

['What other kinds of gender role expectations have you seen?', 'In this way, women are sometimes blamed for wage and employment inequality, but they would be viewed negatively for trying to overcome them, a phenomenon sometimes referred to as the double bind.']
['What can gender roles do to someone?', 'Sexism can exist on a societal level such as in hiring, employment opportunities, and education.']

['What can gender roles do?', 'Women are less likely to be hired or promoted in male-dominated professions such as engineering, aviation, and construction (Figure 12.22) (Blau, Ferber, & Winkler, 2010; Ceci & Williams, 2011).']
['What can you do about gender roles?', 'Think about your family members’ jobs or careers.']
['What is ageism?', 'People often form judgments and hold expectations about people based on their age.']
['What can these judgments lead to?', 'These judgments and expectations can lead to ageism, or prejudice and discrimination toward individuals based solely on their age.']
['What are some examples of older adults?', 'Think of expectations you hold for older adults.']

['What is an example of a common ageist attitude?', 'Ageism is widespread in U.S. culture (Nosek, 2005), and a common ageist attitude toward older adults is that they are incompetent, physically weak, and slow (Greenberg, Schimel, & Martens, 2002) and some people consider older adults less attractive.']

['What did Levy report on?', 'Chang, Kannoth, Levy, Wang, Lee, and Levy (2020) reported on relationships between ageism and health outcomes over a 40-year-plus period from countries around the world.']
['What did the report find?', 'Across 11 health domains, people over 50 were likely to experience ageism most often in the form of being denied access to health services and work opportunities.']

['What was found in the report?', 'Some cultures, however, including some Asian, Latino, and African American cultures, both outside and within the United States afford older adults respect and honor.']
['What does ageism affect?', 'Typically, ageism occurs against older adults, but ageism also can occur toward younger adults.']
['What is ageism?', 'Raymer, Reed, Spiegel, and Purvanova (2017) examined ageism against younger workers.']

['How did they study ageism against younger workers?', 'They found that older workers endorsed negative stereotypes of younger workers, believing that they had more work deficit characteristics (including perceptions of incompetence).']

['What is another form of prejudice?', 'Another form of prejudice is homophobia: an umbrella term referring to prejudice and discrimination of individuals based solely on their sexual orientation, which is often applied to bisexual, lesbian, gay, and other non-heterosexual people.']

['What is the hatred or fear of those who are perceived to break or blur stereotypical gender roles?', 'Transphobia is the hatred or fear of those who are perceived to break or blur stereotypical gender roles, often expressed as stereotyping, discrimination, harassment and/or violence.']
['How widespread is homophobia?', 'Like ageism, homophobia is a widespread prejudice in U.S. society that is tolerated by many people (Herek & McLemore, 2013; Nosek, 2005).']

['How does homophobia influence others?', 'Negative feelings often result in discrimination, such as the exclusion of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ+) people from social groups and the avoidance of LGBTQ+ neighbors and co-workers.']

['Does homophobia also extend to employers deliberately declining to hire qualified LGBTQ+ job applicants?', 'This discrimination also extends to employers deliberately declining to hire qualified LGBTQ+ job applicants, a practice officially outlawed by a 2020 Surpreme Court decision but which remains a significant issue.']
['What is the reason for prejudice and discrimination?', 'Prejudice and discrimination persist in society due to social learning and conformity to social norms.']

['What else do you know about social learning?', 'Children learn prejudiced attitudes and beliefs from society: their parents, teachers, friends, the media, and other sources of socialization, such as social media (O’Keeffe & Clarke-Pearson, 2011).']

['What are some other aspects of social learning?', 'If certain types of prejudice and discrimination are acceptable in a society, there may be normative pressures to conform and share those prejudiced beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors.']
['What is one example of social class?', 'For example, public and private schools are still somewhat segregated by social class.']
['Why is that?', 'Historically, only children from wealthy families could afford to attend private schools, whereas children from middle- and low-income families typically attended public schools.']
['What are the expectations that we have about a person?', 'When we hold a stereotype about a person, we have expectations that they will fulfill that stereotype.']

['What is an expectation held by a person that alters their behavior in a way that tends to make it true?', 'A self-fulfilling prophecy is an expectation held by a person that alters their behavior in a way that tends to make it true.']
['What do we tend to do when we hold stereotypes about a person?', 'When we hold stereotypes about a person, we tend to treat the person according to our expectations.']
['Why is this important?', 'This treatment can influence the person to act according to our stereotypic expectations, thus confirming our stereotypic beliefs.']

['What did this mean to the students?', 'Research by Rosenthal and Jacobson (1968) found that disadvantaged students whose teachers expected them to perform well had higher grades than disadvantaged students whose teachers expected them to do poorly.']
['What are some examples of cause and effect?', 'Consider this example of cause and effect in a self-fulfilling prophecy:']

['What kind of beliefs can make you do bad work?', 'If an employer expects an openly gay job applicant to be incompetent, the potential employer might treat the applicant negatively during the interview by engaging in less conversation, making little eye contact, and generally behaving coldly toward the applicant (Hebl, Foster, Mannix, & Dovidio, 2002).']

['Who does this affect?', 'In turn, the job applicant will perceive that the potential employer dislikes him, and he will respond by giving shorter responses to interview questions, making less eye contact, and generally disengaging from the interview.']

['Is this a bad example?', 'After the interview, the employer will reflect on the applicant’s behavior, which seemed cold and distant, and the employer will conclude, based on the applicant’s poor performance during the interview, that the applicant was in fact incompetent.']
['Why does this happen?', 'Thus, the employer’s stereotype—gay people are incompetent and do not make good employees—is reinforced.']
['What kind of consequences does this have?', 'Treating individuals according to stereotypic beliefs can lead to prejudice and discrimination.']
['What can reinforce stereotypes?', 'Another dynamic that can reinforce stereotypes is confirmation bias.']

['What does it mean?', 'When interacting with the target of our prejudice, we tend to pay attention to information that is consistent with our stereotypic expectations and ignore information that is inconsistent with our expectations.']

['What is the process called when we seek out information that supports our stereotypes and ignore information that is inconsistent with our stereotypes?', 'In this process, known as confirmation bias, we seek out information that supports our stereotypes and ignore information that is inconsistent with our stereotypes (Wason & Johnson-Laird, 1972).']

['What can we do to reduce confirmation bias?', 'In the job interview example, the employer may not have noticed that the job applicant was friendly and engaging, and that he provided competent responses to the interview questions in the beginning of the interview.']

['How did the employer react?', 'Instead, the employer focused on the job applicant’s performance in the later part of the interview, after the applicant changed his demeanor and behavior to match the interviewer’s negative treatment.']
['What social groups do people belong to?', 'As discussed previously in this section, we all belong to a gender, race, age, and social economic group.']
['How do these groups affect us?', 'These groups provide a powerful source of our identity and self-esteem (Tajfel & Turner, 1979).']
['What do the groups serve as?', 'These groups serve as our in-groups.']
['What is an in-group?', 'An in-group is a group that we identify with or see ourselves as belonging to.']
['What is an out-group?', 'A group that we don’t belong to, or an out-group, is a group that we view as fundamentally different from us.']
['What are some examples of groups?', 'For example, if you are a woman, your gender in-group includes all women, and your gender out-group includes all men (Figure 12.23).']

['What are some characteristics of these groups?', 'People often view gender groups as being fundamentally different from each other in personality traits, characteristics, social roles, and interests.']

['What are the in-group biases?', 'Because we often feel a strong sense of belonging and emotional connection to our in-groups, we develop in-group bias: a preference for our own group over other groups.']
['How can these biases affect us?', 'This in-group bias can result in prejudice and discrimination because the out-group is perceived as different and is less preferred than our in-group.']
['What are some things to note about prejudice?', 'One function of prejudice is to help us feel good about ourselves and maintain a positive self-concept.']
['How does it feel to be good about yourself?', 'This need to feel good about ourselves extends to our in-groups:']
['Why do we want to feel good?', 'We want to feel good and protect our in-groups.']
['What does that do for us?', 'We seek to resolve threats individually and at the in-group level.']
['How do we seek to resolve threats?', 'This often happens by blaming an out-group for the problem.']

['What is the act of blaming an out-group when the in-group experiences frustration or is blocked from obtaining a goal?', 'Scapegoating is the act of blaming an out-group when the in-group experiences frustration or is blocked from obtaining a goal (Allport, 1954).']
['What has this chapter discussed?', 'Throughout this chapter we have discussed how people interact and influence one another’s thoughts, feelings, and behaviors in both positive and negative ways.']

['What can we learn from this chapter?', 'People can work together to achieve great things, such as helping each other in difficult times: consider how educators and healthcare workers went to great lengths to help others during the COVID-19 pandemic.']

['What can we learn about people?', 'People also can do great harm to one another, such as conforming to group norms that are immoral and obeying authority to the point of murder: consider the mass conformity of Nazis during WWII.']
['What can we learn about aggression?', 'In this section we will discuss a negative side of human behavior—aggression.']
['What has a number of researchers done to reduce prejudice?', 'A number of researchers have explored ways to reduce prejudice.']
['What was one of the earliest studies?', 'One of the earliest was a study by Sherif et al. (1961) known as the Robbers Cave experiment.']

['What did the Robbers Cave experiment find?', 'They found that when two opposing groups at a camp worked together toward a common goal, prejudicial attitudes between the groups decreased (Gaertner, Dovidio, Banker, Houlette, Johnson, & McGlynn, 2000).']
['What was the key to attitude change in the research?', 'Focusing on superordinate goals was the key to attitude change in the research.']
['What did another study examine?', 'Another study examined the jigsaw classroom, a technique designed by Aronson and Bridgeman in an effort to increase success in desegregated classrooms.']
['What is the jigsaw classroom technique?', 'In this technique, students work on an assignment in groups inclusive of various races and abilities.']

['What is a part of the assignment?', 'They are assigned tasks within their group, then collaborate with peers from other groups who were assigned the same task, and then report back to their original group.']

['What was one of the findings of the Robbers Cave experiment?', 'Walker and Crogan (1998) noted that the jigsaw classroom reduced potential for prejudice in Australia, as diverse students worked together on projects needing all of the pieces to succeed.']
['What can be inferred from the two studies?', 'This research suggests that anything that can allow individuals to work together toward common goals can decrease prejudicial attitudes.']
['What is the future of this study?', 'Obviously, the application of such strategies in real-world settings would enhance opportunities for conflict resolution.']
['What can you tell me about the topic?', 'Humans engage in aggression when they seek to cause harm or pain to another person.']
['What is the motivation for aggression?', 'Aggression takes two forms depending on one’s motives: hostile or instrumental.']

['What are some examples of hostile aggression?', 'Hostile aggression is motivated by feelings of anger with intent to cause pain; a fight in a bar with a stranger is an example of hostile aggression.']

['Why is it instrumental?', 'In contrast, instrumental aggression is motivated by achieving a goal and does not necessarily involve intent to cause pain (Berkowitz, 1993); a contract killer who murders for hire displays instrumental aggression.']
['What are some theories about why aggression exists?', 'There are many different theories as to why aggression exists.']
['What are some of these theories?', 'Some researchers argue that aggression serves an evolutionary function (Buss, 2004).']
['Are men more likely to engage in aggression than women?', 'Men are more likely than women to show aggression (Wilson & Daly, 1985).']

['What other theories of aggression are there?', 'From the perspective of evolutionary psychology, human male aggression, like that in nonhuman primates, likely serves to display dominance over other males, both to protect a mate and to perpetuate the male’s genes (Figure 12.24).']

['What is the reason for male aggression?', 'Sexual jealousy is part of male aggression; males endeavor to make sure their mates are not copulating with other males, thus ensuring their own paternity of the female’s offspring.']
['Are there any negative consequences from engaging in aggression?', 'Although aggression provides an obvious evolutionary advantage for men, women also engage in aggression.']
['What do women typically display more indirectly?', 'Women typically display more indirect forms of aggression, with their aggression serving as a means to an end (Dodge & Schwartz, 1997).']
['What types of attacks are women prone to?', 'For example, women may express their aggression covertly by communication that impairs the social standing of another person.']

['What are other theories of human aggression?', 'Another theory that explains one of the functions of human aggression is frustration aggression theory (Dollard, Doob, Miller, Mowrer, & Sears, 1939).']
['What is the theory of anomie?', 'This theory states that when humans are prevented from achieving an important goal, they become frustrated and aggressive.']
['What is another form of aggression?', 'Another form of aggression is bullying.']
['How can it benefit children?', 'As you learn in your study of child development, socializing and playing with other children is beneficial for children’s psychological development.']
["What is the most important reason play behavior doesn't have positive outcomes?", 'However, as you may have experienced as a child, not all play behavior has positive outcomes.']
['What do some children want to do?', 'Some children are aggressive and want to play roughly.']
['What do some children want?', 'Other children are selfish and do not want to share toys.']
['What is bullying?', 'One form of negative social interactions among children that has become a national concern is bullying.']
['What is the definition of bullying?', 'Bullying is repeated negative treatment of another person, often an adolescent, over time (Olweus, 1993).']

['How is bullying different from other types of aggression?', 'A one-time incident in which one child hits another child on the playground would not be considered bullying: Bullying is repeated behavior.']

['What is the negative treatment typical in bullying?', 'The negative treatment typical in bullying is the attempt to inflict harm, injury, or humiliation, and bullying can include physical or verbal attacks.']
['Can bullying be anything else?', 'However, bullying doesn’t have to be physical or verbal, it can be psychological.']

['What gender differences are found in how girls and boys bully others?', 'Research finds gender differences in how girls and boys bully others (American Psychological Association, 2010; Olweus, 1993).']
['What kind of gender differences do you find?', 'Boys tend to engage in direct, physical aggression such as physically harming others.']
['What gender differences are there?', 'Girls tend to engage in indirect, social forms of aggression such as spreading rumors, ignoring, or socially isolating others.']
['What are some characteristics of bullying?', 'Bullying involves three parties: the bully, the victim, and witnesses or bystanders.']
['What is the act of bullying?', 'The act of bullying involves an imbalance of power with the bully holding more power—physically, emotionally, and/or socially over the victim.']
['What can be positive for the bully?', 'The experience of bullying can be positive for the bully, who may enjoy a boost to self-esteem.']
['What are the negative consequences of bullying?', 'However, there are several negative consequences of bullying for the victim, and also for the bystanders.']

['What are the negative consequences of being the victim of bullying?', 'Being the victim of bullying is associated with decreased mental health, including experiencing anxiety and depression (APA, 2010).']
['What other negative consequences?', 'Victims of bullying may underperform in schoolwork (Bowen, 2011).']
['What can happen to a victim of bullying?', 'Bullying also can result in the victim dying by suicide (APA, 2010).']
['Which traits are more frequently associated with being a bully?', 'Children who are emotionally reactive are at a greater risk for being bullied.']
['What is more frequently associated with them?', 'Bullies may be attracted to children who get upset easily because the bully can quickly get an emotional reaction from them.']
['What is more frequently associated with them?', 'Children who are different from others are likely to be targeted for bullying.']
['Which other traits are most frequently associated with it?', 'Children who are overweight, cognitively impaired, or racially or ethnically different from their peer group may be at higher risk.']
['What is more frequent?', 'Gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender teens are at very high risk of being bullied and hurt due to their sexual orientation.']
['What was the problem with cyberbullying?', 'With widely available mobile technology and social networking media, a new form of bullying has emerged: cyberbullying.']
['What is the definition of cyberbullying?', 'Cyberbullying, like bullying, is repeated behavior that is intended to cause psychological or emotional harm to another person.']
['What is unique about cyberbullying?', 'What is unique about cyberbullying is that it is typically covert, concealed, done in private, and the bully can remain anonymous.']

['What is the response to cyberbullying?', 'This anonymity gives the bully power, and the victim may feel helpless, unable to escape the harassment, and unable to retaliate (Spears, Slee, Owens, & Johnson, 2009).']

['Did you find any interesting things?', 'About one in three middle and high school students report that they have experienced cyberbullying (Patchin, 2016; Patchin, 2019), with some studies indicating that nearly three in five teens have experienced some type of online abusive behavior such as non-repeated name-calling or being sent unsolicited links or images (Anderson, 2018).']

['What can cyberbullying take?', 'Cyberbullying can take many forms, including harassing a victim by spreading rumors, creating a website defaming the victim, threatening the victim, or teasing the victim (Spears et al., 2009).']

['Who are the victims of cyberbullying?', 'Overall, LGBTQ youth are targeted at a higher rate than heterosexual and cisgender youth, and members of minority populations overall are more likely to be cyberbullying victims (Hinjuda & Patchin, 2020).']
['What happens to girls?', 'In terms of gender, experiences vary in terms of both the prevelance and types of cyberbullying experienced and perpetrated.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'In cyberbullying, it is more common for girls to be the bullies and victims.']
['What does that mean?', 'Interestingly, girls who become cyberbullies often have been the victims of cyberbullying at one time (Vandebosch & Van Cleemput, 2009).']

['What else do you know about the study?', 'Girls were more likely to say someone spread rumors about them online while boys were more likely to say that someone threatened to hurt them online (Patchin, 2019).']

['What are the effects of cyberbullying?', 'The effects of cyberbullying are just as harmful as traditional bullying and include the victim feeling frustration, anger, sadness, helplessness, powerlessness, and fear.']
['Are there any other effects?', 'Victims will also experience lower self-esteem (Hoff & Mitchell, 2009; Spears et al., 2009).']

['What is another interesting fact about the article?', 'Furthermore, recent research suggests that both cyberbullying victims and perpetrators are more likely to experience suicidal ideation, and they are more likely to attempt suicide than individuals who have no experience with cyberbullying (John, 2019).']

['What can you tell me about cyberbullying?', 'Cyberbullying is a form of aggression and, depending on the messages and methods, can be considered harassment, stalking, or assault—all subject to prosecution.']

['What else can you tell me about cyberbullying?', 'Finally, while much of the concern and research regarding cyberbullying centers on adolescents, adults (particularly college students) are frequent victims and perpetrators.']
['What is the discussion of bullying about?', 'The discussion of bullying highlights the problem of witnesses not intervening to help a victim.']
['What is the name of the researcher who described the bystander effect?', 'Researchers Latané and Darley (1968) described a phenomenon called the bystander effect.']
['What is the bystander effect?', 'The bystander effect is a phenomenon in which a witness or bystander does not volunteer to help a victim or person in distress.']
['What do they do instead of arguing?', 'Instead, they just watch what is happening.']
['What do social psychologists hold?', 'Social psychologists hold that we make these decisions based on the social situation, not our own personality variables.']
['What was the impetus behind the bystander effect?', 'The impetus behind the bystander effect was the murder of a young woman named Kitty Genovese in 1964.']

['What was the reason for her murder?', 'The story of her tragic death took on a life of its own when it was reported that none of her neighbors helped her or called the police when she was being attacked.']
['How did the killer get away?', 'However, Kassin (2017) noted that her killer was apprehended due to neighbors who called the police when they saw him committing a burglary days later.']

['What does he find?', 'Not only did bystanders indeed intervene in her murder (one man who shouted at the killer, a woman who said she called the police, and a friend who comforted her in her last moments), but other bystanders intervened in the capture of the murderer.']
['What is the likely explanation for this?', 'Social psychologists claim that diffusion of responsibility is the likely explanation.']

['What is the tendency for no one in a group to help because the responsibility to help is spread throughout the group?', 'Diffusion of responsibility is the tendency for no one in a group to help because the responsibility to help is spread throughout the group (Bandura, 1999).']

['Why did the police not call the police?', 'Because there were many witnesses to the attack on Genovese, as evidenced by the number of lit apartment windows in the building, individuals assumed someone else must have already called the police.']
['Why did they assume someone else called?', 'The responsibility to call the police was diffused across the number of witnesses to the crime.']
['What is a diffusion of responsibility?', 'In general, the greater the number of bystanders, the less likely any one person will help.']

['What is the main topic of our study material?', 'You’ve learned about many of the negative behaviors of social psychology, but the field also studies many positive social interactions and behaviors.']
['What is important about the study of prosocial behavior?', 'Researchers have documented several features of the situation that influence whether we form relationships with others.']
['What do you know about social psychology?', 'There are also universal traits that humans find attractive in others.']

['What are some of the important things discussed in this section?', 'In this section we discuss conditions that make forming relationships more likely, what we look for in friendships and romantic relationships, the different types of love, and a theory explaining how our relationships are formed, maintained, and terminated.']
['What is voluntary behavior with the intent to help other people called?', 'Voluntary behavior with the intent to help other people is called prosocial behavior.']
['What is another reason to do so?', 'Research suggests there are many other reasons.']
['What is the definition of altruism?', 'Altruism is people’s desire to help others even if the costs outweigh the benefits of helping.']
['Are there any studies that support this?', 'In fact, people acting in altruistic ways may disregard the personal costs associated with helping (Figure 12.26).']

['What was one example of prosocial behavior?', 'For example, news accounts of the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center in New York reported an employee in the first tower helped his co-workers make it to the exit stairwell.']
['What did the man do after helping a co-worker to safety?', 'After helping a co-worker to safety he went back in the burning building to help additional co-workers.']
['What was the cost of helping the hero?', 'In this case the costs of helping were great, and the hero lost his life in the destruction (Stewart, 2002).']
['What does altruism mean?', 'Some researchers suggest that altruism operates on empathy.']
['What is the capacity to understand another person’s perspective, to feel what they feel?', 'Empathy is the capacity to understand another person’s perspective, to feel what they feel.']
['How is empathy influenced?', 'An empathetic person makes an emotional connection with others and feels compelled to help (Batson, 1991).']
['What do other researchers argue?', 'Other researchers argue that altruism is a form of selfless helping that is not motivated by benefits or feeling good about oneself.']

['What does he say about the feeling of good about oneself after helping others?', 'Certainly, after helping, people feel good about themselves, but some researchers argue that this is a consequence of altruism, not a cause.']

['What does he say about helping?', 'Other researchers argue that helping is always self-serving because our egos are involved, and we receive benefits from helping (Cialdini, Brown, Lewis, Luce, & Neuberg 1997).']
['What does this say about egoism?', 'It is challenging to determine experimentally the true motivation for helping, whether it is largely self-serving (egoism) or selfless (altruism).']
['What is there to know about pure altruism?', 'Thus, a debate on whether pure altruism exists continues.']
['What are the most important factors in determining your personality?', 'You might be surprised to learn that the answer is simple: the people with whom you have the most contact.']
['What is another important factor?', 'This most important factor is proximity.']
['What do you mean by proximity?', 'You are more likely to be friends with people you have regular contact with.']

['How can proximity help us form relationships?', 'For example, there are decades of research that shows that you are more likely to become friends with people who live in your dorm, your apartment building, or your immediate neighborhood than with people who live farther away (Festinger, Schachler, & Back, 1950).']
['Why is it easier to form relationships with people you see often?', 'It is simply easier to form relationships with people you see often because you have the opportunity to get to know them.']
['What are the other factors that influence who we form relationships with?', 'Similarity is another factor that influences who we form relationships with.']
['What does similarity mean?', 'We are more likely to become friends or lovers with someone who is similar to us in background, attitudes, and lifestyle.']
['What is the evidence that opposites attract?', 'In fact, there is no evidence that opposites attract.']
['Why do we attract people who are most like us?', 'Rather, we are attracted to people who are most like us (Figure 12.27) (McPherson, Smith-Lovin, & Cook, 2001).']
['What does sharing things mean?', 'Sharing things in common will certainly make it easy to get along with others and form connections.']
['what kind of things?', 'When you and another person share similar music taste, hobbies, food preferences, and so on, deciding what to do with your time together might be easy.']

['What is homophily?', 'Homophily is the tendency for people to form social networks, including friendships, marriage, business relationships, and many other types of relationships, with others who are similar (McPherson et al., 2001).']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'But, homophily limits our exposure to diversity (McPherson et al., 2001).']

['Are there any other interesting points in the content?', 'By forming relationships only with people who are similar to us, we will have homogenous groups and will not be exposed to different points of view.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects about the article?', 'In other words, because we are likely to spend time with those who are most like ourselves, we will have limited exposure to those who are different than ourselves, including people of different races, ethnicities, social-economic status, and life situations.']
['What is the next question?', 'Once we form relationships with people, we desire reciprocity.']
['What is the give and take in relationships?', 'Reciprocity is the give and take in relationships.']
['How is this related to two way street?', 'We contribute to relationships, but we expect to receive benefits as well.']
['What do we want our relationships to be?', 'That is, we want our relationships to be a two way street.']
['What do we want from our partner?', 'We are more likely to like and engage with people who like us back.']
['What can you tell me about two way street?', 'Self-disclosure is part of the two way street.']
['What is self-disclosure?', 'Self-disclosure is the sharing of personal information (Laurenceau, Barrett, & Pietromonaco, 1998).']
['How do we form intimate connections?', 'We form more intimate connections with people with whom we disclose important information about ourselves.']

['Are we more likely to trust others when we disclose this information?', 'Indeed, self-disclosure is a characteristic of healthy intimate relationships, as long as the information disclosed is consistent with our own views (Cozby, 1973).']
['What did we discuss?', 'We have discussed how proximity and similarity lead to the formation of relationships, and that reciprocity and self-disclosure are important for relationship maintenance.']
['What are the top characteristics that attract women?', 'Researchers have documented several characteristics that humans find attractive.']
['What traits attract the majority of people?', 'First we look for friends and lovers who are physically attractive.']
['What do people consider attractive?', 'People differ in what they consider attractive, and attractiveness is culturally influenced.']

['What are some universally attractive features in women?', 'Research, however, suggests that some universally attractive features in women include large eyes, high cheekbones, a narrow jaw line, a slender build (Buss, 1989), and a lower waist-to-hip ratio (Singh, 1993).']
['What are the top characteristics that attract women?', 'For men, attractive traits include being tall, having broad shoulders, and a narrow waist (Buss, 1989).']

['What is the next most important thing?', 'Both men and women with high levels of facial and body symmetry are generally considered more attractive than asymmetric individuals (Fink, Neave, Manning, & Grammer, 2006; Penton-Voak et al., 2001; Rikowski & Grammer, 1999).']

['What are the next characteristics that attract people?', 'Social traits that people find attractive in potential female mates include warmth, affection, and social skills; in males, the attractive traits include achievement, leadership qualities, and job skills (Regan & Berscheid, 1997).']
['What is the most important thing to look for in a mate?', 'Although humans want mates who are physically attractive, this does not mean that we look for the most attractive person possible.']

['What is the matching hypothesis?', 'In fact, this observation has led some to propose what is known as the matching hypothesis which asserts that people tend to pick someone they view as their equal in physical attractiveness and social desirability (Taylor, Fiore, Mendelsohn, & Cheshire, 2011).']
['Why do we do this?', 'For example, you and most people you know likely would say that a very attractive movie star is out of your league.']
['What is the result of being too close to someone?', 'So, even if you had proximity to that person, you likely would not ask them out on a date because you believe you likely would be rejected.']
['What is interesting about the passage?', 'People weigh a potential partner’s attractiveness against the likelihood of success with that person.']

['Who can be more attractive than me?', 'If you think you are particularly unattractive (even if you are not), you likely will seek partners that are fairly unattractive (that is, unattractive in physical appearance or in behavior).']

["What are the three components of Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love?", 'We typically love the people with whom we form relationships, but the type of love we have for our family, friends, and lovers differs.']
['What are the three components of love?', 'Robert Sternberg (1986) proposed that there are three components of love: intimacy, passion, and commitment.']
['What are these three components connected by?', 'These three components form a triangle that defines multiple types of love: this is known as Sternberg’s triangular theory of love (Figure 12.28).']
['What is intimacy defined as?', 'Intimacy is the sharing of details and intimate thoughts and emotions.']
['What is passion defined as?', 'Passion is the physical attraction—the flame in the fire.']
['What is commitment?', 'Commitment is standing by the person—the “in sickness and health” part of the relationship.']

['What does Sternberg (1986) state that a healthy relationship will have all three components of love—intimacy, passion, and commitment—which is described as consummate love?', 'Sternberg (1986) states that a healthy relationship will have all three components of love—intimacy, passion, and commitment—which is described as consummate love (Figure 12.29).']
['What does he say about love?', 'However, different aspects of love might be more prevalent at different life stages.']
['What are some examples of these types of love?', 'Other forms of love include liking, which is defined as having intimacy but no passion or commitment.']
['What is the presence of passion without intimacy or commitment?', 'Infatuation is the presence of passion without intimacy or commitment.']
['What is the difference between empty love and passionate love?', 'Empty love is having commitment without intimacy or passion.']

['What is the characteristic of close friendships and family relationships?', 'Companionate love, which is characteristic of close friendships and family relationships, consists of intimacy and commitment but no passion.']
['What is the definition of romantic love?', 'Romantic love is defined by having passion and intimacy, but no commitment.']
['What is fatuous love?', 'Finally, fatuous love is defined by having passion and commitment, but no intimacy, such as a long term sexual love affair.']
['What is the second subject?', 'Social Exchange']
['What is the third subject?', 'Theory.']
['What are the most important things we discussed?', 'We have discussed why we form relationships, what attracts us to others, and different types of love.']
['What are some theories of why we form relationships?', 'One theory that provides an explanation is social exchange theory.']

['What does social exchange theory say?', 'According to social exchange theory, we act as naïve economists in keeping a tally of the ratio of costs and benefits of forming and maintaining a relationship with others (Figure 12.30) (Rusbult & Van Lange, 2003).']
['What is the triangular theory of love?', 'People are motivated to maximize the benefits of social exchanges, or relationships, and minimize the costs.']

['What happens when social exchanges create more costs than benefits?', 'People prefer to have more benefits than costs, or to have nearly equal costs and benefits, but most people are dissatisfied if their social exchanges create more costs than benefits.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'Let’s discuss an example.']

['What are some examples of a decision that is made based on the advantages and disadvantages of the decision?', 'If you have ever decided to commit to a romantic relationship, you probably considered the advantages and disadvantages of your decision.']
['What kind of things did you consider?', 'You may have considered having companionship, intimacy, and passion, but also being comfortable with a person you know well.']

['What other factors were considered?', 'You may think that over time boredom from being with only one person may set in; moreover, it may be expensive to share activities such as attending movies and going to dinner.']
['What are some benefits of dating your romantic partner?', 'However, the benefits of dating your romantic partner presumably outweigh the costs, or you wouldn’t continue the relationship.']

['What is the most important information you learned from the text?', 'In 2019, people who worked in the United States spent an average of about 42–54 hours per week working (Bureau of Labor Statistics—U.S. Department of Labor, 2019).']
['Did you find any other interesting information?', 'Sleeping was the only other activity they spent more time on with an average of about 43–62 hours per week.']
['What do you think about the information in this text?', 'The workday is a significant portion of workers’ time and energy.']
['How does the work day impact the workers?', 'It impacts their lives and their family’s lives in positive and negative physical and psychological ways.']

['What is industrial and organizational psychology?', 'Industrial and organizational (I-O) psychology is a branch of psychology that studies how human behavior and psychology affect work and how they are affected by work.']

['What are some of the main contexts industrial and organizational psychologists work in?', 'Industrial and organizational psychologists work in four main contexts: academia, government, consulting firms, and business.']
['What type of degrees are awarded in the field?', 'Most I-O psychologists have a master’s or doctorate degree.']

['What are the three broad areas of I-O psychology?', 'The field of I-O psychology can be divided into three broad areas (Figure 13.2 and Figure 13.3): industrial, organizational, and human factors.']

['What is industrial psychology concerned with describing?', 'Industrial psychology is concerned with describing job requirements and assessing individuals for their ability to meet those requirements.']

['What are some more important things about industrial psychology?', 'In addition, once employees are hired, industrial psychology studies and develops ways to train, evaluate, and respond to those evaluations.']

['What can you tell me about the discrimination?', 'As a consequence of its concern for candidate characteristics, industrial psychology must also consider issues of legality regarding discrimination in hiring.']

['What is the discipline of organizational psychology?', 'Organizational psychology is a discipline interested in how the relationships among employees affect those employees and the performance of a business.']
['What is important about human factors?', 'This includes studying worker satisfaction, motivation, and commitment.']

['What else is important?', 'This field also studies management, leadership, and organizational culture, as well as how an organization’s structures, management and leadership styles, social norms, and role expectations affect individual behavior.']

['What is harassment?', 'As a result of its interest in worker wellbeing and relationships, organizational psychology also considers the subjects of harassment, including sexual harassment, and workplace violence.']

['What is the study of how workers interact with the tools of work and how to design those tools to optimize workers’ productivity, safety, and health?', 'Human factors psychology is the study of how workers interact with the tools of work and how to design those tools to optimize workers’ productivity, safety, and health.']

['What can industrial psychology studies involve?', 'These studies can involve interactions as straightforward as the fit of a desk, chair, and computer to a human having to sit on the chair at the desk using the computer for several hours each day.']
['What can industrial psychology examine?', 'They can also include the examination of how humans interact with complex displays and their ability to interpret them accurately and quickly.']
['In Europe, this field is referred to as what?', 'In Europe, this field is referred to as ergonomics.']
['What is occupational health psychology?', 'Occupational health psychology (OHP) deals with the stress, diseases, and disorders that can affect employees as a result of the workplace.']

['What are some of the things in OHP?', 'As such, the field is informed by research from the medical, biological, psychological, organizational, human factors, human resources, and industrial fields.']

['Why is this field important?', 'Individuals in this field seek to examine the ways in which the organization affects the quality of work life for an employee and the responses that employees have towards their organization or as a result of their organization’s influence on them.']

['How do the responses for employees affect their personal lives?', 'The responses for employees are not limited to the workplace as there may be some spillover into their personal lives outside of work, especially if there is not good work-life balance.']

['What else is notable about OHP?', 'The ultimate goal of an occupational health psychologist is to improve the overall health and well-being of an individual, and, as a result, increase the overall health of the organization (Society for Occupational Health Psychology, 2020).']

['What was the brainchild of a small group of I-O psychologists who met at a conference?', 'In 2009, the field of humanitarian work psychology (HWP) was developed as the brainchild of a small group of I-O psychologists who met at a conference.']

['When did this small group of psychologists form?', 'Realizing they had a shared set of goals involving helping those who are underserved and underprivileged, the I-O psychologists formally formed the group in 2012 and have approximately 300 members worldwide.']
['How many psychologists are in this group?', 'Although this is a small number, the group continues to expand.']
['What is the goal of the group?', 'The group seeks to help marginalized members of society, such as people with low-income, find work.']
['What else does the group do?', 'In addition, they help to determine ways to deliver humanitarian aid during major catastrophes.']

['Does this help them to get out of poverty?', 'The Humanitarian Work Psychology group can also reach out to those in the local community who do not have the knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs) to be able to find gainful employment that would enable them to not need to receive aid.']

['Why do they help them develop these skills?', 'In both cases, humanitarian work psychologists try to help the underserved individuals develop KSAs that they can use to improve their lives and their current situations.']

['Do they get a better job?', 'When ensuring these underserved individuals receive training or education, the focus is on skills that, once learned, will never be forgotten and can serve individuals throughout their lifetimes as they seek employment (APA, 2016).']
['What is the main field of I-O psychology?', 'Table 13.1 summarizes the main fields in I-O psychology, their focuses, and jobs within each field.']
['When did industrial and organizational psychology come about?', 'Industrial and organizational psychology had its origins in the early 20th century.']

['Who were the early psychologists that studied issues that today would be categorized as industrial psychology?', 'Several influential early psychologists studied issues that today would be categorized as industrial psychology: James Cattell (1860–1944), Hugo Münsterberg (1863–1916), Walter Dill Scott (1869–1955), Robert Yerkes (1876–1956), Walter Bingham (1880–1952), and Lillian Gilbreth (1878–1972).']
['What did Cattell, Münsterberg, and Scott have in common?', 'Cattell, Münsterberg, and Scott had been students of Wilhelm Wundt, the father of experimental psychology.']
['What is the history of industrial psychology?', 'Some of these researchers had been involved in work in the area of industrial psychology before World War I.']

['Who else was involved?', 'Cattell’s contribution to industrial psychology is largely reflected in his founding of a psychological consulting company, which is still operating today called the Psychological Corporation, and in the accomplishments of students at Columbia in the area of industrial psychology.']

["What was Münsterberg's most important accomplishment?", 'In 1913, Münsterberg published Psychology and Industrial Efficiency, which covered topics such as employee selection, employee training, and effective advertising.']
['What was the most important fact from the article?', 'Scott was one of the first psychologists to apply psychology to advertising, management, and personnel selection.']
['What year did Scott publish his first book?', 'In 1903, Scott published two books: The Theory of Advertising and Psychology of Advertising.']
['What was special about those books?', 'They are the first books to describe the use of psychology in the business world.']
['what happened in 1911?', 'By 1911 he published two more books, Influencing Men in Business and Increasing Human Efficiency in Business.']
['what was civic science?', 'In 1916 a newly formed division in the Carnegie Institute of Technology hired Scott to conduct applied research on employee selection (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

['What was the focus of all this research?', 'The focus of all this research was in what we now know as industrial psychology; it was only later in the century that the field of organizational psychology developed as an experimental science (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']
['What did the researchers do?', 'In addition to their academic positions, these researchers also worked directly for businesses as consultants.']

['what was the development?', 'When the United States entered World War I in April 1917, the work of psychologists working in this discipline expanded to include their contributions to military efforts.']
['Who was the president of the American Psychological Association?', 'At that time Yerkes was the president of the 25-year-old American Psychological Association (APA).']
['What was the association for?', 'The APA is a professional association in the United States for clinical and research psychologists.']
['What is the APA?', 'Today the APA performs a number of functions including holding conferences, accrediting university degree programs, and publishing scientific journals.']
['What else was he known for?', 'Yerkes organized a group under the Surgeon General’s Office (SGO) that developed methods for screening and selecting enlisted men.']
['What method did they develop?', 'They developed the Army Alpha test to measure mental abilities.']
['What was the Army Beta test?', 'The Army Beta test was a non-verbal form of the test that was administered to illiterate and non-English-speaking draftees.']
['What were the other developers doing?', 'Scott and Bingham organized a group under the Adjutant General’s Office (AGO) with the goal to develop selection methods for officers.']

['What were the selection methods they developed?', 'They created a catalogue of occupational needs for the Army, essentially a job-description system and a system of performance ratings and occupational skill tests for officers (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']
['What did he do after the war?', 'After the war, work on personnel selection continued.']

["What was Millicent Pond's next task?", 'For example, Millicent Pond researched the selection of factory workers, comparing the results of pre-employment tests with various indicators of job performance (Vinchur & Koppes, 2014).']

['When was the first major study on Industrial and organizational psychology?', 'From 1929 to 1932 Elton Mayo (1880–1949) and his colleagues began a series of studies at a plant near Chicago, Western Electric’s Hawthorne Works (Figure 13.4).']

['What was the purpose of this study?', 'This long-term project took industrial psychology beyond just employee selection and placement to a study of more complex problems of interpersonal relations, motivation, and organizational dynamics.']
['What was the result of this project?', 'These studies mark the origin of organizational psychology.']

['What were the effects of the physical work environment?', 'They began as research into the effects of the physical work environment (e.g., level of lighting in a factory), but the researchers found that the psychological and social factors in the factory were of more interest than the physical factors.']
['Did they study anything else?', 'These studies also examined how human interaction factors, such as supervisorial style, increased or decreased productivity.']

['What was the name of a prominent factor that contributed to the development of industrial and organizational psychology?', 'Analysis of the findings by later researchers led to the term the Hawthorne effect, which describes the increase in performance of individuals who are aware they are being observed by researchers or supervisors (Figure 13.5).']

['What did the original researchers find?', 'What the original researchers found was that any change in a variable, such as lighting levels, led to an improvement in productivity; this was true even when the change was negative, such as a return to poor lighting.']
['What was the effect of attention on the effect of attention?', 'The effect faded when the attention faded (Roethlisberg & Dickson, 1939).']

['What was the effect of the Hawthorne-effect concept?', 'The Hawthorne-effect concept endures today as an important experimental consideration in many fields and a factor that has to be controlled for in an experiment.']

['What is significant about the experimental treatment of some kind?', 'In other words, an experimental treatment of some kind may produce an effect simply because it involves greater attention of the researchers on the participants (McCarney et al., 2007).']
['When did researchers begin to study employees’ feelings about their jobs?', 'In the 1930s, researchers began to study employees’ feelings about their jobs.']
["Who conducted the study of employees' feelings?", 'Kurt Lewin also conducted research on the effects of various leadership styles, team structure, and team dynamics (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

['What did Lewin influence?', 'Lewin is considered the founder of social psychology and much of his work and that of his students produced results that had important influences in organizational psychology.']

['What was the effect of leadership style on aggression, group dynamics, and satisfaction?', 'Lewin and his students’ research included an important early study that used children to study the effect of leadership style on aggression, group dynamics, and satisfaction (Lewin, Lippitt, & White, 1939).']

['What was the most important result of his research?', 'Lewin was also responsible for coining the term group dynamics, and he was involved in studies of group interactions, cooperation, competition, and communication that bear on organizational psychology.']
['What did he study in this field?', 'Parallel to these studies in industrial and organizational psychology, the field of human factors psychology was also developing.']
['Who was frederick taylor?', 'Frederick Taylor was an engineer who saw that if one could redesign the workplace there would be an increase in both output for the company and wages for the workers.']
['What did he do with this theory?', 'In 1911 he put forward his theory in a book titled, The Principles of Scientific Management (Figure 13.6).']
['How was this theory used in his book?', 'His book examines management theories, personnel selection and training, as well as the work itself, using time and motion studies.']
["What was Taylor's theory of management?", 'Taylor argued that the principle goal of management should be to make the most money for the employer, along with the best outcome for the employee.']

['What is the best way to achieve that?', 'He believed that the best outcome for the employee and management would be achieved through training and development so that each employee could provide the best work.']

['How does time and motion studies benefit the organization and the employee?', 'He believed that by conducting time and motion studies for both the organization and the employee, the best interests of both were addressed.']
['What were the studies used for?', 'Time-motion studies were methods aimed to improve work by dividing different types of operations into sections that could be measured.']
['What was the purpose of the analyses?', 'These analyses were used to standardize work and to check the efficiency of people and equipment.']
['What is personnel selection?', 'Personnel selection is a process used by recruiting personnel within the company to recruit and select the best candidates for the job.']
['What is the most important factor in determining how much training is necessary for the hired candidate?', 'Training may need to be conducted depending on what skills the hired candidate has.']
['Do companies hire someone because of their personality?', 'Often companies will hire someone with the personality that fits in with others but who may be lacking in skills.']
['What can you tell me about the personality traits?', 'Skills can be taught, but personality cannot be easily changed.']
['What examples of Taylor’s theory in action are given?', 'One of the examples of Taylor’s theory in action involved workers handling heavy iron ingots.']
['How did Taylor prove his theory?', 'Taylor showed that the workers could be more productive by taking work rests.']

['What was the result of this?', 'This method of rest increased worker productivity from 12.5 to 47.0 tons moved per day with less reported fatigue as well as increased wages for the workers who were paid by the ton.']
['What other benefits did Taylor achieve?', 'At the same time, the company’s cost was reduced from 9.2 cents to 3.9 cents per ton.']

['Why did critics say his theory was flawed?', 'Despite these increases in productivity, Taylor’s theory received a great deal of criticism at the time because it was believed that it would exploit workers and reduce the number of workers needed.']

['How did they reject his theory?', 'Also controversial was the underlying concept that only a manager could determine the most efficient method of working, and that while at work, a worker was incapable of this.']

['What was the goal of Taylor’s scientific management approach?', 'Taylor’s theory was underpinned by the notion that a worker was fundamentally lazy and the goal of Taylor’s scientific management approach was to maximize productivity without much concern for worker well-being.']
['Did his theory ever fail?', 'His approach was criticized by unions and those sympathetic to workers (Van De Water, 1997).']
['Who else was involved in the study?', 'Gilbreth was another influential I-O psychologist who strove to find ways to increase productivity (Figure 13.7).']

['What did Gilbreth and her husband, Frank, do?', 'Using time and motion studies, Gilbreth and her husband, Frank, worked to make workers more efficient by reducing the number of motions required to perform a task.']
['What kind of tasks were performed?', 'She not only applied these methods to industry but also to the home, office, shops, and other areas.']
["What else can you tell me about Gilbreth's work?", 'She investigated employee fatigue and time management stress and found many employees were motivated by money and job satisfaction.']

['What year did Gilbreth write the book?', 'In 1914, Gilbreth wrote the book title, The Psychology of Management: The Function of the Mind in Determining, Teaching, and Installing Methods of Least Waste, and she is known as the mother of modern management.']

['Was this a successful book?', 'Some of Gilbreth’s contributions are still in use today: you can thank her for the idea to put shelves inside on refrigerator doors, and she also came up with the concept of using a foot pedal to operate the lid of trash can (Gilbreth, 1914, 1998; Koppes, 1997; Lancaster, 2004).']

['What was significant about her work?', 'Gilbreth was the first woman to join the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in 1926, and in 1966 she was awarded the Hoover Medal of the American Society of Civil Engineers.']
['What did Taylor and Gilbreth’s work improve?', 'Taylor and Gilbreth’s work improved productivity, but these innovations also improved the fit between technology and the human using it.']
['What is the study of machine–human fit called?', 'The study of machine–human fit is known as ergonomics or human factors psychology.']
['What did World War II drive?', 'World War II also drove the expansion of industrial psychology.']

['What was a significant discovery during the study?', 'Bingham was hired as the chief psychologist for the War Department (now the Department of Defense) and developed new systems for job selection, classification, training, ad performance review, plus methods for team development, morale change, and attitude change  (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

['What countries saw growth in I-O psychology during World War II?', 'Other countries, such as Canada and the United Kingdom, likewise saw growth in I-O psychology during World War II (McMillan, Stevens, & Kelloway, 2009).']
['What was another discovery during this study?', 'In the years after the war, both industrial psychology and organizational psychology became areas of significant research effort.']
['What else was discovered during this time period?', 'Concerns about the fairness of employment tests arose, and the ethnic and gender biases in various tests were evaluated with mixed results.']
['What other discoveries were made during this time period?', 'In addition, a great deal of research went into studying job satisfaction and employee motivation (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

['What did you find interesting about the passage?', 'The research and work of I-O psychologists in the areas of employee selection, placement, and performance appraisal became increasingly important in the 1960s.']
['What does title VII cover?', 'When Congress passed the 1964 Civil Rights Act, Title VII covered what is known as equal employment opportunity.']

['What does it protect against?', 'This law protects employees against discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin, as well as discrimination against an employee for associating with an individual in one of these categories.']

['What is the main reason for organizations to be interested in I/O?', 'There are many reasons for organizations to be interested in I/O so that they can better understand the psychology of their workers, which in turn helps them understand how their organizations can become more productive and competitive.']

['How does io affect work performance?', 'For example, most large organizations are now competing on a global level, and they need to understand how to motivate workers in order to achieve high productivity and efficiency.']
['What else did you learn about io?', 'Most companies also have a diverse workforce and need to understand the psychological complexity of the people in these diverse backgrounds.']
["What's the most interesting thing in this chapter?", 'Today, I-O psychology is a diverse and deep field of research and practice, as you will learn about in the rest of this chapter.']

['What other interesting things have you learned about the profession?', 'The Society for Industrial and Organizational Psychology (SIOP), a division of the APA, lists 8,000 members (SIOP, 2014) and the Bureau of Labor Statistics—U.S. Department of Labor (2013) has projected this profession will have the greatest growth of all job classifications in the 20 years following 2012.']

['What other interesting information have you found?', 'On average, a person with a master’s degree in industrial-organizational psychology will earn over $80,000 a year, while someone with a doctorate will earn over $110,000 a year (Khanna, Medsker, & Ginter, 2012).']

['What is the branch of I-O psychology known as industrial psychology?', 'The branch of I-O psychology known as industrial psychology focuses on identifying and matching persons to tasks within an organization.']
['What does this involve?', 'This involves job analysis, which means accurately describing the task or job.']
['What must organizations do after the job analysis?', 'Then, organizations must identify the characteristics of applicants for a match to the job analysis.']
['What else must they do?', 'It also involves training employees from their first day on the job throughout their tenure within the organization, and appraising their performance along the way.']
['How do we select employees?', 'Often, this is done with the help of I-O psychologists.']

['What are the two approaches to job analysis?', 'There are two related but different approaches to job analysis—you may be familiar with the results of each as they often appear on the same job advertisement.']
['What is the first approach to job analysis?', 'The first approach is task-oriented and lists in detail the tasks that will be performed for the job.']
['What is the task-oriented approach?', 'Each task is typically rated on scales for how frequently it is performed, how difficult it is, and how important it is to the job.']
['What is the second approach to job analysis?', 'The second approach is worker-oriented.']
['What is the second approach?', 'This approach describes the characteristics required of the worker to successfully perform the job.']
['What is this second approach called?', 'This second approach has been called job specification (Dierdorff & Wilson, 2003).']
['What is the purpose of job specification?', 'For job specification, the knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs) that the job requires are identified.']
['What are the approaches to job analysis?', 'Observation, surveys, and interviews are used to obtain the information required for both types of job analysis.']
['What is the main idea of this section?', 'It is possible to observe someone who is proficient in a position and analyze what skills are apparent.']

['What is a second approach used?', 'Another approach used is to interview people presently holding that position, their peers, and their supervisors to get a consensus of what they believe are the requirements of the job.']
['What is the importance of job analysis?', 'Research suggests that it can depend on the nature of the descriptions and the source for the job analysis.']

['What other interesting information can you provide?', 'For example, Dierdorff & Wilson (2003) found that job analyses developed from descriptions provided by people holding the job themselves were the least reliable; however, they did not study or speculate why this was the case.']

['What is the database that contains information about different jobs?', 'The United States Department of Labor maintains a database of previously compiled job analyses for different jobs and occupations.']
['What is a benefit of the information in these databases?', 'This allows the I-O psychologist to access previous analyses for nearly any type of occupation.']
['What is the name of the system that provides this information?', 'This system is called O*Net (accessible at www.onetonline.org).']
['What is the purpose of the site?', 'The site is open and you can see the KSAs that are listed for your own position or one you might be curious about  (Figure 13.8).']

['How many KSAs are there?', 'Each occupation lists the tasks, knowledge, skills, abilities, work context, work activities, education requirements, interests, personality requirements, and work styles that are deemed necessary for success in that position.']
['Are there other information available?', 'You can also see data on average earnings and projected job growth in that industry.']

['What is the process of candidate analysis?', 'Once a company identifies potential candidates for a position, the candidates’ knowledge, skills, and other abilities must be evaluated and compared with the job description.']
['What kind of evaluations are needed?', 'These evaluations can involve testing, an interview, and work samples or exercises.']

['What are personality tests used for?', 'You learned about personality tests in the chapter on personality; in the I-O context, they are used to identify the personality characteristics of the candidate in an effort to match those to personality characteristics that would ensure good performance on the job.']
['What can we learn from the article?', 'For example, a high rating of agreeableness might be desirable in a customer support position.']

['What is the best way to correlate personality characteristics with predictions of job performance?', 'However, it is not always clear how best to correlate personality characteristics with predictions of job performance.']
['What can we learn about the article?', 'It might be that too high of a score on agreeableness is actually a hindrance in the customer support position.']
['How so?', 'For example, if a customer has a misperception about a product or service, agreeing with their misperception will not ultimately lead to resolution of their complaint.']

['What can we learn about personality tests?', 'Any use of personality tests should be accompanied by a verified assessment of what scores on the test correlate with good performance (Arthur, Woehr, & Graziano, 2001).']

['What other types of tests that may be given to candidates include IQ tests, integrity tests, and physical tests, such as drug tests or physical fitness tests?', 'Other types of tests that may be given to candidates include IQ tests, integrity tests, and physical tests, such as drug tests or physical fitness tests.']
['What is a candidate analysis and testing?', 'To better understand the hiring process, let’s consider an example case.']
['What is an example of a job advertisement?', 'A company determined it had an open position and advertised it.']
['What happened after the hiring team was contacted?', 'The human resources (HR) manager directed the hiring team to start the recruitment process.']
['How did Imani get the job?', 'Imani saw the advertisement and submitted her résumé, which went into the collection of candidate résumés.']

['What happened after the HR team reviewed the candidates’ credentials?', 'The HR team reviewed the candidates’ credentials and provided a list of the best potential candidates to the department manager, who reached out to them (including Imani) to set up individual interviews.']
['What are the main reasons for a job interview?', 'Most jobs for mid-size to large-size businesses in the United States require a personal interview as a step in the selection process.']
['Are interviews standardized?', 'Because interviews are commonly used, they have been the subject of considerable research by industrial psychologists.']
['What is the basis for the types of questions asked in an interview?', 'Information derived from job analysis usually forms the basis for the types of questions asked.']
['Are there any advantages to using interviews?', 'Interviews can provide a more dynamic source of information about the candidate than standard testing measures.']
['What is discussed in the article?', 'Importantly, social factors and body language can influence the outcome of the interview.']

['What social factors and body language influence?', 'These include influences, such as the degree of similarity of the applicant to the interviewer and nonverbal behaviors, such as hand gestures, head nodding, and smiling (Bye, Horverak, Sandal, Sam, & Vivjer, 2014; Rakić, Steffens, & Mummendey, 2011).']
['What are the two types of interviews?', 'There are two types of interviews: unstructured and structured.']
['How does an unstructured interview work?', 'In an unstructured interview, the interviewer may ask different questions of each different candidate.']
['What are some examples of different questions you might ask?', 'One candidate might be asked about her career goals, and another might be asked about his previous work experience.']
['What is the standard system in the unstructured interview?', 'In an unstructured interview, the questions are often, though not always, unspecified beforehand.']
['How do you evaluate the answers in an unstructured interview?', 'And in an unstructured interview the responses to questions asked are generally not scored using a standard system.']

['How do you evaluate a structured interview?', 'In a structured interview, the interviewer asks the same questions of every candidate, the questions are prepared in advance, and the interviewer uses a standardized rating system for each response.']
['What is the benefit of using the standard system?', 'With this approach, the interviewer can accurately compare two candidates’ interviews.']

['What are the advantages of structured interviews over unstructured interviews?', 'In a meta-analysis of studies examining the effectiveness of various types of job interviews, McDaniel, Whetzel, Schmidt & Maurer (1994) found that structured interviews were more effective at predicting subsequent job performance of the job candidate.']
['What is the purpose of this guide?', 'Let’s return to our example case.']
['What was the interview experience like for Imani?', 'For her first interview, Imani was interviewed by a team of employees at the company.']
['What other details do you know about her interview?', 'She was one of five candidates interviewed that day for the position.']

['How was the interview for all five candidates?', 'Each interviewee was asked the same list of questions, by the same people, so the interview experience was as consistent as possible across applicants.']
["What was the HR team's response to the questions?", 'At the end of the interviews, the HR team met and reviewed the answers given by Imani and the other candidates.']

['What did the HR team do after reviewing the answers?', 'The HR team then identified a few new qualified candidates and conducted a new round of initial interviews, while the first group of potential hires waited to hear back from the company.']
['What is training?', 'Training is an important element of success and performance in many jobs.']

['What is the purpose of orientation?', 'Most jobs begin with an orientation period during which the new employee is provided information regarding the company history, policies, and administrative protocols such as time tracking, benefits, and reporting requirements.']

['What is the goal of orientation training?', 'An important goal of orientation training is to educate the new employee about the organizational culture, the values, visions, hierarchies, norms and ways the company’s employees interact—essentially how the organization is run, how it operates, and how it makes decisions.']

['What else is training related to?', 'There will also be training that is specific to the job the individual was hired to do, or training during the individual’s period of employment that teaches aspects of new duties, or how to use new physical or software tools.']

['What kind of training is often formalized for the employee?', 'Much of these kinds of training will be formalized for the employee; for example, orientation training is often accomplished using software presentations, group presentations by members of the human resources department or with people in the new hire’s department (Figure 13.9).']
['What is the purpose of mentoring?', 'Mentoring is a form of informal training in which an experienced employee guides the work of a new employee.']
['What can we do in the mentoring?', 'In some situations, mentors will be formally assigned to a new employee, while in others a mentoring relationship may develop informally.']
['What can you tell me about the effects of mentoring?', 'Mentoring effects on the mentor and the employee being mentored, the protégé, have been studied in recent years.']

['What did Eby, Allen, Evans, Ng, & DuBois (2008) find in their review of mentoring studies?', 'In a review of mentoring studies, Eby, Allen, Evans, Ng, & DuBois (2008) found significant but small effects of mentoring on performance (i.e., behavioral outcomes), motivation and satisfaction, and actual career outcomes.']

['What did Allen, Eby, Poteet, Lentz, & Lima (2004) find?', 'In a more detailed review, Allen, Eby, Poteet, Lentz, & Lima (2004) found that mentoring positively affected a protégé’s compensation and number of promotions compared with non-mentored employees.']
['What did they find?', 'In addition, protégés were more satisfied with their careers and had greater job satisfaction.']
['What were the effects of the experiment?', 'All of the effects were small but significant.']

['What did Eby, Durley, Evans, & Ragins (2006) find?', 'Eby, Durley, Evans, & Ragins (2006) examined mentoring effects on the mentor and found that mentoring was associated with greater job satisfaction and organizational commitment.']

['What did you find that mentoring was positively related with performance ratings by supervisors?', 'Gentry, Weber, & Sadri (2008) found that mentoring was positively related with performance ratings by supervisors.']
