['What did Allen, Lentz, & Day (2006) find?', 'Allen, Lentz, & Day (2006) found in a comparison of mentors and non-mentors that mentoring led to greater reported salaries and promotions.']

['What do researchers have to say about race and mentoring?', 'Researchers have worked to understand the impacts of gender, race, and ethnicity on mentoring relationships,  especially whether outcomes differ based on the gender or racial/ethnic makeup of the mentor-mentee pair.']

['What happens to women with mentoring?', 'Overall, women and members of underrepresented racial/ethnic populations do not lack access to mentors, but they do lack access to mentors of the same gender, race, and ethnicity, because the senior roles in many organizations are made up of White men (MLDC, 2010).']

['What is important to know about race and mentoring?', 'Results from these studies are mixed, but generally suggest that pairings made up of two people of the same gender or race/ethnicity have better psychosocial outcomes, such as a feeling of more support (Koberg, Boss, & Goodman, 1998; Allen et al, 2006).']

['Do women and people of color experience greater career advancement or higher pay when mentored by people of a different gender or race/ethnicity?', 'On the other hand, women and people of color typically experience greater career advancement or higher pay when mentored by people of a different gender or race/ethnicity (Parks-Yancy, 2012).']

['What is the most important thing you can tell me about the material that I presented you?', 'A 2003 study by Arthur, Bennett, Edens, and Bell examined multiple other studies to determine how effective organizational training is.']

['What were their findings?', 'Their results showed that training was effective, based on four types of measurement: (1) the immediate response of the employee to the training effort, (2) testing at the end of training to demonstrate that learning outcomes were met, (3) behavioral measurements of job activities by supervisors, and (4) results such as productivity and profits.']

['What is the second type of training that Arthur et al studied?', 'The examined studies represented diverse forms of training including self-instruction, lecture and discussion, and computer assisted training.']
['What type of organization are these psychologists involved in?', 'Industrial and organizational psychologists are typically involved in designing performance-appraisal systems for organizations.']
['What are the main reasons for designing these performance-appraisal systems?', 'These systems are designed to evaluate whether each employee is performing satisfactorily.']

['What are some other characteristics of organizational psychologists?', 'Industrial and organizational psychologists study, research, and implement ways to make work evaluations as fair and positive as possible; they also work to decrease the subjectivity involved with performance ratings.']

['Why is this beneficial for organizations?', 'Fairly evaluated work helps employees do their jobs better, improves the likelihood of people being in the right jobs for their talents, maintains fairness, and identifies company and individual training needs.']
['What was discussed in the interview?', 'In our example case, Imani was offered the position and was hired with a 90-day probation period.']
['What was the probation period?', 'During that time, she met with her supervisor to discuss her performance and the expectations of the position and her growth.']
['Was she satisfied with the probation period?', 'At the end of the 90 days, it was determined that Imani was meeting the expectations of her employer and had passed her probationary period.']
['Was Imani happy that she had passed the probation period?', 'Imani was excited to now have a permanent job.']

['How often do employees get performance appraisals?', 'Performance appraisals are typically documented several times a year, often with a formal process and an annual face-to-face brief meeting between an employee and their supervisor.']

['What is important in a performance appraisal?', 'It is important that the original job analysis play a role in performance appraisal as well as any goals that have been set by the employee or by the employee and supervisor.']

['What does the meeting look like?', 'The meeting is often used for the supervisor to communicate specific concerns about the employee’s performance and to positively reinforce elements of good performance.']
['What can the supervisor do?', 'It may also be used to discuss specific performance rewards, such as a pay increase, or consequences of poor performance, such as a probationary period.']

['What is important to the performance appraisal?', 'Part of the function of performance appraisals for the organization is to document poor performance to bolster decisions to terminate an employee.']

['What were the complex processes?', 'Performance appraisals are becoming more complex processes within organizations and are often used to motivate employees to improve performance and expand their areas of competence, in addition to assessing their job performance.']
['What can they be used to do?', 'In this capacity, performance appraisals can be used to identify opportunities for training or whether a particular training program has been successful.']
['Did they describe 360 degree feedback appraisal?', 'One approach to performance appraisal is called 360-degree feedback appraisal (Figure 13.10).']

['What other interesting things did they have to say?', 'In this system, the employee’s appraisal derives from a combination of ratings by supervisors, peers, employees supervised by the employee, and from the employee herself.']
['What other people were involved in the appraisal process?', 'Occasionally, outside observers may be used as well, such as customers.']

['What is the purpose of 360-degree system?', 'The purpose of 360-degree system is to give the employee (who may be a manager) and supervisor different perspectives of the employee’s job performance; the system should help employees make improvements through their own efforts or through training.']

['Was there anything else that stood out to you?', 'The system is also used in a traditional performance-appraisal context, providing the supervisor with more information with which to make decisions about the employee’s position and compensation (Tornow, 1993a).']

['What happened in the study of 360 degrees?', 'Few studies have assessed the effectiveness of 360-degree methods, but Atkins and Wood (2002) found that the self and peer ratings were unreliable as an assessment of an employee’s performance and that even supervisors tended to underrate employees that gave themselves modest feedback ratings.']

['What is a different perspective seeing this variability in ratings as?', 'However, a different perspective sees this variability in ratings as a positive in that it provides for greater learning on the part of the employees as they and their supervisor discuss the reasons for the discrepancies (Tornow, 1993b).']

['What do the users of this study material have to do with employees?', 'In theory, performance appraisals should be an asset for an organization wishing to achieve its goals, and most employees will actually solicit feedback regarding their jobs if it is not offered (DeNisi & Kluger, 2000).']

['Are there any other interesting aspects to this material?', 'However, in practice, many performance evaluations are disliked by organizations, employees, or both (Fletcher, 2001), and few of them have been adequately tested to see if they do in fact improve performance or motivate employees (DeNisi & Kluger, 2000).']

['What is causing the dislike?', 'One of the reasons evaluations fail to accomplish their purpose in an organization is that performance appraisal systems are often used incorrectly or are of an inappropriate type for an organization’s particular culture (Schraeder, Becton, & Portis, 2007).']
['How does an organization’s culture influence an employee?', 'An organization’s culture is how the organization is run, how it operates, and how it makes decisions.']
['What is the relationship between culture and employees?', 'It is based on the collective values, hierarchies, and how individuals within the organization interact.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects about employee evaluation?', 'Examining the effectiveness of performance appraisal systems in particular organizations and the effectiveness of training for the implementation of the performance appraisal system is an active area of research in industrial psychology (Fletcher, 2001).']

['What is the ideal hiring process?', 'In an ideal hiring process, an organization would generate a job analysis that accurately reflects the requirements of the position, and it would accurately assess candidates’']
['What is the term for a list of skills and abilities used to assess a job candidate?', 'KSAs to determine who the best individual is to carry out the job’s requirements.']
['How often does this process not happen?', 'For many reasons, hiring decisions in the real world are often made based on factors other than matching a job analysis to KSAs.']

['What other factors are considered in hiring?', 'As mentioned earlier, interview rankings can be influenced by other factors: similarity to the interviewer (Bye, Horverak, Sandal, Sam, & Vijver, 2014) and the regional accent of the interviewee (Rakić, Steffens, & Mummendey 2011).']

['What are some other interesting factors in hiring?', 'A study by Agerström & Rooth (2011) examined hiring managers’ decisions to invite equally qualified non-obese and obese job applicants to an interview.']
['What were the decisions based on?', 'The decisions of the hiring managers were based on photographs of the two applicants.']

['What else was discovered?', 'The study found that hiring managers that scored high on a test of negative associations with overweight people displayed a bias in favor of inviting the equally qualified non-obese applicant but not inviting the obese applicant.']

['What is the association test?', 'The association test measures automatic or subconscious associations between an individual’s negative or positive values and, in this case, the body-size attribute.']

['What did the study find?', 'A meta-analysis of experimental studies found that physical attractiveness benefited individuals in various job-related outcomes such as hiring, promotion, and performance review (Hosoda, Stone-Romero, & Coats, 2003).']
['What else is interesting about the study?', 'They also found that the strength of the benefit appeared to be decreasing with time between the late 1970s and the late 1990s.']
['What are the criteria used to make hiring decisions?', 'Some hiring criteria may be related to a particular group an applicant belongs to and not individual abilities.']
['How can this group group affect performance?', 'Unless membership in that group directly affects potential job performance, a decision based on group membership is discriminatory (Figure 13.11).']

['What can be done to prevent discrimination?', 'To combat hiring discrimination, in the United States there are numerous city, state, and federal laws that prevent hiring based on various group-membership criteria.']
['What other information are there?', 'They cannot even ask questions that might shed some light on these attributes, such as where you were born or who you live with.']
['Are there any other restrictions that are in place to prevent discrimination in hiring?', 'These are only a few of the restrictions that are in place to prevent discrimination in hiring.']

['What is the name of the agency that enforces anti-discrimination laws?', 'In the United States, federal anti-discrimination laws are administered by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC).']

['What is the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission?', "The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) is responsible for enforcing federal laws that make it illegal to discriminate against a job applicant or an employee because of the person's race, color, religion, sex (including pregnancy), sexual orientation, national origin, age (40 or older), disability, or genetic information."]
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Figure 13.12 provides some of the legal language from laws that have been passed to prevent discrimination.']
['What is equal employment opportunity?', 'The United States has several specific laws regarding fairness and avoidance of discrimination.']
['What does the Equal Pay Act require?', 'The Equal Pay Act requires that equal pay for men and women in the same workplace who are performing equal work.']
['What is the result of the law?', 'Despite the law, persistent inequities in earnings between men and women exist.']
['What was the result of the gender gap study?', 'Corbett & Hill (2012) studied one facet of the gender gap by looking at earnings in the first year after college in the United States.']
['What did it find?', 'Just comparing the earnings of women to men, women earn about 82 cents for every dollar a man earns in their first year out of college.']

['Why did it find that?', 'However, some of this difference can be explained by education, career, and life choices, such as choosing majors with lower earning potential or specific jobs within a field that have less responsibility.']

['What was the most important finding of the study?', 'When these factors were corrected the study found an unexplained seven-cents-on-the-dollar gap in the first year after college that can be attributed to gender discrimination in pay.']
['What is the name of the approach to analysis of the gender pay gap?', 'This approach to analysis of the gender pay gap, called the human capital model, has been criticized.']
["What are the critics' views on the topic?", 'Lips (2013) argues that the education, career, and life choices can, in fact, be constrained by necessities imposed by gender discrimination.']
['What did Lips say?', 'This suggests that removing these factors entirely from the gender gap equation leads to an estimate of the size of the pay gap that is too small.']
['What does the act of 1964 make it illegal to do?', 'Act of 1964 makes it illegal to treat individuals unfavorably because of their race or color of their skin:']

['What is the purpose of this passage?', 'An employer cannot discriminate based on skin color, hair texture, or other immutable characteristics, which are traits of an individual that are fundamental to their identity, in hiring, benefits, promotions, or termination of employees.']
['What is the most important part of this passage?', 'The Pregnancy Discrimination']

['What is Act of 1978?', 'Act of 1978 amends the Civil Rights Act; it prohibits job (e.g., employment, pay, and termination) discrimination of a woman because she is pregnant as long as she can perform the work required.']
['What is the Supreme Court ruling in Griggs v. Duke Power Co.?', 'The Supreme Court ruling in Griggs v. Duke Power Co. made it illegal under Title VII of the Civil Rights']

['Are there any other important aspects of this Supreme Court ruling?', 'Act to include educational requirements in a job description (e.g., high school diploma) that negatively impacts one race over another if the requirement cannot be shown to be directly related to job performance.']
['Did anyone file a lawsuit regarding the ruling?', 'The EEOC (2014) received more than 94,000 charges of various kinds of employment discrimination in 2013.']
['What is the lawsuit based on?', 'Many of the filings are for multiple forms of discrimination and include charges of retaliation for making a claim, which itself is illegal.']

['What is the most important thing to remember about the passage?', 'Only a small fraction of these claims become suits filed in a federal court, although the suits may represent the claims of more than one person.']
['How many suits were filed in federal courts in 2013?', 'In 2013, there were 148 suits filed in federal courts.']

['What does this document describe?', 'Based on a 2020 Supreme Court ruling regarding the application of the Civil Rights Act, federal legislation now protects employees in the private sector from discrimination related to sexual orientation and gender identity.']
['What groups does the law protect?', 'These groups include lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender individuals.']

['Do surveys of workers, studies of complaint filings, wage comparison studies, and controlled job-interview studies provide evidence of discrimination?', 'There is evidence of discrimination derived from surveys of workers, studies of complaint filings, wage comparison studies, and controlled job-interview studies (Badgett, Sears, Lau, & Ho, 2009).']

['Does the document discuss other legal matters that related to discrimination?', 'Prior to the ruling, federal legislation protected federal employees from such discrimination; the District of Columbia and 20 states have laws protecting public and private employees from discrimination for sexual orientation (American Civil Liberties Union, n.d).']
['What does the document say about discrimination?', 'Most of the states with these laws also protect against discrimination based on gender identity.']
['What is gender identity?', 'Gender identity refers to one’s sense of being male, female, neither of these, both of these, or another gender.']
['What is a good resource we can refer to?', "While the Supreme Court's Civil Rights"]

['What is another great resource we can refer to?', 'Act interpretation is regarded as a landmark outcome for LGBTQ people, it will be continually tested by organizations that for various reasons see a need to exclude LGBTQ people from employment or service.']

['What can we learn from the Supreme Court?', 'The First Amendment protects religious organizations from some aspects of anti-discrimination laws, and some recent court decisions have expanded these exceptions so that certain ministries, schools, or other organizations could avoid employing or serving LGBTQ people.']
['What does the ADA of 1990 state?', 'The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990 states people may not be discriminated against due to the nature of their disability.']

['What is a physical or mental impairment that limits one or more major life activities?', 'A disability is defined as a physical or mental impairment that limits one or more major life activities such as hearing, walking, and breathing.']
['What about an employer?', 'An employer must make reasonable accommodations for the performance of the job of an employee with disabilities.']

['What are some examples of reasonable accommodations?', 'This might include making the work facility accessible with ramps, providing readers for blind personnel, or allowing for more frequent breaks.']
['What has the ADA expanded to include?', 'The ADA has now been expanded to include individuals with alcoholism, former drug use, obesity, or psychiatric disabilities.']

['What is the premise of the law?', "The premise of the law is that individuals with disabilities can contribute to an organization and they cannot be discriminated against because of their disabilities (O'Keefe & Bruyere, 1994)."]
['What other topic would you like to review before we get started?', 'The Civil Rights Act and the Age Discrimination in Employment']

['What is the Age Discrimination in Employment?', 'Act make provisions for bona fide occupational qualifications (BFOQs), which are requirements of certain occupations for which denying an individual employment would otherwise violate the law.']
['What are some examples of bona fide occupational qualifications?', 'For example, there may be cases in which religion, national origin, age, and sex are bona fide occupational qualifications.']

['Are there any specific exceptions for race?', 'There are no BFOQ exceptions that apply to race, although the first amendment protects artistic expressions, such as films, in making race a requirement of a role.']

['How about religion?', 'Clearcut examples of BFOQs would be hiring someone of a specific religion for a leadership position in a worship facility, or for an executive position in religiously affiliated institutions, such as the president of a university with religious ties.']
['What is the age discrimination?', 'Age has been determined to be a BFOQ for airline pilots; hence, there are mandatory retirement ages for safety reasons.']
['What about sex?', 'Sex has been determined as a BFOQ for guards in male prisons.']

['What is the most common reason for invoking a BFOQ as a defense against accusing an employer of discrimination?', 'Sex or gender is the most common reason for invoking a BFOQ as a defense against accusing an employer of discrimination (Manley, 2009).']
['What is the test for sex-related BFOQs?', 'Courts have established a three-part test for sex-related BFOQs that are often used in other types of legal cases for determining whether a BFOQ exists.']
['What are the parts of a job?', 'The first of these is whether all or substantially all women would be unable to perform a job.']

['What are some examples of physical limitations that fail as reasons to discriminate?', 'This is the reason most physical limitations, such as “able to lift 30 pounds,” fail as reasons to discriminate because most women are able to lift this weight.']
['What is the second test about?', 'The second test is the “essence of the business” test, in which having to choose the other gender would undermine the essence of the business operation.']
['What is the third test about?', 'This test was the reason the now defunct Pan American World Airways (i.e., Pan Am) was told it could not hire only women flight attendants.']
['What would have happened if they hired men?', 'Hiring men would not have undermined the essense of this business.']
['What is another aspect of the article?', 'On a deeper level, this means that hiring cannot be made purely on customers’ or others’ preferences.']

['What is another aspect of this test?', 'The third and final test is whether the employer cannot make reasonable alternative accommodations, such as reassigning staff so that a woman does not have to work in a men-only part of a jail or other gender-specific facility.']

['What are some reasons why discrimination based on gender is upheld by the courts?', 'Privacy concerns are a major reason why discrimination based on gender is upheld by the courts, for example in situations such as hires for nursing or custodial staff (Manley, 2009).']
['What is the biggest part of the article?', 'Most cases of BFOQs are decided on a case-by-case basis and these court decisions inform policy and future case decisions.']

['What is the second major branch of study and practice within the discipline of industrial and organizational psychology?', 'Organizational psychology is the second major branch of study and practice within the discipline of industrial and organizational psychology.']
['What is the focus of organizational psychology?', 'In organizational psychology, the focus is on social interactions and their effect on the individual and on the functioning of the organization.']

['What was the research that you did?', 'In this section, you will learn about the work organizational psychologists have done to understand job satisfaction, different styles of management, different styles of leadership, organizational culture, and teamwork.']
['What are the different aspects of job satisfaction?', 'Some people love their jobs, some people tolerate their jobs, and some people cannot stand their jobs.']
['What is the meaning of job satisfaction?', 'Job satisfaction describes the degree to which individuals enjoy their job.']
['What is the main idea of this text?', 'It was described by Edwin Locke (1976) as the state of feeling resulting from appraising one’s job experiences.']

['How is this viewed?', 'While job satisfaction results from both how we think about our work (our cognition) and how we feel about our work (our affect) (Saari & Judge, 2004), it is described in terms of affect.']
['What can this affect?', 'Job satisfaction is impacted by the work itself, our personality, and the culture we come from and live in (Saari & Judge, 2004).']
['When is it typically measured?', 'Job satisfaction is typically measured after a change in an organization, such as a shift in the management model, to assess how the change affects employees.']
['Why is it measured?', 'It may also be routinely measured by an organization to assess one of many factors expected to affect the organization’s performance.']

['What else is the topic of this passage?', 'In addition, polling companies like Gallup regularly measure job satisfaction on a national scale to gather broad information on the state of the economy and the workforce (Saad, 2012).']
['How is job satisfaction measured?', 'Job satisfaction is measured using questionnaires that employees complete.']

['What is the Likert scale?', 'Sometimes a single question might be asked in a very straightforward way to which employees respond using a rating scale, such as a Likert scale, which was discussed in the chapter on personality.']

['What do these answers indicate?', 'A Likert scale (typically) provides five possible answers to a statement or question that allows respondents to indicate their positive-to-negative strength of agreement or strength of feeling regarding the question or statement.']

['How is this used?', 'Thus the possible responses to a question such as “How satisfied are you with your job today?” might be “Very satisfied,” “Somewhat satisfied,” “Neither satisfied, nor dissatisfied,” “Somewhat dissatisfied,” and “Very dissatisfied.”']

['How do you go beyond the Likert scale?', 'More commonly the survey will ask a number of questions about the employee’s satisfaction to determine more precisely why they are satisfied or dissatisfied.']
['What type of surveys are these?', 'Sometimes these surveys are created for specific jobs; at other times, they are designed to apply to any job.']

['What are some ways to measure job satisfaction?', 'Job satisfaction can be measured at a global level, meaning how satisfied in general the employee is with work, or at the level of specific factors intended to measure which aspects of the job lead to satisfaction (Table 13.2).']

['What is the strongest factor of job satisfaction?', 'Research has suggested that the work-content factor, which includes variety, difficulty level, and role clarity of the job, is the most strongly predictive factor of overall job satisfaction (Saari & Judge, 2004).']

['What is the correlation between pay level and job satisfaction?', 'In contrast, there is only a weak correlation between pay level and job satisfaction (Judge, Piccolo, Podsakoff, Shaw, & Rich, 2010).']
['Does this correlate with the Judge et al study?', 'Judge et al. (2010) suggest that individuals adjust or adapt to higher pay levels:']
['What happens when pay level increases?', 'Higher pay no longer provides the satisfaction the individual may have initially felt when their salary increased.']

['Why is that important?', 'Measures of job satisfaction are somewhat correlated with job performance; in particular, they appear to relate to organizational citizenship or discretionary behaviors on the part of an employee that further the goals of the organization (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']

['Can you tell me some other interesting aspects of the article?', 'Job satisfaction is related to general life satisfaction, although there has been limited research on how the two influence each other or whether personality and cultural factors affect both job and general life satisfaction.']

['Does it make any sense that job satisfaction has an impact on life satisfaction?', 'One carefully controlled study suggested that the relationship is reciprocal: Job satisfaction affects life satisfaction positively, and vice versa (Judge & Watanabe, 1993).']
['Can you elaborate on this?', 'Of course, organizations cannot control life satisfaction’s influence on job satisfaction.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects about this passage?', 'Job satisfaction, specifically low job satisfaction, is also related to withdrawal behaviors, such as leaving a job or absenteeism (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']
['Are there studies about that?', 'The relationship with turnover itself, however, is weak (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']

['Why is this important?', 'Finally, it appears that job satisfaction is related to organizational performance, which suggests that implementing organizational changes to improve employee job satisfaction will improve organizational performance (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']
['What are the two elements that are important for job satisfaction?', 'There is opportunity for more research in the area of job satisfaction.']

['What are the problems with the concept of job satisfaction measurements?', 'For example, Weiss (2002) suggests that the concept of job satisfaction measurements have combined both emotional and cognitive concepts, and measurements would be more reliable and show better relationships with outcomes like performance if the measurement of job satisfaction separated these two possible elements of job satisfaction.']
['What is the best part of this title?', 'Job stress affects job satisfaction.']
['What is the cause of job stress?', 'Job stress, or job strain, is caused by specific stressors in an occupation.']
['What is the meaning of stress?', 'Stress can be an ambiguous term as it is used in common language.']

['What is the perception and response of an individual to events judged as overwhelming or threatening to the individual’s well-being?', 'Stress is the perception and response of an individual to events judged as overwhelming or threatening to the individual’s well-being (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005).']
['What is the stressor?', 'The events themselves are the stressors.']

['What is an example of a stressor?', 'Stress is a result of an employee’s perception that the demands placed on them exceed their ability to meet them (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005), such as having to fill multiple roles in a job or life in general, workplace role ambiguity, lack of career progress, lack of job security, lack of control over work outcomes, isolation, work overload, discrimination, harassment, and bullying (Colligan & Higgins, 2005).']
['What can you tell me about gender?', 'The stressors are different for women than men and these differences are a significant area of research (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005).']
['What is the result of job stress?', 'Job stress leads to poor employee health, job performance, and family life (Colligan & Higgins, 2005).']
['Are there any specific points we have to learn about?', 'As already mentioned, job insecurity contributes significantly to job stress.']
['Are there any other points related to job stress that we need to know?', 'Two increasing threats to job security are downsizing events and corporate mergers.']
['What other topics should we be studying?', 'Businesses typically involve I-O psychologists in planning for, implementing, and managing these types of organizational change.']

['What is the result of downsizing?', 'Downsizing is an increasingly common response to a business’s pronounced failure to achieve profit goals, and it involves laying off a significant percentage of the company’s employees.']

['What are some aspects of downsizing?', 'Industrial-organizational psychologists may be involved in all aspects of downsizing: how the news is delivered to employees (both those being let go and those staying), how laid-off employees are supported (e.g., separation packages), and how retained employees are supported.']

['What are the other aspects of downsizing?', 'The latter is important for the organization because downsizing events affect the retained employee’s intent to quit, organizational commitment, and job insecurity (Ugboro, 2006).']

['What are the two reasons organizations grow larger?', 'In addition to downsizing as a way of responding to outside strains on a business, corporations often grow larger by combining with other businesses.']

['What is an acquisition?', 'This can be accomplished through a merger (i.e., the joining of two organizations of equal power and status) or an acquisition (i.e., one organization purchases the other).']
['What is the purchasing organization?', 'In an acquisition, the purchasing organization is usually the more powerful or dominant partner.']
['What other factors come into play in mergers?', 'In both cases, there is usually a duplication of services between the two companies, such as two accounting departments and two sales forces.']
['What are some other important aspects about mergers?', 'Both departments must be merged, which commonly involves a reduction of staff (Figure 13.14).']
['What happens when there are only a few employees in each department?', 'This leads to organizational processes and stresses similar to those that occur in downsizing events.']

['What are some ways to minimize the stress of a merger?', 'Mergers require determining how the organizational culture will change, to which employees also must adjust (van Knippenberg, van Knippenberg, Monden, & de Lima, 2002).']

['What are some other important aspects of mergers?', 'There can be additional stress on workers as they lose their connection to the old organization and try to make connections with the new combined group (Amiot, Terry, Jimmieson, & Callan, 2006).']
['What is the purpose of a research paper?', 'Research in this area focuses on understanding employee reactions and making practical recommendations for managing these organizational changes.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Many people juggle the demands of work life with the demands of their home life, whether it be caring for children or taking care of an elderly parent; this is known as work-family balance.']

['What are some other things we should know about the content?', 'We might commonly think about work interfering with family, but it is also the case that family responsibilities may conflict with work obligations (Carlson, Kacmar, & Williams, 2000).']
['What does the literature say about conflicts between work and family?', 'Greenhaus and Beutell (1985) first identified three sources of work–family conflicts:']

['What does it cover?', 'Women often have greater responsibility for family demands, including home care, child care, and caring for aging parents, yet men in the United States are increasingly assuming a greater share of domestic responsibilities.']
['What else did this cover?', 'However, research has documented that women report greater levels of stress from work–family conflict (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005).']
['What is the content about?', 'There are many ways to decrease work–family conflict and improve people’s job satisfaction (Posig & Kickul, 2004).']
['What are these ways?', 'These include support in the home, which can take various forms: emotional (listening), practical (help with chores).']
['What can workplace support do?', 'Workplace support can include understanding supervisors, flextime, leave with pay, and telecommuting.']

['What are some benefits of this?', 'Flextime usually involves a requirement of core hours spent in the workplace around which the employee may schedule their arrival and departure from work to meet family demands.']

['What are some examples of telecommuting?', 'Telecommuting involves employees working at home and setting their own hours, which allows them to work during different parts of the day, and to spend part of the day with their family; this may also be known as ecommuting, working remotely, flexible workspace, or simply working from home.']
['Do many people telecommute?', 'Recall that Yahoo! had a policy of allowing employees to telecommute and then rescinded the policy.']
['What are other ways to support family?', 'There are also organizations that have onsite daycare centers, and some companies even have onsite fitness centers and health clinics.']

['What are some studies about support?', 'In a study of the effectiveness of different coping methods, Lapierre & Allen (2006) found practical support from home more important than emotional support.']

['What did this study find?', 'They also found that immediate-supervisor support for a worker significantly reduced work–family conflict through such mechanisms as allowing an employee the flexibility needed to fulfill family obligations.']

['Did they find anything else important?', 'In contrast, flextime did not help with coping and telecommuting actually made things worse, perhaps reflecting the fact that being at home intensifies the conflict between work and family because with the employee in the home, the demands of family are more evident.']
['What is the study material?', 'Posig & Kickul (2004) identify exemplar corporations with policies designed to reduce work–family conflict.']

['What were some examples of benefits that companies offered to their employees?', 'Examples include IBM’s policy of three years of job-guaranteed leave after the birth of a child, Lucent Technologies offer of one year’s childbirth leave at half pay, and SC Johnson’s program of concierge services for daytime errands.']
['What is the most important thing to know about I-O research?', 'A significant portion of I-O research focuses on management and human relations.']

['Who wrote the research that is significant?', 'Douglas McGregor (1960) combined scientific management (a theory of management that analyzes and synthesizes workflows with the main objective of improving economic efficiency, especially labor productivity) and human relations into the notion of leadership behavior.']
['What was his theory about the world?', 'His theory lays out two different styles called Theory X and Theory Y.']
['What did he think of the employees?', 'In the Theory X approach to management, managers assume that most people dislike work and are not innately self-directed.']
['did the supervisors think they hated their jobs?', 'Theory X managers perceive employees as people who prefer to be led and told which tasks to perform and when.']
['What did the supervisors think?', 'Their employees have to be watched carefully to be sure that they work hard enough to fulfill the organization’s goals.']
['What did Theory X workplaces do to punish tardiness?', 'Theory X workplaces will often have employees punch a clock when arriving and leaving the workplace: Tardiness is punished.']

['What else would be required for an employee to stay late?', 'Supervisors, not employees, determine whether an employee needs to stay late, and even this decision would require someone higher up in the command chain to approve the extra hours.']
['How did supervisors treat their workers?', 'Theory X supervisors will ignore employees’ suggestions for improved efficiency and reprimand employees for speaking out of order.']
['Did this harm productivity?', 'These supervisors blame efficiency failures on individual employees rather than the systems or policies in place.']
["What did they do if this didn't work?", 'Managerial goals are achieved through a system of punishments and threats rather than enticements and rewards.']

['How else did managers treat the employees?', 'Managers are suspicious of employees’ motivations and always suspect selfish motivations for their behavior at work (e.g., being paid is their sole motivation for working).']
['What can you tell me about Theory X and Theory Y?', 'In the Theory Y approach, on the other hand, managers assume that most people seek inner satisfaction and fulfillment from their work.']

['What can you tell me about how people function better?', 'Employees function better under leadership that allows them to participate in, and provide input about, setting their personal and work goals.']

['What can you tell me about the workplace?', 'In Theory Y workplaces, employees participate in decisions about prioritizing tasks; they may belong to teams that, once given a goal, decide themselves how it will be accomplished.']
['What can you tell me about how employees are able to provide input?', 'In such a workplace, employees are able to provide input on matters of efficiency and safety.']

['What is one example of Theory Y in action?', 'One example of Theory Y in action is the policy of Toyota production lines that allows any employee to stop the entire line if a defect or other issue appears, so that the defect can be fixed and its cause remedied (Toyota Motor Manufacturing, 2013).']
['What else can you tell me about Theory Y?', 'A Theory Y workplace will also meaningfully consult employees on any changes to the work process or management system.']
['What else can you tell me about the organization?', 'In addition, the organization will encourage employees to contribute their own ideas.']
['What can you tell me about Theory X?', 'McGregor (1960) characterized Theory X as the traditional method of management used in the United States.']
["What was McGregor's argument?", 'He argued that a Theory Y approach was needed to improve organizational output and the wellbeing of individuals.']
['What can you tell me about Theory Y?', 'Table 13.3 summarizes how these two management approaches differ.']

['What was another management style?', 'Another management style was described by Donald Clifton, who focused his research on how an organization can best use an individual’s strengths, an approach he called strengths-based management.']
['What was one of his findings?', 'He and his colleagues interviewed 8,000 managers and concluded that it is important to focus on a person’s strengths, not their weaknesses.']

['What is one of their findings?', 'A strength is a particular enduring talent possessed by an individual that allows them to provide consistent, near-perfect performance in tasks involving that talent.']
['What was the greatest opportunity for growth?', 'Clifton argued that our strengths provide the greatest opportunity for growth (Buckingham & Clifton, 2001).']
['What is an example of a strength?', 'An example of a strength is public speaking or the ability to plan a successful event.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects about this study?', 'The strengths-based approach is very popular although its effect on organization performance is not well-studied.']

['What was one of their findings?', 'However, Kaiser & Overfield (2011) found that managers often neglected improving their weaknesses and overused their strengths, both of which interfered with performance.']
['What does management have to do with leadership?', 'Leadership is an important element of management.']
['What is the field of study that is studying leadership styles?', 'Leadership styles have been of major interest within I-O research, and researchers have proposed numerous theories of leadership.']

['Who has developed the concepts of transactional leadership versus transformational?', 'Bass (1985) popularized and developed the concepts of transactional leadership versus transformational leadership styles.']

['How does transactional leadership differ from the other styles?', 'In transactional leadership, the focus is on supervision and organizational goals, which are achieved through a system of rewards and punishments (i.e., transactions).']
['How does it prevent change?', 'Transactional leaders maintain the status quo:']
['What are transactional leaders?', 'They are managers.']
['What is unique about transactional leadership?', 'This is in contrast to the transformational leader.']
['What are the four attributes of transformational leadership?', 'People who have transformational leadership possess four attributes to varying degrees:']

['What are these leaders like?', 'They are charismatic (highly liked role models), inspirational (optimistic about goal attainment), intellectually stimulating (encourage critical thinking and problem solving), and considerate (Bass, Avolio, & Atwater, 1996).']

['What is the paper about?', 'As women increasingly take on leadership roles in corporations, questions have arisen as to whether there are differences in leadership styles between men and women (Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen, 2003).']
['What were the gender differences in leadership style?', 'Eagly & Johnson (1990) conducted a meta-analysis to examine gender and leadership style.']

['What did they find?', 'They found, to a slight but significant degree, that women tend to practice an interpersonal style of leadership (i.e., she focuses on the morale and welfare of the employees) and men practice a task-oriented style (i.e., he focuses on accomplishing tasks).']

['What is interesting about the gender differences?', 'However, the differences were less pronounced when one looked only at organizational studies and excluded laboratory experiments or surveys that did not involve actual organizational leaders.']

['What was the most interesting part of the article?', 'Larger gender-related differences were observed when leadership style was categorized as democratic or autocratic, and these differences were consistent across all types of studies.']

['What is the impact of the gender differences?', 'The authors suggest that similarities between genders in leadership styles are attributable to different genders needing to conform to the organization’s culture; additionally, they propose that gender-related differences reflect inherent differences in the strengths each gender brings to bear on leadership practice.']

['What was the other research on gender differences?', 'In another meta-analysis of leadership style, Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen (2003) found that women tended to exhibit the characteristics of transformational leaders, while men were more likely to be transactional leaders.']

['What are the differences between the genders?', 'However, the differences are not absolute; for example, women were found to use methods of reward for performance more often than men, which is a component of transactional leadership.']
['What did they find about gender differences?', 'The differences they found were relatively small.']

['What can you tell me about the gender differences?', 'As Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen (2003) point out, research shows that transformational leadership approaches are more effective than transactional approaches, although individual leaders typically exhibit elements of both approaches.']

['What is the emerging area of research within psychology?', 'A new and emerging area of research within psychology focuses on leadership and the relationship with leaders from the perspective of a follower.']

['What is the followership research?', 'This “followership” research suggests that studies need to examine the leader-follower relationship in both directions—instead of focusing only on leadership—to better understand the dynamics of the relationship.']

['What is the best way to describe the leadership-follower dynamic?', 'Put differently, people are individuals, and because they are different, there probably is no single best leadership-follower dynamic between leaders and followers.']
['What is the difference between a sex and a sexual relationship?', 'For instance, think about the differences between yourself and someone you know well.']
['Why do you think that is?', 'Maybe one of you likes a lot of structure and other seems to work best with less structure.']

['How about different restaurants?', 'Perhaps, one of you is ready to try a new restaurant at any time and the other prefers to go to the tried-and-true place that you’ve visited so many times the servers know your order before you place it.']

['What did you learn about follower types?', 'Some early research has discovered that the characteristics of individual followers will result in different types of relationships with a leader depending on the leadership style.']
['What did you find out about leadership styles?', 'It appears that not all leadership styles work well with all follower types.']
['What are characteristics of followers?', 'One characteristic of followers, for example, is their degree of extroversion.']

['What do people with that degree of extroversion need to interact with?', 'Previous research suggests that individuals with a high degree of extroversion would need a larger amount of interaction with their leaders in order to function well; however, other research suggests this may not necessarily be the case and instead other factors may be at work (Phillips & Bedeian; Bauer et al, 2006).']
["What's an example of a question that you have to ask?", 'Another characteristic of followers is their individual need for growth.']

['What is the reason for their individual need?', 'For followers who have a strong desire to learn and grow within their organization, a leader who provides developmental opportunities might be better received than one who does not.']

['What is the result of a leader pushing them to grow?', 'In addition, for those followers who are low on growth and need strength, leaders who push them to grow may make them less satisfied followers as they feel forced into further development and training, possibly signaling a lower level of achievement from their supervisor.']

['What are some ways to improve the relationship between followers and leaders?', 'Training for leaders in both helping employees who have a strong drive for growth and those who do not appears to be helpful in improving the relationship between both types of followers and their leaders (Schyns, Kroon, & Moors, 2008).']
['What can you tell me about the leader-follower relationship?', 'Finally, an employee’s need for leadership is an important component of the leader-follower relationship.']

['What else is significant about this?', 'Some individuals are significantly more autonomous than others and as a result do not respond as well to leaders who provide a lot of structure and rigidity of processes, in turn reducing the quality of their relationship with their leader.']

['What other important things can you tell me about the relationship?', 'Other employees who are high in need for leadership have a better relationship with their leader if they are provided with a well-structured environment with clear responsibilities and little ambiguity in their work.']

['How can you describe the relationship between leaders and followers?', 'These followers work best in situations where they feel they can comfortably perform the work with little requirement to think outside of the guidelines that have been provided.']

['Can you describe the strong positive relationship?', 'For these individuals, having a leader who is able to set a clear path forward for the employee with little need for deviation promotes a strong positive leader-follower relationship (Felfe & Schyns, 2006).']

['What is the workplace changing today?', 'The workplace today is rapidly changing due to a variety of factors, such as shifts in technology, economics, foreign competition, globalization, and workplace demographics.']
['What do organizations need to do to adapt to changes in these factors?', 'Organizations need to respond quickly to changes in these factors.']

['What can companies do to respond quickly?', 'Many companies are responding to these changes by structuring their organizations so that work can be delegated to work teams, which bring together diverse skills, experience, and expertise.']

['What is the contrast to organizational structures that have individuals at their base?', 'This is in contrast to organizational structures that have individuals at their base (Naquin & Tynan, 2003).']
['What are the team structures?', 'In the team-based approach, teams are brought together and given a specific task or goal to accomplish.']

['What is the most interesting part of this article?', 'Despite their burgeoning popularity, team structures do not always deliver greater productivity—the work of teams is an active area of research (Naquin & Tynan, 2003).']
['Did you learn anything that would be helpful to you during the lecture?', 'There are many contributing factors.']
['Are there any examples of how this works?', 'For example, teams can mask team members that are not working (i.e., social loafing).']

['How can teams be inefficient?', 'Teams can be inefficient due to poor communication; they can have poor decision-making skills due to conformity effects; and, they can have conflict within the group.']
['How do these factors affect the popularity of teams?', 'The popularity of teams may in part result from the team halo effect:']
['How does this effect work?', 'Teams are given credit for their successes.']
['How do individuals get blamed for team failures?', 'but individuals within a team are blamed for team failures (Naquin & Tynan, 2003).']
['What is one aspect of team diversity?', 'One aspect of team diversity is their gender mix.']
['Are there other aspects of team diversity?', 'Researchers have explored whether gender mix has an effect on team performance.']

['What are some other aspects of team diversity?', 'On the one hand, diversity can introduce communication and interpersonal-relationship problems that hinder performance, but on the other hand diversity can also increase the team’s skill set, which may include skills that can actually improve team member interactions.']

['What are some studies about team diversity?', 'Hoogendoorn, Oosterbeek, & van Praag (2013) studied project teams in a university business school in which the gender mix of the teams was manipulated.']
['What did they find?', 'They found that gender-balanced teams performed better, as measured by sales and profits, than teams made up mostly by men.']
['Does gender diversity have an effect on the team?', 'The study did not have enough data to determine the relative performance of teams with more women than men.']
['What did they find?', 'The study was unsuccessful in identifying which mechanism (interpersonal relationships, learning, or skills mixes) accounted for performance improvement.']
['What are the three basic types of teams?', 'There are three basic types of teams: problem resolution teams, creative teams, and tactical teams.']

['What is the purpose of problem resolution teams?', 'Problem resolution teams are created for the purpose of solving a particular problem or issue; for example, the diagnostic teams at the Centers for Disease Control.']
['What is the purpose of creative teams?', 'Creative teams are used to develop innovative possibilities or solutions; for example, design teams for car manufacturers create new vehicle models.']
['What are tactical teams used for?', 'Tactical teams are used to execute a well-defined plan or objective, such as a police or FBI SWAT team handling a hostage situation (Larson & LaFasto, 1989).']

['what is virtual teams?', 'One area of active research involves a fourth kind of team—the virtual team; these studies examine how groups of geographically disparate people brought together using digital communications technology function (Powell, Piccoli, & Ives, 2004).']

['what is the reason for virtual teams becoming more popular?', 'Even before the COVID-19 pandemic, virtual teams were more common due to the growing globalization of organizations and the use of consulting and partnerships facilitated by digital communication.']
["What is the first topic I'll be asking you about?", 'Each company and organization has an organizational culture.']
['What is an organizational culture?', 'Organizational culture encompasses the values, visions, hierarchies, norms, and interactions among its employees.']
['What does it encompass?', 'It is how an organization is run, how it operates, and how it makes decisions—the industry in which the organization participates may have an influence.']
['How can it change?', 'Different departments within one company can develop their own subculture within the organization’s culture.']

['What are the three layers in organizational culture?', 'Ostroff, Kinicki, and Tamkins (2003) identify three layers in organizational culture: observable artifacts, espoused values, and basic assumptions.']

['What are the symbols, language (jargon, slang, and humor), narratives (stories and legends), and practices (rituals) that represent the underlying cultural assumptions?', 'Observable artifacts are the symbols, language (jargon, slang, and humor), narratives (stories and legends), and practices (rituals) that represent the underlying cultural assumptions.']
['What are concepts or beliefs that the management or the entire organization endorses?', 'Espoused values are concepts or beliefs that the management or the entire organization endorses.']
['What are norms?', 'They are the rules that allow employees to know which actions they should take in different situations and which information they should adhere to.']
['What are basic assumptions?', 'These basic assumptions generally are unobservable and unquestioned.']
['Are there any other important aspects to this article?', 'Researchers have developed survey instruments to measure organizational culture.']

['What are the main points of the passage?', 'With the workforce being a global marketplace, your company may have a supplier in Korea and another in Honduras and have employees in the United States, China, and South Africa.']
['What else did you learn about the workplace?', 'You may have coworkers of different religious, ethnic, or racial backgrounds than yourself.']
['What else can you do to make your workplace more interesting?', 'Your coworkers may be from different places around the globe.']
['What else did you learn about diversity?', 'Many workplaces offer diversity training to help everyone involved bridge and understand cultural differences.']
['What is diversity training?', 'Diversity training educates participants about cultural differences with the goal of improving teamwork.']

['What is the evidence that simply working together, particularly if the conditions of work are set carefully that such prejudice can be reduced or eliminated?', 'There is always the potential for prejudice between members of two groups, but the evidence suggests that simply working together, particularly if the conditions of work are set carefully that such prejudice can be reduced or eliminated.']
['What does this study say?', 'Pettigrew and Tropp (2006) conducted a meta-analysis to examine the question of whether contact between groups reduced prejudice between those groups.']
['What did this study find?', 'They found that there was a moderate but significant effect.']

['What else did this study find?', 'They also found that, as previously theorized, the effect was enhanced when the two groups met under conditions in which they have equal standing, common goals, cooperation between the groups, and especially support on the part of the institution or authorities for the contact.']

['What are some of the recognized negative aspects of organizational culture?', 'One well-recognized negative aspect of organizational culture is a culture of harassment, including sexual harassment.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects of this study?', 'Most organizations of any size have developed sexual harassment policies that define sexual harassment (or harassment in general) and the procedures the organization has set in place to prevent and address it when it does occur.']

['What did you learn about the company’s sexual harassment policy and procedures?', 'Thus, in most jobs you have held, you were probably made aware of the company’s sexual harassment policy and procedures, and may have received training related to the policy.']
['What does the equal employment opportunity commission define?', 'The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (n.d.) provides the following description of sexual harassment:']
['What is quid pro quo?', 'One form of sexual harassment is called quid pro quo.']
['What does quid pro quo mean?', 'Quid pro quo means you give something to get something, and it refers to a situation in which organizational rewards are offered in exchange for sexual favors.']
['Who does it involve?', 'Quid pro quo harassment is often between an employee and a person with greater power in the organization.']

['What other examples of quid pro quo are there?', 'For example, a supervisor might request an action, such as a kiss or a touch, in exchange for a promotion, a positive performance review, or a pay raise.']
['What other examples of quid pro quo are there?', 'Another form of sexual harassment is the threat of withholding a reward if a sexual request is refused.']
['What is hostile environment sexual harassment?', 'Hostile environment sexual harassment is another type of workplace harassment.']
['What is a hostile environment?', 'In this situation, an employee experiences conditions in the workplace that are considered hostile or intimidating.']
['What are some examples of hostile environment?', 'For example, a work environment that allows offensive language or jokes or displays sexually explicit images.']
['What is the difference between harassment and bullying?', 'Isolated occurrences of these events do not constitute harassment, but a pattern of repeated occurrences does.']
['What is the law against?', 'In addition to violating organizational policies against sexual harassment, these forms of harassment are illegal.']
['What is workplace violence?', 'Workplace violence is any act or threat of physical violence, harassment, intimidation, or other threatening, disruptive behavior that occurs at the workplace.']
['What kind of violence is it?', 'It ranges from threats and verbal abuse to physical assaults and even homicide (Occupational Safety & Health Administration, 2014).']
['What are the different targets of workplace violence?', 'There are different targets of workplace violence: a person could commit violence against coworkers, supervisors, or property.']
['What warning signs does it give?', 'Warning signs often precede such actions: intimidating behavior, threats, sabotaging equipment, or radical changes in a coworker’s behavior.']
['What happens if they do that?', 'Often there is intimidation and then escalation that leads to even further escalation.']
['What can happen if it escalates?', 'It is important for employees to involve their immediate supervisor if they ever feel intimidated or unsafe.']
['What was one of the important facts that we read?', 'Murder is the second leading cause of death in the workplace.']
['Are there any other facts about the passage?', 'It is also the primary cause of death for women in the workplace.']
['How many people are physically assaulted every year?', 'Every year there are nearly two million workers who are physically assaulted or threatened with assault.']

['What is the most common way that women are murdered in domestic violence situations?', 'Many are murdered in domestic violence situations by boyfriends or husbands who chose the woman’s workplace to commit their crimes.']
['What are some triggers for workplace violence?', 'There are many triggers for workplace violence.']
['What are some of the significant triggers?', 'A significant trigger is the feeling of being treated unfairly, unjustly, or disrespectfully.']
['What other evidence do you have to support the claims?', 'In a research experiment, Greenberg (1993) examined the reactions of students who were given pay for a task.']
['What was the purpose of the study?', 'In one group, the students were given extensive explanations for the pay rate.']
['What did the second group receive?', 'In the second group, the students were given a curt uninformative explanation.']
['How did the students feel as a result?', 'The students were made to believe the supervisor would not know how much money the student withdrew for payment.']
['Did this change their behavior?', 'The rate of stealing (taking more pay than they were told they deserved) was higher in the group who had been given the limited explanation.']
['What is the significance of this study?', 'This is a demonstration of the importance of procedural justice in organizations.']
['What does procedural justice mean?', 'Procedural justice refers to the fairness of the processes by which outcomes are determined in conflicts with or among employees.']

['What was the study about?', 'In another study by Greenberg & Barling (1999), they found a history of aggression and amount of alcohol consumed to be accurate predictors of workplace violence against a coworker.']
['What else did they find?', 'Aggression against a supervisor was predicted if a worker felt unfairly treated or untrusted.']
['Did they find anything else?', 'Job security and alcohol consumption predicted aggression against a subordinate.']

['What else did they find?', 'To understand and predict workplace violence, Greenberg & Barling (1999) emphasize the importance of considering the employee target of aggression or violence and characteristics of both the workplace characteristics and the aggressive or violent person.']

['What is the third subject area within industrial and organizational psychology?', 'Human factors psychology (or ergonomics, a term that is favored in Europe) is the third subject area within industrial and organizational psychology.']

['What is the main focus of this study?', 'This field is concerned with the integration of the human-machine interface in the workplace, through design, and specifically with researching and designing machines that fit human requirements.']
['What kind of integration do they have?', 'The integration may be physical or cognitive, or a combination of both.']

['Why is this important?', 'Anyone who needs to be convinced that the field is necessary need only try to operate an unfamiliar television remote control or use a new piece of software for the first time.']

['What are some examples of workplace design?', 'Whereas the two other areas of I-O psychology focus on the interface between the worker and team, group, or organization, human factors psychology focuses on the individual worker’s interaction with a machine, work station, information displays, and the local environment, such as lighting.']

['What is the history of this study?', 'In the United States, human factors psychology has origins in both psychology and engineering; this is reflected in the early contributions of Lillian Gilbreth (psychologist and engineer) and her husband Frank Gilbreth (engineer).']

["What can you tell me about the chapter that's just begun?", 'Human factor professionals are involved in design from the beginning of a project, as is more common in software design projects, or toward the end in testing and evaluation, as is more common in traditional industries (Howell, 2003).']
['What is another important role of human factor professionals?', 'Another important role of human factor professionals is in the development of regulations and principles of best design.']
['How do these regulations and principles of best design relate to work safety?', 'These regulations and principles are often related to work safety.']

['What are some examples of regulations and principles related to work safety?', 'For example, the Three Mile Island nuclear accident lead to Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) requirements for additional instrumentation in nuclear facilities to provide operators with more critical information and increased operator training (United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, 2013).']

['What is the American National Standards Institute?', 'The American National Standards Institute (ANSI, 2000), an independent developer of industrial standards, develops many standards related to ergonomic design, such as the design of control-center workstations that are used for transportation control or industrial process control.']
['What is the main concern of human factors psychology?', 'Many of the concerns of human factors psychology are related to workplace safety.']
['What are the concerns of the worker?', 'These concerns can be studied to help prevent work-related injuries of individual workers or those around them.']

['What are some activities that may benefit from safety protocols?', 'Safety protocols may also be related to activities, such as commercial driving or flying, medical procedures, and law enforcement, that have the potential to impact the public.']
['What can you tell me about the checklists?', 'One of the methods used to reduce accidents in the workplace is a checklist.']
['What industry uses checklists?', 'The airline industry is one industry that uses checklists.']

['What do they check before takeoff?', 'Pilots are required to go through a detailed checklist of the different parts of the aircraft before takeoff to ensure that all essential equipment is working correctly.']
['What do astronauts do with checklists?', 'Astronauts also go through checklists before takeoff.']

['What is the name of the checklist?', 'The surgical safety checklist shown in Figure 13.15 was developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) and serves as the basis for many checklists at medical facilities.']
['What does safety concerns also lead to?', 'Safety concerns also lead to limits to how long an operator, such as a pilot or truck driver, is allowed to operate the equipment.']
["What is the FAA's definition of an overnight break?", 'Recently the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) introduced limits for how long a pilot is allowed to fly without an overnight break.']
['What does howell (2003) outline?', 'Howell (2003) outlines some important areas of research and practice in the field of human factors.']
['What are these areas summarized in?', 'These are summarized in Table 13.4.']

['What is an example of research in human factors psychology?', 'As an example of research in human factors psychology Bruno & Abrahão (2012) examined the impact of the volume of operator decisions on the accuracy of decisions made within an information security center at a banking institution in Brazil.']
['What was the total number of decisions made by operators and managers?', 'The study examined a total of about 45,000 decisions made by 35 operators and 4 managers over a period of 60 days.']

['What were some of the conclusions from the study?', 'Their study found that as the number of decisions made per day by the operators climbed, that is, as their cognitive effort increased, the operators made more mistakes in falsely identifying incidents as real security breaches (when, in reality, they were not).']
['What did they find?', 'Interestingly, the opposite mistake of identifying real intrusions as false alarms did not increase with increased cognitive demand.']
["What is the bank's reaction to the false alarms?", 'This appears to be good news for the bank, since false alarms are not as costly as incorrectly rejecting a genuine threat.']

['What kind of work is done in the field?', 'These kinds of studies combine research on attention, perception, teamwork, and human–computer interactions in a field of considerable societal and business significance.']

['What is the context of the events that led to the massive data breach for Target in the fall of 2013?', 'This is exactly the context of the events that led to the massive data breach for Target in the fall of 2013.']

['What led to this?', 'Indications are that security personnel received signals of a security breach but did not interpret them correctly, thus allowing the breach to continue for two weeks until an outside agency, the FBI, informed the company (Riley, Elgin, Lawrence, & Matlack, 2014).']

['When did the term stress begin to be used?', 'The term stress as it relates to the human condition first emerged in scientific literature in the 1930s, but it did not enter the popular vernacular until the 1970s (Lyon, 2012).']

['What was the popular use of this term?', 'Today, we often use the term loosely in describing a variety of unpleasant feeling states; for example, we often say we are stressed out when we feel frustrated, angry, conflicted, overwhelmed, or fatigued.']
['Did the widespread use of this term help to define it?', 'Despite the widespread use of the term, stress is a fairly vague concept that is difficult to define with precision.']
['What is the definition of stress?', 'Researchers have had a difficult time agreeing on an acceptable definition of stress.']

['What is the most common definition of stress?', 'Some have conceptualized stress as a demanding or threatening event or situation (e.g., a high-stress job, overcrowding, and long commutes to work).']
['Are there other conceptualizations?', 'Such conceptualizations are known as stimulus-based definitions because they characterize stress as a stimulus that causes certain reactions.']

['What is the problem with stimulus-based definitions of stress?', 'Stimulus-based definitions of stress are problematic, however, because they fail to recognize that people differ in how they view and react to challenging life events and situations.']

['What does the article say about stress?', 'For example, a conscientious student who has studied diligently all semester would likely experience less stress during final exams week than would a less responsible, unprepared student.']

['What has the definition of stress evolved over time?', 'Others have conceptualized stress in ways that emphasize the physiological responses that occur when faced with demanding or threatening situations (e.g., increased arousal).']

['What conceptualizations have evolved based on more qualitative evaluations of stress?', 'These conceptualizations are referred to as response-based definitions because they describe stress as a response to environmental conditions.']

['What is the response-based definition of stress?', 'For example, the endocrinologist Hans Selye, a famous stress researcher, once defined stress as the “response of the body to any demand, whether it is caused by, or results in, pleasant or unpleasant conditions” (Selye, 1976, p. 74).']

['What is the difference between the two definitions?', 'Selye’s definition of stress is response-based in that it conceptualizes stress chiefly in terms of the body’s physiological reaction to any demand that is placed on it.']
['What are the different definitions of stress?', 'Neither stimulus-based nor response-based definitions provide a complete definition of stress.']

['What other things are important in this article?', 'Many of the physiological reactions that occur when faced with demanding situations (e.g., accelerated heart rate) can also occur in response to things that most people would not consider to be genuinely stressful, such as receiving unanticipated good news: an unexpected promotion or raise.']

['What is a useful way to conceptualize stress?', 'A useful way to conceptualize stress is to view it as a process whereby an individual perceives and responds to events that they appraise as overwhelming or threatening to their well-being (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']

['What is the importance of how we appraise—that is, judge—demanding or threatening events?', 'A critical element of this definition is that it emphasizes the importance of how we appraise—that is, judge—demanding or threatening events (often referred to as stressors); these appraisals, in turn, influence our reactions to such events.']
['What are two kinds of appraisals of a stressor?', 'Two kinds of appraisals of a stressor are especially important in this regard: primary and secondary appraisals.']
['What is a primary appraisal?', 'A primary appraisal involves judgment about the degree of potential harm or threat to well-being that a stressor might entail.']

['What kind of stressor would be appraised as a threat?', 'A stressor would likely be appraised as a threat if one anticipates that it could lead to some kind of harm, loss, or other negative consequence; conversely, a stressor would likely be appraised as a challenge if one believes that it carries the potential for gain or personal growth.']

['What are some examples of a threat?', 'For example, an employee who is promoted to a leadership position would likely perceive the promotion as a much greater threat if they believed the promotion would lead to excessive work demands than if they viewed it as an opportunity to gain new skills and grow professionally.']
['Are there any other examples of change?', 'Similarly, a college student on the cusp of graduation may face the change as a threat or a challenge (Figure 14.2).']

['What is secondary appraisal?', 'The perception of a threat triggers a secondary appraisal: judgment of the options available to cope with a stressor, as well as perceptions of how effective such options will be (Lyon, 2012) (Figure 14.3).']

['What can you tell me about secondary appraisal?', 'As you may recall from what you learned about self-efficacy, an individual’s belief in their ability to complete a task is important (Bandura, 1994).']
['What can a person do in response to a threat?', 'A threat tends to be viewed as less catastrophic if one believes something can be done about it (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']

['What is a possible example of this?', 'Imagine that two middle-aged people, Robin and Madhuri, perform breast self-examinations one morning and each notices a lump on the lower region of their left breast.']
['What was their response to the breast lump?', 'Although both view the breast lump as a potential threat (primary appraisal), their secondary appraisals differ considerably.']
['What is the reason Robin is worried about the breast lump?', 'In considering the breast lump, some of the thoughts racing through Robin’s mind are, “Oh my God, I could have breast cancer!']
['How does that affect you?', 'I’ve heard that experience is awful!']
['What is a possible response to the lump?', 'My partner and I won’t have enough money to pay the mortgage.']
['How does that affect you?', 'Oh, this is just horrible…I can’t deal with it!”']
['What does Robin think?', 'On the other hand, Madhuri thinks, “Hmm, this may not be good.']
['What is the student likely to do next?', 'Although most times these things turn out to be benign, I need to have it checked out.']
['What will she do if she has breast cancer?', 'If it turns out to be breast cancer, there are doctors who can take care of it because the medical technology today is quite advanced.']
['How does that affect her?', 'I’ll have a lot of different options, and I’ll be just fine.”']

['Why is the difference?', 'Clearly, Robin and Madhuri have different outlooks on what might turn out to be a very serious situation: Robin seems to think that little could be done about it, whereas Madhuri believes that, worst case scenario, a number of options that are likely to be effective would be available.']
['What does Robin do?', 'As such, Robin would clearly experience greater stress than would Madhuri.']

['How does this passage apply to Stress?', 'To be sure, some stressors are inherently more stressful than others in that they are more threatening and leave less potential for variation in cognitive appraisals (e.g., objective threats to one’s health or safety).']
['Did this change the way people think about stress?', 'Nevertheless, appraisal will still play a role in augmenting or diminishing our reactions to such events (Everly & Lating, 2002).']
