['What does the chapter cover?', 'If a person appraises an event as harmful and believes that the demands imposed by the event exceed the available resources to manage or adapt to it, the person will subjectively experience a state of stress.']
["How does this impact the person's functioning?", 'In contrast, if one does not appraise the same event as harmful or threatening, she is unlikely to experience stress.']
['What is the definition of stress?', 'According to this definition, environmental events trigger stress reactions by the way they are interpreted and the meanings they are assigned.']
['What is another way to describe stress?', 'In short, stress is largely in the eye of the beholder: it’s not so much what happens to you as it is how you respond (Selye, 1976).']
['What does the article about Good Stress? explain?', 'Although stress carries a negative connotation, at times it may be of some benefit.']

['What can stress do for us?', 'Stress can motivate us to do things in our best interests, such as study for exams, visit the doctor regularly, exercise, and perform to the best of our ability at work.']
['What is the other benefits of stress?', 'Indeed, Selye (1974) pointed out that not all stress is harmful.']
['What is not harmful?', 'He argued that stress can sometimes be a positive, motivating force that can improve the quality of our lives.']
['What is eustress?', 'This kind of stress, which Selye called eustress (from the Greek eu = “good”), is a good kind of stress associated with positive feelings, optimal health, and performance.']
['What kind of stress can be beneficial in challenging situations?', 'A moderate amount of stress can be beneficial in challenging situations.']
['What are the other reasons of good stress?', 'For example, athletes may be motivated and energized by pregame stress, and students may experience similar beneficial stress before a major exam.']
['What can be done to improve our memory by stress?', 'Indeed, research shows that moderate stress can enhance both immediate and delayed recall of educational material.']

['What kinds of studies show that?', 'Participants in one study who memorized a scientific text passage showed improved memory of the passage immediately after exposure to a mild stressor as well as one day following exposure to the stressor (Hupbach & Fieman, 2012).']
['What is the good stress?', 'Increasing one’s level of stress will cause performance to change in a predictable way.']

['How will it affect my performance?', 'As shown in Figure 14.4, as stress increases, so do performance and general well-being (eustress); when stress levels reach an optimal level (the highest point of the curve), performance reaches its peak.']

['What is the good stress?', 'A person at this stress level is colloquially at the top of their game, meaning they feel fully energized, focused, and can work with minimal effort and maximum efficiency.']

['What is the optimal level of stress?', 'But when stress exceeds this optimal level, it is no longer a positive force—it becomes excessive and debilitating, or what Selye termed distress (from the Latin dis = “bad”).']
['What is the effect of too much stress on people?', 'People who reach this level of stress feel burned out; they are fatigued, exhausted, and their performance begins to decline.']
['What else do you want to know about the good stress?', 'If the stress remains excessive, health may begin to erode as well (Everly & Lating, 2002).']
['What is a good example of distress?', 'A good example of distress is severe test anxiety.']

['What will it affect me on a test?', 'When students are feeling very stressed about a test, negative emotions combined with physical symptoms may make concentration difficult, thereby negatively affecting test scores.']
['What is the most important information you could tell me about the study material?', 'Stress is everywhere and, as shown in Figure 14.5, it has been on the rise over the last several years.']
['What are some of the stress symptoms that I can relate to?', 'Each of us is acquainted with stress—some are more familiar than others.']

['What can you tell me about some of the ways stress is experienced?', 'In many ways, stress feels like a load you just can’t carry—a feeling you experience when, for example, you have to drive somewhere in a blizzard, when you wake up late the morning of an important job interview, when you run out of money before the next pay period, and before taking an important exam for which you realize you are not fully prepared.']

['What is an experience that evokes a variety of responses, including those that are physiological (e.g., accelerated heart rate, headaches, or gastrointestinal problems), cognitive (e.g., difficulty concentrating or making decisions), and behavioral (e.g., drinking alcohol, smoking, or taking actions directed at eliminating the cause of the stress)?', 'Stress is an experience that evokes a variety of responses, including those that are physiological (e.g., accelerated heart rate, headaches, or gastrointestinal problems), cognitive (e.g., difficulty concentrating or making decisions), and behavioral (e.g., drinking alcohol, smoking, or taking actions directed at eliminating the cause of the stress).']

['Are the responses harmful or beneficial?', 'Although stress can be positive at times, it can have deleterious health implications, contributing to the onset and progression of a variety of physical illnesses and diseases (Cohen & Herbert, 1996).']

['What is stress?', 'The scientific study of how stress and other psychological factors impact health falls within the realm of health psychology, a subfield of psychology devoted to understanding the importance of psychological influences on health, illness, and how people respond when they become ill (Taylor, 1999).']

['What year did health psychology emerge as a discipline?', 'Health psychology emerged as a discipline in the 1970s, a time during which there was increasing awareness of the role behavioral and lifestyle factors play in the development of illnesses and diseases (Straub, 2007).']

['What are the other important things to know about this topic?', 'In addition to studying the connection between stress and illness, health psychologists investigate issues such as why people make certain lifestyle choices (e.g., smoking or eating unhealthy food despite knowing the potential adverse health implications of such behaviors).']
['What do health psychologists do to change their lifestyles?', 'Health psychologists also design and investigate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at changing unhealthy behaviors.']

['Are there any other significant findings in this study?', 'Perhaps one of the more fundamental tasks of health psychologists is to identify which groups of people are especially at risk for negative health outcomes, based on psychological or behavioral factors.']

['What can be done to identify populations who may have an increased risk for illness or disease?', 'For example, measuring differences in stress levels among demographic groups and how these levels change over time can help identify populations who may have an increased risk for illness or disease.']

['What are some of the most important parts of this study material?', 'Figure 14.6 depicts the results of three national surveys in which several thousand individuals from different demographic groups completed a brief stress questionnaire; the surveys were administered in 1983, 2006, and 2009 (Cohen & Janicki-Deverts, 2012).']
['What do the three surveys show?', 'All three surveys demonstrated higher stress in women than in men.']

['What other groups were found to have higher stress?', 'Unemployed individuals reported high levels of stress in all three surveys, as did those with less education and income; retired persons reported the lowest stress levels.']
['What else was noted?', 'However, from 2006 to 2009 the greatest increase in stress levels occurred among men, Hispanic people aged 45–64, college graduates, and those with full-time employment.']

['What was the most common cause of stress?', 'One interpretation of these findings is that concerns surrounding the 2008–2009 economic downturn (e.g., threat of or actual job loss and substantial loss of retirement savings) may have been especially stressful to college-educated employed men with limited time remaining in their working careers.']
['What is the key point of the document?', 'As previously stated, scientific interest in stress goes back nearly a century.']

['Who was the early contributor to the study of stress?', 'One of the early pioneers in the study of stress was Walter Cannon, an eminent American physiologist at Harvard Medical School (Figure 14.7).']
['What was his role in the early study of stress?', 'In the early part of the 20th century, Cannon was the first to identify the body’s physiological reactions to stress.']
['What should you be doing at this time?', 'Imagine that you are hiking in the beautiful mountains of Colorado on a warm and sunny spring day.']
['What is the threat?', 'At one point during your hike, a large, frightening-looking black bear appears from behind a stand of trees and sits about 50 yards from you.']
['What happens when the bear notices you?', 'The bear notices you, sits up, and begins to lumber in your direction.']
['What is the cause of a panic attack?', 'In addition to thinking, “This is definitely not good,” a constellation of physiological reactions begins to take place inside you.']
['What are the physiological reactions to adrenaline?', 'Prompted by a deluge of epinephrine (adrenaline) and norepinephrine (noradrenaline) from your adrenal glands, your pupils begin to dilate.']

['What happens when you are in a fight or flight situation?', 'Your heart starts to pound and speeds up, you begin to breathe heavily and perspire, you get butterflies in your stomach, and your muscles become tense, preparing you to take some kind of direct action.']

['Does it make any sense that this is your fight-or-flight response?', 'Cannon proposed that this reaction, which he called the fight-or-flight response, occurs when a person experiences very strong emotions—especially those associated with a perceived threat (Cannon, 1932).']

['What are the other physiological reactions?', 'During the fight-or-flight response, the body is rapidly aroused by activation of both the sympathetic nervous system and the endocrine system (Figure 14.8).']
['What does the arousal do?', 'This arousal helps prepare the person to either fight or flee from a perceived threat.']

['What is the Fight-or-Flight response?', 'According to Cannon, the fight-or-flight response is a built-in mechanism that assists in maintaining homeostasis—an internal environment in which physiological variables such as blood pressure, respiration, digestion, and temperature are stabilized at levels optimal for survival.']

['What are the benefits of it?', 'Thus, Cannon viewed the fight-or-flight response as adaptive because it enables people to adjust internally and externally to threats in their environment, allowing them to continue to be alive and overcome the threat.']
['who is Hans Selye?', 'Another important early contributor to the stress field was Hans Selye, mentioned earlier.']
['What was significant about Selye?', 'He would eventually become one of the world’s foremost experts in the study of stress (Figure 14.9).']
['What did Selye do?', 'As a young assistant in the biochemistry department at McGill University in the 1930s, Selye was engaged in research involving sex hormones in rats.']

['what happened in his study?', 'Although he was unable to find an answer for what he was initially researching, he incidentally discovered that when exposed to prolonged negative stimulation (stressors)—such as extreme cold, surgical injury, excessive muscular exercise, and shock—the rats showed signs of adrenal enlargement, thymus and lymph node shrinkage, and stomach ulceration.']

['What did Selye realize about the responses?', 'Selye realized that these responses were triggered by a coordinated series of physiological reactions that unfold over time during continued exposure to a stressor.']
['what is the pattern?', 'These physiological reactions were nonspecific, which means that regardless of the type of stressor, the same pattern of reactions would occur.']
['what is this all about?', 'What Selye discovered was the general adaptation syndrome, the body’s nonspecific physiological response to stress.']

['What are the three stages of the general adaptation syndrome?', 'The general adaptation syndrome, shown in Figure 14.10, consists of three stages: (1) alarm reaction, (2) stage of resistance, and (3) stage of exhaustion (Selye, 1936; 1976).']

['What is the body’s immediate reaction upon facing a threatening situation or emergency?', 'Alarm reaction describes the body’s immediate reaction upon facing a threatening situation or emergency, and it is roughly analogous to the fight-or-flight response described by Cannon.']

['What happens during alarm reaction?', 'During an alarm reaction, you are alerted to a stressor, and your body alarms you with a cascade of physiological reactions that provide you with the energy to manage the situation.']
['What is an example of alarm reaction?', 'A person who wakes up in the middle of the night to discover her house is on fire, for example, is experiencing an alarm reaction.']
['What can you tell me about resistance?', 'If exposure to a stressor is prolonged, the organism will enter the stage of resistance.']
['What is the response to the alarm?', 'During this stage, the initial shock of alarm reaction has worn off and the body has adapted to the stressor.']
['Does the body still respond to that stressor?', 'Nevertheless, the body also remains on alert and is prepared to respond as it did during the alarm reaction, although with less intensity.']
['What can you explain resistance?', 'For example, suppose a child who went missing is still missing 72 hours later.']

['How would the parents feel?', 'Although the parents would obviously remain extremely disturbed, the magnitude of physiological reactions would likely have diminished over the 72 intervening hours due to some adaptation to this event.']
['What did you study?', 'If exposure to a stressor continues over a longer period of time, the stage of exhaustion ensues.']

['What else is notable about the exhaustion stage?', 'At this stage, the person is no longer able to adapt to the stressor: the body’s ability to resist becomes depleted as physical wear takes its toll on the body’s tissues and organs.']
['What happens to the body as a result?', 'As a result, illness, disease, and other permanent damage to the body—even death—may occur.']

['What is significant about the article?', 'If a missing child still remained missing after three months, the long-term stress associated with this situation may cause a parent to literally faint with exhaustion at some point or even to develop a serious and irreversible illness.']

['What is the study material?', 'In short, Selye’s general adaptation syndrome suggests that stressors tax the body via a three-phase process—an initial jolt, subsequent readjustment, and a later depletion of all physical resources—that ultimately lays the groundwork for serious health problems and even death.']

['What is the response-based conceptualization of stress?', 'It should be pointed out, however, that this model is a response-based conceptualization of stress, focusing exclusively on the body’s physical responses while largely ignoring psychological factors such as appraisal and interpretation of threats.']

['What is Selye’s model?', 'Nevertheless, Selye’s model has had an enormous impact on the field of stress because it offers a general explanation for how stress can lead to physical damage and, thus, disease.']

['What are the effects of prolonged or repeated stress?', 'As we shall discuss later, prolonged or repeated stress has been implicated in development of a number of disorders such as hypertension and coronary artery disease.']

['What are the physiological mechanisms of stress?', 'The physiological mechanisms of stress are extremely complex, but they generally involve the work of two systems—the sympathetic nervous system and the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis.']

['What happens when a person perceives something as stressful?', 'When a person first perceives something as stressful (Selye’s alarm reaction), the sympathetic nervous system triggers arousal via the release of adrenaline from the adrenal glands.']
['How does this affect you?', 'Release of these hormones activates the fight-or-flight responses to stress, such as accelerated heart rate and respiration.']
['What happens next?', 'At the same time, the HPA axis, which is primarily endocrine in nature, becomes especially active, although it works much more slowly than the sympathetic nervous system.']

['What is the hypothalamus?', 'In response to stress, the hypothalamus (one of the limbic structures in the brain) releases corticotropin-releasing factor, a hormone that causes the pituitary gland to release adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) (Figure 14.11).']

['How does the ACTH effect your body?', 'The ACTH then activates the adrenal glands to secrete a number of hormones into the bloodstream; an important one is cortisol, which can affect virtually every organ within the body.']
['What is cortisol?', 'Cortisol is commonly known as a stress hormone and helps provide that boost of energy when we first encounter a stressor, preparing us to run away or fight.']
['What does cortisol do?', 'However, sustained elevated levels of cortisol weaken the immune system.']

['What are some of the benefits we discussed?', 'In short bursts, this process can have some favorable effects, such as providing extra energy, improving immune system functioning temporarily, and decreasing pain sensitivity.']
['What is the downside of prolonged stress?', 'However, extended release of cortisol—as would happen with prolonged or chronic stress—often comes at a high price.']
['what are some of the harmful effects of prolonged stress?', 'High levels of cortisol have been shown to produce a number of harmful effects.']

['what were some of the harmful effects?', 'For example, increases in cortisol can significantly weaken our immune system (Glaser & Kiecolt-Glaser, 2005), and high levels are frequently observed among depressed individuals (Geoffroy, Hertzman, Li, & Power, 2013).']

['What physiological reaction causes a stressful event?', 'In summary, a stressful event causes a variety of physiological reactions that activate the adrenal glands, which in turn release epinephrine, norepinephrine, and cortisol.']

['what was the effects of these hormones?', 'These hormones affect a number of bodily processes in ways that prepare the stressed person to take direct action, but also in ways that may heighten the potential for illness.']
['What are some of the important aspects of The Physiological Basis of Stress?', 'When stress is extreme or chronic, it can have profoundly negative consequences.']

['What is one negative consequence?', 'For example, stress often contributes to the development of certain psychological disorders, including post-traumatic stress disorder, major depressive disorder, and other serious psychiatric conditions.']
['What are other negative consequences of stress?', 'Additionally, we noted earlier that stress is linked to the development and progression of a variety of physical illnesses and diseases.']

['What diseases are affected by stress?', 'For example, researchers in one study found that people injured during the September 11, 2001, World Trade Center disaster or who developed post-traumatic stress symptoms afterward later suffered significantly elevated rates of heart disease (Jordan, Miller-Archie, Cone, Morabia, & Stellman, 2011).']

['What other diseases are affected by stress?', 'Another investigation yielded that self-reported stress symptoms among aging and retired Finnish food industry workers were associated with morbidity 11 years later.']

['What other things are affected by stress?', 'This study also predicted the onset of musculoskeletal, nervous system, and endocrine and metabolic disorders (Salonen, Arola, Nygård, & Huhtala, 2008).']

['What is another important aspect?', 'Another study reported that male South Korean manufacturing employees who reported high levels of work-related stress were more likely to catch the common cold over the next several months than were those employees who reported lower work-related stress levels (Park et al., 2011).']
['What are other negative consequences of stress?', 'Later, you will explore the mechanisms through which stress can produce physical illness and disease.']
['How does this help us learn the material?', 'For an individual to experience stress, they must first encounter a potential stressor.']
['What are the two categories of stressors?', 'In general, stressors can be placed into one of two broad categories: chronic and acute.']

['Are there any specific examples of stressors?', 'Chronic stressors include events that persist over an extended period of time, such as caring for a parent with dementia, long-term unemployment, or imprisonment.']

['What are some examples of acute stressors?', 'Acute stressors involve brief focal events that sometimes continue to be experienced as overwhelming well after the event has ended, such as falling on an icy sidewalk and breaking your leg (Cohen, Janicki-Deverts, & Miller, 2007).']
['What is the material about?', 'Whether chronic or acute, potential stressors come in many shapes and sizes.']

['What are some of the shapes and sizes of stressors?', 'They can include major traumatic events, significant life changes, daily hassles, as well as other situations in which a person is regularly exposed to threat, challenge, or danger.']
['What are some examples of stressors?', 'Some stressors involve traumatic events or situations in which a person is exposed to actual or threatened death or serious injury.']

['What are some examples of stressors?', 'Stressors in this category include exposure to military combat, threatened or actual physical assaults (e.g., physical attacks, sexual assault, robbery, childhood abuse), terrorist attacks, natural disasters (e.g., earthquakes, floods, hurricanes), and automobile accidents.']

['What are some demographics of the people affected?', 'Men, non-White people, and individuals in lower socioeconomic status (SES) groups report experiencing a greater number of traumatic events than do women, White people, and individuals in higher SES groups (Hatch & Dohrenwend, 2007).']

['What are some symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder?', 'Some individuals who are exposed to stressors of extreme magnitude develop post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a chronic stress reaction characterized by experiences and behaviors that may include intrusive and painful memories of the stressor event, jumpiness, persistent negative emotional states, detachment from others, angry outbursts, and avoidance of reminders of the event (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2013).']
['What are some of the stressors described?', 'Most stressors that we encounter are not nearly as intense as the ones described above.']

['How do stressors affect our lives?', 'Many potential stressors we face involve events or situations that require us to make changes in our ongoing lives and require time as we adjust to those changes.']
['What are some examples of life changes?', 'Examples include death of a close family member, marriage, divorce, and moving (Figure 14.12).']

['What happened in the 60s?', 'In the 1960s, psychiatrists Thomas Holmes and Richard Rahe wanted to examine the link between life stressors and physical illness, based on the hypothesis that life events requiring significant changes in a person’s normal life routines are stressful, whether these events are desirable or undesirable.']

['What did Holmes and Rahe develop?', 'They developed the Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS), consisting of 43 life events that require varying degrees of personal readjustment (Holmes & Rahe, 1967).']

['What was the scale used for?', 'Many life events that most people would consider pleasant (e.g., holidays, retirement, marriage) are among those listed on the SRRS; these are examples of eustress.']

["How did it increase one's risk of illnesses?", 'Holmes and Rahe also proposed that life events can add up over time, and that experiencing a cluster of stressful events increases one’s risk of developing physical illnesses.']

['how was the study made?', 'In developing their scale, Holmes and Rahe asked 394 participants to provide a numerical estimate for each of the 43 items; each estimate corresponded to how much readjustment participants felt each event would require.']
['what did they do with these numerical estimates?', 'These estimates resulted in mean value scores for each event—often called life change units (LCUs) (Rahe, McKeen, & Arthur, 1967).']
['what ranged from 11 to 100?', 'The numerical scores ranged from 11 to 100, representing the perceived magnitude of life change each event entails.']
['What was one of the worst events?', 'Death of a spouse ranked highest on the scale with 100 LCUs, and divorce ranked second highest with 73 LCUs.']
['what else did they find?', 'In addition, personal injury or illness, marriage, and job termination also ranked highly on the scale with 53, 50, and 47 LCUs, respectively.']
['How were the others rated?', 'Conversely, change in residence (20 LCUs), change in eating habits (15 LCUs), and vacation (13 LCUs) ranked low on the scale (Table 14.1).']
['What was the lowest violation of the law?', 'Minor violations of the law ranked the lowest with 11 LCUs.']
['What else can you tell me about the article?', 'To complete the scale, participants checked yes for events experienced within the last 12 months.']
['How is the data collected?', 'LCUs for each checked item are totaled for a score quantifying the amount of life change.']
['What is the most important factor?', 'Agreement on the amount of adjustment required by the various life events on the SRRS is highly consistent, even cross-culturally (Holmes & Masuda, 1974).']

['What happens when someone experiences too many life changes in a short amount of time?', 'Extensive research has demonstrated that accumulating a high number of life change units within a brief period of time (one or two years) is related to a wide range of physical illnesses (even accidents and athletic injuries) and mental health problems (Monat & Lazarus, 1991; Scully, Tosi, & Banning, 2000).']

['What was an example of a case where this has been studied?', 'In an early demonstration, researchers obtained LCU scores for U.S. and Norwegian Navy personnel who were about to embark on a six-month voyage.']

['What was the result of the study?', 'A later examination of medical records revealed positive (but small) correlations between LCU scores prior to the voyage and subsequent illness symptoms during the ensuing six-month journey (Rahe, 1974).']

['What other evidence did they find?', 'In addition, people tend to experience more physical symptoms, such as backache, upset stomach, diarrhea, and acne, on specific days in which self-reported LCU values are considerably higher than normal, such as the day of a family member’s wedding (Holmes & Holmes, 1970).']

['What is the Social Readjustment Rating Scale?', 'The Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS) provides researchers a simple, easy-to-administer way of assessing the amount of stress in people’s lives, and it has been used in hundreds of studies (Thoits, 2010).']
['What is the scale used for?', 'Despite its widespread use, the scale has been subject to criticism.']

['What else is criticism?', 'First, many of the items on the SRRS are vague; for example, death of a close friend could involve the death of a long-absent childhood friend that requires little social readjustment (Dohrenwend, 2006).']
['what else is criticized?', 'In addition, some have challenged its assumption that undesirable life events are no more stressful than desirable ones (Derogatis & Coons, 1993).']

['what else was criticised?', 'However, most of the available evidence suggests that, at least as far as mental health is concerned, undesirable or negative events are more strongly associated with poor outcomes (such as depression) than are desirable, positive events (Hatch & Dohrenwend, 2007).']
['what else is criticism?', 'Perhaps the most serious criticism is that the scale does not take into consideration respondents’ appraisals of the life events it contains.']

['What is the key element in the conceptualization and overall experience of stress?', 'As you recall, appraisal of a stressor is a key element in the conceptualization and overall experience of stress.']
['What are some examples of being fired from work?', 'Being fired from work may be devastating to some but a welcome opportunity to obtain a better job for others.']

['what else is important about this scale?', 'The SRRS remains one of the most well-known instruments in the study of stress, and it is a useful tool for identifying potential stress-related health outcomes (Scully et al., 2000).']
['What are some potential stressors?', 'Potential stressors do not always involve major life events.']

['What are some common examples of daily hassles?', 'Daily hassles—the minor irritations and annoyances that are part of our everyday lives (e.g., rush hour traffic, lost keys, obnoxious coworkers, inclement weather, arguments with friends or family)—can build on one another and leave us just as stressed as life change events (Figure 14.13) (Kanner, Coyne, Schaefer, & Lazarus, 1981).']

['What is the frequency of daily hassles actually a better predictor of both physical and psychological health than are life change units?', 'Researchers have demonstrated that the frequency of daily hassles is actually a better predictor of both physical and psychological health than are life change units.']

['What is the frequency of daily hassles found to be more strongly associated with physical health problems than were life change events?', 'In a well-known study of San Francisco residents, the frequency of daily hassles was found to be more strongly associated with physical health problems than were life change events (DeLongis, Coyne, Dakof, Folkman, & Lazarus, 1982).']

['What are some examples of negative and distressed mood states?', 'In addition, daily minor hassles, especially interpersonal conflicts, often lead to negative and distressed mood states (Bolger, DeLongis, Kessler, & Schilling, 1989).']
['What other interesting topics are there?', 'Cyber hassles that occur on social media may represent a modern and evolving source of stress.']

['What else are there that can be done?', 'In one investigation, social media stress was tied to loss of sleep in adolescents, presumably because ruminating about social media caused a physiological stress response that increased arousal (van der Schuur, Baumgartner, & Sumter, 2018).']
['What is there to learn from the article?', 'Clearly, daily hassles can add up and take a toll on us both emotionally and physically.']
['WHAT IS THE FIRST QUESTION WE HAVE TO ASK?', 'OCCUPATION-RELATED']
['What else did the king have?', 'Stressors.']

['What are situations in which one is frequently exposed to challenging and unpleasant events?', 'Stressors can include situations in which one is frequently exposed to challenging and unpleasant events, such as difficult, demanding, or unsafe working conditions.']

['What are some examples of occupations that are more stressful than others?', 'Although most jobs and occupations can at times be demanding, some are clearly more stressful than others (Figure 14.14).']
['What are some examples of occupations that are more stressful?', 'For example, most people would likely agree that a firefighter’s work is inherently more stressful than that of a florist.']

['How about other examples?', 'Equally likely, most would agree that jobs containing various unpleasant elements, such as those requiring exposure to loud noise (heavy equipment operator), constant harassment and threats of physical violence (prison guard), perpetual frustration (bus driver in a major city), or those mandating that an employee work alternating day and night shifts (hotel desk clerk), are much more demanding—and thus, more stressful—than those that do not contain such elements.']

['What are some of the specific stressors associated with occupations?', 'Table 14.2 lists several occupations and some of the specific stressors associated with those occupations (Sulsky & Smith, 2005).']

['What are some common denominators for these occupations?', 'Although the specific stressors for these occupations are diverse, they seem to share some common denominators such as heavy workload and uncertainty about and lack of control over certain aspects of a job.']

['What is job strain?', 'Chronic occupational stress contributes to job strain, a work situation that combines excessive job demands and workload with little discretion in decision making or job control (Karasek & Theorell, 1990).']

['What did you find interesting about the document?', 'Clearly, many occupations other than the ones listed in Table 14.2 involve at least a moderate amount of job strain in that they often involve heavy workloads and little job control (e.g., inability to decide when to take breaks).']
['What are some of these other jobs?', 'Such jobs are often low-status and include those of factory workers, postal clerks, supermarket cashiers, taxi drivers, and short-order cooks.']

['What has been shown to be associated with increased risk of hypertension (Schnall & Landsbergis, 1994), heart attacks (Theorell et al., 1998), recurrence of heart disease after a first heart attack (Aboa-Éboulé et al., 2007), significant weight loss or gain (Kivimäki et al., 2006), and major depressive disorder (Stansfeld, Shipley, Head, & Fuhrer, 2012)?', 'Job strain can have adverse consequences on both physical and mental health; it has been shown to be associated with increased risk of hypertension (Schnall & Landsbergis, 1994), heart attacks (Theorell et al., 1998), recurrence of heart disease after a first heart attack (Aboa-Éboulé et al., 2007), significant weight loss or gain (Kivimäki et al., 2006), and major depressive disorder (Stansfeld, Shipley, Head, & Fuhrer, 2012).']

['Did the author go into more detail about this?', 'A longitudinal study of over 10,000 British civil servants reported that workers under 50 years old who earlier had reported high job strain were 68% more likely to later develop heart disease than were those workers under 50 years old who reported little job strain (Chandola et al., 2008).']

['What kind of work is he talking about?', 'Some people who are exposed to chronically stressful work conditions can experience job burnout, which is a general sense of emotional exhaustion and cynicism in relation to one’s job (Maslach & Jackson, 1981).']
['What kind of work is the most likely to experience burnout?', 'Job burnout occurs frequently among those in human service jobs (e.g., social workers, teachers, therapists, and police officers).']
['What are the different kinds of burnout?', 'Job burnout consists of three dimensions.']

['What does the first dimension mean?', 'The first dimension is exhaustion—a sense that one’s emotional resources are drained or that one is at the end of their rope and has nothing more to give at a psychological level.']

['What is the second dimension of job burnout?', 'Second, job burnout is characterized by depersonalization: a sense of emotional detachment between the worker and the recipients of their services, often resulting in callous, cynical, or indifferent attitudes toward these individuals.']

['What is the third dimension of job burnout?', 'Third, job burnout is characterized by diminished personal accomplishment, which is the tendency to evaluate one’s work negatively by, for example, experiencing dissatisfaction with one’s job-related accomplishments or feeling as though one has categorically failed to influence others’ lives through one’s work.']

['What is one of the greatest risk factors leading to job burnout?', 'Job strain appears to be one of the greatest risk factors leading to job burnout, which is most commonly observed in workers who are older (ages 55–64), unmarried, and whose jobs involve manual labor.']

['What other factors are associated with job burnout?', 'Heavy alcohol consumption, physical inactivity, being overweight, and having a physical or lifetime mental disorder are also associated with job burnout (Ahola, et al., 2006).']
['What other issues are associated with job burnout?', 'In addition, depression often co-occurs with job burnout.']

['Are there any studies that have been done on this topic?', 'One large-scale study of over 3,000 Finnish employees reported that half of the participants with severe job burnout had some form of depressive disorder (Ahola et al., 2005).']

['What are some of the other factors associated with job burnout?', 'Job burnout is often precipitated by feelings of having invested considerable energy, effort, and time into one’s work while receiving little in return (e.g., little respect or support from others or low pay) (Tatris, Peeters, Le Blanc, Schreurs, & Schaufeli, 2001).']
['What was your most important takeaway from this?', 'As an illustration, consider Tyre, a nursing assistant who worked in a nursing home.']
['What did Tyre do in the nursing home?', 'Tyre worked long hours for little pay in a difficult facility.']

["What was Tyre's supervisor like?", "Tyre's supervisor was domineering, unpleasant, and unsupportive, as well as disrespectful of Tyre's personal time, frequently informing them at the last minute they must work several additional hours after their shift ended or report to work on weekends."]
['What did Tyre have to do with the facility?', 'Tyre had very little autonomy at work.']
['What did Tyre do for the residents?', 'They had little input in day-to-day duties and how to perform them, and was not permitted to take breaks unless explicitly told by their supervisor.']
['How did Tyre feel about the residents?', 'Tyre did not feel as though their hard work was appreciated, either by supervisory staff or by the residents of the home.']
['What did Tyre say?', 'Tyre was very unhappy over the low pay, and felt that many of the residents treated them disrespectfully.']
['What happened after several years?', 'After several years,']
['What happened to Tyre?', 'Tyre began to hate their job.']
['What caused Tyre to hate the job?', 'Tyre dreaded going to work in the morning, and gradually developed a callous, hostile attitude toward many of the residents.']
['What happened after Tyre developed a hostile attitude toward many of the residents?', 'Eventually, they began to feel they could no longer help the nursing home residents.']
['How long did Tyre work there?', 'Tyre’s absenteeism from work increased, and one day they decided that they had had enough and quit.']
['What did Tyre do after quitting nursing?', 'Tyre now has a job in sales, vowing never to work in nursing again.']

['What can be a potent source of stress in our close relationships with friends and family?', 'Finally, our close relationships with friends and family—particularly the negative aspects of these relationships—can be a potent source of stress.']

['What are some negative aspects of close relationships?', 'Negative aspects of close relationships can include conflicts such as disagreements or arguments, lack of emotional support or confiding, and lack of reciprocity.']
['What other factors can be detrimental to a relationship?', 'All of these can be overwhelming, threatening to the relationship, and thus stressful.']
['Stress can cause many problems for us. What are some of the problems that stress can cause?', 'Such stressors can take a toll both emotionally and physically.']

['What else is included in this information?', 'A longitudinal investigation of over 9,000 British civil servants found that those who at one point had reported the highest levels of negative interactions in their closest relationship were 34% more likely to experience serious heart problems (fatal or nonfatal heart attacks) over a 13–15 year period, compared to those who experienced the lowest levels of negative interaction (De Vogli, Chandola & Marmot, 2007).']
['What is the purpose of this section?', 'In this section, we will discuss stress and illness.']
['What are some stress researchers?', 'As stress researcher Robert Sapolsky (1998) describes,']
['What does the stress response consist of?', 'The stress response, as noted earlier, consists of a coordinated but complex system of physiological reactions that are called upon as needed.']

['What are physiological reactions?', 'These reactions are beneficial at times because they prepare us to deal with potentially dangerous or threatening situations (for example, recall our old friend, the fearsome bear on the trail).']
['What can physiological reactions do?', 'However, health is affected when physiological reactions are sustained, as can happen in response to ongoing stress.']

['What are the most important aspects of the stress response?', 'If the reactions that compose the stress response are chronic or if they frequently exceed normal ranges, they can lead to cumulative wear and tear on the body, in much the same way that running your air conditioner on full blast all summer will eventually cause wear and tear on it.']

['What might happen if you are under a lot of stress?', 'For example, the high blood pressure that a person under considerable job strain experiences might eventually take a toll on their heart and set the stage for a heart attack or heart failure.']
['What else?', 'Also, someone exposed to high levels of the stress hormone cortisol might become vulnerable to infection or disease because of weakened immune system functioning (McEwen, 1998).']

['What is the first thing you should do to study these disorders?', 'Physical disorders or diseases whose symptoms are brought about or worsened by stress and emotional factors are called psychophysiological disorders.']

['What are the physical symptoms of psychophysiological disorders?', 'The physical symptoms of psychophysiological disorders are real and they can be produced or exacerbated by psychological factors (hence the psycho and physiological in psychophysiological).']
['What are some frequently encountered psychophysiological disorders?', 'A list of frequently encountered psychophysiological disorders is provided in Table 14.3.']
['what year was the kewley statistically reviewed studies?', 'Friedman and Booth-Kewley (1987) statistically reviewed 101 studies to examine the link between personality and illness.']
['What was the link between personality and illness?', 'They proposed the existence of disease-prone personality characteristics, including depression, anger/hostility, and anxiety.']
['how did norwegians identify depression?', 'Indeed, a study of over 61,000 Norwegians identified depression as a risk factor for all major disease-related causes of death (Mykletun et al., 2007).']

['What is another factor that has been identified as a risk factor for chronic health problems and mortality?', 'In addition, neuroticism—a personality trait that reflects how anxious, moody, and sad one is—has been identified as a risk factor for chronic health problems and mortality (Ploubidis & Grundy, 2009).']
['Are there any topics about which you are interested in?', 'Below, we discuss two kinds of psychophysiological disorders about which a great deal is known: cardiovascular disorders and asthma.']

['What is the first thing you would like to discuss?', 'First, however, it is necessary to turn our attention to a discussion of the immune system—one of the major pathways through which stress and emotional factors can lead to illness and disease.']
['What is the body’s surveillance system?', 'In a sense, the immune system is the body’s surveillance system.']

['What is the immune system?', 'It consists of a variety of structures, cells, and mechanisms that serve to protect the body from invading microorganisms that can harm or damage the body’s tissues and organs.']

['How does it keep us healthy?', 'When the immune system is working as it should, it keeps us healthy and disease free by eliminating harmful bacteria, viruses, and other foreign substances that have entered the body (Everly & Lating, 2002).']
['What is the immune system?', 'Sometimes, the immune system will function erroneously.']
['What is an example of how the immune system can go awry?', 'For example, sometimes it can go awry by mistaking your body’s own healthy cells for invaders and repeatedly attacking them.']
['When this happens, what is the result?', 'When this happens, the person is said to have an autoimmune disease, which can affect almost any part of the body.']
['How can an autoimmune disease affect a person?', 'How an autoimmune disease affects a person depends on what part of the body is targeted.']

['What is another example of an autoimmune disease that affects the joints?', 'For instance, rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune disease that affects the joints, results in joint pain, stiffness, and loss of function.']
['What is another example of an autoimmune disease?', 'Systemic lupus erythematosus, an autoimmune disease that affects the skin, can result in rashes and swelling of the skin.']

['What is another example?', 'Grave’s disease, an autoimmune disease that affects the thyroid gland, can result in fatigue, weight gain, and muscle aches (National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases [NIAMS], 2012).']
['What is the immune system?', 'In addition, the immune system may sometimes break down and be unable to do its job.']
['What is the name of the decreased effectiveness of the immune system?', 'This situation is referred to as immunosuppression, the decreased effectiveness of the immune system.']
['What does immunosuppression make people vulnerable to?', 'When people experience immunosuppression, they become susceptible to any number of infections, illness, and diseases.']

['What diseases can be caused by a decreased immune system?', 'For example, acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) is a serious and lethal disease that is caused by human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which greatly weakens the immune system by infecting and destroying antibody-producing cells, thus rendering an untreated person vulnerable to any of a number of opportunistic infections (Powell, 1996).']

['What else is interesting about this article?', 'The question of whether stress and negative emotional states can influence immune function has captivated researchers for over three decades, and discoveries made over that time have dramatically changed the face of health psychology (Kiecolt-Glaser, 2009).']

['What is the field that studies how psychological factors such as stress influence the immune system and immune functioning?', 'Psychoneuroimmunology is the field that studies how psychological factors such as stress influence the immune system and immune functioning.']

['What is the first name of the person who coined the term psychoneuroimmunology?', 'The term psychoneuroimmunology was first coined in 1981, when it appeared as the title of a book that reviewed available evidence for associations between the brain, endocrine system, and immune system (Zacharie, 2009).']

['What is the central nervous system and immune system?', 'To a large extent, this field evolved from the discovery that there is a connection between the central nervous system and the immune system.']

['What are some examples of evidence for a connection between the brain and the immune system?', 'Some of the most compelling evidence for a connection between the brain and the immune system comes from studies in which researchers demonstrated that immune responses in animals could be classically conditioned (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['What was an example of that?', 'For example, Ader and Cohen (1975) paired flavored water (the conditioned stimulus) with the presentation of an immunosuppressive drug (the unconditioned stimulus), causing sickness (an unconditioned response).']
['What other studies were done?', 'Not surprisingly, rats exposed to this pairing developed a conditioned aversion to the flavored water.']

['What did the taste of the water do to the immune system?', 'However, the taste of the water itself later produced immunosuppression (a conditioned response), indicating that the immune system itself had been conditioned.']

['What did that mean for humans?', 'Many subsequent studies over the years have further demonstrated that immune responses can be classically conditioned in both animals and humans (Ader & Cohen, 2001).']
['What did this study lead to?', 'Thus, if classical conditioning can alter immunity, other psychological factors should be capable of altering it as well.']

['What kind of stressors are studied?', 'Hundreds of studies involving tens of thousands of participants have tested many kinds of brief and chronic stressors and their effects on the immune system (e.g., public speaking, medical school examinations, unemployment, marital discord, divorce, death of spouse, burnout and job strain, caring for a relative with Alzheimer’s disease, and exposure to the harsh climate of Antarctica).']

['How has stress been shown to affect immunity?', 'It has been repeatedly demonstrated that many kinds of stressors are associated with poor or weakened immune functioning (Glaser & Kiecolt-Glaser, 2005; Kiecolt-Glaser, McGuire, Robles, & Glaser, 2002; Segerstrom & Miller, 2004).']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'When evaluating these findings, it is important to remember that there is a tangible physiological connection between the brain and the immune system.']

['What does the sympathetic nervous system innervate?', 'For example, the sympathetic nervous system innervates immune organs such as the thymus, bone marrow, spleen, and even lymph nodes (Maier, Watkins, & Fleshner, 1994).']

['What is another important fact about this passage?', 'Also, we noted earlier that stress hormones released during hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis activation can adversely impact immune function.']

['What do stress hormones do?', 'One way they do this is by inhibiting the production of lymphocytes, white blood cells that circulate in the body’s fluids that are important in the immune response (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['What is the most dramatic example of the link between stress and impaired immune function?', 'Some of the more dramatic examples demonstrating the link between stress and impaired immune function involve studies in which volunteers were exposed to viruses.']

['What is the rationale behind this research?', 'The rationale behind this research is that because stress weakens the immune system, people with high stress levels should be more likely to develop an illness compared to those under little stress.']
['What is the study?', 'In one memorable experiment using this method, researchers interviewed 276 healthy volunteers about recent stressful experiences (Cohen et al., 1998).']

['What did they do to get sick?', 'Following the interview, these participants were given nasal drops containing the cold virus (in case you are wondering why anybody would ever want to participate in a study in which they are subjected to such treatment, the participants were paid $800 for their trouble).']

['What was the test?', 'When examined later, participants who reported experiencing chronic stressors for more than one month—especially enduring difficulties involving work or relationships—were considerably more likely to have developed colds than were participants who reported no chronic stressors (Figure 14.15).']
['What did they do in another study?', 'In another study, older volunteers were given an influenza virus vaccination.']

['What happened?', 'Compared to controls, those who were caring for a spouse with Alzheimer’s disease (and thus were under chronic stress) showed poorer antibody response following the vaccination (Kiecolt-Glaser, Glaser, Gravenstein, Malarkey, & Sheridan, 1996).']
['what is stress?', 'Other studies have demonstrated that stress slows down wound healing by impairing immune responses important to wound repair (Glaser & Kiecolt-Glaser, 2005).']
['What did it do to the skin?', 'In one study, for example, skin blisters were induced on the forearm.']
['What might be stressing you out?', 'Subjects who reported higher levels of stress produced lower levels of immune proteins necessary for wound healing (Glaser et al., 1999).']

['How does stress break your immune system?', 'Stress, then, is not so much the sword that kills the knight, so to speak; rather, it’s the sword that breaks the knight’s shield, and your immune system is that shield.']
['What is the cardiovascular system composed of?', 'The cardiovascular system is composed of the heart and blood circulation system.']

['What are cardiovascular disorders?', 'For many years, disorders that involve the cardiovascular system—known as cardiovascular disorders—have been a major focal point in the study of psychophysiological disorders because of the cardiovascular system’s centrality in the stress response (Everly & Lating, 2002).']
['What are some of the diseases listed in the article?', 'Heart disease is one such condition.']

['How does it affect people?', 'Each year, heart disease causes approximately one in three deaths in the United States, and it is the leading cause of death in the developed world (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2011; Shapiro, 2005).']

['What are some symptoms of heart disease?', 'The symptoms of heart disease vary somewhat depending on the specific kind of heart disease one has, but they generally involve angina—chest pains or discomfort that occur when the heart does not receive enough blood (Office on Women’s Health, 2009).']
['What kind of pain does angina cause?', 'The pain often feels like the chest is being pressed or squeezed; burning sensations in the chest and shortness of breath are also commonly reported.']
['What can the pain spread to?', 'Such pain and discomfort can spread to the arms, neck, jaws, stomach (as nausea), and back (American Heart Association [AHA], 2012a) (Figure 14.17).']
['What is the most important information I need to know about heart disease?', 'A major risk factor for heart disease is hypertension, which is high blood pressure.']
['Why is that important?', 'Hypertension forces a person’s heart to pump harder, thus putting more physical strain on the heart.']
['What other complications does hypertension cause?', 'If left unchecked, hypertension can lead to a heart attack, stroke, or heart failure; it can also lead to kidney failure and blindness.']

['What are the symptoms of high blood pressure?', 'Hypertension is a serious cardiovascular disorder, and it is sometimes called the silent killer because it has no symptoms—one who has high blood pressure may not even be aware of it (AHA, 2012b).']
['What is the study material about?', 'Many risk factors contributing to cardiovascular disorders have been identified.']

['What are the risk factors for heart disease?', 'These risk factors include social determinants such as aging, income, education, and employment status, as well as behavioral risk factors that include unhealthy diet, tobacco use, physical inactivity, and excessive alcohol consumption; obesity and diabetes are additional risk factors (World Health Organization [WHO], 2013).']

['How is the stress factor involved?', 'Over the past few decades, there has been much greater recognition and awareness of the importance of stress and other psychological factors in cardiovascular health (Nusair, Al-dadah, & Kumar, 2012).']

['Are there any other factors involved?', 'Indeed, exposure to stressors of many kinds has also been linked to cardiovascular problems; in the case of hypertension, some of these stressors include job strain (Trudel, Brisson, & Milot, 2010), natural disasters (Saito, Kim, Maekawa, Ikeda, & Yokoyama, 1997), marital conflict (Nealey-Moore, Smith, Uchino, Hawkins, & Olson-Cerny, 2007), and exposure to high traffic noise levels at one’s home (de Kluizenaar, Gansevoort, Miedema, & de Jong, 2007).']
['How does discrimination affect hypertension?', 'Perceived discrimination appears to be associated with hypertension among African Americans (Sims et al., 2012).']

['What are some laboratory-based stress tasks that have been shown to elevate blood pressure?', 'In addition, laboratory-based stress tasks, such as performing mental arithmetic under time pressure, immersing one’s hand into ice water (known as the cold pressor test), mirror tracing, and public speaking have all been shown to elevate blood pressure (Phillips, 2011).']
['What do you want to learn from this material?', 'Sometimes research ideas and theories emerge from seemingly trivial observations.']
["What was the cardiologist's observation?", 'In the 1950s, cardiologist Meyer Friedman was looking over his waiting room furniture, which consisted of upholstered chairs with armrests.']
['What did Friedman do to change the furniture?', 'Friedman decided to have these chairs reupholstered.']

['What happened when the chairs were reupholstered?', 'When the man doing the reupholstering came to the office to do the work, he commented on how the chairs were worn in a unique manner—the front edges of the cushions were worn down, as were the front tips of the arm rests.']

['What else is significant about the waiting room furniture?', 'It seemed like the cardiology patients were tapping or squeezing the front of the armrests, as well as literally sitting on the edge of their seats (Friedman & Rosenman, 1974).']

["How did Friedman come to understand that people tend to think differently than those who don't", 'After researching this matter, Friedman and his colleague, Ray Rosenman, came to understand that people who are prone to heart disease tend to think, feel, and act differently than those who are not.']
['What type of activities do they usually do?', 'These individuals tend to be intensively driven workaholics who are preoccupied with deadlines and always seem to be in a rush.']

['What type of behavior do they exhibit?', 'According to Friedman and Rosenman, these individuals exhibit Type A behavior pattern; those who are more relaxed and laid-back were characterized as Type B (Figure 14.18).']

["How many times more do they have heart disease than Type B's?", 'In a sample of Type As and Type Bs, Friedman and Rosenman were startled to discover that heart disease was over seven times more frequent among the Type As than the Type Bs (Friedman & Rosenman, 1959).']

['What are the major components of the Type A pattern?', 'The major components of the Type A pattern include an aggressive and chronic struggle to achieve more and more in less and less time (Friedman & Rosenman, 1974).']

['What are the characteristics of the Type A pattern?', 'Specific characteristics of the Type A pattern include an excessive competitive drive, chronic sense of time urgency, impatience, and hostility toward others (particularly those who get in the person’s way).']
['What is an example of a person who exhibits Type A behavior pattern?', 'An example of a person who exhibits Type A behavior pattern is Jeffrey.']
["What happened in Jeffrey's life?", 'Even as a child, Jeffrey was intense and driven.']
['Did he accomplish anything in his life?', 'He excelled at school, was captain of the swim team, and graduated with honors from an Ivy League college.']
['How was Jeffrey able to relax?', 'Jeffrey never seems able to relax; he is always working on something, even on the weekends.']
["What is Jeffrey's favorite hobby?", 'However, Jeffrey always seems to feel as though there are not enough hours in the day to accomplish all he feels he should.']

['What does he do at work?', 'He volunteers to take on extra tasks at work and often brings his work home with him; he often goes to bed frustrated late at night because he feels that he has not done enough.']

['What did Jeffrey do with his coworkers?', 'Jeffrey is quick tempered with his coworkers; he often becomes noticeably agitated when dealing with those coworkers he feels work too slowly or whose work does not meet his standards.']
['What is another interesting fact about the character?', 'He typically reacts with hostility when interrupted at work.']
['What else did he do?', 'He has experienced problems in his marriage over his lack of time spent with family.']
["What is Jeffrey's most annoying habit?", 'When caught in traffic during his commute to and from work, Jeffrey incessantly pounds on his horn and swears loudly at other drivers.']
['What else happened?', 'When Jeffrey was 52, he suffered his first heart attack.']
['When did the research begin?', 'By the 1970s, a majority of practicing cardiologists believed that Type A behavior pattern was a significant risk factor for heart disease (Friedman, 1977).']

['What were some of the most recent studies?', 'Indeed, a number of early longitudinal investigations demonstrated a link between Type A behavior pattern and later development of heart disease (Rosenman et al., 1975; Haynes, Feinleib, & Kannel, 1980).']

['Why does that change in the medical literature concern you?', 'Subsequent research examining the association between Type A and heart disease, however, failed to replicate these earlier findings (Glassman, 2007; Myrtek, 2001).']

['What did the researchers shift their attention toward?', 'Because Type A theory did not pan out as well as they had hoped, researchers shifted their attention toward determining if any of the specific elements of Type A predict heart disease.']

['What is the most important factor in the development of heart disease?', 'Extensive research clearly suggests that the anger/hostility dimension of Type A behavior pattern may be one of the most important factors in the development of heart disease.']

['How is that research conducted?', 'This relationship was initially described in the Haynes et al. (1980) study mentioned above: Suppressed hostility was found to substantially elevate the risk of heart disease for both men and women.']
['What other research has been conducted?', 'Also, one investigation followed over 1,000 male medical students from 32 to 48 years.']

['How did the men respond to pressure?', 'At the beginning of the study, these men completed a questionnaire assessing how they react to pressure; some indicated that they respond with high levels of anger, whereas others indicated that they respond with less anger.']

['What did they find?', 'Decades later, researchers found that those who earlier had indicated the highest levels of anger were over 6 times more likely than those who indicated less anger to have had a heart attack by age 55, and they were 3.5 times more likely to have experienced heart disease by the same age (Chang, Ford, Meoni, Wang, & Klag, 2002).']
['Are there any other studies that were done?', 'From a health standpoint, it clearly does not pay to be an angry person.']

['What are the articles on this page?', 'After reviewing and statistically summarizing 35 studies from 1983 to 2006, Chida and Steptoe (2009) concluded that the bulk of the evidence suggests that anger and hostility constitute serious long-term risk factors for adverse cardiovascular outcomes among both healthy individuals and those already suffering from heart disease.']

['How might they contribute to cardiovascular diseases?', 'One reason angry and hostile moods might contribute to cardiovascular diseases is that such moods can create social strain, mainly in the form of antagonistic social encounters with others.']
['What could social strain form?', 'This strain could then lay the foundation for disease-promoting cardiovascular responses among hostile individuals (Vella, Kamarck, Flory, & Manuck, 2012).']
['What is the transactional model?', 'In this transactional model, hostility and social strain form a cycle (Figure 14.19).']

['What are some of the characteristics associated with a Type A personality?', 'For example, suppose Kaitlin has a hostile disposition; she has a cynical, distrustful attitude toward others and often thinks that other people are out to get her.']

['What are some other characteristics of a Type A personality?', 'She is very defensive around people, even those she has known for years, and she is always looking for signs that others are either disrespecting or belittling her.']

['What other characteristics of a Type A personality can you describe?', 'In the shower each morning before work, she often mentally rehearses what she would say to someone who said or did something that angered her, such as making a political statement that was counter to her own ideology.']
['What does Kaitlin do to prepare for her speech?', 'As Kaitlin goes through these mental rehearsals, she often grins and thinks about the retaliation on anyone who will irk her that day.']

['What is the main characteristic of a person who is type A?', 'Socially, she is confrontational and tends to use a harsh tone with people, which often leads to very disagreeable and sometimes argumentative social interactions.']
['Why does Kaitlin argue with others?', 'As you might imagine, Kaitlin is not especially popular with others, including coworkers, neighbors, and even members of her own family.']

['What do people say about Kaitlin?', 'They either avoid her at all costs or snap back at her, which causes Kaitlin to become even more cynical and distrustful of others, making her disposition even more hostile.']

['What does she do?', 'Kaitlin’s hostility—through her own doing—has created an antagonistic environment that cyclically causes her to become even more hostile and angry, thereby potentially setting the stage for cardiovascular problems.']

['What negative emotional states have been linked with heart disease?', 'In addition to anger and hostility, a number of other negative emotional states have been linked with heart disease, including negative affectivity and depression (Suls & Bunde, 2005).']

['What is a tendency to experience distressed emotional states involving anger, contempt, disgust, guilt, fear, and nervousness?', 'Negative affectivity is a tendency to experience distressed emotional states involving anger, contempt, disgust, guilt, fear, and nervousness (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988).']
['What are the effects of negative affectivity?', 'It has been linked with the development of both hypertension and heart disease.']
['What is a study?', 'For example, over 3,000 initially healthy participants in one study were tracked longitudinally, up to 22 years.']

['What happened in the study?', 'Those with higher levels of negative affectivity at the time the study began were substantially more likely to develop and be treated for hypertension during the ensuing years than were those with lower levels of negative affectivity (Jonas & Lando, 2000).']

['What else happened in the study?', 'In addition, a study of over 10,000 middle-aged London-based civil servants who were followed an average of 12.5 years revealed that those who earlier had scored in the upper third on a test of negative affectivity were 32% more likely to have experienced heart disease, heart attack, or angina over a period of years than were those who scored in the lowest third (Nabi, Kivimaki, De Vogli, Marmot, & Singh-Manoux, 2008).']
['What can be said about negative affectivity?', 'Hence, negative affectivity appears to be a potentially vital risk factor for the development of cardiovascular disorders.']

['Why do you believe there is a connection between moods and the heart?', 'For centuries, poets and folklore have asserted that there is a connection between moods and the heart (Glassman & Shapiro, 1998).']

['What other instances have you seen of broken hearts?', 'You are no doubt familiar with the notion of a broken heart following a disappointing or depressing event and have encountered that notion in songs, films, and literature.']

['Who was the first to recognize the link between depression and heart disease?', 'Perhaps the first to recognize the link between depression and heart disease was Benjamin Malzberg (1937), who found that the death rate among institutionalized patients with melancholia (an archaic term for depression) was six times higher than that of the population.']

['What else did this find?', 'A classic study in the late 1970s looked at over 8,000 people diagnosed with manic-depressive disorder (now classified as bipolar disorder) in Denmark, finding a nearly 50% increase in deaths from heart disease among these patients compared with the general Danish population (Weeke, 1979).']

['What did this study find?', 'By the early 1990s, evidence began to accumulate showing that depressed individuals who were followed for long periods of time were at increased risk for heart disease and cardiac death (Glassman, 2007).']

['Are there any other significant findings in the article?', 'In one investigation of over 700 Denmark residents, those with the highest depression scores were 71% more likely to have experienced a heart attack than were those with lower depression scores (Barefoot & Schroll, 1996).']
['What else did the article find?', 'Figure 14.20 illustrates the gradation in risk of heart attacks for both men and women.']
['what is the most interesting information in this material?', 'After more than two decades of research, it is now clear that a relationship exists:']

['what is this relationship?', 'Patients with heart disease have more depression than the general population, and people with depression are more likely to eventually develop heart disease and experience higher mortality than those who do not have depression (Hare, Toukhsati, Johansson, & Jaarsma, 2013); the more severe the depression, the higher the risk (Glassman, 2007).']
['What is the most important thing to remember about this information?', 'Consider the following:']

['What is the most important information in the passage?', 'In one study, death rates from cardiovascular problems was substantially higher in depressed people; depressed men were 50% more likely to have died from cardiovascular problems, and depressed women were 70% more likely (Ösby, Brandt, Correia, Ekbom, & Sparén, 2001).']

['What else has been noted?', 'A statistical review of 10 longitudinal studies involving initially healthy individuals revealed that those with elevated depressive symptoms have, on average, a 64% greater risk of developing heart disease than do those with fewer symptoms (Wulsin & Singal, 2003).']

['What other important information has been noted?', 'A study of over 63,000 registered nurses found that those with more depressed symptoms when the study began were 49% more likely to experience fatal heart disease over a 12-year period (Whang et al., 2009).']

['What did the American Heart Association recommend?', 'The American Heart Association, fully aware of the established importance of depression in cardiovascular diseases, several years ago recommended routine depression screening for all heart disease patients (Lichtman et al., 2008).']
['How did they change their mind about this recommendation?', 'Recently, they have recommended including depression as a risk factor for heart disease patients (AHA, 2014).']

['What can you tell me about Depression and the Heart?', 'Although the exact mechanisms through which depression might produce heart problems have not been fully clarified, a recent investigation examining this connection in early life has shed some light.']

['What has shed some light on the connection in early life?', 'In an ongoing study of childhood depression, adolescents who had been diagnosed with depression as children were more likely to be obese, smoke, and be physically inactive than were those who had not received this diagnosis (Rottenberg et al., 2014).']

['What is one implication of this study?', 'One implication of this study is that depression, especially if it occurs early in life, may increase the likelihood of living an unhealthy lifestyle, thereby predisposing people to an unfavorable cardiovascular disease risk profile.']

['What is the document about?', 'It is important to point out that depression may be just one piece of the emotional puzzle in elevating the risk for heart disease, and that chronically experiencing several negative emotional states may be especially important.']

['What is significant about the emotional puzzle?', 'A longitudinal investigation of Vietnam War veterans found that depression, anxiety, hostility, and trait anger each independently predicted the onset of heart disease (Boyle, Michalek, & Suarez, 2006).']

['What else did they find?', 'However, when each of these negative psychological attributes was combined into a single variable, this new variable (which researchers called psychological risk factor) predicted heart disease more strongly than any of the individual variables.']

['What else did they find?', 'Thus, rather than examining the predictive power of isolated psychological risk factors, it seems crucial for future researchers to examine the effects of combined and more general negative emotional and psychological traits in the development of cardiovascular illnesses.']

['What is the main cause of asthma?', 'Asthma is a chronic and serious disease in which the airways of the respiratory system become obstructed, leading to great difficulty expelling air from the lungs.']

['What is the cause of airway obstruction?', 'The airway obstruction is caused by inflammation of the airways (leading to thickening of the airway walls) and a tightening of the muscles around them, resulting in a narrowing of the airways (Figure 14.21) (American Lung Association, 2010).']

['What are the symptoms of a person with asthma?', 'Because airways become obstructed, a person with asthma will sometimes have great difficulty breathing and will experience repeated episodes of wheezing, chest tightness, shortness of breath, and coughing, the latter occurring mostly during the morning and night (CDC, 2006).']

['What are some important aspects about Asthma?', 'According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), around 4,000 people die each year from asthma-related causes, and asthma is a contributing factor to another 7,000 deaths each year (CDC, 2013a).']
['What else is significant about Asthma?', 'The CDC has revealed that asthma affects 18.7 million U.S. adults and is more common among people with lower income levels (CDC, 2013b).']
['What is the most concerning thing about the passage?', 'Especially concerning is that asthma is on the rise, with rates of asthma increasing 157% between 2000 and 2010 (CDC, 2013b).']
['What are the symptoms of an asthma attack?', 'Asthma attacks are acute episodes in which an asthma sufferer experiences the full range of symptoms.']

['What triggers asthma exacerbation?', 'Asthma exacerbation is often triggered by environmental factors, such as air pollution, allergens (e.g., pollen, mold, and pet hairs), cigarette smoke, airway infections, cold air or a sudden change in temperature, and exercise (CDC, 2013b).']
['what else causes it?', 'Certain regions and neighborhoods are known for having notably high rates of asthma and related diseases due to high rates of concentrated pollution and low air quality.']

['What are some examples of air pollution?', 'For example, Long Beach, California and Bronx, New York contain "asthma alleys" due to the density of trucking, power plants, factories, sewage  works, or other agents of air pollution.']

['What is significant about the document?', 'Psychological factors appear to play an important role in asthma (Wright, Rodriguez, & Cohen, 1998), although some believe that psychological factors serve as potential triggers in only a subset of asthma patients (Ritz, Steptoe, Bobb, Harris, & Edwards, 2006).']

['Can you tell me what else is significant?', 'Many studies over the years have demonstrated that some people with asthma will experience asthma-like symptoms if they expect to experience such symptoms, such as when breathing an inert substance that they (falsely) believe will lead to airway obstruction (Sodergren & Hyland, 1999).']

['What are some of the more interesting aspects of the document?', 'As stress and emotions directly affect immune and respiratory functions, psychological factors likely serve as one of the most common triggers of asthma exacerbation (Trueba & Ritz, 2013).']

['How do negative emotions relate to asthma?', 'People with asthma tend to report and display a high level of negative emotions such as anxiety, and asthma attacks have been linked to periods of high emotionality (Lehrer, Isenberg, & Hochron, 1993).']

['What other research has there been?', 'In addition, high levels of emotional distress during both laboratory tasks and daily life have been found to negatively affect airway function and can produce asthma-like symptoms in people with asthma (von Leupoldt, Ehnes, & Dahme, 2006).']
['What else do they find?', 'In one investigation, 20 adults with asthma wore preprogrammed wristwatches that signaled them to breathe into a portable device that measures airway function.']

['What did they find?', 'Results showed that higher levels of negative emotions and stress were associated with increased airway obstruction and self-reported asthma symptoms (Smyth, Soefer, Hurewitz, Kliment, & Stone, 1999).']

['What did they see it affecting the individual?', 'In addition, D’Amato, Liccardi, Cecchi, Pellegrino, & D’Amato (2010) described a case study of an 18-year-old man with asthma whose girlfriend had broken up with him, leaving him in a depressed state.']
['What did she do afterwards?', 'She had also unfriended him on Facebook, while friending other young males.']
['What happened after he did that?', 'Eventually, the young man was able to “friend” her once again and could monitor her activity through Facebook.']
['How did he feel afterwards?', 'Subsequently, he would experience asthma symptoms whenever he logged on and accessed her profile.']
['What did they find?', 'When he later resigned not to use Facebook any longer, the asthma attacks stopped.']

['What does this study say?', 'This case suggests that the use of Facebook and other forms of social media may represent a new source of stress—it may be a triggering factor for asthma attacks, especially in depressed asthmatic individuals.']

['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Exposure to stressful experiences, particularly those that involve parental or interpersonal conflicts, has been linked to the development of asthma throughout the lifespan.']

['Are there any studies or evidence of this?', 'A longitudinal study of 145 children found that parenting difficulties during the first year of life increased the chances that the child developed asthma by 107% (Klinnert et al., 2001).']
