['What are some other studies?', 'In addition, a cross-sectional study of over 10,000 Finnish college students found that high rates of parent or personal conflicts (e.g., parental divorce, separation from spouse, or severe conflicts in other long-term relationships) increased the risk of asthma onset (Kilpeläinen, Koskenvuo, Helenius, & Terho, 2002).']

['What other studies have been conducted?', 'Further, a study of over 4,000 middle-aged men who were interviewed in the early 1990s and again a decade later found that breaking off an important life partnership (e.g., divorce or breaking off relationship from parents) increased the risk of developing asthma by 124% over the time of the study (Loerbroks, Apfelbacher, Thayer, Debling, & Stürmer, 2009).']
['What is the definition of a headache?', 'A headache is a continuous pain anywhere in the head and neck region.']

['What is the cause of sinus headaches?', 'Inflammation of the sinuses caused by an infection or allergic reaction can cause sinus headaches, which are experienced as pain in the cheeks and forehead.']
['What is the cause of migraine headaches?', 'Migraine headaches are a type of headache thought to be caused by blood vessel swelling and increased blood flow (McIntosh, 2013).']
['What are migraine headaches characterized by?', 'Migraines are characterized by severe pain on one or both sides of the head, an upset stomach, and disturbed vision.']
['Are migraine headaches more common in women?', 'They are more frequently experienced by women than by men (American Academy of Neurology, 2014).']

['Are tension headaches common?', 'Tension headaches are triggered by tightening/tensing of facial and neck muscles; they are the most commonly experienced kind of headache, accounting for about 42% of all headaches worldwide (Stovner et al., 2007).']

['Are tension headaches considered chronic?', 'In the United States, well over one-third of the population experiences tension headaches each year, and 2–3% of the population suffers from chronic tension headaches (Schwartz, Stewart, Simon, & Lipton, 1998).']

['What are the most common causes of headaches?', 'A number of factors can contribute to tension headaches, including sleep deprivation, skipping meals, eye strain, overexertion, muscular tension caused by poor posture, and stress (MedicineNet, 2013).']

['What is stress?', 'Although there is uncertainty regarding the exact mechanisms through which stress can produce tension headaches, stress has been demonstrated to increase sensitivity to pain (Caceres & Burns, 1997; Logan et al., 2001).']

['How does this lead to headaches?', 'In general, tension headache sufferers, compared to non-sufferers, have a lower threshold for and greater sensitivity to pain (Ukestad & Wittrock, 1996), and they report greater levels of subjective stress when faced with a stressor (Myers, Wittrock, & Foreman, 1998).']

['What are some other sources of stress?', 'Thus, stress may contribute to tension headaches by increasing pain sensitivity in already-sensitive pain pathways in tension headache sufferers (Cathcart, Petkov, & Pritchard, 2008).']
['What is the passage about?', 'As we learned in the previous section, stress—especially if it is chronic—takes a toll on our bodies and can have enormously negative health implications.']

['What is an example of using effective coping strategies?', 'When we experience events in our lives that we appraise as stressful, it is essential that we use effective coping strategies to manage our stress.']
['What is coping?', 'Coping refers to mental and behavioral efforts that we use to deal with problems relating to stress.']
['What are the two fundamental kinds of coping?', 'Lazarus and Folkman (1984) distinguished two fundamental kinds of coping: problem-focused coping and emotion-focused coping.']
['What happens in a problem-focused coping?', 'In problem-focused coping, one attempts to manage or alter the problem that is causing one to experience stress (i.e., the stressor).']

['How do problem-focused coping strategies differ from everyday problem-solving?', 'Problem-focused coping strategies are similar to strategies used in everyday problem-solving: they typically involve identifying the problem, considering possible solutions, weighing the costs and benefits of these solutions, and then selecting an alternative (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']
['How does one apply this information to their daily life?', 'As an example, suppose Bradford receives a midterm notice that he is failing statistics class.']
['How would Bradford react to this?', 'If Bradford adopts a problem-focused coping approach to managing his stress, he would be proactive in trying to alleviate the source of the stress.']

['How might he do this?', 'He might contact his professor to discuss what must be done to raise his grade, he might also decide to set aside two hours daily to study statistics assignments, and he may seek tutoring assistance.']
['What is one major thing to remember about problem-focused coping?', 'A problem-focused approach to managing stress means we actively try to do things to address the problem.']

['What is the difference between emotion-focused coping and stress response management?', 'Emotion-focused coping, in contrast, consists of efforts to change or reduce the negative emotions associated with stress.']

['What are these efforts?', 'These efforts may include avoiding, minimizing, or distancing oneself from the problem, or positive comparisons with others (“I’m not as bad off as she is”), or seeking something positive in a negative event (“Now that I’ve been fired, I can sleep in for a few days”).']

['Why do you call them efforts?', 'In some cases, emotion-focused coping strategies involve reappraisal, whereby the stressor is construed differently (and somewhat self-deceptively) without changing its objective level of threat (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']
['What is an example of reappraisal?', 'For example, a person sentenced to federal prison who thinks, “This will give me a great chance to network with others,” is using reappraisal.']

['How does it work in practice?', 'If Bradford adopted an emotion-focused approach to managing his midterm deficiency stress, he might watch a comedy movie, play video games, or spend hours on social media to take his mind off the situation.']

['Why do you refer to this as treating the symptoms rather than the actual cause?', 'In a certain sense, emotion-focused coping can be thought of as treating the symptoms rather than the actual cause.']

['What is the difference between problem-focused and emotion-focused coping?', 'While many stressors elicit both kinds of coping strategies, problem-focused coping is more likely to occur when encountering stressors we perceive as controllable, while emotion-focused coping is more likely to predominate when faced with stressors that we believe we are powerless to change (Folkman &  Lazarus, 1980).']
['What is the difference between emotion and problem-focused coping?', 'Clearly, emotion-focused coping is more effective in dealing with uncontrollable stressors.']
['What are some examples of stress?', 'For example, the stress you experience when a loved one dies can be overwhelming.']
['How would you respond to that?', 'You are simply powerless to change the situation as there is nothing you can do to bring this person back.']
['What would you do after this?', 'The most helpful coping response is emotion-focused coping aimed at minimizing the pain of the grieving period.']
['What is the passage about?', 'Fortunately, most stressors we encounter can be modified and are, to varying degrees, controllable.']

['What can be done to control them?', 'A person who cannot stand her job can quit and look for work elsewhere; a middle-aged divorcee can find another potential partner; the freshman who fails an exam can study harder next time, and a breast lump does not necessarily mean that one is fated to die of breast cancer.']

['What can you tell me about these questions?', 'The desire and ability to predict events, make decisions, and affect outcomes—that is, to enact control in our lives—is a basic tenet of human behavior (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['What is the most significant thing in the article?', 'Albert Bandura (1997) stated that “the intensity and chronicity of human stress is governed largely by perceived control over the demands of one’s life” (p. 262).']
['What did Bandura state?', 'As cogently described in his statement, our reaction to potential stressors depends to a large extent on how much control we feel we have over such things.']

['What can you tell me about perceived control?', 'Perceived control is our beliefs about our personal capacity to exert influence over and shape outcomes, and it has major implications for our health and happiness (Infurna & Gerstorf, 2014).']

['What are the benefits of perceptions of personal control?', 'Extensive research has demonstrated that perceptions of personal control are associated with a variety of favorable outcomes, such as better physical and mental health and greater psychological well-being (Diehl & Hay, 2010).']
['What else do we know about perceived control?', 'Greater personal control is also associated with lower reactivity to stressors in daily life.']

['What did the research say?', 'For example, researchers in one investigation found that higher levels of perceived control at one point in time were later associated with lower emotional and physical reactivity to interpersonal stressors (Neupert, Almeida, & Charles, 2007).']

['How else did they study perceived control?', 'Further, a daily diary study with 34 older widows found that their stress and anxiety levels were significantly reduced on days during which the widows felt greater perceived control (Ong, Bergeman, & Bisconti, 2005).']

['What is the first passage from our study material?', 'People who report higher levels of perceived control view their health as controllable, thereby making it more likely that they will better manage their health and engage in behaviors conducive to good health (Bandura, 2004).']

['Are there any other studies related to perceived control?', 'Not surprisingly, greater perceived control has been linked to lower risk of physical health problems, including declines in physical functioning (Infurna, Gerstorf, Ram, Schupp, & Wagner, 2011), heart attacks (Rosengren et al., 2004), and both cardiovascular disease incidence (Stürmer, Hasselbach, & Amelang, 2006) and mortality from cardiac disease (Surtees et al., 2010).']

['Why is it linked to physical health problems?', 'In addition, longitudinal studies of British civil servants have found that those in low-status jobs (e.g., clerical and office support staff) in which the degree of control over the job is minimal are considerably more likely to develop heart disease than those with high-status jobs or considerable control over their jobs (Marmot, Bosma, Hemingway, & Stansfeld, 1997).']

['What is the link between perceived control and health?', 'The link between perceived control and health may provide an explanation for the frequently observed relationship between social class and health outcomes (Kraus, Piff, Mendoza-Denton, Rheinschmidt, & Keltner, 2012).']

['what else can you tell me about perceived control?', 'In general, research has found that more affluent individuals experience better health partly because they tend to believe that they can personally control and manage their reactions to life’s stressors (Johnson & Krueger, 2006).']

['What is buoyed by the perceived control?', 'Perhaps buoyed by the perceived level of control, individuals of higher social class may be prone to overestimating the degree of influence they have over particular outcomes.']

['what outcomes?', 'For example, those of higher social class tend to believe that their votes have greater sway on election outcomes than do those of lower social class, which may explain higher rates of voting in more affluent communities (Krosnick, 1990).']

['what else can you tell me about perceived control?', 'Other research has found that a sense of perceived control can protect less affluent individuals from poorer health, depression, and reduced life-satisfaction—all of which tend to accompany lower social standing (Lachman & Weaver, 1998).']

['What is the basic reason for social support?', 'The need to form and maintain strong, stable relationships with others is a powerful, pervasive, and fundamental human motive (Baumeister & Leary, 1995).']

['What other benefits are associated with social support?', 'Building strong interpersonal relationships with others helps us establish a network of close, caring individuals who can provide social support in times of distress, sorrow, and fear.']
['What is the soothing impact of social support?', 'Social support can be thought of as the soothing impact of friends, family, and acquaintances (Baron & Kerr, 2003).']

['How does social support benefit you?', 'Social support can take many forms, including advice, guidance, encouragement, acceptance, emotional comfort, and tangible assistance (such as financial help).']

['How do you feel when you get social support?', 'Thus, other people can be very comforting to us when we are faced with a wide range of life stressors, and they can be extremely helpful in our efforts to manage these challenges.']
['What can species mates do for each other?', 'Even in nonhuman animals, species mates can offer social support during times of stress.']

['What is another example of social support?', 'For example, elephants seem to be able to sense when other elephants are stressed and will often comfort them with physical contact—such as a trunk touch—or an empathetic vocal response (Krumboltz, 2014).']

['What was the first study of social support and its benefits?', 'Scientific interest in the importance of social support first emerged in the 1970s when health researchers developed an interest in the health consequences of being socially integrated (Stroebe & Stroebe, 1996).']

['What was further fueled by longitudinal studies showing that social connectedness reduced mortality?', 'Interest was further fueled by longitudinal studies showing that social connectedness reduced mortality.']
['What was the most important study that helped develop this idea?', 'In one classic study, nearly 7,000 Alameda County, California, residents were followed over 9 years.']

['What were the results of the study?', 'Those who had previously indicated that they lacked social and community ties were more likely to die during the follow-up period than those with more extensive social networks.']

['Did they find any other studies about the benefits of social support?', 'Compared to those with the most social contacts, isolated men and women were, respectively, 2.3 and 2.8 times more likely to die.']

['What is the most important part of this study?', 'These trends persisted even after controlling for a variety of health-related variables, such as smoking, alcohol consumption, self-reported health at the beginning of the study, and physical activity (Berkman & Syme, 1979).']

['What are some important aspects of the article?', 'Since the time of that study, social support has emerged as one of the well-documented psychosocial factors affecting health outcomes (Uchino, 2009).']

['What are some examples of well-documented factors?', 'A statistical review of 148 studies conducted between 1982 and 2007 involving over 300,000 participants concluded that individuals with stronger social relationships have a 50% greater likelihood of survival compared to those with weak or insufficient social relationships (Holt-Lunstad, Smith, & Layton, 2010).']

['How do we know that?', 'According to the researchers, the magnitude of the effect of social support observed in this study is comparable with quitting smoking and exceeded many well-known risk factors for mortality, such as obesity and physical inactivity (Figure 14.23).']

['What are some important points in this study material?', 'A number of large-scale studies have found that individuals with low levels of social support are at greater risk of mortality, especially from cardiovascular disorders (Brummett et al., 2001).']

['What are some other important points?', 'Further, higher levels of social supported have been linked to better survival rates following breast cancer (Falagas et al., 2007) and infectious diseases, especially HIV infection (Lee & Rotheram-Borus, 2001).']
['What is so special about social support?', 'In fact, a person with high levels of social support is less likely to contract a common cold.']

['What is the study about?', 'In one study, 334 participants completed questionnaires assessing their sociability; these individuals were subsequently exposed to a virus that causes a common cold and monitored for several weeks to see who became ill.']
['What was their result?', 'Results showed that increased sociability was linearly associated with a decreased probability of developing a cold (Cohen, Doyle, Turner, Alper, & Skoner, 2003).']
['What are some vital sources of social support?', 'For many of us, friends are a vital source of social support.']

['What makes some experience drastic reductions?', 'Many students who leave home to attend and live at college experience drastic reductions in their social support, which makes them vulnerable to anxiety, depression, and loneliness.']

['Does social media also cause loneliness?', 'Social media can sometimes be useful in navigating these transitions (Raney & Troop Gordon, 2012) but might also cause increases in loneliness (Hunt, Marx, Lipson, & Young, 2018).']

['What are some programs that can help students build new social networks?', 'For this reason, many colleges have designed first-year programs, such as peer mentoring (Raymond & Shepard, 2018), that can help students build new social networks.']
['Who are some families?', 'For some people, our families—especially our parents—are a major source of social support.']

['What is the content of this document about?', 'Social support appears to work by boosting the immune system, especially among people who are experiencing stress (Uchino, Vaughn, Carlisle, & Birmingham, 2012).']

['What was the research?', 'In a pioneering study, spouses of cancer patients who reported high levels of social support showed indications of better immune functioning on two out of three immune functioning measures, compared to spouses who were below the median on reported social support (Baron, Cutrona, Hicklin, Russell, & Lubaroff, 1990).']

['Are there other studies done?', 'Studies of other populations have produced similar results, including those of spousal caregivers of dementia sufferers, medical students, elderly adults, and cancer patients (Cohen & Herbert, 1996; Kiecolt-Glaser, McGuire, Robles, & Glaser, 2002).']

['What is important about social support?', 'In addition, social support has been shown to reduce blood pressure for people performing stressful tasks, such as giving a speech or performing mental arithmetic (Lepore, 1998).']

['What are the other types of support that reduce stress?', 'In these kinds of studies, participants are usually asked to perform a stressful task either alone, with a stranger present (who may be either supportive or unsupportive), or with a friend present.']

['Do all people that receive support feel less stressed?', 'Those tested with a friend present generally exhibit lower blood pressure than those tested alone or with a stranger (Fontana, Diegnan, Villeneuve, & Lepore, 1999).']

['What is significant about males and females?', 'In one study, 112 female participants who performed stressful mental arithmetic exhibited lower blood pressure when they received support from a friend rather than a stranger, but only if the friend was a male (Phillips, Gallagher, & Carroll, 2009).']

['Why do females feel less supported?', 'Although these findings are somewhat difficult to interpret, the authors mention that it is possible that females feel less supported and more evaluated by other females, particularly females whose opinions they value.']

['What did you learn about social support?', 'Taken together, the findings above suggest one of the reasons social support is connected to favorable health outcomes is because it has several beneficial physiological effects in stressful situations.']

['What other things did you learn about social support?', 'However, it is also important to consider the possibility that social support may lead to better health behaviors, such as a healthy diet, exercising, smoking cessation, and cooperation with medical regimens (Uchino, 2009).']

['What are the common techniques people use?', 'Beyond having a sense of control and establishing social support networks, there are numerous other means by which we can manage stress (Figure 14.24).']
['What is one of the common techniques people use to combat stress?', 'A common technique people use to combat stress is exercise (Salmon, 2001).']

['What is the benefit of exercise?', 'It is well-established that exercise, both of long (aerobic) and short (anaerobic) duration, is beneficial for both physical and mental health (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['Does it improve physical health?', 'There is considerable evidence that physically fit individuals are more resistant to the adverse effects of stress and recover more quickly from stress than less physically fit individuals (Cotton, 1990).']

['How can it protect against health problems?', 'In a study of more than 500 Swiss police officers and emergency service personnel, increased physical fitness was associated with reduced stress, and regular exercise was reported to protect against stress-related health problems (Gerber, Kellman, Hartman, & Pühse, 2010).']
['What is one reason exercise may be beneficial?', 'One reason exercise may be beneficial is because it might buffer some of the deleterious physiological mechanisms of stress.']

['What was one of the studies that substantiated this?', 'One study found rats that exercised for six weeks showed a decrease in hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal responsiveness to mild stressors (Campeau et al., 2010).']

['How is this beneficial to humans?', 'In high-stress humans, exercise has been shown to prevent telomere shortening, which may explain the common observation of a youthful appearance among those who exercise regularly (Puterman et al., 2010).']
['What was another study?', 'Further, exercise in later adulthood appears to minimize the detrimental effects of stress on the hippocampus and memory (Head, Singh, & Bugg, 2012).']

['How else can this benefit humans?', 'Among cancer survivors, exercise has been shown to reduce anxiety (Speck, Courneya, Masse, Duval, & Schmitz, 2010) and depressive symptoms (Craft, VanIterson, Helenowski, Rademaker, & Courneya, 2012).']
['What can exercise do for your body?', 'Clearly, exercise is a highly effective tool for regulating stress.']

['What is the name of the cardiologist who developed the relaxation response technique?', 'In the 1970s, Herbert Benson, a cardiologist, developed a stress reduction method called the relaxation response technique (Greenberg, 2006).']
['What is the relaxation response technique?', 'The relaxation response technique combines relaxation with transcendental meditation, and consists of four components (Stein, 2001):']
['What year was this technique developed?', 'Another technique to combat stress, biofeedback, was developed by Gary Schwartz at Harvard University in the early 1970s.']

['What is biofeedback?', 'Biofeedback is a technique that uses electronic equipment to accurately measure a person’s neuromuscular and autonomic activity—feedback is provided in the form of visual or auditory signals.']

['What does it accomplish?', 'The main assumption of this approach is that providing somebody biofeedback will enable the individual to develop strategies that help gain some level of voluntary control over what are normally involuntary bodily processes (Schwartz & Schwartz, 1995).']

['what other techniques have been used?', 'A number of different bodily measures have been used in biofeedback research, including facial muscle movement, brain activity, and skin temperature, and it has been applied successfully with individuals experiencing tension headaches, high blood pressure, asthma, and phobias (Stein, 2001).']
['What are some questions about stress?', 'Although the study of stress and how it affects us physically and psychologically is fascinating, it is—admittedly—somewhat of a grim topic.']
['What is Psychology also interested in the study of?', 'Psychology is also interested in the study of a more upbeat and encouraging approach to human affairs—the quest for happiness.']
['What was the statement that states happiness is our right?', 'America’s founders declared that its citizens have an unalienable right to pursue happiness.']
['What is the definition of happiness?', 'When asked to define the term, people emphasize different aspects of this elusive state.']
['What can we infer about the definition of happiness?', 'Indeed, happiness is somewhat ambiguous and can be defined from different perspectives (Martin, 2012).']

['What are some different perspectives on happiness?', 'Some people, especially those who are highly committed to their religious faith, view happiness in ways that emphasize virtuosity, reverence, and enlightened spirituality.']

['What other aspects do they see happiness as?', 'Others see happiness as primarily contentment—the inner peace and joy that come from deep satisfaction with one’s surroundings, relationships with others, accomplishments, and oneself.']

['What do people think of happiness?', 'Still others view happiness mainly as pleasurable engagement with their personal environment—having a career and hobbies that are engaging, meaningful, rewarding, and exciting.']
['What is the point of these different definitions?', 'These differences, of course, are merely differences in emphasis.']
['Are people wrong in defining happiness?', 'Most people would probably agree that each of these views, in some respects, captures the essence of happiness.']

['What is the article about?', 'Some psychologists have suggested that happiness consists of three distinct elements: the pleasant life, the good life, and the meaningful life, as shown in Figure 14.25 (Seligman, 2002; Seligman, Steen, Park, & Peterson, 2005).']
['What does the pleasant life mean?', 'The pleasant life is realized through the attainment of day-to-day pleasures that add fun, joy, and excitement to our lives.']
['What are some things that contribute to this?', 'For example, evening walks along the beach and a fulfilling sex life can enhance our daily pleasure and contribute to the pleasant life.']

['How can one achieve the good life?', 'The good life is achieved through identifying our unique skills and abilities and engaging these talents to enrich our lives; those who achieve the good life often find themselves absorbed in their work or their recreational pursuits.']

['What is the meaning of the meaningful life?', 'The meaningful life involves a deep sense of fulfillment that comes from using our talents in the service of the greater good: in ways that benefit the lives of others or that make the world a better place.']
['What was the article about?', 'In general, the happiest people tend to be those who pursue the full life—they orient their pursuits toward all three elements (Seligman et al., 2005).']

['What is the precise definition of happiness?', 'For practical purposes, a precise definition of happiness might incorporate each of these elements: an enduring state of mind consisting of joy, contentment, and other positive emotions, plus the sense that one’s life has meaning and value (Lyubomirsky, 2001).']

['What is the term characterized as?', 'The definition implies that happiness is a long-term state—what is often characterized as subjective well-being—rather than merely a transient positive mood we all experience from time to time.']
['What has captured the interests of psychologists and other social scientists?', 'It is this enduring happiness that has captured the interests of psychologists and other social scientists.']
['What has happened in the last three decades?', 'The study of happiness has grown dramatically in the last three decades (Diener, 2013).']
['What are some basic questions that happiness investigators routinely examine?', 'One of the most basic questions that happiness investigators routinely examine is this:']

['How happy is the average person in the world?', 'The average person in the world tends to be relatively happy and tends to indicate experiencing more positive feelings than negative feelings (Diener, Ng, Harter, & Arora, 2010).']

['What does the average person deem to be their best life?', 'When asked to evaluate their current lives on a scale ranging from 0 to 10 (with 0 representing “worst possible life” and 10 representing “best possible life”), people in more than 150 countries surveyed from 2010–2012 reported an average score of 5.2.']

['What countries have the highest average scores?', 'People who live in North America, Australia, and New Zealand reported the highest average score at 7.1, whereas those living Sub-Saharan Africa reported the lowest average score at 4.6 (Helliwell, Layard, & Sachs, 2013).']

['What are the five happiest countries worldwide?', 'Worldwide, the five happiest countries are Denmark, Norway, Switzerland, the Netherlands, and Sweden; the United States is ranked 17th happiest (Figure 14.26) (Helliwell et al., 2013).']
['How many people reported that they were "very happy"?', 'Several years ago, a Gallup survey of more than 1,000 U.S. adults found that 52% reported that they were “very happy.”']
['What are some examples of happiness?', 'In addition, more than 8 in 10 indicated that they were “very satisfied” with their lives (Carroll, 2007).']
['How many Americans report being very happy?', 'However, a recent poll found that only 42% of American adults report being "very happy."']

['What is the biggest factor in happiness?', 'The groups that show the greatest declines in happiness are people of color, those who have not completed a college education, and those who politically identify as Democrats or independents (McCarthy, 2020).']
['What does this tell us about happiness?', 'These results suggest that challenging economic conditions may be related to declines in happiness.']
['Does this mean that people are not happy?', "Of course, this interpretation implies that happiness is closely tied to one's finances."]
['What has been researched about this question?', 'Extensive research over the years has examined this question.']
['What were some of the findings?', 'One finding is that age is related to happiness:']
['What was another finding?', 'Life satisfaction usually increases the older people get, but there do not appear to be gender differences in happiness (Diener, Suh, Lucas, & Smith, 1999).']

['What are some of the key findings?', 'Although it is important to point out that much of this work has been correlational, many of the key findings (some of which may surprise you) are summarized below.']
['What is the main idea of the article?', 'Family and other social relationships appear to be key factors correlated with happiness.']
['What has been discovered about married people?', 'Studies show that married people report being happier than those who are single, divorced, or widowed (Diener et al., 1999).']
['What has been discovered about happy individuals?', 'Happy individuals also report that their marriages are fulfilling (Lyubomirsky, King, & Diener, 2005).']
['What is the strongest predictor of happiness?', 'In fact, some have suggested that satisfaction with marriage and family life is the strongest predictor of happiness (Myers, 2000).']

['What other factors can contribute to happiness?', 'Happy people tend to have more friends, more high-quality social relationships, and stronger social support networks than less happy people (Lyubomirsky et al., 2005).']
['What else has been found?', 'Happy people also have a high frequency of contact with friends (Pinquart & Sörensen, 2000).']
['Is higher income good for happiness?', 'In general, extensive research suggests that the answer is yes, but with several caveats.']

['What are the caveats of the study?', 'While a nation’s per capita gross domestic product (GDP) is associated with happiness levels (Helliwell et al., 2013), changes in GDP (which is a less certain index of household income) bear little relationship to changes in happiness (Diener, Tay, & Oishi, 2013).']

['what is the most important information in this article?', 'On the whole, residents of affluent countries tend to be happier than residents of poor countries; within countries, wealthy individuals are happier than poor individuals, but the association is much weaker (Diener & Biswas-Diener, 2002).']

['what does the increase in income have to do with happiness?', 'To the extent that it leads to increases in purchasing power, increases in income are associated with increases in happiness (Diener, Oishi, & Ryan, 2013).']
['What do we know about happiness?', 'However, income within societies appears to correlate with happiness only up to a point.']

['what is the point?', 'In a study of over 450,000 U.S. residents surveyed by the Gallup Organization, Kahneman and Deaton (2010) found that well-being rises with annual income, but only up to $75,000.']
['Did they find anything else?', 'The average increase in reported well-being for people with incomes greater than $75,000 was null.']

['What does this mean for us?', 'As implausible as these findings might seem—after all, higher incomes would enable people to indulge in Hawaiian vacations, prime seats as sporting events, expensive automobiles, and expansive new homes—higher incomes may impair people’s ability to savor and enjoy the small pleasures of life (Kahneman, 2011).']

['What are some examples of the effect of wealth on savoring?', 'Indeed, researchers in one study found that participants exposed to a subliminal reminder of wealth spent less time savoring a chocolate candy bar and exhibited less enjoyment of this experience than did participants who were not reminded of wealth (Quoidbach, Dunn, Petrides, & Mikolajczak, 2010).']
['What can we find out about happiness?', 'Happy people, compared to those who are less happy, are more likely to graduate from college and secure more meaningful and engaging jobs.']
['Are there any other facts about happiness?', 'Once they obtain a job, they are also more likely to succeed (Lyubomirsky et al., 2005).']
['Are there any other facts about happiness?', 'While education shows a positive (but weak) correlation with happiness, intelligence is not appreciably related to happiness (Diener et al., 1999).']
['Are Sanders and Hackney connected?', 'In general, the answer is yes (Hackney & Sanders, 2003).']
['What is the role religion has on happiness?', 'However, the relationship between religiosity and happiness depends on societal circumstances.']

['Is there a certain societal circumstances that affects happiness?', 'Nations and states with more difficult living conditions (e.g., widespread hunger and low life expectancy) tend to be more highly religious than societies with more favorable living conditions.']

['What is the relationship between religiosity and happiness?', 'Among those who live in nations with difficult living conditions, religiosity is associated with greater well-being; in nations with more favorable living conditions, religious and nonreligious individuals report similar levels of well-being (Diener, Tay, & Myers, 2011).']
['What are the factors that influence happiness?', 'Clearly the living conditions of one’s nation can influence factors related to happiness.']
['What is it that people tend to be happier with?', 'To the extent that people possess characteristics that are highly valued by their culture, they tend to be happier (Diener, 2012).']

['What are some examples of how culture affects happiness?', 'For example, self-esteem is a stronger predictor of life satisfaction in individualistic cultures than in collectivistic cultures (Diener, Diener, & Diener, 1995), and extraverted people tend to be happier in extraverted cultures than in introverted cultures (Fulmer et al., 2010).']
["What's the first thing you learned about happiness?", 'So we’ve identified many factors that exhibit some correlation to happiness.']
['What does this mean?', 'Researchers have studied both parenthood and physical attractiveness as potential contributors to happiness, but no link has been identified.']

['What do we learn about parenthood?', 'Although people tend to believe that parenthood is central to a meaningful and fulﬁlling life, aggregate findings from a range of countries indicate that people who do not have children are generally happier than those who do (Hansen, 2012).']

["What's the most important fact from this article?", 'And although one’s perceived level of attractiveness seems to predict happiness, a person’s objective physical attractiveness is only weakly correlated with their happiness (Diener, Wolsic, & Fujita, 1995).']
['What is an important point?', 'An important point should be considered regarding happiness.']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'People are often poor at affective forecasting: predicting the intensity and duration of their future emotions (Wilson & Gilbert, 2003).']

['What other examples are there?', 'In one study, nearly all newlywed spouses predicted their marital satisfaction would remain stable or improve over the following four years; despite this high level of initial optimism, their marital satisfaction actually declined during this period (Lavner, Karner, & Bradbury, 2013).']

["What is wrong with people's forecasting?", 'In addition, we are often incorrect when estimating how our long-term happiness would change for the better or worse in response to certain life events.']

["How do people's estimates get messed up?", 'For example, it is easy for many of us to imagine how euphoric we would feel if we won the lottery, were asked on a date by an attractive celebrity, or were offered our dream job.']

['What else did they discover?', 'It is also easy to understand how long-suffering fans of the Chicago Cubs baseball team, which had not won a World Series championship since 1908, thought they would feel permanently elated when their team finally won another World Series in 2016.']
['What else did they discover?', 'Likewise, it is easy to predict that we would feel permanently miserable if we suffered a disabling accident or if a romantic relationship ended.']
['What happens when people experience emotional reactions to life events?', 'However, something similar to sensory adaptation often occurs when people experience emotional reactions to life events.']

['What happens when people experience emotional reactions?', 'In much the same way our senses adapt to changes in stimulation (e.g., our eyes adapting to bright light after walking out of the darkness of a movie theater into the bright afternoon sun), we eventually adapt to changing emotional circumstances in our lives (Brickman & Campbell, 1971; Helson, 1964).']

['Are people unhappy about the events they are faced with?', 'When an event that provokes positive or negative emotions occurs, at first we tend to experience its emotional impact at full intensity.']

['What are some examples of the life events that can lead to a burst of pleasure?', 'We feel a burst of pleasure following such things as a marriage proposal, birth of a child, acceptance to law school, an inheritance, and the like; as you might imagine, lottery winners experience a surge of happiness after hitting the jackpot (Lutter, 2007).']
['What are some negative life events?', 'Likewise, we experience a surge of misery following widowhood, a divorce, or a layoff from work.']

['How does this affect people in the long run?', 'In the long run, however, we eventually adjust to the emotional new normal; the emotional impact of the event tends to erode, and we eventually revert to our original baseline happiness levels.']

['Does the event make a difference to people?', 'Thus, what was at first a thrilling lottery windfall or World Series championship eventually loses its luster and becomes the status quo (Figure 14.27).']
['What is the research on dramatic life events?', 'Indeed, dramatic life events have much less long-lasting impact on happiness than might be expected (Brickman, Coats, & Janoff-Bulman, 1978).']

['What is the point of life events and happiness?', 'Recently, some have raised questions concerning the extent to which important life events can permanently alter people’s happiness set points (Diener, Lucas, & Scollon, 2006).']
['Are there studies demonstrating this?', 'Evidence from a number of investigations suggests that, in some circumstances, happiness levels do not revert to their original positions.']

['What else do these studies show?', 'For example, although people generally tend to adapt to marriage so that it no longer makes them happier or unhappier than before, they often do not fully adapt to unemployment or severe disabilities (Diener, 2012).']

['What are other studies demonstrating this?', 'Figure 14.28, which is based on longitudinal data from a sample of over 3,000 German respondents, shows life satisfaction scores several years before, during, and after various life events, and it illustrates how people adapt (or fail to adapt) to these events.']
['What is shown in this figure?', 'German respondents did not get lasting emotional boosts from marriage; instead, they reported brief increases in happiness, followed by quick adaptation.']

['What about widows?', 'In contrast, widows and those who had been laid off experienced sizeable decreases in happiness that appeared to result in long-term changes in life satisfaction (Diener et al., 2006).']

['Are there any other studies that show happiness levels changed over time?', 'Further, longitudinal data from the same sample showed that happiness levels changed significantly over time for nearly a quarter of respondents, with 9% showing major changes (Fujita & Diener, 2005).']
['What is the most important thing to note about this article?', 'Thus, long-term happiness levels can and do change for some people.']
['What is the best part of the article?', 'Some recent findings about happiness provide an optimistic picture, suggesting that real changes in happiness are possible.']

["what's an example of one example?", 'For example, thoughtfully developed well-being interventions designed to augment people’s baseline levels of happiness may increase happiness in ways that are permanent and long-lasting, not just temporary.']
['How can this increase happiness?', 'These changes in happiness may be targeted at individual, organizational, and societal levels (Diener et al., 2006).']

['what are three good things?', 'Researchers in one study found that a series of happiness interventions involving such exercises as writing down three good things that occurred each day led to increases in happiness that lasted over six months (Seligman et al., 2005).']

['How can societal happiness be increased?', 'Measuring happiness and well-being at the societal level over time may assist policy makers in determining if people are generally happy or miserable, as well as when and why they might feel the way they do.']

['What are the six key variables that are related to happiness?', 'Studies show that average national happiness scores (over time and across countries) relate strongly to six key variables: per capita gross domestic product (GDP, which reflects a nation’s economic standard of living), social support, freedom to make important life choices, healthy life expectancy, freedom from perceived corruption in government and business, and generosity (Helliwell et al., 2013).']

['What might help policymakers develop programs that increase happiness and well-being within a society?', 'Investigating why people are happy or unhappy might help policymakers develop programs that increase happiness and well-being within a society (Diener et al., 2006).']

['Can you tell me more about this study?', 'Resolutions about contemporary political and social issues that are frequent topics of debate—such as poverty, taxation, affordable health care and housing, clean air and water, and income inequality—might be best considered with people’s happiness in mind.']

['What is the introductory article about?', 'In 1998, Seligman (the same person who conducted the learned helplessness experiments mentioned earlier), who was then president of the American Psychological Association, urged psychologists to focus more on understanding how to build human strength and psychological well-being.']

['What is positive psychology?', 'In deliberately setting out to create a new direction and new orientation for psychology, Seligman helped establish a growing movement and field of research called positive psychology (Compton, 2005).']

['What can you tell me about positive psychology?', 'In a very general sense, positive psychology can be thought of as the science of happiness; it is an area of study that seeks to identify and promote those qualities that lead to greater fulfillment in our lives.']

['Does this study focus on positive traits?', 'This field looks at people’s strengths and what helps individuals to lead happy, contented lives, and it moves away from focusing on people’s pathology, faults, and problems.']
['Did they find any evidence of positive psychology?', 'According to Seligman and Csikszentmihalyi (2000), positive psychology,']

['What topics are studied by positive psychologists?', 'Some of the topics studied by positive psychologists include altruism and empathy, creativity, forgiveness and compassion, the importance of positive emotions, enhancement of immune system functioning, savoring the fleeting moments of life, and strengthening virtues as a way to increase authentic happiness (Compton, 2005).']

['What are some of the recent efforts in the field of positive psychology?', 'Recent efforts in the field of positive psychology have focused on extending its principles toward peace and well-being at the level of the global community.']

['How is this achieved?', 'In a war-torn world in which conflict, hatred, and distrust are common, such an extended “positive peace psychology” could have important implications for understanding how to overcome oppression and work toward global peace (Cohrs, Christie, White, & Das, 2013).']

['What are some studies that have been made?', 'Taking a cue from positive psychology, extensive research over the last 10-15 years has examined the importance of positive psychological attributes in physical well-being.']

['Did it have any positive effects?', 'Qualities that help promote psychological well-being (e.g., having meaning and purpose in life, a sense of autonomy, positive emotions, and satisfaction with life) are linked with a range of favorable health outcomes (especially improved cardiovascular health) mainly through their relationships with biological functions and health behaviors (such as diet, physical activity, and sleep quality) (Boehm & Kubzansky, 2012).']

['What is the quality that has received attention?', 'The quality that has received attention is positive affect, which refers to pleasurable engagement with the environment, such as happiness, joy, enthusiasm, alertness, and excitement (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988).']

['What are the characteristics of positive affect?', 'The characteristics of positive affect, as with negative affect (discussed earlier), can be brief, long-lasting, or trait-like (Pressman & Cohen, 2005).']

['Did they use positive psychology to treat any mental or physical diseases?', 'Independent of age, gender, and income, positive affect is associated with greater social connectedness, emotional and practical support, adaptive coping efforts, and lower depression; it is also associated with longevity and favorable physiological functioning (Steptoe, O’Donnell, Marmot, & Wardle, 2008).']
['What health issues can positive affect lead to?', 'Positive affect also serves as a protective factor against heart disease.']

['Did you find any studies that proved this?', 'In a 10-year study of Nova Scotians, the rate of heart disease was 22% lower for each one-point increase on the measure of positive affect, from 1 (no positive affect expressed) to 5 (extreme positive affect) (Davidson, Mostofsky, & Whang, 2010).']
['What is another example of how this affects our health?', 'In terms of our health, the expression, “don’t worry, be happy” is helpful advice indeed.']

['What has been much work suggesting that optimism—the general tendency to look on the bright side of things—is also a significant predictor of positive health outcomes?', 'There has also been much work suggesting that optimism—the general tendency to look on the bright side of things—is also a significant predictor of positive health outcomes.']
['What are positive affect and optimism related to?', 'Although positive affect and optimism are related in some ways, they are not the same (Pressman & Cohen, 2005).']

['what is the difference between the two?', 'Whereas positive affect is mostly concerned with positive feeling states, optimism has been regarded as a generalized tendency to expect that good things will happen (Chang, 2001).']

['How is optimism different from positive affect?', 'It has also been conceptualized as a tendency to view life’s stressors and difficulties as temporary and external to oneself (Peterson & Steen, 2002).']

['Can we learn anything about optimism?', 'Numerous studies over the years have consistently shown that optimism is linked to longevity, healthier behaviors, fewer postsurgical complications, better immune functioning among men with prostate cancer, and better treatment adherence (Rasmussen & Wallio, 2008).']

['what other things can optimism do?', 'Further, optimistic people report fewer physical symptoms, less pain, better physical functioning, and are less likely to be rehospitalized following heart surgery (Rasmussen, Scheier, & Greenhouse, 2009).']
['What does the study material tell you?', 'Another factor that seems to be important in fostering a deep sense of well-being is the ability to derive flow from the things we do in life.']
['What is flow?', 'Flow is described as a particular experience that is so engaging and engrossing that it becomes worth doing for its own sake (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997).']

['What are some activities you can experience this?', 'It is usually related to creative endeavors and leisure activities, but it can also be experienced by workers who like their jobs or students who love studying (Csikszentmihalyi, 1999).']
['What is the notion of flow?', 'Many of us instantly recognize the notion of flow.']
['What is the notion of flow?', 'In fact, the term derived from respondents’ spontaneous use of the term when asked to describe how it felt when what they were doing was going well.']
['What does flow involve?', 'When people experience flow, they become involved in an activity to the point where they feel they lose themselves in the activity.']

['What are some of the other aspects of flow?', 'They effortlessly maintain their concentration and focus, they feel as though they have complete control of their actions, and time seems to pass more quickly than usual (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997).']

['How is flow beneficial to your well being?', 'Flow is considered a pleasurable experience, and it typically occurs when people are engaged in challenging activities that require skills and knowledge they know they possess.']
['What are some things you can do in flow?', 'For example, people would be more likely report flow experiences in relation to their work or hobbies than in relation to eating.']

['Are there any other aspects of flow?', 'When asked the question, “Do you ever get involved in something so deeply that nothing else seems to matter, and you lose track of time?” about 20% of Americans and Europeans report having these flow-like experiences regularly (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997).']
['What is the notion of flow?', 'Although wealth and material possessions are nice to have, the notion of flow suggests that neither are prerequisites for a happy and fulfilling life.']

['What kind of activities would be a part of this?', 'Finding an activity that you are truly enthusiastic about, something so absorbing that doing it is reward itself (whether it be playing tennis, studying Arabic, writing children’s novels, or cooking lavish meals) is perhaps the real key.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'According to Csikszentmihalyi (1999), creating conditions that make flow experiences possible should be a top social and political priority.']
['What are the scientific research endeavors in this document?', 'In an ideal world, scientific research endeavors should inform us on how to bring about a better world for all people.']

['What does positive psychology promise to be instrumental in helping us understand?', 'The field of positive psychology promises to be instrumental in helping us understand what truly builds hope, optimism, happiness, healthy relationships, flow, and genuine personal fulfillment.']

['What is a mental disorder?', "According to the American Psychiatric Association, a psychological disorder, or mental disorder, is “a syndrome characterized by clinically significant disturbance in an individual's cognition, emotion regulation, or behavior that reflects a dysfunction in the psychological, biological, or developmental processes underlying mental functioning."]
["How do these psychological disorders impact one's daily life?", 'Mental disorders are usually associated with significant distress in social, occupational, or other important activities” (2013).']

['What is the study of psychological disorders, including their symptoms, etiology (i.e., their causes), and treatment?', 'Psychopathology is the study of psychological disorders, including their symptoms, etiology (i.e., their causes), and treatment.']
['What does the term psychopathology mean?', 'The term psychopathology can also refer to the manifestation of a psychological disorder.']

['Why is this important?', 'Although consensus can be difficult, it is extremely important for mental health professionals to agree on what kinds of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are truly abnormal in the sense that they genuinely indicate the presence of psychopathology.']

['Are there certain patterns of behavior that are viewed as abnormal?', 'Certain patterns of behavior and inner experience can easily be labeled as abnormal and clearly signify some kind of psychological disturbance.']

['What are some examples of these abnormal patterns?', 'The person who washes their hands 40 times per day and the person who claims to hear the voices of demons exhibit behaviors and inner experiences that most would regard as abnormal: beliefs and behaviors that suggest the existence of a psychological disorder.']

['Are these patterns considered normal or abnormal?', 'But, consider the nervousness a young man feels when talking to an attractive person or the loneliness and longing for home a first-year student experiences during her first semester of college—these feelings may not be regularly present, but they fall in the range of normal.']

['What would psychologists work to distinguish from inner experiences and behaviors that are merely situational, idiosyncratic, or unconventional?', 'Psychologists work to distinguish psychological disorders from inner experiences and behaviors that are merely situational, idiosyncratic, or unconventional.']

['What are some misconceptions about mental health issues?', 'Mental health issues are often incorrectly viewed as less important than physical illnesses, and sometimes people are blamed or otherwise stigmatized for their condition.']

['What other misconceptions do you think about mental health issues?', 'People with mental illnesses did not choose or create their illness, and cannot simply manage it through positive thinking or other attitudinal changes.']

['What are some important facts about mental health issues?', 'Diagnosis, treatment, and support are all necessary, and all must be considered with respect and sensitivity to the extremely challenging nature of mental illness.']

['What is the most important factor in mental health?', 'While not everyone experiencing difficulty has a psychological disorder, mental health is critical to our ability to function in our relationships, education, and work.']

['Is there anything else interesting about mental health?', 'It is important that people talk with qualified professionals if they are having persistent feelings or experiences in line with the descriptions below; the discussion may or may not lead to a diagnosis, but as with physical illnesses, one has a better chance at success if they raise the issues with doctors or other experts.']

['What is the simplest approach to conceptualizing psychological disorders?', 'Perhaps the simplest approach to conceptualizing psychological disorders is to label behaviors, thoughts, and inner experiences that are atypical, distressful, dysfunctional, and sometimes even dangerous, as signs of a disorder.']
['What are some examples of how you might feel when you are rejected?', 'For example, if you ask a classmate for a date and you are rejected, you probably would feel a little dejected.']
['How would you feel about this?', 'Such feelings would be normal.']

['How is that different from being extremely depressed?', 'If you felt extremely depressed—so much so that you lost interest in activities, had difficulty eating or sleeping, felt utterly worthless, and contemplated suicide—your feelings would be atypical, would deviate from the norm, and could signify the presence of a psychological disorder.']
['What does the definition say?', 'Just because something is atypical, however, does not necessarily mean it is disordered.']

['How are atypical characteristics defined?', 'For example, only about 4% of people in the United States have red hair, so red hair is considered an atypical characteristic (Figure 15.2), but it is not considered disordered, it’s just unusual.']
['Are red hair and unusual in the other countries?', 'And it is less unusual in Scotland, where approximately 13% of the population has red hair (“DNA Project Aims,” 2012).']

['What are atypical characteristics defined as?', 'As you will learn, some disorders, although not exactly typical, are far from atypical, and the rates in which they appear in the population are surprisingly high.']

['What is the definition of a psychological disorder?', 'Using this criterion, a person who walks around a subway platform wearing a heavy winter coat in July while screaming obscenities at strangers may be considered as exhibiting symptoms of a psychological disorder.']
['What did you find interesting about the characters?', 'Their actions and clothes violate socially accepted rules governing appropriate dress and behavior; these characteristics are atypical.']
['What is the main point of this document?', 'Violating cultural expectations is not, in and of itself, a satisfactory means of identifying the presence of a psychological disorder.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Since behavior varies from one culture to another, what may be expected and considered appropriate in one culture may not be viewed as such in other cultures.']

['What are some examples of different cultural norms?', 'For example, returning a stranger’s smile is expected in the United States because a pervasive social norm dictates that we reciprocate friendly gestures.']

['How can a person be considered socially awkward for violating that expectation?', 'A person who refuses to acknowledge such gestures might be considered socially awkward—perhaps even disordered—for violating this expectation.']
['What do some people expect when they return a smile?', 'However, such expectations are not universally shared.']
['What are some cultural differences between Japan and the US?', 'Cultural expectations in Japan involve showing reserve, restraint, and a concern for maintaining privacy around strangers.']
['What does this tell us?', 'Japanese people are generally unresponsive to smiles from strangers (Patterson et al., 2007).']
['What are some examples of eye contact?', 'Eye contact provides another example.']
['What does eye contact mean in the United States and Europe?', 'In the United States and Europe, eye contact with others typically signifies honesty and attention.']
['What does this tell us?', 'However, most Latin-American, Asian, and African cultures interpret direct eye contact as rude, confrontational, and aggressive (Pazain, 2010).']
['What is this all mean?', 'Thus, someone who makes eye contact with you could be considered appropriate and respectful or brazen and offensive, depending on your culture (Figure 15.3).']

['What are the cultural expectations?', 'Hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not physically present) in Western societies is a violation of cultural expectations, and a person who reports such inner experiences is readily labeled as psychologically disordered.']
['How do people perceive these?', 'In other cultures, visions that, for example, pertain to future events may be regarded as normal experiences that are positively valued (Bourguignon, 1970).']

['What might be considered typical in a society at one time may no longer be viewed this way later, similar to how fashion trends from one era may elicit quizzical looks decades later?', 'Finally, it is important to recognize that cultural norms change over time: what might be considered typical in a society at one time may no longer be viewed this way later, similar to how fashion trends from one era may elicit quizzical looks decades later—imagine how a headband, legwarmers, and the big hair of the 1980s would go over on your campus today.']
['What is it about?', 'Many efforts have been made to identify the specific dimensions of psychological disorders, yet none is entirely satisfactory.']

['What is the universal definition of psychological disorder?', 'No universal definition of psychological disorder exists that can apply to all situations in which a disorder is thought to be present (Zachar & Kendler, 2007).']

['What is the definition of harmful dysfunction?', 'However, one of the more influential conceptualizations was proposed by Wakefield (1992), who defined psychological disorder as a harmful dysfunction.']

['What does he state about internal mechanisms?', 'Wakefield argued that natural internal mechanisms—that is, psychological processes honed by evolution, such as cognition, perception, and learning—have important functions, such as enabling us to experience the world the way others do and to engage in rational thought, problem solving, and communication.']

['What does learning allow us to do?', 'For example, learning allows us to associate a fear with a potential danger in such a way that the intensity of fear is roughly equal to the degree of actual danger.']
['What does dysfunction mean?', 'Dysfunction occurs when an internal mechanism breaks down and can no longer perform its normal function.']
['Is there anything else to note?', 'But, the presence of a dysfunction by itself does not determine a disorder.']

['What is the most important thing to remember about the dysfunction?', 'The dysfunction must be harmful in that it leads to negative consequences for the individual or for others, as judged by the standards of the individual’s culture.']

['What is the harm that can be caused by a substance?', 'The harm may include significant internal anguish (e.g., high levels of anxiety or depression) or problems in day-to-day living (e.g., in one’s social or work life).']
['What kind of harmful dysfunction is this?', 'To illustrate, Janet has an extreme fear of spiders.']

['What is going on with Janet?', 'Janet’s fear might be considered a dysfunction in that it signals that the internal mechanism of learning is not working correctly (i.e., a faulty process prevents Janet from appropriately associating the magnitude of fear with the actual threat posed by spiders).']

['What kind of problems is this having?', 'Janet’s fear of spiders has a significant negative influence on daily life: she avoids all situations in which she suspects spiders to be present (e.g., the basement or a friend’s home), and she quit her job last month because she saw a spider in the restroom at work and is now unemployed.']

['What is the harmful dysfunction model?', 'According to the harmful dysfunction model, Janet’s condition would signify a disorder because (a) there is a dysfunction in an internal mechanism, and (b) the dysfunction has resulted in harmful consequences.']

['How is this model different from other models?', 'Similar to how the symptoms of physical illness reflect dysfunctions in biological processes, the symptoms of psychological disorders presumably reflect dysfunctions in mental processes.']

['Are there any other interesting things you found out?', 'The internal mechanism component of this model is especially appealing because it implies that disorders may occur through a breakdown of biological functions that govern various psychological processes, thus supporting contemporary neurobiological models of psychological disorders (Fabrega, 2007).']

['What is the harmful dysfunction model?', 'Many of the features of the harmful dysfunction model are incorporated in a formal definition of psychological disorder developed by the American Psychiatric Association (APA).']
['What is the definition of a psychological disorder?', 'According to the APA (2013), a psychological disorder is a condition that is said to consist of the following:']
['What are some of the terms used to describe schizophrenia?', 'There are significant disturbances in thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.']

['What does disturbed mean?', 'A person must experience inner states (e.g., thoughts and/or feelings) and exhibit behaviors that are clearly disturbed—that is, unusual, but in a negative, self-defeating way.']
['what else does troubling states mean?', 'Often, such disturbances are troubling to those around the individual who experiences them.']

['what is one example of a troubling states?', 'For example, an individual who is uncontrollably preoccupied by thoughts of germs spends hours each day bathing, has inner experiences, and displays behaviors that most would consider atypical and negative (disturbed) and that would likely be troubling to family members.']
['What is the basis of this definition?', 'The disturbances reflect some kind of biological, psychological, or developmental dysfunction.']

['what does that mean?', 'Disturbed patterns of inner experiences and behaviors should reflect some flaw (dysfunction) in the internal biological, psychological, and developmental mechanisms that lead to normal, healthy psychological functioning.']
['What kind of dysfunctions are there?', 'For example, the hallucinations observed in schizophrenia could be a sign of brain abnormalities.']
['What is distress?', 'The disturbances lead to significant distress or disability in one’s life.']

['what is disability?', 'A person’s inner experiences and behaviors are considered to reflect a psychological disorder if they cause the person considerable distress, or greatly impair their ability to function as a normal individual (often referred to as functional impairment, or occupational and social impairment).']

['what is an example of impairment?', 'As an illustration, a person’s fear of social situations might be so distressing that it causes the person to avoid all social situations (e.g., preventing that person from being able to attend class or apply for a job).']
['What are atypical responses?', 'The disturbances do not reflect expected or culturally approved responses to certain events.']
['What does that mean?', 'Disturbances in thoughts, feelings, and behaviors must be socially unacceptable responses to certain events that often happen in life.']

['What are some examples of a person experiencing great sadness?', 'For example, it is perfectly natural (and expected) that a person would experience great sadness and might wish to be left alone following the death of a close family member.']
['What happens when people react as expected?', 'Because such reactions are in some ways culturally expected, the individual would not be assumed to signify a mental disorder.']

['What is the essential criterion for defining disorder?', 'Some believe that there is no essential criterion or set of criteria that can definitively distinguish all cases of disorder from nondisorder (Lilienfeld & Marino, 1999).']

['What is the universal agreement on where the boundary is between disordered and not disordered?', 'In truth, no single approach to defining a psychological disorder is adequate by itself, nor is there universal agreement on where the boundary is between disordered and not disordered.']

['What does the author mean by unwanted thoughts?', 'From time to time we all experience anxiety, unwanted thoughts, and moments of sadness; our behavior at other times may not make much sense to ourselves or to others.']

['What criteria are used to determine if an inner experience or behavior is disordered?', 'These inner experiences and behaviors can vary in their intensity, but are only considered disordered when they are highly disturbing to us and/or others, suggest a dysfunction in normal mental functioning, and are associated with significant distress or disability in social or occupational activities.']
['What is a first step in the study of psychological disorders?', 'A first step in the study of psychological disorders is carefully and systematically discerning significant signs and symptoms.']
['What is the process of arriving at a proper diagnosis?', 'Arriving at a proper diagnosis—that is, appropriately identifying and labeling a set of defined symptoms—is absolutely crucial.']

['What can this process do?', 'This process enables professionals to use a common language with others in the field and aids in communication about the disorder with the patient, colleagues and the public.']
['What is the most important factor in determining the proper treatment for a patient?', 'A proper diagnosis is an essential element to guide proper and successful treatment.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'For these reasons, classification systems that organize psychological disorders systematically are necessary.']

['What is the name of the book that is used by most mental health professionals in the United States?', 'Although a number of classification systems have been developed over time, the one that is used by most mental health professionals in the United States is the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association (2013).']
["What's the difference between the APA and DSM?", '(Note that the American Psychiatric Association differs from the American Psychological Association; both are abbreviated APA.)']

['What is interesting about the DSM?', 'The first edition of the DSM, published in 1952, classified psychological disorders according to a format developed by the U.S. Army during World War II (Clegg, 2012).']
['What has the DSM undergone in the years since it was first published?', 'In the years since, the DSM has undergone numerous revisions and editions.']
['What are the recent editions of the DSM?', 'The most recent edition, published in 2013, is the DSM-5 (APA, 2013).']
['What are some of the disorders that are included in the DSM-5?', 'The DSM-5 includes many categories of disorders (e.g., anxiety disorders, depressive disorders, and dissociative disorders).']

['What is the DSM?', 'Each disorder is described in detail, including an overview of the disorder (diagnostic features), specific symptoms required for diagnosis (diagnostic criteria), prevalence information (what percent of the population is thought to be afflicted with the disorder), and risk factors associated with the disorder.']

['What is the prevalence data?', 'Figure 15.4 shows lifetime prevalence rates—the percentage of people in a population who develop a disorder in their lifetime—of various psychological disorders among U.S. adults.']
['What is the most important piece of data in the article?', 'These data were based on a national sample of 9,282 U.S. residents (National Comorbidity Survey, 2007).']
['What is one of the topics that are related to the DSM-5?', 'The DSM-5 also provides information about comorbidity; the co-occurrence of two disorders.']

['What is an example of comorbidity?', 'For example, the DSM-5 mentions that 41% of people with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) also meet the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (Figure 15.5).']

['What is comorbidity?', 'Problematic substance use is highly comorbid with other mental illnesses; 6 out of 10 people who have a substance use disorder also suffer from another form of mental illness (National Institute on Drug Abuse [NIDA], 2007).']
['What has changed since its first publication?', 'The DSM has changed considerably in the half-century since it was originally published.']
['Why did it change?', 'The first two editions of the DSM, for example, listed homosexuality as a disorder; however, in 1973, the APA voted to remove it from the manual (Silverstein, 2009).']

['What did the DSM-III not list as a disorder?', 'While the DSM-III did not list homosexuality as a disorder, it introduced a new diagnosis, ego-dystonic homosexuality, which emphasized same-sex arousal that the patient viewed as interfering with desired heterosexual relationships and causing distress for the individual.']
['What was the new diagnosis?', 'This new diagnosis was considered by many as a compromise to appease those who viewed homosexuality as a mental illness.']
['What did people feel about it?', "Other professionals questioned how appropriate it was to have a separate diagnosis that described the content of an individual's distress."]
['What was the most recent complaint against it?', 'In 1986, the diagnosis was removed from the DSM-III-R (Herek, 2012).']

['What else did it change?', 'Additionally, beginning with the DSM-III in 1980, mental disorders have been described in much greater detail, and the number of diagnosable conditions has grown steadily, as has the size of the manual itself.']

['What was the manual comprised of?', 'DSM-I included 106 diagnoses and was 130 total pages, whereas DSM-III included more than 2 times as many diagnoses (265) and was nearly seven times its size (886 total pages) (Mayes & Horowitz, 2005).']
['Was DSM-5 longer than DSM-IV?', 'Although DSM-5 is longer than DSM-IV, the volume includes only 237 disorders, a decrease from the 297 disorders that were listed in DSM-IV.']

['What else changed in the manual?', 'The latest edition, DSM-5, includes revisions in the organization and naming of categories and in the diagnostic criteria for various disorders (Regier, Kuhl, & Kupfer, 2012), while emphasizing careful consideration of the importance of gender and cultural difference in the expression of various symptoms (Fisher, 2010).']

['What might be overridden with establishing new diagnoses?', 'Some believe that establishing new diagnoses might overpathologize the human condition by turning common human problems into mental illnesses (The Associated Press, 2013).']

['Why are they sceptical about this?', 'Indeed, the finding that nearly half of all Americans will meet the criteria for a DSM disorder at some point in their life (Kessler et al., 2005) likely fuels much of this skepticism.']

['What was the biggest issue with the DSM-5?', 'The DSM-5 is also criticized on the grounds that its diagnostic criteria have been loosened, thereby threatening to “turn our current diagnostic inflation into diagnostic hyperinflation” (Frances, 2012, para. 22).']
['What was a specific issue?', 'For example, DSM-IV specified that the symptoms of major depressive disorder must not be attributable to normal bereavement (loss of a loved one).']

["Why didn't they consider that?", 'The DSM-5, however, has removed this bereavement exclusion, essentially meaning that grief and sadness after a loved one’s death can constitute major depressive disorder.']
['What is the International Classification of Diseases?', 'A second classification system, the International Classification of Diseases (ICD), is also widely recognized.']
['What organization created this?', 'Published by the World Health Organization (WHO), the ICD was developed in Europe shortly after World War II and, like the DSM, has been revised several times.']

['Was the ICD created for psychological disorder?', 'The categories of psychological disorders in both the DSM and ICD are similar, as are the criteria for specific disorders; however, some differences exist.']

['What is the ICD used for?', 'Although the ICD is used for clinical purposes, this tool is also used to examine the general health of populations and to monitor the prevalence of diseases and other health problems internationally (WHO, 2013).']

['What is the latest edition of the ICD?', 'The ICD is in its 10th edition (ICD-10); however, efforts are now underway to develop a new edition (ICD-11) that, in conjunction with the changes in DSM-5, will help harmonize the two classification systems as much as possible (APA, 2013).']

['What is the difference between the ICD and the DSM?', 'A study that compared the use of the two classification systems found that worldwide the ICD is more frequently used for clinical diagnosis, whereas the DSM is more valued for research (Mezzich, 2002).']

["What's a noteworthy fact about the DSM?", 'Most research findings concerning the etiology and treatment of psychological disorders are based on criteria set forth in the DSM (Oltmanns & Castonguay, 2013).']
['Why is the DSM considered better for research?', 'The DSM also includes more explicit disorder criteria, along with an extensive and helpful explanatory text (Regier et al., 2012).']
['Are there any more interesting things about the article?', 'The DSM is the classification system of choice among U.S. mental health professionals, and this chapter is based on the DSM paradigm.']
['What are the disorders?', 'As these disorders are outlined, please bear two things in mind.']
['What are the two things that psychological disorders represent?', 'First, remember that psychological disorders represent extremes of inner experience and behavior.']

['What is the second thing?', 'If, while reading about these disorders, you feel that these descriptions begin to personally characterize you, do not worry—this moment of enlightenment probably means nothing more than you have had a range of experiences and emotions.']
['What are the range of experiences?', 'Each of us experiences episodes of sadness, anxiety, and preoccupation with certain thoughts—times when we do not quite feel ourselves.']
['Are these episodes problematic?', 'These episodes should not be considered problematic unless the accompanying thoughts and behaviors become extreme and have a disruptive effect on one’s life.']
