['What is the second thing that is biased?', 'Second, understand that people with psychological disorders are far more than just embodiments of their disorders.']

['What is the discrimination against people with these disorders?', 'We do not use terms such as schizophrenics, depressives, or phobics because they are labels that objectify people who have these conditions, thus promoting biased and disparaging assumptions about them.']

['What is the difference between a psychological disorder and a mental illness?', 'It is important to remember that a psychological disorder is not what a person is; it is something that a person has—through no fault of their own.']

['What is the case with psychological disorders?', 'As is the case with cancer or diabetes, those with psychological disorders suffer debilitating, often painful conditions that are not of their own choosing.']
['What is the final argument?', 'These individuals deserve to be viewed and treated with compassion, understanding, and dignity.']

['What is the content of this section about?', 'Scientists, mental health professionals, and cultural healers may adopt different perspectives in attempting to understand or explain the underlying mechanisms that contribute to the development of a psychological disorder.']
['What perspective is used in explaining a psychological disorder?', 'The specific perspective used in explaining a psychological disorder is extremely important.']
['How are the perspectives different?', 'Each perspective explains psychological disorders, their causes or etiology, and effective treatments from a different viewpoint.']
['What is different about each perspective?', 'Different perspectives provide alternate ways for how to think about the nature of psychopathology.']

['What are supernatural perspectives of psychological disorders?', 'For centuries, psychological disorders were viewed from a supernatural perspective: attributed to a force beyond scientific understanding.']

['What other factors contribute to supernatural perspectives of psychological disorders?', 'Those afflicted were thought to be practitioners of black magic or possessed by spirits (Figure 15.6) (Maher & Maher, 1985).']

['What was the view of black magic?', 'For example, convents throughout Europe in the 16th and 17th centuries reported hundreds of nuns falling into a state of frenzy in which the afflicted foamed at the mouth, screamed and convulsed, sexually propositioned priests, and confessed to having carnal relations with devils or Christ.']

['What were these events explained as?', 'Although, today, these cases would suggest serious mental illness; at the time, these events were routinely explained as possession by devilish forces (Waller, 2009a).']
['What else did people think?', 'Similarly, grievous fits by young girls are believed to have precipitated the witch panic in New England late in the 17th century (Demos, 1983).']

['What is the current thought of supernatural causes of mental illness?', 'Such beliefs in supernatural causes of mental illness are still held in some societies today; for example, beliefs that supernatural forces cause mental illness are common in some cultures in modern-day Nigeria (Aghukwa, 2012).']

['What is the biological perspective?', 'The biological perspective views psychological disorders as linked to biological phenomena, such as genetic factors, chemical imbalances, and brain abnormalities; it has gained considerable attention and acceptance in recent decades (Wyatt & Midkiff, 2006).']

['Did the evidence indicate this?', 'Evidence from many sources indicates that most psychological disorders have a genetic component; in fact, there is little dispute that some disorders are largely due to genetic factors.']
['What is the graph in Figure 15.8 about?', 'The graph in Figure 15.8 shows heritability estimates for schizophrenia.']
['What kind of research has been done?', 'Findings such as these have led many of today’s researchers to search for specific genes and genetic mutations that contribute to mental disorders.']

['what else has been discovered?', 'Also, sophisticated neural imaging technology in recent decades has revealed how abnormalities in brain structure and function might be directly involved in many disorders, and advances in our understanding of neurotransmitters and hormones have yielded insights into their possible connections.']
['Has this helped you?', 'The biological perspective is currently thriving in the study of psychological disorders.']
['Did you have any interesting information?', 'Despite advances in understanding the biological basis of psychological disorders, the psychosocial perspective is still very important.']
['What was the perspective based on?', 'This perspective emphasizes the importance of learning, stress, faulty and self-defeating thinking patterns, and environmental factors.']

['What do you think is the best way to think about psychological disorders?', 'Perhaps the best way to think about psychological disorders, then, is to view them as originating from a combination of biological and psychological processes.']
['What do the researchers say about the causes of autism?', 'Many develop not from a single cause, but from a delicate fusion between partly biological and partly psychosocial factors.']
['What is the diathesis-stress model?', 'The diathesis-stress model (Zuckerman, 1999) integrates biological and psychosocial factors to predict the likelihood of a disorder.']

['What can stress lead to?', 'This diathesis-stress model suggests that people with an underlying predisposition for a disorder (i.e., a diathesis) are more likely than others to develop a disorder when faced with adverse environmental or psychological events (i.e., stress), such as childhood maltreatment, negative life events, trauma, and so on.']

['What do these factors contribute to?', 'A diathesis is not always a biological vulnerability to an illness; some diatheses may be psychological (e.g., a tendency to think about life events in a pessimistic, self-defeating way).']

['What is the key assumption of the diathesis-stress model?', 'The key assumption of the diathesis-stress model is that both factors, diathesis and stress, are necessary in the development of a disorder.']

['what is the stress model?', 'Different models explore the relationship between the two factors: the level of stress needed to produce the disorder is inversely proportional to the level of diathesis.']
['How does anxiety affect us?', 'Everybody experiences anxiety from time to time.']
['What is the difference between anxiety and fear?', 'Although anxiety is closely related to fear, the two states possess important differences.']

['Are there other differences?', 'Fear involves an instantaneous reaction to an imminent threat, whereas anxiety involves apprehension, avoidance, and cautiousness regarding a potential threat, danger, or other negative event (Craske, 1999).']
['Are we afraid of anxiety?', 'While anxiety is unpleasant to most people, it is important to our health, safety, and well-being.']

['What are some ways in which anxiety can help us?', 'Anxiety motivates us to take actions—such as preparing for exams, watching our weight, showing up to work on time—that enable us to avert potential future problems.']
['What other ways does anxiety help?', 'Anxiety also motivates us to avoid certain things—such as running up debts and engaging in illegal activities—that could lead to future trouble.']
['What is another factor in anxiety?', 'Most individuals’ level and duration of anxiety approximates the magnitude of the potential threat they face.']

['How else can anxiety affect us?', 'For example, suppose a student who came to the U.S. as a “Dreamer” (someone whose parents didn’t lawfully immigrate) is concerned about the possibility of being unable to continue in the university program or of losing access to academic financial aid, due to changes and litigation around the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.']
['How would they feel?', 'This person likely would experience anxiety of greater intensity and duration than would a 21-year-old junior who entered college as a birthright citizen.']

['What happens when anxiety is too much?', 'Some people experience anxiety that is excessive, persistent, and greatly out of proportion to the actual threat; if one’s anxiety has a disruptive influence on one’s life, this is a strong indicator that the individual is experiencing an anxiety disorder.']

['What is a psychiatric term for excessive and persistent fear and anxiety, and by related disturbances in behavior?', 'Anxiety disorders are characterized by excessive and persistent fear and anxiety, and by related disturbances in behavior (APA, 2013).']
['What is the most common cause of distress?', 'Although anxiety is universally experienced, anxiety disorders cause considerable distress.']

['Are anxiety disorders common?', 'As a group, anxiety disorders are common: approximately 25%–30% of the U.S. population meets the criteria for at least one anxiety disorder during their lifetime (Kessler et al., 2005).']

['Are anxiety disorders more common in women than men?', 'Also, these disorders appear to be much more common in women than they are in men; within a 12-month period, around 23% of women and 14% of men will experience at least one anxiety disorder (National Comorbidity Survey, 2007).']

['What are some of the things that we should know about anxiety disorders?', 'Anxiety disorders are the most frequently occurring class of mental disorders and are often comorbid with each other and with other mental disorders (Kessler, Ruscio, Shear, & Wittchen, 2009).']
['What is the Greek word for fear?', 'Phobia is a Greek word that means fear.']

['What is specific phobia?', 'A person diagnosed with a specific phobia (formerly known as simple phobia) experiences excessive, distressing, and persistent fear or anxiety about a specific object or situation (such as animals, enclosed spaces, elevators, or flying) (APA, 2013).']

['Why do some people have a specific phobia?', 'Even though people realize their level of fear and anxiety in relation to the phobic stimulus is irrational, some people with a specific phobia may go to great lengths to avoid the phobic stimulus (the object or situation that triggers the fear and anxiety).']
['How does the fear make life for them?', 'Typically, the fear and anxiety a phobic stimulus elicits is disruptive to the person’s life.']
['What does the fear do to a person?', 'For example, a man with a phobia of flying might refuse to accept a job that requires frequent air travel, thus negatively affecting his career.']

['What are some of the phobias that have been encountered by clinicians?', 'Clinicians who have worked with people who have specific phobias have encountered many kinds of phobias, some of which are shown in Table 15.1.']

['What are some common phobias?', 'Specific phobias are common; in the United States, around 12.5% of the population will meet the criteria for a specific phobia at some point in their lifetime (Kessler et al., 2005).']
['What is agoraphobia?', 'One type of phobia, agoraphobia, is listed in the DSM-5 as a separate anxiety disorder.']

['What is the symptom of agoraphobia?', 'Agoraphobia, which literally means “fear of the marketplace,” is characterized by intense fear, anxiety, and avoidance of situations in which it might be difficult to escape or receive help if one experiences symptoms of a panic attack (a state of extreme anxiety that we will discuss shortly).']

['Are there specific situations people avoid?', 'These situations include public transportation, open spaces (parking lots), enclosed spaces (stores), crowds, or being outside the home alone (APA, 2013).']
['What is the prevalence of agoraphobia?', 'About 1.4% of Americans experience agoraphobia during their lifetime (Kessler et al., 2005).']
['What is the content of our study material about?', 'Many theories suggest that phobias develop through learning.']
['What is the three major learning pathways?', 'Rachman (1977) proposed that phobias can be acquired through three major learning pathways.']
['What is the first pathway through which a person can learn?', 'The first pathway is through classical conditioning.']

['What is classical conditioning?', 'As you may recall, classical conditioning is a form of learning in which a previously neutral stimulus is paired with an unconditioned stimulus (UCS) that reflexively elicits an unconditioned response (UCR), eliciting the same response through its association with the unconditioned stimulus.']
['What is the response called?', 'The response is called a conditioned response (CR).']
['How does the past association help?', 'For example, a child who has been bitten by a dog may come to fear dogs because of a past association with pain.']
['What is the UCS and the fear it elicits?', 'In this case, the dog bite is the UCS and the fear it elicits is the UCR.']

['How is that learned?', 'Because a dog was associated with the bite, any dog may come to serve as a conditioned stimulus, thereby eliciting fear; the fear the child experiences around dogs, then, becomes a CR.']
['What is the second pathway of phobia acquisition?', 'The second pathway of phobia acquisition is through vicarious learning, such as modeling.']
['How does this work?', 'For example, a child who observes their cousin react fearfully to spiders may later express the same fears, even though spiders have never presented any danger to them.']
['What can you tell me about this phenomenon?', 'This phenomenon has been observed in both humans and nonhuman primates (Olsson & Phelps, 2007).']
['Did you find anything interesting?', 'A study of laboratory-reared monkeys readily acquired a fear of snakes after observing wild-reared monkeys react fearfully to snakes (Mineka & Cook, 1993).']
['What is the third pathway?', 'The third pathway is through verbal transmission or information.']

['What does the third pathway lead to?', 'For example, a child whose parents, siblings, friends, and classmates constantly tell them how disgusting and dangerous snakes are may come to acquire a fear of snakes.']

['What do you find interesting about the article?', 'Interestingly, people are more likely to develop phobias of things that do not represent much actual danger to themselves, such as animals and heights, and are less likely to develop phobias toward things that present legitimate danger in contemporary society, such as motorcycles and weapons (Öhman & Mineka, 2001).']

['What is one theory that suggests that the human brain is evolutionarily predisposed to more readily associate certain objects or situations with fear?', 'One theory suggests that the human brain is evolutionarily predisposed to more readily associate certain objects or situations with fear (Seligman, 1971).']

['What is an example of this?', 'This theory argues that throughout our evolutionary history, our ancestors associated certain stimuli (e.g., snakes, spiders, heights, and thunder) with potential danger.']
["What does it mean that we've adapted?", 'As time progressed, the mind has become adapted to more readily develop fears of these things than of others.']

['What is the evidence that we have evolved fear?', 'Experimental evidence has consistently demonstrated that conditioned fears develop more readily to fear-relevant stimuli (images of snakes and spiders) than to fear-irrelevant stimuli (images of flowers and berries) (Öhman & Mineka, 2001).']
['Is this theory known to be universal?', 'Such prepared learning has also been shown to occur in monkeys.']

['What kind of research is done on monkeys?', 'In one study (Cook & Mineka, 1989), monkeys watched videotapes of model monkeys reacting fearfully to either fear-relevant stimuli (toy snakes or a toy crocodile) or fear-irrelevant stimuli (flowers or a toy rabbit).']
['What happened to the monkeys after they were exposed?', 'The observer monkeys developed fears of the fear-relevant stimuli but not the fear-irrelevant stimuli.']

['What is the name of the journal that helped with our study?', 'Social anxiety disorder (formerly called social phobia) is characterized by extreme and persistent fear or anxiety and avoidance of social situations in which the person could potentially be evaluated negatively by others (APA, 2013).']

['What is the most important thing you learned from this article?', 'As with specific phobias, social anxiety disorder is common in the United States; a little over 12% of all Americans experience social anxiety disorder during their lifetime (Kessler et al., 2005).']

['What are the symptoms of social anxiety disorder?', 'The heart of the fear and anxiety in social anxiety disorder is the person’s concern that they may act in a humiliating or embarrassing way, such as appearing foolish, showing symptoms of anxiety (blushing), or doing or saying something that might lead to rejection (such as offending others).']

['What kind of social situations in which individuals with social anxiety disorder usually have problems include public speaking, having a conversation, meeting strangers, eating in restaurants, and, in some cases, using public restrooms?', 'The kinds of social situations in which individuals with social anxiety disorder usually have problems include public speaking, having a conversation, meeting strangers, eating in restaurants, and, in some cases, using public restrooms.']

['What happens to people with social anxiety disorder?', 'Although many people become anxious in social situations like public speaking, the fear, anxiety, and avoidance experienced in social anxiety disorder are highly distressing and lead to serious impairments in life.']

['What are the consequences?', 'Adults with this disorder are more likely to experience lower educational attainment and lower earnings (Katzelnick et al., 2001), perform more poorly at work and are more likely to be unemployed (Moitra, Beard, Weisberg, & Keller, 2011), and report greater dissatisfaction with their family lives, friends, leisure activities, and income (Stein & Kean, 2000).']

['What is the first thing you will tell me?', 'When people with social anxiety disorder are unable to avoid situations that provoke anxiety, they typically perform safety behaviors: mental or behavioral acts that reduce anxiety in social situations by reducing the chance of negative social outcomes.']

['What are some of the safety behaviors?', 'Safety behaviors include avoiding eye contact, rehearsing sentences before speaking, talking only briefly, and not talking about oneself (Alden & Bieling, 1998).']
['What are some examples of safety behaviors?', 'Other examples of safety behaviors include the following (Marker, 2013):']

['What other effects have been seen on individuals with social anxiety disorder?', 'People with social anxiety disorder may resort to self-medication, such as drinking alcohol, as a means to avert the anxiety symptoms they experience in social situations (Battista & Kocovski, 2010).']

['Does drinking alcohol make any difference?', 'The use of alcohol when faced with such situations may become negatively reinforcing: encouraging individuals with social anxiety disorder to turn to the substance whenever they experience anxiety symptoms.']

['What can you tell me about large scale studies?', 'The tendency to use alcohol as a coping mechanism for social anxiety, however, can come with a hefty price tag: a number of large scale studies have reported a high rate of comorbidity between social anxiety disorder and alcohol use disorder (Morris, Stewart, & Ham, 2005).']
['Are there any other articles in this article?', 'As with specific phobias, it is highly probable that the fears inherent to social anxiety disorder can develop through conditioning experiences.']

['What are some examples of negative social images?', 'For example, a child who is subjected to early unpleasant social experiences (e.g., bullying at school) may develop negative social images of herself that become activated later in anxiety-provoking situations (Hackmann, Clark, & McManus, 2000).']

['Did the article discuss any other interesting findings?', 'Indeed, one study reported that 92% of a sample of adults with social anxiety disorder reported a history of severe teasing in childhood, compared to only 35% of a sample of adults with panic disorder (McCabe, Antony, Summerfeldt, Liss, & Swinson, 2003).']

['What is one of the most well-established risk factors for developing social anxiety disorder?', 'One of the most well-established risk factors for developing social anxiety disorder is behavioral inhibition (Clauss & Blackford, 2012).']

['how does one show behavioral inhibition?', 'Behavioral inhibition is thought to be an inherited trait, and it is characterized by a consistent tendency to show fear and restraint when presented with unfamiliar people or situations (Kagan, Reznick, & Snidman, 1988).']

['where does behavioral inhibition originate?', 'Behavioral inhibition is displayed very early in life; behaviorally inhibited toddlers and children respond with great caution and restraint in unfamiliar situations, and they are often timid, fearful, and shy around unfamiliar people (Fox, Henderson, Marshall, Nichols, & Ghera, 2005).']

['Did they find anything else?', 'A recent statistical review of studies demonstrated that behavioral inhibition was associated with more than a sevenfold increase in the risk of development of social anxiety disorder, demonstrating that behavioral inhibition is a major risk factor for the disorder (Clauss & Blackford, 2012).']

['What is the main topic of discussion?', 'Imagine that you are at the mall one day with your friends and—suddenly and inexplicably—you begin sweating and trembling, your heart starts pounding, you have trouble breathing, and you start to feel dizzy and nauseous.']
['How long does this episode last?', 'This episode lasts for 10 minutes and is terrifying because you start to think that you are going to die.']
['How do you explain what happened?', 'When you visit your doctor the following morning and describe what happened, she tells you that you have experienced a panic attack (Figure 15.9).']

['How do they know you have panic disorder?', 'If you experience another one of these episodes two weeks later and worry for a month or more that similar episodes will occur in the future, it is likely that you have developed panic disorder.']

['what is panic disorder?', 'People with panic disorder experience recurrent (more than one) and unexpected panic attacks, along with at least one month of persistent concern about additional panic attacks, worry over the consequences of the attacks, or self-defeating changes in behavior related to the attacks (e.g., avoidance of exercise or unfamiliar situations) (APA, 2013).']

['What causes panic attacks?', 'As is the case with other anxiety disorders, the panic attacks cannot result from the physiological effects of drugs and other substances, a medical condition, or another mental disorder.']
['What is a panic attack?', 'A panic attack is defined as a period of extreme fear or discomfort that develops abruptly and reaches a peak within 10 minutes.']

['What are the symptoms of a panic attack?', 'Its symptoms include accelerated heart rate, sweating, trembling, choking sensations, hot flashes or chills, dizziness or lightheadedness, fears of losing control or going crazy, and fears of dying (APA, 2013).']

['What happens when they attack?', 'Sometimes panic attacks are expected, occurring in response to specific environmental triggers (such as being in a tunnel); other times, these episodes are unexpected and emerge randomly (such as when relaxing).']
['what can be done about it?', 'According to the DSM-5, the person must experience unexpected panic attacks to qualify for a diagnosis of panic disorder.']
['Is experiencing a panic attack scary?', 'Experiencing a panic attack is often terrifying.']

['What kind of attacks do people have?', 'Rather than recognizing the symptoms of a panic attack merely as signs of intense anxiety, individuals with panic disorder often misinterpret them as a sign that something is intensely wrong internally (thinking, for example, that the pounding heart represents an impending heart attack).']

['What causes panic attacks?', 'Panic attacks can occasionally precipitate trips to the emergency room because several symptoms of panic attacks are, in fact, similar to those associated with heart problems (e.g., palpitations, racing pulse, and a pounding sensation in the chest) (Root, 2000).']

['What kind of things happen to the person with panic disorder?', 'Unsurprisingly, those with panic disorder fear future attacks and may become preoccupied with modifying their behavior in an effort to avoid future panic attacks.']
['What is the panic disorder often characterized by?', 'For this reason, panic disorder is often characterized as fear of fear (Goldstein & Chambless, 1978).']
['What is the main idea of our study?', 'Panic attacks themselves are not mental disorders.']

['How many Americans experience isolated panic attacks in their lives without meeting the criteria for panic disorder?', 'Indeed, around 23% of Americans experience isolated panic attacks in their lives without meeting the criteria for panic disorder (Kessler et al., 2006), indicating that panic attacks are fairly common.']
['What is the most common affliction of Americans?', 'Panic disorder is, of course, much less common, afflicting 4.7% of Americans during their lifetime (Kessler et al., 2005).']

['What is agoraphobia?', 'Many people with panic disorder develop agoraphobia, which is marked by fear and avoidance of situations in which escape might be difficult or help might not be available if one were to develop symptoms of a panic attack.']

['What other disorders are associated with panic disorder?', 'People with panic disorder often experience a comorbid disorder, such as other anxiety disorders or major depressive disorder (APA, 2013).']
['What is the cause of panic disorder?', 'Researchers are not entirely sure what causes panic disorder.']

['What are some of the studies on this?', 'Children are at a higher risk of developing panic disorder if their parents have the disorder (Biederman et al., 2001), and family and twins studies indicate that the heritability of panic disorder is around 43% (Hettema, Neale, & Kendler, 2001).']
['Are there specific genes involved in this disorder?', 'The exact genes and gene functions involved in this disorder, however, are not well-understood (APA, 2013).']
['What is the other major contributing factor?', 'Neurobiological theories of panic disorder suggest that a region of the brain called the locus coeruleus may play a role in this disorder.']

['What is the brain’s major source of norepinephrine?', 'Located in the brainstem, the locus coeruleus is the brain’s major source of norepinephrine, a neurotransmitter that triggers the body’s fight-or-flight response.']

['What do these studies show?', 'Activation of the locus coeruleus is associated with anxiety and fear, and research with nonhuman primates has shown that stimulating the locus coeruleus either electrically or through drugs produces panic-like symptoms (Charney et al., 1990).']

['What is the theory that panic disorder may be caused by abnormal norepinephrine activity in the locus coeruleus?', 'Such findings have led to the theory that panic disorder may be caused by abnormal norepinephrine activity in the locus coeruleus (Bremner, Krystal, Southwick, & Charney, 1996).']

['What are conditioning theories of panic disorder?', 'Conditioning theories of panic disorder propose that panic attacks are classical conditioning responses to subtle bodily sensations resembling those normally occurring when one is anxious or frightened (Bouton, Mineka, & Barlow, 2001).']
['What can we learn about subtle bodily sensations?', 'For example, consider a child who has asthma.']
['What are the symptoms of an acute asthma attack?', 'An acute asthma attack produces sensations, such as shortness of breath, coughing, and chest tightness, that typically elicit fear and anxiety.']

["What can we learn from the child's case?", 'Later, when the child experiences subtle symptoms that resemble the frightening symptoms of earlier asthma attacks (such as shortness of breath after climbing stairs), they may become anxious, fearful, and then experience a panic attack.']
['What can we learn about the subtle symptoms?', 'In this situation, the subtle symptoms would represent a conditioned stimulus, and the panic attack would be a conditioned response.']

['What is the finding that panic disorder is nearly three times as frequent among people with asthma as it is among people without asthma (Weiser, 2007) supports the possibility that panic disorder has the potential to develop through classical conditioning?', 'The finding that panic disorder is nearly three times as frequent among people with asthma as it is among people without asthma (Weiser, 2007) supports the possibility that panic disorder has the potential to develop through classical conditioning.']
['What are the key points in our study material?', 'Cognitive factors may play an integral part in panic disorder.']

['How so?', 'Generally, cognitive theories (Clark, 1996) argue that those with panic disorder are prone to interpret ordinary bodily sensations catastrophically, and these fearful interpretations set the stage for panic attacks.']

['Do they have specific symptoms of panic disorder?', 'For example, a person might detect bodily changes that are routinely triggered by innocuous events such as getting up from a seated position (dizziness), exercising (increased heart rate, shortness of breath), or drinking a large cup of coffee (increased heart rate, trembling).']
["What is the person's reaction to these subtle bodily changes?", 'The individual interprets these subtle bodily changes catastrophically (“Maybe I’m having a heart attack!”).']
['What is the result of such interpretations?', 'Such interpretations create fear and anxiety, which trigger additional physical symptoms; subsequently, the person experiences a panic attack.']

['People with the disorder feel what about their body changes?', 'Support of this contention rests with findings that people with more severe catastrophic thoughts about sensations have more frequent and severe panic attacks, and among those with panic disorder, reducing catastrophic cognitions about their sensations is as effective as medication in reducing panic attacks (Good & Hinton, 2009).']
['How did Alex feel about these things?', 'Alex was always worried about many things.']
['What else did he worry about?', 'He worried that his children would drown when they played at the beach.']
['What worries did he have?', 'Each time he left the house, he worried that an electrical short circuit would start a fire in his home.']
['What was his worry about?', 'He worried that his husband would lose his job at the prestigious law firm.']
['Why was he worried?', 'He worried that his daughter’s minor staph infection could turn into a massive life-threatening condition.']

['What worries constantly weighed heavily on Alex’s mind?', 'These and other worries constantly weighed heavily on Alex’s mind, so much so that they made it difficult for him to make decisions and often left him feeling tense, irritable, and worn out.']
['Did Alex ever worry about driving?', 'One night, Alex’s husband was to drive their son home from a soccer game.']
['What happened after that?', 'However, his husband stayed after the game and talked with some of the other parents, resulting in him arriving home 45 minutes late.']
['What did Alex do to get in touch with his friends?', 'Alex had tried to call his cell phone three or four times, but he could not get through because the soccer field did not have a signal.']
['How did he feel about the situation?', 'Extremely worried,']
['What did Alex do?', 'Alex eventually called the police, convinced that his husband and son had not arrived home because they had been in a terrible car accident.']
['What is the study material?', 'Alex suffers from generalized anxiety disorder: a relatively continuous state of excessive, uncontrollable, and pointless worry and apprehension.']
['What kind of things does the person worry about?', 'People with generalized anxiety disorder often worry about routine, everyday things, even though their concerns are unjustified (Figure 15.10).']

['What is the most common reason for excessive worry?', 'For example, an individual may worry about her health and finances, the health of family members, the safety of her children, or minor matters (e.g., being late for an appointment) without having any legitimate reason for doing so (APA, 2013).']

['What else is going on?', 'A diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder requires that the diffuse worrying and apprehension characteristic of this disorder—what Sigmund Freud referred to as free-floating anxiety—is not part of another disorder, occurs more days than not for at least six months, and is accompanied by any three of the following symptoms: restlessness, difficulty concentrating, being easily fatigued, muscle tension, irritability, and sleep difficulties.']

['How many people will develop symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder during their lifetime?', 'About 5.7% of the U.S. population will develop symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder during their lifetime (Kessler et al., 2005), and females are 2 times as likely as males to experience the disorder (APA, 2013).']
['Are there any symptoms of this disorder?', 'Generalized anxiety disorder is highly comorbid with mood disorders and other anxiety disorders (Noyes, 2001), and it tends to be chronic.']

['What are the complications of this disorder?', 'Also, generalized anxiety disorder appears to increase the risk for heart attacks and strokes, especially in people with preexisting heart conditions (Martens et al., 2010).']

['What is the most significant discovery in this document?', 'Although there have been few investigations aimed at determining the heritability of generalized anxiety disorder, a summary of available family and twin studies suggests that genetic factors play a modest role in the disorder (Hettema et al., 2001).']

['How does worry affect people?', 'Cognitive theories of generalized anxiety disorder suggest that worry represents a mental strategy to avoid more powerful negative emotions (Aikins & Craske, 2001), perhaps stemming from earlier unpleasant or traumatic experiences.']

['What can you tell me about childhood maltreatment?', 'Indeed, one longitudinal study found that childhood maltreatment was strongly related to the development of this disorder during adulthood (Moffitt et al., 2007); worrying might distract people from remembering painful childhood experiences.']

['What are obsessive-compulsive and related disorders?', 'Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders are a group of overlapping disorders that generally involve intrusive, unpleasant thoughts and repetitive behaviors.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects about this section?', 'Many of us experience unwanted thoughts from time to time (e.g., craving double cheeseburgers when dieting), and many of us engage in repetitive behaviors on occasion (e.g., pacing when nervous).']

['What is a disorder?', 'However, obsessive-compulsive and related disorders elevate the unwanted thoughts and repetitive behaviors to a status so intense that these cognitions and activities disrupt daily life.']
['What other disorders are involved in obsessive-compulsive disorder?', 'Included in this category are obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), body dysmorphic disorder, and hoarding disorder.']

['What are the characteristics of obsessive-compulsive disorder?', 'People with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) experience thoughts and urges that are intrusive and unwanted (obsessions) and/or the need to engage in repetitive behaviors or mental acts (compulsions).']

['How does a person with OCD show these characteristics?', 'A person with this disorder might, for example, spend hours each day washing his hands or constantly checking and rechecking to make sure that a stove, faucet, or light has been turned off.']

['What are obsessions?', 'Obsessions are more than just unwanted thoughts that seem to randomly jump into our head from time to time, such as recalling an insensitive remark a coworker made recently, and they are more significant than day-to-day worries we might have, such as justifiable concerns about being laid off from a job.']

['What are obsessions characterized as?', 'Rather, obsessions are characterized as persistent, unintentional, and unwanted thoughts and urges that are highly intrusive, unpleasant, and distressing (APA, 2013).']

['What are common obsessions?', 'Common obsessions include concerns about germs and contamination, doubts (“Did I turn the water off?”), order and symmetry (“I need all the spoons in the tray to be arranged a certain way”), and urges that are aggressive or lustful.']

['What are the effects of obsessions?', 'Usually, the person knows that such thoughts and urges are irrational and thus tries to suppress or ignore them, but has an extremely difficult time doing so.']

['What obsessive symptoms sometimes overlap, such that someone might have both contamination and aggressive obsessions?', 'These obsessive symptoms sometimes overlap, such that someone might have both contamination and aggressive obsessions (Abramowitz & Siqueland, 2013).']

['What are repetitive and ritualistic acts that are typically carried out primarily as a means to minimize the distress that obsessions trigger or to reduce the likelihood of a feared event?', 'Compulsions are repetitive and ritualistic acts that are typically carried out primarily as a means to minimize the distress that obsessions trigger or to reduce the likelihood of a feared event (APA, 2013).']

['What are some examples of compulsions?', 'Compulsions often include such behaviors as repeated and extensive hand washing, cleaning, checking (e.g., that a door is locked), and ordering (e.g., lining up all the pencils in a particular way), and they also include such mental acts as counting, praying, or reciting something to oneself (Figure 15.11).']

['What are the characteristics of the compulsions?', 'Compulsions characteristic of OCD are not performed out of pleasure, nor are they connected in a realistic way to the source of the distress or feared event.']

['Do you think this condition affects you in any way?', 'Approximately 2.3% of the U.S. population will experience OCD in their lifetime (Ruscio, Stein, Chiu, & Kessler, 2010) and, if left untreated, OCD tends to be a chronic condition creating lifelong interpersonal and psychological problems (Norberg, Calamari, Cohen, & Riemann, 2008).']

['What is body dysmorphic disorder?', 'An individual with body dysmorphic disorder is preoccupied with a perceived flaw in physical appearance that is either nonexistent or barely noticeable to other people (APA, 2013).']
['What do people think about themselves when they see physical defects?', 'These perceived physical defects cause people to think they are unattractive, ugly, hideous, or deformed.']
['What is the offending body part?', 'These preoccupations can focus on any bodily area, but they typically involve the skin, face, or hair.']

['What does their preoccupation drive them to do?', 'The preoccupation with imagined physical flaws drives the person to engage in repetitive and ritualistic behavioral and mental acts, such as constantly looking in the mirror, trying to hide the offending body part, comparisons with others, and, in some extreme cases, cosmetic surgery (Phillips, 2005).']

['What is the rate of this disorder among adults?', 'An estimated 2.4% of the adults in the United States meet the criteria for body dysmorphic disorder, with slightly higher rates in women than in men (APA, 2013).']

['What are the differences between hoarding and OCD?', 'Although hoarding was traditionally considered to be a symptom of OCD, considerable evidence suggests that hoarding represents an entirely different disorder (Mataix-Cols et al., 2010).']
['What are some aspects of hoarding disorder?', 'People with hoarding disorder cannot bear to part with personal possessions, regardless of how valueless or useless these possessions are.']
['What is the result of that?', 'As a result, these individuals accumulate excessive amounts of usually worthless items that clutter their living areas (Figure 15.12).']
['What is the most problematic aspect of a cluttered living area?', 'Often, the quantity of cluttered items is so excessive that the person is unable to use his kitchen, or sleep in his bed.']

['What are other aspects of hoarding?', 'People who suffer from this disorder have great difficulty parting with items because they believe the items might be of some later use, or because they form a sentimental attachment to the items (APA, 2013).']

['What is the treatment for hoarding?', 'Importantly, a diagnosis of hoarding disorder is made only if the hoarding is not caused by another medical condition and if the hoarding is not a symptom of another disorder (e.g., schizophrenia) (APA, 2013).']
['What are the studies that lead to this conclusion?', 'The results of family and twin studies suggest that OCD has a moderate genetic component.']
['What other studies are there?', 'The disorder is five times more frequent in the first-degree relatives of people with OCD than in people without the disorder (Nestadt et al., 2000).']

['What are some other studies?', 'Additionally, the concordance rate of OCD among identical twins is around 57%; however, the concordance rate for fraternal twins is 22% (Bolton, Rijsdijk, O’Connor, Perrin, & Eley, 2007).']

['What are some of the other studies?', 'Studies have implicated about two dozen potential genes that may be involved in OCD; these genes regulate the function of three neurotransmitters: serotonin, dopamine, and glutamate (Pauls, 2010).']
['What are some of the limitations of the studies?', 'Many of these studies included small sample sizes and have yet to be replicated.']
['What is the reason for more studies?', 'Thus, additional research needs to be done in this area.']

['What is orbitofrontal cortex?', 'A brain region that is believed to play a critical role in OCD is the orbitofrontal cortex (Kopell & Greenberg, 2008), an area of the frontal lobe involved in learning and decision-making (Rushworth, Noonan, Boorman, Walton, & Behrens, 2011) (Figure 15.13).']

['What triggers this?', 'In people with OCD, the orbitofrontal cortex becomes especially hyperactive when they are provoked with tasks in which, for example, they are asked to look at a photo of a toilet or of pictures hanging crookedly on a wall (Simon, Kaufmann, Müsch, Kischkel, & Kathmann, 2010).']

['Are there other brain regions involved?', 'The orbitofrontal cortex is part of a series of brain regions that, collectively, is called the OCD circuit; this circuit consists of several interconnected regions that influence the perceived emotional value of stimuli and the selection of both behavioral and cognitive responses (Graybiel & Rauch, 2000).']

['Is there anything else of note?', 'As with the orbitofrontal cortex, other regions of the OCD circuit show heightened activity during symptom provocation (Rotge et al., 2008), which suggests that abnormalities in these regions may produce the symptoms of OCD (Saxena, Bota, & Brody, 2001).']

['How is this connected to OCD?', 'Consistent with this explanation, people with OCD show a substantially higher degree of connectivity of the orbitofrontal cortex and other regions of the OCD circuit than do those without OCD (Beucke et al., 2013).']
['What is significant about the findings discussed above?', 'The findings discussed above were based on imaging studies, and they highlight the potential importance of brain dysfunction in OCD.']
['What is the greatest limitation of these findings?', 'However, one important limitation of these findings is the inability to explain differences in obsessions and compulsions.']

['What is another limitation of the study?', 'Another limitation is that the correlational relationship between neurological abnormalities and OCD symptoms cannot imply causation (Abramowitz & Siqueland, 2013).']

['what kind of events can cause posttraumatic stress disorder?', 'Extremely stressful or traumatic events, such as combat, natural disasters, and crimes, place the people who experience them at an increased risk for developing psychological disorders such as posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).']

['what does shell shock mean?', 'Throughout much of the 20th century, this disorder was called shell shock and combat neurosis because its symptoms were observed in soldiers who had engaged in wartime combat.']

['what does rape have to do with posttraumatic stress disorder?', 'By the late 1970s it had become clear that women who had experienced sexual traumas (e.g., rape, domestic battery, and incest) often experienced the same set of symptoms as did soldiers (Herman, 1997).']
['Did they define posttraumatic stress disorder?', 'The term posttraumatic stress disorder was developed given that these symptoms could happen to anyone who experienced psychological trauma.']
['What is the major component of the study material?', 'PTSD was listed among the anxiety disorders in previous DSM editions.']
['What was the latest edition of DSM?', 'In DSM-5, it is now listed among a group called Trauma-and-Stressor-Related Disorders.']

['How is trauma related to the PTSD?', 'For a person to be diagnosed with PTSD, they must be exposed to, witness, or experience the details of a traumatic experience (e.g., a first responder), one that involves “actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence” (APA, 2013, p. 271).']

['What are some examples of trauma?', 'These experiences can include such events as combat, threatened or actual physical attack, sexual assault, natural disasters, terrorist attacks, and automobile accidents.']
['What is one of the criteria for PTSD?', 'This criterion makes PTSD the only disorder listed in the DSM in which a cause (extreme trauma) is explicitly specified.']

['what are the symptoms of PTSD?', 'Symptoms of PTSD include intrusive and distressing memories of the event, flashbacks (states that can last from a few seconds to several days, during which the individual relives the event and behaves as if the event were occurring at that moment [APA, 2013]), avoidance of stimuli connected to the event, persistently negative emotional states (e.g., fear, anger, guilt, and shame), feelings of detachment from others, irritability, proneness toward outbursts, and an exaggerated startle response (jumpiness).']
['How long can these symptoms last?', 'For PTSD to be diagnosed, these symptoms must occur for at least one month.']

['What is the highest rate of PTSD in the United States?', 'Roughly 7% of adults in the United States, including 9.7% of women and 3.6% of men, experience PTSD in their lifetime (National Comorbidity Survey, 2007), with higher rates among people exposed to mass trauma and people whose jobs involve duty-related trauma exposure (e.g., police officers, firefighters, and emergency medical personnel) (APA, 2013).']

['Do you have any more information?', 'Nearly 21% of residents of areas affected by Hurricane Katrina suffered from PTSD one year following the hurricane (Kessler et al., 2008), and 12.6% of Manhattan residents were observed as having PTSD 2–3 years after the 9/11 terrorist attacks (DiGrande et al., 2008).']

['What else are some of the aspects of the study material?', 'Of course, not everyone who experiences a traumatic event will go on to develop PTSD; several factors strongly predict the development of PTSD: trauma experience, greater trauma severity, lack of immediate social support, and more subsequent life stress (Brewin, Andrews, & Valentine, 2000).']

['What are some of the major traumatic events?', 'Traumatic events that involve harm by others (e.g., combat, rape, and sexual molestation) carry greater risk than do other traumas (e.g., natural disasters) (Kessler, Sonnega, Bromet, Hughes, & Nelson, 1995).']
['What are some of the gender differences?', 'Women are more likely to have been traumatized because of sexual trauma, childhood neglect, and childhood physical abuse.']
['What are the gender differences?', 'Men are more likely to have been traumatized by natural disaster, life-threatening accident, and physical violence, either witnessed or directed at them.']

['What are some gender differences?', 'Adolescent boys are more likely to experience accident, physical assault, and witness death/injury; adolescent girls are more likely to experience rape/sexual assault, intimate partner violence, or unexpected death or injury of a loved one.']
['Are there other differences in risk?', 'Assaultive violence and witnessing trauma to others is more prevalent among non-White people when compared to White people.']
['Are there other racial differences in risk?', 'African American males are more likely to be exposed to and victims of violence than males of other races (Kilpatrick, Badour, & Resnick, 2017).']
['What is the most common symptom of PTSD?', 'A 2012 study found that 27% of corrections officers reported experiencing symptoms of PTSD in the past 30 days.']
['What gender differences were there?', 'Rates were higher for males (31%) than females (22%) (Spinaris, Denhof, & Kellaway, 2012).']
['Are there any other studies?', 'A study conducted by Jaegers et al (2019) found that 53.4% of jail correctional officers screened positively for PTSD.']

['What are the rates of PTSD in prison populations?', 'PTSD is more prevalent in prison populations than in the general public, with prevalence estimates of 6% in male prisoners and 21% in female prisoners (Facer-Irwin et al, 2019).']

['What are some of the other risk factors?', 'Factors that increase the risk of PTSD include female gender, low socioeconomic status, low intelligence, personal history of mental disorders, history of childhood adversity (abuse or other trauma during childhood), and family history of mental disorders (Brewin et al., 2000).']

['What are some personality characteristics that have been shown to elevate the risk of PTSD?', 'Personality characteristics such as neuroticism and somatization (the tendency to experience physical symptoms when one encounters stress) have been shown to elevate the risk of PTSD (Bramsen, Dirkzwager, & van der Ploeg, 2000).']

['What is the most important study that supports the idea that genes play a role in PTSD?', 'People who experience childhood adversity and/or traumatic experiences during adulthood are at significantly higher risk of developing PTSD if they possess one or two short versions of a gene that regulates the neurotransmitter serotonin (Xie et al., 2009).']
['What can we learn from this study?', 'This suggests a possible diathesis-stress interpretation of PTSD: its development is influenced by the interaction of psychosocial and biological factors.']
['What is social support?', 'Research has shown that social support following a traumatic event can reduce the likelihood of PTSD (Ozer, Best, Lipsey, & Weiss, 2003).']
['What is social support?', 'Social support is often defined as the comfort, advice, and assistance received from relatives, friends, and neighbors.']

['How does social support help individuals cope during difficult times?', 'Social support can help individuals cope during difficult times by allowing them to discuss feelings and experiences and providing a sense of being loved and appreciated.']

['What other research has been done?', 'A 14-year study of 1,377 people who had served in the Vietnam War found that those who perceived less social support when they came home were more likely to develop PTSD than were those who perceived greater support (Figure 15.14).']

['What else has been learned from the research?', 'In addition, those who became involved in the community were less likely to develop PTSD, and they were more likely to experience a remission of PTSD than were those who were less involved (Koenen, Stellman, Stellman, & Sommer, 2003).']
['What is the process of conditioning that causes PTSD?', 'PTSD learning models suggest that some symptoms are developed and maintained through classical conditioning.']

['What is an unconditioned stimulus that elicits an unconditioned response characterized by extreme fear and anxiety?', 'The traumatic event may act as an unconditioned stimulus that elicits an unconditioned response characterized by extreme fear and anxiety.']
['What is a conditioned stimulus?', 'Cognitive, emotional, physiological, and environmental cues accompanying or related to the event are conditioned stimuli.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'These traumatic reminders evoke conditioned responses (extreme fear and anxiety) similar to those caused by the event itself (Nader, 2001).']

['What is a conditioned response to the traumatic reminder of an airplane crash?', 'A person who witnessed or experienced a plane crash and who developed PTSD may display excessive hypervigilance and distress when planes fly overhead; this behavior constitutes a conditioned response to the traumatic reminder (conditioned stimulus of the sight and sound of an airplane).']

['What is the difference between PTSD and a phobia?', 'Differences in how conditionable individuals are help to explain differences in the development and maintenance of PTSD symptoms (Pittman, 1988).']

['Are there any studies of this?', 'Conditioning studies demonstrate facilitated acquisition of conditioned responses and delayed extinction of conditioned responses in people with PTSD (Orr et al., 2000).']
['What are cognitive factors?', 'Cognitive factors are important in the development and maintenance of PTSD.']

['What are two key processes?', 'One model suggests that two key processes are crucial: disturbances in memory for the event, and negative appraisals of the trauma and its aftermath (Ehlers & Clark, 2000).']

['Why is it so?', 'According to this theory, some people who experience traumas do not form coherent memories of the trauma; memories of the traumatic event are poorly encoded and, thus, are fragmented, disorganized, and lacking in detail.']
['What happens as a result of this?', 'Therefore, these individuals are unable remember the event in a way that gives it meaning and context.']

['What kind of memory are they talking about?', 'A rape victim who cannot coherently remember the event may remember only bits and pieces (e.g., the attacker repeating a word or insult); because the victim was unable to develop a fully integrated memory, the fragmentary memory tends to stand out.']

['Why does it stand out?', 'Although unable to retrieve a complete memory of the event, the victim may be haunted by intrusive fragments involuntarily triggered by stimuli associated with the event (e.g., memories of the attacker’s comments when encountering a person who resembles the attacker).']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'This interpretation fits previously discussed material concerning PTSD and conditioning.']

['What else is unique about the theory?', 'The model also proposes that negative appraisals of the event (“I deserved to be raped because I’m stupid”) may lead to dysfunctional behavioral strategies (e.g., avoiding social activities where men are likely to be present) that maintain PTSD symptoms by preventing both a change in the nature of the memory and a change in the problematic appraisals.']
['Which of the following is an example of a mood disorder?', 'Blake cries all day and feeling that he is worthless and his life is hopeless, he cannot get out of bed.']

['Which of the following is an example of a mood disorder?', 'Crystal stays up all night, talks very rapidly, and went on a shopping spree in which she spent $3,000 on furniture, although she cannot afford it.']

['Which of the following is an example of a mood disorder?', 'Maria recently had a baby, and she feels overwhelmed, teary, anxious, and panicked, and believes she is a terrible mother—practically every day since the baby was born.']
['What is the difference between these individuals?', 'All these individuals demonstrate symptoms of a potential mood disorder.']
['What are mood disorders?', 'Mood disorders (Figure 15.15) are characterized by severe disturbances in mood and emotions—most often depression, but also mania and elation (Rothschild, 1999).']
['What are some things we could learn about mood disorders?', 'All of us experience fluctuations in our moods and emotional states, and often these fluctuations are caused by events in our lives.']

['What types of things could cause people to have a fluctuating mood?', 'We become elated if our favorite team wins the World Series and dejected if a romantic relationship ends or if we lose our job.']
['Do we know why some people have a fluctuating mood?', 'At times, we feel fantastic or miserable for no clear reason.']

['How do mood disorders affect people?', 'People with mood disorders also experience mood fluctuations, but their fluctuations are extreme, distort their outlook on life, and impair their ability to function.']
['What is the DSM-5?', 'The DSM-5 lists two general categories of mood disorders.']
['What are a group of disorders in which depression is the main feature?', 'Depressive disorders are a group of disorders in which depression is the main feature.']
['What is the term for an intense and persistent sadness?', 'Depression is a vague term that, in everyday language, refers to an intense and persistent sadness.']
['What is the most common way to measure depression?', 'Depression is a heterogeneous mood state—it consists of a broad spectrum of symptoms that range in severity.']
['What are the symptoms of depression?', 'Depressed people feel sad, discouraged, and hopeless.']

['What are some other symptoms of a depressive episode?', 'These individuals lose interest in activities once enjoyed, often experience a decrease in drives such as hunger and sex, and frequently doubt personal worth.']

['Are there other things that contribute to depressive disorders?', 'Depressive disorders vary by degree, but this chapter highlights the most well-known: major depressive disorder (sometimes called unipolar depression).']
['What is the defining feature of bipolar disorder?', 'Bipolar and related disorders are a group of disorders in which mania is the defining feature.']
['What is mania?', 'Mania is a state of extreme elation and agitation.']
['What do they experience?', 'When people experience mania, they may become extremely talkative, behave recklessly, or attempt to take on many tasks simultaneously.']
['What is the most recognized of these disorders?', 'The most recognized of these disorders is bipolar disorder.']

['What is one of the symptoms?', 'According to the DSM-5, the defining symptoms of major depressive disorder include “depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day” (feeling sad, empty, hopeless, or appearing tearful to others), and loss of interest and pleasure in usual activities (APA, 2013).']

['What other symptoms?', 'In addition to feeling overwhelmingly sad most of each day, people with depression will no longer show interest or enjoyment in activities that previously were gratifying, such as hobbies, sports, sex, social events, time spent with family, and so on.']

['What are other symptoms of major depressive disorder?', 'Friends and family members may notice that the person has completely abandoned previously enjoyed hobbies; for example, an avid tennis player who develops major depressive disorder no longer plays tennis (Rothschild, 1999).']

['what is the definition of this disorder?', 'To receive a diagnosis of major depressive disorder, one must experience a total of five symptoms for at least a two-week period; these symptoms must cause significant distress or impair normal functioning, and they must not be caused by substances or a medical condition.']
['what are the other symptoms?', 'At least one of the two symptoms mentioned above must be present, plus any combination of the following symptoms (APA, 2013):']

['What else do we know about major depressive disorder?', 'Major depressive disorder is considered episodic: its symptoms are typically present at their full magnitude for a certain period of time and then gradually abate.']

['Do people who have had a major depressive episode ever have another?', 'Approximately 50%–60% of people who experience an episode of major depressive disorder will have a second episode at some point in the future; those who have had two episodes have a 70% chance of having a third episode, and those who have had three episodes have a 90% chance of having a fourth episode (Rothschild, 1999).']
['How long does it last?', 'Although the episodes can last for months, a majority of people diagnosed with this condition (around 70%) recover within a year.']

['What is the remainder of recovery like?', 'However, a substantial number do not recover; around 12% show serious signs of impairment associated with major depressive disorder after 5 years (Boland & Keller, 2009).']
['What is the long-term effect of a relapse?', 'In the long-term, many who do recover will still show minor symptoms that fluctuate in their severity (Judd, 2012).']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Major depressive disorder is a serious and incapacitating condition that can have a devastating effect on the quality of one’s life.']

['What are some common problems this disorder causes?', 'The person suffering from this disorder lives a profoundly miserable existence that often results in unavailability for work or education, abandonment of promising careers, and lost wages; occasionally, the condition requires hospitalization.']

['What else is significant in this section?', 'The majority of those with major depressive disorder report having faced some kind of discrimination, and many report that having received such treatment has stopped them from initiating close relationships, applying for jobs for which they are qualified, and applying for education or training (Lasalvia et al., 2013).']
['What is the article about?', 'Major depressive disorder also takes a toll on health.']

['What is the effect of depression on the body?', 'Depression is a risk factor for the development of heart disease in healthy patients, as well as adverse cardiovascular outcomes in patients with preexisting heart disease (Whooley, 2006).']
['What kind of disorders are these?', 'Major depressive disorder is often referred to as the common cold of psychiatric disorders.']

['How many people have this disorder each year?', 'Around 6.6% of the U.S. population experiences major depressive disorder each year; 16.9% will experience the disorder during their lifetime (Kessler & Wang, 2009).']

['What gender is at a greater risk of suffering from this disorder?', 'It is more common among women than among men, affecting approximately 20% of women and 13% of men at some point in their life (National Comorbidity Survey, 2007).']

['What are the gender differences in the rates of major depressive disorder?', 'The greater risk among women is not accounted for by a tendency to report symptoms or to seek help more readily, suggesting that gender differences in the rates of major depressive disorder may reflect biological and gender-related environmental experiences (Kessler, 2003).']

['What are the most important statistics in relation to major depressive disorder?', 'Lifetime rates of major depressive disorder tend to be highest in North and South America, Europe, and Australia; they are considerably lower in Asian countries (Hasin, Fenton, & Weissman, 2011).']

['What are other statistics of interest?', 'The rates of major depressive disorder are higher among younger age cohorts than among older cohorts, perhaps because people in younger age cohorts are more willing to admit depression (Kessler & Wang, 2009).']

['What are the risk factors for major depressive disorder?', 'A number of risk factors are associated with major depressive disorder: unemployment (including homemakers); earning less than $20,000 per year; living in urban areas; or being separated, divorced, or widowed (Hasin et al., 2011).']
['What are the other factors that can cause comorbid disorders?', 'Comorbid disorders include anxiety disorders and substance abuse disorders (Kessler & Wang, 2009).']
['What is the DSM-5?', 'The DSM-5 lists several different subtypes of depression.']

['What are the subtypes?', 'These subtypes—what the DSM-5 refer to as specifiers—are not specific disorders; rather, they are labels used to indicate specific patterns of symptoms or to specify certain periods of time in which the symptoms may be present.']

['How do they differ?', 'One subtype, seasonal pattern, applies to situations in which a person experiences the symptoms of major depressive disorder only during a particular time of year (e.g., fall or winter).']
['What is the most common name for this subtype?', 'In everyday language, people often refer to this subtype as the winter blues.']

['What is one type of depression?', 'Another subtype, peripartum onset (commonly referred to as postpartum depression), applies to women who experience major depression during pregnancy or in the four weeks following the birth of their child (APA, 2013).']
['What happens when a woman has peripartum depression?', 'These women often feel very anxious and may even have panic attacks.']
['What are some of the symptoms of a woman who has a uterus?', 'They may feel guilty, agitated, and be weepy.']
['What are other symptoms of postpartum depression?', 'They may not want to hold or care for their newborn, even in cases in which the pregnancy was desired and intended.']
['What happens in extreme cases?', 'In extreme cases, the mother may have feelings of wanting to harm her child or herself.']

['Do these women end up harming themselves?', 'In a horrific illustration, a woman named Andrea Yates, who suffered from extreme peripartum-onset depression (as well as other mental illnesses), drowned her five children in a bathtub (Roche, 2002).']

['What is there to know about these women?', 'Most women with peripartum-onset depression do not physically harm their children, but most do have difficulty being adequate caregivers (Fields, 2010).']
['What is the number one issue faced by women?', 'A surprisingly high number of women experience symptoms of peripartum-onset depression.']

['How many women screened positive for peripartum-onset depression?', 'A study of 10,000 women who had recently given birth found that 14% screened positive for peripartum-onset depression, and that nearly 20% reported having thoughts of wanting to harm themselves (Wisner et al., 2013).']

['What does persistent depressive disorder mean?', 'People with persistent depressive disorder (previously known as dysthymia) experience depressed moods most of the day nearly every day for at least two years, as well as at least two of the other symptoms of major depressive disorder.']

['How does someone experience depressed moods most of the day?', 'People with persistent depressive disorder are chronically sad and melancholy, but do not meet all the criteria for major depression.']

['Are people who have persistent depressive disorder ever a risk of going into major depression?', 'However, episodes of full-blown major depressive disorder can occur during persistent depressive disorder (APA, 2013).']

['What is the first fact that caught your attention?', 'To be diagnosed with bipolar disorder, a person must have experienced a manic episode at least once in their life; although major depressive episodes are common in bipolar disorder, they are not required for a diagnosis (APA, 2013).']

['What is manic depression?', 'According to the DSM-5, a manic episode is characterized as a “distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy lasting at least one week,” that lasts most of the time each day (APA, 2013, p. 124).']

['What is the most unusual fact about this article?', 'During a manic episode, some experience a mood that is almost euphoric and become excessively talkative, sometimes spontaneously starting conversations with strangers; others become excessively irritable and complain or make hostile comments.']
['What are some characteristics of a person who is a rambler?', 'The person may talk loudly and rapidly, exhibiting flight of ideas, abruptly switching from one topic to another.']
['What happens when they abruptly switch between topics?', 'These individuals are easily distracted, which can make a conversation very difficult.']
['What are some unusual facts about schizoid personality traits?', 'They may exhibit grandiosity, in which they experience inflated but unjustified self-esteem and self-confidence.']

['Can you tell me how they are unjustified?', 'For example, they might quit a job in order to “strike it rich” in the stock market, despite lacking the knowledge, experience, and capital for such an endeavor.']

['What else is there?', 'They may take on several tasks at the same time (e.g., several time-consuming projects at work) and yet show little, if any, need for sleep; some may go for days without sleep.']

['What else is there?', 'Patients may also recklessly engage in pleasurable activities that could have harmful consequences, including spending sprees, reckless driving, making foolish investments, excessive gambling, or engaging in sexual encounters with strangers (APA, 2013).']
['What are the characteristics of manic depression?', 'During a manic episode, individuals usually feel as though they are not ill and do not need treatment.']

['What are some reckless behaviors that often accompany these episodes?', 'However, the reckless behaviors that often accompany these episodes—which can be antisocial, illegal, or physically threatening to others—may require involuntary hospitalization (APA, 2013).']

['What is the rapid-cycling subtype characterized by?', 'Some patients with bipolar disorder will experience a rapid-cycling subtype, which is characterized by at least four manic episodes (or some combination of at least four manic and major depressive episodes) within one year.']
['Which of the illnesses is less frequent?', 'Bipolar disorder is considerably less frequent than major depressive disorder.']

['what is one of the most important things you learned about this study?', 'In the United States, 1 out of every 167 people meets the criteria for bipolar disorder each year, and 1 out of 100 meet the criteria within their lifetime (Merikangas et al., 2011).']
['which gender has a higher rate', 'The rates are higher in men than in women, and about half of those with this disorder report onset before the age of 25 (Merikangas et al., 2011).']

['Do people with bipolar disorder often have other disorders with it?', 'Around 90% of those with bipolar disorder have a comorbid disorder, most often an anxiety disorder or a substance abuse problem.']
['What is the most important thing you found out about this study?', 'Unfortunately, close to half of the people suffering from bipolar disorder do not receive treatment (Merikangas & Tohen, 2011).']

['What are the suicide rates among those with bipolar disorder?', 'Suicide rates are extremely high among those with bipolar disorder: around 36% of individuals with this disorder attempt suicide at least once in their lifetime (Novick, Swartz, & Frank, 2010), and between 15%–19% die by suicide (Newman, 2004).']
['What does the document say about a strong genetic basis for mood disorders?', 'Mood disorders have been shown to have a strong genetic and biological basis.']

['Do genetics affect the development of other disorders?', 'Relatives of those with major depressive disorder have double the risk of developing major depressive disorder, whereas relatives of patients with bipolar disorder have over nine times the risk (Merikangas et al., 2011).']

['What can you tell me about genetics and development?', 'The rate of concordance for major depressive disorder is higher among identical twins than fraternal twins (50% vs. 38%, respectively), as is that of bipolar disorder (67% vs. 16%, respectively), suggesting that genetic factors play a stronger role in bipolar disorder than in major depressive disorder (Merikangas et al. 2011).']
['What is the main factor in mood disorders?', 'People with mood disorders often have imbalances in certain neurotransmitters, particularly norepinephrine and serotonin (Thase, 2009).']

['what do these imbalances lead to?', 'These neurotransmitters are important regulators of the bodily functions that are disrupted in mood disorders, including appetite, sex drive, sleep, arousal, and mood.']

['what is the difference between these two medications?', 'Medications that are used to treat major depressive disorder typically boost serotonin and norepinephrine activity, whereas lithium—used in the treatment of bipolar disorder—blocks norepinephrine activity at the synapses (Figure 15.16).']

['What is an example of the content of that document?', 'Depression is linked to abnormal activity in several regions of the brain (Fitzgerald, Laird, Maller, & Daskalakis, 2008) including those important in assessing the emotional significance of stimuli and experiencing emotions (amygdala), and in regulating and controlling emotions (like the prefrontal cortex, or PFC) (LeMoult, Castonguay, Joormann, & McAleavey, 2013).']

['How is the prefrontal cortex involved in controlling emotions?', 'People with depression show elevated amygdala activity (Drevets, Bogers, & Raichle, 2002), especially when presented with negative emotional stimuli, such as photos of sad faces (Figure 15.17) (Surguladze et al., 2005).']

['What else is known about the physiological correlates of depression?', 'Interestingly, heightened amygdala activation to negative emotional stimuli among depressed persons occurs even when stimuli are presented outside of conscious awareness (Victor, Furey, Fromm, Öhman, & Drevets, 2010), and it persists even after the negative emotional stimuli are no longer present (Siegle, Thompson, Carter, Steinhauer, & Thase, 2007).']

['What else can be concluded about the physiological correlates of depression?', 'Additionally, depressed individuals exhibit less activation in the prefrontal, particularly on the left side (Davidson, Pizzagalli, & Nitschke, 2009).']

['What else is known about the left prefrontal cortex?', 'Because the PFC can dampen amygdala activation, thereby enabling one to suppress negative emotions (Phan et al., 2005), decreased activation in certain regions of the PFC may inhibit its ability to override negative emotions that might then lead to more negative mood states (Davidson et al., 2009).']

['What else can be inferred about the left prefrontal cortex?', 'These findings suggest that people with depression are more prone to react to emotionally negative stimuli, yet have greater difficulty controlling these reactions.']

['How is cortisol related to mood and bipolar disorder?', 'Since the 1950s, researchers have noted that depressed individuals have abnormal levels of cortisol, a stress hormone released into the blood by the neuroendocrine system during times of stress (Mackin & Young, 2004).']
['What is the fight or flight response?', 'When cortisol is released, the body initiates a fight-or-flight response in reaction to a threat or danger.']

['What is an early life trauma?', 'Many people with depression show elevated cortisol levels (Holsboer & Ising, 2010), especially those reporting a history of early life trauma such as the loss of a parent or abuse during childhood (Baes, Tofoli, Martins, & Juruena, 2012).']
['What is the question?', 'Such findings raise the question of whether high cortisol levels are a cause or a consequence of depression.']

['What is the cause?', 'High levels of cortisol are a risk factor for future depression (Halligan, Herbert, Goodyer, & Murray, 2007), and cortisol activates activity in the amygdala while deactivating activity in the PFC (McEwen, 2005)—both brain disturbances are connected to depression.']
['Why is it important?', 'Thus, high cortisol levels may have a causal effect on depression, as well as on its brain function abnormalities (van Praag, 2005).']

['Are there other causes of depression?', 'Also, because stress results in increased cortisol release (Michaud, Matheson, Kelly, Anisman, 2008), it is equally reasonable to assume that stress may precipitate depression.']

['What can stress have an effect on the human body?', 'Indeed, it has long been believed that stressful life events can trigger depression, and research has consistently supported this conclusion (Mazure, 1998).']

['What can cause depression?', 'Stressful life events include significant losses, such as death of a loved one, divorce or separation, and serious health and money problems; life events such as these often precede the onset of depressive episodes (Brown & Harris, 1989).']

['what else can cause depression?', 'In particular, exit events—instances in which an important person departs (e.g., a death, divorce or separation, or a family member leaving home)—often occur prior to an episode (Paykel, 2003).']

['What happens if these happenings occur in a way that humiliates or devalues the individual?', 'Exit events are especially likely to trigger depression if these happenings occur in a way that humiliates or devalues the individual.']

['Are there more events that can cause depression?', 'For example, people who experience the breakup of a relationship initiated by the other person develop major depressive disorder at a rate more than 2 times that of people who experience the death of a loved one (Kendler, Hettema, Butera, Gardner, & Prescott, 2003).']

['What are the major points made in this section?', 'Likewise, individuals who are exposed to traumatic stress during childhood—such as separation from a parent, family turmoil, and maltreatment (physical or sexual abuse)—are at a heightened risk of developing depression at any point in their lives (Kessler, 1997).']

['What did Kessler do?', 'A recent review of 16 studies involving over 23,000 subjects concluded that those who experience childhood maltreatment are more than 2 times as likely to develop recurring and persistent depression (Nanni, Uher, & Danese, 2012).']
['Who else is at risk?', 'Of course, not everyone who experiences stressful life events or childhood adversities succumbs to depression—indeed, most do not.']

['What is the diathesis-stress interpretation of major depressive disorder?', 'Clearly, a diathesis-stress interpretation of major depressive disorder, in which certain predispositions or vulnerability factors influence one’s reaction to stress, would seem logical.']

['What is the name of a specific gene that might be one culprit?', 'A study by Caspi and others (2003) suggests that an alteration in a specific gene that regulates serotonin (the 5-HTTLPR gene) might be one culprit.']
