['What were the findings of that study?', 'These investigators found that people who experienced several stressful life events were significantly more likely to experience episodes of major depression if they carried one or two short versions of this gene than if they carried two long versions.']

['What else did the study find?', 'Those who carried one or two short versions of the 5-HTTLPR gene were unlikely to experience an episode, however, if they had experienced few or no stressful life events.']
['Did they do a follow-up study?', 'Numerous studies have replicated these findings, including studies of people who experienced maltreatment during childhood (Goodman & Brand, 2009).']

['Who did that study study?', 'In a recent investigation conducted in the United Kingdom (Brown & Harris, 2013), researchers found that childhood maltreatment before age 9 elevated the risk of chronic adult depression (a depression episode lasting for at least 12 months) among those individuals having one (LS) or two (SS) short versions of the 5-HTTLPR gene (Figure 15.18).']
['What was the biggest finding?', 'Childhood maltreatment did not increase the risk for chronic depression for those have two long (LL) versions of this gene.']
['What did the study find?', 'Thus, genetic vulnerability may be one mechanism through which stress potentially leads to depression.']

['What are the cognitive theories of depression?', 'Cognitive theories of depression take the view that depression is triggered by negative thoughts, interpretations, self-evaluations, and expectations (Joormann, 2009).']

['What is the diathesis-stress models based on?', 'These diathesis-stress models propose that depression is triggered by a “cognitive vulnerability” (negative and maladaptive thinking) and by precipitating stressful life events (Gotlib & Joormann, 2010).']

['Who developed the most well-known cognitive theory of depression?', 'Perhaps the most well-known cognitive theory of depression was developed in the 1960s by psychiatrist Aaron Beck, based on clinical observations and supported by research (Beck, 2008).']
['What did Beck theorize?', 'Beck theorized that depression-prone people possess depressive schemas, or mental predispositions to think about most things in a negative way (Beck, 1976).']

['What do these schemas contain?', 'Depressive schemas contain themes of loss, failure, rejection, worthlessness, and inadequacy, and may develop early in childhood in response to adverse experiences, then remain dormant until they are activated by stressful or negative life events.']
['What do these schemas prompt?', 'Depressive schemas prompt dysfunctional and pessimistic thoughts about the self, the world, and the future.']

['What is the consequence of these thoughts?', 'Beck believed that this dysfunctional style of thinking is maintained by cognitive biases, or errors in how we process information about ourselves, which lead us to focus on negative aspects of experiences, interpret things negatively, and block positive memories (Beck, 2008).']

['What are some of the errors in processing information?', 'A person whose depressive schema consists of a theme of rejection might be overly attentive to social cues of rejection (more likely to notice another’s frown), and they might interpret this cue as a sign of rejection and automatically remember past incidents of rejection.']

['Do others agree with him?', 'Longitudinal studies have supported Beck’s theory, in showing that a preexisting tendency to engage in this negative, self-defeating style of thinking—when combined with life stress—over time predicts the onset of depression (Dozois & Beck, 2008).']

['What are the main ideas of the passage?', 'Cognitive therapies for depression, aimed at changing a depressed person’s negative thinking, were developed as an expansion of this theory (Beck, 1976).']

['What is hopelessness theory?', 'Another cognitive theory of depression, hopelessness theory, postulates that a particular style of negative thinking leads to a sense of hopelessness, which then leads to depression (Abramson, Metalsky, & Alloy, 1989).']

['What does hopelessness mean?', 'According to this theory, hopelessness is an expectation that unpleasant outcomes will occur or that desired outcomes will not occur, and there is nothing one can do to prevent such outcomes.']

['What else did the research indicate about hopelessness theory?', 'A key assumption of this theory is that hopelessness stems from a tendency to perceive negative life events as having stable (“It’s never going to change”) and global (“It’s going to affect my whole life”) causes, in contrast to unstable (“It’s fixable”) and specific (“It applies only to this particular situation”) causes, especially if these negative life events occur in important life realms, such as relationships, academic achievement, and the like.']
['Does hopelessness theory apply to other types of situations?', 'Suppose a student who wishes to go to law school does poorly on an admissions test.']

['What happens next?', 'If the student infers negative life events as having stable and global causes, they may believe that their poor performance has a stable and global cause (“I lack intelligence, and it’s going to prevent me from ever finding a meaningful career”), as opposed to an unstable and specific cause (“I was sick the day of the exam, so my low score was a fluke”).']

['Does hopelessness theory cause depression?', 'Hopelessness theory predicts that people who exhibit this cognitive style in response to undesirable life events will view such events as having negative implications for their future and self-worth, thereby increasing the likelihood of hopelessness—the primary cause of depression (Abramson et al., 1989).']

['Do the researches show that hopelessness theory is true?', 'One study testing hopelessness theory measured the tendency to make negative inferences for bad life effects in participants who were experiencing uncontrollable stressors.']

['What happened next?', 'Over the ensuing six months, those with scores reflecting high cognitive vulnerability were 7 times more likely to develop depression compared to those with lower scores (Kleim, Gonzalo, & Ehlers, 2011).']

['What is the third cognitive theory of depression?', 'A third cognitive theory of depression focuses on how people’s thoughts about their distressed moods—depressed symptoms in particular—can increase the risk and duration of depression.']

['What is the third cognitive theory?', 'This theory, which focuses on rumination in the development of depression, was first described in the late 1980s to explain the higher rates of depression in women than in men (Nolen-Hoeksema, 1987).']

['What is the repetitive and passive focus on the fact that one is depressed and dwelling on depressed symptoms, rather that distracting one’s self from the symptoms or attempting to address them in an active, problem-solving manner?', 'Rumination is the repetitive and passive focus on the fact that one is depressed and dwelling on depressed symptoms, rather that distracting one’s self from the symptoms or attempting to address them in an active, problem-solving manner (Nolen-Hoeksema, 1991).']
['What kind of thoughts can cause rumination?', 'I’m never going to get my work done feeling this way” (Nolen-Hoeksema & Hilt, 2009, p. 393).']

['What effect does rumination have?', 'Women are more likely than men to ruminate when they are sad or depressed (Butler & Nolen-Hoeksema, 1994), and the tendency to ruminate is associated with increases in depression symptoms (Nolen-Hoeksema, Larson, & Grayson, 1999), heightened risk of major depressive episodes (Abela & Hankin, 2011), and chronicity of such episodes (Robinson & Alloy, 2003)']
['What is the reason some people consider suicide?', 'For some people with mood disorders, the extreme emotional pain they experience becomes unendurable.']

['What may be the reason they consider suicide?', 'Overwhelmed by hopelessness, devastated by incapacitating feelings of worthlessness, and burdened with the inability to adequately cope with such feelings, they may consider suicide to be a reasonable way out.']

["What is the CDC's definition of suicide?", 'Suicide, defined by the CDC as “death caused by self-directed injurious behavior with any intent to die as the result of the behavior” (CDC, 2013a), in a sense represents an outcome of several things going wrong all at the same time (Crosby, Ortega, & Melanson, 2011).']

['What else does it take to commit suicide?', 'Not only must the person be biologically or psychologically vulnerable, but they must also have the means to perform the suicidal act, and they must lack the necessary protective factors (e.g., social support from friends and family, religion, coping skills, and problem-solving skills) that provide comfort and enable one to cope during times of crisis or great psychological pain (Berman, 2009).']

['What does the DSM-5 say about suicidal behavior?', 'Suicide is not listed as a disorder in the DSM-5; however, people with a mental disorder—especially a mood disorder—have the greatest risk for suicide.']

['What is the most common mental disorder that leads to suicide?', 'Around 90% of those who die by suicide have a diagnosis of at least one mental disorder, with mood disorders being the most frequent (Fleischman, Bertolote, Belfer, & Beautrais, 2005).']

["what can mood disorders do to someone's mental health?", 'In fact, the association between major depressive disorder and suicide is so strong that one of the criteria for the disorder is thoughts of suicide, as discussed above (APA, 2013).']

['What are the most important facts about suicide?', 'Suicide rates can be difficult to interpret because some deaths that appear to be accidental may in fact be acts of suicide (e.g., automobile crash).']
['Are there any other important facts about suicide?', 'Nevertheless, investigations into U.S. suicide rates have uncovered these facts:']
['What was the 10th leading cause of death for all ages in 2010?', 'Suicide was the 10th leading cause of death for all ages in 2010 (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2012).']
['How many suicides happened in 2010 in the United States?', 'There were 38,364 suicides in 2010 in the United States—an average of 105 each day (CDC, 2012).']

['How was suicide caused?', 'Suicide among males is 4 times higher than among females and accounts for 79% of all suicides; firearms are the most commonly used method of suicide for males, whereas poisoning is the most commonly used method for females (CDC, 2012).']
['Are there any other notable things in the article?', 'From 1991 to 2003, suicide rates were consistently higher among those 65 years and older.']

['When did the spike occur?', 'Since 2001, however, suicide rates among those ages 25–64 have risen consistently, and, since 2006, suicide rates have been greater for those ages 65 and older (CDC, 2013b).']

['Who was most susceptible to suicide?', 'This increase in suicide rates among middle-aged Americans has prompted concern in some quarters that baby boomers (individuals born between 1946–1964) who face economic worry and easy access to prescription medication may be particularly vulnerable to suicide (Parker-Pope, 2013).']
['What group had the highest suicide rates?', 'The highest rates of suicide within the United States are among American Indians/Alaskan natives and Non-Hispanic White people (CDC, 2013b).']

['Which state has the highest suicide rate?', 'Suicide rates vary across the United States, with the highest rates consistently found in the mountain states of the west (Alaska, Montana, Nevada, Wyoming, Colorado, and Idaho) (Berman, 2009).']
['What is the most common belief about suicide?', 'Contrary to popular belief, suicide rates peak during the springtime (April and May), not during the holiday season or winter.']
['What is the reason that suicide rates are generally lowest during the winter months?', 'In fact, suicide rates are generally lowest during the winter months (Postolache et al., 2010).']
['What are some of the most important factors relating to suicide?', 'Suicidal risk is especially high among people with substance use problems.']
['What are the consequences of substance use problems?', 'Individuals with alcohol dependence are at 10 times greater risk for suicide than the general population (Wilcox, Conner, & Caine, 2004).']
['What can a suicidal individual do?', 'The risk of suicidal behavior is especially high among those who have made a prior suicide attempt.']
['What other factors?', 'Among those who attempt suicide, 16% make another attempt within a year and over 21% make another attempt within four years (Owens, Horrocks, & House, 2002).']

['What other factors are important to consider when trying to save a life?', 'Suicidal individuals may be at high risk for terminating their life if they have a lethal means in which to act, such as a firearm in the home (Brent & Bridge, 2003).']

['What is another factor that may lead to suicidal behavior?', 'Withdrawal from social relationships, feeling as though one is a burden to others, and engaging in reckless and risk-taking behaviors may be precursors to suicidal behavior (Berman, 2009).']

['How can a sense of entrapment or feeling unable to escape one’s miserable feelings or external circumstances predict suicidal behavior?', 'A sense of entrapment or feeling unable to escape one’s miserable feelings or external circumstances (e.g., an abusive relationship with no perceived way out) predicts suicidal behavior (O’Connor, Smyth, Ferguson, Ryan, & Williams, 2013).']
['What are some other ways to prevent cyberbullying?', 'Tragically, reports of suicides among adolescents following instances of cyberbullying have emerged in recent years.']

['What are some examples of cyberbullying?', 'In one widely-publicized case a few years ago, Phoebe Prince, a 15-year-old Massachusetts high school student, died by suicide following incessant harassment and taunting from her classmates via texting and Facebook (McCabe, 2010).']
['What can be contagious?', 'Suicides can have a contagious effect on people.']
['What is the contagious effect of suicide?', 'For example, another’s suicide, especially that of a family member, heightens one’s risk of suicide (Agerbo, Nordentoft, & Mortensen, 2002).']
['What is another example of suicide?', 'Additionally, widely-publicized suicides tend to trigger additional suicides in some individuals.']

['How are suicides a contagious effect?', 'One study examining suicide statistics in the United States from 1947–1967 found that the rates of suicide increased significantly for the first month after a report about suicide was printed on the front page of the New York Times (Phillips, 1974).']

['What did Austrian researchers find?', 'Austrian researchers found a significant increase in the number of suicides by firearms in the three weeks following extensive reports in Austria’s largest newspaper of a celebrity suicide by gun (Etzersdorfer, Voracek, & Sonneck, 2004).']

['What is the study about?', 'A review of 42 studies concluded that media coverage of celebrity suicides is more than 14 times more likely to trigger copycat suicides than is coverage of non-celebrity suicides (Stack, 2000).']

['What is the most important thing in this study?', 'This review also demonstrated that the medium of coverage is important: televised stories are considerably less likely to prompt a surge in suicides than are newspaper stories.']

['What is the trend of people using online social media to leave suicide notes?', 'Research suggests that a trend appears to be emerging whereby people use online social media to leave suicide notes, although it is not clear to what extent suicide notes on such media might induce subsequent suicides (Ruder, Hatch, Ampanozi, Thali, & Fischer, 2011).']

['Is there anything else that you would like to know?', 'Nevertheless, it is reasonable to conjecture that suicide notes left by individuals on social media may influence the decisions of other vulnerable people who encounter them (Luxton, June, & Fairall, 2012).']
['What kind of factors contribute to suicide?', 'One possible contributing factor in suicide is brain chemistry.']

['What is meant by disturbances in the functioning of serotonin?', 'Contemporary neurological research shows that disturbances in the functioning of serotonin are linked to suicidal behavior (Pompili et al., 2010).']

['what is the function of serotonin?', 'Low levels of serotonin predict future suicide attempts and death by suicide, and low levels have been observed post-mortem among suicide victims (Mann, 2003).']

['What else does serotonin contribute to?', 'Serotonin dysfunction, as noted earlier, is also known to play an important role in depression; low levels of serotonin have also been linked to aggression and impulsivity (Stanley et al., 2000).']
['What is the relationship between these two conditions?', 'The combination of these three characteristics constitutes a potential formula for suicide—especially violent suicide.']

['Does serotonin influence suicide?', 'A classic study conducted during the 1970s found that patients with major depressive disorder who had very low levels of serotonin attempted suicide more frequently and more violently than did patients with higher levels (Asberg, Thorén, Träskman, Bertilsson, & Ringberger, 1976; Mann, 2003).']
['What should we do if someone is suicidal?', 'Suicidal thoughts, plans, and even off-hand remarks (“I might kill myself this afternoon”) should always be taken extremely seriously.']
['What should we do when someone contemplates suicide?', 'People who contemplate terminating their life need immediate help.']

['What other resources can we use?', 'Below is a link to an excellent website that contains resources (including hotlines) for people who are struggling with suicidal ideation, have loved ones who may be suicidal, or who have lost loved ones to suicide: http://www.afsp.org.']
['What other resources are there?', 'You can also contact the 24-hour National Suicide Prevention Hotline by calling 1-800-273-8255 or texting HELLO to 741741 to access their Crisis Text Line.']
['What is schizophrenia?', 'Schizophrenia is a psychological disorder that is characterized by major disturbances in thought, perception, emotion, and behavior.']

['What is the first age schizophrenia is diagnosed?', 'About 1% of the population experiences schizophrenia in their lifetime, and usually the disorder is first diagnosed during early adulthood (early to mid-20s).']

['What are the difficulties of those with schizophrenia?', 'Most people with schizophrenia experience significant difficulties in many day-to-day activities, such as holding a job, paying bills, caring for oneself (grooming and hygiene), and maintaining relationships with others.']
['What are the frequent hospitalizations with schizophrenia?', 'Frequent hospitalizations are more often the rule rather than the exception with schizophrenia.']

['What else do we need to know about schizophrenia?', 'Even when they receive the best treatments available, many with schizophrenia will continue to experience serious social and occupational impairment throughout their lives.']

['What is unique about schizophrenia?', 'First, schizophrenia is not a condition involving a split personality; that is, schizophrenia is not the same thing as dissociative identity disorder (better known as multiple personality disorder).']

['What is the word schizophrenia first coined by the Swiss psychiatrist Eugen Bleuler in 1911, derives from Greek words that refer to a “splitting” (schizo) of psychic functions (phrene)?', 'These disorders are sometimes confused because the word schizophrenia first coined by the Swiss psychiatrist Eugen Bleuler in 1911, derives from Greek words that refer to a “splitting” (schizo) of psychic functions (phrene) (Green, 2001).']

['What is schizophrenia?', 'Schizophrenia is considered a psychotic disorder, or one in which the person’s thoughts, perceptions, and behaviors are impaired to the point where they are not able to function normally in life.']

["What is the difference between a psychotic disorder and the typical person's?", 'In informal terms, one who suffers from a psychotic disorder (that is, has a psychosis) is disconnected from the world in which most of us live.']

['What are the symptoms of schizophrenia?', 'The main symptoms of schizophrenia include hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, disorganized or abnormal motor behavior, and negative symptoms (APA, 2013).']
['What is a hallucination?', 'A hallucination is a perceptual experience that occurs in the absence of external stimulation.']

['What happens when you hear voices?', 'Auditory hallucinations (hearing voices) occur in roughly two-thirds of patients with schizophrenia and are by far the most common form of hallucination (Andreasen, 1987).']

['What happens with the voices?', 'The voices may be familiar or unfamiliar, they may have a conversation or argue, or the voices may provide a running commentary on the person’s behavior (Tsuang, Farone, & Green, 1999).']

['What are beliefs that are contrary to reality and are firmly held even in the face of contradictory evidence?', 'Delusions are beliefs that are contrary to reality and are firmly held even in the face of contradictory evidence.']
['Do they think in a different way?', 'Many of us hold beliefs that some would consider odd, but a delusion is easily identified because it is clearly absurd.']

['what are paranoid delusions?', 'A person with schizophrenia may believe that their mother is plotting with the FBI to poison their coffee, or that their neighbor is an enemy spy who wants to kill them.']

['What kinds of delusions are known as paranoid delusions?', 'These kinds of delusions are known as paranoid delusions, which involve the (false) belief that other people or agencies are plotting to harm the person.']

['do they believe that they are powerful or are special?', 'People with schizophrenia also may hold grandiose delusions, beliefs that one holds special power, unique knowledge, or is extremely important.']

['What is the most important reason to believe this?', 'For example, the person who claims to be Jesus Christ, or who claims to have knowledge going back 5,000 years, or who claims to be a great philosopher is experiencing grandiose delusions.']

['What other delusions can you tell me about?', 'Other delusions include the belief that one’s thoughts are being removed (thought withdrawal) or thoughts have been placed inside one’s head (thought insertion).']

['What is another type of delusion?', 'Another type of delusion is somatic delusion, which is the belief that something highly abnormal is happening to one’s body (e.g., that one’s kidneys are being eaten by cockroaches).']
['What is disorganized thinking?', 'Disorganized thinking refers to disjointed and incoherent thought processes—usually detected by what a person says.']

['What is the best way to detect it?', 'The person might ramble, exhibit loose associations (jump from topic to topic), or talk in a way that is so disorganized and incomprehensible that it seems as though the person is randomly combining words.']
['Are there any other ways to detect disorganized thinking?', 'Disorganized thinking is also exhibited by blatantly illogical remarks (e.g., “Fenway Park is in Boston.']
['Do you live in Boston?', 'I live in Boston.']

['What is the rationale behind that statement?', 'Therefore, I live at Fenway Park.”) and by tangentiality: responding to others’ statements or questions by remarks that are either barely related or unrelated to what was said or asked.']

['What are some examples of disorganized thinking?', 'For example, if a person diagnosed with schizophrenia is asked if they are interested in receiving special job training, they might state that they once rode on a train somewhere.']
['Why is that relevant?', 'To a person with schizophrenia, the tangential (slightly related) connection between job training and riding a train are sufficient enough to cause such a response.']

['What is abnormal motor behavior?', 'Disorganized or abnormal motor behavior refers to unusual behaviors and movements: becoming unusually active, exhibiting silly child-like behaviors (giggling and self-absorbed smiling), engaging in repeated and purposeless movements, or displaying odd facial expressions and gestures.']

['What are some unusual activities that a person with a mental illness might exhibit?', 'In some cases, the person will exhibit catatonic behaviors, which show decreased reactivity to the environment, such as posturing, in which the person maintains a rigid and bizarre posture for long periods of time, or catatonic stupor, a complete lack of movement and verbal behavior.']
['What are negative symptoms?', 'Negative symptoms are those that reflect noticeable decreases and absences in certain behaviors, emotions, or drives (Green, 2001).']

['What is diminished emotional expression?', 'A person who exhibits diminished emotional expression shows no emotion in their facial expressions, speech, or movements, even when such expressions are normal or expected.']
['What is anhedonia?', 'Avolition is characterized by a lack of motivation to engage in self-initiated and meaningful activity, including the most basic of tasks, such as bathing and grooming.']
['What is alogia?', 'Alogia refers to reduced speech output; in simple terms, patients do not say much.']
['what is another negative symptom?', 'Another negative symptom is asociality, or social withdrawal and lack of interest in engaging in social interactions with others.']
['what is anhedonia?', 'A final negative symptom, anhedonia, refers to an inability to experience pleasure.']
['What is anhedonia?', 'One who exhibits anhedonia expresses little interest in what most people consider to be pleasurable activities, such as hobbies, recreation, or sexual activity.']
['What is the evidence that schizophrenia has a genetic basis?', 'There is considerable evidence suggesting that schizophrenia has a genetic basis.']

['How much greater is the risk of developing schizophrenia if family members are diagnosed and developing schizophrenia increases?', 'The risk of developing schizophrenia is nearly 6 times greater if one has a parent with schizophrenia than if one does not (Goldstein, Buka, Seidman, & Tsuang, 2010).']

['Are there other risk factors that increase schizophrenia?', 'Additionally, one’s risk of developing schizophrenia increases as genetic relatedness to family members diagnosed with schizophrenia increases (Gottesman, 2001).']

['What are some important things to know about the content?', 'When considering the role of genetics in schizophrenia, as in any disorder, conclusions based on family and twin studies are subject to criticism.']

['Why are twin studies subject to criticism?', 'This is because family members who are closely related (such as siblings) are more likely to share similar environments than are family members who are less closely related (such as cousins); further, identical twins may be more likely to be treated similarly by others than might fraternal twins.']
['Is there any other important thing to know about twin studies?', 'Thus, family and twin studies cannot completely rule out the possible effects of shared environments and experiences.']
['What is the best way to correct this?', 'Such problems can be corrected by using adoption studies, in which children are separated from their parents at an early age.']

['What other interesting info is there about adoption studies?', 'One of the first adoption studies of schizophrenia conducted by Heston (1966) followed 97 adoptees, including 47 who were born to mothers with schizophrenia, over a 36-year period.']

['Did the adoption studies show that genetics plays a role in schizophrenia?', 'Five of the 47 adoptees (11%) whose mothers had schizophrenia were later diagnosed with schizophrenia, compared to none of the 50 control adoptees.']

['What other studies have consistently reported that for adoptees who are later diagnosed with schizophrenia, their biological relatives have a higher risk of schizophrenia than do adoptive relatives?', 'Other adoption studies have consistently reported that for adoptees who are later diagnosed with schizophrenia, their biological relatives have a higher risk of schizophrenia than do adoptive relatives (Shih, Belmonte, & Zandi, 2004).']

['What is a factor in schizophrenia?', 'Although adoption studies have supported the hypothesis that genetic factors contribute to schizophrenia, they have also demonstrated that the disorder most likely arises from a combination of genetic and environmental factors, rather than just genes themselves.']
['What was the example of schizophrenia?', 'For example, investigators in one study examined the rates of schizophrenia among 303 adoptees (Tienari et al., 2004).']

['What group of adoptees had biological mothers with schizophrenia?', 'A total of 145 of the adoptees had biological mothers with schizophrenia; these adoptees constituted the high genetic risk group.']
['What other factors contribute to schizophrenia?', 'The other 158 adoptees had mothers with no psychiatric history; these adoptees composed the low genetic risk group.']
['What did the researchers do?', 'The researchers managed to determine whether the adoptees’ families were either healthy or disturbed.']

['What was considered disturbed?', 'For example, the adoptees were considered to be raised in a disturbed family environment if the family exhibited a lot of criticism, conflict, and a lack of problem-solving skills.']

['What were the results of the study?', 'The findings revealed that adoptees whose biological mothers had schizophrenia (high genetic risk) and who had been raised in a disturbed family environment were much more likely to develop schizophrenia or another psychotic disorder (36.8%) than were adoptees whose biological mothers had schizophrenia but who had been raised in a healthy environment (5.8%), or than adoptees with a low genetic risk who were raised in either a disturbed (5.3%) or healthy (4.8%) environment.']

['What does this mean?', 'Because the adoptees who were at high genetic risk were likely to develop schizophrenia only if they were raised in a disturbed home environment, this study supports a diathesis-stress interpretation of schizophrenia—both genetic vulnerability and environmental stress are necessary for schizophrenia to develop, genes alone do not show the complete picture.']

['If we accept that schizophrenia is at least partly genetic in origin, as it seems to be, what is the next step?', 'If we accept that schizophrenia is at least partly genetic in origin, as it seems to be, it makes sense that the next step should be to identify biological abnormalities commonly found in people with the disorder.']
['What are the main things that people think about schizophrenia?', 'Perhaps not surprisingly, a number of neurobiological factors have indeed been found to be related to schizophrenia.']

['What is the most common factor that has received considerable attention for many years?', 'One such factor that has received considerable attention for many years is the neurotransmitter dopamine.']

['What are two examples of drugs that increase dopamine levels?', 'Interest in the role of dopamine in schizophrenia was stimulated by two sets of findings: drugs that increase dopamine levels can produce schizophrenia-like symptoms, and medications that block dopamine activity reduce the symptoms (Howes & Kapur, 2009).']

['What is the theory behind schizophrenia?', 'The dopamine hypothesis of schizophrenia proposed that an overabundance of dopamine or too many dopamine receptors are responsible for the onset and maintenance of schizophrenia (Snyder, 1976).']
['how is this implicated?', 'More recent work in this area suggests that abnormalities in dopamine vary by brain region and thus contribute to symptoms in unique ways.']

['Are there differences between the two brain regions?', 'In general, this research has suggested that an overabundance of dopamine in the limbic system may be responsible for some symptoms, such as hallucinations and delusions, whereas low levels of dopamine in the prefrontal cortex might be responsible primarily for the negative symptoms (avolition, alogia, asociality, and anhedonia) (Davis, Kahn, Ko, & Davidson, 1991).']

['does this help in the treatment?', 'In recent years, serotonin has received attention, and newer antipsychotic medications used to treat the disorder work by blocking serotonin receptors (Baumeister & Hawkins, 2004).']

['What is one example of a neurological difference between people with schizophrenia and other cases?', 'Brain imaging studies reveal that people with schizophrenia have enlarged ventricles, the cavities within the brain that contain cerebral spinal fluid (Green, 2001).']

['What does larger than normal ventricles suggest?', 'This finding is important because larger than normal ventricles suggests that various brain regions are reduced in size, thus implying that schizophrenia is associated with a loss of brain tissue.']

['What other differences are present between people with schizophrenia and other cases?', 'In addition, many people with schizophrenia display a reduction in gray matter (cell bodies of neurons) in the frontal lobes (Lawrie & Abukmeil, 1998), and many show less frontal lobe activity when performing cognitive tasks (Buchsbaum et al., 1990).']

['What are the frontal lobes important in?', 'The frontal lobes are important in a variety of complex cognitive functions, such as planning and executing behavior, attention, speech, movement, and problem solving.']
['What does this mean?', 'Hence, abnormalities in this region provide merit in explaining why people with schizophrenia experience deficits in these of areas.']
['What might be the reason for this event occurring?', 'A number of environmental factors that could impact normal brain development might be at fault.']

['What is the most important fact about this information?', 'High rates of obstetric complications in the births of children who later developed schizophrenia have been reported (Cannon, Jones, & Murray, 2002).']

['What are some other facts about influenza?', 'In addition, people are at an increased risk for developing schizophrenia if their mother was exposed to influenza during the first trimester of pregnancy (Brown et al., 2004).']
['What else is significant about this information?', 'Research has also suggested that a person’s emotional stress during pregnancy may increase the risk of schizophrenia in offspring.']

['What is the risk of schizophrenia in offspring whose mothers experienced the death of a relative during the first trimester of pregnancy?', 'One study reported that the risk of schizophrenia is elevated substantially in offspring whose mothers experienced the death of a relative during the first trimester of pregnancy (Khashan et al., 2008).']
['What is another variable that is linked to schizophrenia?', 'Another variable that is linked to schizophrenia is marijuana use.']

['What studies have been done about marijuana use?', 'Although a number of reports have shown that individuals with schizophrenia are more likely to use marijuana than are individuals without schizophrenia (Thornicroft, 1990), such investigations cannot determine if marijuana use leads to schizophrenia, or vice versa.']

['What studies have found marijuana use to be a risk factor for schizophrenia?', 'However, a number of longitudinal studies have suggested that marijuana use is, in fact, a risk factor for schizophrenia.']

['What is another study about marijuana use and schizophrenia?', 'A classic investigation of over 45,000 Swedish military personnel who were followed up after 15 years found that those individuals who had reported using marijuana at least once by the time they were conscripted (drafted) into the military were more than 2 times as likely to develop schizophrenia during the ensuing 15 years than were those who reported never using marijuana; those who had indicated using marijuana 50 or more times were 6 times as likely to develop schizophrenia (Andréasson, Allbeck, Engström, & Rydberg, 1987).']

['Are there any other studies?', 'More recently, a review of 35 longitudinal studies found a substantially increased risk of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders in people who had used marijuana, with the greatest risk in the most frequent users (Moore et al., 2007).']
['What else has been found?', 'Other work has found that marijuana use is associated with an onset of psychotic disorders at an earlier age (Large, Sharma, Compton, Slade, & Nielssen, 2011).']

['What can you tell me about the study?', 'Overall, the available evidence seems to indicate that marijuana use plays a causal role in the development of schizophrenia, although it is important to point out that marijuana use is not an essential or sufficient risk factor as not all people with schizophrenia have used marijuana and the majority of marijuana users do not develop schizophrenia (Casadio, Fernandes, Murray, & Di Forti, 2011).']

['Can you tell me what the studies found?', 'One plausible interpretation of the data is that early marijuana use may disrupt normal brain development during important early maturation periods in adolescence (Trezza, Cuomo, & Vanderschuren, 2008).']

['What are these important developmental periods?', 'Thus, early marijuana use may set the stage for the development of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders, especially among individuals with an established vulnerability (Casadio et al., 2011).']

["What's the importance of early detection of cancer?", 'Early detection and treatment of conditions such as heart disease and cancer have improved survival rates and quality of life for people who suffer from these conditions.']

['What is another important thing to know?', 'A new approach involves identifying people who show minor symptoms of psychosis, such as unusual thought content, paranoia, odd communication, delusions, problems at school or work, and a decline in social functioning—which are coined prodromal symptoms—and following these individuals over time to determine which of them develop a psychotic disorder and which factors best predict such a disorder.']

["What's the greatest risk?", 'A number of factors have been identified that predict a greater likelihood that prodromal individuals will develop a psychotic disorder: genetic risk (a family history of psychosis), recent deterioration in functioning, high levels of unusual thought content, high levels of suspicion or paranoia, poor social functioning, and a history of substance abuse (Fusar-Poli et al., 2013).']

['What is the purpose of further research?', 'Further research will enable a more accurate prediction of those at greatest risk for developing schizophrenia, and thus to whom early intervention efforts should be directed.']
['What are the dissociative disorders?', 'Dissociative disorders are characterized by an individual becoming split off, or dissociated, from their core sense of self.']
['What happens after that?', 'Memory and identity become disturbed; these disturbances have a psychological rather than physical cause.']

['What are the dissociative disorders listed in the DSM-5?', 'Dissociative disorders listed in the DSM-5 include dissociative amnesia, depersonalization/derealization disorder, and dissociative identity disorder.']
['What is amnesia?', 'Amnesia refers to the partial or total forgetting of some experience or event.']

['What is the main characteristic of dissociative amnesia?', 'An individual with dissociative amnesia is unable to recall important personal information, usually following an extremely stressful or traumatic experience such as combat, natural disasters, or being the victim of violence.']
['Are the memory impairments caused by ordinary forgetting?', 'The memory impairments are not caused by ordinary forgetting.']

['what is fugue?', 'Some individuals with dissociative amnesia will also experience dissociative fugue (from the word “to flee” in French), whereby they suddenly wander away from their home, experience confusion about their identity, and sometimes even adopt a new identity (Cardeña & Gleaves, 2006).']
['How long do the fugue episodes last?', 'Most fugue episodes last only a few hours or days, but some can last longer.']

['How common is dissociative amnesia?', 'One study of residents in communities in upstate New York reported that about 1.8% experienced dissociative amnesia in the previous year (Johnson, Cohen, Kasen, & Brook, 2006).']

['What is interesting about the content of this document?', 'Some have questioned the validity of dissociative amnesia (Pope, Hudson, Bodkin, & Oliva, 1998); it has even been characterized as a “piece of psychiatric folklore devoid of convincing empirical support” (McNally, 2003, p. 275).']

['What else is interesting about dissociative amnesia?', 'Notably, scientific publications regarding dissociative amnesia rose during the 1980s and reached a peak in the mid-1990s, followed by an equally sharp decline by 2003; in fact, only 13 cases of individuals with dissociative amnesia worldwide could be found in the literature that same year (Pope, Barry, Bodkin, & Hudson, 2006).']

['Did it ever get better?', 'Further, no description of individuals showing dissociative amnesia following a trauma exists in any fictional or nonfictional work prior to 1800 (Pope, Poliakoff, Parker, Boynes, & Hudson, 2006).']

['How was it diagnosed?', 'However, a study of 82 individuals who enrolled for treatment at a psychiatric outpatient hospital found that nearly 10% met the criteria for dissociative amnesia, perhaps suggesting that the condition is underdiagnosed, especially in psychiatric populations (Foote, Smolin, Kaplan, Legatt, & Lipschitz, 2006).']
['What is depersonalization/derealization disorder?', 'Depersonalization/derealization disorder is characterized by recurring episodes of depersonalization, derealization, or both.']

['What is the definition of depersonalization?', 'Depersonalization is defined as feelings of “unreality or detachment from, or unfamiliarity with, one’s whole self or from aspects of the self” (APA, 2013, p. 302).']

['How does depersonalization affect people?', 'Individuals who experience depersonalization might believe their thoughts and feelings are not their own; they may feel robotic as though they lack control over their movements and speech; they may experience a distorted sense of time and, in extreme cases, they may sense an “out-of-body” experience in which they see themselves from the vantage point of another person.']

['What is the sense of "unreality or detachment from, or unfamiliarity with, the world, be it individuals, inanimate objects, or all surroundings"?', 'Derealization is conceptualized as a sense of “unreality or detachment from, or unfamiliarity with, the world, be it individuals, inanimate objects, or all surroundings” (APA, 2013, p. 303).']

['What might a person who experiences derealization feel like?', 'A person who experiences derealization might feel as though they are in a fog or a dream, or that the surrounding world is somehow artificial and unreal.']

['What is the name of the disorder that makes a person think they are going crazy?', 'Individuals with depersonalization/derealization disorder often have difficulty describing their symptoms and may think they are going crazy (APA, 2013).']
['What is the most well-known dissociative disorder?', 'By far, the most well-known dissociative disorder is dissociative identity disorder (formerly called multiple personality disorder).']

['What causes dissociative identity disorder?', 'People with dissociative identity disorder exhibit two or more separate personalities or identities, each well-defined and distinct from one another.']

['what are the symptoms?', 'They also experience memory gaps for the time during which another identity is in charge (e.g., one might find unfamiliar items in their shopping bags or among their possessions), and in some cases may report hearing voices, such as a child’s voice or the sound of somebody crying (APA, 2013).']

['Did anyone study dissociative identity disorder?', 'The study of upstate New York residents mentioned above (Johnson et al., 2006) reported that 1.5% of their sample experienced symptoms consistent with dissociative identity disorder in the previous year.']
['What kind of controversy did you find?', 'Dissociative identity disorder (DID) is highly controversial.']

['What do they mean by saying people fake symptoms?', 'Some believe that people fake symptoms to avoid the consequences of illegal actions (e.g., “I am not responsible for shoplifting because it was my other personality”).']

['Is there any evidence that people fake symptoms?', 'In fact, it has been demonstrated that people are generally skilled at adopting the role of a person with different personalities when they believe it might be advantageous to do so.']

['Can you give me some examples of people pretending to have multiple personalities?', 'As an example, Kenneth Bianchi was an infamous serial killer who, along with his cousin, murdered over a dozen girls and women around Los Angeles in the late 1970s.']
['What happened to Bianchi and his cousin?', 'Eventually, he and his cousin were apprehended.']

['What was his defense?', 'At Bianchi’s trial, he pled not guilty by reason of insanity, presenting himself as though he had DID and claiming that a different personality (“Steve Walker”) committed the murders.']
['How did his trial go?', 'When these claims were scrutinized, he admitted faking the symptoms and was found guilty (Schwartz, 1981).']
['What is the second reason that DID is controversial?', 'A second reason DID is controversial is because rates of the disorder suddenly skyrocketed in the 1980s.']

['What is the most recent year that DID was identified?', 'More cases of DID were identified during the five years prior to 1986 than in the preceding two centuries (Putnam, Guroff, Silberman, Barban, & Post, 1986).']

['what is this increase from?', 'Although this increase may be due to the development of more sophisticated diagnostic techniques, it is also possible that the popularization of DID—helped in part by Sybil, a popular 1970s book (and later film) about a woman with 16 different personalities—may have prompted clinicians to overdiagnose the disorder (Piper & Merskey, 2004).']

['What other interesting information is there?', 'Casting further scrutiny on the existence of multiple personalities or identities is the recent suggestion that the story of Sybil was largely fabricated, and the idea for the book might have been exaggerated (Nathan, 2011).']

['What can you tell me about the disorder?', 'Despite its controversial nature, DID is clearly a legitimate and serious disorder, and although some people may fake symptoms, others suffer their entire lives with it.']

['People with this disorder tend to report a history of what kind of abuse?', 'People with this disorder tend to report a history of childhood trauma, some cases having been corroborated through medical or legal records (Cardeña & Gleaves, 2006).']
['Did it happen in their childhood?', 'Research by Ross et al. (1990) suggests that in one study about 95% of people with DID were physically and/or sexually abused as children.']
['How can abuse be validated?', 'Of course, not all reports of childhood abuse can be expected to be valid or accurate.']

['What can you tell me about dissociative states?', 'However, there is strong evidence that traumatic experiences can cause people to experience states of dissociation, suggesting that dissociative states—including the adoption of multiple personalities—may serve as a psychologically important coping mechanism for threat and danger (Dalenberg et al., 2012).']

['What are the disorders we have discussed so far typically diagnosed in?', 'Most of the disorders we have discussed so far are typically diagnosed in adulthood, although they can and sometimes do occur during childhood.']

['What are the conditions that do occur during childhood?', 'However, there are a group of conditions that, when present, are diagnosed early in childhood, often before the time a child enters school.']

['What are these conditions listed as in the DSM-5?', 'These conditions are listed in the DSM-5 as neurodevelopmental disorders, and they involve developmental problems in personal, social, academic, and intellectual functioning (APA, 2013).']
['What happens to people with these conditions?', 'While they are often diagnosed in childhood, many people live with them throughout adulthood.']
['What are some disorders that are discussed in this section?', 'In this section, we will discuss two such disorders: attention deficit/ hyperactivity disorder and autism.']
['How does Diego react to this question?', 'Diego is always active, from the time he wakes up in the morning until the time he goes to bed at night.']
['What is the most important thing you wish to share with the reader?', 'His mother reports that he came out the womb kicking and screaming, and he has not stopped moving since.']
["Are you concerned about Diego's attention span?", 'He has a sweet disposition, but always seems to be in trouble with his teachers, parents, and after-school program counselors.']
['What else do you see in his behavior?', 'He seems to accidentally break things; he lost his jacket three times last winter, and he never seems to sit still.']
['What can we learn about his teachers?', 'His teachers believe he is a smart child, but he never finishes anything he starts and is so impulsive that he does not seem to learn much in school.']
['Diego is a child with attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder. What is the disorder?', 'Diego likely has attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']
['What was the first person to describe the symptoms of ADHD?', 'The symptoms of this disorder were first described by Hans Hoffman in the 1920s.']

["What was Hoffman's initial observation?", 'While taking care of his son while his wife was in the hospital giving birth to a second child, Hoffman noticed that the boy had trouble concentrating on his homework, had a short attention span, and had to repeatedly go over easy homework to learn the material (Jellinek & Herzog, 1999).']

['What else was discovered about ADHD?', 'Later, it was discovered that many hyperactive children—those who are fidgety, restless, socially disruptive, and have trouble with impulse control—also display short attention spans, problems with concentration, and distractibility.']
['What else is important about this topic?', 'By the 1970s, it had become clear that many children who display attention problems often also exhibit signs of hyperactivity.']

['What else happened with this discovery?', 'In recognition of such findings, the DSM-III (published in 1980) included a new disorder: attention deficit disorder with and without hyperactivity, now known as attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']

['What is the main characteristic of a child with ADHD?', 'A child with ADHD shows a constant pattern of inattention and/or hyperactive and impulsive behavior that interferes with normal functioning (APA, 2013).']

['What are the signs of inattention?', 'Some of the signs of inattention include great difficulty with and avoidance of tasks that require sustained attention (such as conversations or reading), failure to follow instructions (often resulting in failure to complete school work and other duties), disorganization (difficulty keeping things in order, poor time management, sloppy and messy work), lack of attention to detail, becoming easily distracted, and forgetfulness.']

['What kind of symptoms does it have?', 'Hyperactivity is characterized by excessive movement, and includes fidgeting or squirming, leaving one’s seat in situations when remaining seated is expected, having trouble sitting still (e.g., in a restaurant), running about and climbing on things, blurting out responses before another person’s question or statement has been completed, difficulty waiting one’s turn for something, and interrupting and intruding on others.']
['What kind of symptoms does it have?', 'Frequently, the hyperactive child comes across as noisy and boisterous.']

['What kind of symptoms does it have?', 'The child’s behavior is hasty, impulsive, and seems to occur without much forethought; these characteristics may explain why adolescents and young adults diagnosed with ADHD receive more traffic tickets and have more automobile accidents than do others (Thompson, Molina, Pelham, & Gnagy, 2007).']

['What are some notable facts about this issue?', 'ADHD occurs in about 8% of children (Danielson et al, 2016), and studies estimate that for about 60% of these people, ADHD continues into adulthood (Sibley et al 2016).']

['What else is important about this topic?', 'On the average, boys are 3 times more likely to have ADHD than are girls; however, such findings might reflect the greater propensity of boys to engage in aggressive and antisocial behavior and thus incur a greater likelihood of being referred to psychological clinics (Barkley, 2006).']
['What is important about children with ADHD?', 'Children with ADHD face severe academic and social challenges.']

['What are the challenges for children with ADHD?', 'Compared to their non-ADHD counterparts, children with ADHD have lower grades and standardized test scores and higher rates of expulsion, grade retention, and dropping out (Loe & Feldman, 2007).']
['What other social challenges does it cause?', 'they also are less well-liked and more often rejected by their peers (Hoza et al., 2005).']
['What are some important aspects about this?', 'Children with ADHD face considerably worse long-term outcomes than do those children who do not have ADHD.']

['What are the consequences of not treating it?', 'Adults diagnosed with ADHD in childhood, but not treated for ADHD, have been reported to have poor outcomes in a wide range of areas of life, including social function, education, criminality, alcohol use, substance use, and occupational outcomes (Arnold et al, 2015).']

['What is one of the best pieces of research about ADHD?', 'In one investigation, 135 adults who had been identified as having ADHD symptoms in the 1970s were contacted decades later and interviewed (Klein et al., 2012).']
['What was the result?', 'Compared to a control sample of 136 participants who had never been diagnosed with ADHD, those who were diagnosed as children:']

['What do you find interesting about life problems related to ADHD?', 'had worse educational attainment (more likely to have dropped out of high school and less likely to have earned a bachelor’s degree); had lower socioeconomic status; held less prestigious occupational positions; were more likely to be unemployed; made considerably less in salary; scored worse on a measure of occupational functioning (indicating, for example, lower job satisfaction, poorer work relationships, and more firings); scored worse on a measure of social functioning (indicating, for example, fewer friendships and less involvement in social activities); were more likely to be divorced; and were more likely to have non-alcohol-related substance abuse problems.']
['Are there any studies relating to the issue?', '(Klein et al., 2012)']
['What type of problems are related to it?', 'Longitudinal studies also show that children diagnosed with ADHD are at higher risk for substance abuse problems.']

['What kind of substance abuse problems did childhood ADHD predict?', 'One study reported that childhood ADHD predicted later drinking problems, daily smoking, and use of marijuana and other illicit drugs (Molina & Pelham, 2003).']

['Are there any other problems that are related to it?', 'The risk of substance abuse problems appears to be even greater for those with ADHD who also exhibit antisocial tendencies (Marshal & Molina, 2006).']

['What is the most important information in this passage?', 'Diagnosis, treatment, and general awareness of ADHD has certainly improved in the decades since the people in the above studies were diagnosed.']
['What do recent studies show?', 'Studies that include more recent outcomes show positive effects of treatment as opposed to non-treatment (Harpin, 2013; Arnold 2015).']
['What do the studies indicate?', 'In most cases, the same studies indicate that more research and work needs to be undertaken to understand the most effect treatments and their impacts.']
['What is a significant role in the development of ADHD?', 'Family and twin studies indicate that genetics play a significant role in the development of ADHD.']

['What was the median rate of concordance for identical twins?', 'Burt (2009), in a review of 26 studies, reported that the median rate of concordance for identical twins was .66 (one study reported a rate of .90), whereas the median concordance rate for fraternal twins was .20.']

['What else did the study find?', 'This study also found that the median concordance rate for unrelated (adoptive) siblings was .09; although this number is small, it is greater than 0, thus suggesting that the environment may have at least some influence.']

['What other studies have been done on inattention and hyperactivity?', 'Another review of studies concluded that the heritability of inattention and hyperactivity were 71% and 73%, respectively (Nikolas & Burt, 2010).']

['Are there any important aspects of the Causes of ADHD?', 'The specific genes involved in ADHD are thought to include at least two that are important in the regulation of the neurotransmitter dopamine (Gizer, Ficks, & Waldman, 2009), suggesting that dopamine may be important in ADHD.']

['What are medications used in the treatment of ADHD?', 'Indeed, medications used in the treatment of ADHD, such as methylphenidate (Ritalin) and amphetamine with dextroamphetamine (Adderall), have stimulant qualities and elevate dopamine activity.']

['What kind of effects do these drugs have?', 'People with ADHD show less dopamine activity in key regions of the brain, especially those associated with motivation and reward (Volkow et al., 2009), which provides support to the theory that dopamine deficits may be a vital factor in the development this disorder (Swanson et al., 2007).']

['What is the most interesting information in our study material?', 'Brain imaging studies have shown that children with ADHD exhibit abnormalities in their frontal lobes, an area in which dopamine is in abundance.']

['What can you tell me about how they exhibit abnormalities in their frontal lobes?', 'Compared to children without ADHD, those with ADHD appear to have smaller frontal lobe volume, and they show less frontal lobe activation when performing mental tasks.']
['What is one of the functions of the frontal lobes?', 'Recall that one of the functions of the frontal lobes is to inhibit our behavior.']
['What is the main reason for the abnormalities in this region?', 'Thus, abnormalities in this region may go a long way toward explaining the hyperactive, uncontrolled behavior of ADHD.']
['What did you learn about dietary patterns?', 'By the 1970s, many had become aware of the connection between nutritional factors and childhood behavior.']

['What were the people doing to cause hyperactivity?', 'At the time, much of the public believed that hyperactivity was caused by sugar and food additives, such as artificial coloring and flavoring.']

['What was the appeal of the hypothesis that sugar causes hyperactivity?', 'Undoubtedly, part of the appeal of this hypothesis was that it provided a simple explanation of (and treatment for) behavioral problems in children.']

['Did it really cause hyperactivity?', 'A statistical review of 16 studies, however, concluded that sugar consumption has no effect at all on the behavioral and cognitive performance of children (Wolraich, Wilson, & White, 1995).']

['What is the effect of food additives on non-ADHD children?', 'Additionally, although food additives have been shown to increase hyperactivity in non-ADHD children, the effect is rather small (McCann et al., 2007).']

['Are cigarettes the cause of hyperactivity?', 'Numerous studies, however, have shown a significant relationship between exposure to nicotine in cigarette smoke during the prenatal period and ADHD (Linnet et al., 2003).']
['What did they find regarding smokers?', 'Maternal smoking during pregnancy is associated with the development of more severe symptoms of the disorder (Thakur et al., 2013).']
['Is there anything else you know about the study material?', 'No.']

['What was the content about?', 'Remember, the genetics studies discussed above suggested that the family environment does not seem to play much of a role in the development of this disorder; if it did, we would expect the concordance rates to be higher for fraternal twins and adoptive siblings than has been demonstrated.']

['What is the evidence that ADHD is triggered more by genetic and neurological factors and less by social or environmental ones?', 'All things considered, the evidence seems to point to the conclusion that ADHD is triggered more by genetic and neurological factors and less by social or environmental ones.']
["What is Kanner's involvement in Autism?", 'A seminal paper published in 1943 by psychiatrist Leo Kanner described an unusual neurodevelopmental condition he observed in a group of children.']

['What was the main characteristic of early infantile autism?', 'He called this condition early infantile autism, and it was characterized mainly by an inability to form close emotional ties with others, speech and language abnormalities, repetitive behaviors, and an intolerance of minor changes in the environment and in normal routines (Bregman, 2005).']
['What did he find out about autism?', 'What the DSM-5 refers to as autism spectrum disorder today, is a direct extension of Kanner’s work.']
['What is the most important information in this document?', 'Autism spectrum disorder is probably the most misunderstood of the neurodevelopmental disorders.']

['What was the three main areas?', 'Children with this disorder show signs of significant disturbances in three main areas: (a) deficits in social interaction, (b) deficits in communication, and (c) repetitive patterns of behavior or interests.']
['How can this affect the individuals?', 'These disturbances appear early in life and cause serious impairments in functioning (APA, 2013).']

['What might a child with autism spectrum disorder exhibit deficits in social interaction by not initiating conversations with other children or turning their head away when spoken to?', 'The child with autism spectrum disorder might exhibit deficits in social interaction by not initiating conversations with other children or turning their head away when spoken to.']
['What did the children do?', 'Typically, these children do not make eye contact with others and seem to prefer playing alone rather than with others.']

['What do people think of these social interactions?', 'In some cases, it is almost as though these individuals live in a personal and isolated social world others are simply not privy to or able to penetrate.']

['What else is there to know about social interaction deficits?', 'Communication deficits can range from a complete lack of speech, to one word responses (e.g., saying “Yes” or “No” when replying to questions or statements that require additional elaboration), to echoed speech (e.g., parroting what another person says, either immediately or several hours or even days later), to difficulty maintaining a conversation because of an inability to reciprocate others’ comments.']

['What else are some ways that the individuals have issues communicating?', 'These deficits can also include problems in using and understanding nonverbal cues (e.g., facial expressions, gestures, and postures) that facilitate normal communication.']
['What kinds of repetitive patterns are exhibited in this disorder?', 'Repetitive patterns of behavior or interests can be exhibited a number of ways.']

['What kinds of repetitive patterns are associated with a child?', 'The child might engage in stereotyped, repetitive movements (rocking, head-banging, or repeatedly dropping an object and then picking it up), or they might show great distress at small changes in routine or the environment.']

['What kinds of repetitive patterns are associated with an adult?', 'In some cases, the person with autism spectrum disorder might show highly restricted and fixated interests that appear to be abnormal in their intensity.']

['What other types of repetitive patterns are associated with this disorder?', 'For instance, the person might learn and memorize every detail about something even though doing so serves no apparent purpose.']

['What is the difference between autism spectrum disorder and intellectual disability?', 'Importantly, autism spectrum disorder is not the same thing as intellectual disability, although these two conditions are often comorbid.']
['What is important about the disorder that you found in the article?', 'The DSM-5 specifies that the symptoms of autism spectrum disorder are not caused or explained by intellectual disability.']

['What is autism?', 'Autism spectrum disorder is referred to in everyday language as autism; in fact, the disorder was termed “autistic disorder” in earlier editions of the DSM, and its diagnostic criteria were much narrower than those of autism spectrum disorder.']

['What is spectrum?', 'The qualifier “spectrum” in autism spectrum disorder is used to indicate that individuals with the disorder can show a range, or spectrum, of symptoms that vary in their magnitude and severity: some severe, others less severe.']

['What was the less severe form?', 'The previous edition of the DSM included a diagnosis of Asperger’s disorder, generally recognized as a less severe form of autistic disorder; individuals diagnosed with Asperger’s disorder were described as having average or high intelligence and a strong vocabulary, but exhibiting impairments in social interaction and social communication, such as talking only about their special interests (Wing, Gould, & Gillberg, 2011).']

['What is the issue with DSM5?', 'However, because research has failed to demonstrate that Asperger’s disorder differs qualitatively from autistic disorder, the DSM-5 does not include it, which is prompting concerns among some parents that their children may no longer be eligible for special services (“Asperger’s Syndrome Dropped,” 2012).']

['What are some of the issues from life with autism?', 'Some individuals with autism spectrum disorder, particularly those with better language and intellectual skills, can live and work independently as adults.']
['How do they live independently?', 'However, most do not because the symptoms remain sufficient to cause serious impairment in many realms of life (APA, 2013).']

['What are some of the more important things to know from our content?', 'Current estimates from the Center for Disease Control and Prevention’s Autism and Developmental Disabilities Monitoring Network indicate that 1 in 59 children in the United States has autism spectrum disorder; the disorder is 4 times more common among boys (1 in 38) than in girls (1 in 152) (Baio et al, 2018).']
['What year did this increase occur?', 'Rates of autistic spectrum disorder have increased dramatically since the 1980s.']

['What was the increase in reported cases from 1987 through 1998?', 'For example, California saw an increase of 273% in reported cases from 1987 through 1998 (Byrd, 2002); between 2000 and 2008, the rate of autism diagnoses in the United States increased 78% (CDC, 2012).']

['What is the most important part of the increase?', 'Although it is difficult to interpret this increase, it is possible that the rise in prevalence is the result of the broadening of the diagnosis, increased efforts to identify cases in the community, and greater awareness and acceptance of the diagnosis.']

['What group is the awareness with?', 'In addition, mental health professionals are now more knowledgeable about autism spectrum disorder and are better equipped to make the diagnosis, even in subtle cases (Novella, 2008).']

['What is the origin of autism spectrum disorder?', 'The exact causes of autism spectrum disorder remain unknown despite massive research efforts over the last two decades (Meek, Lemery-Chalfant, Jahromi, & Valiente, 2013).']

['What is one of the major factors that could be responsible for autism?', 'Autism appears to be strongly influenced by genetics, as identical twins show concordance rates of 60%–90%, whereas concordance rates for fraternal twins and siblings are 5%–10% (Autism Genome Project Consortium, 2007).']
['What is one of the reasons that genetics have been implicated in autism?', 'Many different genes and gene mutations have been implicated in autism (Meek et al., 2013).']

['Are there any other genes that have been implicated in autism?', 'Among the genes involved are those important in the formation of synaptic circuits that facilitate communication between different areas of the brain (Gauthier et al., 2011).']

['What other factors have been implicated in autism?', 'A number of environmental factors are also thought to be associated with increased risk for autism spectrum disorder, at least in part, because they contribute to new mutations.']

['What environmental factors are implicated in autism?', 'These factors include exposure to pollutants, such as plant emissions and mercury, urban versus rural residence, and vitamin D deficiency (Kinney, Barch, Chayka, Napoleon, & Munir, 2009).']

['What article is about autism?', 'In the late 1990s, a prestigious medical journal published an article purportedly showing that autism is triggered by the MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine.']
['What were the findings of the study?', 'These findings were very controversial and drew a great deal of attention, sparking an international forum on whether children should be vaccinated.']

['Did they retract the article?', 'In a shocking turn of events, some years later the article was retracted by the journal that had published it after evidence of fraud and unethical practices on the part of the lead researcher.']
['Was the retraction harmful?', 'Despite the retraction, the reporting in popular media led to concerns about a possible link between vaccines and autism persisting.']

['Did anyone else believe this report?', 'A recent survey of parents, for example, found that roughly a third of respondents expressed such a concern (Kennedy, LaVail, Nowak, Basket, & Landry, 2011); and perhaps fearing that their children would develop autism, more than 10% of parents of young children refuse or delay vaccinations (Dempsey et al., 2011).']
['Did these parents fight over the report?', 'Some parents of children with autism mounted a campaign against scientists who refuted the vaccine-autism link.']

['How did Jenny McCarthy react to the news?', 'Even politicians and several well-known celebrities weighed in; for example, actress Jenny McCarthy (who believed that a vaccination caused her son’s autism) co-authored a book on the matter.']
['Did they have evidence that a link exists between autism and vaccinations?', 'However, there is no scientific evidence that a link exists between autism and vaccinations (Hughes, 2007).']

['Did a recent study prove it?', 'Indeed, a recent study compared the vaccination histories of 256 children with autism spectrum disorder with that of 752 control children across three time periods during their first two years of life (birth to 3 months, birth to 7 months, and birth to 2 years) (DeStefano, Price, & Weintraub, 2013).']
['When did they start vaccinations?', 'At the time of the study, the children were between 6 and 13 years old, and their prior vaccination records were obtained.']

['Did they know why the vaccine was administered?', 'Because vaccines contain immunogens (substances that fight infections), the investigators examined medical records to see how many immunogens children received to determine if those children who received more immunogens were at greater risk for developing autism spectrum disorder.']

['What did the study show?', 'The results of this study, a portion of which are shown in Figure 15.19, clearly demonstrate that the quantity of immunogens from vaccines received during the first two years of life were not at all related to the development of autism spectrum disorder.']
['What does this mean?', 'There is not a relationship between vaccinations and autism spectrum disorders.']

['What is the passage about?', 'Since the proliferation of the Internet in the 1990s, parents have been constantly bombarded with online information that can become magnified and take on a life of its own.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'The enormous volume of electronic information pertaining to autism spectrum disorder, combined with how difficult it can be to grasp complex scientific concepts, can make separating good research from bad challenging (Downs, 2008).']

['What did the study show?', 'Notably, the study that fueled the controversy reported that 8 out of 12 children—according to their parents—developed symptoms consistent with autism spectrum disorder shortly after receiving a vaccination.']

['How did the study end up being incorrect?', 'To conclude that vaccines cause autism spectrum disorder on this basis, as many did, is clearly incorrect for a number of reasons, not the least of which is because correlation does not imply causation, as you’ve learned.']

['What is the important information to know about autism spectrum disorder?', 'Additionally, as was the case with diet and ADHD in the 1970s, the notion that autism spectrum disorder is caused by vaccinations is appealing to some because it provides a simple explanation for this condition.']
['Is it true that there are no simple explanations for autism spectrum disorder?', 'Like all disorders, however, there are no simple explanations for autism spectrum disorder.']

['Are there any other important information about the disorder?', 'Although the research discussed above has shed some light on its causes, science is still a long way from complete understanding of the disorder.']
['What is a personality?', 'The term personality refers loosely to one’s stable, consistent, and distinctive way of thinking about, feeling, acting, and relating to the world.']

['what is a personality disorder?', 'People with personality disorders exhibit a personality style that differs markedly from the expectations of their culture, is pervasive and inflexible, begins in adolescence or early adulthood, and causes distress or impairment (APA, 2013).']

['What are some characteristics of personality disorders?', 'Generally, individuals with these disorders exhibit enduring personality styles that are extremely troubling and often create problems for them and those with whom they come into contact.']

['what causes problems?', 'Their maladaptive personality styles frequently bring them into conflict with others, disrupt their ability to develop and maintain social relationships, and prevent them from accomplishing realistic life goals.']
['What are the ten personality disorders?', 'The DSM-5 recognizes 10 personality disorders, organized into 3 different clusters.']
['What are the three clusters of personality disorders?', 'Cluster A disorders include paranoid personality disorder, schizoid personality disorder, and schizotypal personality disorder.']
['What is the most common way that people with these disorders manifest?', 'People with these disorders display a personality style that is odd or eccentric.']
['What is the next cluster?', 'Cluster B disorders include antisocial personality disorder, histrionic personality disorder, narcissistic personality disorder, and borderline personality disorder.']
['What are the characteristics of people with these disorders?', 'People with these disorders usually are impulsive, overly dramatic, highly emotional, and erratic.']

['What is the last cluster?', 'Cluster C disorders include avoidant personality disorder, dependent personality disorder, and obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (which is not the same thing as obsessive-compulsive disorder).']
['What are the symptoms of these disorders?', 'People with these disorders often appear to be nervous and fearful.']
['What is there to know about personality disorder?', 'Table 15.2 provides a description of each of the DSM-5 personality disorders:']

['What is the most common personality disorder?', 'Slightly over 9% of the U.S. population suffers from a personality disorder, with avoidant and schizoid personality disorders the most frequent (Lezenweger, Lane, Loranger, & Kessler, 2007).']
['What can personality disorders lead to?', 'Two of these personality disorders, borderline personality disorder and antisocial personality disorder, are regarded by many as especially problematic.']

['What was the name of the disorder?', 'The “borderline” in borderline personality disorder was originally coined in the late 1930s in an effort to describe patients who appeared anxious, but were prone to brief psychotic experiences—that is, patients who were thought to be literally on the borderline between anxiety and psychosis (Freeman, Stone, Martin, & Reinecke, 2005).']
['What was the current definition of borderline personality disorder in the 1960s?', 'Today, borderline personality disorder has a completely different meaning.']

['What is the different meaning of borderline personality disorder?', 'Borderline personality disorder is characterized chiefly by instability in interpersonal relationships, self-image, and mood, as well as marked impulsivity (APA, 2013).']

['What are some examples of borderline personality disorder?', 'People with borderline personality disorder cannot tolerate the thought of being alone and will make frantic efforts (including making suicidal gestures and engaging in self-mutilation) to avoid abandonment or separation (whether real or imagined).']

['What does it mean to have a schizophrenic partner?', 'Their relationships are intense and unstable; for example, a romantic partner may be idealized early in a relationship, but then later vilified at the slightest sign they appear to no longer show interest.']

['What does it mean to have an unstable view of self?', 'These individuals have an unstable view of self and, thus, might suddenly display a shift in personal attitudes, interests, career plans, and choice of friends.']

['What is one example of a career change?', 'For example, a law school student may, despite having invested tens of thousands of dollars toward earning a law degree and despite having performed well in the program, consider dropping out and pursuing a career in another field.']

['What is another example of impulsivity?', 'People with borderline personality disorder may be highly impulsive and may engage in reckless and self-destructive behaviors such as excessive gambling, spending money irresponsibly, substance abuse, engaging in unsafe sex, and reckless driving.']
