['What is the difference between a person with anger issues and a person without anger issues?', 'They sometimes show intense and inappropriate anger that they have difficulty controlling, and they can be moody, sarcastic, bitter, and verbally abusive.']

['what is one of the most interesting points in this document?', 'The prevalence of borderline personality disorder in the U.S. population is estimated to be around 1.4% (Lezenweger et al., 2007), but the rates are higher among those who use mental health services; approximately 10% of mental health outpatients and 20% of psychiatric inpatients meet the criteria for diagnosis (APA, 2013).']
['What is borderline personality disorder comorbid with?', 'Additionally, borderline personality disorder is comorbid with anxiety, mood, and substance use disorders (Lezenweger et al., 2007).']
['What is the most important factor in the development of borderline personality disorder?', 'Genetic factors appear to be important in the development of borderline personality disorder.']

['What are some of the things that would be affected by genetic factors?', 'For example, core personality traits that characterize this disorder, such as impulsivity and emotional instability, show a high degree of heritability (Livesley, 2008).']

['What is the article about?', 'Also, the rates of borderline personality disorder among relatives of people with this disorder have been found to be as high as 24.9% (White, Gunderson, Zanarani, & Hudson, 2003).']

['What else does the article say about genetics?', 'Individuals with borderline personality disorder report experiencing childhood physical, sexual, and/or emotional abuse at rates far greater than those observed in the general population (Afifi et al., 2010), indicating that environmental factors are also crucial.']
['What is the result of this?', 'These findings would suggest that borderline personality disorder may be determined by an interaction between genetic factors and adverse environmental experiences.']

['What else is said about this?', 'Consistent with this hypothesis, one study found that the highest rates of borderline personality disorder were among individuals with a borderline temperament (characterized by high novelty seeking and high harm-avoidance) and those who experienced childhood abuse and/or neglect (Joyce et al., 2003).']
['What does a moral compass tell us?', 'Most human beings live in accordance with a moral compass, a sense of right and wrong.']
['What can we learn about the moral compass?', 'Most individuals learn at a very young age that there are certain things that should not be done.']
['What do we learn about amoral things?', 'We learn that we should not lie or cheat.']
['What are some things that are considered wrong?', 'We are taught that it is wrong to take things that do not belong to us, and that it is wrong to exploit others for personal gain.']
['What do you know about the moral compass?', 'People with antisocial personality disorder, however, do not seem to have a moral compass.']
['How do these individuals act?', 'These individuals act as though they neither have a sense of nor care about right or wrong.']
['What do you think of people who act this way?', 'Not surprisingly, these people represent a serious problem for others and for society in general.']

['What are some symptoms of Antisocial Personality Disorder?', 'According to the DSM-5, the individual with antisocial personality disorder shows no regard at all for other people’s rights or feelings.']

['Does leaving debts unpaid fall into this category?', 'This lack of regard is exhibited a number of ways and can include repeatedly performing illegal acts, lying to or conning others, impulsivity and recklessness, irritability and aggressiveness toward others, and failure to act in a responsible way (e.g., leaving debts unpaid) (APA, 2013).']

['How is remorse associated with the disorder?', 'People with this disorder have no remorse over their misdeeds; these people will hurt, manipulate, exploit, and abuse others and not feel any guilt.']

['Can a person be diagnosed with this disorder at any age?', 'Signs of this disorder can emerge early in life; however, a person must be at least 18 years old to be diagnosed with antisocial personality disorder.']
['What kind of people have that disorder?', 'People with antisocial personality disorder seem to view the world as self-serving and unkind.']
['How do they think?', 'They seem to think that they should use whatever means necessary to get by in life.']
['How do they view others?', 'They tend to view others not as living, thinking, feeling beings, but rather as pawns to be used or abused for a specific purpose.']
['What do they often have an over-inflated sense of themselves and can appear extremely arrogant?', 'They often have an over-inflated sense of themselves and can appear extremely arrogant.']
['Why are they so arrogant?', 'They frequently display superficial charm; for example, without really meaning it they might say exactly what they think another person wants to hear.']
['How are they incapable of understanding other people?', 'They lack empathy: they are incapable of understanding the emotional point-of-view of others.']

['What else do people with this disorder do?', 'People with this disorder may become involved in illegal enterprises, show cruelty toward others, leave their jobs with no plans to obtain another job, have multiple sexual partners, repeatedly get into fights with others, and show reckless disregard for themselves and others (e.g., repeated arrests for driving while intoxicated) (APA, 2013).']
['What is the DSM-5?', 'The DSM-5 has included an alternative model for conceptualizing personality disorders based on the traits identified in the Five Factor Model of personality.']

['What are the impairments in self (identity or self-direction) and interpersonal (empathy or intimacy) functioning?', 'This model addresses the level of personality functioning such as impairments in self (identity or self-direction) and interpersonal (empathy or intimacy) functioning.']

['What are the other identifiers?', 'In the case of antisocial personality disorder, the DSM-5 identifies the predominant traits of antagonism (such as disregard for others’ needs, manipulative or deceitful behavior) and disinhibition (characterized by impulsivity, irresponsibility, and risk-taking) (Harwood, Schade, Krueger, Wright, & Markon, 2012).']

['What is the model that explains negative consequences?', 'A psychopathology specifier is also included that emphasizes traits such as attention seeking and low anxiousness (lack of concern about negative consequences for risky or harmful behavior) (Crego & Widiger, 2014).']

['What are some of the risk factors for antisocial personality disorder?', 'Antisocial personality disorder is observed in about 3.6% of the population; the disorder is much more common among men, with a 3 to 1 ratio of men to women, and it is more likely to occur in men who are younger, widowed, separated, divorced, of lower socioeconomic status, who live in urban areas, and who live in the western United States (Compton, Conway, Stinson, Colliver, & Grant, 2005).']

['who is at risk?', 'Compared to men with antisocial personality disorder, women with the disorder are more likely to have experienced emotional neglect and sexual abuse during childhood, and they are more likely to have had parents who abused substances and who engaged in antisocial behaviors themselves (Alegria et al., 2013).']

['What is another relevant document in this study material?', 'Family, twin, and adoption studies suggest that both genetic and environmental factors influence the development of antisocial personality disorder, as well as general antisocial behavior (criminality, violence, aggressiveness) (Baker, Bezdjian, & Raine, 2006).']

['What are some traits that are related to this disorder?', 'Personality and temperament dimensions that are related to this disorder, including fearlessness, impulsive antisociality, and callousness, have a substantial genetic influence (Livesley & Jang, 2008).']

['What can you tell me about the development of antisocial behavior?', 'Adoption studies clearly demonstrate that the development of antisocial behavior is determined by the interaction of genetic factors and adverse environmental circumstances (Rhee & Waldman, 2002).']

['What kinds of adverse circumstances are they talking about?', 'For example, one investigation found that adoptees of biological parents with antisocial personality disorder were more likely to exhibit adolescent and adult antisocial behaviors if they were raised in adverse adoptive family environments (e.g., adoptive parents had marital problems, were divorced, used drugs, and had legal problems) than if they were raised in a more normal adoptive environment (Cadoret, Yates, Ed, Woodworth, & Stewart, 1995).']

['What are the two factors which were included in the study?', 'Researchers who are interested in the importance of environment in the development of antisocial personality disorder have directed their attention to such factors as the community, the structure and functioning of the family, and peer groups.']
['What is the result of this study?', 'Each of these factors influences the likelihood of antisocial behavior.']

['What is the name of the study that measured risk factors for violence at 10, 14, 16, and 18 years of age?', 'One longitudinal investigation of more than 800 Seattle-area youth measured risk factors for violence at 10, 14, 16, and 18 years of age (Herrenkohl et al., 2000).']
['What are some other factors that were examined?', 'The risk factors examined included those involving the family, peers, and community.']
['What was included in the study?', 'A portion of the findings from this study are provided in Figure 15.20.']
['Why would that be?', 'Those with antisocial tendencies do not seem to experience emotions the way most other people do.']

['What do these individuals fail to show in response to environment cues that signal punishment, pain, or noxious stimulation?', 'These individuals fail to show fear in response to environment cues that signal punishment, pain, or noxious stimulation.']

['What else do you find interesting?', 'For instance, they show less skin conductance (sweatiness on hands) in anticipation of electric shock than do people without antisocial tendencies (Hare, 1965).']
['What can we learn from the passage?', 'Skin conductance is controlled by the sympathetic nervous system and is used to assess autonomic nervous system functioning.']
['What is the sympathetic nervous system?', 'When the sympathetic nervous system is active, people become aroused and anxious, and sweat gland activity increases.']

['What does increased sweat gland activity, as assessed through skin conductance, mean?', 'Thus, increased sweat gland activity, as assessed through skin conductance, is taken as a sign of arousal or anxiety.']

['What can you tell me about antisocial personality disorder?', 'For those with antisocial personality disorder, a lack of skin conductance may indicate the presence of characteristics such as emotional deficits and impulsivity that underlie the propensity for antisocial behavior and negative social relationships (Fung et al., 2005).']

['What is the most important piece of information that was presented in the course?', 'Another example showing that those with antisocial personality disorder fail to respond to environmental cues comes from a recent study by Stuppy-Sullivan and Baskin-Sommers (2019).']
['What is the study about?', 'The researchers studied cognitive and reward factors associated with antisocial personality disorder dysfunction in 119 incarcerated males.']
['What was the experiment?', 'Each subject was administered three tasks targeting different aspects of cognition and reward.']

['What did they study?', 'High-magnitude rewards tended to impair perception in those with antisocial personality disorder, worsened executive function when they were consciously aware of the high rewards, and worsened inhibition when the tasks placed high demand on working memory.']

['What is the most important reason you want to study this topic?', 'Before we explore the various approaches to therapy used today, let’s begin our study of therapy by looking at how many people experience mental illness and how many receive treatment.']
['What are some of the statistics?', 'According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (2017), 18.9% of U.S. adults experienced mental illness in 2017.']

['What other statistics did they provide?', 'For teens (ages 13–18), the rate is similar to that of adults, and for children ages 8–15, current estimates suggest that approximately 13% experience mental illness in a given year (National Institute of Mental Health [NIMH], 2017).']

['What is the significant information?', 'According to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), in 2017, 14.8% of adults received treatment for a mental health issue (NIMH, 2017).']

['What percentages are shown in Figure 16.2?', 'These percentages, shown in Figure 16.2, reflect the number of adults who received care in inpatient and outpatient settings and/or used prescription medication for psychological disorders.']
['What is the title of the passage?', 'Children and adolescents also receive mental health services.']

['What are some facts about mental disorders?', "The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) found that approximately half (50.6%) of children with mental disorders had received treatment for their disorder within the past year (NIMH, n.d.)."]
['what else do you learn from the passage?', 'However, there were some differences between treatment rates by category of disorder (Figure 16.3).']

['what were these differences?', 'For example, children with anxiety disorders were least likely to have received treatment in the past year, while children with ADHD or a conduct disorder were more likely to receive treatment.']

['What does this study material cover?', 'Let’s take a look at the history of mental health treatment from the past (with some questionable approaches in light of modern understanding of mental illness) to where we are today.']
['How did people with mental illness feel about being treated?', 'For much of history, people with mental illness have been treated very poorly.']
['What was the popular opinion about mental illness?', 'It was believed that mental illness was caused by demonic possession, witchcraft, or an angry god (Szasz, 1960).']
['What happened to people with mental illness?', 'For example, in medieval times, abnormal behaviors were viewed as a sign that a person was possessed by demons.']
['How was demonic possession treated?', 'If someone was considered to be possessed, there were several forms of treatment to release spirits from the individual.']
['Who treated these people?', 'The most common treatment was exorcism, often conducted by priests or other religious figures:']
['How was the person released from their spirits?', 'Incantations and prayers were said over the person’s body, and they may have been given some medicinal drinks.']

['What was another form of treatment?', 'Another form of treatment for extreme cases of mental illness was trephining: A small hole was made in the afflicted individual’s skull to release spirits from the body.']
['Did people die from demonic possession?', 'Most people treated in this manner died.']

['What other practices involved execution or imprisonment of people with psychological disorders?', 'In addition to exorcism and trephining, other practices involved execution or imprisonment of people with psychological disorders.']
['Did people live in detention?', 'Still others were left to be homeless beggars.']
['What happened to people with mental illness?', 'Generally speaking, most people who exhibited strange behaviors were greatly misunderstood and treated cruelly.']

['Did anyone think a demonic possession caused mental illness?', 'The prevailing theory of psychopathology in earlier history was the idea that mental illness was the result of demonic possession by either an evil spirit or an evil god because early beliefs incorrectly attributed all unexplainable phenomena to deities deemed either good or evil.']

['What did you find interesting about the passage?', 'From the late 1400s to the late 1600s, a common belief perpetuated by some religious organizations was that some people made pacts with the devil and committed horrible acts, such as eating babies (Blumberg, 2007).']
['How were these people treated?', 'These people were considered to be witches and were tried and condemned by courts—they were often burned at the stake.']

['How many people were burned?', 'Worldwide, it is estimated that tens of thousands of mentally ill people were killed after being accused of being witches or under the influence of witchcraft (Hemphill, 1966)']
['What can you tell me about the 18th century?', 'By the 18th century, people who were considered odd and unusual were placed in asylums (Figure 16.4).']

['What was the first institution created for the specific purpose of housing people with psychological disorders?', 'Asylums were the first institutions created for the specific purpose of housing people with psychological disorders, but the focus was ostracizing them from society rather than treating their disorders.']
['What happened to those considered odd and unusual?', 'Often these people were kept in windowless dungeons, beaten, chained to their beds, and had little to no contact with caregivers.']
['Who was a French physician?', 'In the late 1700s, a French physician, Philippe Pinel, argued for more humane treatment of people with mental illness.']

['How did he advocate for the humane treatment of mental illness?', 'He suggested that they be unchained and talked to, and that’s just what he did for patients at La Salpêtrière in Paris in 1795 (Figure 16.5).']
['What did he do at La Salpêtrière?', 'Patients benefited from this more humane treatment, and many were able to leave the hospital.']
['What did the 19th century refer to?', 'In the 19th century, Dorothea Dix led reform efforts for mental health care in the United States (Figure 16.6).']

['What did she investigate?', 'She investigated how those who are mentally ill and poor were cared for, and she discovered an underfunded and unregulated system that perpetuated abuse of this population (Tiffany, 1891).']
['What did Dix do to stop this abuse?', 'Horrified by her findings, Dix began lobbying various state legislatures and the U.S. Congress for change (Tiffany, 1891).']
['What happened as a result?', 'Her efforts led to the creation of the first mental asylums in the United States.']
['What was the typical asylum like?', 'Despite reformers’ efforts, however, a typical asylum was filthy, offered very little treatment, and often kept people for decades.']
['What were some other things about this material?', 'At Willard Psychiatric Center in upstate New York, for example, one treatment was to submerge patients in cold baths for long periods of time.']

['How was the treatment administered?', 'Electroshock treatment was also used, and the way the treatment was administered often broke patients’ backs; in 1943, doctors at Willard administered 1,443 shock treatments (Willard Psychiatric Center, 2009).']
['What was done to stop the treatment?', '(Electroshock is now called electroconvulsive treatment, and the therapy is still used, but with safeguards and under anesthesia.']
['What was the purpose of the electroshock?', 'A brief application of electric stimulus is used to produce a generalized seizure.']
['What is the controversy over its effectiveness versus the side effects?', 'Controversy continues over its effectiveness versus the side effects.)']
['What was the overall treatment like in the past?', 'Many of the wards and rooms were so cold that a glass of water would be frozen by morning (Willard Psychiatric Center, 2009).']
['What was the conclusion of the article?', 'Willard’s doors were not closed until 1995.']
['Did anyone help with the changes?', 'Conditions like these remained commonplace until well into the 20th century.']
['When did antipsychotic medications become more popular?', 'Starting in 1954 and gaining popularity in the 1960s, antipsychotic medications were introduced.']
['how did antipsychotic medications become more popular?', 'These proved a tremendous help in controlling the symptoms of certain psychological disorders, such as psychosis.']

['What is the common diagnosis of individuals in mental hospitals, and it was often evidenced by symptoms like hallucinations and delusions, indicating a loss of contact with reality?', 'Psychosis was a common diagnosis of individuals in mental hospitals, and it was often evidenced by symptoms like hallucinations and delusions, indicating a loss of contact with reality.']

['what is the mental retardation facilities and community mental health centers construction act?', 'Then in 1963, Congress passed and John F. Kennedy signed the Mental Retardation Facilities and Community Mental Health Centers Construction Act, which provided federal support and funding for community mental health centers (National Institutes of Health, 2013).']
['What did this legislation do?', 'This legislation changed how mental health services were delivered in the United States.']
['What was the result of this?', 'It started the process of deinstitutionalization, the closing of large asylums, by providing for people to stay in their communities and be treated locally.']
['What were the major problems of the past?', 'In 1955, there were 558,239 severely mentally ill patients institutionalized at public hospitals (Torrey, 1997).']
['what were the results of the deinstitutionalization?', 'By 1994, by percentage of the population, there were 92% fewer hospitalized individuals (Torrey, 1997).']
['What can I find this material?', 'Today, there are community mental health centers across the nation.']

['What are community mental health centers?', 'They are located in neighborhoods near the homes of clients, and they provide large numbers of people with mental health services of various kinds and for many kinds of problems.']

['Why did they go from institutions to community centers?', 'Unfortunately, part of what occurred with deinstitutionalization was that those released from institutions were supposed to go to newly created centers, but the system was not set up effectively.']

['What were some of the problems that existed?', 'Centers were underfunded, staff was not trained to handle severe illnesses such as schizophrenia, there was high staff burnout, and no provision was made for the other services people needed, such as housing, food, and job training.']
['What happened as a result of this?', 'Without these supports, those people released under deinstitutionalization often ended up homeless.']
['Did mental illness play a large role in the homeless population?', 'Even today, a large portion of the homeless population is considered to be mentally ill (Figure 16.7).']

['How do the statistics compare to the reality?', 'Statistics show that 26% of homeless adults living in shelters experience mental illness (U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development [HUD], 2011).']
['What were the concerns regarding those involved in the corrections system?', 'Mental health issues are also significant concerns regarding those involved in the corrections system.']

['what was the estimated rates ranging?', 'According to a 2006 special report by the Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS), approximately 705,600 adults with mental health issues were incarcerated in the state prison system, and another 78,800 were incarcerated in the federal prison system.']
['What were the 479,000 doing?', 'A further 479,000 were in local jails.']

['what was the population?', 'According to the study, “people with mental illnesses are overrepresented in probation and parole populations at estimated rates ranging from two to four times the general population” (Prins & Draper, 2009, p. 23).']
['What is the correctional system facing?', 'The correctional system faces increasing burdens in managing and supporting people with mental health issues (Torrey et al., 2014).']

['What are the consequences of incarceration?', 'The incarceration experience itself exacerbates existing issues, triggers disturbances, or leads to long term effects such as PTSD, depression, or other disorders.']

['what else does it involve?', 'While incarcerated, people are often subjected to or witness violence or sexual assault, face isolation from family, and endure other physical or emotional traumas (Edgemon & Clay-Warner, 2019).']

["what's special about mental health treatment today?", 'Today, instead of asylums, there are psychiatric hospitals run by state governments and local community hospitals focused on short-term care.']

['How long do people stay in these hospitals?', 'In all types of hospitals, the emphasis is on short-term stays, with the average length of stay being less than two weeks and often only several days.']
['Why do they limit the length of stay?', 'This is partly due to the very high cost of psychiatric hospitalization, which can be about $800 to $1000 per night (Stensland, Watson, & Grazier, 2012).']
['what does insurance cover?', 'Therefore, insurance coverage often limits the length of time a person can be hospitalized for treatment.']
['Why do people go to hospitals?', 'Usually individuals are hospitalized only if they are an imminent threat to themselves or others.']
['What else should you know about mental illnesses?', 'Most people who have mental illnesses are not hospitalized.']

['What might someone do if they are feeling very depressed, complains of hearing voices, or feels anxious all the time?', 'If someone is feeling very depressed, complains of hearing voices, or feels anxious all the time, they might seek psychological treatment.']
['What might someone do to refer someone for treatment?', 'A friend, spouse, or parent might refer someone for treatment.']
['How do you find a mental health practitioner?', 'The individual might go see their primary care physician first and then be referred to a mental health practitioner.']

['Why do some people seek treatment?', 'Some people seek treatment because they are involved with the state’s child protective services—that is, their children have been removed from their care due to abuse or neglect.']
['What might be recommended for the parents and children?', 'The parents might be referred to psychiatric or substance abuse facilities and the children would likely receive treatment for trauma.']
['What might be the goal of treatment?', 'If the parents are interested in and capable of becoming better parents, the goal of treatment might be family reunification.']

['What happens if the parents do not want to change?', 'For other children whose parents are unable to change—for example, the parent or parents who are heavily addicted to drugs and refuse to enter treatment—the goal of therapy might be to help the children adjust to foster care and/or adoption (Figure 16.8).']
['What does the criminal justice system do?', 'Some people seek therapy because the criminal justice system referred them or required them to go.']
['What might be required of them?', 'For some individuals, for example, attending weekly counseling sessions might be a condition of parole.']
['How do they seek services involuntarily?', 'If an individual is mandated to attend therapy, they are seeking services involuntarily.']
['What is the difference between involuntary treatment and voluntary treatment?', 'Involuntary treatment refers to therapy that is not the individual’s choice.']
['What does voluntary treatment mean?', 'Other individuals might voluntarily seek treatment.']
['What does voluntary treatment mean?', 'Voluntary treatment means the person chooses to attend therapy to obtain relief from symptoms.']
['What can happen during psychological treatment?', 'Psychological treatment can occur in a variety of places.']
['What are some of those places?', 'An individual might go to a community mental health center or a practitioner in private or community practice.']
['What might happen during psychological treatment?', 'A child might see a school counselor, school psychologist, or school social worker.']
['What can happen to an incarcerated person?', 'An incarcerated person might receive group therapy in prison.']
['What are some of the requirements to get treatment?', 'There are many different types of treatment providers, and licensing requirements vary from state to state.']

['Who performs these types of treatment?', 'Besides psychologists and psychiatrists, there are clinical social workers, marriage and family therapists, and trained religious personnel who also perform counseling and therapy.']
['What are some of the funding sources for mental health treatment?', 'A range of funding sources pay for mental health treatment: health insurance, government, and private pay.']
['What is a fact about health insurance?', 'In the past, even when people had health insurance, the coverage would not always pay for mental health services.']

['What changed with the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act of 2008?', 'This changed with the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act of 2008, which requires group health plans and insurers to make sure there is parity of mental health services (U.S. Department of Labor, n.d.).']

['How does that help?', 'This means that co-pays, total number of visits, and deductibles for mental health and substance use treatment need to be equal to and cannot be more restrictive or harsher than those for physical illnesses and medical/surgical problems.']

['What are some of the obstacles to mental health treatment?', 'Finding treatment sources is also not always easy: there may be limited options, especially in rural areas and low-income urban areas; waiting lists; poor quality of care available for indigent patients; and financial obstacles such as co-pays, deductibles, and time off from work.']

['What type of resources are available?', 'Over 85% of the l,669 federally designated mental health professional shortage areas are rural; often primary care physicians and law enforcement are the first-line mental health providers (Ivey, Scheffler, & Zazzali, 1998), although they do not have the specialized training of a mental health professional, who often would be better equipped to provide care.']
['What are some other problems in rural areas?', 'Availability, accessibility, and acceptability (the stigma attached to mental illness) are all problems in rural areas.']

['What type of treatment does the stigma involve?', 'Approximately two-thirds of those with symptoms receive no care at all (U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2005; Wagenfeld, Murray, Mohatt, & DeBruiynb, 1994).']

['What is the most important thing you can tell me about the passage?', 'At the end of 2013, the U.S. Department of Agriculture announced an investment of $50 million to help improve access and treatment for mental health problems as part of the Obama administration’s effort to strengthen rural communities.']

['What is the goal of therapy?', 'One of the goals of therapy is to help a person stop repeating and reenacting destructive patterns and to start looking for better solutions to difficult situations.']
['What is the goal of the poem?', 'This goal is reflected in the following poem:']
['What are two types of therapy?', 'Two types of therapy are psychotherapy and biomedical therapy.']
['What issues do both therapy help people with?', 'Both types of treatment help people with mental health issues, such as depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia.']
['What is the purpose of psychotherapy?', 'Psychotherapy is a psychological treatment that employs various methods to help someone overcome personal problems, or to attain personal growth.']
['What has modern practice evolved into?', 'In modern practice, it has evolved into what is known as psychodynamic therapy, which will be discussed later.']
['What is unique about biomedical therapy?', 'Biomedical therapy involves medication and/or medical procedures to treat psychological disorders.']

['What are some things that we should learn?', 'First, we will explore the various psychotherapeutic orientations outlined in Table 16.1 (many of these orientations were discussed in the Introduction chapter).']
['What was the first form of psychotherapy?', 'Psychoanalysis was developed by Sigmund Freud and was the first form of psychotherapy.']
['What was the most important thing about psychoanalysis?', 'It was the dominant therapeutic technique in the early 20th century, but it has since waned significantly in popularity.']

['What did Freud believe most of our psychological problems are the result of?', 'Freud believed most of our psychological problems are the result of repressed impulses and trauma experienced in childhood, and he believed psychoanalysis would help uncover long-buried feelings.']

['What were the methods used?', 'In a psychoanalyst’s office, you might see a patient lying on a couch speaking of dreams or childhood memories, and the therapist using various Freudian methods such as free association and dream analysis (Figure 16.9).']
['What happens in free association?', 'In free association, the patient relaxes and then says whatever comes to mind at the moment.']

['Did Freud feel that the ego would at times try to block, or repress, unacceptable urges or painful conflicts during free association?', 'However, Freud felt that the ego would at times try to block, or repress, unacceptable urges or painful conflicts during free association.']
['What would a patient do if they tried to block?', 'Consequently, a patient would demonstrate resistance to recalling these thoughts or situations.']
['What is dream analysis?', 'In dream analysis, a therapist interprets the underlying meaning of dreams.']
['What is the main idea of psychoanalysis?', 'Psychoanalysis is a therapy approach that typically takes years.']
['What else do we know about psychoanalysis?', 'Over the course of time, the patient reveals a great deal about himself to the therapist.']

['who is the therapist?', 'Freud suggested that during this patient-therapist relationship, the patient comes to develop strong feelings for the therapist—maybe positive feelings, maybe negative feelings.']

['What does Freud call the transference of positive or negative emotions associated with the patient’s other relationships to the psychoanalyst?', 'Freud called this transference: the patient transfers all the positive or negative emotions associated with the patient’s other relationships to the psychoanalyst.']
['Who is seeing the psychoanalyst?', 'For example, Crystal is seeing a psychoanalyst.']
['What does she say about her psychoanalyst?', 'During the years of therapy, she comes to see her therapist as a father figure.']

['What does she do with her therapist?', 'She transfers her feelings about her father onto her therapist, perhaps in an effort to gain the love and attention she did not receive from her own father.']

['What is the psychodynamic perspective?', 'Today, Freud’s psychoanalytical perspective has been expanded upon by the developments of subsequent theories and methodologies: the psychodynamic perspective.']

["What is the difference between psychodynamic perspective and Freud's original model?", 'This approach to therapy remains centered on the role of people’s internal drives and forces, but treatment is less intensive than Freud’s original model.']

['What is the main reason play therapy is used with children?', 'Play therapy is often used with children since they are not likely to sit on a couch and recall their dreams or engage in traditional talk therapy.']

['What does play therapy use to help clients?', 'This technique uses a therapeutic process of play to “help clients prevent or resolve psychosocial difficulties and achieve optimal growth” (O’Connor, 2000, p. 7).']

['What toys are used to play out hopes, fantasies, and traumas?', 'The idea is that children play out their hopes, fantasies, and traumas while using dolls, stuffed animals, and sandbox figurines (Figure 16.10).']
['What else is the therapist doing with them?', 'Play therapy can also be used to help a therapist make a diagnosis.']

['How is the child to be diagnosed?', 'The therapist observes how the child interacts with toys (e.g., dolls, animals, and home settings) in an effort to understand the roots of the child’s disturbed behavior.']
['How does the therapist communicate with the child?', 'Play therapy can be nondirective or directive.']
['What happens in nondirective?', 'In nondirective play therapy, children are encouraged to work through their problems by playing freely while the therapist observes (LeBlanc & Ritchie, 2001).']

['What happens in directive?', 'In directive play therapy, the therapist provides more structure and guidance in the play session by suggesting topics, asking questions, and even playing with the child (Harter, 1977).']
['What does psychoanalysis help people do?', 'In psychoanalysis, therapists help their patients look into their past to uncover repressed feelings.']
['What do therapists focus on?', 'In behavior therapy, a therapist employs principles of learning to help clients change undesirable behaviors—rather than digging deeply into one’s unconscious.']

['What are the implications of this?', 'Therapists with this orientation believe that dysfunctional behaviors, like phobias and bedwetting, can be changed by teaching clients new, more constructive behaviors.']
["What is the therapist's role in operant conditioning techniques?", 'Behavior therapy employs both classical and operant conditioning techniques to change behavior.']
['What is one of the techniques in behavior therapy?', 'One type of behavior therapy utilizes classical conditioning techniques.']
['What can you tell me about conditioning techniques?', 'Therapists using these techniques believe that dysfunctional behaviors are conditioned responses.']

['What can you tell me about the conditioning principles developed by Ivan Pavlov?', 'Applying the conditioning principles developed by Ivan Pavlov, these therapists seek to recondition their clients and thus change their behavior.']
['What kind of behaviors do you have in the class?', 'Emmie is eight years old, and frequently wets her bed at night.']
['What else can you tell me about the behaviors?', 'She’s been invited to several sleepovers, but she won’t go because of her problem.']
['How did you get her to stop?', 'Using a type of conditioning therapy, Emmie begins to sleep on a liquid-sensitive bed pad that is hooked to an alarm.']
['What does that alarm do?', 'When moisture touches the pad, it sets off the alarm, waking up Emmie.']

['What else do you have to say about the behavior?', 'When this process is repeated enough times, Emmie develops an association between urinary relaxation and waking up, and this stops the bedwetting.']
['How long did it take Emmie to stop wetting her bed?', 'Emmie has now gone three weeks without wetting her bed and is looking forward to her first sleepover this weekend.']

['What is the most commonly used therapeutic technique?', 'One commonly used classical conditioning therapeutic technique is counterconditioning: a client learns a new response to a stimulus that has previously elicited an undesirable behavior.']
['What are two counterconditioning techniques?', 'Two counterconditioning techniques are aversive conditioning and exposure therapy.']
['What is the purpose of aversive conditioning?', 'Aversive conditioning uses an unpleasant stimulus to stop an undesirable behavior.']
['What is exposure therapy?', 'Therapists apply this technique to eliminate addictive behaviors, such as  smoking, nail biting, and drinking.']

['What is aversion therapy?', 'In aversion therapy, clients will typically engage in a specific behavior (such as nail biting) and at the same time are exposed to something unpleasant, such as a mild electric shock or a bad taste.']
['What happens after they encounter the unpleasant stimulus?', 'After repeated associations between the unpleasant stimulus and the behavior, the client can learn to stop the unwanted behavior.']
['What is aversion therapy?', 'Aversion therapy has been used effectively for years in the treatment of alcoholism (Davidson, 1974; Elkins, 1991; Streeton & Whelan, 2001).']
['What is antabuse?', 'One common way this occurs is through a chemically based substance known as Antabuse.']

['What other side effects?', 'When a person takes Antabuse and then consumes alcohol, uncomfortable side effects result including nausea, vomiting, increased heart rate, heart palpitations, severe headache, and shortness of breath.']

['What happens after the side effects?', 'Antabuse is repeatedly paired with alcohol until the client associates alcohol with unpleasant feelings, which decreases the client’s desire to consume alcohol.']
['What does Antabuse do?', 'Antabuse creates a conditioned aversion to alcohol because it replaces the original pleasure response with an unpleasant one.']

['what is exposure therapy?', 'In exposure therapy, a therapist seeks to treat clients’ fears or anxiety by presenting them with the object or situation that causes their problem, with the idea that they will eventually get used to it.']
['How does this therapy work?', 'This can be done via reality, imagination, or virtual reality.']
['Who invented exposure therapy?', 'Exposure therapy was first reported in 1924 by Mary Cover Jones, who is considered the mother of behavior therapy.']
["What was Peter's relationship to Jones?", 'Jones worked with a boy named Peter who was afraid of rabbits.']

['What was the result of the experiment?', 'Her goal was to replace Peter’s fear of rabbits with a conditioned response of relaxation, which is a response that is incompatible with fear (Figure 16.11).']
['What did Jones do to help Peter?', 'Jones began by placing a caged rabbit on the other side of a room with Peter while he ate his afternoon snack.']
['What did Jones do next?', 'Over the course of several days, Jones moved the rabbit closer and closer to where Peter was seated with his snack.']

['How long did it take Peter to be able to hold the rabbit?', 'After two months of being exposed to the rabbit while relaxing with his snack, Peter was able to hold the rabbit and pet it while eating (Jones, 1924).']
['What is the purpose of this document?', 'Thirty years later, Joseph Wolpe (1958) refined Jones’s techniques, giving us systematic desensitization.']
['What is systematic desensitization?', 'Using this method, a person creates a hierarchy of anxiety, ranging from the least-anxiety-producing stimulus to the feared object.']
['What are the activities paired with?', 'These activities are paired with relaxation techniques, which are taught to the client beforehand and used during the graduated exposures.']
['What are the relaxation techniques?', 'The idea is that a person cannot be nervous and relaxed at the same time.']

['How can a person relax when they are facing environmental stimuli that make them nervous or fearful?', 'Therefore, if they can learn to relax when they are facing environmental stimuli that make them nervous or fearful, they can eventually eliminate the unwanted fear response.']
['Where are the graduation exposures?', '(Figure 16.12).']
['What are some examples of how it works?', 'For example, Jayden is terrified of elevators.']
['What can the therapist tell him to make him less afraid of elevators?', 'Nothing bad has ever happened to him on an elevator, but he’s so afraid of elevators that he will always take the stairs.']
['What happened next?', 'That wasn’t a problem when Jayden worked on the second floor of an office building, but now he has a new job—on the 29th floor of a skyscraper in downtown Los Angeles.']
['Who helped Jayden overcome his fear?', 'Jayden knows he can’t climb 29 flights of stairs in order to get to work each day, so he decided to see a behavior therapist for help.']
['What did the behavior therapist do to help Jayden?', 'The therapist asks Jayden to first construct a hierarchy of elevator-related situations that elicit fear and anxiety.']

['What situations elicit fear and anxiety?', 'They range from situations of mild anxiety such as being nervous around the other people in the elevator, to the fear of getting an arm caught in the door, to panic-provoking situations such as getting trapped or the cable snapping.']
['What did the therapist do next?', 'Next, the therapist uses progressive relaxation.']
['What is progressive relaxation?', 'They teach Jayden how to relax each of his muscle groups so that he achieves a drowsy, relaxed, and comfortable state of mind.']
['How does this work?', 'Once he’s in this state, the therapist asks Jayden to imagine a mildly anxiety-provoking situation.']
['What does Jayden imagine?', 'Jayden is standing in front of the elevator thinking about pressing the call button.']
['What does this scenario require?', 'If this scenario causes Jayden anxiety, he lifts his finger.']
['What would the therapist do after Jayden was in the scene?', 'The therapist would then tell Jayden to forget the scene and return to his relaxed state.']
['What does Jayden do after that?', 'They repeat this scenario over and over until Jayden can imagine himself pressing the call button without anxiety.']

['how does progressive relaxation help?', 'Over time the therapist and Jayden use progressive relaxation and imagination to proceed through all of the situations on Jayden’s hierarchy until he becomes desensitized to each one.']

['What did Jayden and the therapist do next?', 'After this, Jayden and the therapist begin to practice what he only previously envisioned in therapy, gradually going from pressing the button to actually riding an elevator.']
['What is the goal of Jayden?', 'The goal is that Jayden will soon be able to take the elevator all the way up to the 29th floor of his office without feeling any anxiety.']

['How does virtual reality exposure therapy work?', 'Sometimes, it’s too impractical, expensive, or embarrassing to re-create anxiety- producing situations, so a therapist might employ virtual reality exposure therapy by using a simulation to help conquer fears.']

['What anxiety disorders is it used to treat?', 'Virtual reality exposure therapy has been used effectively to treat numerous anxiety disorders such as the fear of public speaking, claustrophobia (fear of enclosed spaces), aviophobia (fear of flying), and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), a trauma and stressor-related disorder (Gerardi, Cukor, Difede, Rizzo, & Rothbaum, 2010).']
['What is the main idea of this passage?', 'Some behavior therapies employ operant conditioning.']
['What did you learn about operant conditioning?', 'Recall what you learned about operant conditioning:']
['What was the most important fact you learned?', 'We have a tendency to repeat behaviors that are reinforced.']
['What happens to other behaviors?', 'They become extinguished.']
['What can be done with operant conditioning?', 'These principles, defined by Skinner as operant conditioning, can be applied to help people with a wide range of psychological problems.']
['What is one popular operant conditioning intervention?', 'One popular operant conditioning intervention is called the token economy.']

['What is a token economy?', 'This involves a controlled setting where individuals are reinforced for desirable behaviors with tokens, such as a poker chip, that can be exchanged for items or privileges.']
['What are token economies used for?', 'Token economies are often used in psychiatric hospitals to increase patient cooperation and activity levels.']

['What are tokens used for?', 'Patients are rewarded with tokens when they engage in positive behaviors (e.g., making their beds, brushing their teeth, coming to the cafeteria on time, and socializing with other patients).']
['What can they do with tokens?', 'They can later exchange the tokens for extra TV time, private rooms, visits to the canteen, and so on (Dickerson, Tenhula, & Green-Paden, 2005).']
['What is the main idea of cognitive therapy?', 'Cognitive therapy is a form of psychotherapy that focuses on how a person’s thoughts lead to feelings of distress.']
['What is the idea behind cognitive therapy?', 'The idea behind cognitive therapy is that how you think determines how you feel and act.']
['How do cognitive therapists help their clients?', 'Cognitive therapists help their clients change dysfunctional thoughts in order to relieve distress.']
['How does the therapist help them?', 'They help a client see how they misinterpret a situation (cognitive distortion).']
['What are some examples of cognitive distortion?', 'For example, a client may overgeneralize.']
['What are some examples of people feeling stupid and worthless?', 'Because a person failed one test in Psychology 101, they feel stupid and worthless.']
['What happens to the client then?', 'These thoughts then cause their mood to worsen.']
['How else do therapists help them?', 'Therapists also help clients recognize when they blow things out of proportion.']

['What is an example of blowing things out of proportion?', 'Because Ray failed his Psychology 101 test, he has concluded that he’s going to fail the entire course and probably flunk out of college altogether.']
['What is the effect of Ray’s thinking?', 'These errors in thinking have contributed to Ray’s feelings of distress.']
['How is it reformed?', 'His therapist will help him challenge these irrational beliefs, focus on their illogical basis, and correct them with more logical and rational thoughts and beliefs.']
['Who developed this?', 'Cognitive therapy was developed by psychiatrist Aaron Beck in the 1960s.']

['What did he focus on initially?', 'His initial focus was on depression and how a client’s self-defeating attitude served to maintain a depression despite positive factors in her life (Beck, Rush, Shaw, & Emery, 1979) (Figure 16.13).']

['what is cognitive therapy about?', 'Through questioning, a cognitive therapist can help a client recognize dysfunctional ideas, challenge catastrophizing thoughts about themselves and their situations, and find a more positive way to view things (Beck, 2011).']
['What are the concepts in this chapter?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapists focus much more on present issues than on a patient’s childhood or past, as in other forms of psychotherapy.']

['What was the first form of cognitive-behavioral therapy?', 'One of the first forms of cognitive-behavioral therapy was rational emotive therapy (RET), which was founded by Albert Ellis and grew out of his dislike of Freudian psychoanalysis (Daniel, n.d.).']
['What influenced Ellis’s therapeutic approach?', 'Behaviorists such as Joseph Wolpe also influenced Ellis’s therapeutic approach (National Association of Cognitive-Behavioral Therapists, 2009).']
['What is the main idea of cognitive-behavioral therapy?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) helps clients examine how their thoughts affect their behavior.']
['What does cbt aim to change?', 'It aims to change cognitive distortions and self-defeating behaviors.']
['What does this approach aim to change?', 'In essence, this approach is designed to change the way people think as well as how they act.']

['What is cognitive therapy?', 'It is similar to cognitive therapy in that CBT attempts to make individuals aware of their irrational and negative thoughts and helps people replace them with new, more positive ways of thinking.']
['What is CBT like?', 'It is also similar to behavior therapies in that CBT teaches people how to practice and engage in more positive and healthy approaches to daily situations.']

['How does it help?', 'In total, hundreds of studies have shown the effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral therapy in the treatment of numerous psychological disorders such as depression, PTSD, anxiety disorders, eating disorders, bipolar disorder, and substance abuse (Beck Institute for Cognitive Behavior Therapy, n.d.).']

['What else can CBT help with?', 'For example, CBT has been found to be effective in decreasing levels of hopelessness and suicidal thoughts in previously suicidal teenagers (Alavi, Sharifi, Ghanizadeh, & Dehbozorgi, 2013).']
['What is another example of this?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy has also been effective in reducing PTSD in specific populations, such as transit workers (Lowinger & Rombom, 2012).']
['What is the ABC model?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy aims to change cognitive distortions and self-defeating behaviors using techniques like the ABC model.']
['What are the characteristics of the ABC model?', 'With this model, there is an Action (sometimes called an activating event), the Belief about the event, and the Consequences of this belief.']
['What kind of events could the model be used for?', 'Let’s say Jon and Joe both go to a party.']
['What did they do at the party?', 'Jon and Joe each have met an interesting person at the party and spend a few hours chatting with them.']
['What did they do at the end of the party?', "At the end of the party, Jon and Joe ask to exchange phone numbers with the person they've been talking to, and the request is refused."]
['How did that make them feel?', 'Both Jon and Joe are surprised, as they thought things were going well.']
['What can be done with the model?', 'Let’s say Jon tells himself he is a loser, or is ugly, or “has no game.”']
['What happens to Jon after he gets depressed?', 'Jon then gets depressed and decides not to go to another party, which starts a cycle that keeps him depressed.']
['What did Joe do after he realized he had bad breath?', 'Joe tells himself that he had bad breath, goes out and buys a new toothbrush, goes to another party, and meets someone new.']
['What is the topic of your assignment?', 'Jon’s belief about what happened results in a consequence of further depression, whereas Joe’s belief does not.']
['Why is Jon so depressed?', 'Jon is internalizing the attribution or reason for the rebuffs, which triggers his depression.']
['How does the study relate to CBT?', 'On the other hand, Joe is externalizing the cause, so his thinking does not contribute to feelings of depression.']
['What is the main idea of cognitive-behavioral therapy?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy examines specific maladaptive and automatic thoughts and cognitive distortions.']
['What are some examples of cognitive distortions?', 'Some examples of cognitive distortions are all-or-nothing thinking, overgeneralization, and jumping to conclusions.']

['What is an example of overgeneralization?', 'In overgeneralization, someone takes a small situation and makes it huge—for example, instead of saying, “This particular person was not interested in me,” the man says, “I am ugly, a loser, and no one is ever going to be interested in me.”']
['What does reflects extremes mean?', 'All or nothing thinking, which is a common type of cognitive distortion for people suffering from depression, reflects extremes.']
['What does it mean to be black or white?', 'In other words, everything is black or white.']
['How does it affect their lives?', 'After being turned down for a date, Jon begins to think, “No woman will ever go out with me.']
['How does he feel as a result?', 'I’m going to be alone forever.”']
['Does he do anything to feel better?', 'He begins to feel anxious and sad as he contemplates his future.']

['What kind of distortion is this?', 'The third kind of distortion involves jumping to conclusions—assuming that people are thinking negatively about you or reacting negatively to you, even though there is no evidence.']
['What is an example of a person who is a good listener?', 'Consider the example of Savannah and Hillaire, who recently met at a party.']
['What do they have in common?', 'They have a lot in common, and Savannah thinks they could become friends.']
['What does she do?', 'She calls Hillaire to invite her for coffee.']
['Did Savannah get a response?', 'Since Hillaire doesn’t answer, Savannah leaves her a message.']
['What did Savannah do after this?', 'Several days go by and Savannah never hears back from her potential new friend.']
['What does Hillaire do?', 'Maybe Hillaire never received the message because she lost her phone or she is too busy to return the phone call.']

['What happens after she asks?', 'But if Savannah believes that Hillaire didn’t like Savannah or didn’t want to be her friend, she is demonstrating the cognitive distortion of jumping to conclusions.']
['What did a client say about the therapy?', 'One client said this about his cognitive-behavioral therapy:']
['What is the focus of humanistic psychology?', 'Humanistic psychology focuses on helping people achieve their potential.']
['What is the goal of humanistic therapy?', 'So it makes sense that the goal of humanistic therapy is to help people become more self-aware and accepting of themselves.']
['What else is important about this type of therapy?', 'In contrast to psychoanalysis, humanistic therapists focus on conscious rather than unconscious thoughts.']
['What else is unique about the therapists?', 'They also emphasize the patient’s present and future, as opposed to exploring the patient’s past.']
['what was the therapeutic orientation that carl rogers developed?', 'Psychologist Carl Rogers developed a therapeutic orientation known as Rogerian, or client-centered therapy.']
['What did Roger modify this method to?', 'Note the change from patients to clients.']
['What was the problem with patients?', 'Rogers (1951) felt that the term patient suggested the person seeking help was sick and looking for a cure.']

['what was the person taking control?', 'Since this is a form of nondirective therapy, a therapeutic approach in which the therapist does not give advice or provide interpretations but helps the person to identify conflicts and understand feelings, Rogers (1951) emphasized the importance of the person taking control of his own life to overcome life’s challenges.']
['What is the technique of client-centered therapy?', 'In client-centered therapy, the therapist uses the technique of active listening.']
['What is the technique of active listening?', 'In active listening, the therapist acknowledges, restates, and clarifies what the client expresses.']
['What does the therapist do?', 'Therapists also practice what Rogers called unconditional positive regard, which involves not judging clients and simply accepting them for who they are.']

['What is the most important thing to remember from the article?', 'Rogers (1951) also felt that therapists should demonstrate genuineness, empathy, and acceptance toward their clients because this helps people become more accepting of themselves, which results in personal growth.']
['What do you think about this?', 'For anyone considering therapy, these are important questions.']
['What else did you find helpful?', 'According to the American Psychological Association, three factors work together to produce successful treatment.']
['What are the factors that determine the effectiveness of evidence-based treatment?', 'The first is the use of evidence-based treatment that is deemed appropriate for your particular issue.']
['What is the second important factor?', 'The second important factor is the clinical expertise of the psychologist or therapist.']
['What is the third factor?', 'The third factor is your own characteristics, values, preferences, and culture.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Many people begin psychotherapy feeling like their problem will never be resolved; however, psychotherapy helps people see that they can do things to make their situation better.']
['What are some benefits of psychotherapy?', 'Psychotherapy can help reduce a person’s anxiety, depression, and maladaptive behaviors.']

['What else?', 'Through psychotherapy, individuals can learn to engage in healthy behaviors designed to help them better express emotions, improve relationships, think more positively, and perform more effectively at work or school.']
['What is the purpose of this study material?', 'Many studies have explored the effectiveness of psychotherapy.']

['What has this study found?', 'For example, one large-scale study that examined 16 meta-analyses of CBT reported that it was equally effective or more effective than other therapies in treating PTSD, generalized anxiety disorder, depression, and social phobia (Butlera, Chapmanb, Formanc, & Becka, 2006).']

['Was this study the only one to perform so well?', 'Another study found that CBT was as effective at treating depression (43% success rate) as prescription medication (50% success rate) compared to the placebo rate of 25% (DeRubeis et al., 2005).']
['Did any other studies show these things?', 'Another meta-analysis found that psychodynamic therapy was also as effective at treating these types of psychological issues as CBT (Shedler, 2010).']

['Did any study find a specific factor that was more important than others?', 'However, no studies have found one psychotherapeutic approach more effective than another (Abbass, Kisely, & Kroenke, 2006; Chorpita et al., 2011), nor have they shown any relationship between a client’s treatment outcome and the level of the clinician’s training or experience (Wampold, 2007).']

['How did the person and therapist relate to each other?', 'Regardless of which type of psychotherapy an individual chooses, one critical factor that determines the success of treatment is the person’s relationship with the psychologist or therapist.']
['What are some of the specialized treatments?', 'Individuals can be prescribed biologically based treatments or psychotropic medications that are used to treat mental disorders.']
['Are they used in combination with psychotherapy?', 'While these are often used in combination with psychotherapy, they also are taken by individuals not in therapy.']
['What is the name of this type of therapy?', 'This is known as biomedical therapy.']

['What are the medications used to treat psychological disorders called?', 'Medications used to treat psychological disorders are called psychotropic medications and are prescribed by medical doctors, including psychiatrists.']
['Are they prescribed in other states?', 'In Louisiana and New Mexico, psychologists are able to prescribe some types of these medications (American Psychological Association, 2014).']
['What are different types and classes of medications?', 'Different types and classes of medications are prescribed for different disorders.']

['What are the different medications used to treat specific disorders?', 'An individual with depression might be given an antidepressant, an individual with bipolar disorder might be given a mood stabilizer, and an individual with schizophrenia might be given an antipsychotic.']
["How do these medications change a person's chemical balance?", 'These medications treat the symptoms of a psychological disorder by altering the levels or effects of neurotransmitters.']

['What are the effects of these medications?', 'For example, each type of antidepressant affects a different neurotransmitter, such as SSRI (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor) antidepressants that increase the level of the neurotransmitter serotonin, and SNRI (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) antidepressants that increase the levels of both serotonin and norepinephrine.']
['What happens when these medications are used?', 'They can help people feel better so that they can function on a daily basis, but they do not cure the disorder.']
['Are there any side effects to the medications?', 'Some people may only need to take a psychotropic medication for a short period of time.']
['How long can you take these medications?', 'Others with severe disorders like bipolar disorder or schizophrenia may need to take psychotropic medication for a long time.']

['What are some interesting aspects of the material?', 'Psychotropic medications are a popular treatment option for many types of disorders, and research suggests that they are most effective when combined with psychotherapy.']
['Are there any studies about this?', 'This is especially true for the most common mental disorders, such as depressive and anxiety disorders (Cuijpers et al, 2014).']

['What else is interesting about this section?', 'When considering adding medication as a treatment option, individuals should know that some psychotropic medications have very concerning side effects.']
['What is the most important information in this section?', 'Table 16.2 shows the commonly prescribed types of medications, how they are used, and some of the potential side effects that may occur.']

['When was electroconvulsive therapy developed?', 'Another biologically based treatment that continues to be used, although infrequently, is electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) (formerly known by its unscientific name as electroshock therapy).']
['What does ECT involve?', 'It involves using an electrical current to induce seizures to help alleviate the effects of severe depression.']

['What does ECT help with?', 'The exact mechanism is unknown, although it does help alleviate symptoms for people with severe depression who have not responded to traditional drug therapy (Pagnin, de Queiroz, Pini, & Cassano, 2004).']
['How well does ECT work?', 'About 85% of people treated with ECT improve (Reti, n.d.).']

['What is the memory loss associated with repeated administrations?', 'However, the memory loss associated with repeated administrations has led to it being implemented as a last resort (Donahue, 2000; Prudic, Peyser, & Sackeim, 2000).']

['What are some alternatives to ECT?', 'A more recent alternative is transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), a procedure approved by the FDA in 2008 that uses magnetic fields to stimulate nerve cells in the brain to improve depression symptoms; it is used when other treatments have not worked (Mayo Clinic, 2012).']
['What is the first meeting between a person and a therapist?', 'Once a person seeks treatment, whether voluntarily or involuntarily, they have an intake done to assess their clinical needs.']
['What is the first meeting between a therapist and a client?', 'An intake is the therapist’s first meeting with the client.']

['What information does the therapist gather?', 'The therapist gathers specific information to address the client’s immediate needs, such as the presenting problem, the client’s support system, and insurance status.']
['What does the therapist inform the client about?', 'The therapist informs the client about confidentiality, fees, and what to expect in treatment.']
['What does confidentiality mean?', 'Confidentiality means the therapist cannot disclose confidential communications to any third party unless mandated or permitted by law to do so.']
['What is a common discussion during the intake?', 'During the intake, the therapist and client will work together to discuss treatment goals.']
['What happens after that?', 'Then a treatment plan will be formulated, usually with specific measurable objectives.']
['What is the treatment plan for?', 'Also, the therapist and client will discuss how treatment success will be measured and the estimated length of treatment.']

['What are the different modalities of treatment?', 'There are several different modalities of treatment (Figure 16.14): Individual therapy, family therapy, couples therapy, and group therapy are the most common.']

['What is the difference between individual therapy and individual psychotherapy?', 'In individual therapy, also known as individual psychotherapy or individual counseling, the client and clinician meet one-on-one (usually from 45 minutes to 1 hour).']
['What do the client do in therapy?', 'These meetings typically occur weekly or every other week, and sessions are conducted in a confidential and caring environment (Figure 16.15).']

['How do the clients help the clinician?', 'The clinician will work with clients to help them explore their feelings, work through life challenges, identify aspects of themselves and their lives that they wish to change, and set goals to help them work towards these changes.']
['How long does therapy last?', 'A client might see a clinician for only a few sessions, or the client may attend individual therapy sessions for a year or longer.']
['What else should you know about the individual therapy?', 'The amount of time spent in therapy depends on the needs of the client as well as her personal goals.']
['What does group therapy consist of?', 'In group therapy, a clinician meets together with several clients with similar problems (Figure 16.16).']
['Why does he meet with several clients?', 'When children are placed in group therapy, it is particularly important to match clients for age and problems.']

['What are some benefits of group therapy?', 'One benefit of group therapy is that it can help decrease a client’s shame and isolation about a problem while offering needed support, both from the therapist and other members of the group (American Psychological Association, 2014).']
['What are some ways the clients may feel shame?', 'A nine-year-old sexual abuse victim, for example, may feel very embarrassed and ashamed.']
['What does the group do for this boy?', 'If he is placed in a group with other sexually abused boys, he will realize that he is not alone.']
['What can group therapy do for them?', 'A child struggling with poor social skills would likely benefit from a group with a specific curriculum to foster special skills.']
['How can group therapy benefit a woman?', 'A woman suffering from post-partum depression could feel less guilty and more supported by being in a group with similar women.']
['What are the key elements of group therapy?', 'Group therapy also has some specific limitations.']

['Are there any other important facts about the passage?', 'Members of the group may be afraid to speak in front of other people because sharing secrets and problems with complete strangers can be stressful and overwhelming.']
['What are the drawbacks of working in a group?', 'There may be personality clashes and arguments among group members.']
['What could be a concern about the group?', 'There could also be concerns about confidentiality: Someone from the group might share what another participant said to people outside of the group.']
['What is another benefit of group therapy?', 'Another benefit of group therapy is that members can confront each other about their patterns.']
['What kind of problems can be addressed through group therapy?', 'For those with some types of problems, such as sexual abusers, group therapy is the recommended treatment.']
['What is the group treatment for this population considered?', 'Group treatment for this population is considered to have several benefits:']
['What is the strongest educational component of the group therapy sessions?', 'Groups that have a strong educational component are called psycho-educational groups.']

['What might the groups discuss?', 'For example, a group for children whose parents have cancer might discuss in depth what cancer is, types of treatment for cancer, and the side effects of treatments, such as hair loss.']
['Where do group therapy sessions with children take place?', 'Often, group therapy sessions with children take place in school.']
['What is the name of the person who leads the sessions?', 'They are led by a school counselor, a school psychologist, or a school social worker.']
['What might the groups focus on?', 'Groups might focus on test anxiety, social isolation, self-esteem, bullying, or school failure (Shechtman, 2002).']

['How has group therapy been used for children facing challenges?', 'Whether the group is held in school or in a clinician’s office, group therapy has been found to be effective with children facing numerous kinds of challenges (Shechtman, 2002).']

['What happens in group therapy?', 'During a group session, the entire group could reflect on an individual’s problem or difficulties, and others might disclose what they have done in that situation.']

['What kind of interventions are used when a clinician is facilitating a group?', 'When a clinician is facilitating a group, the focus is always on making sure that everyone benefits and participates in the group and that no one person is the focus of the entire session.']

['What are some ways groups are organized?', 'Groups can be organized in various ways: some have an overarching theme or purpose, some are time-limited, some have open membership that allows people to come and go, and some are closed.']
['Are there different styles of groups?', 'Some groups are structured with planned activities and goals, while others are unstructured:']

['How is unstructured group work different from structured group work?', 'There is no specific plan, and group members themselves decide how the group will spend its time and on what goals it will focus.']

['What can become a complex and emotionally charged process, but it is also an opportunity for personal growth?', 'This can become a complex and emotionally charged process, but it is also an opportunity for personal growth (Page & Berkow, 1994).']
['What is couples therapy?', 'Couples therapy involves two people in an intimate relationship who are having difficulties and are trying to resolve them (Figure 16.17).']
['What kind of relationship do they have?', 'The couple may be dating, partnered, engaged, or married.']

['What is the primary therapeutic orientation used in couples counseling?', 'The primary therapeutic orientation used in couples counseling is cognitive-behavioral therapy (Rathus & Sanderson, 1999).']
['How does couples counseling work?', 'Couples meet with a therapist to discuss conflicts and/or aspects of their relationship that they want to change.']
['What does the therapist do when they meet?', 'The therapist helps them see how their individual backgrounds, beliefs, and actions are affecting their relationship.']

['How does a therapist help them?', 'Often, a therapist tries to help the couple resolve these problems, as well as implement strategies that will lead to a healthier and happier relationship, such as how to listen, how to argue, and how to express feelings.']
['What can the therapist do to help the couple?', 'However, sometimes, after working with a therapist, a couple will realize that they are too incompatible and will decide to separate.']
['What is the purpose of couples therapy?', 'Some couples seek therapy to work out their problems, while others attend therapy to determine whether staying together is the best solution.']
['What is the most important thing I should know about counseling couples?', 'Counseling couples in a high-conflict and volatile relationship can be difficult.']

['What does that mean?', 'In fact, psychologists Peter Pearson and Ellyn Bader, who founded the Couples Institute in Palo Alto, California, have compared the experience of the clinician in couples’ therapy to be like “piloting a helicopter in a hurricane” (Weil, 2012, para. 7).']
['What is family therapy?', 'Family therapy is a special form of group therapy, consisting of one or more families.']

['What is one of the most predominant theoretical orientations in family therapy?', 'Although there are many theoretical orientations in family therapy, one of the most predominant is the systems approach.']

['What does this approach describe?', 'The family is viewed as an organized system, and each individual within the family is a contributing member who creates and maintains processes within the system that shape behavior (Minuchin, 1985).']
['Does this approach influence anyone else?', 'Each member of the family influences and is influenced by the others.']
['What is the goal of this approach?', 'The goal of this approach is to enhance the growth of each family member as well as that of the family as a whole.']
['How does it benefit families?', 'Often, dysfunctional patterns of communication that develop between family members can lead to conflict.']
['How can it help a family with this dynamic?', 'A family with this dynamic might wish to attend therapy together rather than individually.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'In many cases, one member of the family has problems that detrimentally affect everyone.']

['What are some examples of how family members can be affected by a mental health issue?', 'For example, a mother’s depression, teen daughter’s eating disorder, or father’s alcohol dependence could affect all members of the family.']

['What would a therapist do?', 'The therapist would work with all members of the family to help them cope with the issue, and to encourage resolution and growth in the case of the individual family member with the problem.']

['What type of therapy is family therapy?', 'With family therapy, the nuclear family (i.e., parents and children) or the nuclear family plus whoever lives in the household (e.g., grandparent) come into treatment.']
['What happens in family therapy?', 'Family therapists work with the whole family unit to heal the family.']
['What are the different types of family therapy?', 'There are several different types of family therapy.']

['what is the significance of structural therapy?', 'In structural family therapy, the therapist examines and discusses the boundaries and structure of the family: who makes the rules, who sleeps in the bed with whom, how decisions are made, and what are the boundaries within the family.']
['What is the main reason for family therapy?', 'In some families, the parents do not work together to make rules, or one parent may undermine the other, leading the children to act out.']
['How does the therapist help them resolve these issues?', 'The therapist helps them resolve these issues and learn to communicate more effectively.']
['What is the purpose of this document?', 'In strategic family therapy, the goal is to address specific problems within the family that can be dealt with in a relatively short amount of time.']

["What is the therapist's role in a group therapy session?", 'Typically, the therapist would guide what happens in the therapy session and design a detailed approach to resolving each member’s problem (Madanes, 1991).']
['What are some important points about addiction?', 'Addiction is often viewed as a chronic disease (Figure 16.18).']

['How does addiction effect the person?', 'The choice to use a substance is initially voluntary; however, because chronic substance use can permanently alter the neural structure in the prefrontal cortex, an area of the brain associated with decision-making and judgment, a person becomes driven to use drugs and/or alcohol (Muñoz-Cuevas, Athilingam, Piscopo, & Wilbrecht, 2013).']
['What can happen as a result of addiction?', 'This helps explain why relapse rates tend to be high.']

['What else can happen as a result of addiction?', 'About 40%–60% of individuals relapse, which means they return to abusing drugs and/or alcohol after a period of improvement (National Institute on Drug Abuse [NIDA], 2008).']
['What is the goal of substance-related treatment?', 'The goal of substance-related treatment is to help a person with an addiction stop compulsive drug-seeking behaviors (NIDA, 2012).']
