['Does the long term treatment mean anything?', 'This means a person with addiction will need long-term treatment, similar to a person battling a chronic physical disease such as hypertension or diabetes.']
['What types of treatments are used to treat addiction?', 'Treatment usually includes behavioral therapy and/or medication, depending on the individual (NIDA, 2012).']

['Do there are specific types of substance-related disorders?', 'Specialized therapies have also been developed for specific types of substance-related disorders, including alcohol, cocaine, and opioids (McGovern & Carroll, 2003).']

['What is the most cost-effective way to treat addictions?', 'Substance-related treatment is considered much more cost-effective than incarceration or not treating those with addictions (NIDA, 2012) (Figure 16.19).']
['What is the best thing to learn from this text?', 'Specific factors make substance-related treatment much more effective.']
['Which of these factors is most important?', 'One factor is duration of treatment.']

['How long does the treatment last?', 'Generally, a person with addict needs to be in treatment for at least three months to achieve a positive outcome (Simpson, 1981; Simpson, Joe, & Bracy, 1982; NIDA, 2012).']
['Why do the treatments last that long?', 'This is due to the psychological, physiological, behavioral, and social aspects of abuse (Simpson, 1981; Simpson et al., 1982; NIDA, 2012).']

['What happens while in the treatment?', 'While in treatment, a person with addiction might receive behavior therapy, which can help motivate the person with addiction to participate in the treatment program and teach strategies for dealing with cravings and how to prevent relapse.']
['What other important things should be considered?', 'Also, treatment needs to be holistic and address multiple needs, not just the drug addiction.']

['What does holistic treatment mean?', 'This means that treatment will address factors such as communication, stress management, relationship issues, parenting, vocational concerns, and legal concerns (McGovern & Carroll, 2003; NIDA, 2012).']

['What is the most widespread treatment modality?', 'While individual therapy is used in the treatment of substance-related disorders, group therapy is the most widespread treatment modality (Weiss, Jaffee, de Menil, & Cogley, 2004).']

['What is the rationale behind using group therapy for addiction treatment?', 'The rationale behind using group therapy for addiction treatment is that people with addiction are much more likely to maintain sobriety in a group format.']

['Why do people join a support group?', 'It has been suggested that this is due to the rewarding and therapeutic benefits of the group, such as support, affiliation, identification, and even confrontation (Center for Substance Abuse Treatment, 2005).']

['What are the benefits of group therapy?', 'For teenagers, the whole family often needs to participate in treatment to address issues such as family dynamics, communication, and relapse prevention.']
['What is the most important factor in teen drug addiction?', 'Family involvement in teen drug addiction is vital.']

['What is the relationship between parental involvement and substance abuse?', 'Research suggests that greater parental involvement is correlated with a greater reduction in use by teen substance abusers.']
['What other benefits does that have?', 'Also, mothers who participated in treatment displayed better mental health and greater warmth toward their children (Bertrand et al., 2013).']
['Does individual therapy work better than group therapy?', 'However, neither individual nor group therapy has been found to be more effective (Weiss et al., 2004).']

['What is the focus of addiction treatment?', 'Regardless of the type of treatment service, the primary focus is on abstinence or at the very least a significant reduction in use (McGovern & Carroll, 2003).']

['what medications are used?', 'Treatment also usually involves medications to detox a person with addiction safely after an overdose, to prevent seizures and agitation that often occur in detox, to prevent reuse of the drug, and to manage withdrawal symptoms.']
['what other substances are used?', 'Getting off drugs often involves the use of drugs—some of which can be just as addictive.']
['What are the dangers of detox?', 'Detox can be difficult and dangerous.']
['What is the most common addiction?', 'Frequently, a person with an addiction to drugs and/or alcohol has an additional psychological disorder.']
['What is comorbid disorder?', 'Saying a person has comorbid disorders means the individual has two or more diagnoses.']

['What can it mean when someone has a substance-related diagnosis and another psychiatric diagnosis?', 'This can often be a substance-related diagnosis and another psychiatric diagnosis, such as depression, bipolar disorder, or schizophrenia.']

["What are the consequences of a person's addiction?", 'These individuals fall into the category of mentally ill and chemically addicted (MICA)—their problems are often chronic and expensive to treat, with limited success.']
['What else?', 'Compared with the overall population, people who use illicit drugs or misuse prescription drugs are twice as likely to have a mood or anxiety disorder.']

['What can I learn about drug use?', 'Drug use can cause symptoms of mood and anxiety disorders and the reverse is also true—people with debilitating symptoms of a psychiatric disorder may self-medicate and misuse substances.']
['What is the best treatment for comorbidity?', 'In cases of comorbidity, the best treatment is thought to address both (or multiple) disorders simultaneously (NIDA, 2012).']
['What are some types of treatment for comorbidity?', 'Behavior therapies are used to treat comorbid conditions, and in many cases, psychotropic medications are used along with psychotherapy.']

['What is the evidence that bupropion (trade names: Wellbutrin and Zyban), approved for treating depression and nicotine dependence, might also help reduce craving and use of the drug methamphetamine?', 'For example, evidence suggests that bupropion (trade names: Wellbutrin and Zyban), approved for treating depression and nicotine dependence, might also help reduce craving and use of the drug methamphetamine (NIDA, 2011).']
['What can you tell me about Zyban?', 'However, more research is needed to better understand how these medications work—particularly when combined in patients with comorbidities.']
['What is the sociocultural perspective?', 'The sociocultural perspective looks at you, your behaviors, and your symptoms in the context of your culture and background.']
['What is an example of this?', 'For example, José is an 18-year-old Hispanic male from a traditional family.']
['Why does José come to treatment?', 'José comes to treatment because of depression.']
['What is the intake session about?', 'During the intake session, he reveals that he is gay and is nervous about telling his family.']
['Why is he nervous?', 'He also discloses that he is concerned because his religious background has taught him that being gay is wrong.']

['What is the content of the passage?', 'Mental health professionals must develop cultural competence (Figure 16.20), which means they must understand and address issues of race, culture, and ethnicity.']

['What are some other important aspects of the study of psychiatric disorders?', 'They must also develop strategies to effectively address the needs of various populations for which Eurocentric therapies have limited application (Sue, 2004).']

['What is the article about?', 'For example, a counselor whose treatment focuses on individual decision making may be ineffective at helping a Chinese client with a collectivist approach to problem solving (Sue, 2004).']

['What is multicultural counseling and therapy?', 'Multicultural counseling and therapy aims to offer both a helping role and process that uses modalities and defines goals consistent with the life experiences and cultural values of clients.']

['Does it promote a more comprehensive approach to mental health?', 'It strives to recognize client identities to include individual, group, and universal dimensions, advocate the use of universal and culture-specific strategies and roles in the healing process, and balances the importance of individualism and collectivism in the assessment, diagnosis, and treatment of client and client systems (Sue, 2001).']
['What is the therapeutic perspective?', 'This therapeutic perspective integrates the impact of cultural and social norms, starting at the beginning of treatment.']

['How does it work?', 'Therapists who use this perspective work with clients to obtain and integrate information about their cultural patterns into a unique treatment approach based on their particular situation (Stewart, Simmons, & Habibpour, 2012).']
['What can sociocultural therapy include?', 'Sociocultural therapy can include individual, group, family, and couples treatment modalities.']

['What are the key findings of the article?', 'Statistically, ethnic minorities tend to utilize mental health services less frequently than White, middle-class Americans (Alegría et al., 2008; Richman, Kohn-Wood, & Williams, 2007).']
['What are the reasons they do not use the services?', 'Perhaps the reason has to do with access and availability of mental health services.']

['What are some barriers to services?', 'Ethnic minorities and individuals of low socioeconomic status (SES) report that barriers to services include lack of insurance, transportation, and time (Thomas & Snowden, 2002).']

['Are they more likely to use the services?', 'However, researchers have found that even when income levels and insurance variables are taken into account, ethnic minorities are far less likely to seek out and utilize mental health services.']

["Is this the only reason why they don't use the services?", 'And when access to mental health services is comparable across ethnic and racial groups, differences in service utilization remain (Richman et al., 2007).']

['How did this study contribute to the overall discussion?', 'In a study involving thousands of women, it was found that the prevalence rate of anorexia was similar across different races, but that bulimia nervosa was more prevalent among Hispanic and African American women when compared with non-Hispanic']
['What other races were included in the study?', 'White people (Marques et al., 2011).']

['What happened to the Hispanic women compared to the other races?', 'Although they have similar or higher rates of eating disorders, Hispanic and African American women with these disorders tend to seek and engage in treatment far less than White women.']

['What can you tell me about the race?', 'These findings suggest ethnic disparities in access to care, as well as clinical and referral practices that may prevent Hispanic and African American women from receiving care, which could include lack of bilingual treatment, stigma, fear of not being understood, family privacy, and lack of education about eating disorders.']
['What causes the imbalance between atypical and typical depressive symptoms?', 'Perceptions and attitudes toward mental health services may also contribute to this imbalance.']

['Why do people not seek treatment?', 'A recent study at King’s College, London, found many complex reasons why people do not seek treatment: self-sufficiency and not seeing the need for help, not seeing therapy as effective, concerns about confidentiality, and the many effects of stigma and shame (Clement et al., 2014).']

['Why do they fear psychiatric hospitalization?', 'And in another study, African Americans exhibiting depression were less willing to seek treatment due to fear of possible psychiatric hospitalization as well as fear of the treatment itself (Sussman, Robins, & Earls, 1987).']

['What do many African Americans prefer instead of mental health treatment?', 'Instead of mental health treatment, many African Americans prefer to be self-reliant or use spiritual practices (Snowden, 2001; Belgrave & Allison, 2010).']

['What is another interesting fact about the article?', 'For example, it has been found that the Black church plays a significant role as an alternative to mental health services by providing prevention and treatment-type programs designed to enhance the psychological and physical well-being of its members (Blank, Mahmood, Fox, & Guterbock, 2002).']

['How is stigma related to the study material?', 'Additionally, people belonging to ethnic groups that already report concerns about prejudice and discrimination are less likely to seek services for a mental illness because they view it as an additional stigma (Gary, 2005; Townes, Cunningham, & Chavez-Korell, 2009; Scott, McCoy, Munson, Snowden, & McMillen, 2011).']
['Why do they view it as additional stigma?', 'For example, in one recent study of 462 older Korean Americans (over the age of 60) many participants reported suffering from depressive symptoms.']

['What are the symptoms of depression?', 'However, 71% indicated they thought depression was a sign of personal weakness, and 14% reported that having a mentally ill family member would bring shame to the family (Jang, Chiriboga, & Okazaki, 2009).']
['What is a barrier to treatment?', 'Language differences are a further barrier to treatment.']

['Are there any other reasons?', 'In the previous study on Korean Americans’ attitudes toward mental health services, it was found that there were no Korean-speaking mental health professionals where the study was conducted (Orlando and Tampa, Florida) (Jang et al., 2009).']

['What can we do to overcome this issue?', 'Because of the growing number of people from ethnically diverse backgrounds, there is a need for therapists and psychologists to develop knowledge and skills to become culturally competent (Ahmed, Wilson, Henriksen, & Jones, 2011).']
['Are there any other ways to overcome this issue?', 'Those providing therapy must approach the process from the context of the unique culture of each client (Sue & Sue, 2007).']
